title: American Solo Sailor May Change a Culture
description: At 3 a.m. Wednesday, Ryan Breymaier had been prone on a two-inch foam pad for barely 30 minutes when the call came for him to get up. He was delivering the 60-foot racing sailboat Hugo Boss from Newport, R.I., to Manhattan as training for the Imoca Ocean Masters New York to Barcelona race, in which he and Pepe Ribes of Spain will sail across the Atlantic against four other teams starting Sunday.

title: Identity Intelligence: Image Is Everything
description: An excerpt of a document obtained by Edward J. Snowden, a former contractor with the National Security Agency, referring to the agencys use of images in intelligence gathering.

title: Lesson for P.O.W.s Father: Men Sometimes Do Come Back
description: WASHINGTON  For five years Robert Bergdahl waged a fathers war for the return of his soldier son.

title: Police Search for Upset Teenager Who Sank Into the Hudson
description: A distraught student left her elite high school in Harlem between classes on Thursday, classmates and witnesses said, and went to Fort Washington Park, along the Hudson River. She laid her phone and wallet on a rock on the bank of the river. She walked into the water and sank beneath the surface.

title: Players Seek Approval of $40 Million Deal in Video Games Case
description: College athletes, prohibited under N.C.A.A. rules from being paid, are moving closer to being compensated for the use of their likenesses in video games.

title: After 5 Months of Sales, Colorado Sees the Downside of a Legal High
description: DENVER  Five months after Colorado became the first state to allow recreational marijuana sales, the battle over legalization is still raging.

title: Environmental Groups Focus on Change by Strengthening Their Political Operations
description: ST. LOUIS  When the police arrested seven students at Washington University in St. Louis recently after a crowd of protesters sought to crash a board of trustees meeting, leaders of the environmental movement were thrilled.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 31, 2014
N.S.A. Collecting Millions of Faces From Web Images
description: The National Security Agency is harvesting huge numbers of images of people from communications that it intercepts through its global surveillance operations for use in sophisticated facial recognition programs, according to top-secret documents.

title: Another Slog for Mets, but This Time, Its Worth It
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Mets were asking much of Jacob deGrom without much to offer him in return. Their bullpen was depleted and their spirit broken after a loss in 14 innings the night before, and now they were asking him to pitch deep into their game against the Philadelphia Phillies, to be effective and efficient and essentially carry the team.

title: A Soldier Is Missing. What Comes Next?
description: When the United States Army in eastern Afghanistan discovered that one of its soldiers, Pfc. Bowe Bergdahl, was missing in action, it began a frantic search. As detailed in the classified military logs given to WikiLeaks by Pfc. Bradley Manning, now Chelsea Manning, the initial hunt for the captured sergeant included surveillance drones, armed checkpoints and infantry raids on suspected militant strongholds. Intercepts of Taliban communications included in the military records reveal that the militants immediately thought to use the capture for propaganda purposes, and derided American forces for looking in all the wrong places. Andrew W. Lehren

title: Orphan Black Recap: Verbal Knife Fights End in the Cut of Truth
description: Spoiler warning for any readers who arent certified members of Clone Club.

title: An Entertaining Match, Not Only for the Volleys
description: PARIS  We play tennis crazy because were both a little crazy, Fabio Fognini said before his third-round match Saturday at the French Open against Gal Monfils.

title: Texas Beer Finds Home in the Heart of New York
description: Until last year, one of the few ways Texans living in New York could get a bottle of Shiner Bock, the popular craft beer from an 105-year-old brewery in Shiner, Tex., was to carry the beer back in their luggage. Or find a New York bar that had smuggled the beer into the city.

title: With More Inmates on Dialysis, Officials Deal With Rising Costs
description: Less than 1 percent of the Texas prison population needs dialysis, a treatment that removes waste and water from the bloodstream.

title: When a Favor Goes Beyond a Courtesy
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Two Works Recount Texas A&Ms Flight to Another League
description: The Texas A&M University football teams win over top-ranked Alabama in 2012 will never be forgotten by the Aggie faithful, but the game is not the only memory that a Texas A&M University System regent carries from that day.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 1, 2014
description: For crying out loud, secure your weed. If you can legally possess it, thats fine. But it has no place in an elementary school.

Cuomo secured the endorsement of the Working Families Party on Saturday night, easing the popular Democrats path as he runs for re-election and solidifying his broader political prospects.

description: OKLAHOMA CITY  The ball bounced on the rim once, then kissed off the backboard, trickled off the rim again and fell through the net. When it did, Tim Duncan, who had released it, allowed himself a look to the heavens.

title: Corrections: June 1, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Philadelphia Inquirer Co-Owner Among 7 Killed in Massachusetts Plane Crash
description: BOSTON  At the last minute on Saturday, Lewis Katz, a philanthropist and co-owner of The Philadelphia Inquirer, invited Anne Leeds, a longtime friend and neighbor from Longport, N.J., to accompany him and two others on a quick day trip to Concord, Mass. They were going up to help support a nonprofit education effort.

description: Try unscrambling the paragraphs from an article about the New York City school chancellor, then invite students to create their own scrambles.

description: CHICAGO  Many men with prostate cancer put off using chemotherapy as long as possible, fearing its side effects.

title: Tracking Obamas Climate Rules for Power Plants
description: Im in Beijing to participate in a week of meetings related to the unfolding international science effort called Future Earth, so I wont be able to weigh in in a timely fashion on President Obamas planned Monday release of regulations restricting carbon dioxide emissions from existing American power plants.

title: In Our Pages: June 2
description: 1914: French Cabinet Agrees to Hand in Resignation

title: Long After a Divorce, the Question of Family Photographs Lingers
description: My parents split suddenly when I was 18, mere weeks before I went to college. Now that Im 40, the last stinging tentacles of their divorce have largely dissolved, though some still linger. They tug and burn when I least expect it.

title: Hagel Celebrates U.S. Soldiers Release With a Surprise Afghan Visit
description: BAGRAM AIR BASE, Afghanistan  Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl had departed for Landstuhl Medical Center in Germany eight hours before, but that did not stop Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel from taking a figurative victory lap around this base to celebrate the release of the lone remaining American prisoner of war in the Afghan conflict.

title: Worlds Best Dad
description: TIMES INSIDER  Welcome to the June 2014 Times Premier Puzzle Pack. This time around were celebrating Fathers Day. If youve ever been important in the life of a child or youre just remembering your own father, this pack is for you.

title: Suspect Held in Jewish Museum Killings
description: PARIS  The French authorities announced Sunday that they had arrested a man in the killing of three people last month at the Jewish Museum in Brussels, identifying the suspect as a 29-year-old Frenchman with a long criminal history who had traveled to Syria last year to join with radical Islamist fighters there.

title: Intruders for the Plugged-In Home, Coming In Through the Internet
description: Home, connected home. The front door opens with a tap on an iPhone. The lights come up as if by magic. The oven sends a text: Dinner is ready.

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 10 P.M. (AMC) HALT AND CATCH FIRE Set in Texas during the 1980s tech boom, this new series stars Lee Pace (Lincoln, Pushing Daisies) as Joe McMillan, a former IBM salesman who enlists the help of a has-been computer engineer (Scoot McNairy, above left, with Mackenzie Davis and Mr. Pace) and a talented computer science student (Ms. Davis) to reverse-engineer an IBM PC. The story is fiction, but based on the actual technology race of that decade, in which companies were trying to create their own version of a PC. With AMCs Mad Men, focusing on the ad executive Don Draper, ending next year, the network seems to be looking for another period drama that can seduce viewers with old-fashioned customs and atavistic sins, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. Joe, like Don, is handsome, suave and moodily enigmatic, a salesman who pitches his product with passionate intensity. Unfortunately, Halt and Catch Fire doesnt seem to carry the same panache. The period music is fun, but there is nothing particularly glamorous about high-tech Dallas. Most of all, the early 1980s are not a distant enough memory to cast a retro glow.

title: Federers Exit Is No Shock, Especially to His Opponent
description: PARIS  Roger Federer and Ernests Gulbis are both running out of time.

title: Small Businesses Trying to Stay Afloat in Chelseas Rising Tide of Wealth
description: For more than a decade, Alan Kraus and Mohinder Singh have worked on the same stretch of Ninth Avenue, watching and worrying as the currents of change have engulfed their corner of Chelsea.

title: Google Glass Enters the Operating Room
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Before scrubbing in on a recent Tuesday morning, Dr. Selene Parekh, an orthopedic surgeon here at Duke Medical Center, slipped on a pair of sleek, black glasses  Google Glass, the wearable computer with a built-in camera and monitor.

title: Mexico Authorizes Arrests in Fraud at Citigroup Unit
description: Updated, 7:56 p.m. | The authorities in Mexico have issued arrest warrants for former executives of Citigroups Mexican subsidiary, Banamex, in an investigation of a $400 million fraud.

title: Bouchard Helps Ensure a Big Day for Canada
description: PARIS  Eugenie Bouchard is in a hurry.

title: Three Kidnapped Missionaries Are Freed in Cameroon
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Two Italian priests and a Canadian nun, kidnapped nearly two months ago near Cameroons border with Nigeria in a region rife with Boko Haram militants, have been freed, Cameroons communications minister said on Sunday.

title: President of Georgian Abkhazia Resigns Under Pressure
description: MOSCOW  The president of Abkhazia, a breakaway region of Georgia heavily supported by Russia, resigned on Sunday after less than a week of unrest during which demonstrators stormed the presidential administration building and the Kremlin sent high-level emissaries from Moscow in a bid to calm the situation.

title: Lewis Katz, Victor in Fight to Own Philadelphia Inquirer, Dies at 72
description: Lewis Katz, a co-owner of The Philadelphia Inquirer who had only recently emerged triumphant in a battle for control of the newspaper, died in a plane crash on Saturday night in Massachusetts. He was 72.

title: Maleficent Casts Spell, Burying Ways to Die
description: LOS ANGELES  Angelina Jolie and Walt Disneys live-action label turned out surprisingly large crowds for Maleficent over the weekend, as Seth MacFarlane discovered there is no surer way to die in the West than making a vanity film.

title: Tony Awards Predictions: Leading Actress in a Musical
description: Do you think Kelli OHara will score a big upset next Sunday and win the Tony Award for best actress in a musical for Broadways Bridges of Madison County? Or will front-runner Jessie Mueller and Beautiful: The Carole King Musical emerge dominant, with the show winning the Tony for best musical over A Gentlemans Guide to Love & Murder? As we survey the 800 Tony voters this week for our annual predictions story, were adding new voices to the mix: Yours.

title: Administration Defends Swap With Taliban to Free U.S. Soldier
description: WASHINGTON  Top Obama administration officials pushed back on Sunday against Republican criticism that a deal freeing the last American held prisoner in Afghanistan could allow dangerous Taliban leaders to return to the fight, might encourage terrorist groups to seize American hostages and possibly violated a law requiring notification of Congress.

title: Love-Struck Hero in a Quandary: The Other Womans a Real Doll
description: The music for the ballet Copplia abounds in vitality, color, melody, folk energy, innocence, narrative charm and youthful freshness in each of its three acts. You seem to breathe more deeply when listening to it; your head clears. The composer is Lo Delibes; his 1870 score has several features that have never been surpassed in the ballet repertory. In the overture (and again in Act II), a sweet, high, ravishing violin melody suddenly takes the air after a soft horn introduction, like the answer to a prayer or light after darkness. What mazurka and what czardas are more irresistible than those here? In the Act I variations on a Slavic theme, the fast-cascading joy of one rapid string phrase squeezes the heart.

title: Six Climbers Are Missing on Mount Rainier
description: VANCOUVER, Wash.  Six climbers were missing and presumed dead on Sunday in an avalanche or fall on Mount Rainier in Washington State, in what could be the worst accident on the mountain in decades.

title: At WWDC, Apple Is Set to Make Push Into Monitoring Health and Home
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple is unlikely to introduce new devices this week, the things that most excite customers and investors these days. But the company is expected to dive deeper into two new areas: connected health and the so-called smart home.

title: Prospecting for Riches in Broadway Bombs
description: Hi! Im so-and-so. And Im a recovering flopaholic!

title: A Lawman With a Lot to Deal With, Including Himself
description: Every time a new tortured-cop show turns critics all gushy and trend-chasing television watchers all buzzy, a guy in Wyoming just shrugs and emits a noncommittal grunt. Hes Sheriff Walt Longmire, and if hes upset that shows like The Following and True Detective get more attention than his does, hes not letting on.

title: Obama to Take Action to Slash Coal Pollution
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Monday will announce one of the strongest actions ever taken by the United States government to fight climate change, a proposed Environmental Protection Agency regulation to cut carbon pollution from the nations power plants 30 percent from 2005 levels by 2030, according to people briefed on the plan who spoke anonymously because they had been asked not to reveal details.

title: Mentally, G.I. Has Long Path Back to Idaho
description: WASHINGTON  For Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the road home to Idaho began with a brief helicopter ride from the rugged frontier of eastern Afghanistan to Bagram Air Base, north of Kabul. His return to anything close to a normal life will take much longer.

title: The Bergdahls News Conference
description: Jani and Robert Bergdahl, the parents of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, addressed supporters on Sunday.

title: Another Ending for Arsenio Hall
description: The February announcement that Arsenio Halls syndicated late-night show would return for a second season turned out to be both premature and mistaken. CBS Television Distribution, which owns the show with Tribune Media, has announced a cancellation because of a ratings decline among the viewers most advertisers pay for in late night, people between the ages of 18 and 49. (The ratings leader in that group is Jimmy Fallon on NBC.) Mr. Hall, left, who had a hit syndicated late-night show in the early 1990s, revived the franchise with some fanfare in September, and he scored some early impressive ratings. But the late-night scene had become intensely crowded, with as many as 10 shows fighting for a shrinking number of viewers. The ratings drop set in motion a pattern of downgrades from a host of local television stations, which began relegating Mr. Halls show to little-watched hours of the night. In February, his old friend Jay Leno appeared on the show with a letter confirming a second year. The ratings slide forced CBSs syndication division to rescind that decision.

title: Yankees Robertson Fails, Making Twins Hughes a Winner
description: Even though Phil Hughes was once an 18-game winner for the Yankees, had been an All-Star and had helped them win a World Series as an important relief pitcher, things could hardly have ended worse for him in the Bronx. A 4-14 record last season, including a 1-10 mark at home, made him the target of loud booing by fans who were only too happy to see him leave.

title: Relevant? Nurturing? Well, Sos Your Old Man
description: When our young daughters first decided to play on top of our Honda minivan, parked in our driveway, my wife was worried. But to me, it seemed no less safe than chasing a ball that frequently ended up in the street. And they loved the height, the novelty, the danger. So I let them stay. They never fell. And with the summer weather here, playing on the car is once again keeping them occupied for hours.

title: Mermaids Flashlights, and Other Illuminations
description: The graceful sight of a lighthouse  preferably on a cliff with ocean waves crashing onto the rocks below  is more than a postcard symbol of summer. Its a reminder of what happens when nature turns violent. In Light House, performed at the Invisible Dog Art Center on Friday, the choreographer Anne Zuerner drew on movements from the natural world, both calm and forceful.

title: Skirball Announces  Its 2014-15 Season
description: Classic Shakespeare, Canadian acrobats and a GPS-led trek are among events planned for the 2014-15 season at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts at New York University. Highlights include King Lear, from Sept. 29 to Oct. 12, presented by Shakespeares Globe, the company behind Broadways recent productions of Twelfth Night and Richard III; Quebecs high-flying troupe Cirque Alfonse (Oct. 13 to 19); and the Joshua Light Show Festival, a psychedelic mix of music, light, dance and projections (Oct. 23 to 25). Next spring, a three-week run of Remote New York is to guide participants through the city with GPS instructions delivered via headphones. More information: nyuskirball.org.

title: For Ensembles and Singers, a Night of Backbreaking Labor
description: The NY Phil Biennial presented a diptych of New York premieres dedicated to manual labor on Friday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. Julia Wolfes Anthracite Fields (2014) commemorates the Pennsylvania coal miners whose work fueled the industrial revolution. Steven Mackeys Dreamhouse (2003) examines the process of building a house. Both works feature singers and an ensemble mixing acoustic and amplified instruments; both express unease with the American culture of comfort and consumption.

title: A Composers Sensual Side
description: During the composer and conductor Pierre Boulezs tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic in the 1970s, he challenged the repertorial status quo and reached out to new audiences with events like the Rug Concerts, where patrons lounged on cushions while listening to contemporary music.

title: Hachette Chief Leads Book Publishers in Amazon Fight
description: As a young book editor at Little, Brown & Company in 1992, Michael Pietsch paid $80,000  $45,000 more than the next-highest bidder  for a postmodern novel by a little-known writer named David Foster Wallace.

title: Showcasing Music Till the Sun Comes Up
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Caetano Veloso, the bossa nova elder statesman, was holding court here on Saturday evening, floating his baritone voice and easy guitar over an amphitheater audience that swayed and sang along as he offered a slightly raunchy paean to his native Brazilian sounds.

title: Returning to Ice, Rangers Have Spring in Their Strides
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  After the Rangers first practice since their triumph over the Montreal Canadiens in the Eastern Conference finals, their coach spoke to the news media Sunday under a makeshift tent in front of their training complex. With the warm sunshine outside and a breezy spirit inside, the scene had the feel of a September training camp. The Rangers, though, have games ahead in June as they make their first Stanley Cup finals appearance in 20 years.

title: Library Reveals Details and Costs of Upgrade Plan
description: The New York Public Librarys revised renovation plan  to upgrade the Mid-Manhattan Library and create more public space in its flagship Fifth Avenue building  is expected to cost about $300 million, according to library officials who outlined new details of the project in interviews.

title: A Post-Punk Band in Early Metamorphosis, Luxuriating in Unease
description: There is great meaning in the post-punk reaction, as there is always great meaning in the reaction of any child toward unstable parents. That reaction wasnt confined to one period of time. It didnt stop in, say, 1981. Punk, behind sound, is declarative and self-annihilating at the same time. It wants to assert itself and to disappear, and has done so, in regular overlapping cycles, all over the place, for all kinds of reasons.

title: No-Trump Outscores the Major at Eastern States Regional
description: At the Eastern States Regional in Manhattan last month, the winners of the main pair event on the second day, May 22, were Augie Boehm and Donald Simmons of New York City. They finished 0.75 match points ahead of Deborah Murphy of San Francisco and Gary Donner of Bluffton, S.C. Third were R. Jay Becker of New York City and Ron Smith of Las Vegas.

title: Duda Homer Leaves Mets Delighted, if Exhausted
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Mets and the Philadelphia Phillies were already familiar with each other, as division rivals, but on Sunday, as they entered extra innings for the third time in three days, they seemed to understand each other on a deeper, more intimate level.

title: Kind of Test
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  We havent had an Andrea Carla Michaels Monday puzzle since March, but shes back with a phonetic hint theme that unfurled itself slowly for me.

title: The Rise and Fall of the Goddess of Democracy
description: A 33-foot-high statue became a mute yet powerful actor in the final drama on Tiananmen Square in 1989, reinvigorating the student protests and infuriating Communist Party leaders who crushed the demonstrations, and the statue, five days after its birth.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: A Digital Agency Draws a Pair of Aces in Brazil
description: AN acclaimed advertising creative team that has been celebrated for several successful campaigns is joining a digital agency on a fast growth curve to help it grow faster.

title: The Story of Gay America, via Personal Interviews
description: David Isay, the founder of the nonprofit oral history group StoryCorps, tried for many years with little success to raise money for a project to collect stories from the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and questioning community.

title: Down on Modis Farm
description: Indias new prime minister has a lot of new seed to plant.

title: Inside the Fixing: How a Gang Battered Soccers Frail Integrity
description: ROVANIEMI, Finland  A man arrived at the police station here in 2011 with an unusual tip. He told the police that a Singaporean man was fixing matches with the local professional soccer team. The police were incredulous.

title: Can the Market Stave Off Global Warming?
Sex Crimes That Shouldnt Be
description: As creatures who are both participants in public life, and individuals with private lives and concerns, we are constantly challenged to balance our own needs and rights against the public good. In many cases, that challenge comes down to weighing the societal benefits of transparency against the need for for personal privacy. The most familiar and heated debates of late, of course, involvehigh-tech government spying without consent from individuals  surveillance that in many cases extended to the unsuspecting persons bedrooms.

title: A River Runs Through Their Pictures and Lives
description: More than half a century since Inge Morath photographed the Danube, nine young female photographers will follow her footsteps and add to her legacy.

title: Americas Highways, Running on Empty
description: WASHINGTON  IF you think your commute is getting worse, its probably not your imagination. And no, its not because there are more cars on the road. The potholes, the stalled construction projects, the congestion  its because the highway trust fund is almost empty and, without a fix, could run out of money this summer.

title: Clinical Drug Trials
description: To the Editor:

title: A Vicious Cycle of Imprisonment
description: To the Editor:

title: That College Degree: More Valuable Than Ever
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
