description: THE HAGUE  The top American envoy to the United Nations, Samantha Power, recently made an impassioned case for the International Criminal Court, a tribunal based here that the United States had pilloried only a decade ago.

title: The Theater Beyond the Clintons
description: One of the many problems with our all-Hillary-all-the-time news fixation is the way it obscures other juicy Democratic dramas, shoving their stars into the wings.

title: Birds Leave Nest Involuntarily, and Oakland Fumes
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  It started as a well-intentioned attempt by the United States Postal Service here to rid its trucks of bird droppings: A tree trimmer was hired to prune the lush ficus trees that grow next to the post offices parking lot, not far from City Hall. But in the course of the job, five baby black-crowned night herons fell from their nests and were injured.

title: The Art of Focus
description: Like everyone else, I am losing the attention war. I toggle over to my emails when I should be working. I text when I should be paying attention to the people in front of me. I spend hours looking at mildly diverting stuff on YouTube. (Look, theres a bunch of guys who can play Billie Jean on beer bottles!)

title: Subway Expands Its Slate of Original Web Shows
description: The Subway restaurant chain is taking a foot-long approach to original online video programming, sponsoring a second web series and considering a renewal for its first entry into the growing field.

title: Guns and Mental Illness
description: It is difficult to read stories about Elliot Rodger, the 22-year-old man who went on a murderous spree in Isla Vista, Calif., last month, without feeling some empathy for his parents.

title: Health Experts See Benefits in Push to Cut Pollution
description: The Obama administration contends that its new plan to cut carbon pollution from power plants will not just fight climate change, but will also quickly improve public health, preventing up to 100,000 asthma attacks and 2,100 heart attacks in the first year the rules take effect.

title: Strategy and Objectives for Gaining Soldiers Release Shifted Over Time
description: WASHINGTON  For two and a half years, the Obama administration maneuvered to make a deal to free Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl the start of a larger peace process for Afghanistan, one that would ease the American exit from the country.

title: Freedom for Sgt. Bergdahl, at a Price
description: It would be extremely coldhearted not to feel relief that Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl is back in American hands after being held captive by the Taliban for nearly five years. American soldiers need to know their government will not abandon them if they are taken prisoner, especially with the war in Afghanistan in its prolonged final stage.

title: Pilgrims Pride Raises Its Bid for Hillshire, Topping Tyson
description: Updated, 10:27 p.m. | Pilgrims Pride has raised its takeover bid for Hillshire Brands, people briefed on the matter said Monday, turning up the heat in a battle over the maker of Jimmy Dean sausages and Ball Park hot dogs.

title: Do Drug Companies Make Drugs, or Money?
description: I just want to emphasize that this is an industry where it is composed of really great people, working to do good things for patients, for doctors and actually for society, and when I look at our employees, there is sort of a noble purpose to working in the pharmaceutical industry.

title: Keeping Track: Confidential Sources, Wage War and College Athletes
description: Protecting Sources

title: Nearing a Climate Legacy
description: The greenhouse gas reductions required by the Obama administrations proposed rule on power plants will not get the world to where it has to go to avert the worst consequences of climate change. But they are likely to be enormously beneficial: good for the nations health, good for technological innovation, good for President Obamas credibility abroad, and, in time, good for the planet and future generations.

title: Investigators Find Recorders in Jet Crash Near Boston
description: BEDFORD, Mass.  Using a crane to lift its charred wreckage, investigators on Monday evening recovered the cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder from the executive jet that crashed here on Saturday night, killing all seven people aboard.

title: De Blasio Family Begins Move to Gracie Mansion
description: In: a rocking chair and a sewing table with sentimental value. Out: a bookshelf, a Christmas tree stand, votive candles and plastic storage bins.

title: Recorded Noise Might Offer Clues to Missing Plane
description: HONG KONG  Scientists plan to release detailed information on Wednesday about a mysterious noise, possibly that of an ocean impact, recorded by two undersea receivers in the Indian Ocean about the time that Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 ceased satellite transmissions and vanished on March 8.

title: Seattle Approves $15 Minimum Wage, Setting a New Standard for Big Cities
description: SEATTLE  The City Council here went where no big-city lawmakers have gone before on Monday, raising the local minimum wage to $15 an hour, more than double the federal minimum, and pushing Seattle to the forefront of urban efforts to address income inequality.

title: One Announcers Quest for a Triple Crown
description: A look back at the Belmont Park announcer Tom Durkins seven missed chances of calling a Triple Crown winner before his retirement this summer.

title: The Crossroads at Cold Harbor
description: By late spring 1864, Lt. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant was relentlessly pursuing his advance on the Confederate capital at Richmond, Va. With his recent appointment as commander of the Union armies, Grant had brought a new approach to the war  one of absolute and brutal attrition. Knowing that he could replace as many men as he lost, even as the rebel army suffered from a desperate shortage of manpower, he had bulldozed his way across Virginia in what was named the Overland Campaign, throwing tens of thousands of men against the Confederate wall.

title: One Last Shot for the Voice of Racing
description: His hypnotist was back on call, but Tom Durkin was in a state of anything but deep sleep. He was riffling through the more than 2,000 words in his notebook on Monday, trying to match words with images, poring over videotape of dozens of horse races and anticipating every imaginable outcome for the 146th running of the Belmont Stakes.

title: Anger Among Indians After Killings of 2 Girls
description: KATRA SAADATGANJ, India  Sohan Lal reached the police outpost at 11 oclock on the night his daughter disappeared, he said, already desperate for help. He bent down before the officer in charge and clutched his feet, telling him to hurry, hurry.

title: Belmont Park Braces for a Triple Crown Crowd
description: With more than 100,000 fans expected to watch California Chrome attempt to win the Triple Crown on Saturday, the Belmont Stakes will provide its annual economic jolt to Belmont Park, which often enough has a relative handful of fans rattling around the huge premises.

title: One Party, Two Factions: Souths Republicans Look a Lot Like Its 1970s Democrats
description: JACKSON, Miss.  When Senator Thad Cochran initially won his seat in 1978, he became the first Republican elected to the Senate from Mississippi since Reconstruction, a signal moment in what was then an overwhelmingly Democratic state.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 2, 2014
description: June 2, 2014

title: June 3 Primaries | The Upshot Countdown
description: The Upshots Nate Cohn explains the two most important June 3 primaries in 30 seconds.

title: Amid Crown Chase, a Battle for Racings Soul
description: In May 1995, when New York became the last major horse racing center in the United States to legalize the race-day use of Lasix, a diuretic that reduces bleeding in horses respiratory systems, the decision was celebrated throughout the thoroughbred industry as a great step forward.

title: What Thanksgiving Turkey May Come With
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Crossword puzzles, as a rule, are fairly plain to look at. Black and white, square (mostly)  there really isnt a lot of oomph to them from a visual perspective.

title: French Officials Twist U.S. Arms in Bank Inquiry
description: Facing the prospect of a guilty plea in the United States, the giant French bank BNP Paribas has enlisted the support of a powerful ally: its own government, including top regulators and even the French president.

title: Hoboken Mayor Gets U.S. Flood Money in Awkward Ceremony With Christie
description: Mayor Dawn Zimmer of Hoboken had 230 million reasons to celebrate on Monday, but she did not receive a congratulatory hug from Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey. Or a pat on the back. Or even a perfunctory handshake.

title: After a Pledge of Allegiance, Some Doubters
description: For a brief moment, the progressive heavens opened on Saturday night. Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo proclaimed himself a could-be (stranger things have happened) progressive Democrat.

title: Dealing With the Enemy
Kings Are Tough, but Rangers Are Rested
description: Do not operate while fatigued, the warning labels often say. But that is exactly what the Los Angeles Kings may have to do when the Stanley Cup finals open at Staples Center on Wednesday.

title: A Long Island Institution Is Cooling Its Ovens
description: BAY SHORE, N.Y.  The white box with the blue script and cellophane window was an indelible part of growing up on Long Island.

title: Suspended Again, Hill Is Cut by Giants
description: Will Hill, an athletically gifted safety for the Giants who has failed three drug tests in three seasons, was released by the team Monday. Hill had been expected to add depth at safety, especially since starting free safety Stevie Brown is recovering from reconstructive knee surgery.

title: Officer Is Killed in a Motorcycle Crash
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was fatally injured Monday afternoon after the motorcycle he was riding collided with a car on Linden Boulevard in Queens, a police spokesman said.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,309 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: A National Title, if Not a Court, of Its Own
description: After a long day of classes at Beacon School on Manhattans Upper West Side, Felipe Osses-Knig hops on his bicycle carrying a body-size bag containing books, a change of clothes and a tennis racket. He rides the nearly six miles from West 61st Street across the city to Randalls Island to play tennis until 8 p.m.

title: Seeking to Expand an Uptown Site, N.Y.U. Finds Itself in an Alley Fight
description: I am shocked and appalled at N.Y.U., Aldo Bozzi shouted during a community board meeting two weeks ago. And this is just beginning. New York is going to decay if this is going to be permitted.

title: Citing Pressure and Threats, Egypts Answer to Jon Stewart Calls It Quits
description: CAIRO  Mohamed Morsi did not enjoy being ridiculed on television as president. With the election of Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the laughter has stopped.

title: Cano Is Quiet in Mariners Rout of Yankees, but Fans in Bronx Arent
description: A rainout at the end of April allowed Robinson Cano a temporary reprieve from the jeers he had heard upon his previous return to Yankee Stadium. By the time Cano came back to the Bronx with the Seattle Mariners to make up the postponed game, he would have been more integrated onto his new team, and perhaps Yankee fans would have softened their stance on a player who had been a critical part of the teams success in the last decade.

title: Mets Overcome Leadoff Concerns to Win in Nine
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Mets had a handful of flaws at the start of the season. For one, they lacked a leadoff hitter. Eric Young Jr. had not established himself as an everyday player. And Juan Lagares was not exactly a true leadoff hitter.

title: Fearing Converts to Terrorism, France Intercepts Citizens Bound for Syria
description: PARIS  The three young Frenchmen were arrested as they tried to make their way to Syria to wage jihad. They had not harmed anyone in France or made plans to do so, according to the evidence at their trial in January, but in France these days, seeking to fight in Syria is enough to bring a charge of plotting terrorism  and in this case sentences of three to five years in prison.

title: The Supreme Court Blunder That Liberals Tend to Make
description: WASHINGTON  In the waning months of his presidency, Lyndon Johnson took a tremendous risk. He nominated Supreme Court Justice Abe Fortas, who had once been Johnsons personal lawyer and remained a confidant, to become chief justice.

title: How Much Hospitals Charged Medicare for the Same Types of Cases
description: Data released by the federal government shows that hospitals across the country charge Medicare differing amounts for the same procedure.

title: Bowe Bergdahls Vanishing Before Capture Angered His Unit
description: WASHINGTON  Sometime after midnight on June 30, 2009, Pfc. Bowe Bergdahl left behind a note in his tent saying he had become disillusioned with the Army, did not support the American mission in Afghanistan and was leaving to start a new life. He slipped off the remote military outpost in Paktika Province on the border with Pakistan and took with him a soft backpack, water, knives, a notebook and writing materials, but left behind his body armor and weapons  startling, given the hostile environment around his outpost.

title: The Playlist | The Best of Queen Bey
description: Jody Rosen, Ts critic at large, wrote about Beyonc Knowles for the cover of Ts culture issue, which hits newsstands June 15. The way she sings, her approach to rhythm and harmony, her dancing  its all very strange and sui generis, he says of the singer. Shes an avant-gardist masquerading as the worlds biggest pop diva. Here, Rosen tracks the most essential tunes from the woman on top of the world.

title: Personal Statement
description: The humble T-shirt becomes a stylish message board thanks to flashy type and aggressive graphics.

title: Beyonc: The Woman on Top of the World
description: A few years ago, Beyonc Knowles was like any other record-breaking pop star in an already crowded field. Then something changed.

title: Everything Must Go
description: The poet Tom Healy and his pal, the sculptor Tom Sachs, orbit a world of consumption so conspicuous it can be seen from outer space.

title: Edward Finkelstein, 89, Dies; Took Macys to Its Highs and Lows
description: Edward S. Finkelstein, a master merchandiser who turned Macys into one of the nations smartest, fastest-growing department store chains, only to see it wind up in bankruptcy court, died on Saturday at his home in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 89.

title: Word of the Day | pliable
description: pliable \pli--bl\ adjective

title: Rangers and Kings Share a Cast of High-Pressure Achievers
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Game 7 of the Stanley Cup finals is set for June 18 in Los Angeles. If it gets that far, if the Rangers and the Kings battle to one last game, there will be a Cup at stake and a lot of streaks on the line. Something will have to give.

title: Amid Sense of Incompletion, Petkovic Trudges Ahead in Paris
description: PARIS  Andrea Petkovic prepared for her French Open fourth-round match against Kiki Bertens by spending some time on one of her favorite websites: YouTube.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 3, 2014
description: Who would think that you would send a child upstairs and they never came back?

title: Corrections: June 3, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Whats on Tuesday
description: 8 P.M. (CW) FAMOUS IN 12 An ordinary family, above, moves to Los Angeles to seek fame while being filmed around the clock for 12 weeks in activities guided by Harvey Levin and his TMZ crew. Family members will wage individual fame campaigns on social media while each week a star power meter will analyze the information to determine who has a shot at a Kardashian-like existence  and who should return to anonymity.

title: Marilyn Beck, Hollywood Columnist Without the Gush, Dies at 85
description: Marilyn Beck, a widely read newspaper columnist and broadcast figure who helped introduce a style of impartial journalism to the celebrity gossip beat, died on Saturday at her home in Oceanside, Calif. She was 85.

title: A Chic Idea for Chinas Green-Minded Set
description: A Hong Kong-based environmental movement to clean up the textile and apparel industry, one of the worlds largest polluters, is recruiting young talent to make the concept of eco fashion more attractive to the urban middle class in China.

title: Ukraine Pushes Back as Rebels Attack in the East
description: LUHANSK, Ukraine  Ukraines minister of internal affairs said Tuesday that the central governments security forces had begun a new phase of the campaign against separatist fighters in the city of Slovyansk, destroying rebel checkpoints and equipment and engaging in firefights.

title: Test Yourself | History, June 3
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | Unveiling New Carbon Plan, E.P.A. Focuses on Flexibility
description: In Unveiling New Carbon Plan, E.P.A. Focuses on Flexibility, Coral Davenport writes about the Obama administrations proposal to cut greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Assads Win Is Assured, but Limits Are Exposed
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  As Syrians went to the polls on Tuesday in an election virtually certain to give President Bashar al-Assad a new term, buses ferried government workers from their offices to cast ballots. Security checkpoints blocked some people from leaving neighborhoods if they did not have inked fingers proving they had taken part. And a few citizens pronounced themselves so enthusiastic that they had voted several times.

title: How to Succeed in Washington Without Really Trying
description: We seem to be in the midst of several national conversations. Every day, in fact, on MSNBC or Fox News or NPR or Sarah Palins Facebook page or my brother in-laws Twitter feed, new national conversations are being set aloft over something or other of great importance  cyberbullying, digital diets, slut-shaming, Benghazi and all that. But the only way to have your national conversation rise above the others is to have a face of that conversation  your very own Pussy Riot, Edward Snowden, Sandra Fluke, New York City carriage horses or Duck Dynasty guys. Or that cattle rancher from Nevada, whats his name?

title: Do You Like School?
description: A recent Op-Ed essay topping The Timess most-emailed list argues that the majority of employees in America do not feel engaged at work. They feel underappreciated by their supervisors, overwhelmed by how much they have to do, and dont feel that what they are doing even matters. Is school any different?

title: Exploring the Photographic Spirit
description: An amazing little camera caught Elizabeth Morans attention at a family reunion. It was as tiny as a spy camera, cartoonishly so.

title: Living on Purpose
description: My late father had a longtime friend, a retired kosher butcher, who lived down the hall in their South Jersey apartment building. Past 90, Manny was older and frailer than my father; he leaned on a cane and could barely see well enough to recognize faces. But every morning, and again in late afternoon, he walked through my dads unlocked front door to be sure he was all right and to kibitz a bit.

title: California Chromes Quest for the Triple Crown, and the Lives He Transformed
description: LOS ALAMITOS, Calif.  Art Sherman is not a complicated man. He is 77 and proud of a life that is longer on memories than it is on bankroll. Sixty years ago, he was a Brooklyn kid in California learning about horses from a crew of cowboys.

title: Euro Zone Edges Closer to Dreaded Deflation
description: PARIS  Consumer prices in the euro zone ticked ever closer to outright deflation, official data showed Tuesday, making it almost certain that the European Central Bank will move to ease monetary policy this week.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Andreessen Horowitz Increases Bet on Zenefits, a Human Resources Firm
description: Just months after investing in Zenefits, a human resources software company, Andreessen Horowitz has increased its investment.

title: New York Today: Summons Season
description: Happy pleasant Tuesday morning.

title: Elections in Syria
description: The ballot is expected to give Bashar al-Assad another term as president.

title: New King or, Spaniards Ask, Is It Time for No King?
description: MADRID  There is no doubt that King Juan Carlos played an essential role in ushering Spain toward democracy, and later remained a respected voice that could speak for his nation abroad while also providing a necessary balm at critical moments to heal old wounds and mediate disputes at home from above the political fray.

title: Obama, in Poland, Renews Commitment to Security
description: WARSAW  President Obama flew here Tuesday to unveil a $1 billion security plan intended to demonstrate the United States rock-solid commitment to stand with Central and Eastern Europe against Russian aggression, but it did not settle nerves rattled by the crisis in neighboring Ukraine.

title: Fewer Hong Kongers Support 1989 Tiananmen Protests, Survey Finds
description: Sympathy and support for the student-led protests in Tiananmen Square a quarter-century ago have ebbed somewhat in Hong Kong this year, although a clear majority still believes that the Chinese government was wrong in suppressing the protests, according to an annual survey released on Tuesday.

title: K.K.R. to Buy Internet Brands for $1.1 Billion
description: The private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has agreed to buy Internet Brands, which operates a portfolio of websites and software, in a bet that it can help the company expand its services.

title: 1975: Juan Carlos to be Sworn In As King of Spain
description: MADRID  With the death of Generalissimo Francisco Franco early this morning, Spain today calmly prepared for a new era under Prince Juan Carlos as its first king since 1931.

title: Tiananmen, Forgotten
description: BEIJING  I dont remember the first time I heard the term liu si  June 4  which is how the Tiananmen protests, the widespread demonstrations in 1989 that ended in bloodshed, are referred to in China. It was perhaps sometime around 2003, when I was 15 or 16. The term was probably uttered at the dinner table by one of my parents, both of whom were on the Avenue of Eternal Peace, the street in front of Tiananmen Square, on that night. They bore witness to the senseless killing, a memory that has haunted them ever since.

title: Mixed Reaction to the Bergdahl Deal
description: Prisoner swap or negotiations with terrorists? Questions arise after the freeing of five senior Taliban figures in exchange for the American soldier Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl.

title: A Start-Up That Helps Businesses Assess Customer Service
description: Start-Up: StellaService.

title: Q. and A.: Louisa Lim on the Pivot Point for Chinas Contemporary History
description: Louisa Lims new book, The Peoples Republic of Amnesia: Tiananmen Revisited, describes how government policy and fast economic growth have conspired to make most Chinese ignorant about the June 4, 1989, massacre in Beijing and crackdowns in scores of cities across China. But in an interview, Ms. Lim, a former Beijing correspondent for National Public Radio who recently completed a fellowship in the United States, argued that the massacre was crucial to understanding todays China. Excerpts follow:

title: Intersection | El Raval, Barcelona
description: In Barcelonas Raval neighborhood, locals draw inspiration from rock stars and the citys history.

title: In Debate Over Coal, Looking to Lessons of 90s Tobacco Fight
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agencys proposed regulation of power plant emissions signals the beginning of a fight over coal and climate change. Any chance of a resolution is likely to depend on the combatants agreeing to a reduction in emissions in exchange for help to coal-dependent regions and assistance to workers struggling with higher energy costs.

title: Morning Agenda: Frances Direct Appeal on Bank
description: With the prospect of a guilty plea in the United States looming, the French bank BNP Paribas has enlisted the support of a powerful ally: its own government, including top regulators and the French president, DealBooks Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write. President Franois Hollande recently reached out to the White House to raise concerns about a plea deal, injecting a political undercurrent into a law enforcement investigation.

title: Tony Awards Predictions: Best Musical
description: Will the emotional punch of Beautiful: The Carole King Musical send that show soaring to victory on Sunday in the race for the best musical Tony Award? Will cleverness carry the day with a win for A Gentlemans Guide to Love & Murder? Or will comic antics  as well as the lack of a clear favorite in this category  be enough for Aladdin to land Disneys first best musical Tony since The Lion King in 1998?

title: The Small Stuff, Again
description: Following my recent rant about misused hyphens, heres a quick look at another much-abused punctuation mark: the comma.

title: Daily Report: The Search for Computers That Can Spot Their Own Security Flaws
description: If only computers were smart enough to defend themselves against malevolent hackers. Such is the premise of an ambitious two-year contest with a $2 million first prize, posed to the worlds computer programmers by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, better known by the acronym Darpa. It is the blue-sky, big-think organization within the Defense Department that created a precursor of the Internet in the late 1960s and more recently held a contest that spurred development of self-driving cars, Kenneth Chang reports.

title: Art of Huang Yin Toys With Concept of a Lie
description: Drops of sweat run down the comically exaggerated faces of the little boys in the artist Huang Yins oil paintings. With slicked-back hair and red, doll-like cheeks, they smoke, clutching full glasses of wine, their faces creased in laughter.

title: Stephen Colbert on Thomas Piketty
description: What happens when you cross a parody of a blowhard right-wing talk-show host with an influential French economist who seeks a fight against global inequality? Now we know, after the Thomas Piketty World Tour continued Monday night with a stop at The Colbert Report.

title: Another Man Freed as Brooklyn District Attorneys Office Reviews Cases
description: On a rain-drenched night in the summer of 1997, Sherwin Gibbons was shot dead, murdered as he sipped a beer in the vestibule of a building in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

title: Obama Defends Swap of Taliban for American P.O.W.
description: WARSAW  President Obama defended on Tuesday the prisoner swap that freed an American soldier in Afghanistan and vowed to keep watch over the five Taliban figures released from the American prison camp in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, in exchange.

title: WWDC Dissected: A New Era for Apple, but an End for Some Apps
description: As it tends to do a few times a year, the technology industry paused on Monday for a day of product news and promises from Apple. Making iOS and the Macintosh operating systems work better? Check. A Snapchat competitor? Check. Better cloud computing capabilities? Check.

title: Stuck in an Underground Village
description: Dear Diary:

title: Declassified U.N. Cables Reveal Turning Point in Rwanda Crisis of 1994
description: WASHINGTON  On April 12, 1994, six days after a plane carrying Rwandas president was shot down, setting off a wave of killings, Madeleine K. Albright, the American ambassador to the United Nations at the time, sent a cable to the State Department proposing that the United States take the lead in pushing to withdraw most of the United Nations peacekeeping force operating there.

title: With Choice at Tiananmen, Student Took Road to Riches
description: BEIJING  A few days after the crackdown on the Tiananmen Square protests 25 years ago, the Chinese government filled the airwaves with a list of the 21 most wanted student leaders accused of stirring up an antigovernment rebellion. At the top of the list was a 20-year-old student at Peking University named Wang Dan, who set up an unofficial student union to mobilize his classmates to demand democracy.

title: How Hillshire Can End Its Deal for Pinnacle
description: Shareholders who had protested Hillshire Brands takeover of Pinnacle Foods will most likely be heartened by the packaged foods companys decision to talk to its two unsolicited suitors.

title: Pakistan Shaken by Faraway Arrest of Political Boss
description: LONDON  When British police officers mounted a dawn raid on a calm London suburb on Tuesday, with orders to arrest the powerful Pakistani political boss Altaf Hussain, the reverberations were felt most intensely 4,000 miles away in the port city of Karachi.

title: Here Are the CFDA Winners...
description: Joseph Altuzarra and Rihanna were among the winners from Monday nights fashion awards show.

title: CFDA Awards: The Verdict
description: The envelopes have been opened, Rihanna has made the requisite news (via a sheer crystal mesh dress and skull cap; O.M.G., O.M.G., etc.), and the 2014 CFDA awards have come to an end. What do you need to know about the evening?

title: Tea Party Challenge in Mississippi G.O.P. Primary Goes to the Wire
description: WASHINGTON  There was no clear winner early Wednesday in the most hard-fought Republican Senate primary race this year, with the six-term incumbent Thad Cochran of Mississippi and his Tea Party-backed challenger, State Senator Chris McDaniel, running neck and neck after a night of lead changes.

title: Whose Writing Career Do You Most Envy?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Zo Heller and Daniel Mendelsohn discuss writers whose careers they covet.

title: Converting a Run-Down Power Plant
description: A ruin on the banks of the Hudson River, the closed Glenwood power plant site has haunted the city of Yonkers for decades.

title: Facts & Figures: Female Hurricanes
description: Researchers from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign have found that powerful hurricanes with female names were deadlier than equally strong hurricanes with male names, apparently because people are less afraid of girls.

title: Whats News in Washington: Super-ish Tuesday
description: Good morning from a balmy Washington. It may be only June, but a miniature SuperTuesdayis upon us, with primary elections taking place in eight states today.

title: Sperm Donation is Full of Euphemisms, and an 11-Year-Old is Full of Questions
description: Since agreeing to become a sperm donor for my good friends, Tori and Kelly, Ive noticed an impressive variety of euphemisms are used when discussing the subject in polite company. My mother regularly calls to inquire how that thing is going with the girls, for example, and acquaintances will praise me for my decision to donate, as if Ive just dropped off some gently used housewares at my local Salvation Army.

title: Morning Views
description: President Obamas proposed emissions restrictions on power plants may be insufficient by themselves to forestall the severest impacts of climate change. But they are ultimately good for the nations health, good for technological innovation, good for President Obamas credibility abroad, and, in time, good for the health of the planet and future generations, says  The New York Times editorial board.

title: Marilyn Monroes World War II Drone Program
description: Working 10 hours a day for $20 a week in a World War II defense plant 70 years ago was 18-year-old Norma Jeane Dougherty, wife of a young United States merchant seaman assigned overseas. Her company, called Radioplane, in Burbank, Calif., founded by the British character actor Reginald Denny, made small remote-controlled pilotless aircraft, intended to help United States Army and Navy anti-aircraft gunners refine their targeting skills.

title: In Escape Rooms, Video Games Meet Real Life
description: Everything is interactive these days, thanks to video games and the Internet, even Neil Patrick Harriss forthcoming autobiography, which is being written in the style of a 1980s Choose Your Own Adventure book. One of the most interesting fusions of digital culture with an older form  in this case, theater  is the escape room, which locks people behind a closed door and asks them to find a way out.

title: Maya Angelou Memorial Service to Be Streamed Online
description: A memorial service will be held for Maya Angelou at the Wait Chapel of Wake Forest University, in Winston-Salem, N.C., on Saturday morning, the university announced. Ms. Angelou, who died on May 28, was the Reynolds Professor of American Studies at the university, a position to which she was appointed in 1982.

title: Obama Defends Bergdahl Prison Deal
description: The president defended the United States prisoners exchange that freed Army Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl from Taliban captivity after five years.

title: Year-End Roundup 2013-2014 | Social Studies, History, Geography and Civics
description: At the end of every school year, we look back and collect the years teaching materials for each subject area so teachers can find them all in one place.

title: With New Government, Analysts Expect Policy Shift for Selling Public Companies
description: MUMBAI  As the National Democratic Alliance government led by the newly elected Prime Minister Narendra Modi begins to fall into place, analysts expect his mantra ofmaximum governance, minimum government to translate to a strategic sale of stakes in ailing publicly owned companies.

title: Disapproval Is Swift for French Merger Plan
description: PARIS  France is a nation where regional identity is fierce, embodied in the sparkling wine of Champagne or choucroute, the sauerkraut revered in Alsace.

title: Rangers Like Richards, and May Buy Him Out
description: LOS ANGELES  Brad Richards has done exactly what the Rangers asked of him in July 2011 when they signed him to a nine-year, $60 million contract. He has provided playmaking and leadership, ushering the Rangers to their first Stanley Cup finals since 1994. It is unlikely they would have gotten this far without him.

title: So What?
description: This spring, those who enjoy arguing about language (and they are many) turned their attention to a perennial but still-unsolved question: Is it O.K. to start a sentence with the word so?

title: In Our Pages: June 4
description: 1939: Senate Keeps Gold Clause

title: Instagram Goes Beyond Its Gauzy Filters
description: On Instagram, as in Lake Wobegon, everyone is above average.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 9
description: Final rosters for the World Cup were due Monday and, while some teams made their hard decisions weeks ago, there were still a few surprises.

title: Sharapova and Bouchard Gain French Open Semifinals
description: PARIS  At about 2:30 Tuesday afternoon, Rafael Nadal was celebrating his 28th birthday in the players lounge at Roland Garros.

title: The Dubious Campaigns to Fight Overregulation
description: Most businesses cannot make plans without making predictions about what their regulators will do. Some have argued that this task has been complicated by the fact that old regulations are rarely repealed, even as new ones are added, making for overlapping requirements and outdated regulations.

title: The Left and Masculinity
description: My last post tried to pin down what I find troublesome about how conservatives sometimes engage with arguments about sex, violence, misogyny and masculinity whether the context is rape on college campuses or the Santa Barbara murders. As a complement, let me try to pin down why the lefts framing of these issues often leaves me even colder, using as an example a particularly passionate argument from the left-wing gadfly Fredrik De Boer, in which he reacts to watching the video the killer left behind:

title: Today in Small Business: Seattle Goes to $15 an Hour
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Patrick Cannon, Former Mayor of Charlotte, Pleads Guilty to Fraud
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  The Tuesday morning docket in the Federal District Court here seemed mostly ordinary, as men accused of fraud and drug trafficking, clad in orange jumpsuits, came and went.

title: CFDA Red Carpet Photos
description: The stars of the fashion world converge on Alice Tully Halls red carpet for the CFDA awards.

title: Handicapping the Kellogg Takeover Talk
description: Kellogg looks like someone wants to eat it for breakfast.

title: Behind the Mask  A Reality Check on Chinas Plans for a Carbon Cap
description: BEIJING  Having covered Chinas stance on global warming since 1988, Ive gotten attuned to the need to tread carefully when something is said that feels like a shift in the official position of this greenhouse gas giant.

title: Not the Official Kind, but Still a Wisconsin Pardon
description: BOSCOBEL, Wis.  Aware of the awkwardness, the two men arranged to meet in the evening quiet of the local community center. Their only previous encounter, a decade ago, had ended with a thrown punch and a broken nose.

title: With Suspension Cut, Rangers Daniel Carcillo Can Return in Game 4
description: LOS ANGELES  Gary Bettman, the commissioner of the N.H.L., has shortened the 10-game suspension to Rangers forward Daniel Carcillo for shoving a linesman in Game 3 of the Eastern Conference finals against Montreal on May 22.

title: Image of the Day: June 3
From Exiled Students, Sympathy for One Who Chose Another Path
description: In the spring of 1989, Wang Dans image, with his tousled hair and oversized, plastic-framed glasses, became known to millions around the world as he rallied students on Beijings Tiananmen Square. A history major at the elite Peking University, he chose the path of protest that led to imprisonment and, eventually, to exile following the crackdown on June 4 of that year.

title: Israel Condemns Plan in Washington to Work With New Palestinian Alliance
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Tuesday that he was deeply troubled by the Obama administrations decision to work with the new Palestinian government, signaling new strains in the often rocky relationship between Israel and the United States, two close and critical allies.

title: Illinois: Six are Shot in Laundromat in Chicago
description: Six people were shot in a laundromaton the South Side of Chicago on Mondaynight, the latest outbreak in a wave of gun violence plaguing the city. The shootings happened shortly after8 p.m.in a coin laundry in the 7900 block of South Colfax Avenue, a police spokesman said. The victims, described as two teenagers and four adults by police, were taken to hospitals. None of the injuries were believed to be life-threatening, the police said. Although the number of homicides in Chicago had dropped amid increased police efforts  there were more than 500 homicides in 2012  violence has jumped in recent months.

title: A Prisoner of War, but Not a Hero
description: LEAVE no soldier behind.

title: Portraits of People in Myanmar
description: Humans of New York is a photoblog that uses street photography to document the lives of all sorts of people living in the big apple. With nearly 6 million likes on Facebook, the project has started a storytelling revolution and produced a New York Times bestselling book.

title: Wisconsin Spirits, Meet New York Cocktails
description: Fedora, the snug basement restaurant in Greenwich Village, has named one drink after a town in south-central Wisconsin  the Lake Delton Mule  and another, the Root Beer Butterfest Float, for an annual dairy festival in Reedsburg, Wis. Fedoras nearby sister restaurant, Perla, serves a cocktail called National Lampoons Wisco Vacation, no explanation needed.

title: A reading of SKYMALL by Tom Healy
description: The American poet reads his poem on consumption.

title: Reid and McConnell Duel Over Proposed Amendment on Campaign Spending
description: WASHINGTON  Offering drastically different opinions about the role of money in politics, the Senate leaders Harry Reid and Mitch McConnell on Tuesday made a rare joint appearance before the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: CFDA Winners
description: Joseph Altuzarra and Rihanna were among the winners from Monday nights fashion awards show.

title: An Americans Plea From an Egyptian Jail
description: Mohamed Soltan, an American citizen jailed last year by Egypts military-backed government, appealed to President Obama for help in a video message smuggled out of a prison in Cairo.

title: A C.I.A. Mole Hunt In the Era of Hackers
description: David Ignatiuss fast, sometimes frantic new thriller, The Director, is about a mole in the C.I.A., a ghost in the national security machine, a worm in the system.

title: A Young Photographers Fresh View on Fashion
description: The 30-year-old photographer and filmmaker Erik Madigan Heck has gained acclaim for hyper-real, richly colorful images that elevate fashion portraiture to fine art. A new series of 13 of his large-scale images, The Absorbed Tradition, debuts tomorrow at New Yorks BOSI Contemporary gallery. They will also be featured as part of a special new Heck-curated and photographed issue of Creem magazine, out this month. I decided that I needed to make a whole magazine that articulated a sort of remedy to the problem that I had created in my head, Heck says of the Creem project, which was that everything in fashion image culture resembled everything else.

title: An Opera About Little Rock Integration, With Libretto by Henry Louis Gates Jr.
description: Ever since John Adams had his first operatic hit with Nixon in China, operas based on the headlines and recent history rather than mythological tales and literary adaptations have become plentiful. The University of Central Arkansas is hoping to add the story of the Little Rock Nine  nine black students who enrolled at what had been an all-white high school in Little Rock, Ark., in 1957  to the operatic annals. The school is in the process of commissioning the composer Tania Len and the scholar Henry Louis Gates Jr. to create a work about the incident, and hopes to present the premiere in September 2017, around the 60th anniversary of the events.

title: Dock to Dish, a Cookbook That Celebrates the Greenmarket and More
description: To Savor: A Timely Catch for Restaurants

title: Latest Incarnation of King Crimson Plans U.S. Tour
description: Robert Fripp, the founding guitarist and driving creative force of the British progressive rock band King Crimson, has declared the band dead several times since 1974, but this week he allowed that there was life in it yet. On his online diary Mr. Fripp noted that the groups latest lineup  its eighth since 1969, first announced in September  had just convened in London for rehearsals, and was planning to tour the United States in the fall. The tour is to begin in Albany on Sept. 9 and end in Seattle on Oct. 6. There will be three performances at the Best Buy Theater in Manhattan, Sept. 18-20.

title: Wheelies: The Trolling for Trails Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: The Reporter, the Source, and the Supreme Court
description: Updated at 3:16 p.m. with comment from James Risen

title: Charles Masson Jr. Returns to the Restaurant Scene at the Baccarat Hotel
description: Headliner

title: Car Buyers Crowded Showrooms in May, Unfazed by Surge in Recalls
description: Automakers announced robust sales in the United States in May as several reported double-digit growth over last year  including General Motors, which continued to post strong results despite a widening recall crisis.

title: Found Poem Favorite | Ginger Rogers, Who Danced With Astaire and Won an Oscar for Drama
description: This poem, one of 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest, was written by Elizabeth Thomas and comes from Ginger Rogerss 1995 New York Times obituary.

title: An Existence So Vanilla, Its Stifling
description: His secret is nothing terrible, just a thought that hes kept private, but the man tells it bashfully: I want to live more fully than I do now. Thats the quiet wish of the restless 30-somethings in the Japanese playwright Toshiki Okadas The Sonic Life of a Giant Tortoise, presented by the Play Company in Dan Rothenbergs splendidly cast production at Jack, in Brooklyn.

title: Obama Strengthens Ties With Poland
description: President Obama and President Bronislaw Komorowski of Poland discussed American support for Eastern European allies ahead of a plan to spend $1 billion in training armed forces on Russias borders.

title: Seeking Clues in Mans Arc From Life in Florida to Fatal Blast in Syria
description: VERO BEACH, Fla.  The storefront Islamic center tucked in a nondescript shopping center here has no imam, so the task of leading the small group of men and boys gathered to pray usually falls to the eldest, or the one who knows the Quran the best.

title: Greenwich Concours: Sunny Days, a Big Turnout and a Record Auction
description: The Greenwich Concours d'lgance, now in its 19th year, celebrates classic cars from all over the world, with the spotlight last Sunday on European marques. The day was sunny, and that contributed to a big turnout, for the show and the Bonhams auction held there.

title: Lessons From the Old School
description: The chef Chip Smith and his wife, Tina Vaughn, moved to New York in 2012 after shutting their restaurant in North Carolina, but the Simone, which they opened in November, doesnt feel like a transplanted Southern flower. It is a classic Manhattan restaurant that seems to have emerged on East 82nd Street fully formed out of a time capsule sealed in the last century.

title: First Victim in a Cluster of Stabbings
description: Whether she was practicing her drumming, riding her bike around her neighborhood in Brooklyn or going to the movies, Tanaya Copeland was often accompanied by friends in purple, fellow members of a community marching band who had known her, in some cases, since middle school.

title: Staging Base for Afghan War Handed Over to Kyrgyzstan
description: In another symbolic step toward the exit from Afghanistan, the United States on Tuesday formally handed Kyrgyzstan control of Manas Air Base, once a major staging point for personnel and cargo bound for the Afghan war.

title: The Gun Report: June 3, 2014
description: Are shooting drills and temporary lockdowns now a way of life in American schools, and do they take a toll on our nations schoolchildren?

title: Scene City: Inside the CFDA Awards and After-Parties
description: Rihanna and other celebrities add sparkle to the annual fashion awards.

title: Tiananmens Most Wanted
description: The protesters had been cleared out of Tiananmen Square for just over a week when the Beijing Public Security Bureau issued a most-wanted circular on June 13, 1989, bearing the names and photographs of 21 student leaders.

title: Syrians Vote in Presidential Election
description: Voting began in areas held by the Syrian government for an election that President Bashar al-Assad is certain to win and that the opposition has called a farce.

title: These Chiles? Nothing to Fear
description: AKUMAL, Mexico  There is no one American cuisine, and I suppose you can say there is no one Bittman cuisine either. The nation developed without respect for what was here before the Europeans flooded in, and what might have been was supplanted by anything goes. This culinary manifest destiny can be fascinating, of course; my block has Turkish, Southwestern, Tex-Mex and Italian, all within 100 feet of one another. (Thats before you cross the avenue.) None are very good, but you cant complain about variety.

title: Eli Broads Art Showcase in Los Angeles, Still Unfinished, Sues Over Delays
description: LOS ANGELES  The flagship museum of the billionaire financier and art collector Eli Broad, still under construction, has filed a $19.8 million lawsuit against a German company for what it describes as delays in fabricating the building blocks for its unusual latticed facade.

title: Telling Congress What Families Need, One City, State or Hearing at a Time
description: Recently, Ellen Bravo, executive director of Family Values at Work, testified before the Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions. The hearing was billed as a roundtable discussion of Economic Security for Working Women, but economic security for working women means security for their families, and nearly every policy that would help ease the struggle for working women would improve life in the workplace for men as well.

title: New Member of Obamas Economic Team Has International Expertise
description: One of the worlds top scholars of international economics is set to be the newest addition to the Obama administration economic team.

title: Waking Up Louisvilles Downtown
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  William Weyland is well known here for a string of offbeat projects recycling old buildings.

title: Byliner, an Online Publisher of Long-Form Writing, Seeks Partners
description: Byliner, a company that publishes long, literary journalism and fiction online and as e-books, told its contributors Tuesday that it has been struggling and is seeking partners to ensure its future.

title: Potential Sale of Law School Raises Debate Over Who Should Profit
San Franciscos Ice Cream Scene Gets Even Hotter
description: Its perpetual chill be damned, San Francisco is an ice cream lovers utopia, a city where frozen-dairy shrines like Bi-Rite Creamery, Humphry Slocombe and Mitchells court perpetual lines and impassioned debate about their relative merits. The past few years have brought a new batch of scoop shops and trucks whose products are quintessentially Northern Californian, with an emphasis on local, organic ingredients and flavors that range from the slavishly seasonal to the doggedly avant-garde. Its the kind of ice cream youd expect, in other words, from one of the most gastronomically fixated cities in the country.

title: Hotel Review: Hotel Unique in So Paulo, Brazil
description: Rates

title: Restaurant Report: Thunderbird in Indianapolis
description: The Indianapolis dining scene has come a long way in a short time. Locals talk about how its growing out of its generic roots, gaining a consciousness about non-chain businesses. Take, for example, Thunderbird. In the up-and-coming Fountain Square neighborhood, the 80-seat restaurant, which opened in February, is housed in the former home of a rockabilly nightclub from the 1950s and 60s.

title: A Winding, Watery Way to the World Cup
description: In the last few days, Ive explored a gold mining town, eaten lots of curries and taken a boat down the Essequibo River to visit waterfalls and old Dutch forts  all in Guyana, the English-speaking, Caribbean-influenced country on South Americas north coast. What brings me this virtually tourist-free nation of 750,000?

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Steps for Succession in Spain
description: Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy held a cabinet meeting to lay out the steps for Prince Felipe to succeed his father, a day after King Juan Carlos said he would abdicate the throne.

title: Live Analysis of the Primaries, County by County
description: On Tuesday night, The Upshot and The Times political staff followed the results of the Republican Senate primaries in Mississippi and Iowa in a slightly different way. Nate Cohn, who has been writing about the Senate races, joined Jonathan Martin of The New York Timess Washington bureau. As the election results rolled in, county by county, their analysis was complemented by county-level mapping.

title: The Potential Downside of Natural Gas
description: CONVENTIONAL wisdom, strongly promoted by the natural gas industry, is that natural gas drives down American emissions of carbon dioxide, by substituting for carbon-rich coal. The climate stabilization plan announced by the Obama administration on Monday relies on that. But in other ways, cheap natural gas drives emissions up.

title: American Jailed in Egypt Appeals to Obama for Help
description: In an emotional video message recently smuggled out of a Cairo prison, Mohamed Soltan, an Egyptian-American who was arrested last year by Egypts military-backed government, appealed to President Obama for help.

title: U.S. Imposes Steep Tariffs on Importers of Chinese Solar Panels
description: The Commerce Department on Tuesday imposed steep duties on importers of Chinese solar panels made from certain components, asserting that the manufacturers had benefited from unfair subsidies.

title: Jack Kirbys Boldly Drawn Gods
description: Part of an occasional series on vintage comics.

title: Twitter Chat About New E.P.A. Carbon Pollution Regulations
description: Coral Davenport, who reports on energy and environment policy from the Washington bureau of The New York Times, answered questions on Tuesday from readers on Twitter. The discussion was spurred by President Obamas announcement of Environmental Protection Agency regulations to cut emissions rates from the nations power plants 30 percent from 2005 levels by 2030. Followers of @TheCaucus Twitter account asked about a variety of issues, including the politics and timing of the rule, its effect on coal-producing states, the implications of the regulations for global negotiations on climate change, and more.

title: Brazilian President Rejects Criticism Over World Cup
description: BRASLIA  The year was 1970. Agents of Brazils military dictatorship had arrested Dilma Rousseff, then a member of a fledgling urban guerrilla group, the Palmares Armed Revolutionary Vanguard. Inside the prison where she was being held in So Paulo, a debate raged among the inmates: Should they support Brazil in that years World Cup?

title: Groomed for Greatness | A Mens Spa Where Discretion is Key
description: No man wants a woman to know when hes gotten what the hairstylist Julien Farel calls a salt-and-pepper camouflage  where you blend your gray discreetly to get back to your natural color. And so what happens at JF Men  Farels new mens-only salon, which opened below his new Restore Salon and Spa flagship at the Loews Regency Hotel on the Upper East Side of Manhattan  stays at JF Men. Its almost like Vegas, Farel laughs. Indeed, the intimate space feels akin to a modern-day gentlemens club: a lounge for relaxing after a power lunch, a flat-screen TV, a bar cart  Were only missing the cigar, Farel quips in a thick French accent. Need to get your shoes shined while you get a little taken off the back? No problem.

title: People Lost in Transit, Strangeness Abounding
description: The playwright Julia Jarcho and the director Alice Reagan share a fondness for strangeness, for edges that dont quite line up.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an e-mail. Sign up

title: Southern Politicians Try to Hold Back the Tides
description: Its always taken longer to get to the future in the South, and the regions social tardiness has been on display in this seasons political races. For the moment, at least,harsh and fossilized language is still required of both Republican and Democratic candidates.

title: Dinosaur Fossil Smuggler Gets 3-Month Sentence
description: A Florida fossil hunter who illegally dug up dinosaur skeletons from the Gobi Desert in Mongolia was sentenced on Tuesday to three months in prison on charges that he smuggled the bones into the United States, then used them to reassemble a Tyrannosaurus bataar, above, that he sold for $1 million through a New York auction house.

title: My Wars Are Ending
description: On Dec. 31, the Air Force shut down rescue operations at Bastion Air Base in Afghanistan. It closed five years of lifesaving in the Helmand Province by Pedro and Guardian, as the HH-60G Pave Hawks and Pararescue/Combat Rescue officers were known, and became just the latest in the list of places Ive gone, to which I will go no more. The first ones were Balad Air Base and Camp Victory, in Iraq. Then Kandahar, and most recently, Camp Bastion in Afghanistan.

title: A Reckless Trajectory: Ingnue to Courtesan to Streetwalker
description: The dramatic fortitude required to pull off a good Manon  the troubled courtesan drawn between greed and love  is fairly attainable. Kenneth MacMillans earthy, naturalistic choreography reads like text. But for a great Manon, more is at stake. A ballerina doesnt so much dance the role as let it consume her body, bit by bit. Its like a fever.

title: Childbirth, a Lit Torch and a Trot
description: Diary of an Image by DD Dorvillier: thats the title of the four-week program currently underway at Danspace Project at St. Marks Church. But not all the work is by Ms. Dorvillier. On Friday and Saturday, for the second of two weekends, the choreographer invited colleagues to present solos of their own. Commonalities between the pieces appeared coincidental, except perhaps for purposeful awkwardness and a compulsion to repeat.

title: Garden Workshops at a Vermont Inn
description: The Woodstock Inn & Resort in Woodstock, Vt., this summer is sharing the talents of its No. 1 green thumb, the master gardener Ben Pauly, who will lead a series of hands-on sessions exploring the art and technique of gardening.

title: Busy Comings and Goings, and Tangled Partnerings
description: In a program note accompanying his new work, The Oracle, Daniel Gwirtzman assures his audience that there are so many ways into a dance. Listen to the score, he suggests, or trace the geometries of the movement. Imagine what might happen next, or consider the metaphors embedded in the choreography. Whatever you do, Create your own frame, he urges.

title: Retro Rap That Puts Women Down
description: On Sunday night at Hot 97 Summer Jam, Lil Wayne was at the end of his mini-set, in the middle of his protge Nicki Minajs performance, when he gleefully rapped his verse from the Chris Brown hit Loyal, concluding with the incessant refrain: These hos aint loyal!

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Ukraine, South Africa and Iran.

title: Musical Mischief With Dvorak
description: The Budapest Festival Orchestra was almost halfway into its performance of Dvoraks Slavonic Dance No. 8 (Op. 72) on Monday evening when Gaspar Szente, one of its percussionists, ambled through the string section to the front of the stage. Sitting down on the stool that had been placed there for the next concertos solo cellist, he calmly reached into his breast pocket and pulled out a tiny brass cymbal. Another leisurely gesture brought forward a mallet. With his head cocked attentively, he waited for his entrance. Then he played, intermittently producing delicate, pealing notes that improbably became the musics emotional focus.

title: Any Ghosts Here? A Team Is in Pursuit
description: Say this for Bryan Singer: He has range. Hes the director and a producer of X-Men: Days of Future Past, which has grossed more than $500 million worldwide in less than two weeks. And, at the same time, hes an executive producer of the new online series Spooked, which looks as if it could have been made on the X-Men budget for moist towelettes.

title: Far From Beijing, Jaded Students Inspired to Protest
description: They were the children of poor farmers and factory workers, the first in their families to attend college, and for that they were grateful. But in the spring of 1989, the students at Hubei University, a provincial college in the Yangtze River city of Wuhan, were jaded beyond their years.

title: Off Her High Horse and Back Home
description: Here are some reasons to like, or at least be interested in, the first episode of Jennifer Falls, a new sitcom beginning on Wednesday on TV Land. Or not.

title: A Paltry Start in Curbing Global Warming
description: Tim Jackson, professor of sustainable development at the University of Surrey in Britain, uses a nifty back-of-the-envelope calculation to underscore the challenge of giving the worlds poor a shot at prosperity while preventing a global climate disaster.

title: Spoleto, Known for Its Operas, Has Drama Left Over for the Concert Stage
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The Spoleto Festival USA has seemed to be in more or less permanent reconstruction mode in recent years, thanks to the renovation of some of its main performance spaces: first the weather-beaten Memminger Auditorium (reopened in 2008), then the College of Charlestons Sottile Theater (2009) and the historic Dock Street Theater (2010). Now the end is in sight, with work well along on a rebuilding and acoustical upgrade of the Gaillard Auditorium, which is scheduled to reopen next May.

title: Should We Die?
description: If letting a scientist study your child could help stop human aging, would you allow it?

title: Into the Sanctum With a Master of Awe and Mysticism
description: Composers are inspired by myriad sources, including a particular event, emotion, person or landscape. The prime inspiration of the Estonian composer Arvo Prt, however, was suppressed for a long stretch of his career. Beginning in the 1960s, Mr. Prt, a convert to the Eastern Orthodox faith, wrote works whose religious character irked the Soviet authorities at a time when the official credo was atheism.

title: An Affirmation of Faith at Carnegie Hall
description: Orthodox priests in black robes and conical caps rubbed shoulders with pop stars and actors, including Bjrk, Antony Hegarty and Keanu Reeves, at Carnegie Hall on Saturday at a sold-out concert of music by Arvo Prt. No other living composer has so fervent a following or such a diverse group of fans. When Mr. Prt, bearded, frail and smiling shyly, took a bow at the end of the evening  this was his first visit to New York in 30 years  the roar that greeted him seemed unanimous.

title: Steven Spinola
description: Mr. Spinola, 65, is the president of the Real Estate Board of New York, or Rebny, the industrys leading trade association in the city with about 15,000 members. He is the longest-serving president of the group, having held the position since 1986. Rebnys focus lately has been on the citys recently released affordable housing plan.

title: European Central Bank Chief Looks for Silver Bullet
description: FRANKFURT  Mario Draghi might feel like a doctor trying to treat a chronically ill patient with unproven medicines.

title: Europe Struggles to Avoid Deflations Grip
description: ATHENS  In her upscale three-story beauty salon in a middle-class suburb of Athens, Doria Tsirigotis used to charge 30 euros for a haircut. But when a wrenching recession set in, her competitors started cutting their prices, first to 20 euros, then to 10 and even as low as 5  or less than $7.

title: Iran Offers a Window to the West
description: Given a chance  and a week  to visit Iran, John Moore took to the road in central Iran to see daily life in a place that has opened a bit to the West.

title: For Goldmans New Strategy Officer, Putting the Bank Back in Banker
description: When Stephen M. Scherr started at Goldman Sachs more than 20 years ago, the firm operated out of the public eye. Run by a consortium of partners, it did not have to disclose much about its financial health to the world.

title: New York City Teachers Vote for Raise and a Nine-Year Contract
description: New York City teachers have approved a nine-year labor contract, their union announced on Tuesday, a deal that raises pay by 18 percent but leaves questions about the future of their health benefits.

title: Narendra Modi, the Prime Minister of India: A Leader Who Is What He Wears
description: Even by the standards of a world that has seen blogs devoted to Michelle Obamas dress sense, the pre-election makeovers of Franois Hollande and Dilma Rousseff, and the canonization of Nelson Mandelas shirts, the image-craft of Indias new prime minister, Narendra Modi  and its fashion fallout  has been something of a case study.

title: Budapest Orchestra Has Bows Seized Over Ivory Concerns
description: Updated, June 4, 2:52 p.m. |

title: Massad Is Confirmed as Chairman of Futures Commission
description: The Senate confirmed the nomination of Timothy G. Massad as chairman of the Commodity Futures Commission on Tuesday, as well as two other commissioners to lead the agency, Sharon Y. Bowen and J. Christopher Giancarlo.

title: Google Offers New Encryption Tool
description: The National Security Agencys snooping is about to get more difficult.

title: Visa Is Preparing a Standard for Prepaid Debit Cards
description: Prepaid debit cards are growing in popularity, but its often hard to know whether a card is a good deal or not before you buy one, because theres no requirement that the cards disclose their fees and terms in a uniform way. To help clue in consumers, Visa Inc. said on Tuesday that it would soon flag prepaid cards that meet a set of consumer-friendly standards, like flat monthly fees.

title: As Obama Acts on Pollution and Bergdahl, G.O.P. Talks of an Erosion of Trust
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administrations actions in the case of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl and in issuing new power plant emissions restrictions have deepened its rift with congressional Republicans, who see the moves as the latest troubling examples of the White House circumventing Congress.

title: Coal Pollution and Climate Change
Semifinal Reunion for Gulbis and Djokovic
description: PARIS  Flower power was no match for Ernests Gulbis at the French Open on Tuesday.

title: Missing, Captured, Freed: The Case of Bowe Bergdahl
description: To the Editor:

title: A Future for Bike Share
description: To the Editor:

title: A Docu-Ad Looks at Hardship of Those Without Bank Access
description: REMEMBER the longtime pitch for Campbells Chunky soup, the soup that eats like a meal? A project that American Express is to introduce Wednesday can be described as a commercial that watches like a documentary.

title: Shipping Oil by Rail
description: To the Editor:

title: Gail Collins Responds to Readers: Excitement Mounts! Sort of
description: In her recent column, Excitement Mounts! Sort Of, Gail Collins writes about what weve learned so far this election season. Readers had these questions for her:

title: Womens Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Marijuana
Segregation by Ability
Clippers Sale Silences a Dialogue on Race
description: A few weeks ago, we seemed to be on the verge of having a national conversation about race, racism and prejudice.

title: Iraqs Best Hope
description: SULAIMANI, Iraq  I am a sucker for commencements, but this one filled me with many different emotions.

title: Upscale Dairies Grow in India, Promising Safer Milk
description: GURGAON, India  On a 26-acre farm a couple hours drive inland from Mumbai, hundreds of black-and-white Holstein-Friesian cows laze around, dining on seasonal greens and listening to a custom playlist of rap, pop, classical and even devotional music. They are treated to a routine medical checkup before heading to a rotary milking parlor, where their udders are gently squeezed, until the cows step away, at will.

title: In BNP Case and Beyond, Regulators Search for Penalties to Fit the Crimes
description: United States bank regulators are descending deep into the plumbing of the financial system as they seek the most fitting punishment for the giant French bank now in the cross hairs of the law enforcement authorities.

title: Massachusetts: Details Emerge on Fatal Jet Crash
description: The crew of the Gulfstream IV jet that crashed in Bedford on Saturday night made comments about aircraft control before the plane ran off the runway and exploded, according to federal investigators analyzing the cockpit voice recorder and the flight data recorder on Tuesday. An investigator did not specify the nature of the comments. The investigator also said that a crew member had indicated the plane was ready to lift off, but it was unclear why the aircraft failed to do so. All seven people on board were killed. The flight data recorder indicated that the jet reached 165 knots, and that brake pressure rose and the aircraft decelerated before it careered into a gully.

title: G.M. Officials Say They Expect Mary Barra Will Be Cleared of Wrongdoing
description: DETROIT  The moment captured a new sense of confidence that General Motors has been anxiously awaiting from Mary T. Barra, its embattled chief executive.

title: Plan to Honor Big Developer in Brooklyn Is Criticized
description: The Municipal Art Society is well known for campaigns to save Grand Central Terminal and Lever House and to stop towers  that would have cast long shadows over Central Park.

title: Cases Revolution Fund Invests in Supplier of Childrens Lunches
description: Stephen M. Case, the investor and co-founder of AOL, is taking an increasing interest in the food business.

title: Tunisian Man Accused Last Year of Terrorism Pleads Guilty to Lesser Counts
description: A Tunisian man who federal prosecutors said last year had wanted to commit acts of terrorism pleaded guilty on Tuesday to two charges that did not specifically mention terrorism.

title: Horse Racing Still Stumbling in Antidrug Push
description: BALTIMORE  When California Chrome finally made his way back to the stables at Pimlico Race Course after winning the Preakness Stakes more than two weeks ago, fans cheered and rushed toward him, their camera phones held high and clicking.

title: Smuggling Remembrance Into Tiananmen Square
description: As my colleague Dan Levin reported from Beijing, the authorities in China appeared to step up their censorship of the Internet to blot out even oblique discussion of the 25th anniversary of the violent crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square on June 3 and 4, 1989.

title: Dai-ichi to Buy Protective Life for $5.7 Billion
description: Dai-ichi Life Insurance, one of Japans biggest life insurers, agreed on Tuesday to buy the Protective Life Corporation for about $5.7 billion, as Japanese companies continue to seek growth outside their home country.

title: Aiming Financial Weapons From Treasury War Room
description: WASHINGTON  In a dingy suite of offices in a Treasury Department annex, the troops work into the night, armed with paperwork, computers and a clock on the wall set to Tehran time. They blast out advisories ordering banks to block targeted people, then threaten them with consequences  fines that can range into millions of dollars  if they do not.

title: HOW THE INDUSTRY FARED IN MAY
description: Strong sales were reported as recalls are up industrywide.

title: Monarchies, More Useful Than You Think
description: The decision by the 76-year-old King Juan Carlos of Spain to abdicate in favor of his 46-year-old son, Crown Prince Felipe, inevitably revives the question of why so many monarchs still reign across Europe.

title: A Prosecutors Reputation Sinks Lower
description: When Kenneth Thompson was campaigning last year to unseat the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles Hynes, his main line of attack was that the office Mr. Hynes had run for nearly 24 years was ethically compromised, badly managed and a discredit to law enforcement.

title: BNP Paribas Pinned Hopes on Legal Memo, in Vain
description: BNP Paribas, under investigation for doing business with Sudan and other countries that the United States has blacklisted, is hashing out the final details of a criminal guilty plea for its parent company. Several months ago, the giant French bank thought it had a secret weapon to avoid that fate altogether.

title: Protesters Cite New Details of Albuquerque Police Shooting as Reason for Rally
description: ALBUQUERQUE  The 13 protesters who stormed the mayors office here and were arrested and jailed Monday said they were spurred by renewed outrage over the latest development in a string of fatal police shootings: An autopsy released last week showed the bullet that killed a homeless man, James Boyd, had been fired into his lower back.

title: Amazons Power Play
description: Amazon, the online retailer, has often described itself as obsessed with making customers happy. But lately the company has been making some of its users extremely unhappy by making it hard or impossible for them to buy books published by the Hachette Book Group  in the United States and delaying the deliveries of titles from the Bonnier Media Group in Germany.

title: Dont Harsh Our Mellow, Dude
description: The caramel-chocolate flavored candy bar looked so innocent, like the Sky Bars I used to love as a child.

title: How The Industry Fared In May
description: Strong sales were reported as recalls are up industrywide.

title: Critics Are Questioning American Military Credo of Leaving No One Behind
description: WASHINGTON  The deadly rescue mission in Afghanistan in 2002 began when Petty Officer First Class Neil C. Roberts, a member of the Navys classified SEAL Team Six, fell out of a helicopter that came under enemy fire as it tried to land on the snowy ridge line of an 11,000-foot mountain.

title: Favorite for Triple Crown Inspires a Run on Betting Tickets
description: For veteran gamblers, the rhythms of victory are familiar, if too elusive, on most afternoons.

title: Michigan Senate Passes Plan to Ease Detroit Pension Cuts
description: The Michigan Senate on Tuesday agreed to Gov. Rick Snyders call for spending millions in state funds to spare the pensions of Detroit retirees from deeper cuts and to avoid the sale of artworks from the citys museum, part of a larger bargain aimed at bringing a swift close to the nations largest municipal bankruptcy.

title: Deal to Free Bowe Bergdahl Puts Obama on Defensive
description: WASHINGTON  The White House argued on Tuesday that the unique circumstances presented by the opportunity to return Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl gave President Obama the authority to lawfully bypass a federal statuterequiring the Pentagon to notify Congress a month before he transferred the five Taliban detainees necessary to complete the deal.

title: Corporate Rivalries and Strategies Extend to the Street
description: When his Manhattan hedge fund entered a corporate relay race, a young trader named David Nightingale gained a leadership role: ringer.

title: Live-Blogging the Tiananmen Square Anniversary
description: Today marks the 25th anniversary of the Chinese militarys crackdown on the protests in Tiananmen Square, and The Times reported on how the event was remembered. In Hong Kong, a huge nighttime rally took place in Victoria Park. But in mainland China the situation was starkly different: The authorities were intent on silencing any mention of the anniversary, arresting dissidents and others, and prohibiting social media postings that allude even remotely to the crackdown.

title: It Will Be Incomparably More Difficult to Rule China
description: On June 4, 1989, Chinese troops conducted a bloody crackdown on thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. At the time, Nicholas Kristof, The New York Timess Beijing bureau chief, reported that by ordering soldiers to fire on the unarmed crowds, the Chinese leadership has created an incident that almost surely will haunt the government for years to come.

title: Judges Decision to Hear Inmates Case Threatens Practice of Solitary Confinement
description: More than 200 inmates at Pelican Bay, Californias toughest prison, have spent over a decade locked in windowless 8-foot-by-12-foot cells for 22 hours or more a day. Dozens more have been in solitary confinement for 15 years  or even longer.

title: In Stanley Cup Finals, Big Markets Dont Mean Big Viewership
description: The Stanley Cup finals between the Rangers and Los Angeles Kings are the ninth being carried by NBC and its cable companion, NBCSN (and its Versus and OLN antecedents), a long period of media stability for the N.H.L. Under NBC, the finals have averaged as many as 5.7 million viewers (last years Original Six battle between Boston and Chicago) and as few as 1.8 million (the 2007 Ottawa-Anaheim series). Now, as teams from the nations two largest markets meet, some wonder if this is the formula for record viewership.

title: Let Sleeping Dogs Lie
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Its game night here at Wordplay, and Jim Hilger has gotten out some of his favorites for us.

title: All the Worlds a Stage: One Players View of It
description: In his light-footed and lovable new solo show, Just Jim Dale, the man of the hour and a half recalls an early turning point in his path toward a long career in show business. When the young Mr. Dale was taken to his first West End musical, Me and My Girl, he watched a comic dazzle the audience with a tumble into the orchestra pit and felt a sudden, churning yearning to be up there, basking in the laughter. He turned to his father and asked how he might make a go of it.

title: Sams Club Plans a Safer Credit Card
description: Sams Club plans to announce a new credit card on Wednesday that will make it the first major American retailer to switch to a more secure payment card technology that has been widely discussed since a customer-data breach at Target late last year.

title: A Growing Challenge for Germans Who Live by Bread Alone
description: SCHOPFHEIM, Germany  On Sunday mornings, the line at the backdoor of Fritz Trefzgers bakery snakes through the courtyard as customers wait for their chance to step into the inner sanctum of his kitchen.

title: Former Prosecutor in Brooklyn Was Consumed by Campaign, Emails Show
description: As a contentious campaign intensified, the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, was grasping to stay on top.

title: Sather Is Used to Stanley Cup Finals, if Not With the Rangers
description: LOS ANGELES  Glen Sather used to be at these things all the time, though not lately  not in 24 years, in fact. But Sather, the guiding force of the Rangers, seemed perfectly at home at the Staples Center on Tuesday, taking part in media day as his team prepared for Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals against the Los Angeles Kings.

title: On the Line in Governors Stanley Cup Bets: Rice Cakes vs. Cupcakes
description: ALBANY  California has fine wines. New York has world-class steaks.

title: Blurred Lines Between Duty and Friendship
description: Let us eavesdrop on an email exchange between two men who have been friends for 40 years, talking in the way people do when they have known each other for most of their adult lives.

title: Den Dekker Grabs an Opportunity in Center
