My son, who has some special needs, got upset and began screaming that he hated his uncle and called him selfish and stupid. A subsequent talk with my sister did not go well. She downplayed her husbands yelling and thinks we should have corrected my son for his outburst. I disagree. No one yells at my son but me. Ideas?

title: Common Spaces
description: The Kitchen

title: Jay DeFeo
description: Mitchell-Innes & Nash

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: sunburned teenagers, MERS and MRSA. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Ibrahim El-Salahi: Selected Works, 1962-2010
description: Skoto Gallery

title: Joyce Robins: Paint and Clay
description: Theodore:Art

title: Fund Manager Sets Goats Grazing in Blighted Detroit
description: To most of the world, the solution to debt-ridden Detroit is money. But for one hedge fund manager, its goats.

title: What Im Reading
description: On my nightstand right now is a stack of books about soccer. They were part of my plan to write a column called, at least in my own mind, How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the World Cup. (Columnists dont choose the headlines).

title: Shoo-Ins Are Few in Heated Tony Race
description: IN a departure from recent Tony Awards seasons, when popular musicals like The Book of Mormon, Once, and Kinky Boots were dominant, voters for Sundays prizes are likely to spread them around. But among which shows? Which performers and artists? Making predictions is unusually difficult this year, with few clear-cut favorites, more wild cards than usual and some fierce races involving Hollywood stars, veteran stage actors and past Tony winners.

title: Clip: Edge of Tomorrow
description: A scene from the film featuring Tom Cruise and Emily Blunt.

title: Killed in Action by Aliens, Over and Over Again
description: Tell me if youve heard this one before. A man wakes up and quickly realizes that hes repeating yesterday, down to the last meal, salutation and conversation. Hes trapped in a kind of time loop. He cant escape, but, he realizes, he can change. That may not make sense, given the logic of the space-time continuum, but it works just fine in fiction because, well, its fiction. To put it another way, There are no paradoxes in time travel, there cant be. Or so says a character in Robert A. Heinleins 1964 novel, Farnhams Freehold, about space, time and the apocalypse.

title: Celebrating in Prospect Park
description: Celebrate Brooklyn!, in its 36th year, will put on a series of free concerts by an all-star lineup.

title: For Fathers Day in London, a Brawnier Tea
description: In honor of Fathers Day on June 15, the Milestone Hotel in Londons Kensington neighborhood is offering Gentlemans Afternoon Tea.

title: Guggenheim Abu Dhabi Plans a Preview Show
description: The Guggenheim Abu Dhabi, one of three museums being built on the windswept Saadiyat Island in the capital of the United Arab Emirates, has been a quieter presence than the two other institutions there. The Louvre Abu Dhabi, designed by the French architect Jean Nouvel, which is scheduled to open next year, and the Zayed National Museum, created by the British architect Norman Foster and to be completed in two years, have each had exhibitions at Manarat Al Saadiyat, the islands exhibition and visitor center, offering previews of their institutions. Now it is the Guggenheims turn.

title: The Islands Treasured by Offshore Tax Avoiders
description: Did you know that United States companies earned $129 billion in 2010 in three small groups of islands?

title: Clip: Obvious Child
description: A scene from the film, featuring Jenny Slate and Jake Lacy.

title: Right Guy Is Just One in a World of Choices
description: We first encounter Donna Stern, the 28-ish heroine of Gillian Robespierres Obvious Child, doing standup in a ratty Brooklyn club, putting her own idiosyncratic spin on the currently popular style of boundaryless, confessional, body-conscious humor. Donna is played by Jenny Slate, whose rsum (Saturday Night Live, Parks and Recreation, Bobs Burgers) reads like a Google map of the modern comic universe and who easily juggles the sweet and nasty sides of her temperament.

title: Pro Wrestlers Add Heft to Campaign for Better Parenting by Fathers
description: THE Advertising Council is joining forces with World Wrestling Entertainment on a public service campaign promoting the importance of men being better fathers.

title: A Regent of Retro and Future
description: Every narrative needs a tension, and in the kinetic, fantastical saga of Janelle Mones career, it boils down to the tug-of-war between abandon and control. At the Prospect Park Bandshell on Wednesday night, she was wheeled onstage in a straitjacket, her posture and pompadour briefly evoking the Bride of Frankenstein. Breaking free, she headed straight into Givin Em What They Love, a prowling funk processional whose title refrain lands somewhere between a boast and a pledge.

title: A Home Invader, Creepily Charismatic
description: There is no one who resembles a sleeping princess, a fairy godmother or a dashing romantic savior in the Dutch filmmaker Alex van Warmerdams malevolent adult fairy tale, Borgman. The storys magic is black, its perfidy driven by evil spirits.

title: Theater Listings for June 6-12
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Comedy Listings for June 6-12
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for June 6-12
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Days After a Federal Seizure, Another Type of Ransomware Gains Ground
description: SAN FRANCISCO It has been mere days since federal agents seized control of computer networks used by hackers to infect victims with CryptoLocker, a piece of malware known as ransomware, which encrypts the contents of computing devices so hackers can demand a ransom to decrypt it.

title: Unanswered Questions From G.M.s Report
description: Matthew L. Wald, a Times business reporter, had three unanswered questions after the release of an internal investigation into General Motors ignition switch problems.

title: 70 Years After D-Day, Veterans Return to Normandy
description: With the youngest participants in the 1944 storming of five Normandy beaches now 88, these anniversary commemorations may be, for many, the last memorial pilgrimage.

title: A Scary Experience With Edible Marijuana
This Weeks Movies | June 6, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review Obvious Child, The Fault in Our Stars and Edge of Tomorrow.

title: European Central Bank on Inflation Fight
description: The European Central Bank president, Mario Draghi, announced several measures to fight low inflation and boost the euro zone economy.

title: Fixes After BP Spill Not Enough, Board Says
description: HOUSTON  Federal safety regulators warned on Thursday that another disastrous offshore oil well blowout could happen despite regulatory improvements in the four years since a BP well explosion in the Gulf of Mexico killed 11 workers and dumped millions of gallons of oil into the sea.

title: With Obama and Putin in France for Dinner, Hollande Leaves Room for Seconds
description: PARIS  Gourmand though he may be, it seems highly improbable that President Franois Hollande of France was moved by appetite alone to host two successive dinners here on Thursday night.

title: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for June 6-12
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: In Memoir, Hillary Clinton Discusses Russia, Syria and Iraq
description: In her memoir Hard Choices, Hillary Rodham Clinton writes about the United States troubled reset with Russia, says her vote authorizing the war in Iraq was wrong, calls Syria a wicked problem and gives a timetable of the raid that led to the death of Osama bin Laden, according to CBS News, which obtained a copy of the book before its publication next week.

title: Jazz Listings for June 6-12
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Classical & Opera Listings for June 6-12
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Book Fight: Amazon vs. Publishers
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance Listings for June 6-12
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Verizon Challenges Netflixs Warning Messages Blaming It for Slow Streaming Service
description: Verizon fired back at Netflix on Thursday after it was revealed that Netflix showed its customers an error message blaming Verizons network for slowing the streaming of Netflixs programming.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for June 6-12
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Tea Party Dead-Enders
description: The Tea Party is five years old this election season, which means its done teething and spitting up on itself, but still prone to temper tantrums, irrational outbursts and threats to take its toys and storm off if it doesnt get its way.

title: Spare Times for Children for June 6-12
description: SPROUTFEST

title: In Brazen Strike, Sunni Militants Storm Central Iraqi City
description: BAGHDAD  Hundreds of Sunni militants stormed the central Iraqi city of Samarra early Thursday, taking control of neighborhoods and government buildings in a siege that provoked a panicked government counteroffensive to prevent the loss of the town.

title: The Climate Domino
description: Maybe its me, but the predictable right-wing cries of outrage over the Environmental Protection Agencys proposed rules on carbon seem oddly muted and unfocused. I mean, these are the people who managed to create national outrage over nonexistent death panels. Now the Obama administration is doing something that really will impose at least some pain on some people. Where are the eye-catching fake horror stories?

title: Spare Times for June 6-12
description: Museums and Sites

title: The Political War
description: Pity Abraham Lincoln. Everything that should have gone right for the Union cause in the spring of 1864 had, in just a few weeks, gone defiantly and disastrously wrong.

title: Where Bigfoot Roamed
description: As a comedian, Bobcat Goldthwait can seem like a colicky baby, spitting punch lines punctuated by random screams. As a filmmaker, however, hes more focused and less predictable, channeling his choleric style into pointed satires on American society that sometimes hit their marks with uncomfortable directness.

title: It Takes Some Heat to Create Movie Stars
description: Until it disintegrates in an explosion of sentimentality, Trust Me qualifies for what could be called The Day of the Locust award. That imaginary honor, named for the Nathanael West novel, would be bestowed on the years nastiest, most stomach-turning movie about no-holds-barred Hollywood wheeling and dealing. Such films are usually box office poison, but they still are made, perhaps because they give their creators a chance to vent.

title: Clip: Ping Pong Summer
description: A scene from the film, directed by Michael Tully.

title: Its 1985 All Over Again
description: From its revenge-of-the-nerd narrative to its soaked-in-nostalgia style, Ping Pong Summer revisits the 1980s with such slavish affection that you suspect its writer and director, Michael Tully, of being notably transformed during those boom-box-blighted years. The film fairly beams with the afterglow of lost virginity.

title: Shifts in Wireless Market May Sway a Sprint Deal
description: WASHINGTON  In the view of Sprint and T-Mobile USA, less is more.

title: President Obama Was Right
description: Americans dont have a common ancestry. Therefore, we have to work hard to build national solidarity. We go in for more overt displays of patriotism than in most other countries: politicians wearing flag lapel pins, everybody singing the national anthem before games, saying the Pledge of Allegiance at big meetings, revering sacred creedal statements, like the Gettysburg Address.

title: Did Colorado Go Too Far With Pot?
Nigerian Sect Kills Villagers Along Border
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The Boko Haram men, disguised in army uniforms, gathered the villagers together and promised them protection.

title: Back Where He Belonged: An All-Satchmo Day
description: MAYBE it was the 50th anniversary of Hello, Dolly having knocked the Beatles off the top of the pop charts (May 9, 1964), but it occurred to me recently that with a little advance work, I could spend an entire day in New York with Louis Armstrong.

title: Louis and Lucille Armstrongs Creole Red Beans and Rice
description: Courtesy of Louis Armstrong House Museum Time: 6 hours

title: Key Questions in the Release of Bowe Bergdahl
description: Sorting out the facts and the controversy surrounding the release of the lone American prisoner of war from the Afghan conflict.

title: Steven H. Scheuer Is Dead at 88; He Put the TV Review Before the Show
description: Steven H. Scheuer, a television critic who helped change how newspapers reviewed programs and thus how viewers decided what to watch, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: House Democrats Set Off to Energize the Faithful, With a Focus on Women
description: CHICAGO  It is a politically gloomy midterm election year for Democrats, but Representative Nancy Pelosi and some of her House colleagues were on a roll this week.

title: Researchers Race to Save Coral in Miami
description: MIAMI  With dredging set to begin this weekend in the Port of Miami, researchers are scrambling to salvage a much larger than expected trove of delicate corals that were not in the original marine life rescue plan for the undersea area.

title: Belatedly, Europe Takes On Low Inflation
description: After months of doing too little, the European Central Bank on Thursday announced a series of policies to bolster the euro zones frail economy and avert deflation, which would weaken it even further.

title: Where Some May Say No Thanks for the Memories
description: YEKATERINBURG, Russia  On the embankment of the lake at the heart of this city in the Urals, a half-built shopping center is slowly being turned into a monument to a man and an era that few in Russia remember fondly at all, even in the mans native region.

title: A Horror Story Borrows From History
description: The director Ti West, whose credits include the very fine horror movie The House of the Devil, has a talent for dread. Hes so good at raising the little hairs on your neck and keeping them on alert that you can only feel let down when he doesnt deliver a movie that makes good on his setup. Thats the case with his latest, The Sacrament, a neo-exploitation flick that shifts from the unnerving to the hollow after it becomes evident that Mr. West is more interested in showing how his characters die than how they lived. It doesnt help that he seems to encourage you to wish the worst on at least some of them, notably a troika that serves as this tales metaphoric blind mice.

title: Clip: The Sacrament
description: A scene from The Sacrament, directed by Ti West.

title: Soaring, and Souring, in Postseason Spotlight
description: LOS ANGELES  The Kings Justin Williams, a decent offensive producer in the regular season, is a monster during the playoffs. The Rangers Rick Nash, a big-ticket goal scorer in the regular season, has been virtually unable to score in the postseason.

title: Remembering D-Day With Their Brothers in Arms
description: STONY BROOK, N.Y.  Every morning, Lieutenant Michael Settanni wakes up next to his bunkmate, Cpl. Ben Gebbia, in a modest room in a home shared with about 350 other military men.

title: An Old Warplanes Do-Over Flight in France
description: Revisiting the skies it last braved during World War II, the New York-based war horse known as the Whiskey 7 was back over Normandy on Thursday, once again opening its doors and letting parachutists jump into the frigid air outside, 70 years after its  and the worlds  most famous invasion.

title: Clip: The Case Against 8
description: A scene from the documentary.

title: After Heartbreak, Time for Results
description: Rapid, aggressive police work led to the arrest on Wednesday of a suspect in the shocking stabbings of two children in a Brooklyn public-housing elevator on Sunday.

title: A Tale That Nearly Had No End
description: As gay men living in California, Ben Cotner and Ryan White were flabbergasted, Mr. White recalled, by the passage of Proposition 8, their states 2008 ballot measure to deny the right of same-sex couples to marry. They didnt expect it to win.

title: On a Team of Stars, Only One Plays Like It
description: Sometimes, you really can predict baseball  at least when Masahiro Tanaka pitches. Those other days are the troublesome ones for the Yankees.

title: Chester Nez, 93, Dies; Navajo Words Washed From Mouth Helped Win War
description: To the end of his life, Chester Nez recalled the first message he sent over the radio while serving at Guadalcanal: Enemy machine gun nest on your right. Destroy.

title: A Legal Chess Game Leading to I Do
description: Opening in theaters before airing on HBO on June 23, The Case Against 8 follows the legal challenge to Proposition 8, the 2008 referendum that banned same-sex marriage in California. Because the Supreme Court effectively nullified the ban last year  the decision said the initiatives supporters lacked the standing to appeal a federal ruling striking it down  this documentary from Ben Cotner and Ryan White is less a work of immediacy than of backstage intrigue.

title: Some See G.M. Report as Powerful Ammunition for Change
description: WASHINGTON  The chief for regulatory affairs is gone. So is a senior lawyer and two midlevel engineers. Two safety executives were also let go. The list is long  at least 20 in all  of those dismissed or disciplined by General Motors for their role in the companys failure to correct a deadly safety defect in millions of its small cars.

title: At French Open, Simona Halep Carries the Hopes of Romania
description: PARIS  One of the quirks and delights of the Grand Slam tournaments is that the historical tennis figures are often still here on site, playing in the senior events, watching from the stands or the commentary booths, hobnobbing in the hallways and presidents boxes.

title: Bond Rally Is Squeezing the Trading at Big Banks
description: Wall Streets biggest firms this year made an extraordinary wager that they probably now regret.

title: Surviving a German Trading Floor, Ruefully
description: In The Wolf of Wall Street, Jordan Belfort cuts short an explanation of his work, because, he says, we probably couldnt follow the details. Master of the Universe attempts that explanation but offers a sobering antidote to irrational exuberance and a psychological case study in the financiers mind-set. This indefatigable tell-all documentary from Marc Bauder cedes the floor to Rainer Voss, a German ex-trader who tells us with clarity about how it all works.

title: How to Meet Cute in France: Whimsical Stabbings, Genial Strokes
description: Life doesnt proceed as methodically as in the screenplay of a skillfully plotted commercial film. Unforeseen events interrupt the flow and destroy the symmetry. The randomness of life and the capriciousness of human nature were recurrent motifs in French New Wave movies of the 1960s and 70s. And in 2 Autumns, 3 Winters, the Gallic filmmaker Sbastien Betbeders breezy, lighthearted homage to the films of Jean-Luc Godard and others, fate keeps stepping in to alter the destinies of its three principal characters, Arman (Vincent Macaigne), Benjamin (Bastien Bouillon) and Amlie (Maud Wyler).

title: Shooting Leaves One Dead at Seattle Pacific University
description: SEATTLE  A man armed with a shotgun opened fire on the campus of Seattle Pacific University on Thursday afternoon, leaving three people wounded and one dead before being taken into custody, the Seattle police said.

title: Woman in an Endless Coma, Circled by Endless Debate
description: Thought and feeling are never far apart in the films of Marco Bellocchio. From his precocious beginnings in the 1960s with Fists in the Pocket and China Is Near, Mr. Bellocchio, now 74, has explored weighty ideas  about Italian society and politics, about the struggle between faith and secularism in the modern world, about authority, idealism and sexual desire  with passionate, at times melodramatic, ardor.

title: The Complex Battle to Achieve the Perfect Dirt
description: A week before the 146th running of the Belmont Stakes, a tractor with wheels practically the size of horses towed a grader along the track while a worker on the back checked the depth of the dirts surface every couple of feet.

title: For a Decade, G.M. Response to a Fatal Flaw Was to Shrug
description: Just six months ago, a group of senior General Motors executives gathered to review a series of PowerPoint slides concerning a question that had been smoldering inside G.M. for a decade: Should the company recall hundreds of thousands of small cars because of a dangerous defect?

title: Playing Ball in the Shadow of Warfare
description: If nothing else, The Only Real Game, a documentary about baseball in Manipur, in northeastern India, serves as an antidote to the Disney film Million Dollar Arm, which also involves baseball and India. Here, Americas game is played with armed troops looking on and with very little prospect of a happy ending.

title: Faces of an Immigration System Overwhelmed by Women and Children
description: SAN ANTONIO  This is what it looks like when an immigration system is overwhelmed by tens of thousands of women and children from Central America.

title: Events in New Jersey for June 8-14, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Girl, 7, Recovering From Elevator Stabbing
description: Her best friend is dead, stabbed to death on Sunday by a strange man who followed them into an elevator in a public housing project in East New York, Brooklyn. A suspect is in custody, his history of violence and mental illness now the subject of intense scrutiny.

title: Clip: Burts Buzz
description: A scene from the documentary.

title: Syria: Assad Praises Election and Iran
description: A day after his re-election in a disputed vote, President Bashar al-Assad said on Thursday that the 73 percent turnout the government reported in the vote sent a message that Syrians were determined to manage their own affairs, brushing off criticism of the vote and calls for an internationally brokered political transition. Syrias state news agency reported that Mr. Assad, who made the comments during a meeting with a high-ranking Iranian official, Alaeddin Boroujerdi, also praised Irans nuclear program, the subject of intense international negotiations. Iran says the program is for civilian purposes, while the United States says it is a military program. Mr. Boroujerdi was part of a delegation of election observers from Iran  a country that has provided considerable support to ensure the survival of Mr. Assad. The Iranian delegation declared that the election, in which the president garnered 89 percent of the vote, was free and fair. Mr. Assads opposition has denounced the election as a farce.

title: Missed Out on Millions, but Hes the Spartan Sort
description: The word icon is given quite a workout in Burts Buzz, a documentary about the man whose likeness adorns Burts Bees products. Its to the films detriment. Not only is the word overused these days, but it also has no business being applied to a pitchman for a product line that may have fans but is hardly a dominant cultural force. The film, by Jody Shapiro, seems so hagiographic that when it finally gets around to its 20 minutes worth of interesting stuff, youre not sure whether to trust it.

title: Saudi Arabia: Camels and Livestock Are to Be Tested for Traces of a Virus
description: The authorities in Saudi Arabia, alarmed over the rising human death toll from the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome coronavirus, said they would start testing the kingdoms entire population of camels and other livestock next week, Saudi newspapers reported Thursday. The Arab News quoted Fahd Balghuneim, the agriculture minister, as saying the tests to determine the extent of infection would be conducted via blood or mucus samples. Saudi Arabia has in the past few days adopted a more aggressive response to the virus, known as MERS, which originated in the country two years ago and has been linked to camels, which spread the virus to humans. On Tuesday, the Health Ministry said a review showed that the death toll was 282, 92 more than reported a day earlier, and it announced that the deputy health minister had been relieved. On Wednesday, in the clearest evidence yet that MERS can be passed directly from camels to humans, research published in The New England Journal of Medicine said genetic sequencing had shown that a Saudi man who died of MERS in November had a strain virtually identical to that in one of the camels in his herd.

title: Events on Long Island for June 8-14, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Tense Search, Chilling Note and an Arrest in Brooklyn Stabbings
description: Around 8 p.m. Wednesday, a man paused at a corner in Ozone Park, Queens, and scrawled letters and symbols on a stop sign:

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 5, 2014
Crossing Borders Through Cinema
description: Filmistaan celebrates the power of cinema to bridge divides, but the mirth doesnt entirely travel in this Bollywood production about an aspiring actor, Sunny (Sharib Hashmi), who is kidnapped by Pakistani militants. While the film mixes genres in the inimitable Bollywood style, that premise, at least, is played for laughs.

title: Bringing Blood to the Neighborhood
description: In the 1980s, Hong Kong cinema came up with its own version of a comic monster movie. It was no Ghostbusters, but Mr. Vampire, mixing traditional Chinese folk tales of hopping vampires with action and humor, proved successful, spawning numerous sequels.

title: Witness Says Senator Was Marginalized
description: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y.  Malcolm A. Smith was feeling marginalized, as his State Senate colleague put it at his bribery and wire fraud trial on Thursday.

title: Rushing Headlong Into the Hurly-Burly
description: Hearts beat fast in the thrilling new Macbeth that has transformed the Park Avenue Armory into a war zone, and every breath starts to feel like a gasp. Rob Ashford and Kenneth Branaghs galloping British-born production, which opened on Thursday night with Mr. Branagh in the title role, saturates everyone in it in adrenaline. Make that everyone watching it, as well.

title: Language Originally Known As Mocha
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Every now and then, people write to me asking for advice on constructing and, although I sadly no longer have time to actually collaborate with constructors, I always enjoy discussing the aspects of construction. Once in a while, among those who write to me, there emerges a truly nice person with charmingly good manners, who is not only smart but loves the process of learning and furthermore, puts it to good use.

title: Astros End Trend By Selecting Pitcher Out of High School
description: SECAUCUS, N.J.  In 1991, the Yankees selected Brien Taylor, a high school left-hander, with the first overall pick in baseballs amateur draft. His failure to make the majors scared teams away from showing similar faith in a prep pitcher in the 22 drafts that followed.

title: A Culture of Child Rape in Liberia
description: Looking for a villain in Jessica Vales documentary? Theres competition. Obviously, in Small Small Thing: The Olivia Zinnah Story, about a 7-year-old rape victim in Liberia, there is the man who attacked her so brutally that her genitals were mangled and covered in scar tissue. He was a 20-year-old cousin. She was left with a fistula requiring numerous surgeries to repair, if it could be fixed at all.

title: Navy Pilots Under the Gun
description: At last its come along: the Reefer Madness of gay rights. In D M W Greers supposed drama Burning Blue, a military official worries aloud that if man-on-man sex among its fighter pilots is not punished severely, the Navy could be perceived as being run by a perverse cult.

title: What Experts Say About the Belmont Stakes
description: Some respected veterans of the horse racing world were asked to assess Saturdays Belmont Stakes, in which California Chrome could end the sports Triple Crown drought. Some quotations have been condensed.

title: Shaken, G.I.s Hometown Waits for All the Facts
description: HAILEY, Idaho  From the time of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahls capture five years ago, Zaneys River Street Coffee House has been ground zero for information about and support for the soldier and his family.

title: Hes Just Like Her Ex-Boyfriend, Down to the Tattoo
description: Alfred Hitchcock disliked whodunits; he felt viewers became too bound up in guessing the solution. That principle holds true for the director Jane Weinstocks The Moment, a psychological thriller that shrouds its mysteries in layers of hallucination and unreliable narration.

title: A Journey for the Soles and the Soul
description: The Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela in Spain, where, legend holds, the Apostle James is buried, has drawn pilgrims since the Middle Ages. So its not as if the most popular Camino de Santiago, the 500-mile Camino Francs, which starts at St.-Jean-Pied-de-Port in the Pyrenees, needs any publicity. Still, The Way, Emilio Estevezs 2011 film about four modern-day hikers  one played by his father, Martin Sheen  introduced many to the trek and its meditative pleasures.

title: Debating the Possibility of Winning by a Nose Patch
description: California Chromes owners would be ecstatic if a nose  and perhaps a nasal strip  makes the difference in the one-and-a-half-mile Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

title: What Ive Been Watching
description: Now it can be told: All of the recent Times columnist forays into interactivity and transparency the reader Q&As, the reading lists have been building up to this weeks launch of our new Op-Ed app, which offers readers an all-access pass to the high-stakes, occasionallydrug-fueled world of Times opinion journalism.

title: Wars Elite Tough Guys, Hesitant to Seek Healing
description: After his fourth combat tour, to Afghanistan in 2011, Sgt. First Class Michael B. Lube, a proud member of the Army Special Forces, came home alienated and angry. Once a rock-solid sergeant and devoted husband, he became sullen, took to drinking, got in trouble with his commanders and started beating his wife.

title: Cracking Down on Illegal Mortgage Referrals
description: A federal agency is aggressively going after mortgage, title and real estate companies that it believes are violating laws prohibiting payments or incentives for customer referrals.

title: On the Road, and on the Run
description: The first stage of Italian neorealism documented wartime destruction and endemic poverty; the second, rosier stage added a touch of fantasy; the third recorded the spiritual emptiness of Italys economic miracle. Dino Risis Il Sorpasso (1962), originally released in the United States as The Easy Life and newly out from Criterion in a dual-format edition, is of that third stage.

title: Billionaire Issues Statement About Times Article
description: The billionaire Chinese financier Xiao Jianhua, the subject of a New York Times profile on Wednesday, said he did not make money through his political connections but by following Warren Buffetts value investing strategy.

title: Rangers Put Aside Turnover That Led to Overtime Loss in Game 1
description: LOS ANGELES  The Rangers said they had no concerns about Dan Girardi, whose turnover led to Justin Williamss overtime goal in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals.

title: Surrounded by Nature
description: A petite and picturesque Upper West Side penthouse, with a lush wraparound terrace that replicates the Old World charm of a European garden yet provides forever views of Central Park and the evolving cityscape to the south, is poised to enter the market at $3.995 million. The monthly maintenance for the light-filled two-bedroom two-bath unit, PHC, is $3,468.

title: Global Times Editor Apologizes to Chinese Veterans Over Online Post
description: The editor of a prominent Chinese newspaper has apologized after saying in a tweet suggesting that some soldiers in Chinas 1979 war with Vietnam shirked participation in dare-to-die squads that carried out risky, suicidal missions.

title: N.I.H. Seeks $4.5 Billion to Try to Crack the Code of How Brains Function
description: The National Institutes of Health set an ambitious $4.5 billion price tag on its part of President Obamas Brain Initiative on Thursday, stamping it as an effort on the scale of the Human Genome Project.

title: Lowly Cubs Sweep as Mets Fill Bases but Dont Clear Them
description: CHICAGO  With the crack of Anthony Rizzos bat, there was no doubting what would happen next. No doubt the ball would land in the bleachers in right-center field to put the Chicago Cubs ahead. No doubt the Mets would strand base runners with the game still in reach. And no doubt that the crowd would sing Go, Cubs, Go, the teams anthem.

title: He Was a Different Person
description: Susan Ullman has worked for better support services for Special Operations troops after her husband, a sergeant in the Army Special Forces, committed suicide.

title: Breaking Down a Bid for History at the Belmont Stakes
description: The horses for the 146th running of the Belmont Stakes are listed in order of post position with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Both have also selected their win-place-show horses for the Belmont, which will be run at 6:52 p.m. Saturday, and both are picking California Chrome to become the first Triple Crown winner since 1978. The morning-line odds were set by Eric Donovan of Belmont Park. (The trainers are pictured.)

title: My Travels With Brazils World Cup Curse
description: An animated storybook by the magazines contributing illustrator, Christoph Niemann, about a World Cup game from 64 years ago that still haunts Brazil.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 6, 2014
description: We broke these guys. We need to do our best to send them back into the civilian sector as whole as possible.

title: The Workout | Becoming Rocky Balboa
description: Andy Karl plays Rocky Balboa in the Broadway adaptation of Rocky. He shares some of the strength- training moves he uses to stay in shape for the shows workout montages and fight scenes.

title: Tavi Forever
description: From tween blogger to feminist editrix to Broadway actor, Tavi Gevinson is embarking on her next project: being a grown-up.

title: The Workout: Becoming Rocky Balboa
description: Not many Broadway stars have to dodge punches on stage. But for Andy Karl, it is all in a nights work.

title: Word of the Day | franchise
description: franchise \fran-chiz\ noun and verb

title: Openness on Israeli Issues Seen in Survey of Iranians
description: JERUSALEM  An unusual survey of Iranian public opinion indicates that 40 percent of Iranians would be willing to give up any ability to produce nuclear weapons in the future in return for the full removal of sanctions.

title: Girls Night Out With Jamaican Spice
description: There is no Lily at Miss Lilys 7A, a hyper-stylized Jamaican restaurant that opened by Tompkins Square Park last month, namesake of a place on Houston Street. What there is is an exuberantly clashing Caribbean color scheme, some retro reggae album covers, bottled jerk sauces and waitresses in short shorts.

title: In Thailand, Growing Intolerance for Dissent Drives Many to More Authoritarian Nations
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  Thailand, long the liberal bastion of Southeast Asia, has traditionally been a haven for refugees from its less democratic neighbors. Now, in the wake of a recent coup, a small group of Thai intellectuals are making the reverse journey  heading to Cambodia and other more repressive nations as their own country cracks down on dissent.

title: As in Past, Underdog Goal Is to Exploit Divisive Party
description: With a ticket led by State Senators Wendy Davis of Fort Worth and Leticia Van de Putte of San Antonio, Democrats are hoping to break a political drought that has lasted since 1998, the last time a member of their party held statewide office.

title: Facing the Law, but Running to Uphold It
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Halfway Houses Meet Fraction of Demand for Former Inmates
description: When Terry Pelz, a former warden with the Texas Department of Criminal Justice, testified against a prison gang leader, Mark Fronckiewicz, in the 1993 capital murder trial of a fellow inmate, he had choice words.

title: North Korea Detains 3rd American in New Threat to Relations With U.S.
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A municipal worker from Ohio on a tour of North Korea has been detained there for unspecified illegal acts, making him the third American known to be currently held in the isolated country and threatening to further aggravate its tense relationship with the United States.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Whats On Friday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) FRIDAY NIGHT SPOTLIGHT: PIRATE PICTURES The comedian Greg Proops takes his humor to the high seas as host of this monthlong festival, which begins with Frank Lloyds silent version of The Sea Hawk (1924), about a British noble (Milton Sills) sold into slavery who escapes and turns himself into a pirate king. Henry Kings The Black Swan (1942), starring Tyrone Power as a swashbuckler intent on cleaning up the Caribbean after hes named governor of Jamaica, follows at 10:15; Frank Borzages The Spanish Main (1945), in which a Dutch ships captain (Paul Henreid) turns Caribbean pirate and kidnaps the future bride (Maureen OHara) of a corrupt Spanish governor (Walter Slezak), at midnight; Felix Feists Pirates of Tripoli (1955), with Henreid as a buccaneer trying to help a deposed Arab princess (Patricia Medina) reclaim her throne, at 2 a.m.; Sidney Salkows The Golden Hawk (1952), with Rhonda Fleming and Sterling Hayden as pirates who join forces against yet another corrupt Caribbean governor, at 3:30; and Lew Landerss Hurricane Island (1951), about a captain (Jon Hall) searching for the fountain of youth alongside Ponce de Len (Edgar Barrier), at 5.

title: Suspect Arrested in Killing of Three Mounties in New Brunswick
description: OTTAWA  A man suspected of fatally shooting three Canadian Mounties and wounding two others, putting a Canadian city under a virtual siege, was arrested early Friday, the police said.

title: George J. Armelagos, Anthropologist Who Told Skeletons Tales, Dies at 77
description: George J. Armelagos was a reader of bones.

title: A Modern-Day Knight Who Helped Fleeing Tiananmen Activists
description: HONG KONG  WHEN tens of thousands of people gathered in Hong Kong this week to mourn the military carnage against protesters in Beijing 25 years ago, Chan Tat Ching stood among them, holding a candle and bowing to honor the dead.

title: A Solution to Horse Racings Medication Problems
description: On-track pharmacies have the potential to restore racing integrity in America.

title: Events in Westchester for June 8-14, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Corrections: June 6, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Events in Connecticut for June 8-14, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Bear Rescue Plan Delayed by Permit Problems
description: When a group of international animal welfare advocates reached an agreement with a Chinese bear bile farm in April to turn it into a sanctuary, they planned to transport 28 of the sickest animals to their rescue center for treatment. That plan has hit a snag because it is taking longer than expected to obtain a government permit for the bear transfer.

title: Journalist Detained in Shenzhen Said to Be American
description: A journalist based in Hong Kong who was arrested last week by the Chinese police is an American citizen, people close to the case said Friday.

title: In Vietnam, Paying Communities to Preserve the Forests
description: KALKILL, Vietnam  Before the patrollers spotted the interlopers, they heard the sounds of illegal logging.

title: Test Yourself | Editing, June 6, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | Young Love, Complicated by Cancer
description: In Young Love, Complicated by Cancer, A. O. Scott reviews the film The Fault in Our Stars.

title: Populist Party Fails to Capture Seat in British Parliament
description: LONDON  Despite momentum from a surprisingly strong showing in recent European elections, the populist right-wing United Kingdom Independence Party failed to win its first seat in the British Parliament when it finished second to the Conservative candidate in a special election, according to results announced Friday.

title: What Was Your Favorite Field Trip?
description: Have you ever taken a field trip that broadened your horizons  or taught you something that you would have never learned from a textbook? Perhaps you visited a Buddhist temple, a butterfly conservatory or a historic cemetery? Or maybe you just took a class trip that was really fun?

title: Horse Racing Fades in Italy
description: The immaculate racetracks of Naples loomed like coliseums in the mind of Marco Casino.

title: British Video Game Retailer Raises $203.4 Million in I.P.O.
description: LONDON  Game Digital, the British video game retailer controlled by the hedge fund Elliott Management, said on Friday that it had raised about $203 million in its initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange.

title: On 70th Anniversary, the Memories of D-Day Are Replayed at Normandy
description: VIERVILLE-SUR-MER, France  At Camp Dog Green, recreated just a few miles inland from where combat raged on and around the Normandy beaches in June 1944, soldiers in American uniforms and nurses with the Red Cross insignia on their breast pockets mill among the drab green tents, tuning their tinny radios to the music of Glenn Miller. They appear to be just waiting for orders.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: New York Today: Dont Fear the Mosquitoes
description: Good morning to you on this clearing Friday.

title: Best of Both Worlds? Northeast Cut Emissions and Enjoyed Growth
description: Some critics of the Environmental Protection Agencys new requirements for power plants argue that forcing emissions reduction will curtail economic growth. But the recent experience of states that already cap carbon emissions reveals that emissions and economic growth are no longer tightly tied together.

title: Awkward Diplomacy as Leaders Gather
description: BNOUVILLE, France  As President Obama wrapped up a four-day European trip on Friday, the violent conflict over Ukraine seemed to move toward a new phase of diplomacy, but it remained unclear whether the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, was genuinely willing or able to call off a pro-Russian uprising across his border.

title: Vietnam Says Video Shows Chinese Ship Intentionally Sinking Boat
description: Vietnam has released a video that it says shows a Chinese fishing boat intentionally ramming into a smaller Vietnamese fishing boat, causing it to sink.

title: Suicide Bomb Hits Convoy of an Afghan Candidate
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bombing on Friday struck a convoy of vehicles carrying one of the candidates in Afghanistans presidential runoff election next week. The candidate, Abdullah Abdullah, escaped unharmed, but at least six other people were killed.

title: One More Senior Official Reportedly Kills Himself
description: Depression and suicide reportedly claimed another Chinese government official this week, bringing to at least 15 the number of officials said to have committed suicide in the last 18 months, according to Chinese news media.

title: Daily Report: Changes in Wireless Market May Influence a Sprint Deal
description: In the view of Sprint and T-Mobile USA, less is more, Edward Wyatt reports.

title: Plotting the World Cup Coverage
description: Andrew Das, an assistant sports editor, will fly to Brazil this weekend to prepare coverage of the World Cup soccer tournament, which begins on Thursday. We asked him what readers can expect.

title: Its Not Too Soon to Pay Attention to Senate Polling
description: Just five months until Novembers midterm elections and already early polling results have countered some expectations. In Arkansas, the Democrat Mark Pryor is showing surprising strength in a red state, and in North Carolina, Kay Hagan is trailing as an incumbent in a battleground state. We wont know how accurate polling is until after the election, so for now, the very relevant question is, How much should we care about early polls?

title: Morning Views
description: President Obamas opponents have pounced on the decision to trade five Taliban leaders in exchange for the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl. This is yet another example of the hypocrisy which now pervades the Republican party and the conservative movement, The New York Times editorial board writes. The critics seeking political advantage dont care about the life or mental state of a particular soldier, or of a principle of loyalty that should provide comfort to any soldier in danger of capture. They live only for the attack.

title: Morning Agenda: S.E.C. Takes on High-Speed Trading
description: S.E.C. TAKES ON HIGH-SPEED TRADING | Regulators have been slow to react to changes in the stock market, which in the last decade has evolved into a place dominated by high-speed traders. Now, the Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking to update the markets rules for the new era, DealBooks William Alden writes. On Thursday, Mary Jo White, the chairwoman of the S.E.C., unveiled a sweeping package of recommendations for new rules and other changes geared toward strengthening the structure of the market and improving disclosures for investors.

title: For Some Retirees, a Second Act Is Easier Than Expected
description: NEVER in a million years did Cheryl Delaney expect to spend her retirement working with the elderly. Her entire career had been in the financial sector  as a bank officer and loan administrator, in collections and finally as an office manager at Fidelity Investments in Boston. Changing bedpans was not on her bucket list.

title: Struggling to Understand Slenderman
description: Slenderman, a fictional character said to have inspired two young Wisconsin girls to stab a third, continues to disturb America. Beyond the obviously upsetting nature of the crime, many are asking what  if anything  it says about contemporary society that a figment of the Internets imagination might have driven two children to violence.

title: Soaring Past Low Expectations
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.  Giant, pallid and fleshy, the faces of Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum are plastered all over Los Angeles. On billboards, buildings and buses, their mirrored-sunglasses-wearing selves seem to be promoting their new movie, 22 Jump Street, everywhere.

title: Orange Is the New Black Recap: Season 2 Begins in a More Menacing World
description: Episode 1, Season 2: O.K., so maybe The Litch had started to feel too comfortable, its Secret Santa and movie nights making it seem more Smith College common room than womens minimum-security prison.

title: Singing Nun Wins Italian TV Talent Show
description: ROME  She trilled and thrilled millions of YouTube viewers with songs by Alicia Keys, Cyndi Lauper and Bon Jovi. She belted out a duet with Kylie Minogue, both of them clad in black, albeit with vastly different approaches to style.

title: We Are the World (Cup)
description: PARIS  At dinner recently, one of my 5-year-old twins announced that he intended to learn Croatian.

title: Vodafone Reveals Direct Access by Governments to Customer Data
description: LONDON  A number of governments have the ability to tap directly into the communication network run by the British telecommunications company Vodafone, a level of surveillance that elicited outrage from privacy advocates when the company disclosed it on Friday.

title: Remembering Operation Bluestar on Its 30th Anniversary
description: Thirty years ago, on June 6, 1984, the Indian Army open fired on the Akal Takht, the shrine inside the Golden Temple of Amritsar, one of the holiest sites for Indias Sikh community, in the state of Punjab. Jarnail Singh Bhindranwale, the militant Sikh leader with a popular following in the state, had occupied the temple with armed followers.

title: In Our Pages: June 7
description: 1939: New Yorks Woman of 1939

title: 217,000 Jobs Added, Nudging Payrolls to Levels Before the Crisis
description: After a series of peaks and valleys that confounded optimists and pessimists alike this year, the American economy seems to have settled into a healthy, if not spectacular, pace of job creation.

title: China Will Deport Detained Artist, Australia Says
description: BEIJING  An Australian artist born in China who was detained shortly after publicizing images of a replica of Tiananmen Square he made out of ground pork will be deported from China, Australian officials said on Friday.

title: Subway Hero Rescues Wedding Ring
description: Dear Diary:

title: Whats News in Washington: D-Day Remembrance
description: Good Friday morning from Washington. It has been a week focused on veterans of war and prisoners of war and it concludes with commemorating the beginning of the end of the last World War.

title: In Jobs Report, Two Milestones
description: This mornings jobs report has two important labor market milestones. First, the total number of nonfarm jobs has finally climbed back above its pre-recession level. This comes fully six years and four months after employment last peaked, meaning that it has taken longer to recover from this recession than in any previous post-World War II downturn.

title: Vanishing Into the Role
description: Six years ago, the Australian actor Guy Pearce played an unusual but crucial role in The Hurt Locker, Kathryn Bigelows Academy Award-winning Iraq drama. Appearing at the beginning of the film, Mr. Pearce was a bomb expert who seemed set to be a primary character. As it turned out, his performance was limited to a single scene, but its impact set up the films high-stakes authenticity.

title: On Set | Tavi Gevinson Grows Up
description: Writer, actress and Rookie editor in chief Tavi Gevinson talks coming of age, Kanye and her dream interview subject.

title: Quick Action Kept School Shooting Casualties Down, Police Say
description: SEATTLE  Students at Seattle Pacific University gathered on campus Friday in small prayer circles and at large candlelight vigils to mourn the violence that exploded in a science and engineering building, when a young man walked in with a shotgun on Thursday afternoon. One student was killed and two others were wounded. One of them remained hospitalized Friday in serious condition after hours of surgery.

title: Good News on Jobs. Why Arent We Happier?
description: We did it, America! Six and a half years after the Great Recession began, and five years after it ended, we have now regained all the jobs lost during the downturn. Huzzah!

title: For Miami Heat and Spurs, Hot Arena Plays Big Role in Game 1
description: SAN ANTONIO  As the temperature began to climb inside AT&T Arena Thursday night, the failure of the air-conditioning system seemed to be nothing but an annoyance.

title: Buying a Guaranteed Retirement Income, for Some Peace of Mind
description: Many workers long for the sense of security that only an old-fashioned pension can provide. The big insurers are well aware of this, and thats why many of them are offering new ways for investors to buy and build a pension on their own.

title: Found Poetry Favorite | The Elvish Doings in the Forest
description: This poem, by Libbie, is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest. It comes from a dance review, Theres Brightness When the Fog Clears.

title: A Four-Month Streak of Sturdy Job Growth
description: The United States economy has added more than 200,000 jobs in each of the past four months, the Labor Department reported Friday.

title: Teenagers in The Times | May 2014
description: On the first Friday of every month we publish a collection of articles about teenagers featured in The New York Times.

title: The Politics of the P.O.W. Coverage
description: The story has dominated the headlines for a week  the dramatic swap of an American prisoner of war for five Taliban prisoners.

title: Trying to Go Legit, Despite the In-Laws
description: The first intimation that Power, a new series starting Saturday on Starz, is not about the West Wing or the building of the Hoover Dam comes in the opening credits.

title: Interview With a Torturer
description: LONDON  In 1997, in the newly democratic South Africa, a black female psychologist met a white male convict in Pretoria Central Prison. The psychologist, Pumla Gobodo-Madikizela, had just completed a doctoral fellowship at Harvard and had returned to the country to serve on the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. The man she had asked to meet was Eugene de Kock, a former policeman nicknamed Prime Evil, who had led a covert counterterrorism unit dedicated to the torture and killing of anti-apartheid activists.

title: Private Jobs Have Recovered. Government Jobs Still Lag.
description: The United States economy has finally exceeded its pre-recession employment peak, as many analysts of todays jobs report have noted. But that milestone obscures two very different stories  in the private and public sectors. The public sector  federal, state and local government  still isnt close to returning to its pre-recession employment levels.

title: 5th Batch of Clinton-Era Papers Is Released
description: WASHINGTON  The National Archives unsealed about 2,000 documents from the Clinton administration on Friday, the fifth such release in recent months of memos, transcripts and speeches that had been withheld from public view.

title: Zlatan Ibrahimovic: Im Never Satisfied
description: The Swedish soccer star talks to Wm. Ferguson aboutgrowing upan outsider in Sweden, the motivational power of anger and missing the World Cup  despite being the best.

title: Obama and Putin Meet Briefly Over Ukraine
description: BNOUVILLE, France  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia held private talks with President Obama and with the newly elected leader of Ukraine on Friday as both sides in the violent conflict in Eastern Europe tried to ease a geopolitical showdown that has shaken the post-Cold War order.

title: New Fire Commissioner Returns to a Challenged Department
description: In a room deep inside Fire Department headquarters in Downtown Brooklyn, flat screens line the walls, tracking every fire and emergency medical incident in New York City. The last time Daniel A. Nigro was in this operations hub, before his retirement as chief of department a year after the terrorist attack of Sept. 11, the room had all the technological grandness of a broom closet.

title: The World Cup Hairdo Hall of Fame
description: In his travels throughout Brazil in anticipation of the World Cup, Christoph Niemann, the magazines contributing illustrator, found soccer fever so intense that he couldnt help seeing famous footballers  and their hair  wherever he looked.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Letters: My Accidental Jihad
description: My Accidental Jihad

title: Nazism
description: WHY THE GERMANS? WHY THE JEWS?  Envy, Race Hatred, and the Prehistory of the Holocaust  By Gtz Aly  Metropolitan/Holt, $30.

title: The Top Shelf of Journalism Books
description: This week, David Carr, The Timess Media Equation columnist and a culture reporter, reviews The Invention of News, by Andrew Pettegree. I asked Carr and a few of his colleagues to recommend their favorite books about journalism.

title: Going Native
description: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

title: Fire on the Mountain
description: Michael Koryta is a fearless stylist who has put his hand to ghost stories, historical novels, killer-thrillers, revenge tragedies, morality tales and detective stories. Hes now swinging from the high wire with THOSE WHO WISH ME DEAD (Little, Brown, $26), a heart-thumping backwoods adventure that sends two creatively sadistic killers into Montanas Beartooth Mountains, where they spark a monster forest fire to flush out the only witness to their crimes: Jace Wilson, a 14-year-old boy. Jace was just trying to escape his reputation as class coward when he dived into a quarry near his Indiana home. But when he swam into a dead man  and spotted the killers flinging a second victim into the water  Jace knew he was going to die. Reborn with a new name, he finds himself among the bad kids in a grueling wilderness survival course, parked there when his parents couldnt be persuaded to put him in a traditional witness protection program. Jaces hunters, the Blackwell brothers, are heartless sociopaths whose professional detachment is etched in their unnervingly precise grammar and careful diction. (The way they say things. Like theyre alone in the world. Like it was built for the two of them and theyre lords over it.) There will be no mercy from that quarter.

title: Border Crossings
description: In The Italian System, a wry, knowing story in Francesca Marcianos first collection, The Other Language, the unnamed protagonist is planning a lifestyle guide for Americans. Seven years earlier  a period that evokes the scent of a fairy tale  she had moved to New York from Rome on a whim, having secured a place in a creative writing workshop at the New School. She fell in love with the city and so has never left, despite the fact that this place she adores hasnt exactly opened its arms to welcome her. She found work as a language teacher, initially telling herself this is simply a way to pay the rent. But, as is often the way with the quotidian, teaching became her real job and she forgot about other aspirations. And yet those aspirations dont quite disappear. In the fresh new days of spring, she determines to put together a book, The Italian System, about how to live a Roman life in New York.

title: Acting the Brute
description: We humans often like to trumpet our uniqueness among all the worlds biodiversity. We pride ourselves on our exalted, big-brained status and our resulting separation from everything else we lump together as nature. For Jeffrey Moussaieff Masson, the salient feature of our distinction is neither the power of language nor the potential for extreme acts of creativity nor even an opposable thumb. It is, rather, our singular capacity for violence.

title: Paperback Row
description: NO EASY DAY: The Autobiography of a Navy SEAL  The Firsthand Account of the Mission That Killed Osama bin Laden,  by Mark Owen with Kevin Maurer. (New American Library, $16.) The May 2011 raid on Abbottabad, Pakistan, is the heart of this boots-on-the-ground account, but Owen (a pseudonym for Matt Bissonnette, a former member of the SEALs who served 13 consecutive combat deployments) also details the formation and evolution of one of the militarys most elite units.

title: Editors Choice
description: CANT WE TALK ABOUT SOMETHING MORE PLEASANT?, written and illustrated by Roz Chast. (Bloomsbury, $28.) This scorchingly honest, achingly wistful graphic memoir looks at the last years of Chasts nonagenarian parents.

title: As the World Turns
description: One recent morning, I helped my son search for his misplaced shoes. They were nowhere to be found, so I took a peek under the couch. This was a rash move. The bend and twist required for under-couch viewing set off a wicked spin of dizziness, as I feared it would.

title: B.A.s and I.O.U.s
description: Were having the wrong conversation about higher education in our country. So argues Suzanne Mettler in her provocative new book, Degrees of Inequality, based on the eight years she spent studying a college system that she argues works well for those born into well-off families but few others. Tuition rates of $50,000 or more at private four-year colleges? The trillion-plus dollars Americans collectively owe on college loans? In Mettlers telling, those should be the least of our worries when considering the caste system that is now higher education in the United States.

title: Publish or Perish
description: Lets be honest, no one likes literary wunderkinder. Twenty-eight-year-olds are bad enough. Twenty-eight-year-olds whose first books become blockbusters? Thats just irritating. Joel Dicker, the 28-year-old Swiss author behind The Truth About the Harry Quebert Affair, doesnt even have the decency to write dreck. His darkly comic debut thriller (already a blockbuster in Europe!) is unimpeachably terrific.

title: Talking Talent | An Artists Directorial Debut
description: Andrew Levitas has the Midas touch. The 36-year-old artist, one of only a handful of American painters to ever study at the prestigious Socit Nationale des Beaux-Arts in Paris, had never made a movie before he cast Garrett Hedlund and a whole slew of Oscar darlings (Amy Adams, Jennifer Hudson, Richard Jenkins, Terrence Howard) in his directorial debut, Lullaby. On June 13, his semi-autobiographical film about family and mortality will prove that the New York-based multihyphenate can write and direct the way he paints  with the confidence of a seasoned veteran and the vulnerability of a true artist.

title: Settling Scores
description: Its 1794 in London. In the dark Virginia & Baltick coffeehouse, huddling in the pungent shadow of tallow candles, four rich men are hatching a plan to marry off their daughters. Risen from the underbelly of the city, wheeling and dealing, theyve made their fortunes in cloth, fur and timber. Theyre successful and wealthy, but now they want sons-in-law with titles who will produce grandchildren of a certain kind.

title: Conrad in Vietnam
description: Ward Just is both a writers writer and an astute tracker of human souls under duplicity and duress. He writes incisively, with striking imagery and with deep knowledge of how people in power behave, from ambassadors coping with the worlds hot spots to Midwestern community leaders suppressing a local crime. Like many distinguished novelists, Just was a journalist first, covering Washington, London and Saigon before the release of his first novel in 1970. American Romantic, his 18th, is one of his finest. It has all the qualities Justs regular readers look forward to, yet its an equally good place to be introduced to his work.

title: California Pioneers the Court-Aided One-Day Divorce
description: MARISSA YORK, a real estate broker in Manhattan, used a $50 online do-it-yourself divorce kit when she and her husband of more than nine years decided to part ways. Their breakup was relatively amicable, she said, so she figured they could save money by avoiding lawyers. We didnt want to drag it out over months or years, she said.

title: Bright Young Assistants
description: My Salinger Year, Joanna Rakoffs breezy memoir of being a bright young assistant in the mid-1990s, opens with her decision to leave graduate school, desert her nice college boyfriend and move to New York to write poetry. Almost immediately, she falls for an overbearing aspiring novelist, takes a poorly paid job at a famous literary agency and lands in an unheated apartment in Williamsburg. I wanted to be extraordinary, she admits. Instead, she joins a legion of girls from comfortable backgrounds determined to live uncomfortably, at least briefly, in vague pursuit of Art.

title: Leaders Meet to Honor D-Day
description: President Obama joined President Franois Hollande of France and others for a dinner while in Europe.

title: Young and in Debt in New York City
description: For young people, moving to New York City hasnt made much mathematical sense for decades. The jobs dont pay enough, the internships dont pay at all, and the rents are prohibitive by any sane standard.

title: Jackie Robinson and Nixon: Life and Death of a Political Friendship
description: Here in Yankee Stadiums locker room after Game 5 of the 1952 World Series, Senator Richard Nixon of California, Republican nominee for vice president, congratulates Jackie Robinson on the Brooklyn Dodgers 6-5 win over the Yankees. (The Dodgers ultimately lost in seven games.)

title: Inside the List
description: Spotted: The actress and singer Lea Michele, who plays Rachel Berry on Glee, has a book on the advice, how-to and miscellaneous list: Brunette Ambition, her breezily memoiristic style guide and advice manual for women, is No. 13 in its second week. Among other things, Michele reveals she once tried to cover up an outbreak of acne using a strategy shed seen on TV. It didnt go well: Hilariously, she writes, I thought I had picked up a great concealing trick from Sex and the City, when Carrie uses a black eyeliner to turn a zit into a beauty mark. Brilliant, except my skin was so bad I needed about 16 beauty marks. I went out with my girlfriends with black dots all over my face thinking I had the world fooled. They took one look at me and asked, What . . . did you do to your face?  These days, Michele more often opts for a homemade facial mask and the services of a professional dermatologist to keep her skin clear. She also goes without makeup if possible. Whenever I can, I give my skin a vacation, she says. Its nice to remember what I actually look like.

title: Fashions Embrace of Reality TV
description: The fashion/reality TV love affair is still going strong

title: This Is What a Cursed Soccer Stadium Looks Like
description: The place was built for a coronation, a colossal theater where hundreds of thousands could bear witness and celebrate. When Maracan opened in 1950, in the heart of Rio, it was the worlds largest stadium, the site of what Brazil was certain would be its first World Cup championship. And things started well enough: The host country breezed through to the final match, where, because of tournament rules at the time, it needed only a draw against Uruguay to win the whole event. With little more than 10 minutes to go, the score was 1-1, and the fans were on edge. Then the Uruguayan winger Alcides Ghiggia put them over with a sudden strike. Only three people have, with just one motion, silenced the Maracan, he famously said later. Frank Sinatra, Pope John Paul II and me.

title: Reply All: The 5. 25.14 Issue
description: CAN THE NERVOUS SYSTEM BE HACKED?

title: Who Made That Autocorrect?
description: How fast will new Word 6.0 fix typos? How fast can you make them? asked an advertisement in a computer magazine from October 1993. The newest version of Microsofts word processor came with a brand-new feature called AutoCorrect. Type in SHip teh cartons friday, and the program would correct your text to Ship the cartons Friday.

title: The World Cup Soundtrack
description: The volume rattles the bones. The gyrations evoke scenes of lustful abandon. In some of funks most explicit forms, tracks sprinkled with the prerecorded sounds of machine-gun fire exalt the drug gangs still in control of some of Rio de Janeiros favelas. On certain nights, the bass from the amps resonates from the hillside slums into the bastions of the privileged classes, as if to remind them: Rio doesnt belong just to you.

title: Sleep Now, Die Later
description: The perils of napping; Clay Aiken vs. Henry Clay.

title: Help! Ive Fallen, and I Dont Want Help
description: I was on the subway when another passenger passed out. The train made an emergency stop, and medical responders assisted the person, despite her screaming  after she came to  that she wanted to be left alone. If the woman was saying she did not want to be helped, even if in critical condition, is someone ethically allowed to obey her and let her suffer? Or would it be a crime to let her suffering continue? ELISABETH BUCHWALD, SCARSDALE, N.Y.

title: Where the View Gets a Standing Ovation
description: Ive got to be where my spirit can run free, sings the lost-soul title character in the hit Broadway revival of Pippin. Got to find my corner of the sky.

title: Pakistan Suspends License of Leading News Channel
description: LONDON  The Pakistani government on Friday suspended the broadcasting license of Geo News, a popular television channel, in a major escalation of Geos dispute with the countrys powerful Inter-Services Intelligence spy agency.

title: Today in Small Business: Why Burt Was Ousted
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Former Investment Banker Joins Vatican Financial Watchdog
description: The Vatican has turned to a European banker to help oversee its financial watchdog.

title: Give Kids Your Undivided Attention  or No Attention At All
description: Here is what I wish Id known, from 14-some years into this parenting gig: Leave the children alone when you must and then really be with them when you can. Or, to put it slightly differently: Alternate fully engaging with fully ignoring them. There is, of course, an implied instead of here  instead of half paying attention to them all the time (cough smartphone cough).

title: Thoughts on Dark Pools and Michael Lewis
description: The new Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into high frequency trading and so-called dark pools  as announced yesterday by Chairwoman Mary Jo White is long overdue. As speed has become the most important factor in getting the absolute best price, high-frequency traders have gained advantages over other investors that are undeniable. Some of these firms almost never have down days anymore. More and more, the average investor has to feel that the game is rigged.

title: Not Just an Easy Commute
description: Midtown East does not usually make an apartment hunters shortlist.

title: Dj View
description: Vaux Le Vicomte, a quieter but equally majestic alternative to Versailles, has undergone a simple yet spectacular restoration. The wooden doors blocking the view through the north and south arcades of the chateau have been removed, reinstating the original transparency between the interiors and the grounds proposed in the 17th century by the architect Louis Le Vau and the royal gardener Andr Le Ntre. vaux-le-vicomte.com

title: Summer Reads, Courtesy of JPMorgan
description: JPMorgan Chase provides advice to clients across the globe on complex financial matters.

title: Video Reviews of The Fault in Our Stars, Edge of Tomorrow and Obvious Child
description: In this video, Times critics offer their thoughts on Obvious Child, The Fault in Our Stars and Edge of Tomorrow. Read all of this weeks reviews.

title: Gone With Barely a Trace
description: The flamboyantly decorated Windsor Arcade of 1901, on Fifth Avenue from 46th to 47th Street, spread a layer of Beaux-Arts frosting over the site of a gruesome hotel fire, and presents a cautionary tale for anyone wrestling with memory and monuments.

title: Biking Just Beyond the Big City
description: As passionate cyclists and campers, Bronx residents Lukas Herbert and Laura Willis have introduced friends to their avocation and hope to see their fellow city riders discover the joys of multiple-day bicycle touring. But they know an impediment exists.

title: The Invasion of Europe From the West Has Begun
description: PARIS  As 160,000 Allied soldiers began to swarm the Normandy beaches on June 6, 1944, an ocean away New York Times editors scrambled to put out a special 6 a.m. edition heralding a seminal moment of World War II.

title: For Missing Major Crown, Djokovic Must Dethrone a Dominant King
description: PARIS  Novak Djokovic knows that the road to his first French Open title goes through Rafael Nadal. It is a road he has not crossed before, but one he knows he can cross.

title: Family-Friendly Tax Reform and The Poor
description: Having promised them some time ago, before a week of travel left me behind on blog posts, I hope to have responses up next week to some of the recent macro-level liberal takes on reform conservatism from E.J. Dionne,William Galston, and my colleague Tom Edsall, among others.

title: World Leaders Honor D-Day Anniversary
description: President Franois Hollande of France and President Obama spoke to veterans at the Normandy American Cemetery at Omaha Beach on the 70th anniversary of the D-Day landing.

title: D-Days Wheels Roll Again
description: TRHAM, FRANCE  Like many families spending part of this summer on the road, Kevin and Brenda Goodwin of Felixstowe, England, are taking their holiday in a big R.V. with two beds, a kitchen, a bathroom with a shower and a pair of bicycles lashed to the front.

title: Saudi Arabia and Iran Reach Out Tentatively
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The fevered struggle between Saudi Arabia and Iran for regional dominance has for years aggravated nearly every conflict across the Middle East as the two nations armed, funded and encouraged each others adversaries.

title: Feeling Old on the Internet
description: Would you like to know how many times the moon has orbited the earth since you were born  or, more soberingly, what percentage of people born on the same day as you have died? Now you can find out this information, along with a great many more depressing facts about your senescence, at the website Youre Getting Old.

title: Ronaldo, Neymar and Iniesta in (Superslow) Motion
description: How three World Cup stars do what they do best.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Invention of News
description: This week, David Carr discusses Andrew Pettegrees The Invention of News; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the weeks literary news; Molly Worthen talks about new books by and about Jimmy Carter; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Wheelies: The Z06 Power Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Bergdahl Missteps
description: The right-wing backlash to the prisoner exchange that freed Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl is unseemly, to put it politely, as we said on our editorial page this morning  a jumble of hypocritical flip-flops and hyperbolic statements based on no evident facts, with a nice thick coating of politicizing and propagandizing.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Invention of News
description: This week, David Carr and Molly Worthen.

title: Like Smoldering Sparks, Wars Ephemera
description: As autographed pictures go, there may be none so damning as the one that David Lloyd George, Britains prime minister during the latter part of World War I, inscribed on Dec. 1, 1933: To Chancellor Hitler, with admiration for his brilliant gift of courage.

title: Shares of Arista Networks Surge in Debut
description: Updated, 5:20 p.m. |

title: Throw FIFA Out of the Game
description: WASHINGTON  MOST people associate FIFA, the organization that oversees international soccer, with the quadrennial joy of the World Cup. But as the 2014 tournament begins next week in Brazil, FIFA is plagued by levels of corruption, graft and excess that would shame Silvio Berlusconi.

title: You Dont Have to Hate Your Job
description: It was a collective howl of powerlessness, despair, cynicism and rage:

title: Outkast Returns
description: With Outkast is coming to New York this weekend to perform at the Governors Ball festival, Ben Ratliff and Rachel Kaadzi Ghansah discuss the duo and its legacy.

title: Bergdahl and Our Distance from the Battlefield
description: I have a big, big problem with many of the people who so quickly judge the actions of Bowe Bergdahl, and I have a big, big problem with many of those who jump in to say how the soldiers around him should or shouldnt feel and how our armed forces should or shouldnt behave.

title: Egypts Election: A View From Cairo
For Another Kind of Platform
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is expanding wireless coverage in stations across New York, but for now theres still a good chance of getting caught on a platform with nothing new to read or see on your phone. If you find that possibility horrifying, you might consider downloading Tunnel Vision, an app that turns the subway map into a fount of information about both New York and the subway system itself.

title: Driven | 2014 Subaru XV Crosstrek Hybrid
description: Subaru adds a hybrid, but not many M.P.G.s.

title: For de Blasio, Deals, Drama and (Maybe) Progress
description: If you have been in or around Downtown Brooklyn in recent days, you may have found yourself noticing a darkened haze in the color of the local mood ring. On Tuesday, activists gathered in Borough Hall to grieve over the fate of Long Island College Hospital, which is to be converted into a condominium site with some sort of health care facility, though it is uncertain how much of one. The hospital effectively closed last month, leaving residents in surrounding areas worried about curtailed services, in particular the prospect of waiting a dangerously long time for an ambulance. On May 31, a man in Red Hook did die after what was reported to be a long wait, and though it was unclear whether a direct connection existed, the episode served as a dramatic confirmation of the communitys apprehension.

title: Classical Playlist: John Adams, Handel, Lewis Spratlan and More
