description: LEWIS SPRATLAN: Apollo and Daphne Variations; other worksBoston Modern Orchestra Project, Gil Rose, conductorEliot Gattegno, on soprano and alto saxophones(BMOP/Sound)The American composer Lewis Spratlan, born in 1940, gained wide attention in 2000 when a concert version of Act II of his opera Life Is a Dream, which was completed in 1978 but had never been staged, won the Pulitzer Prize for Music. This welcome new recording from the impressive Boston Modern Orchestra Project offers three ingeniously written and distinctive Spratlan works. A Summers Day (2008) uses a simple, dreamy Celtic tune at the start as a jumping-off place for an elusive, complex suite that ruminates on the tensions below the surface of an inviting day. In his Concerto for Saxophone and Orchestra (2006), Mr. Spratlan finds a gripping, fresh approach to what might seem an awkward classical music genre; the music evolves from mystical musings to raw, jazzy vehemence. Apollo and Daphne Variations is like a Spratlan version of a Schumann suite, with alternating episodes of whimsy, frenzy and innocence. (Anthony Tommasini)

title: Image of the Day: June 6
Lamb, Slow-Roasted the Moroccan Way, Without the Barbecue Spit
description: Though some of us grill outdoors all year long, summer is the usual time for playing with fire.

title: Video: The Subaru XV Crosstrek Hybrid Wont Save Much Green
description: Subaru and Prius owners are fiercely loyal to their rides. Subie drivers (who often dwell in polar vortex regions) pledge their allegiance to the Symmetrical All-Wheel Drive flag. The evangelical hybrid camp is more obsessed with fuel economy than getting places quickly. Conversely, its unwise to off-road a Prius, and the only way to guarantee lofty m.p.g.s in a Subaru is coasting from a mountain summit.

title: A Shift in Locale, but Still Hearty Italian
description: Francescas Italian Bistro, to the delight of its ardent fans, has relocated from its former strip-mall quarters to the quaint center of Coventry. The restaurant, while bigger, is still cozy: a dozen tables with a view into the kitchen, where gusts of flame kick up as Salvatore Urso deglazes a pan.

title: Outkast Returns: What Does It Mean and Why Should We Care?
description: To begin a sentence saying Outkast is . . . constitutes a philosophical impossibility.

title: Movie Review: Obvious Child
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews Obvious Child.

title: Movie Review: The Fault in Our Stars
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews The Fault in Our Stars.

title: Movie Review: Edge of Tomorrow
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Edge of Tomorrow.

title: Weekend Autos Calendar: Steve McQueen Cool Comes to California
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: Liquidnet, a Dark Pool Operator, Is Fined $2 Million Over Customer Data
description: Liquidnet Holdings, a brokerage firm that operates a secretive trading venue, has agreed to pay a $2 million fine to settle accusations that it improperly used confidential information about its customers in marketing a new product, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Friday.

title: A Two-in-One Tower
description: While a team approach to real estate development is not unusual, a new residential project near Madison Square Park is putting a different spin on the concept. Instead of a single high-rise created by multiple partners, the building is essentially split in half between two partners.

title: U.S. and European Job Markets Take Different Paths
description: MORE than five years after the collapse of Lehman Brothers in September intensified a credit crisis, the labor market in the United States has almost recovered  at least as measured by the number of unemployed people. But in most of Europe, the number of jobless workers remains substantially higher than it was then.

title: Uber Attains Eye-Popping New Levels of Funding
description: Updated, 8:40 p.m. | Only a few months ago, Silicon Valley start-ups were celebrated for drawing investors into paying for multibillion-dollar valuations.

title: Book Review Podcast: The Invention of News
description: In The New York Times Book Review, David Carr reviews Andrew Pettegrees The Invention of News: How the World Came to Know About Itself. Mr. Carr writes:

title: Happenings | The Beloved Bangkok Eatery Bo.Lan Pops Up in New York
description: So many pop-ups happen solely for marketing purposes these days that its refreshing to find one that reflects the original intent behind the concept: fleeting, spontaneous pleasure. This weekend, New Yorkers can rejoice in the news that, apropos of nothing, one of Bangkoks most beloved eateries, Bo.Lan, is operating an outpost in a massive, tumbledown art studio opposite the UPS hangar on Greenwich Street. On Saturday and Sunday, the wife-and-husband chef duo of Bo Songvisava and Dylan Jones (their restaurants moniker is a Kimyeification of their names) will dish up a tasting menu of regional Thai specialties for an intimate group of strangers.

title: Cooking With Nuts and Seeds
description: For years, nutritionists have been urging us to eat nuts in place of high-carb and sugary snacks. Regulators allow purveyors of peanuts, almonds, walnuts, pistachios, hazelnuts and pecans to make claims that these nuts, as part of a diet low in saturated fats and cholesterol, may help reduce the risk of heart disease.

title: So You Want to Watch a Weepie
description: Are you looking for a little bring-me-down? Have you been distraught by reports of Netflix shutdowns in the middle of the night, just when the new season of Orange Is the New Black became available? Has someone shamed you for reading young-adult literature?

title: Whos Listening to that Vodafone Call?
description: Since Edward Snowdens revelations, many Internet and telecommunications firms have begun telling the world more about the kind and quantity of private information public agencies seek and get from thema small step toward peeling back the shroud of secrecy over government surveillance.

title: A Preview of the Belmont Stakes
description: If California Chrome wins the Belmont Stakes, he will become the first horse to win the Triple Crown since 1978.

title: Hundreds Gather to Remember 6-Year-Old Victim of Brooklyn Stabbing
description: On an implacably sunny morning in eastern Brooklyn, hundreds of people mourned a death much too young and much too abhorrent.

title: Taking a Spin: What if the Democrats Won in Appalachia?
description: This weeks spin of the Upshot Senate wheels yields a result that is at once timely and strangely anachronistic: The Democrats retain control of the Senate, by the margin of upset victories in Appalachia.

title: Nigerian Television Becomes Front for U.S. in Terrorism Fight
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department is financing a new 24-hour satellite television channel in the turbulent northern region of Nigeria that American officials say is crucial to countering the extremism of radical groups such as Boko Haram. The move signals a ramping up of American counterinsurgency efforts to directly challenge the terrorist group, which abducted nearly 300 Nigerian schoolgirls in April.

title: Speaking of Commencement
description: Looking out at all of you today, in your floppy caps and ill-fitting gowns, Im pleased to see how prepared you are for this momentous occasion.

title: Promoting Citys Spirit, de Blasio Aims to Bring Democratic Convention to Brooklyn
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio does not think there are enough Democrats in Brooklyn.

title: Changing the Way Tony Awards Are Picked
Soccer Stars Neymar and Iniesta on Set
description: A behind-the-scenes look at the video and photo shoot with Neymar da Silva Santos Jr. and Andrs Iniesta for the World Cup issue of The New York Times Magazine.

title: Bens Music Box
description: Ben plays his music box.

title: Ghostbusters, Forrest Gump and A Hard Days Night to Return to Theaters
description: Everything old is new again  or at least, with some technological tweaking, it can seem that way. Three films, Forrest Gump, Ghostbusters and A Hard Days Night  each celebrating an anniversary  are getting big-screen re-releases this summer. Ghostbusters and A Hard Days Night are also getting deluxe Blu-ray DVD reissues.

title: Gays in the Military 1993-1999
description: Just a week into Bill Clintons presidency, his national security team was forced to confront whether service members should be discharged for coming out as gay.

title: Beastie Boys Win $1.7 Million in Suit Over Unauthorized Use of Music
description: The Beastie Boys have prevailed once again in a legal fight to prevent the unauthorized use of the bands music, this time winning a $1.7 million judgment against the Monster Beverage Corporation, Reuters reported.

title: New York City Bids for the 2016 Democratic National Convention
description: A June 5 letter from Mayor Bill de Blasio to the chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee.

title: A Vegan Restaurant That Isnt About Denial
description: Vegans refrain from fun foods like butter or bacon but they can drink, which may be why Goldies, a new vegan restaurant in Asbury Park, has a stunning, cocktail-friendly chefs bar, sculpted by a local craftsman to resemble a long, undulating wave.

title: Horse Racings Dark Side
description: Sports columnist William C. Rhoden questions if the horse racing industry deserves a Triple Crown winner.

title: A Risk-Takers Game: Insider Trading
description: Its probably safe to say that Phil Mickelson didnt offer a fist bump or a tournament ball, as he often does for fans, when two F.B.I. agents confronted him outside the locker room at Muirfield Village Golf Club in Dublin, Ohio, last month.

title: What a Soccer Deal Says About Alibaba
description: Jack Mas decision to buy half of Chinas most popular soccer club has done prospective investors in Alibaba a favor.

title: Survivor of Attack on Jewish Museum in Brussels Dies
description: PARIS  The sole surviving victim of the shooting last month at the Jewish Museum in Brussels died in a hospital on Friday, said Eric Van der Sypt, the spokesman for Belgiums federal prosecutors office, raising the final death toll in the attack to four.

title: Video: Horse Racings Dark Side
description: If California Chrome wins the Belmont Stakes, he will become the first horse to win the Triple Crown since 1978.

title: Risking a Leg, Instead of Seeing a Doctor
description: Is healthcare a human right?

title: Highlights of the Singing Nun
description: Known worldwide as the singing nun, Sister Cristina Scuccia won the second edition of The Voice of Italy on Thursday. Here are some highlights of her run.

title: A Ride Across America | An Unlikely Hotbed of Food Activism in Small-Town Virginia
description: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, theyll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

title: Aftermath of Blast Near Afghan Candidate
description: Two bombs exploded in Kabul, striking a caravan carrying Abdullah Abdullah, an Afghan presidential candidate. The blast killed six people, but left Mr. Abdullah unharmed.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 6
description: The 2014 World Cup begins Thursday, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: A Toast to Mudslinging: This Drinks for Mississippi
description: No two ways about it: The race for the Mississippi Senate seat long held by Thad Cochran is ugly. A supporter of his challenger, Chris McDaniel, faces charges for breaking into a nursing home and photographing Mr. Cochrans wife, who is being treated for dementia. The bitter primary race was so close on Tuesday that it is now heading to a runoff election June 24.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: California Chromes Crew
description: California Chrome, a shiny chestnut colt with a signature white blaze, has won six consecutive races, including the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes, by a combined 27 1/2 lengths.

title: Youths Facing Deportation to Be Given Legal Counsel
description: The Obama administration said Friday that it was starting a program to provide lawyers for children facing deportation as it scrambles to deal with the soaring number of unaccompanied minors illegally crossing the border from Mexico.

title: Walmarts New C.E.O. Stresses Technology to Improve Customer Service
description: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark.  Harry Connick Jr., Pharrell Williams, Robin Thicke and Sarah McLachlan all put on a show here Friday at the annual shareholders meeting of Walmart Stores.

title: Fear of Equities Drives More Investors to Cash
description: IF a lot of your portfolio is still sitting in cash after a five-year bull market in equities, youre not alone. Investors at all wealth levels around the world are holding substantial amounts of cash that have increased since 2012. What this means for investors and the markets that depend on their money is intriguing.

title: Bill Cunningham | A-twirl
description: A preview of summer dressing: hula-hoop-size hats with long or short dresses or with shorts, and dashing men.

title: The N.R.A.s Tea Party Moment
description: Has the National Rifle Association spawned a movement it cant control, more radical than the radicals and ultimately self-destructive?

title: Bill Cunningham | A-twirl
description: Like a rainbow-colored tornado, a woman on Eighth Avenue was spinning what appeared to be 45 hula hoops. On Wednesday, family night at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, hula hoops were revived for the kindergarten set. Last Saturday, more than 5,000 picnickers boarded ferries at Battery Park for the Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic held at Liberty State Park. It was a preview of summer dressing: hula-hoop-size hats with long or short dresses or with shorts, and dashing men.

title: Move Over, Penguins, Marathon Coming Through
description: At the tail end of the most bone-chilling winter in recent years, I left New York for Antarctica, the coldest and driest place on earth, where the sun never completely sets.

title: Lost in Time in Englands Northeast
description: My gateway drug to serious Anglophilia was horses  the British Pony Club Manual of Horsemanship, my English saddle made by Barnsby  but the addiction was truly about words. What, for example, could Hounds, gentlemen, please possibly mean? This was a sign along the roadside near the stable where we kept my horse outside St. Louis. I turned it over in my mind for months before I understood that drivers were being asked to slow down if foxhounds were in the vicinity.

title: In Argentina, Wine, Art and Altitude
description: Our friends love modern art but dont really drink; my companion and I are closer to the reverse. So as we researched places where we could travel and all come away happy, Colom, in northwest Argentina, stood out. Its a mountain winery with a contemporary art museum and sounded like the perfect two-couple compromise  a little bit high culture, a little bit grand cru.

title: A Starter Kit for Military Collectors
description: To the Army, it was known simply as the G503 or the quarter-ton, but to millions of soldiers it quickly became the jeep, a coinage generally linked to a character from the Popeye cartoon strip, Eugene the Jeep. Today, wartime jeeps are ubiquitous at military vehicle shows, and they are starting point for most people getting into the collecting hobby.

title: Austrian Journalist Convicted in Holocaust Restitution Case Vows to Appeal
description: PARIS  Stephan Templ, an Austrian journalist convicted of defrauding the Austrian state of about $748,000 in a Holocaust restitution case, vowed Friday to appeal to the European Court for Human Rights in Strasbourg, France, after a high court in Vienna sentenced him to one year in prison and two years of probation.

title: Extravagant Wedding Cakes Rise Again
description: Reports of the demise of the wedding cake have been exaggerated.

title: Obama Aide Defends Remarks on Bergdahls Honor
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, found herself in a familiar predicament this week: under fire from Republicans for statements she made about a murky sequence of events involving Americans in a distant land.

title: I Was Promised Flying Cars
description: AS an astronomy-obsessed kid in the 1970s, I subsisted on a steady diet of science fiction. It promised a future filled with technological wonders: talking computers, bionic limbs, flying cars. Forty years later, though much of that future has arrived, its still missing what I consider its most important ingredient. Sure, weve got the iPhones Siri, and the Food and Drug Administration just approved a prosthetic arm controlled by signals from the brain  but where are our smooth-gliding flying machines, our Landspeeders (Star Wars) and airborne DeLoreans (Back to the Future)?

title: A Player Who Is Rarely at a Loss for Words
description: PARIS  Ernests Gulbis entertained on and off the court in his run to the semifinals of the French Open, his best showing at a Grand Slam event. Gulbis spoke candidly and memorably throughout the tournament.

title: A Dual Review of Whats New, Starring George Takei and Tracey Emin
description: George Takei, Star Trek alum, announcer for The Howard Stern Show and gay activist whose documentary, To Be Takei, hits theaters in August, takes on Tracey Emin, a rabble-rousing English artist who rose to fame in the 1990s with confessional works like Everyone I Have Ever Slept With 1963-1995. A moving series of her digital neons, I Promise to Love You, is on view now at the Cosmopolitan Hotel in Las Vegas. A musical inspired by Takeis childhood incarceration in U.S. internment camps comes to Broadway this fall.

title: A Splashy and Celestial Affair
description: Nick Denton, the publisher and founder of Gawker Media, was married to Derrence Washington at the American Museum of Natural History on May 31.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Readers Choice: Wholl Take a Tony?
description: The deadline for Tony Award voters to turn in ballots was 6 p.m. on Friday, but dozens of ArtsBeat readers have already weighed in with picks and predictions this week ahead of Sundays Tony ceremonies. Howd you call the major races?

title: A Good Man With Pepper Spray
description: And the only thing that can stop a bad man with a gun is a good man withpepper spray! So it went in the attempted mass shooting at Seattle Pacific University Thursday, when a gunman opened fire in a campus hall. One student was killed, several others injured. But it could have been far worse had not a student campus monitor, Jon Meis, pepper-sprayed the shooter and put him a chokehold.

title: Big Ticket | $30.4 Million for a Midtown Three-Bedroom
description: Another of the glassy three-bedroom aeries in the popular A line at the Extell Development Companys 90-story Midtown tower, One57, sold for $30,449,175 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. For now, the monthly carrying costs for the 4,483-square-foot condominium, No. 61A, are a mere $7,545, thanks to a tax abatement.

title: In Britain, Childs Weight Leads to Parents Arrest
description: LONDON  The parents of an 11-year-old boy were arrested in Britain on suspicion of neglect and child cruelty after authorities grew alarmed about the childs weight.

title: Inequality, Fertility and the Rich
description: In my post earlier today on the distributional impact of a new child tax credit, I noted that the benefits to richer families under a plan like Senator Mike Lees would diminish if, in pursuit of revenue neutrality, the plan phased out its expanded tax credit at higher income levels. (The current child tax credit has a phase-out that begins at $110,000 for married joint filings.) But as a coda, its worth noting that to the extent that family-friendly policy actually boosts fertility a highly uncertain question, to be sure egalitarian liberals might want to think twice abouta child tax credit phase-out, because then they wouldnt reap the potentially egalitarian benefits of higher fertility in the upper class.

title: Drifting Back to the Real World
description: Richard Strauss, born in Munich 150 years ago this Wednesday, must have laughed over the condemnations, even from many critics, of his opera Salome after its 1905 premiere in Dresden. Before long, of course, this succs de scandale was playing to eager audiences across Europe. The royalties Strauss earned paid for his bucolic villa in Garmisch.

title: Booed in the 60s, but Time Will Tell
description: Its anyones guess what Jimmy Giuffre was thinking when he improvised the stark, intriguing solo clarinet pieces intended for his 1962 Columbia album, Free Fall. Along with the five that made the cut, there were five others that saw the light of day some 35 years later, as bonus tracks on an overdue reissue. Small gems of oblique investigation, they bear titles that seem to hint at Giuffres state of mind; among them is one with a lonesome air, played in shadowy subtones, that he called Time Will Tell.

title: D-Day Combat Vehicles
description: Images from a 70th anniversary D-Day rally of military vehicles in and around Normandy, France.

title: Double Strawberry Cheesecake
description: Melissa Clark makes a stunner of a dessert: a lighter, more flavorful double strawberry cheesecake made with goat cheese and red wine.

title: A Strawberry Cheesecake That Is Red and White and Pink All Over
description: Picture a strawberry cheesecake: white and creamy cake on the bottom, bright red berries on top. Maybe the berries are fresh and ripe and leak a little of their tart juice onto the dense cake below. More likely, the berries are sealed in shiny, syrupy goop. Either way, you get a separation of strawberries and cream, with the two playing off each other in juicy-creamy succession.

title: Two Paths to the Same Destination
description: Nick Denton, the publisher and founder of Gawker Media, was approaching a group of his wedding guests who were smoking on a terrace of the American Museum of Natural History. Those familiar with the stern side of Mr. Denton, who was married at the museum on May 31 to Derrence Washington, might have thought they would be reprimanded. Instead he grinned and said: Were gathering everyone for a group photo. We have a guy up there.

title: Not a Happy Camper
description: Im about to thrust my child into a four-week-long situation that I know, from experience, to be a total misery. Of course, Im not going to tell her this. Introducing children to new and potentially life-altering experiences necessarily means trying to convince them that terrible things are just fine, even good.

title: Smooth Sounds Dont Always Slide Into Easy Categories
description: Jos James

title: Evening Hours | A Breath of Fresh Air
description: Stepping out for fun and to do good.

title: Code Name Parmigiano
description: Behind the scenes at a Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese producer.

title: The World Through Stewart Rahrs Neon Glasses
description: At a recent lunch at the Trump Grill, Stewart Rahr, a man of unnaturally orange skin who wears bright yellow Ray-Bans wherever he goes, whipped out his iPhone to prove that, despite tabloid reports to the contrary, hes really a good guy.

title: Diesels: Not Just for the Big Guys Anymore
description: TESTED 2014 Ram 1500 EcoDiesel

title: Electric, but Not Bragging About It
description: PALO ALTO, CALIF.  Electric cars, by the nature of how their motors function, are capable of dispensing right-now torque in big satisfying jolts.

title: Hauling Heavy Loads as It Lightens Wallets
description: ABERDEEN, N.C.  I wince as a half-yard of mulch cascades from the bucket of the skid-steer loader into the cargo bed of the 2015 GMC Sierra Denali 2500, a plume of drab dust mushrooming out to coat the Onyx Black body with flecks of bark and sawdust.

title: A Night Out With Jessica Seinfeld
description: Jessica Seinfeld took one look at her friend Beth Buccini on Wednesday night at her Baby Buggy charity event and moved in to give her a pat-down. Maybe it had something to do with Ms. Seinfelds new short, blond haircut, which she refers to jokingly as butch lesbian cousin.

title: GMC Sierra Denali: The $64,000 Question
description: As high-end pickups add the latest luxury appointments, truck prices have continued their steady climb. But is the GMC Sierra Denali  or any pickup  worth $64,575?

title: Think Like a Doctor: Arachnophobia Solved!
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 36-year-old woman with several weeks of fever, fatigue, diarrhea and chest pain along with an ugly sore on the back of her leg. The correct diagnosis is

title: The GT40, Born of Fords Feud
description: The Ford GT40 meets all the requirements for a platinum-grade collectible: Its gorgeous, it has great bloodlines as one of the most successful endurance-racing cars of the 1960s and its rare (with just over 100 built).

title: Shoe Companies Show a Red Card to Black Soccer Cleats
description: Over the years, soccer has gone through a number of memorable, if often regrettable, fashion trends. There was the alarming popularity of short shorts; the odd fixation on puffy, bloused jerseys; the bumblebee sock phase (not to be confused with the leg-warmer sock craze); and, in what was surely the sports couture low point, a brief dabble with the unitard.

title: Three to Watch
description: Name Neymar

title: A Rare Taste of Vietnam on Long Island
description: It might seem that Pho Maxia, a new Vietnamese restaurant in Westbury, epitomizes the word no. There are no reservations, no credit cards, and no liquor license.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: Group of Catholic and Orthodox Officials Endorses Marriage for Some Priests
description: In a step that is sure to fuel the debate over mandatory celibacy, a high-level group of Catholic and Orthodox officials is calling on the Vatican to allow married men to serve as Eastern Catholic priests in North America.

title: A Bridge Deal From the Reisinger Knockout Teams
description: The Reisinger Knockout Teams used to be a very popular event. Recently, though, the number of entries has dropped noticeably. This year, six teams took part in a round robin on Memorial Day in New York City at the end of the Eastern States Regional.

title: Prancing Into History of One Golden City
description: A vibrant performance of Mozarts Prague Symphony capped the concert of the American Classical Orchestra on Thursday at Alice Tully Hall and, with it, the ensembles season.

title: A Composer Beyond His Twilight Zone
description: Even the most obscure composers can have a remarkably large presence on YouTube. While researching the music of Marius Constant, whose works I was admittedly not familiar with before Wednesday evening, I was surprised to find hundreds of results on YouTube. But maybe thats not unexpected after all, considering he composed the theme to the television classic The Twilight Zone.

title: From a Wistful Queen, Longing and Regret
description: Divadom, like the price of gold, thrives on scarcity. The most elaborate mystiques and fervent cults build up around singers one rarely hears live. Any artist sounds better in a mixture of memories and hopes than in life.

title: Who Will Be the Next David Beckham?
description: Really sexy. Super-foxy. I mean, that body.

title: Wishing His Listeners Luck, a Pianist Dives In
description: Speaking to the audience that packed Lincoln Centers Kaplan Penthouse on Wednesday night for his adventurous recital titled Liszt Inspections, the probing Italian pianist Marino Formenti ended his introductory comments with two words of encouragement.

title: Secular Group, on Eve of Big Meeting, Fires Top Official Who Elevated Its Profile
description: Atheists and nonbelievers from across the country will muster on Capitol Hill next week for a summit meeting organized by the Secular Coalition for America, a growing alliance of groups that has been giving the religious right an intensifying case of heartburn by lobbying for the separation of government and religion.

title: Plane Wreck at Los Gatos
description: The folk singer Barbara Dane released this version of Plane Wreck at Los Gatos in 1973.

title: A Work Is Rushed to a Debut, by Design
description: The work that opened the New York Philharmonics concert on Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall was selected for performance only two days earlier. There was not even time to list it in the program.

title: An Artful Stealth Theme, Returning on Padded Feet
description: The jazz drummer Jeff Ballard tends to close the distance between himself and the other musicians he plays with. His drumming is active, busy, rarely loud and constantly shuffling pattern and timbre: Hes often trying to connect with, illustrate and magnify whatever else is happening around him.

title: A Country Negotiation in Brooklyn
description: Short of outright heckling, there probably arent many more dispiriting things you can shout at a performer from the crowd than Are you on Spotify?

title: James and Air-Conditioning Are Expected to Return for Game 2
description: SAN ANTONIO  When LeBron James noticed during warm-ups that AT&T Center was warmer than usual Thursday night for the start of the N.B.A. finals, he did something unusual for a creature of habit: He cut his routine short and sat on the scorers table, waiting for the game to start.

title: A Selection of Documents From the National Archives
description: Here is a selection of the roughly 2,000 documents released on Friday. Subjects include Rwanda, policies toward gays in the military, the Oklahoma City bombing and Vice President Al Gores presidential campaign.

title: State Street Financial Literacy Test
description: A series of questions was posed to 2,880 investors in the first quarter of 2014 in 16 countries globally.

title: Q. & A. | Hans-Ulrich Obrist on Curating the Swiss Pavilion at the Venice Architecture Biennale
description: As if summer travelers needed any more incentive to descend on the sinking city of Venice, tomorrow the 14th International Architecture Exhibition of the Venice Biennale opens to the public. This years edition, directed by Rem Koolhaas, gets back to the basics of modern architecture, with dozens of exhibitions at national pavilions that delve into formative moments of the 20th century. The Swiss Pavilion is headed by Hans-Ulrich Obrist, the omnivorous curator and co-director of exhibitions and programs at the Serpentine Galleries in London. In it, Obrist has brought together two 20th-century figures whose research has influenced architectural thinking in their own time and since: the Swiss political economist Lucius Burckhardt and the English architect Cedric Price. Here, Obrist walks through the genesis of the pavilions exhibition A Stroll Through a Fun Palace, whose title refers to Prices great unrealized construction, Fun Palace, and Burckhardts concept of Strollology.

title: Russia Releases Greenpeace Ship
description: MOSCOW  Russian prosecutors released a Greenpeace International ship nearly nine months after seizing it following a high-seas protest at the first offshore oil platform in the Arctic, the organization announced Friday.

title: Hacking Into Prime Time With Attitude
description: I love seeing the insides of things, Mackenzie Davis said, tucking her bleached bob behind her ears, a giraffes neck expanse above her slashed and safety-pinned Bart Simpson T-shirt. It just fascinates me and always has.

title: Dazzling a Prince, Slowly, Gently, on Point
description: Your world is not the only world: Thats the lesson of Romantic ballet. And when a grown woman moves from one world to another, she herself is transformed. In Prokofievs Cinderella, not only does the title characters dream come true, but she becomes her dream version of herself.

title: Giving a Satirist of the Third Reich the Last Laugh
description: The Nazis kept a long list of writers to settle scores with, but one in particular inflamed them: the left-wing satirist Kurt Tucholsky. In magazine articles and comic poems, he took aim at nationalists, militarists and fat cats. He dipped his pen in a special, distilled venom to describe Hitler and his followers, whom he ridiculed as little people in the refrain of Die Muler Auf! (Mouths Open!), one of his most famous poems.

title: World Cup Crib Sheet: Picking a Winner
description: We continue our series of crib sheets to help readers watch the World Cup like true fanatics. If, as a World Cup follower, you remain a free agent without any national-team loyalties, use this chart to help you arrive at a winning team.

title: Eviction Battles Imperil a Queens Art Haven
description: Battles between artists and landlords are nearly as plentiful in New York City as galleries themselves. But a recent spate of attempted evictions and other conflicts in a three-story brick building in Ridgewood, Queens, is buffeting a young outpost of the art world just as the area is earning a reputation for affordable studio space and vibrant openings.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking
description: An internal investigation at General Motors into a faulty ignition switch concludes that theres been an 11-year history of failures at the company. But the companys C.E.O. said there is no proof of a conspiracy to hide the issue. Meanwhile, the faulty ignition switch  which costs less than a dollar to replace  has been blamed for more than a dozen deaths, led to recalls of millions of vehicles and resulted in a multi-million-dollar fine.

title: Carl Icahn Discloses Stake in Family Dollar
description: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor who has taken on the likes of Apple and eBay, has identified a new target: Family Dollar Stores.

title: Knausgaard Tour Arrives in Manhattan
description: So, its the Beatles, right? asked a passer-by on Thursday night to the crowd lined up outside McNally Jackson bookstore in SoHo for a conversation between Zadie Smith and the Norwegian novelist Karl Ove Knausgaard. People started queuing at about 4 p.m., two hours before the scheduled start of Mr. Knausgaards second New York City event in three nights to promote his six-part autobiographical novel My Struggle. (The third volume to be translated into English was published last week.)

title: Graduating to Hit Shows
description: It was a sitcom about Philadelphia-area third graders who reunited in their late 20s, and it was spun from the fertile minds of David Crane, a creator of Friends, and Jeffrey Klarik, a writer-producer of Mad About You. In the fall of 2006, The Class was the new CBS show with the seasons highest hopes. It was not to be dismissed.

title: Friday Night Music: Lucius in Kansas
description: Ive been on the road within Europe for the last couple of days, not much time to seek out new music. So a really nice minimalist performance from one of my standing favorites; I love watching the evident joy of the performers:

title: A Deadline for Goats to Get Out of Detroit
description: The campaign by the hedge fund manager Mark Spitznagel to let goats graze in Detroit has hit a snag.

title: Bracing Beethoven Interpreter
description: The inaugural NY Phil Biennial, perhaps the most ambitious and extensive contemporary-music festival yet overseen by an American orchestra, has understandably claimed lots of attention. But starting Wednesday, the New York Philharmonic presents the first of three programs over three weeks featuring the distinguished pianist Yefim Bronfman, artist in residence this season with the orchestra, as soloist in the five Beethoven piano concertos and the Triple Concerto for Violin, Cello and Piano.

title: Texts and Context, at the Modern
description: Although it was 100 years ago that Gertrude Steins Tender Buttons: Objects, Food, Rooms was published, her Cubist writings about interior space evoked through light, emotions and memory, keep appearing in different guises, seeming just as contemporary now as when they were written. An exhibition opening on Wednesday at the Museum of Modern Art has adapted its titled from a phrase in Tender Buttons. Called Sites of Reason: A Selection of Recent Acquisitions, it brings together 16 works by 13 artists, all of which have entered MoMAs collection over the past few years but are only now on view there for the first time.

title: In Its 10th Year, a Brooklyn Debut
description: Over the past decade, Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet has developed a reputation for its powerhouse dancing and glamorous repertory, which skews toward the work of high-profile European choreographers. Its 10th anniversary brings a couple of firsts: first appearance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and first season under both a new artistic director, Alexandra Damiani, and new associate choreographer, Crystal Pite, who will create two new pieces for the troupe over the next three years.

title: Unflinching View at a Festival
description: Private Violence, Cynthia Hills gripping documentary film about domestic violence against women opens the 25th anniversary of the Human Rights Watch Festival on Friday with the cinematic equivalent of a brass-knuckled punch in the face. The film tells the stories of Deanna Walters, a North Carolina woman trying to escape an abusive husband, and Kit Gruelle, a dedicated advocate for battered women who championed Ms. Walterss quest for justice after she was kidnapped and relentlessly brutalized in her husbands truck during a four-and-a-half-day cross-country trip. When a North Carolina prosecutor decided that the severity of her beatings only a qualified as a misdemeanor Ms. Walters, with Ms. Gruelles encouragement, filed kidnapping charges.

title: Northside Festival Booms in Brooklyn
description: Its just another four nights in Brooklyn, only more so. Clubs are full of local bands and selected visitors; theres more music than anyone could possibly attend. The sixth annual Northside Festival, expanding each year, promises some 400 bands playing in Williamsburg and Greenpoint from Thursday through Sunday. There are free but ticketed shows (with an online R.S.V.P. to the festival) at McCarren Park, to be headlined, on Saturday, by Thee Oh Sees, playing typically brief, frenzied sets of manic garage rock, and on Sunday by Chvrches with their gleaming synth-pop conundrums. Music badges, for $80, encourage club hopping, but are subject to capacity limits; strategic fans may want to choose particular shows.

title: A Rebranded Vice President
description: HBOs dramas are known for throwing surprises at viewers, but the shocker of the year may have come last week on one of its comedies: Selina Meyer got a haircut. Selina, the vice president and title character of Veep, walked into the office rebranded, as she put it, sporting a new, shorter look. I never knew you had so much neck, one member of her inner circle said. Another, out of earshot, was less kind. Its the worst use of scissors since my failed vasectomy, he said.

title: Tyras Next Top Show, Yoko Onos Touchy Prints and Altuzarras Latest Milestone
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: Photos from France, Central African Republic, India and Afghanistan.

title: Nazi Art-Looting Case May Proceed, Court Rules
description: A federal appeals court in California issued a potentially far-reaching decisionFridaythat allows the victims of Nazi-related looting and their heirs to press ahead with legal efforts to reclaim stolen artwork. The case involves two large portrayals of Adam and Eve by the 14th-century master Lucas Cranach the Elder that were taken from the prominent Jewish Dutch dealer Jacques Goudstikker in a forced sale and are now in the collection of the Norton Simon Museum in California. Goudstikkers daughter-in-law, Marei Von Saher, has been trying to reclaim the dyptich for years but has repeatedly run into legal stumbling blocks. In a 2-to-1 decision, though, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed a lower courts decision and permitted Ms. Von Sahers lawsuit to proceed. The diptych was recovered and returned to the Netherlands after World War II, when the Dutch negotiated a partial settlement with Goudstikkers widow, which did not cover the work.The Norton Simon bought the paintings in 1971 from a collector. In 2012, a district judge ruled against Ms. Von Saher, saying that the United States had fulfilled its obligations to restitute the art, and that any effort to alter the Dutch resolution of the case would interfere with the federal governments sole authority over foreign policy. But the appeals panel noted that the United States had signed two international agreements  one in Washington in 1998, and another in Terezin, Czech Republic, in 2009  intended to remove obstacles to the recovery of possessions stolen by the Nazis. The Norton Simon released a statement saying it remains confident that it holds complete and proper title to the paintings and that it would continue to pursue, consistent with its fiduciary duties, all appropriate legal options.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: Taking a Stand, on Stools
description: The Vagina Monologues, Eve Enslers classic paean to women and their genitalia, is always a bit of a feminist rally: part humor, part outrage. That spirit of celebration and defiance runs through Los Monlogos de la Vagina, the Spanish-language version of the show at the Westside Theater, where the ebullient Daphne Rubin-Vega is bringing an extraordinary warmth and vivacity to the proceedings.

title: Ubers True Valuation Will Be About Timing
description: Talk about getting rich quick. Ubers fund-raising round, announced Friday, made it worth $17 billion just five years after the car service company started.

title: Under Cover: Ronaldo, Messi and Neymar: Capturing Soccers Biggest Stars
description: Every four years, people around the world grab their noisemakers, don their team jerseys and gather in stadiums, living rooms and local bars to watch the World Cup. How can such an expansive and consuming event be covered in a 60-page magazine issue? And then how do you boil that into a single cover image?

title: Nowhere to Turn
description: The killing of six people by a troubled 22-year-old in Isla Vista, Calif., last month is only one of the most recent in a string of shootings by young, disaffected men. Such episodes are a trauma for the communities that are hit, especially the families of the victims and the perpetrator. But they also cause a shiver of dread in certain parents all over the country, particularly those with teenagers and young adult children who seem capable of violence: Could my boy ever do that?

title: Facebook Under Fire for Temporarily Blocking Pages in Pakistan
description: LONDON  Facebook said on Friday that it had blocked users in Pakistan from access to the pages of a popular Pakistani rock band and several left-wing political pages, drawing sharp criticism from free-speech activists who accused the American company of caving in to government censors.

title: Calls for Rebirth, Not Demolition, in Detroit
description: To the Editor:

title: To Ensure Dignity for All
description: To the Editor:

title: A Shower of Petals
Educating Young Girls
description: To the Editor:

title: Mixed Sentiment in the Bergdahl Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Maria Sharapova Is Finding Her Stride on Clay at Roland Garros
description: PARIS  Uh, wheres the grunt? Chris Evert asked on the eve of the womens final at the French Open.

title: Prayer Meeting Shows Popes Larger Vision
description: VATICAN CITY  From the earliest days of his papacy, when he walked slowly into a grand reception hall in the Apostolic Palace for his first meeting with a curious diplomatic corps, Pope Francis has promoted a fairly conventional foreign policy agenda: fight poverty, pursue peace, bridge ecumenical or interreligious divisions and protect the environment.

title: Week in Pictures for June 6
description: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes a tribute to Maya Angelou, a peek at Belmont Park and a memorial for a young stabbing victim.

title: Is Softball Sexist?
description: OVER the next three weeks, baseball players from around the country will compete in three regional tryouts for a chance to make it onto the United States baseball team. These are among the most elite, dedicated and talented athletes in their sport, and the best of them will go on to play against teams from Japan, Australia, Canada, Hong Kong, Venezuela and Taiwan in the World Cup tournament held in September in Miyazaki, Japan. But the team receives almost no attention, and many of its members werent even able to play their sport in high school. These baseball players are women.

title: 12 Contenders Who Just Missed Out on a Triple Crown
description: When a chestnut colt named Affirmed won the Triple Crown in 1978, he was the third horse to do so in six years, and it seemed that achieving the holy grail of horse racing was no longer so arduous a quest.

title: Hard Lessons From Belmont
description: IVE been fooled by the Belmont Stakes before.

title: Syria: Drought Adds to Woes, U.N. Says
description: The supply of safe water in Syria is now one-third of the level it was before March 2011 when the civil war began, Unicef said Friday in a report that warns of new levels of suffering because of a worsening regional drought. The report said the 9.6 million Syrians affected by the conflict, half of them children, are at increased risk of disease because the water scarcity has compounded problems caused by damage to water and sewage systems. Parts of Syria have received the lowest levels of rainfall in more than half a century, the report said, and most parts of the country have only received half the average rainfall of a normal year. The drought also threatens to put new pressures on Jordan, Lebanon and Iraq, where Syrian refugees are already straining the water supply.

title: Festival Draws Stars of Christian Preaching (Not as Seen on Television)
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Quick: Name a famous American preacher.

title: Where to Watch the World Cup in New York
description: A guide to finding a place to watch the worlds game.

title: Where Should You Watch the World Cup in New York City?
description: Outside Brazil, there is probably no better place to watch the World Cup than the worlds city  New York. The usual spots, like The Football Factory, in Manhattan, and Woodwork, in Brooklyn, will be showing the games, of course, but every four years, the list of places to watch grows longer. Tapas bars are transformed into cheering sections for La Roja. Italian spaghetti joints become filled with passionate Azzurri fans. And bars typically crowded with American football loyalists draw fans of that other brand of football.

title: Buying Upstate New York Land, V.A. Closes Chapter in Building Cemeteries
description: WASHINGTON  As the Allies gathered in France on Friday to honor the Americans who stormed the beaches of Normandy 70 years ago, a final resting place for World War II veterans had just been carved out of fields of grasses and clover in upstate New York.

title: Roundup: Can New E.P.A. CO2 Rules Have a Climate Impact?
description: A prime challenge in trying to limit the human influence on the climate is that the atmosphere is a commons. One countrys actions limiting greenhouse gas emissions can be rendered moot if others dont act, as well.

title: Report Finds Higher Risks if Oil Line Is Not Built
description: WASHINGTON  If the Keystone XL pipeline is not built  and more oil from the Canadian oil sands is moved by rail  there could be hundreds more deaths and thousands more injuries than expected over the course of a decade, according to an updated State Department analysis of the contested project that was released Friday.

title: Vows | Coming Home Again
description: Tiffani Faranda and Michael Hermalyn grew up on the same street, shared a first kiss, and were always friends. And they say their marriage will always have traces of their third grade friendship.

title: Taxi Driver Solidarity
description: CHICAGO  Never timid in its rush to expand, Uber, the app-based car service, skirted city law when it told drivers in its UberX ride-sharing program last month that they could start picking up passengers at OHare International Airport.

title: Hot Spots: All in the Family
description: Politicians run ads heavily featuring family members to soften their image and present a positive front. Plus, who will run an ad denouncing a politicians young child?

title: General Motors Recalls 105,500 Vehicles in 2 Actions
description: General Motors is recalling about 105,500 vehicles in two actions  one because a warning chime is inoperative and the other because air bags may not deploy in a crash, the automaker said. So far this year, the automaker has issued 34 recalls covering nearly 15.9 million vehicles across North America, including 13.9 million in the United States.

title: P.O.W. Deal Gives Qatar a Victory, and a New Test
description: DOHA, Qatar  The five hardened Taliban militants were quickly whisked in a fleet of cars to the shoulder of a highway on the outskirts of the capital just as they arrived. There, out of the public eye and under the watchful gaze of Qatari security, they exchanged warm hugs with a welcome delegation and then once more were whisked off into hiding.

title: I Approved This Message; My Family Delivered It
description: WASHINGTON  Still relatively early in the 2014 election cycle, candidates are trying to introduce themselves  or reintroduce, as the case may be  to voters. And amid a panoply of negative spots, image mavens and ad wizards have found a way to try to help their politicians cut through the clutter: family, family, family. A look at some of the latest ads that feature kin (appealing parents, cute children) in supporting roles.

title: Internet Giants Erect Barriers to Spy Agencies
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Just down the road from Googles main campus here, engineers for the company are accelerating what has become the newest arms race in modern technology: They are making it far more difficult  and far more expensive  for the National Security Agency and the intelligence arms of other governments around the world to pierce their systems.

title: Congress Versus Hobbit
description: Lets talk about tax reform.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 6, 2014
description: June 6, 2014

title: G.M. Lawyers Hid Fatal Flaw, From Critics and One Another
description: DETROIT  To the legal department at General Motors, secrecy ruled.

title: General Motors Recalls 105,500 Vehicles
description: General Motors is recalling about 105,500 vehicles in two actions  one because a warning chime is inoperative and the other because air bags may not deploy in a crash, the automaker said. So far this year, the automaker has issued 34 recalls covering nearly 15.9 million vehicles across North America, including 13.9 million in the United States. The largest recall announced on Friday involves the warning-chime issue and includes about 69,500 of the automakers newest pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles, including 57,500 in the United States. The models affected by the recall are the 2014 Chevrolet Silverado and GMC Sierra light-duty pickups, the 2015 Silverado and Sierra heavy-duty pickups and the 2015 Chevrolet Tahoe, Suburban and GMC Yukon and Yukon XL S.U.V.s. The air bag problem affects 36,000 vehicles in North America, including 31,500 in the United States. The models covered by the recall are the 2012 Buick Verano and the Chevrolet Camaro, Cruze and Sonic.

title: Day of Reckoning for N.C.A.A.
description: I began writing about the N.C.A.A. two and a half years ago, more or less by accident. Assigned by The New York Times Magazine to imagine a scheme in which athletes in the revenue sports  football and mens basketball  get paid, I was awakened for the first time to inequities in the world of big-time college sports. Of course I knew that the coaches were getting rich while the players were getting nothing; everybody knew that. But I didnt think that much about it. Neither did most fans, I would venture to guess.

title: Seattle Leads the Way
description: The new $15-an-hour minimum wage approved this week in Seattle does more than guarantee a raise to tens of thousands of workers in the city. As the highest minimum in the nation, it changes the terms of the minimum-wage debate and expands the realm of the possible in setting new minimums.

title: In Memoir, Hillary Clinton Emphasizes Her Softer Side
description: In Hillary Rodham Clintons first bid for president in 2008, her campaign seemed determined to make a powerful point: She was strong. She was tough. She was ready to lead.

title: Wanting to Believe in California Chrome
description: Thirty-seven years ago, Richard Migliore first felt the magic of a Triple Crown. He was a 13-year-old exercise rider fibbing about his age to work out a filly at Belmont Park. He saw the newspapermen, as they were called then, clamoring around Seattle Slews barn.

title: Gov. Christies Money Troubles
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey already has a famous traffic jam on the George Washington Bridge tarnishing his reputation as a Republican comer and putting a damper on his ambitions for higher office. His latest budget difficulties, which have caused him to backtrack on a promise to repair the states pension system, adds one more stain to his rsum.

title: Stabbing Case Shows Lapses in Treatment for the Mentally Ill
description: During much of his five years of incarceration for choking his mother with an electrical cord, Daniel St. Hubert was prone to aggressive outbursts and violence, assaulting inmates and correctional workers. It took three years before he was even deemed psychologically fit to stand trial.

title: Plan to Build Ice Center in the Bronx Stalls Amid a Feud
description: An ambitious effort to convert the Kingsbridge Armory into a national ice sports center has stalled in recent weeks amid a bitter feud and two lawsuits over future profits and control of the development group behind the project.

title: Israeli-Palestinian Collision Course
description: The recent collapse of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks has sharpened tensions and put the two sides on a collision course. The feuding Palestinian factions, Fatah and Hamas, formed a government this week, prompting Israel to retaliate with plans for hundreds of new housing units in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. The Palestinians threatened unspecified countermeasures. It is clearly time for all sides to think hard about where this is headed.

title: Kings Work on Ice, but Most Live on the Beach
description: MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif.  When the Los Angeles Kings won the Stanley Cup two years ago, the trophys first postgame trip was to a small bar near the beach, within walking distance of nearly every players home.

title: Gunman Attacks Georgia Courthouse and Dies in Firefight, Authorities Say
description: CUMMING, Ga.  A man was shot to death on Friday by law enforcement officials after he brought an arsenal, including an assault rifle and a large supply of ammunition, to the county courthouse here and tried to mount what the authorities described as a frontal assault on the building.

title: Obama Nominates Ambassadors to France and Ireland
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday nominated Jane D. Hartley, the chief executive officer of an economic consulting firm, to be ambassador to France, once more propelling a campaign fund-raiser into a prominent diplomatic position.

title: Show Up at Dinner
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  We have what seems like a minitheme in todays puzzle by John Lieb, and this cluster of cross-referenced clues is pretty much what almost kept me from finishing the puzzle.

title: Many Bettors at a Loss Since the OTBs Closed
description: For decades, they were outposts for the self-identified degenerate, the moldering province of otherwise antisocial men with crumpled newsboy caps on their heads and racing forms tucked beneath their armpits.

title: U.N. Chief Picks Jordanian Prince for Rights Post
description: GENEVA  United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on Friday nominated a veteran diplomat and relative of Jordans royal family to be the agencys next high commissioner for human rights.

title: In Some States, Emissions Cuts Defy Skeptics
description: The cries of protest have been fierce, warning that President Obamas plan to cut greenhouse gases from power plants will bring soaring electricity bills and even plunge the nation into blackouts. By the time the administration is finished, one prominent critic said, millions of Americans will be freezing in the dark.

title: Egyptian Election Law Helps to Block Opposition
description: CAIRO  The military-appointed interim president of Egypt on Friday issued an election law that experts say all but eliminates the chance of parliamentary opposition to his successor, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former general who installed the interim government.

title: Sons of Major Leaguers, but Not Always Stars
description: On July 2, 1903, Jack Doscher took the mound for the Chicago Cubs. The son of Herm Doscher, a third baseman and outfielder in the early days of the National League, Jack is believed to have been the first son of a former big leaguer to play in the majors.

title: For Fans in Bronx, Jennifer Lopezs Homecoming Was Overdue
description: Since releasing her debut studio album, On the 6, an ode to the subway line she rode growing up in the Bronx, Jennifer Lopez has leaned on a narrative that has followed her through forays into singing, dancing and acting. And a hit single, Jenny From the Block, became a catchy moniker for the performer.

title: In Fraud Trial, F.B.I. Agent Testifies That Senator Funneled Money to Lawmakers
description: WHITE PLAINS  A real estate developer from Rockland County came to New York City dangling tens of thousands of dollars in cash and checks and slowly began to set a trap. State Senator Malcolm A. Smith, federal prosecutors tried to demonstrate on Friday, took the bait.

title: Rangers Moore Set to Return From Suspension for Game 2
description: LOS ANGELES  The Rangers expected one lineup change for Game 2 on Saturday, while two others remained uncertain.

title: In Debate, Rangel Irritates His Main Challenger, Along With the Moderator
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel and his main challenger, State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat, lashed out at each other on Friday during their first televised debate: Mr. Rangel accused Mr. Espaillat of running a racially based campaign and Mr. Espaillat charged that their district had suffered under Mr. Rangels leadership.

title: Warfares Never-Ending Story
description: The world looked back to the future last week as 18 national leaders gathered to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the D-Day invasion that triggered the end to World War IIs apocalyptic ravaging of Europe.

title: California: Tree Trimmer Wont Be Charged
description: No charges will be brought against Ernesto Pulido, a tree trimmer in Oakland who knocked five baby herons from their nests a month ago while trimming trees for the United States Postal Service. The case was investigated by the federal Fish and Wildlife Service, which said Thursday that no further action is warranted. Mr. Pulido could have faced a $15,000 fine and six months in jail for violating the Migratory Bird Treaty Act of 1918. Ive never been happier, Mr. Pulido said. The birds are expected to fully recover. Two will be released on Saturday.

title: Karen DeCrow Dies at 76; Feminist Lawyer and Author Led NOW
description: Karen DeCrow, who was president of the National Organization for Women during the 1970s, a turbulent period in which she helped lead campaigns for passage of the Equal Rights Amendment and against sex discrimination in education and sports, died on Friday at her home in Jamesville, N.Y., a suburb of Syracuse. She was 76.

title: Two States Repeal Education Standards
description: The governors of Oklahoma and South Carolina signed bills within the past week repealing the Common Core state standards, guidelines for childrens achievement in reading and math between kindergarten and high school graduation. Both states had been among the 46 and the District of Columbia that had adopted the standards, written by a group of educators and other experts convened by the National Governors Association and the Council of Chief State School Officers. But as resistance grew in their states, lawmakers moved to replace them with standards developed within the states. Gov. Nikki R. Haley of South Carolina signed that states bill last week, and Gov. Mary Fallin of Oklahoma signed a bill on Thursday that would require educators in the state to set new standards to replace the Common Core.

title: Neither Player Nor Bat Was Ready for the Fog
description: The broken air-conditioning system at San Antonios AT&T Center on Thursday in Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals was highly unusual, but those saunalike conditions did not compare to the Fog Game during the Stanley Cup finals on May 20, 1975, between the Buffalo Sabres and the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Newly Pro, and Adding Experience to Mets System
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Mets have tried to restock their organization with young, talented positions players, using their first-round picks from 2011 to 2013 on the high school prospects Brandon Nimmo, Gavin Cecchini and Dominic Smith. None have reached Class AA yet.

title: Andrei N. Mironov, Soviet-Era Political Prisoner and Activist, Dies at 60
description: MOSCOW  After Andrei N. Mironov was killed in Ukraine by artillery fire on May 24 while working with an Italian photojournalist, news accounts described him as an interpreter for foreign journalists there.

title: A Rough Guide to Brooklyn for Conventioneers
description: With Brooklyn making its bid to host the 2016 Democratic National Convention, borough boosters are already getting set to roll out the red carpet. Heres a rough draft of the welcoming committees visitors guide.

title: Bernard Telsey: The Shows Must Go On
description: As one of more than 800 Tony Award voters, the casting director Bernard Telsey gets invited to every new Broadway show that is eligible for an award, so hes a regular at Sunday matinees  most of them a quick walk from his Hells Kitchen brownstone. Indeed, Sunday is hardly ever a day off: He is always fielding requests from producers and directors obsessing over their theater, television and film projects. But Mr. Telsey, 54, has become adept at carving out time for his wife, Anne Marino, an executive with Tommy Hilfiger; their sons Daniel Marino, 25, who lives in Brooklyn, and Felix Telsey, 14; and the familys Maltese poodles, Wally and Louie.

title: Champions Bested by a Grueling Race
description: Since 1978, 12 horses who won the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness have failed to capture the Belmont, one missing glory by a nose, others in a landslide.

title: Russian State Media Focuses Attacks on Kerrys Spokeswoman
description: The rhetorical sniping between Russian and American officials over the separatist uprisings in Ukraine appeared to escalate a notch this week when state television channels controlled by the Kremlin devoted an unusual amount of time to reporting on, and so amplifying, recent attacks by Russian bloggers on a State Department spokeswoman, Jen Psaki.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 7, 2014
description: No hard feelings, but my job is to make their job hard.

title: U.S.s Young Players Expected to Contribute Now and Lead Later
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  When Jurgen Klinsmann was given a contract extension through 2018 by U.S. Soccer in December, it allowed him the luxury of keeping an eye on the long-term future of the national team. His roster for the 2014 World Cup reflects that, introducing a new generation of American players.

title: A Shaken-Up Lineup Stirs the Yankees Offense
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Contemplating a weeks worth of offensive feebleness, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi opted for something familiar to try and shake out some hits to begin a 10-game trip.

title: Your Slightly-Better-Than-a-Dartboard Guide to Choosing a Team in the World Cup
description: For those who like the pageantry but couldnt care less about the tactics, a guide to picking a team in the World Cup and finding a place to cheer among your newfound compatriots.

title: Watching the Worlds Game, in the Worlds City
description: On a gloriously sunny afternoon recently, Lunasa, an East Village pub, was packed seven deep at the bar, as three TVs showed the days big games. Soccer games, that is, in Germany, Portugal and England.

title: Fire Breaks Out at TGI Fridays Near Rockefeller Center
description: A fast-moving fire at a restaurant near Rockefeller Center on Friday night sent flames and smoke shooting into the night sky as diners ran for the exits and dozens of firefighters rushed to extinguish the blaze, the authorities said.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) ENOUGH SAID (2013) Julia Louis-Dreyfus, in a Golden Globe-nominated role, plays Eva, a divorced massage therapist in Los Angeles who finds her life emptying out as her daughter (Tracey Fairaway) prepares to leave for Sarah Lawrence College. Then she meets Albert (James Gandolfini, above, with Ms. Louis-Dreyfus), another divorced parent of a college-bound girl, and although he isnt her usual type, Eva suddenly finds herself falling for this funny, tender and sexy slob. Enter Marianne (Catherine Keener), a glamorous bohemian poet and Evas new client  who, Eva finds out a little too late, also happens to be Alberts former wife. And so Eva listens to Mariannes complaints about her ex  hes a bore and a loser, clumsy in bed and unable to take care of himself  and surreptitiously tries to correct the faults in Albert that caused their marriage to disintegrate. The real genius of Enough Said is that it takes this entirely plausible anecdotal circumstance and unlocks both its farcical potential and its latent profundity, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this small miracle of a movie written and directed by Nicole Holofcener. This movie will make you laugh and leave you in tears. Some of the pathos is the accidental byproduct of seeing Mr. Gandolfini, so playful and alive, in one of his final major movie roles and feeling once again the loss of his remarkable gift. There is also the pang of the empty nest, that mixture of grief and pride that is the special anguish of modern parents. But there is also something deeper. The ache that Enough Said leaves behind comes from the blunt force of truth.

title: No Pockets, No Problem
description: Space Billiards is a pool hall of the sort that feels nocturnal on even a bright day. But it is not a dour place, and it isnt filled with unsavory hustlers. In its slightly manic, neon-noir way, it exudes a quirky sense of cheer. Simple strobe lights jitter across walls. A seemingly endless string of dance hits plays. The wall behind the red couch is covered with small mirrors. At some tables youll find cheap American beer; at other tables, bottles of OB Lager and soju, the beer and liquor of South Korea.

title: The Oz Moment
description: Ill never forget eyeballing Ebbets Field for the first time. I had seen photographs in the sports pages, and grainy images on TV. And I had seen grass before, even growing up in Brooklyn. Still, I was totally unprepared for what the verdant playing field looked like in person in what, in a few years, the NBC peacock would introduce as living color.

title: Tribal Elder of the Fields
description: Lounging on the thick grass in Strawberry Fields, Jimmy Peters gazed up at the penthouse apartment of a new luxury high-rise on West 57th Street.

title: Poseys Late Homer Lifts Giants Past Mets
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Mets and the San Francisco Giants were tied in the eighth inning Friday night. But after San Franciscos Angel Pagan drew a leadoff walk and moved into scoring position, the Giants were so confident that they had their closer, Sergio Romo, start to warm up.

title: Corrections: June 7, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: No More Banging on the Shutters
description: The suspense was getting to just about everyone.

title: Poroshenko Takes Ukraine Helm With Tough Words for Russia
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Petro Oleksiyovych Poroshenko, a pro-European, billionaire confectioner, was sworn in on Saturday as the fifth president of Ukraine, promising to put an end to a separatist insurrection in the east that has divided the country for months.

title: World Cup Crib Sheet: Know Your Superstars
description: We continue our series of crib sheets to help readers watch the World Cup like true fanatics. For sports fans who want to know who the Lebron James of soccer is, here are world soccer stars and their analogs in American sports.

title: Morning Views
description: The New York Times cautions American officials dealing with the Palestinian Authoritys new unity government, a coalition of the extremist Hamas and more moderate Fatah factions. Many experts say that if there is ever to be an Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement, the editorial board writes, the Palestinians must be united. But the United States has to be careful to somehow distinguish between its support for the new government and an endorsement of Hamas and its violent, hateful behavior.

title: Tracy Morgan Critically Hurt in New Jersey Car Crash
description: The actor and comedian Tracy Morgan finished a stand-up comedy show in Delaware on Friday night and headed back to New York City with several other comedians. Around 1 a.m., a tractor-trailer slammed into the back of their luxury van, overturning it and setting off a chain reaction that involved four other vehicles.

title: Five Experts Evaluate E.C.B.'s Policy Shift
description: We think this is a significant package, Mario Draghi, president of the European Central Bank, said on Thursday. He was describing the measures the bank had announced to combat the euro zones crippling combination of slow growth and superlow inflation.

title: Is My Landlord Responsible for the Damage?
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Camp: Love It or Hate It? Readers Comment
description: From Not a Happy Camper, in the Styles section:

title: Two New Legal-Themed Documentaries
description: Ive spent the past weekend at the Berkshire International Film Festival in western Massachusetts, and I want to recommend two terrific law-related documentary films I saw there. One is directly law-related: The Case Against 8, the story of the federal court case that led to the invalidation of Californias Proposition 8 and to the arrival of marriage equality there. The film, by Ben Cotner and Ryan White, is now playing commercially in New York and Los Angeles, will soon open elsewhere, and will be shown on HBO on June 23 (disclosure: I had a tiny consulting role in the making of the film, actually a discussion of Supreme Court procedure over a cup of coffee with the filmmakers.)

title: Letters to the Sports Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Milwaukee Suburb Tries to Cope With Girls Stabbing
description: WAUKESHA, Wis.  At Horning Middle School last week, some girls painted cat whiskers on their faces with liquid eyeliner, in tribute to a fellow sixth grader who loved cats but who lay in a hospital recovering from 19 stab wounds that the authorities say were inflicted by two friends who had lured her into a park to kill her.

title: Across Iraq, Insurgents Show Reach in Attacks
description: BAGHDAD  Militants attacked a university in the western city of Ramadi early Saturday, forcing students and professors to flee gunfire and shelling, while in the capital, at least 48 people were killed by car bombs in an apparently coordinated series of explosions.

title: A Golfer Who Lived Large and Played Larger
description: TUSTIN, Mich.  Near a horse-and-carriage crossing in this small town, the golfing bon vivant Walter Hagen lives on, his memory carefully cultivated by a retired couple who never saw him swing a club.

title: Variety: A Vowel-less Crossword Puzzle
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  We havent seen many of these vowel-less crossword puzzles in The New York Times since records have been kept of these things (there have been five since 1997, if you count this one), and we havent seen one since 2006. But if you wait long enough, Im told, everything comes back into style, and Arthur Schulman, who created the first four, has a new vowel-less crossword for us.

title: Gay Pride Promotions
description: Companies such asHilton,KimptonandAmerican Airlineshave long marketed to the gay community. This month in a most public display of affection,Marriott International, a company with conservative Mormon roots, is wrapping three of its Washington, D.C., hotels in photo banners, including Jason Collins, the N.B.A.s first openly gay basketball player, and Geena Rocero, a transgender model. The campaign urges travelers to share photos on Instagram under #LoveTravels @MarriottIntl.

title: A Vow to End Hollow Nods and Salutes
description: After the release last Thursday of the internal report on General Motors failure to recall thousands of defective cars for more than a decade, Mary T. Barra, the chief executive, addressed the companys employees. In her remarks, Ms. Barra projected an earnest and urgent desire to reform the companys culture, which she said was permeated by bureaucratic processes that avoided accountability. That culture meant no one took responsibility for faulty ignition switches in Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars that were ultimately responsible for at least 13 deaths.

title: With Nuclear Talks Sputtering, U.S. and Iran Plan Meeting
description: WASHINGTON  Senior American officials plan to meet in Geneva on Monday and Tuesday with an Iranian delegation in an attempt to advance the stalled nuclear talks, the State Department announced Saturday.

title: Performing Without Net: Stars of YouTube Take to the Stage
description: A capacity 12,500 tickets were sold. More than 70 performers appeared on three stages. There were 150 security guards, a necessity whenever swarms of shrieking teenage girls assemble. Coke sponsored a live web stream of the festivities.

title: Resurgent Maria Sharapova Holds Off Simona Halep to Win French Open
description: PARIS  Before the womens final at the French Open on Saturday, much of the discussion was about Simona Haleps year.

title: Obama Plans Steps to Ease Student Debt
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday will take executive actions to ease the burden of college loan debt for potentially millions of Americans, in a White House event coinciding with Senate Democrats plans for legislation to address a concern of many voters in this midterm election year.

title: When Sources May Have Lied
description: Somaly Mam described having been trafficked into a brothel as a young girl in Cambodia, then escaping and helping othersand she came to run a couple of organizations in Cambodia that battled forced prostitution. She wrote an autobiography, was feted at the State Department and Kennedy Center, and celebrated by journalists. Including me. I wrote one column about her life story in 2008 after her autobiography was published in the U.S., and made several references to her after that, most recently in 2011.

title: Stumped? Invoke the 5-Minute Rule
description: This interview with Victor Allis, chief executive of Quintiq, a software company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Planting for Profit, and Greater Good
description: A lemon tree springs from the soil in Jason Aramburus backyard in Berkeley, Calif., alongside rose bushes, birds of paradise, strawberry plants and squash blossoms. The garden is thriving, but its upkeep requires almost no effort from Mr. Aramburu. Instead, a foot-high soil sensor does much of the work.

title: For Afghan Lovers, Joy Is Brief, Ending in Arrest
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  His Juliet thinks she is pregnant with her Romeos child.

title: LeBron James Shows a Growing Willingness to Take the Lead on Social Issues
description: SAN ANTONIO  It is easy now, as Donald Sterling has thrown up his hands in surrender, to forget what it was like April 26, in the hours after a bombshell of an audio recording was released. The outrage over the racist rants was instantaneous  except from where it might have been expected to be greatest. The N.B.A., it seemed, was stunned into near silence.

title: Britain Frees Pakistani in Inquiry
description: LONDON  The British police on Saturday released the Pakistani political leader Altaf Hussain, four days after he was arrested on suspicion of money laundering, but said that he remained under investigation.

title: U.S. Crew Is Arrested on Honduras River Job
description: MEXICO CITY  When Robert Mayne, a marine salvage expert, sailed from Florida to the Mosquito Coast of northeastern Honduras, he carried with him a business plan that would allow him to make some money while helping the poverty-stricken people of the region.

title: After California Chromes Belmont Defeat, Owner Stands on an Unseemly Soapbox
description: Steve Coburn was the picture of cheerful equanimity before California Chrome, the horse he partly owns, took the long walk Saturday evening onto the dirt track of Belmont Park, burial ground of Triple Crown dreams.

title: In Newly Released Clinton Papers, Ire Over Speeches
description: WASHINGTON  Bill Clintons speeches as president were notoriously long, exemplified by his State of the Union addresses, which were wordier than any other presidents in the modern era.

title: Haiti in Transition
description: Dissatisfaction with rebuilding efforts since the 2010 earthquake is stirring political unrest in Haiti, and the president and Senate are locked in a standoff over an overdue election.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, June 8
