description: With low inflation, it is more difficult for debt to come down and for economic growth to come back, so you could have a period of stagnation."Reza Moghadam, the director of the European department at the International Monetary Fund in Washington. Economists are worried that an outbreak of ultralow inflation across the 18-nation euro zone is doing more harm than good.

title: Attitudes About Work
description: Readers discuss some of the factors that make people love or hate their jobs.

title: The Fixer Offense in Soccer
description: The passionate rivalries of World Cup soccer will soon be enthralling sports fans across the globe, along with throngs of fanatic gamblers placing untold millions in bets.

title: Stop Holding Us Back
description: This month, more than three million high school students will receive their diplomas. At more than 80 percent, Americas graduation rate is at a record high. More kids are going to college, too. But one-third of the nations African-American and Latino young men will not graduate.

title: Pot Rules
description: WASHINGTON  IN the last chapter, I covered how not to get high. In this one, I will cover how to get high.

title: Dear Millennials, Were Sorry
description: AMONG Americans age 40 and older, theres a pastime more popular than football, Candy Crush or HBO.

title: Detroits Fight Against Blight
description: At one level, a new report about blight in Detroit can be seen as a cartographic inventory of the abandoned homes, vacant lots and rundown industrial sites that have spread through the once-thriving Motor City like a metastasized cancer. But there is another way to look at this important document: as the starting point for fresh conversation about what needs to be done to stabilize and revive Detroit and other declining cities around the country.

title: Haiti Elections in Doubt as Ex-Presidents Stir Pot
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  When he returned to Haiti from exile three years ago, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the former priest turned president turned deposed president, promised to stay out of politics. Yet the political party he founded and continues to inspire has routinely sent thousands of people into the streets to protest the current government, demanding the resignation of the prime minister.

title: Stjepan Hauser
description: Stjepan Hauser is a Croatian cellist and half of the group 2Cellos, which is known for its covers of popular rock songs. A YouTube video of the duo playing AC/DCs Thunderstruck has gotten more than 18 million views so far.

title: Madam Secretary Made a Difference
description: WHEN politicians have trouble spinning their own glories, thats a problem.

title: The Ghosts in the Machine
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ky.  A SURPRISING number of knife attacks on and by teenagers have appeared in the national news in recent weeks, but in terms of sheer tragic weirdness, nothing can match the case of two 12-year-old Wisconsin girls who stabbed a classmate 19 times, nearly killing her  and then said they did it to appease someone called Slenderman.

title: How to Beat Malaria, Once and for All
description: MAE SOT, Thailand  MALARIA is a seasonal disease; with tropical rains come the fevers. In the news media, malaria is also seasonal. Every spring around World Malaria Day we hear about its devastating effects, including deaths in the hundreds of thousands. This year the reports were encouraging: Infections have been reduced and many lives saved. In May, researchers reported in Science that yet another potential malaria vaccine may be around the corner. Malaria seems to be on the retreat.

title: A View From Gitmo
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba  THE weeks national debate around the exchange of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl for five Afghans imprisoned at Guantnamo Bay found me at the American base in Cuba for meetings with my clients. Here, too, the swap is the talk of the town  among prisoners, among guards and between the two groups.

title: There Is No Alternative
description: IF the excerpts currently circulating in the press are any indication, Hillary Clintons latest memoir will resemble pretty much every recent political memoir from a potential presidential candidate: That is, it will be chloroform in print.

title: The Biology of Risk
description: SIX years after the financial meltdown there is once again talk about market bubbles. Are stocks succumbing to exuberance? Is real estate? We thought we had exorcised these demons. It is therefore with something close to despair that we ask: What is it about risk taking that so eludes our understanding, and our control?

title: Obama on Obama on Climate
description: WHEN it comes to dealing with the worlds climate and energy challenges I have a simple rule: change America, change the world.

title: Starting Out Behind
description: Todays young people, ages 18 to 24, should have been the lucky ones. They were preteens or teenagers when the recession hit in late 2007, with high school and college still ahead. Unlike those who had to enter the work force in the depths of the downturn, they had time, or so it seemed, to wait out the weak economy.

title: The War on Coal Already Happened
description: Im trying to pull together some thoughts about interests and ideology in the fight over climate policies, and found myself wondering what exactly is at stake in the supposed war on coal. And the answer is, surprisingly little  at least as far as jobs are concerned. Heres total employment in coal mining (the earlier numbers are from Historical Statistics of the United States, Millennial Edition; the later from the FRED database):

title: When a Shared ID Leads to a Grim Predicament
description: We live, it has been said many times, in the era of oversharing. Sometimes this produces awkward situations. Other times, it produces something much worse.

title: Watchful Eyes in Booth Certify the Action on the Track
description: The time that elapsed from when the track announcer Tom Durkin, in his signature cadence, declared that the horses have reached the starting gate until the official sign was posted on the infield video board was a matter of minutes.

title: Wind? Biofuels? Get Real, a Contrarian Says
description: Every so often we need someone to put in a kind word for the devil, if only to remind us of unpleasant facts. On energy policy, we need someone willing to declare flat out that if oil didnt exist, we would have to invent it. No other substance comes close to oil when it comes to energy density, ease of handling, and flexibility.

title: In South Sudan, a Ghost of Wars Past: Child Soldiers
description: BENTIU, South Sudan  Stretched out on a tarp on the floor of a makeshift hospital on a dirt road outside this town, a soldier in a leg cast was laughing and joking with other wounded fighters. His smile was broad and innocent, his voice not yet changed by puberty.

title: Child Migrants Strain Makeshift Arizona Shelter
description: PHOENIX  Immigration officials overwhelmed by a flood of women and children from Central America who illegally crossed the border from Mexico are moving hundreds of unaccompanied boys and girls this weekend to a makeshift detention center in Nogales, Ariz.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 8
description: The Taliban released a video on Wednesday of their handover of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl to American troops, and it quickly went viral. The exchange  five Taliban prisoners were released from Guantnamo Bay in exchange for Sergeant Bergdahl  drew criticism from some lawmakers, who disagreed with President Obamas decision. The story was made murkier when soldiers who served with Sergeant Bergdahl called him a deserter and some blamed him for the deaths of six to eight soldiers who were killed in a search mission for him.

title: The Astros Are on the Verge of Winning for Losing
description: The Houston Astros picked first in the draft for the third year in a row on Thursday.

title: With She Knows a Band, an Agent Is Born
description: When I was 18 years old, I walked into a nightclub in Highland, Ind., with a woman 10 years my senior who was my teacher at the Barbizon modeling school in Chicago. (Be a model, or just look like one!) My grandmother had signed me up for the class. She hoped honing my table-setting skills might land me a suitable husband, and if I learned the Dior turn along the way, that would be nice, too. My Barbizon teachers presence matters only inasmuch as her looks allowed me into Club Dimensions sans ID. She bore a passing resemblance to Snow White (alabaster skin, glossy black hair, matte red lips). We were new friends, and Id driven to her house in Highland for a visit from my apartment in suburban Chicago.

title: After a Girls Accusation, the Questions Pile Up
description: The first scene of Conviction, the new play by Carey Crim, begins with a celebration, as two couples toast a successful high school production of Romeo and Juliet directed by Tom Hodges, one of the husbands. But the scene ends on a dark note, as Tom takes a phone call from the school principal and frowns. Ominous music fills the air, and the play soon turns tense and gripping.

title: Online Learning Goes to Harvard
In Pitching Veggies to Kids, Less Is More
description: One of the fiercest marketing battles in the world takes place in kitchens and at dining room tables across the world. The sellers are parents, trying everything to persuade their children to eat their vegetables.

title: As Though the Other Good Horses Werent There
description: Steve Wolfson is the son of Louis Wolfson, the owner of Affirmed, the 1978 Triple Crown champion. He formerly directed the operations at Harbor View Farm in Florida, where Affirmed was bred. Wolfson, 73, shared his memories of Affirmed and discussed issues facing the thoroughbred racing industry with Tom Pedulla.

title: Affordable Housing Thats Very Costly
description: Abington House, at 500 West 30th Street near the High Line in West Chelsea, is a new luxury residential building and, like a lot of new luxury developments in Manhattan, its extremely expensive. The cheapest two-bedroom apartment now listed there rents for $5,850 a month. That gets you only one bathroom; a two-bed, two-bath can run as high as $8,695.

title: Kings Resilience Rests, Quietly, With Jonathan Quick
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.  As N.H.L. fans seek a definitive statement on the Los Angeles Kings resilience, the best place to look may be the quietest corner of their dressing room.

title: Playoff Overtime Isnt the Grueling Slog It Used to Be
description: Many sports have overtime, extra time or extra innings. But in hockey, extra periods of play have traditionally been a physically grueling ordeal, sometimes stretching into the next morning.

title: Alexander Shulgin, Psychedelia Researcher, Dies at 88
description: Alexander Shulgin, a chemist who specialized in the creation of and experimentation with mind-altering substances, and who introduced the controversial drug popularly known as Ecstasy for potential therapeutic use, died on Monday at his home in Lafayette, Calif., east of Oakland. He was 88.

title: Bird? Plane? No, but the Same View for Tennis Matches
description: PARIS  On a gray day at the French Open, thousands of spectators watched Roger Federer sit for a changeover on Philippe Chatrier Court. A moment later, a miniature jet the size of a small automobile appeared over the rim of the stadium.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 5
description: The 2014 World Cup begins Thursday, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Remembering Maya Angelou
description: Former President Bill Clinton, Oprah Winfrey and the first lady, Michelle Obama, eulogize Maya Angelou at a memorial service in Winston-Salem, N.C.

title: More Scrutiny, Still Spectacular
description: A 30 percent rise in stocks made 2013 a fruitful year for the owners of American businesses, the shareholders; while the growth in rewards was less generous for top employees, their compensation was still enormous. Average total pay for the 200 most highly paid chief executives tracked by Equilar, an executive compensation data firm, rose 6 percent, to $20.7 million.

title: What Hillary Rodham Clinton Did
description: My Sunday column takes aim at the commonly heard narrative that Hillary Clinton as Secretary of State was glamorous but didnt really achieve much or leave any legacy. I think thats completely wrong, and that she did have a significant impactjust not the usual kind. I think this is an issue that is going to spark more debate this week following publication of Clintons book on Tuesday and as the presidential campaign approaches. So let me know if you agree, or where you think she didor didnthave impact.

title: How the Pay Figures Were Calculated
description: To measure the amounts that chief executives were paid last year, Sunday Business asked Equilar Inc., an executive compensation data firm, to compile and analyze pay data from corporate filings.

title: The Pay at the Top
description: 200 of the highest-paid chief executives in American business.

title: An Elusive Jackpot
description: If you were Marissa Mayer of Yahoo, making nearly $25 million for one years worth of work  not to mention getting $50,000 in company-paid personal security  the gender pay gap would probably not be a major concern. Women scaling the heights of corporate America tend to have compensation packages that are as jaw-droppingly gigantic as men at a similar level.

title: A Hamlet Wrapped in Yarn
description: Walk through downtown Oyster Bay these days and youll find 48 trees, 34 lampposts and four kiosks wrapped in bands of green, royal blue, purple, light blue and yellow crocheted yarn.

title: Cruz Fires Up G.O.P. Delegates in Texas
description: FORT WORTH  After patiently waiting in a line that snaked outside the doorway of a cavernous exhibit hall on Saturday, John Justice was just a few feet from reaching his goal  being photographed with Ted Cruz, the United States senator and Tea Party favorite.

title: Unfamiliar Name Becomes Hurdle for Hispanic Candidate
description: With the chances of Texas Democrats winning a statewide office in November hinging on a higher turnout among Hispanics, the only Hispanic on their statewide ticket goes by the last name Van de Putte.

title: Belmont Stakes: Tonalist Denies California Chrome the Triple Crown
description: Tonalist, ridden by Joel Rosario, won the 146th running of the Belmont Stakes on Saturday at Belmont Park, denying California Chrome his shot at becoming the 12th Triple Crown winner and the first since Affirmed in 1978.

title: Concealed Weapons, and the Sanctity of Marriage
description: One man is standing on a bridge, poised to jump. Everything has gone wrong in his life. Another man, passing by, recognizes him from his college days and casually calls out his name. Everything in the second mans life has gone right. Everything except his marriage. Maybe, in Murray Schisgals Luv, these two old pals can help each other.

title: Voter Turnout as Big as Texas? Not Really
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: In Paris, the Ultimate Rivalry Begins Its Next Chapter
description: PARIS  Despite smashing that racket in the semifinals, Novak Djokovic has been determined to keep the mood lighter at this French Open, and he stayed true to his plan on Saturday.

title: Its Good to Be a Female C.E.O., if You Can Get There
description: Female executives and their pay have been making headlines lately, from Yahoo to General Motors to The New York Times. We know that women face many obstacles on their way to the corner office (just 4.9 percent of chief executives at the 1,000 biggest companies are women), but do they continue to be treated differently once they arrive there? The answer is yes  but in different ways than the female employees below them.

title: Willie Nelson Rode on Bus but Called Another Home
description: The entertainer Willie Nelson has a ranch in Texas and a residence in Hawaii, but the place that he calls home is a bus named Honeysuckle Rose.

title: Sharpton Warns Against Race-Baiting in New York Contest
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton sent out a stern warning on Saturday against race-baiting in the contest for the 13th Congressional District in New York.

title: Charity in Mexico Takes More Than Good Intentions and Cash
description: CIUDAD JUREZ, Mexico  When 40 children with special needs were removed from an orphanage here last month, officials at the facility said that employees looked on helplessly, unable to get a clear reason.

title: Deep in the Heart of Prospero
description: The shipwreck that opens Shakespeares Tempest is often staged with billowing sails, splintering masts and despairing sailors lurching across heaving decks amid blasts of rain and wind. Yet that is not the way the play begins in the current production by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey in Madison.

title: After Thrill of Triple Crown Bid, Frustration for Delayed Passengers
description: The first train arrived an hour before post time for the opening race, pulling into a creaky rail station unaccustomed to the crowd.

title: Strike One
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  O.K, heres the thing: There are times when the creative vision of a puzzle maker outpaces that of some of the technology that exists to support that vision. And because there are many third party programs and apps with which to download The New York Times Crossword  programs and apps that The Times does not control  not everyone will have the same experience. I might have alluded to that yesterday, when I was driving myself crazy trying to think of a way to explain this puzzle. I feel better now, so here we go.

title: Baby-Boomer Misery Confronts a Funnier Future
description: Whats so great about licking postage stamps, anyway? Audiences at Hartford Stage will be forgiven if they dont stop to think this through as Mark Nelson, playing the first of the four title characters in Christopher Durangs Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike, waxes rhapsodic about stamp-licking. His brilliant, showstopping rant about the vanished joys of yesteryear  coonskin caps, Dinah Shore, rotary-dial telephones, Bishop Fulton J. Sheen, handwritten letters and, yes, even the icky, glue-backed stamps for posting them  bursts forth in a torrent that vanquishes any and all cavils.

title: Seeking National Glory, Clubs Tap Global Talent
description: The champions of premier French and British club leagues defended their titles this year by doing the usual: importing world-class talent.

title: Urged to Multiply, Iranian Couples Are Dubious
description: TEHRAN  In their early 30s, married, and with prospects for successful careers, Bita and Sherag could be contemplating the logical next step in their lives: becoming parents.

title: Though Not Quietly, Kentucky Moves to Cut Reliance on Coal
description: BURGIN, Ky.  The E. W. Brown power plant rides like an ocean liner on a rolling ridge in Kentucky, its smokestacks and plumes visible across fields of corn and cattle for miles around.

title: Giants Series Gives Mets Another Look at What They Lost in Pagan
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Angel Pagan keeps his World Series ring, the one he won with the San Francisco Giants in 2012, in his house, in a secure location he does not readily divulge. Every now and then, he takes it out and admires it. The ring motivates him.

title: Behind the Slightly-Better-Than-a-Dartboard Guide to Choosing a Team
description: As a nation of immigrants, Americans tend to have more choices than most when it comes to rooting for a team in the World Cup. You get the United States  thats your safety school, so to speak. Unfortunately, the U.S. national team never figures to go very deep into the tournament. So you can choose to root for your ancestors or, if you want, a team that speaks to you, and not your national or ethnic pride. If thats your chosen course, this is a chart for you.

title: Fresh Legs Stamp Out a Coronation
description: The gates popped open Saturday, and 11 horses charged past the grandstand for a mile-and-a-half marathon nicknamed, fittingly, the Test of the Champion. All eyes were on California Chrome, in pursuit of the first Triple Crown since 1978. There appeared to be little to worry about as jockey Victor Espinoza spurted him along the rail and glided him into the first turn almost easier than he had in his six previous races, all victories.

title: Seeing Squalor and Unconcern in a Mississippi Jail
description: JACKSON, Miss.  Open fires sometimes burn unheeded in the solitary-confinement units of the East Mississippi Correctional Facility, a privately run state prison in Meridian, 90 miles east of here.

title: Bergdahl Was in Unit Known for Its Troubles
description: The platoon was, an American military official would assert years later, raggedy.

title: Cleveland Clinic Chief Out of Running for V.A.
description: WASHINGTON  Dr. Delos M. Cosgrove, the chief executive of the Cleveland Clinic, said Saturday he had been considered by President Obama for the job of secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs, but had withdrawn his name and would stay at the clinic.

title: Outside Money Floods Alaska in Senate Race
description: ANCHORAGE  A big part of being an Alaskan is harboring a suspicion of all things Lower 48. Its an inclination that runs so deep that locals have a proper noun to describe everywhere else  Outside.

title: Hillary Clintons Book Hard Choices Portrays a Tested Policy Wonk
description: The rollout of Hillary Rodham Clintons new book, Hard Choices, as a prelude to a possible 2016 run for the White House, has had all the subtlety of a military operation ramping up to full speed: the leak of the Benghazi chapter to Politico late last month (presumably to get talk about that hot-button topic out of the way early), the cover story in the latest issue of People magazine, the wall-to-wall lineup of television interviews this week, a grueling cross-country book tour.

title: Portraying Horse as Hero, Soon Fallen
description: Heading into the Belmont Stakes, California Chrome was the undisputed story.

title: As Bowe Bergdahl Heals, Details Emerge of His Captivity
description: WASHINGTON  Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl has told medical officials that his captors locked him in a metal cage in total darkness for weeks at a time as punishment for trying to escape, and while military doctors say he now is physically able to travel he is not yet emotionally ready for the pressures of reuniting with his family, according to American officials who have been briefed on his condition.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 7, 2014
description: June 7, 2014

title: Orphan Black Recap: Meet the New Clone, the One With the Flannel Shirt
description: Season 2, Episode 8: As I watched Saturdays installment of Orphan Black for the second time, something continued to bother me. The introduction of Tony, a transgendered clone played by Tatiana Maslany, is certainly a surprising development and another intriguing variation on the shows central themes of individual identity within a select group and nature vs. nurture.

title: Hope Wilts as Tradition Stays Strong
description: The traditional blanket of white carnations placed on the winner of the Belmont Stakes was made with 445 flowers painstakingly glued to a seven-foot-long velveteen quilt by Tony Green, who felt deep in his bones on Saturday morning that California Chrome would win the Triple Crown.

title: Handwriting on Wall for Yankees as Ball Flies Over It
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  The pitch was down, almost at Salvador Perezs shoe tops, just where Yankees starter David Phelps wanted it. Then Perez swung and drove the ball where Phelps never expected, toward the Kansas City Royals bullpen in left field.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 8, 2014
description: Anybody with a lot of children is either very rich or very irresponsible. There is no other way.

title: U.S. Displays Improvement Across the Field and a Breakthrough at the Front
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  After struggling with a scoring slump dating to last year, Jozy Altidore hit his stride Saturday with two goals in a convincing 2-1 win over Nigeria that could give the United States national team momentum for its arrival in Brazil for the World Cup.

title: The Intimacy of Anonymity
description: Thanks to Facebook and Instagram, oversharing ones personal life feels as authentic as reality TV. Right now anonymous posts hold the key to the truth.

title: Stephen Boehmke, Nicholas Koster
description: Stephen Paul Boehmke and Nicholas Simon Koster were married Saturday evening at Basilica Hudson, an event and performance space in Hudson, N.Y., by Miguel Escobar, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion.

title: Sarah Brody, Bradley Cohen
description: Sarah Michele Brody and Bradley Heath Cohen are to be married Sunday at the Temple, a synagogue in Atlanta. Rabbi Peter S. Berg will officiate, with Rabbi Ed Snitkoff, an uncle of the groom, assisting.

title: Samantha Ladd and Justin Sughrue
description: Mary Samantha Ladd and Justin Halsey Sughrue were married Saturday at St. Peters-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Narragansett, R.I. The Rev. Casey Shobe, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony with assistance from the Rev. Paul Sughrue, the grooms uncle and a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Grace Chung, James An
description: Grace Eun-Ha Chung, the daughter of Eun Sook Chung and Kwan Ho Chung of Flushing, Queens, was married Friday to James Sung-Ho An, the son of H. Christine An and Chae Hun An of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. The Rev. Edwin M. Moore, a Southern Baptist minister, officiated at the Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Lindsey Bruett, Christopher Burrage
description: Lindsey Diesl Bruett, the daughter of Karen D. Bruett and William H. Bruett Jr. of Gladstone, N.J., was married Saturday to Christopher Lincoln Burrage, the son of Helen D. Burrage and Walter S. Burrage Jr. of Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass. The Rev. Dr. William L. Fox, president of St. Lawrence University and a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at an outdoor ceremony at Shelburne Farms in Shelburne, Vt.

title: Laura Silverman, Samuel Temes
description: Laura Elizabeth Silverman, a daughter of Jo Ann B. Silverman and Eric F. Silverman, both of New York, was married Saturday evening to Samuel Benjamin Temes, a son of Delia C. Temes and Sanford P. Temes of Manlius, N.Y. Rabbi Ira J. Schiffer officiated at the Mountain Top Inn and Resort in Chittenden, Vt.

title: Megan OKeefe, Jason Madden
description: Megan Elizabeth OKeefe and Jason Scott Madden were married Saturday at the Mid Ocean Club in Tuckers Town, Bermuda. The Right Rev. Nicholas B.B. Dill, an Anglican priest and the Bishop of Bermuda, performed the ceremony.

title: Alexandra Thomas, Christian Burset
description: Alexandra Moran Thomas and Christian Russo Burset were married Saturday at the Princeton University Chapel. Msgr. Thomas J. Mullelly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Mary Beth Anton, a Presbyterian minister, taking part.

title: Lydia Gray and Ryan McDevitt
description: Lydia Calley Gray, a daughter of Abby Aldrich Gray and David M. Gray of Baltimore, was married Saturday to Ryan Hanft McDevitt, the son of Barbara E. Hanft and Roland D. McDevitt of Silver Spring, Md. The Rev. Canon Jonathan T. Huyck, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the vacation home of the brides family in South Dartmouth, Mass.

title: Lauren Kerwin, Timothy McNamara
description: Lauren Burdett Kerwin and Timothy William McNamara were married Saturday evening at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Michael A. Majkowski, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Ron Hartwig, Robert Pierce Jr.
description: Myron Arthur Hartwig and Robert Wilson Pierce Jr. were married Saturday in Los Angeles. The Very Rev. Mark R. Kowalewski performed the ceremony at St. Johns Episcopal Cathedral, with the Very Rev. Daniel G. Ade, also an Episcopal priest, taking part.

title: Samantha Rubin, Nick Berger
description: Samantha Ashley Rubin and Nicholas Adam Berger were married Saturday evening at the Gramercy Park Hotel in New York. Rabbi William H. Kraus officiated.

title: Varina Winder, Jeffrey Brown
description: Varina Jane Winder and Jeffrey Lawrence Brown were married Saturday at the Estate at Moraine Farm in Beverly, Mass. The officiant was Mark O. Gul, a friend of the couple who received a one-day designation from the governor to solemnize the marriage.

title: Far From Home, Bound by Sickness
description: Dani Lynn Simons and Sarah Marie Charlop-Powers were married Saturday at Camp Lakota, a childrens summer camp in Wurtsboro, N.Y. Rabbi Leora Kaye officiated.

title: Jessica Pan, Donny Hoang
description: Jessica Yunfen Pan and Dr. Quan Van Manh Hoang were married Saturday at the Prince of Peace Church in Olathe, Kan. The Rev. Gary Pennings, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Ginny Too and Emily McNabb
description: Ginny Mei-Yu Too and Emily Anne McNabb were married Saturday. C. Megan Bradley, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Mill City Museum in Minneapolis.

title: Alexa Gibbs, Bruno Maranhao
description: Lt. Alexa Nicole Gibbs and Bruno Maranhao were married Saturday at the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Springfield, Ill. The Very Rev. John Nolan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Ry Russo-Young, Colin Spoelman
description: Ry Russo-Young and Colin Robert Spoelman were married Saturday afternoon at Plymouth Church in Brooklyn. Marcy S. Friedman, a justice of the New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan, officiated.

title: Amy Fernandez and Eduardo Horta
description: Amy Elizabeth Fernandez and Eduardo Filipe Horta were married Saturday at the Sagamore Resort on Lake George in Bolton Landing, N.Y. Judge Peter M. Forman, of the Dutchess County Court in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., officiated.

title: Ashley Ciaburri, Matthew Rainwater
description: Ashley Gibson Ciaburri, the daughter of Gail Gibson Ciaburri and Dr. Daniel G. Ciaburri of New York, was married Saturday to Matthew Gibson Rainwater, a son of Marilyn Gibson Rainwater and Cecil B. Rainwater Jr. of Atlanta. The Rev. Kevin V. Madigan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Shannon McAllister, Roy Demeshulam
description: Shannon Kathleen McAllister, a daughter of Colleen Grady McAllister and Russell L. McAllister of Waterford, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Roy Izak Demeshulam, a son of Lazar Demeshulam of New York and the late Lorie Fein Demeshulam. Rabbi Shir Yaakov Feinstein Feit officiated at Point O Pines, a camp in Brant Lake, N.Y.

title: Abigail Manship, Marc Aleksinas
description: Abigail Elizabeth Manship, the daughter of Lynn K. Manship and Dr. Mark E. Manship of Salem, Ind., was married Saturday afternoon in Louisville, Ky., to Marc Andrew Aleksinas, a son of Robin C. Aleksinas and Michael J. Aleksinas of Greenville, S.C. The Very Rev. Joan Pritcher, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church Cathedral, where she serves as dean in the interim.

title: Sarah Dobkin, Edwin Davisson
description: Sarah Emily Dobkin and Edwin Steuart Davisson were married Saturday in Princeton, N.J. Dr. Robert E. Accordino, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at Princeton Universitys Holder Hall, the residential hall where the couple met.

title: Bethany Lesser, Anthony Kusich
description: Bethany Lesser and Anthony Fajardo Kusich were married Saturday evening at the Whittemore House, a historic building in Washington. Rabbi Esther Lederman officiated.

title: Katherine Drizos, David Cavell
description: Katherine Jean Drizos, the daughter of Elizabeth K. Drizos and George M. Drizos of Macungie, Pa., was married Saturday to David Franklin Cavell, a son of Cathleen Cohen Cavell and Stanley L. Cavell of Brookline, Mass. Nancy Bauer, who received permission from Massachusetts, officiated at the deCordova Sculpture Park and Museum in Lincoln, Mass.

title: Chessia Kelley, Peter McBride
description: Chessia Bucklin Kelley, a daughter of Mona V. Kelley and Kevin J. Kelley of Three Lakes, Wis., was married Saturday evening to Peter Nevins McBride, the son of Pamela W. McBride and W. Peter McBride of Franklin Lakes, N.J. The grooms father, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Foundry, an event space in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Tiffani Faranda, Michael Hermalyn
description: Tiffani Frances Faranda and Michael Zachary Hermalyn were married Friday evening at Florentine Gardens, an event space in River Vale, N.J. The Rev. Michael J. Sheehan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with Rabbi Bill Kurry taking part.

title: Thaddeus Strassberger, Giuseppe Mallardo
description: Thaddeus Hughes Strassberger and Giuseppe Mallardo were married Thursday by Tomas Dyson, a marriage registrar at Islington Town Hall in London.

title: Dehn Gilmore and James Salzmann
description: Dehn Wolcott Henry Gilmore and James Ross Salzmann were married Saturday at the Episcopal Church of St. Thomas in Camden, Me. The Rev. Mark D. W. Edington, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Karen Segall, Jeremy Bass
description: Karen Michelle Segall and Jeremy Seth Bass were married Saturday evening at Pippin Hill Farm, an event space in North Garden, Va. Rabbi Michael Gillette officiated.

title: A Walk That Led Down the Aisle
description: Dr. Heather Lynn Paladine and Edward Fredrick Berliner are to be married Sunday at the Manhattan Penthouse, an event space in New York. William J. Paladine III, the brother of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.

title: Melissa Weiner and Ildefonso De Jesus Jr.
description: Melissa Erin Weiner and Ildefonso De Jesus Jr. were married Saturday evening at the New England Aquarium in Boston. Beverly A. Cook, a Massachusetts justice of the peace, officiated.

title: An Exclusive Gown for a Designers Daughter
description: To paraphrase her father, the bride didnt wear fashion, she wore a wedding dress.

title: United as They Journeyed Back in Time
description: Joanna Amy Brooks and Marcus Andreas Klostermeyer are to be married Sunday afternoon by Cantor Leslie Friedlander at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Jacqueline McKeon, William Shufelt
description: Jacqueline Elizabeth McKeon, the daughter of Patricia A. Finnegan of Darien, Conn., and the late Robert B. McKeon was married Saturday afternoon to William Stuart Shufelt, a son of Douglas G. Shufelt of Wilmington, Vt., and the late Elizabeth D. Shufelt. The Rev. Joseph M. McShane, a Roman Catholic priest and the president of Fordham University, who was a friend of the brides father, performed the ceremony at the Most Holy Trinity Church in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Kings Again Take the Lead Only When Necessary: At the End
description: LOS ANGELES  Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals was decided in overtime. Game 2 on Saturday night at Staples Center went to double overtime, more than four hours after the first puck was dropped. Eighty-two shots were fired on goal. When the last one eluded the outstretched glove of Henrik Lundqvist, the Los Angeles Kings grabbed a stranglehold on the series.

title: Steve Coburn Lashes Out at Racing Industry, Capping an Emotional Five Weeks
description: Steve Coburn was afforded five weeks of fame beyond the clichd 15 minutes, and he made the most of his time in the limelight.

title: Corrections: June 8, 2014
description: NATIONAL

title: On the Scene at the Belmont Stakes
description: An estimated crowd of 100,000 attended Belmont Park on Saturday to watch California Chrome run for the Triple Crown.

title: Giants Rally in Ninth to Send Mets to Fifth Straight Loss
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Mets catcher Anthony Recker stood still, his hand on his hip, staring blankly into the distance. The Mets were clinging to a 4-3 ninth-inning lead over the San Francisco Giants, the best team in baseball.

title: World Cup Crib Sheet: Very Important Charts
description: We complete our series of crib sheets to help readers watch the World Cup like true fanatics. To see which team asked for a Jacuzzi in every hotel room, and more, check out the charts below.

title: 2014 Tony Awards: Hugh Jackman on His Hosting Plans
description: For complete coverage of the Tony Awards, including performance videos, predictions and an interactive ballot, please visit The Timess Tony Awards special section.

title: A Plea to the Daughters of Title IX: Why Dont More Women Coach?
description: When I first registered my daughter, Lily, for soccer five years ago, I made a conscious decision to take a back seat. I wouldnt volunteer to be the head coach. Instead, I would take a role as an assistant/orange-slice dispenser. The plan was for me to lend support, but not loom too large over my daughter.

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 68TH ANNUAL TONY AWARDS Hugh Jackman, above, will sing and dance his way across the stage of Radio City Music Hall as host of this ceremony honoring excellence on Broadway. Performers include the nominees Neil Patrick Harris and the cast of Hedwig and the Angry Inch, Sutton Foster and the cast of Violet, and Idina Menzel, in a song from If/Then, as well as Alan Cumming in a reprisal of his Tony Award-winning role from Cabaret. Other highlights include a 10th-anniversary celebration by the cast of Wicked; Patti LaBelle, Gladys Knight and Fantasia in performance with the cast of After Midnight; Sting in a work from his coming musical, The Last Ship; and Jennifer Hudson in a number from Finding Neverland, a Harvey Weinstein project.

title: In Our Pages: June 9
description: 1889: The Tonquin Railway

title: How Much Should We Pay For Art?
description: How do we decide, as a capitalist society, what creative expression is worth? That question, posed by Ester Bloom at The Billfold, gets more vexed every day.In a time when more and more art is available for free online, we as a society have to figure out how to value and support it.

title: At Swearing-In, Ex-General Vows Inclusive Egypt
description: CAIRO  Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former general who led the military takeover here nearly one year ago, was sworn in as president on Sunday, testing the bet that a new strongman can overcome the economic dysfunction and political polarization that bedeviled Egypts three-year experiment with democracy.

title: 3 Inmates Escape in Quebec in Latest Helicopter Jailbreak
description: OTTAWA  Three men escaped from a Quebec jail on Saturday night aboard a helicopter, the second aerial breakout in the province in 15 months.

title: A Half-Century of Guiding Young Scholars in Harlem
description: Edouard E. Plummer works out of a room inside a Harlem public school that would be spacious  if it were a storage closet. Still, he has found a way to pack its shelves and cover its walls with a growing testament to a half-century of achievements that rival those of headmasters at the swankiest prep schools.

title: Nadal Denies Djokovic, and Defies Belief, Once Again
description: PARIS  After all the consecutive victories and the confidently clenched fists, after the new hires and the new attitude, the 2014 French Open was just another red-clay rerun for Novak Djokovic.

title: Critics of P.O.W. Swap Question the Absence of a Wider Agreement
description: WASHINGTON  When the heads of the two major intelligence committees criticized the Obama administration on Sunday for swapping Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl for five members of the Taliban, they homed in on one part of the deal that the White House has struggled for a week, unsuccessfully, to explain. The question is why the five were released without any commitments to a larger agreement, under which the Taliban would renounce international terrorism, and begin a process of reconciliation with the government of Afghanistan.

title: Sisi Ascends to the Presidency
description: Abdel-Fattah el-Sisi was sworn in Sunday as Egypts president.

title: Is It Possible to Be a Male Feminist?
description: Who is the male feminist? Perhaps we should first ask: Does he even exist?

title: Calvin and Hobbes Creator Returns, Briefly
description: Bill Watterson, the creator of Calvin and Hobbes who retired in 1995 and withdrew from the public eye for almost two decades, has finally returned to drawing comic strips, if only for a brief moment. Last week, Mr. Watterson was the ghost artist for a handful of panels on Stephan Pastiss Pearls Before Swine for a storyline in which Mr. Pastis is replaced as the artist of the strip by a second grader named Libby.

title: Rift Deepens in Britain Over Claims of School Infiltration Plot by Islamic Extremists
description: A dispute over how to combat the threat of homegrown Islamic extremism in British schools has provoked a political crisis, prompting the personal intervention of Prime Minister David Cameron, a public apology from one senior minister and the resignation of an adviser to another.

title: Border Makes China and India Bristle, Even as They Seek Closer Ties in Trade
description: NEW DELHI  Chinas state news media has welcomed Indias new prime minister, Narendra Modi, as a pragmatic new partner on economic matters, noting that as a regional leader, he made four visits to Beijing seeking investment and even went to the trouble of printing his business cards in Chinese characters, in the auspicious color of red.

title: In Egypt, Back to Rule By a Strongman
description: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former general who led the military takeover in Egypt nearly one year ago, was sworn in as the countrys president on Sunday. The reactions to Sisis election ranged from downright joyous to cautiously optimistic to unapologetically cynical.

title: Terrorists Attack Airport in Pakistan, Killing 13
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  In a ferocious terrorist assault that stretched into Monday morning, suspected Islamist militants infiltrated Pakistans largest international airport in Karachi, waging an extended firefight against security forces that resulted in 23 deaths and shook the countrys already fragile sense of security.

title: Rangers Fume Over a Tangle in the Crease
description: LOS ANGELES  Whether a play included goaltender interference, perhaps the most disputed penalty in hockey, is not reviewable by replay officials, despite frequent pleas to make it so. The Rangers Henrik Lundqvist became the latest to issue that request, after Game 2 of the Stanley Cup finals Saturday night.

title: Tonalists Owner Savors Victory but Offers Some Criticism of His Own
description: Robert Evans was gracious Saturday evening when a reporter relayed the sour-grapes comments from Steve Coburn, one of California Chromes owners.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Vanity Fair Ad Gives Life to What Killed the Cat
description: SCHWEPPES, for many years, sold tonic water as curiously refreshing. Hendricks gin staged a theater of curiosities and billed its unusual website as a Curiositorium. And it is, of course, common knowledge what curiosity did to that cat.

title: 2014 Tony Awards: Gentlemans Guide and All the Way Take Top Honors
description: Charles Isherwood, a theater critic for The Times, and Eric Grode, a writer and critic for The Times, live-blogged the 68th annual Tony Awards.

title: Trying to Stop Fight at Staten Island Bar, Man Dies After He Is Punched
description: Closing time was approaching early Sunday morning at the Drunken Monkey, a Staten Island bar with a reality television claim to fame, when a group of stragglers began fighting.

title: At Vatican, Day of Prayer With Focus on Uniting
description: VATICAN CITY  In a richly symbolic ceremony, Pope Francis oversaw a carefully orchestrated prayer summit with the Israeli and Palestinian presidents on Sunday as Jews, Christians and Muslims offered invocations for peace in the Vatican gardens.

title: Andy Murray Picks Amlie Mauresmo as His New Coach
description: PARIS  It was the French Opens best off-court chess match: Andy Murray versus the news media on the topic of his new coach.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of June 9
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: From China, With Pragmatism
description: As an American Fulbright lecturer living in Beijing, I am regularly confronted with lost in translation ethical conversations. At a recent lunch with United States Embassy officers and local Chinese intellectuals, we had a complete cultural breakdown over red envelopes.

title: Yankees Offense Goes Back to Sleep, Squandering a Solid Start by Kuroda
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  On a partly cloudy Sunday morning, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi led more than a dozen reporters down a hallway to the visitors dugout at Kauffman Stadium and sat down. Ever optimistic, Girardi then cited run-scoring doubles by Brian McCann and Carlos Beltran the previous two nights as encouraging signs for his clubs struggling offense.

title: Five Killed in Las Vegas Shootings
description: Two police officers and another person were killed in a shooting rampage on Sunday morning in Las Vegas, the authorities said.

title: Philharmonics Contemporary Foray Ends, With a Promise of More
description: Avery Fisher Hall looked to be about half-full for a concert by the New York Philharmonic on Friday night, the orchestras next-to-last program for the inaugural NY Phil Biennial, conducted by the vibrant German-born composer Matthias Pintscher. The Philharmonic, the institutional curator of this bracing festival, may have hoped that every event would attract capacity crowds; some, in smaller halls, did.

title: A Paragon of Honor, With a Little Time Off for Love
description: Akshay Kumar has made a career of playing Indian Everymen, sweet goofballs who succeed accidentally while upholding traditional values. He may cut down villains  theres plenty of fighting in movies like Chandni Chowk to China and Singh Is Kinng  but he honors mothers and aunties and helps the poor.

title: For Audience and Young Composers, a Chance to See Works Take Flight
description: I want to clarify the articulation in the oboes in measure four, George Manahan, the music director of the American Composers Orchestra, announced to his players on Saturday evening, before they began Andy Akihos Tarnished Mirrors.

title: Teenage Angst Trumps Sci-Fi at the Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES  Social media came of age in Hollywood over the weekend.

title: Stacked Deck
description: Dealing with the Taliban over American P.O.W.'s.

title: T h r e e  S t r i k e s
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  All is forgiven, Tom McCoy. You can come home now.

title: A Lowly Scorned Shopgirl Takes On the Upper Crust
description: However current the issues of income inequality, a living wage and an arbitrary criminal justice system may be, Within the Law reminds us that they have long been fodder for popular entertainment.

title: Good With the Scalpel, but Lacks People Skills
description: Reading The Dinner, by the Dutch author and misanthrope Herman Koch, was rather like being stabbed in the eyeball with a hot needle. The book was such a huge international best seller that Mr. Koch is demonstrably not alone in his fascination with all things loathsome about humanity, and The Dinner did tell a propulsive tale. It is a hard act to follow, but say this about his new novel, Summer House With Swimming Pool: This is a book in which someone actually does stick a hot needle in his own eyeball. The blood, pus and pain that follow are lovingly described.

title: Dutilleux and Ravel Mingle With Sir Mix-a-Lot
description: SEATTLE  It has been quite a spring for the Seattle Symphony.

title: More Than Just the Father of a Famous Actor
description: Robert De Niro, one of the most respected and successful actors of his generation, ended up in a very different field from his father, the painter Robert De Niro Sr. But he knows that one thing is true for all artists no matter what the discipline: Talent isnt enough. What separates someone at the top from countless skilled contemporaries who spend their careers in semi-obscurity has as much to do with serendipity as it does with ability.

title: A Shoeshine Box, With a Luster All Its Own, Emerges From the Shadows
description: A 1930s shoeshine stand bedecked with gilded knobs and beaded fringe, which was once exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art  where it played a role in a famous directors ouster  resurfaced last month and is headed back into the public eye.

title: Persistence Can Be Its Own Reward, Even for a Confrontational Band
description: There must be a positive lesson to be extracted from the story of Eyehategod. This band from New Orleans has endured 26 years  through opiates, hurricanes, homelessness, jail and probation. It has survived a name that has never gotten any less puerile; the recent death of a drummer, Joey LaCaze, who helped define its angry and sensuous sound; touring whenever possible; recording a lot less often; and a kind of artfully antisocial behavior.

title: Tracy Morgan, Still Critical, Is More Responsive
description: The actor and comedian Tracy Morgan remained in critical condition on Sunday after he was injured in a crash in New Jersey over the weekend. Mr. Morgan, 45, a former cast member of Saturday Night Live and 30 Rock, had several serious injuries, including a broken leg, a broken femur, a broken nose and several broken ribs, his publicist Lewis Kay said on Sunday. He was hurt when a tractor-trailer slammed into the back of the luxury van he was riding in as he left a comedy show in Delaware around 1 a.m. on Saturday. Mr. Morgan is expected to remain in the hospital for several weeks, Mr. Kay said.

title: Focusing on a Mystery, and Their Own Dramas
description: When a series follows one murder investigation for an entire season, the conceit can sometimes look like a European refinement. Broadchurch, Spiral and The Fall are just a notable few of the many imported shows that proved so broodingly intense that it sometimes seemed as if networks and basic cable here could never catch up.

title: Biggest Master Point Winner at Eastern States Regional
description: John Kranyak of Las Vegas won more master points (78.7) than anyone else at the Eastern States Regional in Manhattan last month. He had three firsts and one second in four Swiss Team events.

title: A Work Moves, Even if Some of the Figures Do Not
description: Diary of an Image by DD Dorvillier, the four-week performance series that has been running at Danspace Project in St. Marks Church since May 21, has mostly evaded providing a clear, defining image of DD Dorvillier. A Catalogue of Steps rearranged fragments from her early works. The Solo Performances over two weekends were created and performed by people other than Ms. Dorvillier. And on Friday, when she debuted her own work, also called Diary of an Image, she gave over the first part of the piece to stationary silhouettes of other dancers.

title: Governors Ball
description: Scenes from the music festival on Randalls Island.

title: A Mix of Fact and Imagination, As Seen on Radio
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Musics opera house must have hosted plenty of Valkyries in its time. But Jeanine De Bique is almost certainly the first to stride onstage accessorized with a broom and dishwashing gloves, singing about how much she hates her job.

title: Jennifer Lopez Bows Out of World Cup Ceremony
description: Jennifer Lopez will not perform as planned at the opening ceremony of the 2014 World Cup in So Paulo, Brazil, on Thursday because of what FIFA officials are calling production issues, The Associated Press has reported. Ms. Lopez was scheduled to appear alongside the rapper Pitbull and the Brazilian star Claudia Leitte for a performance of We Are One (Ole Ola), the official song of the soccer tournament, before the opening match between Brazil and Croatia. All three artists perform on the recording of the track, which was released in April and written and co-produced by Pitbull. A replacement for Ms. Lopez has not been announced.

title: Pass It On
description: As soon as I saw a photograph of an African soccer ball, stitched together from old rags in the geometric patterns so familiar to us, I wanted to tell its story.

title: Pass It On
description: This short video shows how a Congolese man turns scraps into a soccer ball for village children, so they can play the sport they love.

title: An Invasion of Color at Chelsea Art Gallery
description: The famously chromophobic Chelsea got a shock of color on Thursday night: lime green, sunshine yellow, orange and spring green on the walls of the Gemini G.E.L. at Joni Moisant Weyl Gallery, defying conventional wisdom that galleries must be white. The masterminds were two architects known for shaking up hotels and houses with bold hues: Peter Stamberg (who held court in a fluorescent orange jacket from Joe Fresh) and Paul Aferiat (in pink seersucker), founders of Stamberg Aferiat & Associates.

title: Aftermath of the Karachi Airport Attack
description: The scene at the airport in Karachi, Pakistan, after militants stormed past security, firing automatic weapons and hurling grenades.

title: When Offenders Get On With Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Noncompete Clauses Increasingly Pop Up in Array of Jobs
description: BOSTON  Colette Buser couldnt understand why a summer camp withdrew its offer for her to work there this year.

title: After Period of Turmoil, Riverside Church Elects New Leader
description: Riverside Church, one of the nations most prominent liberal Protestant pulpits, on Sunday elected as its new senior minister the Rev. Dr. Amy K. Butler, making her the first woman to head the church in its 84-year history.

title: A Tarnished View of the Manhattan Skyline
description: To the Editor:

title: The Politics of Appointing Justices to the Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Tiananmen, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Taxidermy Meets Arts and Crafts
description: A hobby that saw its heyday in Victorian Britain is enjoying a revival in London.

title: As a British Pastime Is Revived, Some Critters Get Second Lives
description: LONDON  Now pull the skin up over the skull like a hood, Margot Magpie instructed her students. They were hunched over wooden tables, each holding a scalpel in one hand and a white mouse, gutted, in the other.

title: End of Altidores Slump Lifts U.S. Hopes
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  As the United States national team prepares for the World Cup in Brazil, it is riding the momentum of a three-game winning streak and perhaps a dose of newfound confidence from its starting striker, Jozy Altidore.

title: Peaceful Nonreconciliation Now
description: MAALE SHOMRON, West Bank  JOHN KERRYS failed Middle East peace effort has made it clear that a negotiated political agreement is impossible at the moment. The two-state formula enjoyed decades of exclusive stardom, in which its appeal thwarted all innovative and alternative thought.

title: Shifts in Charity Health Care
description: Health care reform was supposed to relieve the financial strain on hospitals that have provided a lot of free charity care to poor and uninsured patients. The reform law, known as the Affordable Care Act, was expected to insure most of those patients either through expanded state Medicaid programs for the poor or through subsidized private insurance for middle-income patients, thereby funneling new revenues to hospitals that had previously absorbed the costs of uncompensated care.

title: Reconstruction Planned for Infamous Townhouse in Greenwich Village
description: The house at 18 West 11th Street is one of Greenwich Villages most famous. It has been a home to literary and Broadway royalty, the site of a deadly accidental bombing by Weatherman radicals and, once rebuilt, a sweet neighborhood fixture with a stuffed Paddington Bear wearing seasonal outfits in its angled picture window.

title: Tipped Into Poverty
description: When Senate Republicans recently blocked a vote to raise the federal minimum wage, they snubbed the estimated 27.8 million people who would earn more if the measure became law. The hardest hit are the roughly 3.3 million Americans who work for tips, nearly three out of four of whom are women. Workers in predominantly tipped jobs  including restaurant servers, bartenders, hairstylists  are twice as likely as other workers to live below the poverty line. They need a raise, and Congress should give it to them.

title: A Model for Juvenile Detention Reform
description: States are sending fewer and fewer children to juvenile correctional facilities, partly in response to research showing that locking up young people increases the risk that they will eventually drop out of school and become permanently entangled with the justice system.

title: A Triple Crown Tradition Prevails at Belmont Stakes Despite Sour Grapes
description: California Chromes co-owner Steve Coburn was upset, and so were the multitudes who had their hearts set Saturday on a victory by the colt in the 146th running of the Belmont Stakes and the first Triple Crown in 36 years. But, like all of us who at one time or another need to heed the guiding, loving hand of a spouse, the voluble cowboy should have listened to his wife, Carolyn, and just zipped it when the cameras were in his face.

title: Cyberattack Insurance a Challenge for Business
description: Julia Robertss smile is insured. So are Heidi Klums legs, Daniel Craigs body and Jennifer Lopezs derrire. But the fastest-growing niche in the industry today is cyberinsurance.

title: Ebola Gets Worse in West Africa
description: The World Health Organization warned last Wednesday that the epidemic caused by the deadly Ebola virus in West Africa, which had seemed to be waning, has recently taken a turn for the worse. The afflicted nations and their neighbors will need to redouble their efforts to contain a virus for which there is neither a cure nor a vaccine.

title: Ready for Spotlight, a Course Is Restored to Its Shaggy Self
description: PINEHURST, N.C.  As one of the countrys first golf resorts, Pinehurst has long been viewed as an American cradle of the sport. The resorts showcase golf course, known as Pinehurst No. 2, hosted its first major event more than 100 years ago and evolved into a masterpiece of the nations best-known golf architect, Donald Ross.

title: In Crown Heights, Once Torn by Race Riots, a Friendly Game of Soccer
description: The World Cup may be days away, but in Brooklyn, the Crown Heights Cup game on Sunday may be almost as important. In some ways, it is more important.

title: Religious Constriction
description: I am both shocked and fascinated by Americans religious literalism.

title: Netflix Investors to Vote on C.E.O.-Chairman Split
description: Netflix has had its share of battles of late, including opposing Comcasts proposed takeover of Time Warner Cable and pointing fingers at Verizon for some instances of its streaming video services being slowed. But the online video titan has also quietly faced restiveness among some of its shareholders.

title: In Texarkana, Uninsured and on the Wrong Side of a State Line
description: TEXARKANA, Tex.  On a hazy, hot evening here, Janice Marks ate a dinner of turkey and stuffing at a homeless shelter filled with plastic cots before crossing a few blocks to the Arkansas side of town to start her night shift restocking the dairy cases at Walmart.

title: Tyson Is Said to Win Battle for Hillshire Brands
description: Updated, 8:18 a.m. | In the battle for Jimmy Dean sausages, it appears that Tyson Foods has won.

title: Interests, Ideology and Climate
description: There are three things we know about man-made global warming. First, the consequences will be terrible if we dont take quick action to limit carbon emissions. Second, in pure economic terms the required action shouldnt be hard to take: emission controls, done right, would probably slow economic growth, but not by much. Third, the politics of action are nonetheless very difficult.

title: At Rios Beaches, Kicks Go Over Net
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The most impressive move in Brazilian sports has nothing to do with soccer, takes place on sand and is known, delightfully, as the Shark Attack.

title: An American Life, Lived in Shadows
description: TULSA, Okla.  Ignacio, a father of four, bounces along in his pickup truck, driving at exactly the speed limit through an aging suburb. The clock says 6:44 a.m. Religious pendants hang off the mirror. His teenage son sits beside him, chatty if half-awake, as they approach an apartment building for a day of roofing in dire heat.

title: Brazils Other Favorite Sport
description: Born on Copacabana Beach in the 1960s, futevolei is a uniquely Brazilian sport.

title: Are Reparations Due to African-Americans?
Face of the N.C.A.A., Battered Early and Often
description: INDIANAPOLIS  A large oil painting hangs in the office of Mark A. Emmert, the president of the N.C.A.A. It depicts a boxer in a gym preparing for a bout, a team of trainers huddled around him.

title: Port Authority Land Purchase Is Boon to Bayonne, and Christie
description: When the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced in June 2010 that it had purchased a 131-acre tract of land on the waterfront in the city of Bayonne for $235 million, the deal seemed like an auspicious one for the agency.

title: Five Dead in Shooting Rampage in Las Vegas
description: In a shooting rampage that left five people dead, two assailants killed two Las Vegas police officers on Sunday at a pizza restaurant and fatally shot a third person at a nearby Walmart before dying in a suicide pact, the authorities said.

title: Day After Catcher Is Sent to Minors, Mets Are Swept Again in Trip Finale
description: SAN FRANCISCO  It was only the seventh inning, but David Wright was perhaps the Mets last hope. He was given a rare day off, but the Mets were a run behind the San Francisco Giants with two outs and the tying run on first base.

title: Degree? Check. Enthusiasm? Check. Job? Not So Fast.
description: He pulled the maroon robes over his shoulders and straightened his cap, his body tingling with that nothing-can-kill-this-day kind of vibe. Then he heard his mother calling his name  Jelani! Jelani!  and suddenly he was standing, then shouting, then high-fiving his fellow college graduates.

title: 3-Pointer No Longer Domain of Small Players in N.B.A.
description: SAN ANTONIO  Bob McAdoo, with his graceful, high-arcing jumper, was a rarity for an N.B.A. big man. At 6 feet 9 inches, he could pull shot blockers like Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Artis Gilmore and Bob Lanier out near the top of the key and shoot over them or drive past them. Three times, McAdoo led the league in scoring, and in 1975, he was named the N.B.A.s most valuable player.

title: A Proud Swirl of Sound and Spectacle
description: The parade could be seen and heard several blocks away from Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, where determined visitors armed with folding chairs and coolers had been lining the route since early Sunday morning. Red, white and blue flags fluttered like capes from the backs of people heading toward Bryant Park. Salsa music pumped from the floats and coursed through the streets. Cheers rose above the roar of Midtown traffic.

title: A Proud Swirl of Red, White and Blue
description: Spectators lined Fifth Avenue to watch the 57th National Puerto Rican Day Parade, a start-of-summer tradition in New York City.

title: For Buffalo, Few Points on the Ice but Plenty in the TV Ratings
description: The hockey fans of Buffalo are proving that their passion for the sport does not wane, even when the Sabres have a miserable points percentage  the worst in their history.

title: Stretching the Limits Seems to Suit the Kings
description: LOS ANGELES  The Los Angeles Kings relentless run this postseason may be the most inexplicable one in the 121 years of the Stanley Cup.

title: Morris A. Adelman Dies at 96; Saw Oil as Inexhaustible
description: Morris A. Adelman, an energy economist who marshaled free-market principles and hard data in arguing that the worlds oil supply was not running out, died May 8 at his home in Newton, Mass. He was 96. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he taught and researched for 65 years, announced the death on May 15.

title: Time Inc. to Set a Lonely Course After a Spinoff
description: Sometime late next year Time Inc., the company that all but created the modern magazine business, will leave its home of more than five decades, the Time & Life Building in Rockefeller Center, and head to new quarters in downtown Manhattan.

title: Video Gamings Big Expo, and G.M.s Shareholder Meeting
description: G.M. HOLDING SHAREHOLDERS MEETING

title: Free Music, at Least While It Lasts
description: Late last Thursday, I stopped at the fruit stand and some big, vivid red grapes caught my eye. The vendor said a two-pound bunch would be $6, which seemed steep. I was about to tell him as much, and then came to my senses and gave him the money.

title: David Nadien, Philharmonic Concertmaster, Is Dead at 88
description: David Nadien, a violinist whose appointment as concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic raised eyebrows because of his thriving career as a studio musician, died on May 28 in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: Japan Seeks to Squelch Its Tiny Cars
description: SHINSHIRO, Japan  Toshie Yamadas kei, with its pint-size engine and tiny wheels, looks more like a Fisher-Price toy car than a regular truck. But dont underestimate her Nissan NT 100 Clipper microtruck. At a recent farmers market, where she sells orchids from her flower farm here in central Japan, she loaded up a mountain of crates, buckets and a folding table before hopping in and zipping away.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 8, 2014
description: June 8, 2014

title: The Well-Followed on Social Media Cash In on Their Influence
description: Good thing social media did not exist during the era of Mad Men. It might have put Don and Peggy out of business.

title: Reuniting With Mother at the Zoo
description: Dear Diary:

title: G.M. Report Illustrates Managers Disconnect
description: WASHINGTON  The report released last week on how General Motors failed for years to recognize a safety defect in millions of small cars contained no new scientific or engineering insights. What it did was reinforce a point about the sociology of management: From cars to space shuttles, from offshore oil wells to nuclear reactors, the people who make the decisions are often out of step with the mechanical details.

title: Sterlings Ban and Fine Wont Change, Silver Says
description: SAN ANTONIO  N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver said Sunday that the process of removing the Clippers owner Donald Sterling from the league was nearing an end, even though Sterling had a lawsuit pending against the league and had not signed a term sheet that his wife, Rochelle, agreed to with Steve Ballmer for a $2 billion sale.

title: War Gear Flows to Police Departments
description: NEENAH, Wis.  Inside the municipal garage of this small lakefront city, parked next to the hefty orange snowplow, sits an even larger truck, this one painted in desert khaki. Weighing 30 tons and built to withstand land mines, the armored combat vehicle is one of hundreds showing up across the country, in police departments big and small.

title: Penny Dreadful Recap: Vanessas Sin and Obsession
description: Season 1, Episode 5: When Vanessa set out to flirt with Victor Frankenstein earlier in Penny Dreadful, she cooed a few lines of Wordsworth at him, from the Intimations of Immortality, to be precise. In Closer Than Sisters, the first episode to air since Showtime announced that the show has been renewed for a second season, she switches over to another Romantic poet, John Keats  and appears to be setting herself up for the worst kind of immortality.

title: 2014 Tony Awards: Gentlemans Guide and All the Way Are Named Top Shows
description: Overcoming death-defying odds  modest ticket sales, little-known stars and limited appeal to tourists  A Gentlemans Guide to Love & Murder won the Tony Award for best musical on Sunday night, in a ceremony that stood out for spreading the wealth among many shows. As for performers, one reigned supreme: Audra McDonald made history by winning her sixth prize for acting, the most ever.

title: Halt and Catch Fire Recap: Joe Reveals a Scar
description: Season 1, Episode 2: Is Halt and Catch Fire a mystery, or is it a procedural? The second episode of AMCs new drama about the dawn of the personal computer industry dances upon this question.

title: Popular Demand
description: As government and internal investigations into the ignition-switch defect have built since the February recall of Cobalts and other General Motors models, Cobalt owners have remained loyal to the brand.

title: Judge Voids Expansion of Discount Drug Program
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge has struck down a new rule requiring drug companies to offer certain drugs at discounted prices, saying the Obama administration had no authority to issue the rule.

title: James and the Heat Coolly Even the N.B.A. Finals
description: SAN ANTONIO  The air-conditioning system at AT&T Center was in working order Sunday night, and so was LeBron James.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 4
description: The 2014 World Cup begins Thursday, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday June 9, 2014
description: Its impossible to understand what it is to move when you have nothing. To risk everything  losing your bed, your sense of community  for an uncertain benefit? Theres no way you want to risk that.

title: Word of the Day | scintilla
description: scintilla \sin-ti-l\ noun

title: Worlds Oldest Man, Though Only Briefly, Dies at 111 in New York
description: Alexander Imich, a Polish-born psychic researcher who was certified the oldest man on earth, died Sunday morning at a senior residence in Manhattan. He had turned 111 on Feb. 4.

title: Tony Winners
description: Play:

title: Not the Movies, but Real Theater
description: Youre asking people to care about something that may not affect their lives, may not even affect their childrens lives, Anderson Cooper said, introducing the CBS broadcast of the Tony Awards on Sunday night.

title: Whats On Monday
description: 9 P.M. (ABC) HILLARY CLINTON: PUBLIC AND PRIVATE  ONE ON ONE WITH DIANE SAWYER In an interview at her home in Washington, Mrs. Clinton (above right with Ms. Sawyer) discusses her new book, Hard Choices, as well as the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the aftermath of the concussion she sustained in 2012 and whether she will release her medical records if she runs for president in 2016.

title: Steve Coburns Proposal Aside, Belmont Field Is Traditionally Small
description: California Chrome headed back to California after Saturdays Belmont Stakes, in which he failed to become the first Triple Crown winner since 1978, but the debate about the format of the three-race series continued.

title: In Communist Party Parlance, Adultery Has Many Names
description: The Communist Party regularly employs a variety of muffled euphemisms for sexual misdeeds: moral corruption, dissolute lifestyle and the like. But in a rare display of lucidity, Chinas top antigraft body actually used the Chinese word for adultery  tongjian ()  last week while announcing the expulsion of a party member.

title: Morning Views
description: The New York Times editorial board supports a settlement in a lawsuit between the Justice Department and the State of Ohio over care in juvenile correctional facilities. Ohio will sharply reduce and eventually end solitary confinement, the board writes, citing statistics indicating higher likelihood of mental problems and suicidal behavior in youngsters forced to endure it. The Justice Departments settlement with Ohio puts states on notice that solitary policies need to change. If adopted nationally, the principles in that settlement would go a long way toward humanizing juvenile detention.

title: Golfs Mona Lisa Got a Buzzcut
description: The worlds best golfers will compete for the U.S. Open at Pinehurst. The resorts landmark course recently got a makeover, and its new look is anything but manicured and green.

title: Corrections: June 9, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Lloyds Sets Price Range for TSB Unit Below Book Value
description: LONDON  The Lloyds Banking Group announced on Monday the price range for the initial public offering of its TSB Banking Group unit, one that is below what analysts think is the book value of the business.

title: Britains Man Group to Acquire Pine Grove Asset Management
description: LONDON  The British hedge fund manager Man Group said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Pine Grove Asset Management, a hedge fund manager based in the United States.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Social Media Celebrities Meet Their Biggest Fans
description: In Performing Without Net: Stars of YouTube Take to the Stage, Brooks Barnes writes about social media celebrities appearing at events with their fans.

title: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, June 9, 2014
description: Can animals can have a tangible effect on childrens health and well-being?

title: Cinven to Buy Spanish Fiber Optic Network Operator
description: LONDON  The European private equity firm Cinven said Monday that it had agreed to pay 510 million euros, or about $696.8 million, for Gas Natural Fenosas fiber optic network operator in Spain and Latin America.

title: China Accuses Vietnam of Ramming Ships to Stop Rig
description: China says that Vietnamese ships have rammed Chinese vessels 1,416 times since a dispute over a Chinese oil rig in the South China Sea flared up in May and that Vietnam has used frogmen to attempt to disrupt Chinas controversial exploratory drilling operations.

title: Photographing a Difficult Love in South Africa
description: I first encountered the South African photographer Zanele Muholi two winters ago in her native country. I was so shy and in awe of her work that I half-hoped she wouldnt remember that last encounter. As the foremost chronicler of black lesbians and transgender people in South Africa, Ms. Muholi is an artist and activist, advocating for rights for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people on a continent where they are under attack.

title: What Are Your Experiences With Internet-Based Urban Legends?
description: Do you know any scary or strange stories that are presented on the Internet as true? Do you believe the stories are real or made-up?

title: Behind the Cover Story: Sam Borden on Klinsmann as the Coach and Change-Agent of American Soccer
description: Sam Borden, European sports correspondent for The Times, wrote this weeks cover story about the German coach of the U.S. mens national soccer team, Jrgen Klinsmann.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: New York Today: Aint No Sunshine
description: Good dreary Monday morning to you.

title: Daily Report: Businesses Struggle to Obtain Insurance Against Cyberattacks
description: Julia Robertss smile is insured. So are Heidi Klums legs, Daniel Craigs body and Jennifer Lopezs derrire. But the fastest-growing niche in the industry today is cyberinsurance, Nicole Perlroth and Elizabeth A. Harris report.

title: In Our Pages: June 10
description: 1939: Sun Sets Fire to Girls Hat

title: Assault on Pakistan Airport Signals Talibans Reach and Resilience
description: LONDON  Only a week ago, the Pakistani Taliban appeared to be on the ropes. Violent rivalries had split the insurgency in two. Peace talks with the government had collapsed. Military jets had pounded militant hide-outs in the tribal belt.

title: Kabuls City on the Hill
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Just south of the city center is the most famous of Kabuls many dun-colored mountains. It is called TV Hill, after the telecom and broadcast antennas that crowd its peak like needles in a pincushion. One of the most visible signs of the Western presence in Afghanistan, it is hailed as a symbol of post-Taliban progress.

title: The Challenges of Enforcing Customer Service Policies
description: A gate agent stopped me recently as I was boarding a flight to Dallas. After inspecting my carry-on bag, she asked me if it would fit.

title: How to Pay for Only the Health Care You Want
description: One reason health insurance is expensive is that most plans cover just about every medical technology  not just the ones that work, or the ones that are worth the price. This not only drives up costs, but also forces many Americans into purchasing coverage for therapies they may not value. But theres no reason things couldnt be different, and better for consumers.

title: Minimum Wage: Who Makes It?
description: Minimum-wage increases could appear on the ballot in as many as 34 states this year. President Obama has also proposed increasing the federal minimum wage to $10.10, from $7.25. Who makes the minimum wage, and who would be affected by any of the proposed increases?

title: Prison for 5 in Murder of Journalist
description: MOSCOW  Moscows highest criminal court on Monday sentenced five men to prison, including two to life sentences, for the 2006 murder of the investigative journalist Anna Politkovskaya, but left unsolved the question of who ordered the killing, the highest-profile attack on a Russian journalist of the last decade.

title: Europes Age of Diminished Expectations
description: Joe Weisenthal informs us that Spanish bond yields are now about the same as US yields. This is telling us two things, one good, one bad. The good news is that investors no longer have much fear of a euro crackup any time soon. The bad news is that they expect Europe to remain depressed for a long time.

title: Chinese Ex-General Warns U.S. Over Magazine Article
description: A reminder to the Americans puffed up with pride and arrogance, making threatening gestures: Do not be ultimately defeated by our lethal trump weapon in your absent-mindedness.

title: Morning Agenda: Tysons Winning Bid for Hillshire
description: TYSON SAID TO WIN BATTLE FOR HILLSHIRE | It appears that Tyson Foods has emerged victorious in the battle for Hillshire Brands, the maker of Ball Park hot dogs and Jimmy Dean sausages, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced writes. Hillshire, which is also home to its namesake lunch meats, is expected to declare Tyson the winner of a bidding war, people briefed on the matter said on Sunday.
