description: As the founder of a business intelligence software company, it can be hard to explain my job to those outside my industry. Whenever I catch up with friends or family members, I can see the question coming a mile away: What exactly does your company do again?

title: Sunni Militants Drive Iraqi Army Out of Mosul
description: BAGHDAD  Sunni militants spilling over the border from Syria on Tuesday seized control of the northern city of Mosul, Iraqs second largest, in the most stunning success yet in a rapidly widening insurgency that threatens to drag the region into war.

title: If Robots Drove, How Much Safer Would Roads Be?
description: Human error is the culprit in 93 percent of automobile crashes  including the pileup last weekend that left Tracy Morgan in critical condition, caused, prosecutors say, by a truck driver who had been awake for 24 hours.

title: A Case Study in Lifting College Attendance
description: Sydney Nye was a straight-A student with an SAT score high enough to apply to any college in the country. When her senior year of high school in Wilmington, Del., started about nine months ago, she had dreams of becoming a chemical engineer.

title: Arm Syrias Opposition
description: Washington  In February, I resigned as the American ambassador to Syria, after 30 years foreign service in Africa and the Middle East. As the situation in Syria deteriorated, I found it ever harder to justify our policy. It was time for me to leave.

title: Morning Agenda: A Closer Look at Ubers Valuation
description: A CLOSER LOOK AT UBERS VALUATION | When the car ride service Uber was valued on Friday at $18.2 billion, some called the figure nuts and insane. After all, it was hard to believe that a four-year-old company that exists on an iPhone could be worth more than longstanding institutions like Alcoa and Tiffany, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. But a look at the basic math suggests that Ubers valuation might still be too low.

title: In Our Pages: June 11
description: 1889: His Royal Highness on High

title: Intersection | Detroits Industrial Chic
description: In the historic Eastern Market neighborhood of Detroit, local style is inspired by the industrial surroundings.

title: Who Ordered Politkovskayas Murder?
description: Almost eight years after the gruesome murder of Anna Politkovskaya, one of Russias most respected investigative journalists, Moscows highest criminal court has finally sentenced five men to prison, two of them for life. The court ruled Monday that these men were part of a conspiracy to assassinate Ms. Politkovskaya in her apartment block on Oct. 7, 2006. These convictions signal some progress in Russias glacial investigations of the murder, but the case is not closed.

title: In Performance: Tony Award Winners
description: On Sunday night Tony Awards were given to two actors who recently participated in a small concert produced by The New York Times as part of a special Tony Awards edition of the In Performance series.

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help
description: Heres the latest batch of sound-alike mix-ups, including a couple I dont recall seeing before. Add these to your watch list.

title: New And Not Improved
description: OK, were obviously in for a lot of breathless hype about the new conservatism, as supposedly exemplified by Room to Grow, which self-consciously lays out what are supposed to be bold new conservative policy ideas. One thing you dont find amid the hype, however, is much actual description of the new ideas in question. Thats because the ideas dont bear too much scrutiny.

title: Whats News in Washington: In Six States, Its Primary Day
description: Good Tuesday morning from Washington. Hillary Rodham Clintons book Hard Choices comes out today, kicking off her much-anticipated book tour, furthering speculation about her intentions for 2016 and consuming a whole lot of political oxygen. But on the ground it remains midterm season, and it is primary day.

title: The Release of Bowe Bergdahl
description: President Obama makes a controversial prisoner swap.

title: Madame Tussauds Fits Maya Angelou
description: Dear Diary:

title: Allergan, Maker of Botox, Rejects Valeants $53 Billion Offer
description: Updated, 12:42 p.m. |

title: Fashion Awards: Beyond Vogue and Up With Mens Wear
description: For the last few years, Vogue has had something of a lock on the fashion awards market  ever since American Vogue introduced its fashion fund award with the Council of Fashion Designers of America in 2003, which was followed by Who Is on Next?, the Italian Vogue/AltaRoma prize established in 2005; the British Vogue and the British Fashion Council designer award in 2008; and the Fashion Design Council of India and Indian Vogue award in 2012. Well, now GQ is getting in on the act.

title: Whos Your Mommy? We Dont Know  Yet
description: Over a year ago, despite my many doubts, I agreed to become a sperm donor for my good friends, Tori and Kelly. Saying yes, it turns out, was the easy part. It took nearly a year of failed attempts before Kelly conceived. For the round of I.V.F. that finally worked, moreover, both of my friends decided to harvest eggs. The clinic then transferred the two best resulting embryos, one from each woman, to increase Kellys odds of conceiving.

title: Israel Parliament Elects Ex-Speaker as President to Succeed Peres
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli Parliament on Tuesday elected Reuven Rivlin, a veteran Likud Party politician and former minister and Parliament speaker, as the countrys next president, ending what many here described as the most unseemly race in Israels history for what is largely a ceremonial post.

title: The Pundits and the President
description: This seems to be the season for centrist Obama-bashing. Hes ineffectual, were told, a drag on his party, Democrats are complaining (although none on the record), and so on.

title: How Has Parenthood Informed Your Writing Life?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Mohsin Hamid discuss how fatherhood has influenced their work.

title: Police Statements Cloud Alleged Rape and Murder Case, Analysts Say
description: In the span of two weeks, the Indian police have offered different versions of the alleged rape and murder of two cousins in Uttar Pradesh State who were found hanging from a tree on May 28, in an event that invited widespread censure of the state government and a rebuke from the United Nations in India, as well as a statement from its secretary general, Ban Ki-moon.

title: Despite Clash in Ukraine, Cease-Fire Talks Advance
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  The foreign ministers of Russia, Poland and Germany on Tuesday signaled progress toward a cease-fire in Ukraine, even as up to 40 separatists were reported to have been killed in a fierce battle for control of an airport in the east of the country.

title: The Rabbi Cardinal OConnor Never Knew: His Grandfather
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  In his 16 years as the Catholic Churchs top official in New York, Cardinal John Joseph OConnor was a staunch friend and defender of the Jewish people.

title: Bosnias Cup Debut Turns Part of St. Louis Into Sarajevo West
description: ST. LOUIS  The whiteboard propped on the sidewalk read Sretno Zmajevi, or Good Luck Dragons, referring to the nickname for the Bosnian national soccer team. And the message rippled down the street.

title: Banksy Confesses: He Made the Eavesdropping Mural
description: LONDON  In a rare exchange with the public, the elusive graffiti artist Banksy has acknowledged painting a mural depicting secret agents eavesdropping on a telephone booth, which appeared in April in the city of Cheltenham, where one of Britains intelligence agencies has its headquarters.

title: Walkabout: Transit Strike Threatens to Disrupt World Cup
description: Cup Half-FullWith the World Cup set to start in So Paulo on Thursday, Brazil is facing the latest in a series of obstacles and frustrations in hosting the games:a transit strikein the city that threatens to disrupt the opening. (BBC)

title: Found Poem Favorite | Born Alive
description: This poem, by Joanna Gerber, is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest. It comes from a Science article, Space Ripples Reveal Big Bangs Smoking Gun.

title: In Shareholder Address, G.M. Chief Vows Safety
description: DETROIT  General Motors chief executive, Mary T. Barra, told shareholders on Tuesday that the company was making major changes in its operations in the wake of an internal investigation of its recall of defective small cars.

title: After 7 Months, British Hacking Case Heads to the Jury
description: LONDON  With one of Britains most riveting trials  a seven-month courtroom marathon that exposed the inner workings of the tabloid news media and the personal lives of two friends of the prime minister  nearing its conclusion, the judge gave this reminder to the jury: No one is so powerful they can ignore the law.

title: New Works and Programming by Laurie Anderson to Highlight New York Live Arts Season
description: Commissioned works by Kyle Abraham and RoseAnne Spradlin, among others, as well as the third annual Live Ideas mini-festival, to be programmed by the composer Laurie Anderson, are among the highlights of the 2014-15 season at New York Live Arts, the Chelsea dance theater directed by the choreographer Bill T. Jones. The season, which Mr. Jones announced Tuesday, will include 71 performances by more than 22 artists and ensembles, including the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company.

title: Does Obamas Unpopularity Matter?
description: My last postoffered 1400 words in response to a Jonathan Chait tweet; now let me offer a few more in response to his actual rebuttal tomy recent columnon why the Democrats need Hillary Clinton to hold their presidential majority together. Here, fromhis latest post, is a two-part argument that Im overstating the significance of President Obamas stuck-in-the-40s approval ratings for his partys fortunes in 2016. First, because of the Republicans:

title: Chobanis Science Lesson
description: The Greek yogurt company Chobani raised hackles last week with a message under some of its lids that read, Nature got us to 100 calories, not scientists. #howmatters. The company hasapologized, but some scientists say the controversy suggests something bigger about anti-science sentiment in America.

title: Ukrainians Find Jobs and a Slice of Russia in Arctic Norway
description: BARENTSBURG, Norway  While scientists up here in the high Arctic monitor global warming by studying the movement of polar bears, ice floes and glaciers, Nikolai Mikitenko tracks the meltdown in Ukraine, the land of his birth more than 2,000 miles away, through the migration of desperate coal miners.

title: Hong Kong Rebel Loses His Trademark Long Hair
description: No matter what he did to the laws  making them as a legislator in the somber wooden chamber of Hong Kongs Legislative Council, or breaking them when he burst into a room to disrupt a public forum  Leung Kwok-hungs long unkempt hair had been a constant in his decade as one of the citys most animated legislators. That was, until his hair was cut short on Monday.

title: In Store | At Rachel Comeys New SoHo Flagship, Form Follows Fashion
description: It is fitting that Rachel Comey, who hosts intimate dinner parties rather than runway shows during fashion week, has chosen to open her first brick-and-mortar outpost just downstairs from her own SoHo apartment next door. The downtown designer with a cult following has a knack for keeping things personal  and for not taking fashion too seriously. Its important for the store to be a tad funny, she says. Indeed, the buzz surrounding the shop  which her most ardent followers have been hoping and wishing for for the past 13 years  has been on overdrive since Comey released a photo of a cheeky flag, painted with the help of her good friend Leanne Shapton, hanging outside the then-raw space on Crosby Street. It poked fun at the storefronts mainstream-Manhattan neighbors: SoulCycle, Jamba Juice and Duane Reade.

title: Rangers Create Bounces; L.A. Kings Jonathan Quick Swats Them Away
description: As the puck bounced tantalizingly near what seemed like an open net and a sure chance at a goal in Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals Monday, Rangers forward Mats Zuccarellos stick took an extra microsecond to make contact with it. He was in perfect position, poised to make all the overwrought pregame buildup seem valid, primed to make Madison Square Garden erupt, ready to determine both teams fortunes.

title: Trial of South Korean Ferry Crew Begins
description: GWANGJU, South Korea  The captain and 14 other crew members of the South Korean ferry that sank in April, leaving 304 people dead or missing, went on trial here on Tuesday. The defendants faced the anger of victims relatives at the courthouse, where senior crew members denied the homicide charges against them.

title: Appreciating the Flavors of West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  Michael Ratney, the United States consul general here, is a fan of the television show Chopped, in which cooks must whip up an appetizer, entre and dessert from baskets of disparate, often unpalatable, ingredients. So for a dinner party last week, Mr. Ratney gave the consulates Swiss-born chef, Ursula Imran al Sous, a challenge: Make a menu out of items from West Bank purveyors that Washington underwrites.

title: Reporters Notebook: Palestinian Feast
description: To celebrate the diversity of Palestinian products grown on the West Bank, Americas top diplomat to the region prepared a feast inspired by the Chopped television Series.

title: Baby Got Back Story: Sir Mix-a-Lot Was an Early Interactive Success
description: Before Sir Mix-a-Lot broke through to the pop charts in 1992, hed found some success on the rap charts with his first two albums, Swass and Seminar. But his label, Def American, struggled to get widespread airplay in promoting his third album, Mack Daddy. The first single they released, One Times Got No Case, went nowhere. Increasing their efforts for the second single, Baby Got Back, the label reached out to the Box, a cable network that played music videos based on viewer requests on the telephone. As Sheila Rule wrote in The New York Times:

title: Children at the Border
description: More than a few online commenters were annoyed, angered or exasperated by an editorial last week, Children on the Run, which told of the recent surge of tens of thousands young migrants being caught at the southern border. These children, many of them traveling alone, are straining the Border Patrols resources and prompting the Obama administration to take urgent steps to ease what looks to us like a refugee crisis, but to others like an invasion.

title: Recording the Polar Bears View of its Changing Arctic Environment
description: I first encountered the wildlife filmmaker Adam Ravetch in 2007 when writing about Arctic Tale, a film on polar bears and walruses that he co-directed for National Geographic in 2007 and which meshed fictional storytelling and astonishing imagery.

title: Incentives and Technology
description: The invaluable Mark Thoma leads me to this post attacking what I thought was a totally obvious takedown of Roger Pielke Jr.. In general, reading attacks on oneself should be done in very limited doses, but in this case I learned something  namely, that what I assumed was obvious apparently isnt to everyone.

title: Voter Fraud Is Rare, but Myth Is Widespread
description: Is vote fraud common in American politics? Not according to United States District Judge Lynn Adelman, who examined the evidence from Wisconsin and ruled in late April that virtually no voter impersonation occurs in the state and that no evidence suggests that voter-impersonation fraud will become a problem at any time in the foreseeable future.

title: Image of the Day: June 10
Czech Pawns In a System That Stifled
description: On Aug. 20, 1968, Warsaw Pact troops led by the Soviet Union invaded Czechoslovakia, putting a violent end to the reformist socialist experiment known as the Prague Spring. The following winter, a student named Jan Palach set himself on fire in Wenceslas Square, an act of protest that is the starting point of Burning Bush, Agnieszka Hollands thoughtful, gripping, crisply acted new film.

title: Today in Small Business: Managing People Who Hate Each Other
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Bergdahl Briefing Fails to Allay Senators Doubts
description: WASHINGTON  Senators emerged Tuesday from a classified, closed-door briefing on the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl seemingly less convinced than ever about the wisdom of swapping five high-level Taliban prisoners for the Army soldier after he spent years in captivity.

title: Sex in Assisted Living: Intimacy Without Privacy
description: Trulah Goin Mills had developed dementia and couldnt be left alone in the house, but when she and her husband, Lewis, moved into an assisted living facility in Boise, Idaho, in 2012, one lifelong quality remained intact.

title: Euronexts I.P.O. Will Be a Tough Sell
description: Euronexts initial public offering looks like a tough sell. The firm is seeking a valuation of 1.3 billion euros to 1.8 billion euros when it floats later this month. Anchor investors have a vested interest in backing the issue. But for other buyers, it is a leap of faith.

title: Gail Collins Responds to Readers: Congress Versus Hobbit
description: Gail Collins, Op-Ed columnist, answered a few questions posed by commenters about her latest column, Congress Versus Hobbit.

title: You Can Skip the Fitting, Mom
description: IN THE DECADE-PLUS since the psychologist Barry Schwartz published his oft-cited book The Paradox of Choice: Why More is Less, the options available to the American bride have increased beyond measure. She can legally marry another woman in many states. She can skip the whole wedding racket entirely, in protest or preoccupation or boredom, and suffer no social stigma whatsoever. Or  and this is a hedge I have observed among many urban millennials  she can sort of back up slowly, shruggingly, consciously down the aisle: save the blood-diamond money for a down payment on a Clinton Hill condominium; hire friends to do the organic catering; and buy her frock, perhaps in electric-blue, from Etsy or similar.

title: Commodities Regulator Names New Enforcement Chief
description: Updated, 7:45 p.m. | Wall Streets smallest regulator has hired a big-name enforcement director.

title: Excerpt: Just Jim Dale
description: A scene from the actors one-man show, at the Laura Pels Theater, about his varied career in show business.

title: Disgraced Will Reach Broadway, Though Without Aasif Mandvi
description: Ayad Akhtars blistering play Disgraced, which had a critically acclaimed Off Broadway run in 2012 and won the Pulitzer Prize for drama the next year, will open on Broadway this fall at the Lyceum Theater, one of the lead producers, Matthew Rego, confirmed on Tuesday.

title: Wheelies: The Average Age Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Fans Wait Hours to See Hillary Clinton at Book Signing
description: Andre Morales, a 36-year-old from Brooklyn, arrived before 3 a.m. Tuesday and planned to ask Hillary Rodham Clinton how it felt to work for President Obama after he had defeated her in the 2008 Democratic primary.

title: Arms Windfall for Insurgents as Iraq City Falls
description: The insurgent fighters who routed the Iraqi army out of Mosul on Tuesday did not just capture much of Iraqs second-largest city. They also gained a windfall of arms, munitions and equipment abandoned by the soldiers as they fled  arms that were supplied by the United States and intended to give the troops an edge over the insurgents.

title: European Antitrust Authorities Contend That ICAP Colluded to Rig Rates
description: BRUSSELS  The European Commission is accusing the British financial firm ICAP of collusion, saying it tried to fix a benchmark interest rate tied to the yen.

title: Health Officials Call for More Fish in Diets of Children and Pregnant Women
description: Federal officials on Tuesday announced that they would recommend for the first time that women who are pregnant or breast-feeding and young children eat a minimum of two servings of low-mercury seafood every week for their health.

title: City Settles Occupy Protesters False-Arrest Lawsuit
description: The City of New York has agreed to pay nearly $600,000 to resolve a lawsuit accusing police officers of falsely arresting Occupy Wall Street participants who were walking on a sidewalk in the East Village on New Years Day 2012.

title: Tracy Morgans New Series Is Still a Go Whenever He Recovers, FX Says
description: The FX cable networks affirmed their commitment on Tuesday to the injured comedian Tracy Morgan, saying that a new series announced earlier in the spring to star Mr. Morgan would still be waiting for him when he recovers from his injuries.

title: Markets Are Less Volatile. Should We Worry?
description: If the stock market was a person, right now it would be a supremely easygoing retiree on the beach in Key West drinking a pia colada. Mr. Market is very, very relaxed.

title: Judge Rejects Teacher Tenure for California
description: LOS ANGELES  A California judge ruled Tuesday that teacher tenure laws deprived students of their right to an education under the State Constitution and violated their civil rights. The decision hands teachers unions a major defeat in a landmark case, one that could radically alter how California teachers are hired and fired and prompt challenges to tenure laws in other states.

title: Cherche Midi Opens
description: Headliner

title: Turning to National Front, but Keeping a Distance
description: BOHAIN-EN-VERMANDOIS, France  Armand Pollet, the representative of the far-right National Front in this struggling, largely rural town in the north, sat back in his leather easy chair recently and smiled with satisfaction, declaring that his party was now locked in place as Frances third mainstream party.

title: A Bouillabaisse Dinner, Halvah Spreads and More
description: To Share: A Bouillabaisse Dinner Is Quite a Catch

title: Knicks, in Selecting Fisher, Take a Different Approach
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Derek Fisher conceded Tuesday, as he was introduced as the new coach of the Knicks, that he had no experience as a coach at any level. He did not dismiss the empty lines on his rsum, but then again it hardly seemed to matter to the man who hired him, the Knicks new president, Phil Jackson, who won 11 N.B.A. titles as a coach.

title: Google to Buy Skybox Imaging for $500 Million
description: Updated, 3:57 p.m. | Google agreed on Tuesday to buy Skybox Imaging, a provider of high-quality satellite images, for $500 million, as the technology giant continues to work on fulfilling its lofty ambitions for its Internet offerings.

title: A Legislative Assault on the Financial Stability Oversight Council
description: Two new bills are pending in the House that relate to the Financial Stability Oversight Council and its ability to designate which parts of the financial system are too big to fail and thus in need of greater regulatory scrutiny. Both show how political the entire issue has become.

title: Ireland Investigating Complaints Against Unwed Mother Homes
description: DUBLIN  The Irish government said Tuesday it would begin an investigation into allegations of neglect and criminality at so-called mother-and-baby homes over several decades.

title: Disapproval of Obama Doesnt Mean Long-Term Trouble for Democrats
description: The Democratic coalition is thought to have an advantage in national elections, but President Obamas approval ratings have sagged into the low-to-mid 40s. Its possible that his weak approval ratings are a sign of weakness in the Democratic coalition, as Ross Douthat, a New York Times columnist, argued on Sunday. Low presidential approval ratings can presage the collapse of a political coalition, like the fall of the Republican coalition in the last years of the George W. Bush administration.

title: 1956: Elvis Is Introduced to the Nation
description: This feature looks at the first time famous names or terms appeared in The Times. Have an idea for someone or something you would like to read about? Send a suggestion in the comments section.

title: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 2
description: The 2014 World Cup begins Thursday, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times have counted down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

title: Oregon Shooting Draws Obamas Outrage on Gun Laws
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, speaking hours after a gunman killed a student and wounded a teacher at an Oregon high school, said Tuesday that his failure to push through stricter gun laws was the greatest frustration of his presidency, declaring, Were the only developed country on earth where this happens.

title: From the I.R.S., a Taxpayer Bill of Rights
description: The Internal Revenue Service has been accused of a lot of things, but being user-friendly is not usually one of them.

title: E.U. Official Criticizes U.S. Move Against Norwegian Air
description: BRUSSELS  The European Unions top transport official expressed deep disappointment on Tuesday with an attempt by American lawmakers to block plans by Norwegian Air Shuttle to offer new cut-rate flights across the Atlantic, and hinted at possible legal action if Washington failed to grant an operating license to the budget carriers long-distance subsidiary.

title: Alabama and Mississippi Voted Last Week. No Official Results Yet.
description: A week after primary elections in eight states, two of them  Alabama and Mississippi  have not posted any results on an official state government website. The two stand alone among states that held primaries on June 3 in not publishing any results in a central location. California, Iowa, Montana, South Dakota, New Mexico and New Jersey had unofficial election-night results sites, in many cases updated live on election night.

title: Trickle-Down Fragrances
description: Perfume lovers can now buy a deeply scented bottle of a new eau de toilette, blended with natural oils of sandalwood and jasmine absolute sambac, both imported from India, formulated by the French-trained perfumer who has worked on scents from luxurious niche brands like Atelier Cologne, which last year introduced a pair of fragrances in sleek glass bottles infused with either gold or silver, retailing at $195.

title: Chris Christie Spares No Legal Expense
description: Anyone who slogged through the 344-page report on Bridgegate from New Jersey Gov. Chris Christies lawyers in March understood that this old fashioned whitewash would be extremely expensive.The governor hired one of the nations big time law firms, Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, which dutifully declared that Gov. Christie was not to blame for the massive traffic jams last year. Those problems were the work of others, the report insisted. The governors hands were clean.

title: A Glimpse (and a Taste) of Celebrity
description: Gato galloped into town in March, pursued by the food media and Bobby Flay fans in a thundering cloud of hoofbeats. The first new restaurant Mr. Flay and his business partner, Laurence Kretchmer, have opened in New York City in nearly a decade, Gato is nominally Mediterranean, but the chef rides herd on pastas and pizzas and romesco sauces with a go-for-broke intensity thats 100 percent American. Mr. Flay brushes flavor on his ingredients in thick impasto strokes, making each plate a three-dimensional aggregation of char, smoke, capsicum, sugar, acid and fat. The cooking at Gato is many things, often all at the same time, but it is rarely shy.

title: 2014: Clinton Fans at a Book Signing
description: Supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton waited in line at the Barnes & Noble in Union Square for Mrs. Clintons first book signing on a nationwide tour to promote her new memoir.

title: Unexpected Love Stories
description: Like his hero, Johnny Cash, hes a man in black: weathered Levis, motorcycle boots, a T-shirt with a box of cigarettes straining the chest pocket. A long-ago rock star who toured the world but never managed to get rich, Dale arrives to crash at his sons Morningside Heights apartment like a leftover from a more analog time. Broke and unemployed, he has no idea how to navigate a world ruled by technology.

title: Tony Awards Face Criticism Over In Memoriam Segment
description: What happened to the In Memoriam segment of the Tony Awards?

title: Delay Urged on Actions Tied to Tests by Schools
description: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, one of the countrys largest donors to educational causes and a strong backer of the academic guidelines known as the Common Core, has called for a two-year moratorium on states or school districts making any high-stakes decisions based on tests aligned with the new standards.

title: Q. and A. | Banks on Tapping Into Her Inner Goddess
description: Early press on Jillian Banks, the 25-year-old songstress who goes simply by Banks, focused largely on how little was actually known about her. The Los Angeles native seemed to appear out of nowhere, dropping a song, Before I Ever Met You, on Soundcloud in early 2013 to huge acclaim, and appearing in only a handful of photos in which her dark, searching eyes and model-like cheekbones were hidden in shadow or behind her long brown hair. At a time when many of her peers were blasting out songs about their famous exes and tipping off TMZ to their whereabouts, Banks was  quite literally  shrouded in obscurity. (Appropriately, the singer showed up for her interview with T clad in head-to-toe black, hair hanging over her face.)

title: Beach Volleyball for All at a California Hotel
description: Fairmont Miramar Hotel & Bungalows, a 302-room property in Santa Monica, Calif., is holding its third annual Vilebrequin Beach Volleyball Games.

title: To Aid the Blind, an Assist From Cameras
description: In two labs some 50 miles apart in Israel, computer scientists and engineers are refining devices that employ tiny cameras as translators of sorts. For both teams, the goal is to give blind people a form of sight  or at least an experience analogous to sight.

title: Obamas Moments of Freedom Send His Aides Scrambling
description: WASHINGTON  The bear was loose again on Tuesday.

title: Egypts Inaction on Sexual Attacks Stirs Fury
description: CAIRO  Rape victims and womens rights advocates lashed out on Tuesday at the escalating attempts by the Egyptian government and news media to dismiss a plague of sexual assaults more than three years after the Arab Spring uprising began to expose the scale of the problem.

title: Families Flee Mosul Amid Gunfire
description: Thousands of residents fled Mosul in northern Iraq after the city was seized by militants belonging to the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, an extremist group.

title: A.I.G. Names Successor to Benmosche, Who Nursed It Through Fiscal Crisis
description: Updated, 8:29 p.m. | The American International Group on Tuesday named a successor to Robert H. Benmosche, the insurers chief executive and the voluble leader who oversaw its recovery from the financial crisis.

title: Keep Your Government Hands Off My Cheese
description: Cheese, or at least all good cheese, arises out of the mysterious mating of milk, enzymes and bacteria, and federal bureaucrats do not take kindly to either mysteries or germs. This week, a few of those bureaucrats horrified cheese-eaters across the country by banning cheese that is ripened or aged on wooden boards, apparently unaware that they are upsetting the natural rhythms of the universe.

title: The Grandfather Gets Busted
description: The D.E.A. spent months investigating the Sinaloa cartels operation in the Detroit area and tracking their most prolific drug mule: Leo Sharp, a World War II veteran with no criminal record.

title: A Health Insurer Calls, With Questions
description: Not long after she signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, Judy Shoemaker received a phone call that puzzled her.

title: Do You Speak Tech?
description: The tech industrys influence on where people can live and how they spend their time is well documented. Now it may be influencing the way we talk as well.

title: Marketing Dominos in the Lunchroom
description: Companies like Dominos are making more healthful versions of their food to sell in schools, prompting concerns about the use of brands in the school lunch line.

title: Appeals Court Rules Bloomberg Plan for Taxi of Tomorrow Is Legal
description: A state appeals court on Tuesday ruled that a plan for a nearly uniform fleet of yellow taxis in New York City was legal, reversing a lower-court ruling and resuscitating a program initially enacted under the Bloomberg administration but opposed by Mayor Bill de Blasio.

title: The Dominos Smart Slice Goes to School
description: Given the current uproar over new federal rules aimed at getting schoolchildren to eat more healthfully, you might think fast food was an endangered species on the cafeteria line. But Dominos is delivering a pizza it calls the Smart Slice to more than 3,000 lunchrooms in 38 states, up from 3 states in 2010. And one force driving those sales is the new rules themselves. These pies contain fewer of the worrisome ingredients found in regular pizzas. But they also give the students a hefty dose of marketing for the Dominos brand, and many other companies are following the same path to the lunchroom.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

title: G.M. Chief on Ignition Switch Problems
description: Mary T. Barra, General Motors chief executive, spoke at a news conference ahead of the annual shareholders meeting.

title: In Ireland, 10 Years of Fresh Air
description: On the morning of March 29, 2004, global television crews gathered outside a Dublin restaurant stocked with celebrating lawmakers to witness what few thought possible in this welcoming land of brilliant but noxious pubs.

title: Restaurant Review: The Rest in Salt Lake City
description: Along a once humdrum stretch of Main Street in Salt Lake City, tucked behind a storefront called Bodega  a half ramshackle corner store, half taco-peddling beer tavern  is this subterranean speakeasy, the Rest.

title: Reading List  | The Top 100 Best-Selling Education Books of 2014 (So Far)
description: The book trailer for The End of Your Life Book Club, No. 67 on our list.

title: From Cocktails to Kimchi in Los Angeless Koreatown
description: With Koreans making up more than a quarter of the immigrants who live in Los Angeless Koreatown, that cultural flavor is palpable in the neighborhoods remarkable concentration of late-night restaurants, bars and clubs. Thanks to the recent arrival of the Line Hotel in Koreatown  a design-minded homage to all things Korean, and to the street-cool sensibilities of K-town  a whole new audience is getting an introduction to city greats that have long been under the radar: croon-worthy karaoke joints, meticulously frothed cappuccinos, fiery grocery kimchi, some of the best Korean barbecue anywhere. A spate of new businesses (a speakeasy here, a microbrewery there) has only added to the areas energetic night life.

title: Hotel Review: Heywood Hotel in Austin, Tex.
description: Rates

title: At E3, Nintendo Unveils a Mario World Designed by You
description: If you have ever played the first Super Mario Bros., the influential video game from the 80s, you have probably also ventured into the many subsequent games and levels for Mario created by Nintendo.

title: Beethoven Thats Not for Bruisers
description: The fourth of Beethovens five piano concertos is the only one that begins with the soloist playing alone. The melody is a statement with the nobility of a Greek temple, a quiet expanse broken only by a playful little burst of a scale, like a giggle atop the Acropolis at sunrise.

title: Beatles Sing in German, and a Nazi Flag Waves
description: LOS ANGELES  The Nazis, those perpetual video game villains who seemed to have been felled in recent years by a virulent zombie contagion, are back. Nothing that has been announced here this week at the Electronic Entertainment Expo, the annual video game trade show better known as E3, has been as surprising or delightful  granted, an odd word to apply to the return of National Socialism  as the recent emergence of a new Wolfenstein game as one of the very best releases of the year.

title: The Last Gun Report
description: Last Thursday, Jennifer Mascia and I posted our last Gun Report. It was my feeling that although it had been a useful tool  a daily statement about gun violence in America  The Gun Report had run its course. During the year and change that we published it, readers got a close-up look at the many forms gun violence takes  the horrifying incidents involving children shooting other children; the drive-by shootings; the shootings that result from a moments rage; and so on. There werent just one or two shootings each day; there were 30 or more. On weekends, the carnage was horrific. The Gun Report also became a place where gun proponents and gun opponents could voice their views in the comment section.

title: O. J. and the White Bronco Ride Again
description: Beginning last fall, we seem to have entered a 12-month period heavy with anniversaries, which allows us to pause and ask: Why observe them? Perhaps to note a traumatic moment in history (the 50th of President John F. Kennedys assassination) or a turning point (the 50th of the Civil Rights Act and Freedom Summer). Perhaps to commemorate heroism (the 70th of D-Day). Perhaps to relish a cultural sea change (the 50th of the Beatles on The Ed Sullivan Show; the 45th of Woodstock).

title: A Justice Alone, Even if Surrounded
description: Last fall the pugilistic Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia gave an interview to Jennifer Senior in New York Magazine so playful and revealing that the transcript could nearly be made into a stage play and movie, in the manner of Frost/Nixon.

title: Cold War Spy or Just Wife?
description: In Ethel Sings: The Unsung Song of Ethel Rosenberg, the playwright Joan Beber issues a posthumous pardon to Ethel Rosenberg, executed for conspiring to commit espionage in 1953.

title: Seeing Red in the Gene Pool
description: Redhead deposits arent wanted at the worlds largest sperm bank, leading a photographer to document gingers in all their blazing, freckled varieties.

title: A Symphonys Viral Video
description: The Seattle Symphony commissioned the piece that won this years Pulitzer Prize for music, Become Ocean, by John Luther Adams. But it is a late-20th-century work that is bringing the orchestra broader fame this week: its performance with Sir Mix-A-Lot of his bawdy song Baby Got Back, which by Tuesday had been seen more than 1.5 million times on YouTube.

title: Colombia Says It Has Begun Peace Talks With Rebels
description: The government of Colombia announced on Tuesday that it had begun exploratory peace talks with a second rebel group, just days ahead of a hotly contested presidential election that could hinge on how voters perceive the efforts of President Juan Manuel Santos to end decades of guerrilla warfare.

title: Hong Kong Regulators Tense About China Loans
description: Updated, 8:25 p.m. | A surge in business loans to the slowing mainland Chinese economy has prompted Hong Kong regulators to impose strict financial rules four years before they are required under new global standards.

title: The Heroines Retinue as a Magical Force Field
description: Frederick Ashtons three-act Cinderella (1948) is a story of hope fulfilled, a comedy of contrasting characters and a classical ballet dense with sensuous movement. Though New York has been having a Cinderellathon in 2014  the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical on Broadway, and Rossinis La Cenerentola at the Metropolitan Opera and Massenets Cendrillon at Juilliard Opera, both in April  this treatment of the old fairy tale takes the prize for dramatic poetry. Still, it looked a pale echo of itself on Monday when it joined American Ballet Theaters repertory.

title: Pictures of the Day: Germany and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Germany, New York, Pakistan and Italy.

title: A Season for the Blossoming of Hopes and Talents
description: Infectious passion for dancing has been the special thrill of New York City Ballet since the start of this year, and during the spring season that ended on Sunday the level kept rising. The sheer danciness of Alexei Ratmanskys Namouna: A Grand Divertissement on opening night was irresistible. Justin Pecks new Everywhere We Go, the seasons big premiere, had weak aspects, yet just look at how its cast was dancing its heart out! No wonder it won ovations.

title: Oracles Database of Youth
description: Lawrence J. Ellison may have figured out a secret to seeming young: Ignore getting older, and act cutting-edge.

title: Pentagon on Friendly Fire Strike
description: The Pentagon press secretary, Rear Adm. John Kirby, said five American troops were killed during a security operation in southern Afghanistan.

title: Hillary Rodham Clinton and the Power of Style
description: THIS WEEKS PUBLICATION of Hillary Rodham Clintons Hard Choices has proved a predictably exciting opportunity for Clintonologists, 2016 election obsessives and pundits everywhere to revisit all sorts of issues that otherwise may have been considered, if not resolved, at least over  from the questions surrounding the couples marriage to Mrs. Clintons relationship with President Obama to the whole hair brouhaha.

title: A Genre Dabbler Gets His Accolades
description: Donovan Leitch  or just Donovan, as he became known  might have become a painter instead of a musician. As he tells it, he was considering arts school when he decided, instead, to take his guitar and hitchhike to London, where he began performing as a folk singer. By 1965 he had won a following, as well as recording and publishing contracts, with ballads like Catch the Wind and Colors, guitar-accompanied folk songs similar to one Bob Dylan was writing  not surprisingly since they were both drawing from the large well of English, Irish, Scottish and American folk melodies.

title: Art Matters | The Second Life of Performance
description: Once left behind by the competitive market, live art is now everywhere  thanks in large part to its staunchest advocate, RoseLee Goldberg.

title: Why So Many World Cup Fans Dislike Argentina
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Argentina has one of the most successful national soccer teams in the world, and the country has won the World Cup twice, in 1978 and 1986. In this years tournament, the team ranks among the most formidable competitors, with Brazils coach, Luiz Felipe Scolari, even predicting a final showdown with Argentina.

title: World Cups Most Pessimistic Country: England?
description: The most downcast soccer fans in the world  relative to the quality of their national team  are the citizens of England.

title: Australias Odd World Cup Optimism
description: The Socceroos, as the Australian national soccer team are known, enter the World Cup ranked by FIFA as the 62nd-best team in the world, the lowest standing of any of the 32 teams that earned a slot. Theyve also been dealt the toughest possible draw, facing not only the reigning champions and runners-up in their group, but also highly rated Chile. No wonder oddsmakers give the Aussies less than a 1-in-2,500 chance of winning the tournament.

title: Morgan Stanley Sees Itself as Two Firms in One
description: The more risk-averse Morgan Stanley that has emerged since the financial crisis may tell a tale of two Wall Streets. But it may also tell a tale of two businesses within the bank.

title: World Cup Opinions in 19 Countries: Likes, Dislikes, Predictions
description: Argentina, the United States and Iran appear to be the most disliked World Cup teams. Brazilian fans enter the World Cup as the most confident, though Argentines and Spaniards arent far behind in their home-country optimism. And fans across many countries agree that the Brazilians play the most attractive form of soccer.

title: Methodology of World Cup Study
description: The study of public opinion about the World Cup is based on 19,780 interviews conducted by YouGov in 19 countries between May 19 and June 2. YouGov conducted the interviews online, after selecting respondents from opt-in panels recruited by YouGov or its partners.

title: European Tech Start-Ups Pay Off for Index Ventures
description: LONDON  The European venture capital firm Index Ventures has been on a roll.

title: Endowment Chief to Exit at Harvard
description: Jane L. Mendillo, the manager of Harvards $32.7 billion endowment, plans to step down by the end of the year, the university said on Tuesday.

title: Detroit Denies Last-Minute Reprieve for Goats
description: The hedge fund manager Mark Spitznagel has been denied a last-minute reprieve for his guerrilla urban farming project.

title: More Lands of Fantasy
description: As Game of Thrones obsessives grimace and wait for George R. R. Martins next novel, The Winds of Winter, he and his publisher, the Bantam imprint of Random House, are tossing fans a couple of dragon bones.

title: A Lethal Culture of Secrecy at G.M.
Economic Growth and the Failure to Cut Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Glimpses of Mosul in Islamist Hands on YouTube
description: Video uploaded to YouTube on Tuesday appeared to offer glimpses of Iraqs second-largest city, Mosul, in the hands of Islamist militants after the sudden retreat of Iraqi Army soldiers.

title: The Use of Child Soldiers
description: To the Editor:

title: Cold Winter and Ukraine Lead to Lower Global Growth Forecast
description: WASHINGTON  The World Bank has downgraded its estimate of the worlds economic expansion in a new forecast released Tuesday, with developing economies posting disappointing growth rates and the frigid winter in the United States and the crisis in Ukraine weighing on growth, too.

title: Change at Housing Agency
Colleges Focus on Alcohol and Drugs as Serious Crime Dips
description: Colleges have become more aggressive about punishing alcohol and drug offenses, even as the rate of serious crime on campuses has dropped, according to a government report released Tuesday.

title: Knicks Name Derek Fisher as Coach
description: Phil Jackson, the New York Knicks president, and Derek Fisher, their new coach, spoke after Mr. Fisher was hired to replace Mike Woodson.

title: Privately Run Jails
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Shoppers Change Hong Kong Border Area
description: HONG KONG  Smoking a cigarette outside a mall in the border town of Sheung Shui, a man who gave his name only as Chen stands next to a wheeled cart filled with purchases. He is visiting from the Chinese city of Shantou, 177 miles away, a trip he makes several times a year.

title: A V.A. Doctors View
description: To the Editor:

title: Target Hires an Outsider as Its Data Watchdog
description: Target named a seasoned security expert as its new chief information security officer on Tuesday, on the eve of its annual shareholders meeting, as the retailer sought to bolster its data defenses and calm investor chagrin after the extensive hacking it experienced last year.

title: Amazon Stops Taking Advance Orders for Lego and Other Warner Videos
description: The Everything Store is shrinking again. Amazon customers who want to order forthcoming Warner Home Video features, including The Lego Movie, 300: Rise of an Empire, Winters Tale and Transcendence, are finding it impossible to do so.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT LEASE

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,311 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: A Bellwether for London Realty
description: LONDON  When the global bank HSBC sold its London headquarters tower to a Spanish buyer in spring 2007, at the height of the credit and property boom, the deal was the single largest real estate transaction in British history.

title: Holder Criticizes Ban on Gay Boy Scout Leaders
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Tuesday sharply criticized the Boy Scouts of Americas policy that bans gay scout leaders, calling it a relic of an age of prejudice and insufficient understanding. In remarks to the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, a gay-rights group, Mr. Holder said, The continuation of a policy that discriminates against gay adult leaders, by an iconic American institution, only preserves and perpetuates the worst kind of stereotypes. There is little Mr. Holder can do to oppose the policy. The Supreme Court ruled in 2000 that the Boy Scouts have a constitutional right to ban gay members.

title: Sports Should Be Childs Play
description: THE national furor over concussions misses the primary scourge that is harming kids and damaging youth sports in America.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: What Causes Weight Gain
description: If I ask you what constitutes bad eating, the kind that leads to obesity and a variety of connected diseases, youre likely to answer, Salt, fat and sugar. This trilogy of evil has been drilled into us for decades, yet thats not an adequate answer.

title: Bloomberg Hires Jacki Kelley, Ad Executive, for Media Business
description: Bloomberg has hired a senior advertising executive, Jacki Kelley, as chief operating officer of its media business, the company announced on Tuesday, its latest hire from outside journalism as it seeks to transform its business under new leadership.

title: Official Backs Marines Move to Classify Photos of Forces With Taliban Bodies
description: WASHINGTON  In an apparent expansion of the governments secrecy powers, the top official in charge of the classification system has decided that it was legitimate for the Marines to classify photographs that showed American forces posing with corpses of Taliban fighters in Afghanistan.

title: Eric Cantor Defeated by David Brat, Tea Party Challenger, in G.O.P. Primary Upset
description: WASHINGTON  In one of the most stunning primary election upsets in congressional history, the House majority leader, Eric Cantor, was soundly defeated on Tuesday by a Tea Party-backed economics professor who had hammered him for being insufficiently conservative.

title: Erez Itzhaki
description: Mr. Itzhaki, 44, is a principal of Itzhaki Acquisitions, a real estate development company formerly known as the Keystone Group. His company is involved in boutique condominium projects, including Modern 19 in Chelsea, and is a partner with the developer Michael Shvo and others on a development planned in SoHo.

title: F.C.C. Chief Plans Action on Wi-Fi in Schools
description: WASHINGTON  Visiting a middle school in Oakland earlier this year, Tom Wheeler, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, got a glimpse of just how badly American schools need better high-speed Internet connections.

title: Music Industry Officials Agree on Need for Licensing Rule Changes, but Little Else
description: The complex system of music licensing came under attack in a congressional hearing on Tuesday, as entertainment and media executives pleaded for changes to how music rights were acquired and paid for online and by radio and television stations.

title: One Key to Success: A Belief in a Future
description: CHICAGO  Tim Jacksons job is to convince young people that they have a stake in the future.

title: Officials Assigned for World Cup Opener
description: Yuichi Nishimura, 42, of Japan, will be the referee for the World Cups opening match on Thursday night, when Brazil plays Croatia in So Paolo. Toru Sagara and Toshiyuki Nagi, also of Japan, will be the linesmen, and Alireza Faghani of Iran was assigned to be the fourth official.

title: Merkel Cites Threats in Warning to Cameron
description: BERLIN  German-British tensions over who should next lead the European Union appeared to heighten on Tuesday as Chancellor Angela Merkel delivered a scarcely veiled rebuke to Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, warning that threats will not work as the 28 members struggle to mend new fissures in their unity aggravated by European Parliament elections last month.

title: Getting a Kiehls Product Into a Mans Orbit
description: THE market for mens personal care products grew 15 percent from 2008 to 2013, according to Mintel, a market research firm. But while a makeup brand introducing a new mascara can seek publicity from countless beauty publications and bloggers, mens brands face a hurdle: Although men are buying products like face scrub and anti-aging cream, they are not reading extensively about the items or trading grooming tips on the golf course.

title: After Rough-Hewed Restoration, Experience at Pinehurst Is Devalued
description: PINEHURST, N.C.  The Pinehurst 12, headlined by Phil Mickelson, are those players in this weeks United States Open field who participated in the tournament the last two times it was held here, in 1999 and 2005.

title: Microsoft Protests Order to Disclose Email Stored Abroad
description: Microsoft is challenging the authority of federal prosecutors to force the giant technology company to hand over a customers email stored in a data center in Ireland.

title: On Trials Tapes, Talk of New York Politics, Secret Cash and Strip Clubs
description: WHITE PLAINS  The picture of New York City politicians emerging from secretly recorded conversations at the bribery trial of State Senator Malcolm A. Smith is not one likely to be found in high-school civics textbooks.

title: P.F. Changs Investigating Possible Data Breach
description: P.F. Changs China Bistro said Tuesday that it is investigating a potential security breach that may have led to the theft of information from thousands of customer credit cards.

title: Martha Hyer, Oscar-Nominated Actress, Dies at 89
description: Martha Hyer, an Oscar-nominated movie actress who starred alongside Humphrey Bogart, Dean Martin, Frank Sinatra and Shirley MacLaine in the 1950s and 1960s, died on May 31 at her home in Santa Fe, N.M. She was 89.

title: I.R.S. Publishes Guide It Says Will Help Ensure Taxpayer Rights
description: The Internal Revenue Service on Tuesday unveiled a Taxpayer Bill of Rights that is intended to ensure the rights to privacy, confidentiality and a fair appeals process in dealings with the agency. This reinforces for the average taxpayer the fairness of the system, the agencys commissioner, John Koskinen, said. He said the timing had nothing to do with the investigations that the I.R.S. is facing after being accused of giving improper scrutiny to conservative groups while reviewing their applications for tax-exempt status. He said that the decision was meant to help taxpayers comfort level with the I.R.S.

title: Virginia Governor May Try to Expand Medicaid on His Own
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Gov. Terry McAuliffe has lost his battle with the legislature over Medicaid expansion, an enormous retreat from the high expectations he set for a liberal agenda. However, he is thought to be studying how to press the issue by executive action  a legally and politically uncertain course.

title: Open Winner Savors Title, and Friendships
description: FLEET, England  Circulars announcing The Boy Is Back in Town hung throughout the North Hants clubhouse, where Justin Rose spent an afternoon last month signing autographs, answering questions and posing for photographs with the United States Open trophy he won last June.

title: F.D.A. Rule May Alter Cheese-Aging Process
description: A decision by the Food and Drug Administration to question the use of wooden planks to age some cheeses has produced a stink that rivals Limburger, prompting an uproar among the artisanal cheese makers and consumers who fear they might lose access to products like obscure blue cheeses from Vermont and imported Parmigiano-Reggiano.

title: Why Did Cantor Lose? Not Easy to Explain
description: Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, lost his primary on Tuesday night in one of the most stunning electoral upsets in recent memory. It is not easy to explain his defeat, or the extent to which his campaign apparently underestimated the severity of the threat posed by David Brat, a Tea Party-backed economics professor.

title: Campaigning for Environment, Seminary to Divest Some Holdings
description: The trustees of Union Theological Seminary, a historic cradle of liberal Protestantism in New York City, voted unanimouslyon Tuesday to divest the schools $108.4 million endowment from fossil fuel companies. Union is said to be the first seminary to take up the divestment tactic in a campaign by environmentalists to combat climate change. Last month, Stanford University announced it would divest, but only from coal companies. The president of Union, Serene Jones, said, Climate change poses a catastrophic threat, and as stewards of Gods creation we simply must act. The seminary had already divested from tobacco and liquor companies.

title: Smart Growth on the East Side
description: With the sun setting on his final term, Mayor Michael Bloomberg tried last fall to push through a grand rezoning plan for East Midtown that would have brought many more office towers and a flood of workers to a 73-block area around Grand Central Terminal. He said it met an urgent need to keep the city competitive, with up-to-date buildings and improved transportation above and below ground. The plan died in the City Council, under criticism from community members and elected officials who said it was too drastic and too complicated to wave through.

title: Student Borrowers and the Economy
description: President Obama took an important step this week when he signed an executive order providing relief to millions of struggling student loan borrowers and urged Congress to pass a student loan refinancing bill that is scheduled for a vote in the Senate on Wednesday. Both the executive order and the refinancing bill speak to a grave problem that has trapped recent college graduates and threatens the long-term health of the economy.

title: Bank of America Mortgage Settlement Is Said to Be Deadlocked
description: Bank of America and the Justice Department have reached an impasse in negotiations over a multibillion-dollar settlement deal, raising the stakes in an investigation into the banks role at the center of the mortgage crisis.

title: Wylie Dufresne Says He Is Forced to Close WD-50
description: Updated | June 11, 2014

title: Clauses That Hurt Workers
description: Many businesses have long required that executives and other important employees agree not to work for a competitor for a year or two after they leave. Now some employers are unfairly imposing that requirement on all kinds of workers, including lower-wage employees like camp counselors, interns and yoga instructors, The Times has found.

title: The Real War of Ideas
description: The takeover Tuesday of the Iraqi city of Mosul by Sunni extremists who spilled over the Syrian border underscores the clash of world views that is underway in the whole Eastern Mediterranean, which I saw close up during my visit to Kurdistan a few days ago. And its not what you think.

title: In Tough Market, Investment Banks Seek Shelter or Get Out
description: The world of Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and the rest of the investment banks is being remade, squeezed by new regulations and record low volatility in the markets.

title: Montana: Prosecutors Agree to Improve Sex Assault Response
description: A standoff between the Justice Department and an elected county attorney in western Montana endedon Tuesdaywith an agreement under which local prosecutors promised to improve their response to sexual assault cases. The agreement came months after a lacerating report by federal authorities accused the Missoula County attorneys office of gender bias in handling sexual assault cases. The county attorney, Fred Van Valkenburg, sued federal judiciary officials, arguing they had no right to investigate his office. Under the deal, that challenge is being dropped, and the attorneys office has promised to set up new policies and training for sexual assault cases and to communicate better with victims and the police.

title: Championship Experience, if Not a Championship Roster
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  From the time I left home Tuesday morning and walked down Edgecombe Avenue in the Sugar Hill neighborhood of Harlem, Knicks fans up and down the block were torn between buzzing and fretting over the news that Derek Fisher would be the Knicks new coach.

title: Rangels Top Rival Stirs Up Deportation Debate
description: Signs that a congressional race has entered its final two weeks: dueling statements, accusations of outrageous behavior and liberal use of the words desperate and unconscionable.

title: When Companies Close Doors to the Future
Order for Microsoft to Disclose Data Stored Outside of U.S.
description: Microsoft is challenging the authority of federal prosecutors to force it to hand over a customers e-mail stored in one of its overseas data centers.

title: Another Voice Joins Chorus for Fair Pay
description: The rent is $1,187 for the walk-up apartment on East 117th Street in Manhattan where Solomon Perez, 30, lives with his wife and their 2-year-old daughter. He delivers food for Indus Valley, an Indian restaurant on the Upper West Side, making $5.25 an hour plus tips. Mr. Perez said the restaurant takes a cut of about 10 percent of the tips in online orders, like ones that come through Seamless, the Internet food-delivery hub.

title: A Fight as U.S. Girls Face Genital Cutting Abroad
description: ATLANTA  Last summer, an American-born teenager of Somali descent fled her parents home in a suburb here after she discovered that a coming vacation to Somalia would include a sacred rite of passage: the cutting of her genitalia. In Guinea, a New Yorker escaped to the American Embassy after an aunt told her that her family trip would involve genital cutting. And in Seattle, at least one physician said parents had sent girls back to Somalia to undergo cutting.

title: New York City Hotel Workers Contract May Grow More Lucrative
description: Workers may be protesting against low wages all around the country, but unionized hotel employees in New York City are not sharing the pain. They have just been offered an additional series of raises that would lift a maids annual pay to nearly $70,000 in 10 years.

title: 3-0 Hole Rangers Inhabit? Only 5 of 320 Teams Have Overcome It
description: Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault was subdued and downcast Tuesday, like most of his players, standing on the brink of elimination, peering grimly into the abyss.

title: L.I.R.R. Popularity Led to Crush After the Belmont
description: A little over three weeks ago, the Long Island Rail Road had a lot of money riding on a horse race in Baltimore.

title: Exhausted and Bereft, Iraqi Soldiers Quit Fight
description: BAGHDAD  The infantryman and his colleagues were already worn down after six months of fighting militants in western Iraq, men flush with weapons and zeal. Army commanders had no answer for the daily deadly ambushes and no broader strategy for prevailing in the longer war.

title: Help for Referees, in a Can
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Even casual soccer fans may already be familiar with the sports infamous magic spray, the ubiquitous mist that team trainers use on seemingly every type of injury to help stricken  or, as they are occasionally known, faking  players recover from grave maladies without missing a single kick.

title: Eric Cantor Aside, Immigration Is Unlikely to Dominate Politics
description: Eric Cantors defeat will most likely lead to a round of speculation about the dominant role that immigration may play in the midterm elections and the 2016 presidential campaign. But you should view that speculation with a somewhat skeptical eye, because immigration has rarely determined the outcome of national elections.

title: Netflix Orders New Childrens Show Based on Magic School Bus
description: Continuing the expansion of its original content for children, Netflix has ordered a new series based on Scholastic Medias Magic School Bus, the long-running television series that encouraged young people to pursue science.

title: A Troubled Son (or Is He Wicked?) Is Just the Start of a Familys Trouble
description: Your sympathies are constantly shifting as you watch Our New Girl, a drama by the Irish-born writer Nancy Harris that cross-pollinates two very different genres. On the one hand, Ms. Harriss London-set play, which opened at the Atlantic Theater Companys smaller stage on Tuesday night, is a serious study of a well-heeled but harassed contemporary woman trying to keep her marriage and family from fraying. At the same time, Ms. Harris stocks her play with the classic elements of a thriller: a sullen child who may harbor violent impulses, a comely nanny who may not be as innocent as she appears.

title: Athenas Counterpart
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  There is absolutely nothing wrong with this puzzle. It is a light-hearted and amusing tribute to June 14s Flag Day holiday, and Ian Livengoods puzzle offers us a chance to identify the prominent features of the flags of four countries. So far, so good.

title: Former Ambassador to Syria Urges Increasing Arms Supply to Moderate Rebels
description: WASHINGTON  Robert S. Fords misgivings about the Obama administrations policy toward Syria became so great last summer that he sought to leave his post as the senior United States envoy for Syria.

title: Careening Into a Bottomless Vortex
description: Greta Gerwig turns out to be the perfect person to ride right over the edge of a cliff with. Now dont say you havent been warned. Because over the cliff is where this surprising actress will have taken you by the end of The Village Bike, the genuinely daring new play by Penelope Skinner that opened on Tuesday night at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

title: Eric Cantors Voting Record: Angering Allies Is Part of the Job
description: As majority leader, Eric Cantor was charged with running the House and electing his Republican colleagues. The tension between the two caused him to schedule, and to vote for, some legislation that angered the conservative base.

title: No Body Is Found, but a Man Is Charged With Murder
description: Ramona Moore chatted with a neighbor outside their Bronx homes one July day in 2012. As the story goes, she was eating a mango, and when she saw that her neighbor wanted one, too, she went inside to get one. The neighbor never saw her again.

title: Coast Cleared by Others, W.N.B.A. Finally Finds Its Gay Pride
description: When Brittney Griner, the No. 1 pick in the 2013 W.N.B.A. draft, heard about her leagues new campaign to market games to people who are lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender, she said, What are we going to have, T-shirts, shoes?

title: Emergency Housing Unit Is Unveiled in Brooklyn
description: In the months after Hurricane Sandy, thousands of New Yorkers faced a daunting search for temporary housing. The supply of vacant apartments ran dry. Cramped hotel rooms prolonged a sense of limbo. Many people just stayed put in dank, waterlogged houses.

title: Elodie Lauten, Who Wove Opera From Allen Ginsbergs Poetry, Dies at 63
description: Elodie Lauten, an American composer known for her operatic setting of the work of Allen Ginsberg, died on June 3 in Manhattan. She was 63.

title: Success Academy Seeks 14 More Charter Schools in New York City
description: A charter school network that recently clashed with Mayor Bill de Blasio over the use of public school space is seeking to vastly expand its footprint in New York City, announcing on Tuesday that it wants to open 14 more schools over the next two years.

title: Kidd and Fisher Carve New Niche for Veterans: Coachs Office
description: MIAMI  In the middle of a championship series that has featured several senior N.B.A. citizens, including San Antonios 38-year-old spiritual and strategic centerpiece, Tim Duncan, the hiring on Tuesday of Derek Fisher, 39, to coach the Knicks did not go unnoticed.

title: Bob Welch, Pitching Ace and Prototype for Todays Power Arms, Dies at 57
description: Bob Welch, a flame-throwing right-hander for the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Oakland As who overcame alcoholism to win 211 games, including 27 in 1990, a single-season total no other pitcher has reached in the past 40 years, died on Monday in Seal Beach, Calif. He was 57.

title: The Circus That Doesnt Leave Town
description: The circus is in town, but this big tent has nothing to do with Ringling Brothers or trained lions and elephants. Instead it is the carnival theme popping up across New York City in unexpected ways and in unexpected places: acrobats twirling over patrons in downtown nightclubs, men in leotards juggling mud at $475 dinner theater shows in Midtown, gyms offering circus yoga, school children learning about clowning in different cultures, and fire breathers spitting flames onto tin ceilings at bars in Brooklyn.

title: Michael Schmidt, 68, Maker of Photographic Narratives, Dies
description: The German photographer Michael Schmidt was known for presenting stark black-and-white images in dramatic sequence, to powerful emotional effect. A recent project was a penetrating tour of the global food industry that included arresting images of factory farms, a cows bulging udder, supermarkets and a single apple. It won an international award just days before Mr. Schmidts death on May 24 in Berlin. He was 68.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 10, 2014
Overlooked in Mets Focus on the Future, a Nice Victory
description: A certain inevitability hangs over the Mets. Once the season begins to crumble, the future rapidly becomes the present. When the Mets arrived home Sunday after an 11-game trip, in the middle of a six-game losing streak, they appeared to have reached that point more quickly than they had expected.

title: Bank of America and the Financial Crisis
description: Bank of America, including Countrywide, issued about $640 billion in mortgage-backed securities before the financial crisis.

title: ISIS: Behind the Group Overrunning Iraq
description: Background on the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the Islamist group that gained control of the second-largest city in Iraq.

title: Cantors Loss a Bad Omen for Moderates
description: WASHINGTON  The House Republican leadership, so solid in its opposition to President Obama, was torn apart Tuesday by the defeat of its most influential conservative voice, Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader. His demise will reverberate all the way to the speakers chair, pull the top echelons of the House even further to the right and most likely doom any ambitious legislation, possibly through the next presidential election.

title: Tanaka Follows Iwakuma, Then Sets Himself Apart
description: SEATTLE  When Masahiro Tanaka went from high school into the Japanese professional leagues with the Tohoku Rakuten Golden Eagles in 2007, his mentor was the teams ace and best player, Hisashi Iwakuma.

title: Fargo Recap: Its a Turducken
description: Season 1, Episode 9: Gasp. Lester Nygaards transformation is stunningly complete.

title: The Downward Ramp
description: With the bursting of the tech bubble at the start of the 21st century, two decades of growth at the high end of the job market  once the province of college graduates with strong cognitive abilities  came to an abrupt halt, according to detailed studies of employment and investment patterns by three Canadian economists. We are still feeling the ramifications.

title: The Franchising of Architecture
description: As leading architects race to put their visual signatures on every nook and cranny of the world, one critic wonders whether globalization is really such a good thing.

title: Overestimating How Hard We Exercise
description: Most of us know that moderate exercise is good for us. But surprisingly few of us know what moderate exercise means, research shows. An instructive new study found that many of us underestimate how hard we should exercise to achieve maximum health benefits, and overestimate how vigorously we are actually working out.

title: New York Comic Con Branching Out From Javits Center
description: Its name may emphasize comic books, but New York Comic Con at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in October also celebrates film, television and video games. ReedPop, which organizes the show, is making that appreciation of all things pop culture more official by declaring Oct. 3-12 New York Super Week, a citywide festival that will include gaming events, lectures, concerts, comedy shows and more.

title: Word of the Day | transition
description: transition \tran(t)-si-shn, tran-zi-\ noun and verb

title: The Old Is New Again at E3 for Sony and Microsoft
description: LOS ANGELES  Many music and movie fans of a certain age are accustomed to buying the same works again and again as technologies change.

title: Spurs Set Blazing Pace and Hang On Late
description: MIAMI  Within minutes of taking the court at American Airlines Arena on Tuesday night, the San Antonio Spurs demolished a 23-year-old record for offensive efficiency.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 9 P.M. (Spike TV) GUYS CHOICE 2014 This awards ceremony, taped on Saturday at Sony Pictures Studios in Culver City, Calif., honors the things men like most, as voted by viewers. Sandra Bullock (above left) is celebrated for a Decade of Hotness; Matthew McConaughey (above right) is Guy of the Year; Kevin Hart is King of Comedy; and Rihanna is the Most Desirable Woman.

title: Members of Congress React to Cantors Defeat Via Twitter
description: Representative Eric Cantors defeat in Tuesday nights primary election in Virginia was a major jolt to congressional politics. Among those reacting on Twitter to the defeat of the House majority leader were a number of his colleagues in the House of Representatives and Senate.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 11, 2014
description: The results tonight will move the party further to the right, which will marginalize us further as a national party.

title: Gabriel Kolko, Left-Leaning Historian of U.S. Policy, Dies at 81
description: Gabriel Kolko, an influential left-leaning historian who argued that American domestic and international policies have long been driven more by the interests of big business than by the interests of the people, died on May 19 at his home in Amsterdam. He was 81.

title: Jeter Starts Two Rallies and Ellsbury Caps a Victory
description: SEATTLE  Derek Jeter played his first major league game just a few hundred yards outside the walls of Safeco Field, in the long since demolished Kingdome.

title: Fall of an Apparatchik
description: Wow  Eric Cantor lost his primary, by a large margin. Amazing.

title: Morning Views
description: Noncompete clauses are harmful to both employees and the economy as a whole, writes The New York Times editorial board. While the board recognizes these policies have reasonable utility in deterring upper management from defecting to competitors, the restrictions can be needlessly hampering to lower-wage employees who statistically earn more money over the years the more professional freedom they enjoy. More broadly, The Times points to studies showing that gratuitously stringent noncompete policies stifle entrepreneurship.

title: Beijing Police Detain Student Over Tiananmen Tweet
description: The Beijing authorities have detained a woman linked with a Twitter posting suggesting that a method for sending spam text messages might also be used to rally public awareness of the 25th anniversary of the deadly crackdown on the Tiananmen protest movement.

title: Paul Takes On Clinton Over Her Dead Broke Comments
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Rand Paul dismissed comments from Hillary Rodham Clinton that she and her husband were struggling to make ends meet after they left the White House, saying they were disconnected.

title: Corrections: June 11, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Traffic Snarls in Europe as Taxi Drivers Protest Against Uber
description: LONDON  Europes taxi drivers on Wednesday picked a fight with Uber, an increasingly popular smartphone car-paging service, and dared consumers to choose sides.

title: Where Eric Cantor Won and Lost
description: Map of the results and charts of his margins in previous elections.

title: In American Journalists Photographs, Rare Glimpse of Indias First Prime Minister
description: In January 1952, Margaret Lee Weil, a 30-year-old journalist and photographer, arrived in India to pursue her dream of catching a glimpse of the man whom she had hero-worshipped from 10,000 miles away all these years, according to a particularly effusive diary entry.

title: Emirates Cancels Major Order From Airbus
description: PARIS  Airbus suffered a major blow on Wednesday to its latest commercial jet program after one of its largest customers, Emirates Airline, said it had decided to cancel a multibillion-dollar order for 70 long-range planes.

title: Test Yourself | Math, June 11, 2014
description: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Sunni Militants Drive Iraqi Army Out of Mosul
description: In Sunni Militants Drive Iraqi Army Out of Mosul, Suadad Al-Salhy, Kareem Fahim and Rick Gladstone report on how Iraqs second-biggest city was seized in a rapid assault by insurgents.

title: Iraq Militants, Pushing South, Aim at Capital
description: BAGHDAD  Sunni militants consolidated and extended their control over northern Iraq on Wednesday, seizing Tikrit, the hometown of Saddam Hussein, threatening the strategic oil refining town of Baiji and pushing south toward Baghdad, their ultimate target, Iraqi sources said.

title: Mac and Cheese for Fancy People
description: An old hardcover copy of The Escoffier Cook Book sits in the library of The New York Times, battered and dog-eared, classified on its front endpaper by someone with exquisite penmanship as a book to be shelved amid titles dedicated to Foreign Foods.

title: Theres a True Story Behind The Mule: The Sinaloa Cartels 90-Year-Old Drug Mule
description: The Lincoln pickup truck with Iowa plates was hurtling down Interstate 94, headed for Detroit. A dozen D.E.A. officers in unmarked cars were scattered along a 70-mile stretch, from Kalamazoo to Jackson, Mich. From on-ramps and overpasses, they watched traffic flash by as they tried to spot the truck. They believed it was carrying a major shipment of cocaine.

title: Seeing Red in the Gene Pool
