description: Phil Mickelson, the famed golfer, did not trade in the shares of Clorox just as the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn was mounting an unsolicited takeover bid for the company in 2011, say four people briefed on the matter.

title: A Family That Plays Together Reconvenes at Pinehurst
description: PINEHURST, N.C.  On the first week of his summer break, Maverick McNealy was on a resort golf course with his mother, his father and two of his three siblings. Standing off the 10th hole at Pinehurst No. 2 on Wednesday, McNealy smiled and said, It feels like a typical McNealy family golf vacation.

title: Putting a Cap on Cantor
description: Pardon me. Im having trouble getting my thoughts together today. Im so upset about Eric Cantor.

title: Weapons Stockpile Seen in Oregon School Attack
description: TROUTDALE, Ore.  The police on Wednesday identified the assailant who killed a student and wounded a teacher here as a 15-year-old student who had planned to hurt more people when he arrived at his high school in this Portland suburb with two family guns and hundreds of rounds of ammunition.

title: Spurs Set Records, and Their Shooting Guru Offers Only a Shrug
description: MIAMI  The San Antonio Spurs were well on their way to obliterating all kinds of records for shooting proficiency, and the one man who might have allowed himself to delight in what was happeningTuesdaynight at American Airlines Arena instead seemed completely unaffected by it all.

title: The Army Alone Cant Save Iraq
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  THE Obama administration must help the Iraqi government retake the city of Mosul from Islamists and stem their march toward Baghdad. But military aid will not be enough. For lasting success, the United States must compel Iraqs divisive leadership to pursue government by reconciliation just as vigorously as it pursues battlefield victory.

title: With Marijuana Legalized, a City in Washington State Says, Not So Fast
description: SEATTLE  The first retail shops selling legal recreational marijuana in Washington State are preparing to open next month. Cash registers are standing by, and the first crops are almost ready for harvesting. But not every part of the state is joining the party.

title: Why Polling Fails
description: ERIC CANTOR wasnt the only person at a loss for words on Tuesday night.

title: Technocrat to Afghan Populist, Ashraf Ghani Is Transformed
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  When dealing with Western officials, Ashraf Ghani presents himself as the rare technocrat who possesses both the cultural savvy and practical expertise needed to put Afghanistan back on track if he is elected president in the runoff vote on Saturday.

title: Security and Enthusiasm Clash in Theater of the Absurd
description: She is a theater lifer, all but born to this Atlantis in the West 40s.

title: World Cup 2014: Brazil Defeats Croatia, 3-1
description: In the end, its the result that everyone expected, but not before Croatia scared Brazilian fans everywhere with a shock 1-0 lead.

title: Irans World Cup Zeal Wanes as Match Draws Near
description: TEHRAN  In a city where few people are allowed to organize large gatherings, and fun is enjoyed in private, the public celebrations of a year ago are legendary.

title: Cantors Lesson: Hedging on Immigration Is Perilous
description: The lesson that immigration advocates say they gleaned from Tuesdays election results is, simply put, that hedging on such an intensely charged issue can be politically fatal.

title: She Gets No Respect
description: Heres a riddle: Why would a Hurricane Alexandra be deadlier than an identical Hurricane Alexander?

title: A New Battle for Equal Education
description: When states are sued for providing inferior education to poor and minority children, the issue is usually money  disproportionately more money for white students, less for others. A California judge has now brought another deep-rooted inequity to light: poor teaching.

title: Does Tenure Protect Bad Teachers or Good Schools?
The Scourge of Sexual Violence
description: The failure of the Egyptian government, now led by Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, to respond aggressively to sexual assaults has justifiably outraged rape victims and womens rights advocates. A video posted on the Internet of a horrifying mass sexual assault on a woman on Sunday in Cairos Tahrir Square now poses a serious test for Mr. Sisi.

title: Luiz Felipe Scolari, Brazils Manager, Shoulders Grief and Expectation
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  As the manager of Brazils national team, Luiz Felipe Scolari was already facing incredible pressure to win the World Cup. But just days before Thursdays opening match, his emotions were suddenly clouded with grief.

title: Cantor Forgot Virginia Roots, Voters Contend
description: GLEN ALLEN, Va.  This once rural community that is now a suburb of Richmond has no downtown, only a patchwork of shopping centers and colonial-style housing developments carved out of forests of white pine and oak.

title: FIFA Chief Indicates He Will Seek Fifth Term
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Sepp Blatter on Wednesday all but declared his intention to run for a fifth term as FIFAs president, declaring that my mission is not finished in a speech to a congress of soccers top officials.

title: World Cup 2014: Mexico Defeats Cameroon, 1-0
description: Mexico needed to win to put pressure on Croatia, its rival for the second qualifying spot, and it did, 1-0.

title: After Primary Upset, G.O.P. Fears Infighting Will Take a Toll
description: WASHINGTON  The sudden and decisive fall of the House majority leader, Eric Cantor of Virginia, at the hands of a conservative primary opponent tore open divisions among Republicans on Wednesday, setting off a new wave of fear that the internecine feuding would stymie policy-making and imperil Republican presidential prospects in 2016.

title: World Cup 2014: Netherlands Defeats Spain, 5-1
description: The defending champions limped off in defeat as the Dutch triumphed in the remake of the 2010 final as Spanish-language horror film.

title: World Cup 2014: Chile Defeats Australia, 3-1
description: Chile scored two quick goals to jump out to an early lead and held on against Australia for the victory in the teams opening Group B match.

title: Randolph-Macon College a Political Hotbed in Hiding
description: Randolph-Macon College, with its neo-Georgian buildings and oak-shaded walkways tucked away in the hamlet of Ashland, Va., fits no ones image of a political hotbed. Yet the Republican who defeated Eric Cantor in a congressional primary this week is a professor there  and so is the Democrat he will run against in November.

title: Teacher Tenure Ruling in California Is Expected to Intensify Debate
description: LOS ANGELES  The landmark court decision on Tuesday finding Californias teacher tenure laws unconstitutional is likely to lead to a flood of copycat lawsuits in other states, shifting the battleground on the issue from the legislatures to the courts.

title: The Deli Guy, the Waitress, the Actress and the Blackout
description: Harold McClam, a guitar-strumming sandwich maker in New York City in the mid-1960s, has a lot in common with the new musical Fly by Night, which is more or less centered on him. Both man and musical have a dopey appeal that is irresistible in small doses and an unfortunate way of sabotaging themselves by getting stuck in a groove.

title: Goldman Sachs Misses Out on Big Alibaba Payoff
description: Goldman Sachs has a reputation for consistently holding the winning lottery ticket numbers. But it got rid of the ticket that is poised to be one of this years biggest payoffs.

title: One Hundred Percent
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  What phrase do you use to convey 100% of something?

title: At Senators Trial, Video Shows Discussion of Paying G.O.P. Leaders for Support
description: WHITE PLAINS  The three men sat around a coffee table in a gold-wallpapered suite of the Essex House on Central Park South and talked about an improbable plot: enticing New York Citys five Republican county leaders to help State Senator Malcolm A. Smith, a Democrat, run for mayor as a Republican.

title: Israeli Airstrike in Gaza Strip Kills Palestinian
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli airstrike late Wednesday killed a Palestinian, who was believed to be a militant, as he rode a motorcycle in the northern Gaza Strip and seriously wounded a man accompanying him and a 7-year-old boy who was passing by, according to health officials in Gaza.

title: Legal Confusion Follows Federal Judges Ruling on Same-Sex Marriage in Wisconsin
description: In her ruling last Friday that struck down Wisconsins amendment limiting marriage to a man and a woman, Judge Barbara B. Crabb spoke plainly on the basic question.

title: Lenders Enlisted in Effort to Preserve Stuyvesant Town for the Middle Class
description: One month after word circulated that Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village was for sale, the battle is fully engaged to preserve this increasingly rare oasis for middle-class families in Manhattan.

title: Mayor Criticizes Cab Plan After a Courts Reversal
description: One day after an appeals court revived a Bloomberg administration proposal for a nearly uniform fleet of yellow cabs, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday denounced the plan, calling its adoption a broken process on many levels.

title: 3 Sought in Series of Laundry Robberies
description: Their plan seemed simple enough. One man stood outside Express Laundry in Brooklyn on Saturday. It was around midnight, and the coast was clear. He gave a partner a cue.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 11, 2014
Cuomo Adds 100 Officers to Units Fighting Heroin
description: A hundred State Police investigators are being added to drug units around New York with a mandate to tackle a growing heroin problem, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Wednesday.

title: When the Trophy Is the Biggest Star
description: While hockey may have struggled to keep its footing among the most popular sports in the United States in recent years, it has held tight to the status of having the coolest championship trophy. The Stanley Cup is the most singular of trophies, a 35-pound hunk of silver recognizable instantly even by those who do not watch a second of the playoffs.

title: Michigan: Another Retiree Group Agrees to Pension Cuts
description: The board of Detroits general retirement system voted Wednesday to endorse the citys bankruptcy plan, becoming the latest retiree group to support a so-called grand bargain that includes outside funding and base pension cuts of 4.5 percent for former municipal workers. Pensioners must vote on the proposal by July 11 and could face steeper reductions if they reject the debt-slimming plan, which is subject to a federal judges approval. As part of the bargain, which would also keep a city-owned art collection off the auction block, two national foundations committed a combined $13 million to the Detroit Institute of Arts, the museum announced Wednesday. This week, automakers made a $26 million pledge. The artwork has been targeted by some creditors as a source of cash.

title: Court Requires Warrants for Tracking Locations by Cellphone
description: In a groundbreaking case, a federal appeals court in Atlanta on Wednesday ruled that the Fourth Amendment protects information about peoples locations based on the cell towers their mobile phones are using. The ruling means investigators must get judicial warrants to obtain cell site data about someone. It builds on a ruling by the Supreme Court in 2012 finding that the police needed a warrant to attach a GPS device to a suspects car. While the court held that investigators should have obtained a warrant to get his locational data, it declined to overturn his conviction because the legal principle was not yet clear at the time of the investigation.

title: White House Outlines Steps to Protect Covert Identities
description: The White House on Wednesday outlined the steps it would take to prevent the disclosure of covert officials identities when the president is traveling abroad. The moves are in reaction to the accidental revelation last month of the Central Intelligence Agencys top spy in Afghanistan.

title: Massachusetts: Venue Change Is Sought in Marathon Case
description: Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who is accused in last years marathon bombings, filed court documents on Wednesday saying that they want their clients trial moved out of Boston. The lawyers did not say why they were seeking a new location, but indicated that they were trying to spare Mr. Tsarnaev the death penalty. In early court filings, Mr. Tsarnaevs lawyers have referred to Bostons news media coverage of the bombings, suggesting that the pretrial publicity there would prevent Mr. Tsarnaev from receiving a fair trial. If the court grants the move, the trial could still be held in Massachusetts, avoiding the intense feelings in Boston while benefiting from the states general anti-death-penalty tilt.

title: Familiar Course to Defeat for deGrom
description: Last season, when Matt Harvey pitched a brilliant game and was ultimately let down by his offense, he often recited the same message. He said that his job was to pitch as well as he could, to give his offense a chance, and that he could do nothing more than that.

title: For Rangel and Challengers, a Subdued Debate
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel discarded his props and toned down the racial language during the first live televised debate that pitted him against State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat and the Rev. Michael A. Walrond as he seeks a 23rd term to represent the 13th Congressional District.

title: Ugandan Official to Be Next General Assembly Chief
description: The United Nations General Assembly chose Sam Kutesa, Ugandas foreign minister, as its next president on Wednesday, bypassing concerns of rights advocates and Western officials over Ugandas  law criminalizing homosexuality, which took effect four months ago. Mr. Kutesa was selected by acclamation, without a vote. The one-year post is largely ceremonial but carries significance because the president leads General Assembly meetings. Mr. Kutesa said nothing about gay rights in his acceptance speech but vowed to promote gender equality and womens rights. Asked by reporters afterward about his views on gays, he said, As long as they respect privacy, I have no problem with it at all. Philippe Bolopion, the United Nations director at Human Rights Watch, said the Uganda law makes him a questionable choice. Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general, supported Mr. Kutesas presidency but has expressed concern about the law, urging its repeal.

title: Pakistan: Brothers Sentenced Again for Cannibalism
description: An antiterrorism court in Punjab Province on Wednesday sentenced two brothers accused of cannibalism each to 11 years and four months in prison. The brothers, Muhammad Arif and Farman Ali, were arrested in April after the police found a babys head at their home in remote Bhakkar. They were convicted after a similar discovery in 2011 but were released after 18 months because, lawyers said, Pakistani law has no specific provisions against cannibalism. This time they were convicted of terrorism, desecrating a corpse and concealing evidence, said Mian Muhammad Rizwan, the public prosecutor in the case. Mr. Arif said that his older brother had disinterred a babys body and that the two had cooked and eaten the remains.

title: Brazil: With World Cup Near, Airport Staff Plans Strike
description: The workers at Rio de Janeiros airports said they would go on a 24-hour strike on Thursday, the opening day of the World Cup soccer tournament. Other strikes have recently affected Brazilian cities as unions exert leverage at a time when the government is trying to avert major problems. The workers at Rios international airport and two domestic airports said they were seeking better conditions and a new collective bargaining agreement. It was not clear how the strike would affect the thousands of visitors flowing into Rio, which will host several games, including the World Cup final. Union officials said that as much as 80 percent of the airport work force would keep working during the strike, Brazilian news organizations reported. In So Paulo, subway workers voted not to resume their strike.

title: Mets Reach Intersection of Expectation and Patience
description: The Mets most dependable starting pitcher was a seventh-round draft choice from an Ohio high school who was not considered a top prospect as he clawed through the minor leagues. That pitcher, Jon Niese, cannot relate to the expectations that stalk so many others in the organization.

title: Phyllis Patterson, Who Revived 16th Century, Dies at 82
description: Phyllis Patterson, who brought 16th-century Europe to Southern California in the 1960s when she helped found the first contemporary Renaissance fair, died on May 18 in a hospital in San Rafael, Calif. She was 82 and lived in a log cabin nearby, in Novato.

title: Glenn Britt, Cable Chief Who Saw Broadbands Future, Dies at 65
description: Glenn A. Britt, the longtime chief executive of Time Warner Cable, whose career encompassed the shift from televisions with rabbit ears to streaming video, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 65.

title: Yankees Ellsbury Has Reputation as Dirt Rat (Its Praise)
description: SEATTLE  Jacoby Ellsbury has earned some earthy nicknames over the years, mostly stemming from his six seasons with the Boston Red Sox.

title: Security of Sites Storing Small Radioactive Material Is Found to Be Lacking
description: Radioactive chunks of industrial metal that could be used in terrorist attacks are sometimes secured at sites around the country with no more than ordinary padlocks, according to congressional auditors. Also, auditors called ineffective the procedures for doing background checks of employers handling the materials.

title: The Eloquence of Silence
description: In her final interview, the intensely private heiress Rachel Bunny Mellon opened the doors to her legendary Virginia estate and the unparalleled treasures of her lifetime.

title: A Series of Indecisive Moments
description: In this weekly series, Ts photo editors share the most compelling visual projects theyve discovered.

title: Selected Poems by Charles Wright
description: Poems by Charles Wright, the newly named poet laureate.

title: Charles Wright Named Americas Poet Laureate
description: The Library of Congress is to announce on Thursday that the next poet laureate will be Charles Wright, the author of nearly two dozen collections of verse that fuse the legacy of European modernism with mystical evocations of the landscape of the American South.

title: Should Runners Get Pedicures?
description: Jackie Cartier of Boulder, Colo., has been running for 10 years. That has left her feet beaten up and bruised, with thick calluses and the occasional missing toenail. But she wont step foot in a salon to have a pedicure.

title: Anchor of Rangers Buoys Them Just in Time
description: After practice one afternoon, Henrik Lundqvist discussed his hockey mortality. You dont know how many chances you get in the playoffs, Lundqvist said. Before you know it, it might be over.

title: Word of the Day | conveyance
description: conveyance \kn-va-n(t)s\ noun

title: Lundqvists 40 Saves Give Rangers a Shot
description: Madison Square Garden once again served as the Rangers fortress Wednesday night. They held off the Los Angeles Kings, 2-1, refusing to allow the indignation of seeing them lift the Stanley Cup on home ice.

title: Rafael Frhbeck, 80, Dies; Conductor Made the World a Podium
description: Rafael Frhbeck de Burgos, a Spanish conductor known for his frequent guest appearances with the worlds foremost symphony orchestras, died on Wednesday in Pamplona, Spain. He was 80.

title: Polarization Is Dividing American Society, Not Just Politics
description: It is common for Americans to lament the polarization and dysfunction of Washington, but Congress might be doing a better job of representing the public than voters care to admit.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 12, 2014
description: The days of just going to Washington and things happening in a vacuum are over.

title: Whats On Thursday
description: 8 P.M. (FX) WANDERLUST (2012) Jennifer Aniston and Paul Rudd star as Linda and George, out-of-work Manhattanites unable to sell their microloft in the West Village. Then they stumble onto Elysium, an intentional community in rural Georgia, where good vibrations  and not a little smoke  fill the air, and the only blackberries grow on trees. Established decades earlier by Carvin (Alan Alda), now in a wheelchair and battling memory loss, and his hippie friends, the commune is home to a touchy-feely guitar-strumming collage led by Seth (Justin Theroux), a creepy Lothario; and a novelist and nudist (Joe Lo Truglio) who wears the occasional sanitary pouch (like a hairnet, but lower) when hes crushing grapes for homemade wine. Part of what gives this movie unexpected resonance is that Linda and George have joined only somewhat voluntarily, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this mostly funny comedy from David Wain. Like other Americans seeking simplicity and maybe a chicken coop out back, they want off the road, at least for a while. Theres something touching about this desire, though Mr. Wain doesnt let Linda and George fly their freak flags for long.

title: Rookie Jets Cornerback Gets the Green Light to Bump and Run
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Dexter McDougle, a rookie cornerback, was ecstatic when the Jets training staff allowed him to trade the red jersey he had worn since he joined the team as a third-round draft choice for a green one that signified he was free to engage in contact drills.

title: Stout Performance Extends the Finals
description: A stellar game by goaltender Henrik Lundqvist and goals from Martin St. Louis and Benoit Pouliot helped the Rangers cut the Kings lead in the Stanley Cup finals to 3-1.

title: Corrections: June 12, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Kings Head Home Empty-Handed but Hoping for Redemption
description: The Los Angeles Kings entered Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night needing one victory to clinch their second Stanley Cup in three years.

title: Xi of Two Minds: Be a Good Neighbor, or Assert Chinas Power?
description: If youre sometimes discombobulated by Chinas foreign policy gyrations, there may be some consolation in knowing that so, apparently, is President Xi Jinping. A new report argues that Chinas external strategy under him remains an unstable compound of impulses: swelling ambitions that China will use its growing economic and military power to subdue rivals versus a longstanding desire for a stable, benign regional setting so that the ruling Communist Party can tend to domestic priorities.

title: Synthesis Lost
description: Brad DeLong has some notes on the evident trouble weve been having maintaining the neoclassical synthesis  the doctrine, made famous by Paul Samuelson but actually there in Keynes too, that macroeconomic policy is needed for full employment but once you have that a relatively free-market policy works.

title: In Testimony Against N.C.A.A., Economics Professor Suggests Players Should Be Paid
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Three days into a federal antitrust trial involving the N.C.A.A., the key witness has been Roger Noll, a 74-year-old economics professor emeritus at Stanford. His studies and theories form much of the basis for the allegation that the N.C.A.A. has engaged in price fixing by systematically depriving players a piece of lucrative broadcast and video-game contracts.

title: Tanaka Earns Win No. 10 as Yankees Beat Mariners
description: SEATTLE  Masahiro Tanaka is putting together the type of rookie season that even longtime baseball fans cannot remember seeing.

title: Greenpeace and Other Advocates Fear Clampdown After Leaked Report
description: NEW DELHI  A confidential intelligence report submitted to the prime ministers office and leaked to the local media criticizing foreign-funded nongovernmental organizations, including Greenpeace India, for their detrimental effect on the Indian economy has caused many social activists to worry about the security of their operations.

title: European Court Upholds $1.44 Billion Fine Against Intel
description: BRUSSELS  An appeals court on Thursday upheld an antitrust fine of 1.06 billion euros against the computer chip giant Intel, giving more teeth to the European Unions power to hold multinational technology giants accountable  even if the case is years old and Intel no longer wields the sort of power over consumers that got it into trouble in the first place.

title: Test Yourself | English, June 12, 2014
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | Killing a Patient to Save His Life
description: In Killing a Patient to Save His Life, Kate Murphy reports on an experimental medical procedure.

title: BNP Paribas Executive Leaves as Trade Investigation Grows
description: Updated, 8:13 p.m. | A senior BNP Paribas executive is stepping down in the face of an investigation into whether the bank did business with countries blacklisted by the United States.

title: An Interview With Xi, Long Before He Was Chinas Leader
description: Chinas president, Xi Jinping, belongs to the sent-down generation of urban youths assigned to labor in the countryside during the radical fervor of the Cultural Revolution, and while many of his peers rue that era as a lost decade, in a newly unearthed interview, Mr. Xi describes his seven rural years as a life-transforming immersion in poverty, hard work, spartan eating and bed fleas.

title: British Discount Retailer B&M Raises $1.81 Billion in I.P.O.
description: LONDON  B&M European Value Retail, the British discount retailer, said on Thursday that it had raised 1.08 billion pounds, or about $1.81 billion, in its initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange.

title: Prison Sentence Feared for Detained Rights Lawyer
description: A lawyer who met with Pu Zhiqiang, a crusading human rights lawyer who was detained after a meeting in Beijing to mark the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown, has expressed pessimism about the prospect of his speedy release.

title: On the Road to a Photo of America
description: Last month, the New York Times staff photographer Todd Heisler and a reporter, Damien Cave, set off on an ambitious journey to travel up Interstate 35, chronicling how the middle of America is being changed by immigration. With two weeks left on their assignment, Mr. Heisler took a moment to record a brief yet personal account for Lens regarding his experiences on the road.

title: Will You Be Watching the World Cup?
description: The World Cup, which is held every four years, begins on Thursday in Brazil and will last until mid-July. Thirty-two countries are contending for the title of world champion. The last time around, Spain won  but who will win this year? And will you be watching?

title: U.S. Drone Hits Pakistan for 2nd Time in 12 Hours
description: LONDON  An American drone struck a militant compound in Pakistans tribal belt for the second time in 12 hours on Thursday, killing at least 10 suspected members of the Haqqani network in a suddenly intense resurgence of the C.I.A. offensive in Pakistan.

title: Kurdish Fighters Take a Key Oil City as Militants Advance on Baghdad
description: ERBIL, Iraq  Kurdish forces exploited the mayhem convulsing Iraq on Thursday to seize complete control of the strategic northern oil city of Kirkuk as government troops fled in the face of advancing Sunni militants. The insurgents pressed their advance southward toward Baghdad, warned officials of occupied Mosul to renounce allegiance to the central government and threatened to destroy religious shrines sacred to Shiites.

title: New York Today: Brazil vs. Croatia, in Queens
description: Good Thursday morning to you.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: First Year May Be Critical for Lowering Asthma and Allergy Risk
description: Childhood exposure to allergens and germs is generally believed to protect against the development of asthma and allergy, but a new study suggests that this effect happens only with exposure in the first year of life.

title: Facebook to Let Users Alter Their Ad Profiles
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If you have ever wondered why Facebook showed you that advertisement for a new iPhone game or a cheap flight to Bermuda, you will soon be able to find out.

title: Q. and A.: Anson Chan on Beijings Pressure Tactics in Hong Kong
description: Anson Chan served as the No. 2 official in Hong Kong in the last years of the British colonial administration as well as in the first four years of the government following the territorys return to China in 1997. During her time in office she was often referred to as Hong Kongs Iron Lady and regarded as one of Asias most powerful women.

title: Oil Rig Operator Shelf Drilling to List in London
description: LONDON  Shelf Drilling, a Dubai-based operator of oil rigs, is looking to become the latest company to cash in on a buoyant market for London stock offerings.

title: Daily Report: Facebook to Give Users More Control Over Marketing Data
description: If you have ever wondered why Facebook showed you that ad for a new iPhone game or a cheap flight to Bermuda, you will soon be able to find out, Vindu Goel reports.

title: Morning Views
description: The forces of political nihilism not only remain alive and well within the Republican Party, but they are on the rise, writes The New York Times editorial board. The Times finds the defeat of Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, by David Brat, an upstart of the distant extremes, to be both regrettable and disconcerting. For the Republicans of Virginias Seventh Congressional District, even Mr. Cantor, who had been one of the most implacable opponents to the reform of immigration, health care and taxation, was apparently too moderate. His crime (in addition to complacent campaigning)? He was occasionally obliged, as a leader, to take a few minimalist steps toward governing, like raising the debt ceiling and ending a ruinous shutdown.

title: Women Who Belong in the Kitchen: Jody Adams
description: Jody Adams remembers her first job as a 25-year-old cook, working directly on the hot line. I cut myself. I burned myself. I was a mess; I cried, she said. But I survived.

title: The Economic Damage of Recession News
description: Real gross domestic product (G.D.P.) in the United States shrank by 1 percent in the first quarter of the year. What made this announcement seem so significant?

title: Freshdesk Raises $31 Million for Customer Support Software
description: Stock market investors have rallied around Zendesk, a customer service software company that went public last month.

title: How Thad Cochran Is Trying to Avoid Eric Cantors Fate
description: In winning his state senate seat in 2007, Chris McDaniel drew just over 10,000 votes. In winning a sixth United States Senate term a year later, Thad Cochran drew 766,000.

title: In Our Pages: June 13
Cantor Resigns as House Majority Leader
description: Representative Eric Cantor, Republican of Virginia, announced he would resign from his position as House majority leader within weeks of a stunning defeat in the primary election.

title: Morning Agenda: Mickelson Not Linked to Clorox
description: MICKELSONS ROLE OVERSTATED IN INSIDER INQUIRY | The golfer Phil Mickelson did not trade in the shares of Clorox as the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn was mounting a takeover bid for the company in 2011, according to people briefed on the matter, Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess write in DealBook. Recent news reports said that Clorox was among the stocks that federal authorities were examining as part of a two-year investigation into well-timed trades made by Mr. Mickelson and the gambler William T. Walters.

title: Russian Absurdism, With Floating Furniture
description: PARIS  Robert Wilson was sketching. Circles within circles, horizontal lines punctuating them, numbers and words alongside. The diagram was a visual rendition of the structure of one of his early works, The Life and Times of Joseph Stalin, but he could doubtless do exactly the same thing for any of the numerous theater and opera pieces he has created and directed in the course of a 45-year career.

title: Finding Her Future Looking to the Past
description: LOS ANGELES  In October, before starting an international theater tour, the songwriter Lana Del Rey consulted a clairvoyant. She was instructed to write down four questions in advance and sleep on them. The first question on the list, Ms. Del Rey said in an interview in May at her house here, was Am I meant for this world?

title: Sex, Violence and Power, With a Feminist Slant
description: A few years ago, the British playwright Penelope Skinner found herself in an editing suite, staring at a womans breasts. She had written an episode of Fresh Meat, a sitcom about college students, which contained a sex scene. The woman in it had just a few lines, and Ms. Skinner didnt want her to serve as merely a source of titillation. So in the script shed stated, She does not take her top off.

title: A Conversation With Andrew Wilson, Chief Executive of Electronic Arts
description: LOS ANGELES  For years, the video game publisher Electronic Arts struggled to convince investors that its vision for the future of games was working.

title: Selfies With Purpose': The Latest Big E-Commerce Idea
description: The above headline may sound like pie-in-the-sky thinking, but it is actually part of the business plan (and purpose) of a new e-commerce social network called Fitbay, which just raised $2 million in seed funding from Steadfast Venture Capital of New York and Creandum, a Nordic venture capitalist company and Spotify investor. Fitbay aims to be the Facebook of social shopping according to Christian Wylonis, its founder and chief executive.

title: Whats News in Washington: Cantor Fallout Continues
description: GoodThursdaymorning from a rainy Washington.

title: The World Cup, by the Numbers
description: Paul the octopus predicted Spain would win the World Cup in 2010, but in 1950, no one could have predicted the United States teams victory over one of the best soccer squads in the world.

title: China Calls Japan the Aggressor in Flybys Over Sea
description: HONG KONG  Chinas Ministry of National Defense accused Japan on Thursday of airborne brinkmanship over the East China Sea, rejecting Tokyos account of the latest close encounters between military aircraft from the two increasingly estranged countries.

title: Incumbents Fear Cantors Loss Will Fill Tea Partys Sails
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional Republicans thought they had found an answer for the conservative insurgencies that had toppled unsuspecting incumbents in recent years: Be prepared, be aggressive and be conservative.

title: Cantors Defeat Also Thrusts Jack Trammell, a Democrat, Into the Spotlight
description: WASHINGTON  Jack Trammell is an associate professor of sociology, a romance novelist, a descendant of Appalachian farmers and the father of seven children in what he calls a blended family.

title: Private Health Care Exchanges Enroll More Than Predicted
description: Employers are moving more quickly than forecasted to offer health insurance to their workers through private exchanges, according to new data from Accenture, a consulting firm.

title: An Uncomfortable Moment With Nathan Fielder
description: Nathan Fielder, the star of the Comedy Central show Nathan for You, explains his stunt to get out of handcuffs before a robotic arm pulls down his pants, exposing him to a group of minors.

title: Nathan Fielders Ingenious Dumb Humor
description: The new cafe at 1802 Hillhurst Avenue looked familiar, but something was off. It was nestled into a strip mall in Los Feliz, on the east side of Los Angeles, and its logo was a double-tailed mermaid, rendered in black and green, wearing a crown and a smile. Its name, spelled out in blocky white letters, was recognizable, too, except for a blunt dtournement up top: DUMB STARBUCKS COFFEE. The store was the creation of Nathan Fielder, a Canadian-born comedian, and he designed it to look exactly like an outpost of the ubiquitous coffee chain  that is, until you realized that the word dumb was everywhere. The menu listed 27 beverages with names like Dumb Iced Caramel Macchiato and Dumb Chai Tea Latte. Cups came in sizes from Dumb Tall to Dumb Venti. Two baristas manned the counter, with DUMB STARBUCKS COFFEE emblazoned on their green aprons. I hired them on Craigslist, Fielder told me recently. The ad actually asked for people who worked at Starbucks before, so we wouldnt have to train them. A rack of easy-listening CDs kept to the theme: Dumb Jazz Standards, Dumb Norah Jones Duets. The cafe quietly opened for business on a Friday last February. I didnt expect things to get as crazy as they did, Fielder said.

title: Britains Top Financial Authorities Focus on Perils of Debt
description: Updated, 8:52 p.m. | LONDON  Speaking before a roomful of black-tie clad bankers, the two most powerful stewards of the British economy on Thursday warned of risks in the countrys red-hot housing market.

A Watch Sells for $18,750. It Was Not a Timex.

title: Parental Collusion on Spending and Rules: Harder Than It Sounds
description: Parenting would be a little easier if everyone set the same rules for their children. No iPhone until kids can pay for one themselves. No sneakers over $100. No birthday parties with elaborate presents, or at least a declaration of a goody-bag truce. Some restraint on giving fancy new vehicles to teenagers.

title: House Delays Vote on Easing School Meal Standards
description: WASHINGTON  A House vote on an Agriculture Department spending bill containing a provision that would allow schools to opt out of the Obama administrations nutrition standards for school meals has been delayed until sometime next week, a senior Republican aide said Thursday.

title: Captive Audience, Mad Interrogator
description: Dave Eggerss short new novel has a long, awkward title: Your Fathers, Where Are They? And the Prophets, Do They Live Forever? And it turns out to be a labored, predictable and tiresome piece of fiction lacking the emotional wisdom and dazzling prose that have distinguished so much of this authors earlier work.

title: Orange Is the New Black Recap: The Prison of Stereotypes
description: Season 2, Episode 3: Shes back!

title: 184 Questions to Write or Talk About
description: Weve posted a fresh Student Opinion question nearly every weekday for the last five academic years. Every June, just as we do with that years lesson plans, we round them all up and post them in one place.

title: Amazon Introduces New Music Streaming Service
description: Amazon introduced a music streaming feature on Thursday that gives subscribers to its Prime service access to thousands of songs free and without interruptions from advertising.

title: Hes a Great Pet, Even if He Does Singe Your Hair
description: War and peace. Humans and animals. Contemplation of our bestial versus our spiritual sides. These may be too much heavy baggage to attach to a corporate product like How to Train Your Dragon 2. But such matters are there for you to ponder in this sequel to the 2010 blockbuster that recertified DreamWorks Animation, after a fallow period, as a major player in Hollywoods cartoon sweepstakes. And pop mythology nowadays has a way of seeping into the culture and sending far-reaching undercurrents.

title: Anti-Overdose Drug Becoming an Everyday Part of Police Work
description: Amid the weeknight bustle of a Walmart parking lot in Centereach, N.Y., a young woman in a pickup truck had lost consciousness and was turning blue.

title: Russia Sees American Adventurism in Iraq Behind Current Conflict
description: MOSCOW  Expressing alarm over the conflict in Iraq on Thursday, Russia said it had long predicted that American and British adventurism there would end badly.

title: After Much Debate, Picasso Curtain Will Be Moved From the Four Seasons
description: One of New York Citys largest and most public artworks is headed for a new home, bringing to an end LAffaire Tricorne.

title: AirAsia India Sets Off on Maiden Flight
description: NEW DELHI  The maiden flight of AirAsia India, the newest entrant in the countrys aviation sector, took off from Bangalore for the state of Goa on Thursday, marking the first time that an airline with foreign investment began operations in the country.

description: David Leonhardt, who wrote about a study on the opinions of sports fans around the world on the eve of the World Cup, will take questions on Facebook today at 2 p.m.

description: The American public is willing to pay more to curb climate change.

description: This interview with Adam Nash, chief executive of Wealthfront, an online financial management firm, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: His Job Whittled Down, Twitters No. 2 Resigns
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Twitters chief operating officer, Ali Rowghani, resigned on Thursday, after months of watching his responsibilities shrink.

title: Please Advise
description: What is advice for? Should it reassure us, or shake us up? Should it encourage us to compare ourselves to the advice giver or to the rest of humanity? And can it really help us?

title: Meeting in the Middle, More or Less
description: Justin Griffiths grew up in Stamford, Conn. He had rented in various places in Fairfield County, most recently a one-bedroom at the Lockworks, a new building in Stamfords South End. It overflowed with amenities, including his two favorites, a swimming pool and an outdoor grilling area.

title: Markets Are Restacking the Building Blocks of a Financial Crisis
description: If any of the ingredients that make up a new and powerful financial crisis are missing from the current commercial bouillabaisse, it is awfully difficult to discern just what they might be.

title: Maazel to Slow Down, on Doctors Orders
description: Lorin Maazel, always a dynamo on the podium  always, in his case, meaning since he was 8  has posted a message on his website saying that his doctors have advised him to slow down, and that he will therefore give up his directorship of the Munich Philharmonic. He also said he would not take any professional engagements during the 2014-15 season.

title: Now Booking | A Techno-Utopian Bar in San Francisco for Those Who Like to Think While They Drink
description: Since merriment sometimes just isnt enough, the Interval, a Mensa-courting bar that opens this month in the Fort Mason Center, also offers a library stacked with 1,000 literary masterworks and reference books, an ambient soundtrack created by Brian Eno and, later this year, two robots: One will make drinks, while the other will write predictions about the future on the spaces massive chalkboard. Conceived by the San Francisco-based collective the Long Now Foundation  whose board of directors includes Eno and the Whole Earth Catalog creator Stewart Brand  the Interval will also host regular salons for cerebral scenesters.

title: Efforts by Colleges to Curb Assaults Focus on Fraternities
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  At the University of Tennessee this year, some fraternity pledges had hot sauce poured on their genitals. At Emory in Atlanta, pledges were required to consume items not typical for eating and to engage in fistfights. And at Wesleyan in Connecticut, a few months after the university reached a settlement with a woman who said she was raped at a fraternity house, another woman said that she was raped at a different fraternity house.

title: Goldmans Unusually Quiet Role in Battle for Botox Maker
description: Goldman Sachs is known for successfully defending its clients against hostile takeover attempts. So it was little surprise when Allergan, the maker of Botox, hired Goldman to fend off an unsolicited $53 billion acquisition by Valeant Pharmaceuticals.

title: Bill Gates Asks, How Would You Give Away $50K?
description: Bill Gates, the wealthiest American and an advocate of philanthropic giving, turned to his 16.2 million Twitter followers on Thursday to solicit ideas for how to give away $50,000.

title: The Innovation That Grew and Grew
description: Could anything be simpler than a box in a corner of a TV screen continuously showing the score of a game and the time remaining?

title: Theater Listings for June 13-19
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Christie to Appear With Jimmy Fallon. Cue the Uncomfortable Laughter.
description: For Gov. Chris Christie, the decision by people within his camp to cause a traffic jam in Fort Lee, N.J., by closing traffic lanes at the George Washington Bridge has caused him no end of pain.

title: Fending Off the Bosss Outbursts
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: How Obamas Climate Goals Will Play in Silicon Valley
description: If the United States is going to achieve President Obamas new climate change goals, an X factor is how Silicon Valley will respond. Success will depend, many analysts think, on whether the policy will spur entrepreneurs to come up with new technologies and create a clean energy economy.

title: Jake Gyllenhaal to Make Broadway Debut
description: The Oscar-nominated actor Jake Gyllenhaal will make his Broadway debut in the American premiere of Nick Paynes Constellations. The play, a hit in London in 2012, will have a limited run at the Manhattan Theater Clubs Samuel J. Friedman Theater, with previews starting on Dec. 16. It will open on Jan. 13, 2015.

title: Comedy Listings for June 13-19
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Image of the Day: June 12
Missing Collateral a Sign of Weakness in Chinas Financing Chains
description: Faith in metal-backed lending in China is corroding  and so is confidence in the countrys giant credit system. Authorities and banks, including Standard Chartered and Citic, are investigating whether traders at Qingdao port used the same lot of copper and aluminum to back multiple loans. Vanishing collateral isnt a new problem, but could prove to be Chinas weakest link.

title: Coke Can Be Sued by Rival Over Juice Claim, Court Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Thursday unanimously allowed a false advertising suit against a Coca-Cola juice blend to move forward, saying the companys practices allegedly mislead and trick consumers, all to the injury of competitors.

title: In Her Words | Elizabeth Hawes on Fashion and Style
description: For Ts culture issue, out this Sunday, Alice Gregory wrote about The Most Brilliant American Fashion Designer: Elizabeth Hawes, the writer, designer and feminist who passed away in 1971. Throughout her career, Hawes offered an honest, often funny appraisal of the fashion world as it was and as she thought it should be. She was a proponent of using style to get what you want (and, essentially, to become who you want to be), and a wicked critic. While researching the piece, Gregory amassed a collection of Hawess wittiest one-liners from her nine books. Here, she lists her 10 favorite quips from the most important woman in fashion youve never heard of.

title: The Most Brilliant American Fashion Designer
description: Introducing Elizabeth Hawes: genius writer, wry cultural commentator, perverse humorist, gifted artist and truly modern thinker. Youve never heard of her.

title: When One Students Enrollment Was News
description: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. Negro Is Enrolled in Louisiana School appeared on June 9 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

title: An Alert When the Policy Lapses
description: Michael Pirron is feeling pretty good these days.

title: Bolinas, Calif., the Town That Didn't Want Company
description: The Grand Hotel is neither, really. Forty-five years ago  before the poets Robert Creeley and Lawrence Ferlinghetti bought houses nearby; before a food co-op and a naturopathic store opened down the street; before the rustic surfing town of Bolinas, Calif., was the sort of place where a tourist would consider spending the night  the Grand Hotel was merely Vic Amorosos house, with a garage that doubled as a bric-a-brac shop.

title: Rangers Will Need More Luck to Come Back Against the Kings
description: The Rangers needed a supernatural force field over their goal line Wednesday night to keep from being unceremoniously swept out of the Stanley Cup finals by the Los Angeles Kings. While that made for a thrilling moment for the Madison Square Garden faithful, it came with the knowledge that the Rangers might need similar otherworldly happenings to intervene in three more games.

title: Palestinian Premier Says New Government Lacks Power in Gaza
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The Palestinian Authority has had a new government for 10 days now, but the prime minister, Rami Hamdallah, acknowledged on Thursday that he still lacked any authority in the Hamas-dominated Gaza Strip and that nothing had yet changed on the ground.

title: Tony Committee Decision to Drop Sound Design Awards Prompts Noisy Outcry
description: Sound designers working on Broadway and at theaters nationwide erupted in outrage after a committee that oversees the Tony Awards decided Wednesday to eliminate future awards for best sound design of a play and of a musical.

title: Just Like the Last One, Only Different
description: More is more and is, at times, just right in 22 Jump Street, an exploding piata of gags, pratfalls, winking asides, throwaway one-liners and self-reflexive waggery. This is, of course, the sequel to 21 Jump Street, the 2012 hit that borrowed its title and undercover brother shtick from the old television show best known for its hair-gel hottie, Johnny Depp. For a second time, Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum play lovable undercover cops who  in between dodging danger and jokes that fly almost as fast as they do on The Simpsons  insinuate themselves into a juvenile population, whose resistance to these charmers has been rendered completely futile, much like that of the movies audience.

title: Checking In With the International Desk on Iraq
description: Kyle Crichton, an international editor, was involved in our coverage of Iraq from 2003 to 2010. We asked him how the desk is handling the coverage now, as insurgents push toward Baghdad.

title: Clip: 22 Jump Street
description: A scene from the film featuring Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum.

title: Jill Abramson, Ex-Times Editor, to Teach at Harvard
description: Jill Abramson, the former executive editor of The New York Times, will teach undergraduate courses in narrative nonfiction at Harvard this fall, the university announced on Thursday.

title: When a Stressful Hospital Stay Makes You Sick
description: The woman was rolled into the emergency department by paramedics. Struggling to breathe, she bent forward, hands on her knees, using gravity to help expand her chest.

title: Primary Voters, Maybe Not So Extreme After All
description: It would be easy to interpret Eric Cantors loss as evidence that primary elections are adding to or even driving the polarization in Congress by replacing centrist members with more extreme substitutes. But doing so would be a mistake.

title: Indian Points Tritium Problem and the N.R.C.s Regulatory Problem
description: Updated, 7:01 p.m. | The Indian Point nuclear power plant, 30 miles from New York City (and 8 miles from my house), has been run safely and reliably for the most part. But its at a critical juncture, with New York Governor Andrew Cuomo having vowed to shut it down and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission weighing relicensing for the two operating reactors.

description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

In addition to the bars and saloons where soccer fans gather on a regular basis, hotels are opening rooftops for viewings; big screens are being erected in Dumbo, Brooklyn, and on 46th Street in Manhattans Little Brazil; and normally staid restaurants are being converted into arenas for the faithful.

title: Juan Gabriel Vsquez Wins International Impac Dublin Literary Award
description: The Colombian novelist Juan Gabriel Vsquez on Thursday became the first South American writer to win the lucrative International Impac Dublin Literary Award, for The Sound of Things Falling (Riverhead Books).

title: Ruby Dee, a Ringing Voice for Civil Rights, Onstage and Off, Dies at 91
description: Ruby Dee, one of the most enduring actresses of theater and film, whose public profile and activist passions made her, along with her husband, Ossie Davis, a leading advocate for civil rights both in show business and in the wider world, died on Wednesday at her home in New Rochelle, N.Y. She was 91.

title: U.S. Scrambles to Help Iraq Fight Off Militants as Baghdad Is Threatened
description: WASHINGTON  The White House, confronted by an unexpected crisis on a battlefield it thought it had left behind, scrambled Thursday to reassure Iraq that it would help its beleaguered army fend off militants who have overrun much of the country and now threaten Baghdad.

title: Soccer and Internal Discord, on Display for World to See
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Brazil reaffirmed its reputation as a powerhouse of global soccer in the opening match here of the World Cup on Thursday, setting off street parties around the country, but its widening political fissures were also on display for an international audience.

title: The Privacy Paradox, a Challenge for Business
description: People around the world are thrilled by the ease and convenience of their smartphones and Internet services, but they arent willing to trade their privacy to get more of it.

title: With Eric Cantors Loss, Is Immigration Reform Dead?
description: People who say immigration reform is good and dead, now that House majority leader Eric Cantor lost his primary to an immigration hard-liner, include those who really want it to be dead. These are the ones shoving the pillow into immigration reforms face.
