description: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food  from its original source to a place on your table.

title: Award Categories for Grammys Are Tweaked
description: The continually moving target of Grammy Award categories has shifted once again, with a handful of tweaks announced on Thursday that affect about 20 categories.

title: Spare Times for June 13-19
description: Jazz Age Lawn Party (Saturday and Sunday) Hosted and conceived by the musician Michael Arenella, this annual event on Governors Island transports guests to the Roaring Twenties with hot jazz, vaudeville, tap dancing and vintage automobiles.

title: Ex-Leader of Ivory Coast Is Ordered to Stand Trial
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Laurent Gbagbo, the former Ivory Coast strongman whose refusal to accept electoral defeat in 2010 set off a brief but bloody civil war, was ordered to stand trial Thursday by the International Criminal Court in The Hague.

title: How Obama Can Increase Taxes on Carried Interest
description: President Obama could change the tax treatment of carried interest with a phone call to the Treasury Department. But the White House will need a precise understanding of the regulatory landscape to make a change that is fair, easy to administer, and will hold up in court.

title: Deconstructing the Illusion
description: To the trophy-hunting diner, the more difficult a restaurant is to find, the more alluring it is. Consider, then, the checklist for Houdini Kitchen Laboratory: No sign. Unmarked entrance at the back of a former brewery. (Better yet, through a fence to the back yard, a.k.a. loading dock.) On a bleak block of industrial buildings with graffiti palimpsests and rusted drips from what pass for windows.

title: What to Do When Crawdad Grows Anxious
description: Crazed commuters, fretful parents and overwrought executives are not the only ones to suffer from anxiety  or to benefit from medication for it. The simple crayfish has officially entered the age of anxiety, too.

title: Bergdahl Departs Germany for Treatment in Texas
description: WASHINGTON  Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, the American prisoner of war freed on May 31 in exchange for five senior members of the Taliban, left Ramstein Air Base in Germany on Thursday afternoon and will arrive in the United States early Friday to begin treatment at a Texas military medical facility, the Pentagon said.

title: Boehner Slams Obamas Response to Iraq
description: House Speaker John A. Boehner commented on the crisis in Iraq on Thursday and attacked President Obamas response to the escalating violence, saying the president was taking a nap.

title: Countries Weigh In on Iraqs Unrest
description: Britain, the United States, the United Nations and countries in the region react to the intense fighting in Iraq.

title: Teenage Endurance Driver Takes Exams While Preparing for Le Mans
description: PARIS  Alessandro Latif didnt betray any emotion while waiting for his exams to begin on the campus of the British School of Paris in Le Vsinet, a suburb of the French capital. But you could sense his excitement, nervousness and fatigue.

title: Treasurys Domestic Finance Chief to Leave
description: The Treasury Departments top official for domestic finance, Mary J. Miller, plans to step down this fall after having helped to oversee the rollout of the Dodd-Frank overhaul of financial regulations.

title: After Police Dog Is Injured, Partner Responds Quickly
description: For the past eight years, Officer Anthony Compitello and Caesar left for work every morning together, came home every evening together and spent nearly every hour in between working together.

title: A Wedding and a Funeral
description: Tears spill from the eyes of Maung Tin May. This is supposed to be the happiest day of her life.

title: Kids and Parents: Happy to Move Up, Sad to Say Goodbye
description: This morning was the step-up ceremony at my childrens school. Its the fifth time Ive attended this same event (its a K-8 school) and it always follows the same leisurely pattern: acknowledging the teachers; various presentations; songs from each of the different music classes; speeches from the fifth graders who are moving on to middle school; and a class gift from the graduating eighth grade (that had a separate graduation ceremony the day before). There is no pomp and circumstance, there are no flat hats. Its a pleasant, charming way of acknowledging the passing of another year and the inevitable forward movement of children. And the first time I attended, I felt like chewing my own arm off to escape.

title: Brazil vs. Croatia: Live Blog
description: In the end, its the result that everyone expected, but not before Croatia scared Brazilian fans everywhere with a shock 1-0 lead.

title: Life in the Fast Lane
description: My widowed father is 80 and has begun dating a woman close to his age. She has tremendous joie de vivre, but my siblings and I worry that she is wearing our father out, scheduling social events nearly every night of the week. We want our father to enjoy his life, but not at the expense of his health, which seems to be failing. We have raised our concerns with our father, who has not taken them to heart. But we disagree about whether to speak with his new partner. Should we?

title: We Didnt Have a Plan, but the Baby Did
description: About a year into our marriage, my wife and I decided we were ready for the adventure of having a child. Despite our best efforts, it wasnt happening. We didnt know why. One night as we were watching television, my wife turned to me and said, I think youre the problem.

title: Wheelies: The Made for Europeans by Tennesseans Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Stepans Sweep (of a Glove) Helps His Team Avoid One
description: Soccer has its Hand of God. Now hockey has its Hand of Stepan.

title: UBS Hires Veteran Bank of America Executive
description: UBS has hired Jerry Marcus, a former head of Bank of America Merrill Lynchs retail investment banking group, as a vice chairman for its Americas investment bank, the Swiss firm said on Thursday.

title: Casino Owner Caesars Redefines Itself, but Still Has Mountain of Debt
description: Caesars Entertainment, the owner of several casinos, is taking a page from the Dynegy playbook. That is not meant as a compliment.

title: Bain Capitals Mark Nunnelly Retires
description: Mark Nunnelly, a longtime managing director of Bain Capital, has retired from the Boston-based private equity firm, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

title: Haitian Art and Dance in Brooklyn
description: Haitian art  a rich blend of African and European, Christian and Voodoo influences  impresses all the more when you remember that it emerges from a swirl of poverty, political violence and natural disasters.

title: Q. and A. | Wild Belle Spreads Its Island Vibes
description: Reggae-based pop music has unlikely torchbearers in Elliot and Natalie Bergman, a.k.a. Wild Belle. The brother-sister duo grew up around Chicago, a city thats more Buddy Guy than Bob Marley, and spent much of their childhood like modern-day Von Trapps, singing songs around the piano with their parents and two other siblings. Elliot, who plays keyboard and saxophone and, at 32, is seven years Natalies senior, would go on to study jazz and play in an Afrobeat band, Nomo, at the University of Michigan. And the siblings travels, both literal and sonic, helped expand their musical purview. The resulting mix of sounds  indie pop tinged with reggae and 70s soul  can be heard throughout Wild Belles debut album, Isles, released last year. And though they insist the title is more about the albums structure than its influences (each song is its own island, Natalie has said), it might just as easily be a nod to Chris Blackwells Island Records, whose catalogue of ska and reggae hits surely left an impression.

title: A Logo for America
description: A video of the work by Alfredo Jaar.

title: Anatomy | How to Train Your Dragon 2
description: Dean DeBlois narrates a sequence from How to Train Your Dragon 2.

title: Drug Merger Discussion Leaves Out a Key Risk
description: As shareholders of the global pharmaceutical giant Mallinckrodt consider approving its $5.6 billion bid for Questcor Pharmaceuticals, a small but fast-growing California company, they must try to assess the risks associated with the deal.

title: Mallinckrodt, Questcor and Questions About Acthar
description: Mallinckrodt announced in April that it intended to merge with Questcor Pharmaceuticals, which makes the immune system drug Acthar. But a key filing last month did not disclose adverse effects from the drug that were reported to regulators.

title: Clip: The Rover
description: A scene from The Rover, directed by David Michod and featuring Guy Pearce and Robert Pattinson.

title: Jump-Start Your Workday With an 8 A.M. Rave
description: THREE tall, glowing jellyfish puppets swept around the club floor, illuminating the broad grins and sweat-soaked brows of the wildly hopping dancers. Thumping house remixes of Tears for Fears Everybody Wants to Rule the World and Missy Elliotts Work It rattled the balcony railings. Two D.J.s pumped their fists as a small pack of brass players appeared on the balcony, bleating along to the electronic soundtrack under stark strobe lights.

title: European Film Directors Issue Appeal for Imprisoned Ukrainian Colleague
description: Top European film directors, including Pedro Almodvar, Mike Leigh, Andrzej Wajdaand Wim Wenders, have appealed to President Vladimir V. Putin and other Russian officials about the fate of Oleg Sentsov, a Ukrainian filmmaker who was arrested in Crimea last month on suspicion of plotting terrorist acts.

title: Dean DeBlois Narrates a Scene From How to Train Your Dragon 2
description: In this video, the director Dean DeBlois discusses a sequence from How to Train Your Dragon 2, a sequel to the 2010 blockbuster. This scene features the lead character Hiccup (voiced by Jay Baruchel) flying through the clouds with his dragon companion, Toothless.

title: Low Vitamin D Tied to Premature Death
description: People with low blood levels of vitamin D are more likely to die prematurely than those with normal levels, a new analysis has found.

title: Homeless Lamp, the Juice Sucker
description: Excerpt from a video of a performance by the artist Ivn Navarro and his flourescent light bulb sculpture on the streets of Chelsea.

title: In World Cup, Mexico Believes Anything Can Happen After Rough Road to Brazil
description: NATAL, Brazil  In the eyes of the Mexican writer Juan Villoro, a frequent commentator on soccer and, thus, a person with a keen sense of narrative structure, the Mexico national teams undulant path to this city unfolded much like the plot of a telenovela.

title: Training at the Top of the World
description: Higher Unplugged looks at the making of the film Higher, which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

title: Clip: Witching & Bitching
description: A scene from the film, directed by Alex de la Iglesia.

title: Clip: Lullaby
description: A scene from the film directed by Andrew Levitas.

title: Three Confirmations to Fed Board May Strengthen Yellens Hand
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday brought the Federal Reserve Board a little closer to full strength, confirming Lael Brainard, a former Treasury Department official, to one of the three open seats by a vote of 61 to 31.

title: New Flights to Colombia
description: Two airlines have announced plans to add flights to Cartagena this year, reflecting the growth in American tourism demand in Colombia.

title: Police Tactics Under Increased Scrutiny at World Cup
description: Protesters in Brazil accused the police of using excessive force to prevent a small group of demonstrators opposed to what they call lavish spending on the World Cup from reaching the stadium in So Paulo where the tournament began on Thursday afternoon.

title: Defending Guilty Pleasures
description: Should we feel bad about reading for fun? A Slate critique of young-adult fiction last week had readers answering mostly in the negative. But beyond any specific genre, there may be a larger conversation to be had about which books are good, which books are fun, and whether there needs to be a difference.

title: In Store | Everlane Pops Up in SoHo
description: Since 2011, the online-only basics brand Everlanehas, with its motto of radical transparency, encouraged consumers to ask where and how their clothes are made  and how much they are marked up(which in Everlanes case is a fraction of the usual amount).Starting tomorrow, shoppers will have the chance to sample the brands understated (and, compared to similar offerings, underpriced) staples in person at a SoHo pop-up. And though its not Everlanes first appearance in New York, its by far its largest and most social outing. Called Open House, the space, which operates through June 28, will host catered events with other transparency-minded organizations from the food world, such as Gather Journal and Edible Schoolyard NYC. Every garment and accessory sold in the store  whose perforated-plywood interiors come courtesy of the Isa restauranteur Taavo Somers creative agency, Friends and Family will be sold alongside an infographic detailing its origin story.

title: Getting to the Heart of Suriname
description: Nelson Tiapoe pointed out two mature trees just a few feet apart amid the dense jungle vegetation. When you see a mango tree and a cacao tree together, you know people used to live here, he said. He was leading me and a 62-year-old Dutch man named Ton through the dense Amazonian rain forest of central Suriname just across the Upper Suriname River from his eco-resort, Knini Paati.

title: Friulano, an Italian White Wine That Makes Friends Easily
description: CIVIDALE DEL FRIULI, Italy  You may have sipped a pleasant pinot grigio from Friuli, a region in the far northeast of Italy known for its white wines and more properly called Friuli-Venezia Giulia. But you are less likely to have had a glass of friulano, a more distinguished wine that is worth discovering.

title: Built on Historic Foundations
description: Sometimes theres too much theory. Sometimes too little. Theres not enough animating Exposed: A History of Lingerie, an otherwise nicely produced exhibition at the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology. Organized by Colleen Hill, the museums associate curator of accessories, it presents 80 examples of European and American undergarments and accessories dating from the 18th century to the present, all from the museums permanent collection.

title: Woman Is Found Hanged in Indian State
description: NEW DELHI  The body of a 19-year-old woman was found hanging by her scarf from a eucalyptus tree in a village in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh on Thursday morning, the police said. It was the third similar gruesome discovery in the state in two weeks.

title: Living With Cancer: The Fault in Our Stars
description: Cancer books suck, says 16-year-old Hazel Grace Lancaster. But she has a favorite and so do I. Mine is the novel John Green wrote about her.

title: Harriss Run in Angry Inch Wont Get Any Longer
description: Neil Patrick Harris, who won the Tony Award for best actor in a musical for  Hedwig and the Angry Inch, will not extend his run in the show beyond his scheduled departure date of Aug. 17 in spite of strong ticket demand, the shows lead producer said on Thursday. Taking over for Mr. Harris will be Andrew Rannells, a Tony nominee as Elder Price in The Book of Mormon and a cast member of the HBO series Girls, according to the producer, David Binder.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Remember the Problems With Mortgage Defaults? Theyre Coming Back With Student Loans
description: Student loans, along with mortgages and car loans, have become one of the three largest sources of credit, exceeding credit-card debt. This growth in student debt appears to have caught regulators unprepared. Compared with mortgages, auto loans and credit cards, student loans are loosely regulated, and that regulatory weakness is particularly threatening to consumers because they cant discharge their debts through bankruptcy and escape lenders who are causing them harm.

title: James Jebusa Shannons Portraits Rescued From Obscurity
description: ONCE FORGOTTEN PAST, NOW RECALLED IN PAINTING

title: Marijuanas Journey to Legitimacy
description: Great social policy changes are not an easy sell, says Jonathan Martin, a reporter for The Seattle Times, in Riley Mortons assured documentary Evergreen. Hes not kidding: This record of Washington States battle over Initiative 502, which legalized possession of small amounts of recreational marijuana in 2012, is predictably loaded with rancor. The battle isnt over whether pot should be legalized, but to what extent.

title: Questioning the Unimaginable: A Fifth FIFA Term for Sepp Blatter
description: RIO dE JANEIRO  There was that face again.

title: Iraqi Army Retakes Government Complex in Central Ramadi
description: Efforts to stem the rise of the Islamic State.

title: A History of Awesome in One Room
description: THE MORGAN LIBRARY & MUSEUM does not usually put trash on the wall, but there are exceptions. Among the nearly 60 rare books, manuscripts and objects on exhibit in Marks of Genius: Treasures From the Bodleian Library is a constellation of khaki-colored papyrus scraps retrieved about a century ago from an ancient dump outside the vanished Egyptian city of Oxyrhynchus. Over the years, excavations at the site have yielded census forms, invoices, bureaucratic correspondence and the occasional literary find  in this instance, a fragment of verse by Sappho, inscribed in Greek in the second century A.D., from the first of the nine books of poems she is known to have written.

title: A German Rebel in South Africa
description: Jrgen Schadeberg left Nazi Germany to pursue photography in South Africa, where he documented the black struggle and trained a generation of photographers.

title: A Photographer Recalls Her Life Within a Demimonde
description: A long time ago, a doctor told the photographer Nan Goldin that she had the genes of an Olympic athlete. Just as well: Even while eliding the details of her colorful, adventurous past, Nan Goldin: I Remember Your Face contains enough throwaway references to bodily harm to make her and her admirers grateful for the gifts of biology.

title: Movies Listings for June 13-19
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Arriving Late to the Party, but Dancing on All the Clichs
description: Our big museums were built by businessmen, and significant changes are usually about making money. In these days of international markets and a cosmopolitan tourist flow, it pays for Western Modernist strongholds to look culturally embracing. This helps explain the Guggenheims UBS MAP Global Art Initiative, a three-phase collecting venture that finds the museum buying and showing the kinds of work it has paid little attention to in the past.

title: Letters: Summer Reading Issue
description: Summer Reading Issue

title: Navigating Persistence and Despair
description: A line Ben Watt sang at Joes Pub on Wednesday night  Who am I fooling when I say I have no regrets?  could encapsulate his songwriting. Its modest, pensive, backhanded, self-questioning, emotional yet elegantly restrained.

title: Antics Pierced by Angst
description: Emily Dickinson, a very American poet, may have called hope the thing with feathers. But for the British playwright Alan Ayckbourn, hope is largely a flightless creature. It flaps its wings from time to time, but it seldom gets far off the ground.

title: The Battle Money Couldnt Win
description: The dowdy loft building at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 52nd Street is about as blank as a building can get, just limestone and windows. But it sent the Vanderbilt family over the edge, the symbol of their defeat after years of attempts to preserve the residential sanctity of this stretch of New Yorks most famous address.

title: Schomburg to Create Center to Study Slave Trade
description: The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture is establishing a major new center for the analysis of the trans-Atlantic slave trade, the only such center based in a public research library, Schomburg officials said on Thursday.

title: Jayson Musson: Exhibit of Abstract Art
description: Salon 94 Bowery

title: Ken Price: Specimen Rocks
description: Matthew Marks Gallery

title: A Car Is Stolen, Setting Off an Angry Pursuit
description: The Rover, David Michds new film, takes place in Australia 10 years after an unspecified event called the Collapse, which has left everyone in a bad mood and catastrophically short of shaving supplies. This is not quite the apocalyptic ground zero of The Road or The Road Warrior (speaking of Down Under dystopias). Roving bands of armed men drive around shooting, but some of them wear uniforms and fill out government paperwork when they catch someone. Money still works (American dollars are preferred over Australian), and there seems to be enough food, gasoline and ammunition to keep everybody alert, mobile and angry.

title: A Painter and His Poets: The Art of George Schneeman
description: Poets House

title: Barely Moving, but Communicating Volumes
description: The Canadian performance artist Dana Michel is a real original, peculiar to the nth degree and remarkably compelling onstage. She scarcely dances; she scarcely speaks; her manner is oblique. It would be easy to make what she does sound ridiculous. Yet no sooner does she take the stage than she creates a complex world. Shes doing a singular form of acting, and were caught up by the strangeness of both her outward behavior and her characters private thoughts. For me and others, she was the one important discovery of the American Realness Festival at the Abrons Arts Center in January.

title: Events in Westchester for June 15-21, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: A Show That Really Gets Into Your Head
description: PHILADELPHIA  Clambering upward in dim violet light, stepping from one glass platform to another, you trigger flashes of light and polyps of sound. You climb through protective tubes of metallic mesh as you make your way through a maze of pathways. You are an electrical signal coursing through a neural network. You are immersed in the human brain.

title: Mark Rothko: The Watercolors 1941-47
description: Pace Gallery

title: The Antidote to Sweet
description: PHILADELPHIA  With her site-specific sphinx-goddess on view at the former Domino Sugar Factory in Brooklyn, Kara Walker is making a bold leap from two dimensions into three. And she has many more thoughts brewing on the subjects of sculpture and architecture, to judge from Ruffneck Constructivists, a smart, gripping and confrontational show she organized for the Institute of Contemporary Art here.

title: Conversation Served With Cocktails
description: IT was at some point between mixing caipirinhas and doing a little dance to Ann-Margrets rendition of Thirteen Men (Last night I was dreaming/I dreamed about the H-bomb) that Bryan Richgruber, a bartender at Big Bar in the East Village, quietly said, Isnt this a great bar?

title: Sycamore Takes 10% Stake in Express and Seeks a Deal
description: The investment firm Sycamore Partners disclosed on Thursday that it had acquired a 9.9 percent stake in Express Inc., the fashionable retailer that has hit a slump of late, and is interested in buying the rest of the company.

title: Missed Connections
description: Is there room in American fiction for another brilliant young migr writer? There had better be, because here he is. Boris Fishmans first novel, A Replacement Life, is bold, ambitious and wickedly smart.

title: A Difficult Woman, With a Past Worth Writing About
description: In Violette, Emmanuelle Devos plays one of those impossible women who cant give anyone, most of all herself, a break. For Violette Leduc, a black marketeer turned celebrated writer, life is a series of crushing disappointments, from the mother who never took her hand to the friends who never stay. Early in the film when a friend leaves the home they share, he sneaks out like a thief. He knows her too well. She doesnt let him go; rather, she chases him down a road, frantically pulling at him and howling. This is a woman who doesnt feed on misery: She gorges on it.

title: Man Without a Country
description: The last full-length book Stefan Zweig wrote was a memoir called The World of Yesterday, an elegy for the Viennese culture that had nurtured his literary talent and was, in 1941, in the process of being wiped out by fascism and world war. The book was completed in Brazil, where Zweig and his second wife, Lotte, had settled after years of expatriate hopscotching and where they would commit suicide on Feb. 22, 1942.

title: Out of Berlin, the Heart of an Artist
description: BERLIN  Before Jasper Johns or Jackson Pollock, there was Marsden Hartley, Americas first great modern painter of the 20th century. He achieved this distinction in Paris and most of all in Berlin between early 1912 and late 1915. There he produced a stream of paintings that synthesized Cubism and other European modernisms, mixed in non-Western motifs and mysterious symbols and culminated in his lusty, elegiac German Officer paintings.

title: In Serious Pursuit, Even in Clown Shoes
description: In a musicians work, you often hear a position or an effect or a big idea: humor, revision, argument, discipline, cynicism, romance. Its just something extra to engage, a filter or transformer between the creative force inside him and the expectations of his listeners. Not so much, though, in the work of Charles Gayle, who played through opening night of this years Vision Festival on Wednesday night at Roulette, as bandleader and duet partner and conductor; playing saxophone, piano and bass; and in and out of clown clothes. He seems almost transparent: Your hearing cuts right through to what animates him.

title: Hellfighters, High Finance and an Heiress
description: Before the 15th New York National Guard Regiment was formed, black Americans who wanted to enlist against the Germans in World War I had to join the French or Canadian Army. By the end of the war, this all-black regiment was famous on both sides of the Atlantic for never losing an inch of ground to the enemy, or a single man to capture.

title: F.D.A. Issues Clarification, but Cheese Makers Are Wary
description: The panic over what appeared to be a change in the federal rules that govern the craft of artisan cheese making seems to be dying down, but cheese makers remain suspicious, even after the Food and Drug Administration said late Wednesday that it had erred.

title: Agnes Varda in Chris Markers Studio
description: The French filmmaker Agns Varda visits with Chris Marker at his home.

title: An Extended Family Puts on a Big Recital
description: Alvin Ailey died almost 25 years ago at the too-young age of 58, yet his company, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, remains undeniably robust, unlike many that have lost their founders. So much so that its no longer just a company. The institution has tiers, as showcased Wednesday during the inaugural Ailey Spirit Gala at the David H. Koch Theater, where the main company shared the stage with members of Ailey II, the Ailey School and AileyCamp.

title: Orpheus Descending and Arising
description: The indomitable Yefim Bronfman stars in the New York Philharmonics minifestival of Beethovens piano concertos unveiled on Wednesday at Avery Fisher Hall with glowing performances of the first and fourth concertos.

title: Who Was Gyp the Blood?
description: Q.My father used to tell me that when he was a little boy, he was scared to death at hearing stories about a gangster known as Gyp the Blood. Can you tell me something about this person?

title: Clip: Hellion
description: A scene from the film, directed by Kat Candler.

title: Mosul Residents Flee as Unrest Spreads
description: Thousands of Mosul residents continued to flee the violence in Iraqs second-largest city after Al Qaeda-inspired militants seized the area.

title: Protests Spread Across Brazil
description: Demonstrators clashed with the police in So Paulo and Rio de Janeiro a few hours before the opening game of the World Cup.

title: Player Tumbles; Opposition Falls
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  It was Dia dos Namorados on Thursday, the Brazilian equivalent of Valentines Day, which meant there were chocolates and flowers and couples holding hands tucked among the sea of yellow jerseys that stretched from the Itaquera neighborhood over to Jardins. From sunrise all the way until the shimmering moon peeked above the skyline, Brazilians showed their passion for one another, and for soccer, as the World Cup began.

title: Brides Gather Outside Court to Jeer Restaurateur Who Dashed Wedding Plans
description: The balding man dressed in black knew plenty of the people in the Brooklyn courtroom, watching on Thursday morning as he pleaded guilty to charges of tax fraud. But as he hurried out of the courthouse and into a waiting car, he did not lift his eyes to acknowledge a single one of them.

title: Celebrating a Salsa Legacy
description: FROM the beginning, the kinetically danceable Latin music style known as salsa had deep New York roots. It was created by musicians who, though mostly of Caribbean origins, lived here, played in clubs here for audiences trying to find their footing here and recorded in studios here for a label that was also born here: Fania Records.

title: When Teenage Anger Spirals Like a Texas Tornado
description: Going nowhere slowly and with great deliberation, Hellion presents a fractured family locked in a closed loop of adolescent misbehavior and adult retaliation. The instigator is Jacob (Josh Wiggins), a troubled 13-year-old whose father, Hollis (Aaron Paul), has withdrawn into boozy depression after the death of his wife. Now a distant parent and indifferent housekeeper, Hollis provides little for Jacob and his younger brother (Deke Garner), aside from junk food and remonstrations.

title: Oy Gevalt! Untranslated Yiddish Recordings Stall State Senators Trial
description: WHITE PLAINS  In an odd twist in a courtroom saga dense with allegations of political corruption, the fate of State Senator Malcolm A. Smith and two other defendants may be put on hold because, of all things, Yiddish.

title: Two Bands of True Believers Hurtling Toward a Collision
description: There are moments in Policeman when it feels as if the director Nadav Lapid is drawing one very large noose around his characters. Thats especially true early in this hypnotic, slow-building shocker from Israel, before the narrative pieces have slid into place, revealing Mr. Lapids intentions. Certainly, nothing looks out of the ordinary in the opening images of five men bicycling up a steep country road. That is until one, Yaron (Yiftach Klein), breaks away and begins riding so hard and fast toward the camera that he looks as if he might break through the screen.

title: Abandon the Two-State Solution?
Now Screening | Travels With Agns Varda
description: In her new five-part travel series From Here to There (available through SundanceNOWs subscription program, Doc Club), the French filmmaker Agns Varda, now 86, sometimes referred to as The Grandmother of New Wave, attends art and film festivals, visits old friends, interviews favorite artists and makes new acquaintances. Most of the time, a camera is in her hand. Occasionally, someone else is filming and she enters the scene. Whether in front of the lens or behind it, her curiosity is boundless and rooted in a desire to share her friendships and pleasures. The main subject is the other,' she says. Im present in my films, Im among the others.

title: Keeping Troubled Youths Out of Solitary
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurant Workers
From the Friedman Forum: What Is a Job Today, and Who Is Getting Hired?
description: From the Editor: Below are the prepared remarks Thomas L. Friedman delivered today at the start of his second annual Next New World forum. This years conference, held in San Francisco, focused on the question, What is a job today, and who is getting hired? Speakers included Andrew McAfee, co-founder of the M.I.T. Initiative on the Digital Economy; Sebastian Thrun, chief executive of Udacity; Laszlo Bock, head of human resources at Google; David Coleman, president and chief executive of the College Board; and Jeff Weiner, chief executive of LinkedIn.

title: The Cathedral and the Towers
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping Students Succeed
description: To the Editor:

title: Brokers Fight Rule to Favor Best Interests of Customers
description: David OBrien, a certified financial planner, has tried to repair the retirement portfolios of several victims over the years. There was the high school science teacher who didnt realize she had been sold a variable annuity, where layers of incomprehensible fees devoured nearly 2.5 percent of her retirement savings each year. Then there was the woman fighting cancer, who was also sold a high-cost annuity, but whose underlying investments were tied up in a money-market type fund  one that cost 1.5 percent annually.

title: Jazz Listings for June 13-19
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: This Weeks Movies | June 13, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review 22 Jump Street, How to Train Your Dragon 2 and The Rover.

title: Tenure Decision Draws Sharp Debate
description: Timothy R. Williams is a community moderator, monitoring comments submitted to the website.

title: Events in New Jersey for June 15-21, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Iraq, Greece, Ukraine and France.

title: Clip: Test
description: A scene from the film, directed by Chris Mason Johnson.

title: 36 Hours in Venice
description: As frustrating as it is fascinating, Venice is not an easy city to get to know. Getting lost is a given. The crowds can be beastly. And yes, the whole place is sinking  literally under rising sea levels, and figuratively beneath the weight of day-tripping tourists. But these obstacles have not hindered this beguiling city from establishing itself over the past decade as the pre-eminent place in Italy for contemporary art. More recently, a wave of high-end hotels has opened along the Grand Canal, and back alleys have been set abuzz with new nightspots and a revived restaurant scene. So leave the famous sights to the crowds and instead drink up the less overt charms of this watery wonderland.

title: Grimly Staring in the Mirror, a Dancer in 85
description: Test, set in San Francisco in 1985, captures with extraordinary precision and sensitivity the moment when an H.I.V. test became available, and the citys gay men faced the daunting prospect of finding out their status. In those scary days, there was no pharmaceutical regimen that could arrest the disease. And as one man, looking ahead to a future of sexual self-discipline, puts it, Monogamy seems so unnatural. In the golden era of promiscuity and unprotected sex, the notion of suddenly having to use condoms seemed almost an affront, not to mention inconvenient.

title: Events on Long Island for June 15-21, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut for June 15-21, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Ford Lowers Gas Mileage on 6 Models, All 2013-14s
description: For the second time in less than a year, the Ford Motor Company is lowering the fuel-economy ratings for some of its vehicles.

title: Kentile Floors Sign, a Stalwart Remnant of a Grittier Brooklyn, Will Get a New Home
description: It is confirmed: The Kentile Floors sign in Brooklyn is coming down.

title: An Insurer and an Ad Agency Join Forces, Again
description: A WALK down memory lane for a major marketer and one of its former advertising agencies, inspired by Mad Men, is ending with a reunion.

title: When Chaos Trumps Civility
description: The opening scenes of Amat Escalantes Heli establish the terrible contradiction that ensnares its main character, a young Mexican factory worker. First, we see a brazen but also unnervingly businesslike act of brutality, in which a group of men drag two bound-and-battered hostages from the bed of a pickup truck and hang one of them, stripped to his underwear, from a highway overpass. Then we meet Heli (Armando Espitia) as he answers a knock on the door and chats with a friendly census worker in a bright yellow polo shirt. Her questions sound reasonable enough at first: How many people in the household? What is your profession? Later they will seem grotesquely irrelevant to the facts of Helis life.

title: Global Rules for Auditors? Dont Hold Your Breath
description: Chris Cox, who as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission tried to bring international accounting rules to the United States, has now done an about-face.

title: One Generation Passes; Another One Grumbles
description: Am I a hardhearted meanie because I watched Lullaby, a solemn, triple-hankie sobfest about assisted suicide, in a state of dry-eyed impatience? Maybe so. But Lullaby, the directorial debut of Andrew Levitas, a jack of all artistic trades, is the kind of manipulative, clich-infested hokum that alienates moviegoers by its insistence on hogging all the tears. Its subliminal message  Im more sensitive than you could possibly be  is exclusionary, and much of its stilted dialogue (Its hard to love someone whos got an expiration date stamped on their forehead) is cringe worthy.

title: The Fix Isnt In
description: How big a deal is the surprise primary defeat of Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader? Very. Movement conservatism, which dominated American politics from the election of Ronald Reagan to the election of Barack Obama  and which many pundits thought could make a comeback this year  is unraveling before our eyes.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Jesus, Youll Be the Stick-Up Guy. SpongeBob, Youre a Lookout.
description: Not counting a prologue right out of Macbeth, the Spanish comedy Witching & Bitching begins as a madcap heist picture. In Madrid, a group of hapless would-be criminals  dressed as a silver Christ, a soldier, Minnie Mouse, the Invisible Man and SpongeBob SquarePants  steals gold from a pawnshop.

title: Taking On Teacher Tenure Backfires
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  IN his decision on Tuesday to strike down Californias teacher-tenure system, Judge Rolf M. Treu of Los Angeles Superior Court ruled that laws protecting teachers from dismissal violated the states constitutional commitment to provide a basically equal opportunity to achieve a quality education and drew parallels with prior cases concerning school desegregation and funding levels.

title: Cy Twombly Works Donated to Tate Modern
description: Since 2010, the Tate Modern in London has devoted a gallery to Cy Twombly, the postwar American painter who died in 2011. In it are three large paintings from his Bacchus series  enormous abstract canvases of drippy red spirals dating from 2006-8  along with five bronze sculptures and assemblages of found objects, such as the top of an olive barrel, that were made between 1979 and 1991.

title: Secrets of the Ordinary Dad
description: His gut was a jellyroll or two over the belt line and he smoked these discount cigarettes he bought by the carton, but that didnt keep him from showing me one of his more nimble tricks. Wed wait till just after kickoff at the football game, the Cougars of Washington State. Then hed lead me around the side where we could sneak in by crawling under a small opening in a big chain-link fence. I was 6 or 7.

title: Private Toll Road Considered to Counter Population Boom
description: Facing traffic congestion that is only expected to get worse, officials in North Texas are weighing a proposal to build a toll road for commuters into Dallas. The Texas Turnpike Corporation of Dallas has proposed a private toll road, the only of its kind in the state, connecting Greenville and Wylie, and local transportation officials say they are keeping an open mind.

title: Truth as a Tinderbox That Must Disappear
description: Depicting his combustible material with a cool head and a steady hand, the Iranian filmmaker Mohammad Rasoulof  defying a 20-year government ban on his work  makes Manuscripts Dont Burn a slow-motion explosion of anti-authoritarian rage.

title: Save the Frick Collection
description: AMERICA has few mansions built by a family with an art collection they meant to share with the public. So when word came this week that the Frick Collection, on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, was planning toexpand and build a six-story addition where there is now a discreet garden and a splashing fountain with lily pads  one of those few places in the cityscape where we are allowed to stop and breathe  I felt blunt disappointment, as well as betrayal.

title: Under the Skin
description: CHICAGO  TRANSGENDER Americans scored a major victory for equality last month, when the Department of Health and Human Services overturned a decades-old ban on Medicare coverage for gender-confirming surgeries.

title: A Young Mans Dark-Roasted Day
description: A day-in-the-life story, A Coffee in Berlin follows the downward-sloping fortunes of Niko, a scruffily poetic slacker who loses his girlfriend, his drivers license and his financial support from Daddy. And thats before night falls.

title: New York Attorney General Supports a Bill Regulating Payroll Cards
description: After firing a warning shot last July, New Yorks attorney general has stepped up his battle against the A.T.M.-style cards that some of the states largest employers use to pay their workers.

title: Democrats Hope for Shift in Their Favor
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Those Offensive Linemen Make a Filling Meal
description: One witch and four cheerleaders enact savage revenge on the stars of a high school football team in All Cheerleaders Die, a trashy horror caper oozing blood and pheromones.

title: Hostile Takeover Bids for Big Firms Across Industries Make a Comeback
description: Endurance Specialty Holdings offer for Aspen Insurance Holdings in April did not get much attention from the broader business world.

title: A Move to Get Youths to Take Tuition Aid After Foster Care
description: By the time Corey Vollette decided to go to college  after years spent adrift after dropping out of high school  it was too late to take advantage of an exemption from tuition and fees at a public college or university in Texas.

title: In Emerging Markets, What Scares Most Investors Entices Oppenheimer
description: The day has been long for Justin M. Leverenz, who runs Americas largest emerging markets mutual fund at Oppenheimer Funds.

title: Westchester Adopts a New Plan to Save Rye Playland
description: How to save Rye Playland, the old-timey amusement park in Rye, N.Y., owned by Westchester County, has been a conundrum, and a source of local tension, for years.

title: Winding Journeys to the N.B.A.s Summit
description: MIAMI  Fortune is not often discriminatory when it chooses those it will ultimately smile upon. Eleven years ago, before he became the ink-swathed and enigmatic Birdman, Chris Andersen was merely a very tall tag-along, uncomfortably folded into the way back of my Volvo station wagon.

title: From Invalid to Nanny, in a Twinkling of an Eye
description: The Mexican director Claudia Sainte-Luce orchestrates the beginning of The Amazing Catfish to show her sluggish main character  a young supermarket clerk, also named Claudia  finally waking up, in a manner of speaking. First she literally awakens, in an ineffably eerie, dimly lighted scene. But its during a sudden hospital visit, in a room with an older woman named Martha (Lisa Owen), that she feels the unfamiliar tug of family.

title: Clothes Make the Player
description: The Great Neck Weekend Softball league  with its modest slogan: The Greatest Pickup Game on Earth  does not take itself too seriously.

title: Methodists to Sell Shares as a Protest Over Israel
description: The pension board of the nations largest mainline Protestant denomination, the United Methodist Church, has decided to divest its shares in a British company that supplies security equipment to Israel for use in prisons and in the occupied West Bank.

title: U.S. Bishops Seek to Match Vatican in Shifting Tone
description: NEW ORLEANS  They are rethinking what kinds of houses they live in, and what kinds of cars they drive. They are wondering whether, in anticipation of the 2016 presidential election, they need to rewrite their advice to parishioners to make sure that poverty, and not just abortion, is discussed as a high-priority issue. And they are trying to get better about returning phone calls, reaching out to the disenchanted and the disenfranchised, and showing up at events.

title: U.S. Denies Talk on 2022 World Cup
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The president of the United States Soccer Federation, Sunil Gulati, denied a report that FIFA had asked it to form an organizing committee that could take over preparations for the 2022 World Cup if it is taken away from Qatar.

title: A Good Ruling on Privacy
description: The capacity of cellphones to track peoples movements and provide a vivid picture of their private lives poses a substantial and growing threat to privacy.

title: The Port Authority Is Fooled Again
description: The purchase of 131 acres along the waterfront of Bayonne, N.J., in 2010 was a fabulous bargain for the seller, the struggling city of Bayonne, and a windfall for New Jerseys governor, Chris Christie. It was not such a good deal for the buyer  the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Iraq in Peril
description: Whats happening in Iraq is a disaster and it is astonishing that the Iraqis and the Americans, who have been sharing intelligence, seem to have been caught flat-footed by the speed of the insurgent victories and the army defections.

title: A Lot of Oops Moments, but the Scores at the U.S. Open Arent Too Shabby
description: PINEHURST, N.C.  Matt Kuchars second shot at the 18th hole rolled through the green, sped down an embankment and did not stop until it was in the clubhouse. A Brandt Snedeker bunker shot ricocheted behind him and settled in the woods. Justin Rose came within an inch of a hole in one, but after his ball flirted with the cup, it ended up so far from the hole Rose chose a wood to play his next shot. In a flash, a near ace became a bogey.

title: A Woman Is Courted, but the Suitor Is Her Father
description: To the mini-trend in films about aging parents in decline (Amour, Away From Her, the recent Grand Dpart), add I Am I, a wispy vanity project for the writer-director-actress Jocelyn Towne. Rachael (Ms. Towne) is at her mothers funeral when she encounters Gene (Kevin Tighe), her father, who left shortly after Rachael was born. Gene, his memory dimming, has been in a retirement home. When he meets Rachael, he falls under the delusion that she is her mother, for whom he still carries a torch. Rachael, to know him better, eventually decides to play along.

title: Obamas Odds With Congress: Bad to Worse
description: WASHINGTON  One day in April, President Obama called Representative Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, to wish him a happy Passover. However the call started, it went downhill from there. By days end, both sides were arguing about what was said and taking shots at the other for not getting along.

title: The Big Burn
description: When the United States invaded Iraq in 2003, it effectively destroyed the Iraqi government. Slowly learning from that mistake, the U.S. spent the next eight years in a costly round of state-building. As Dexter Filkins, who covered the war for The Times, wrote in a blog post this week for The New Yorker, By 2011, by any reasonable measure, the Americans had made a lot of headway but were not finished with the job.

title: Stewart Tributes Fill Day 1 of U.S. Open as Mickelson Feels the Crowds Support
description: PINEHURST, N.C.  The United States Open course and the fans who lined it showed their softer side on Thursday. How could a mushy sentimentality not prevail given that wherever you looked on Pinehurst No. 2 on a leaden morning, the ghost of Payne Stewart lurked?

title: Reaction to Brazils First Goal
description: From across the country, Brazilian fans react to their teams first goal of the 2014 World Cup.

title: The Iraqi Army Was Crumbling Long Before Its Collapse, U.S. Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  The stunning collapse of Iraqs army in a string of cities across the north reflects poor leadership, declining troop morale, broken equipment and a sharp decline in training since the last American advisers left the country in 2011, American military and intelligence officials said Thursday.

title: Brazils First Goal
description: Across the country, Brazilian fans react to their teams first goal of the 2014 World Cup, in what would be a 3-1 victory against Croatia.

title: In Weapons Case, Prosecutors Press 2 Brothers to Urge 3rd to Come to U.S. to Plead Guilty
description: It was an unusual example of family pressure, exerted by federal prosecutors against two brothers.

title: After Florida State Rape Case, Police Will Revise Procedures
description: The police department in Tallahassee, Fla., the target of stinging criticism and national attention for its handling of a rape accusation against Florida State Universitys Heisman Trophy winner, Jameis Winston, has begun working with a respected womens advocacy group to rewrite its sexual assault complaint policy.

title: Spain Enters as a Favorite Thats Forgotten
description: SALVADOR, Brazil  For the first time in more than 60 years, the World Cup is back in the spiritual home of soccer, and it is only natural that the pretournament spotlight has been overwhelmingly focused on the hosts and their enormously popular players.

title: Job Losses in Need of Interpreting
description: New York is the city of tongues, a metropolis where language has about 800 separate tributaries, the babbling global capital of human speech.

title: Iraqis Who Fled Mosul Say They Prefer Militants to Government
description: ERBIL, Iraq  After Islamic extremists swarmed his city this week, Saad Hussein fled here with his wife and six children. But after one night, he was on his way back home to Mosul, hearing that things were quiet there.

title: Clip: The Signal
description: A scene from William Eubanks film featuring Brenton Thwaites and Laurence Fishburne.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 12, 2014
The Tip of the Iceberg: Rethinking Life After High School
description: Ivory Tower, a documentary about soaring costs and other problems confronting higher education, cant seem to decide what points it wants to make and ends up making none. Parts of it seem like free advertising for the institutions it visits, which include Harvard, Arizona State University and experimental institutions like Deep Springs College. Other parts sound the already familiar lament that students come out of college with crushing debts and no prospects for the kinds of jobs that would enable them to pay off those debts. There are suggestions that colleges do a poor job of actually educating students, and that the cost issue is a result of bloated administrative salaries and a rush to build showpiece campuses.

title: The Worlds Ball
description: An evolution, from 1930 to today.

title: Hackers Take a Road Trip, With a Sci-Fi Detour
description: William Eubanks The Signal demonstrates the fine line between paranoid science-fiction fantasy and demo reel. Both involve impressive visions of reality reimagined, and both defy logic extravagantly and yet somehow casually, too. Mr. Eubanks diverting but disconnected film might fairly be described as a little bit of each.

title: Vermont G.O.P. Finds Candidates in Short Supply
description: MONTPELIER, Vt.  The Vermont Republican Party website makes a plain-spoken appeal: CANDIDATES WANTED.

title: Family Guy
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  We have a big day coming up this weekend, and if you are a dad or have ever been important in the life of a child, Wordplay wishes you a happy Fathers Day.

title: Take a Dive, Have a Drink
description: A game you can play while the footballers are playing theirs.

title: With Data and Resolve, Tacoma Fights Pollution
description: TACOMA, Wash.  Last year, environmental engineers working for this city had an unnerving worry. After a decade and tens of millions of dollars devoted to a fastidious cleanup of its corner of Puget Sound, Tacomas shore front was in danger of being contaminated with a highly toxic chemical.

title: Former BP Engineer Wins New Trial in Case on Gulf Spill
description: A federal judge in New Orleans has ordered a new trial for a former BP engineer convicted of deleting text messages relevant to an investigation of the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill, concluding that outside information influenced the jurys verdict.

title: A Dominatrix Who Hates Heels
description: Emmanuelle Seigner hates high heels and avoids wearing them at all costs. When the designer Tom Ford asked her to walk in a fashion show, she successfully pleaded with him to put her in flats. But there was no avoiding them in her latest film, Venus in Fur, directed by her husband, Roman Polanski, in which she plays a dominatrix of sorts whose sartorial centerpiece is a pair of thigh-high kinky boots.

title: Tanks, of Unknown Origin, Roll Into Ukraine
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Ukraines interior minister claimed on Thursday that an armored column from Russia had crossed the border into eastern Ukraine overnight and had fought with Ukrainian troops during the day.

title: As Sunni Militants Threaten Its Allies in Baghdad, Iran Weighs Options
description: TEHRAN  In years past, Iranian officials would smirk when recalling how the United States had done the dirty work for them by removing the Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein, a Sunni who led an eight-year war against Shiite Iran.

title: Officials to Investigate Reports of Mistreatment of Minors Caught Crossing Border
description: Border officials opened an investigation on Thursday into claims by legal aid groups that border agents were mistreating unaccompanied minors caught crossing the Southwest border illegally.

title: The Goal Heard Round Brazil
description: When Neymar drove the ball into the back of the net for Brazils first goal, pandemonium ensued around the host country.

title: Dino? Ol Blue Eyes? All the Above, by Jerry
description: The movie widely regarded as Jerry Lewiss masterpiece, The Nutty Professor (1963), arrives with a swagger on the occasion of its 51st anniversary in a deluxe 50th Anniversary Collectors Edition, from Warner Bros. Home Entertainment.

title: Building Nuclear Weapon Would Take Years, Not Months, Iran Says in Report
description: WASHINGTON  The Iranian government this week published its first detailed study of how long it estimates it would take its scientists and engineers to assemble a nuclear weapon, saying that with its current infrastructure, the required time span is in years.

title: Giant Seeks Return to Pre-Injury Success
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants safety Stevie Brown intercepted a pass against the Jets in a preseason game on Aug. 24 and was racing down the left side when he spotted an opening toward the middle of the field. He pushed off on his left leg  and it buckled.

title: Chicago Winces After a Jewel Is Stamped Trump
description: CHICAGO  There was a collective sigh of relief when Donald Trump opened his 92-story hotel and condominium tower here six years ago.

title: In Bitterly Contested House Primary, a State Legislator Defends His Record
description: In 2007, Hispanic lawmakers saw a crisis brewing on eastern Long Island: Under the direction of the Suffolk County executive, Steve Levy, the police were raiding rooming houses full of immigrants and arresting drivers, many of them Hispanic, who lacked licenses or identification. The county jail was running checks to catch inmates in the country illegally.

title: Campus Colleagues, Basketball Teammates, and Now, Political Rivals
description: ASHLAND, Va.  Before the two professors became overnight political rivals in one of the most improbable, high-profile races in memory, they knew each other best as basketball teammates.

title: Concerns on Mad Cow Lead to Recall
description: Dozens of Whole Foods stores in the Northeast and a restaurant in New York received beef over an eight-month period that may not have been properly slaughtered to reduce the threat of mad cow disease, federal officials said on Thursday.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for June 13-19
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Greece Wars With Courts Over Ways to Slash Budget
description: ATHENS  The Greek government has made a range of painful cuts to salaries, pensions and jobs for public workers over the last four years, saying they were needed to satisfy the demands of the international creditors that bailed the country out. But the Greeks hurt by those steps, and the nations courts, have a different idea.

description: Classical

Dance Listings for June 13-19
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for June 13-19
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Cantor Loss May Temper House Leaders
description: WASHINGTON  For all the talk of a lurch to the right after the primary election defeat this week of the House majority leader, Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the race to remake the Republican leadership may actually leave its top ranks more moderate.

title: Neymar Gives Brazil All the Scoring It Needs
description: Brazil held its collective breath after it fell behind, 1-0, in the 11th minute when Marcelo tipped the ball into his own goal.

description: A memo from the doctor for President Obama provides details on his current state of health, with some interesting trivia (he occasionally chews nicotine gum).

title: Obamas Checkup: Healthy, but Ouch, That Right Foot
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is often on his feet, and it is starting to hurt.

title: Hot Off the Press
description: Objects made from paper, or inspired by it, are being elevated to artistic heights. Whether crinkled or cut out, prints age-old medium is a material of modern design.

title: Despite Upheavals, NBC Extends Lauers Contract
description: NBCs Today show issued a new endorsement of its longtime anchor Matt Lauer on Thursday, signing the veteran newsman to a contract extension that will keep him in place on the morning show for what NBC described as multiple more years.

title: Word of the Day | amnesty
description: amnesty \am-n-ste\ noun and verb

title: Heats Crash Course Cant Prevent Another Wreck Against the Spurs
description: MIAMI  It was no fun. Before meeting the San Antonio Spurs on Thursday night in Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals, the Heat spent a substantial portion of Wednesday huddled in a darkened room watching film of their well-publicized debacle in Game 3.

title: A Dance-Off With Fallon. Next Up, Clinton?
description: Gov. Chris Christies appearance on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon on Thursday resembled a spurned suitors return to the site of his humiliation.

title: Tanakas Early Performance Eliciting Praise From Nearly Everyone but Him
description: SEATTLE  Masahiro Tanaka is neither impressed nor surprised that a little more than two months into his first major league season, he is one of only two pitchers with 10 victories.

title: Whats on Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Showtime) DAVID BECKHAM INTO THE UNKNOWN Just in time for the World Cup, the director Anthony Mandler follows Mr. Beckham, above, the retired soccer superstar, and his friends Derek White and Dave Gardner into the heart of the Amazon in Brazil, where they travel by motorcycle and boat from Manaus to Angelin, across the Negro and Cuieras Rivers, and deep into the rain forest to mingle with the remote Yanomami tribe.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 13, 2014
description: We have to have a home, have to have a car thats not going to fall apart in the middle of the desert, but within reason we have to live simply.

title: In Trying to Halt the Mets Slide, Wright Is Enduring His Own Struggles
description: Often this season, when the Mets have started to slide, David Wright has stressed the importance of stopping it before it gets worse. He has sounded urgent and a tad desperate, perhaps because in each of the previous five seasons, he felt a sense of inevitability set in, like a man standing atop a leaky dam staring down a flood.

title: At Rangers Practice, Mood Is Light but Focused
description: LOS ANGELES  The Rangers have reached the point of the Stanley Cup finals where mileage in the air and wear on their bodies provide yet another test of mettle for them and their opponents, the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Cameroon Players Say Protest and Late Arrival Have Not Affected Morale
description: NATAL, Brazil  Four days after Cameroon players refused to board a flight to Brazil in a dispute over World Cup pay, Coach Volker Finke attributed the disagreement to cultural norms in Africa and played down its significance to the teams preparations.

title: Corrections: June 13, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Businessman Guilty of Killing and Eating Tigers
description: A businessman in the southwestern region of Guangxi has pleaded guilty to charges of killing and eating at least three tigers last year, the state-run news agency Xinhua reported.

title: Found Poem Favorite | Reaching Up With Adaptations
description: This poem, by Miguel M., is one of the 11 winners of our fifth annual Found Poem Student Contest.

title: Chase Whitley, Under Control Again, Guides Yankees to Sweep of Mariners
description: SEATTLE  If a team is going to beat the Yankees rookie right-hander Chase Whitley, it will have to be earned. He has not given away much in his six starts.

description: A Times reporter was too scared to take the first ride on the new Thunderbolt roller coaster at Coney Island. But his daughter wasnt.

title: 6 Qs About the News | The Sneaker Comes of Age
description: In The Sneaker Comes of Age, Alex Williams writes about the triumph of the fashion sneaker.

title: Unicredit Receives Approval for Online Banking Unit I.P.O.
description: LONDON  The Italian lender Unicredit has received approval from regulators for an initial public offering of its online banking arm that could value the unit at up to $3.62 billion.

title: Iraqi Shiite Cleric Issues Call to Arms
description: BAGHDAD  The specter of sectarian war and partition of Iraq grew on Friday as the countrys top Shiite cleric implored his followers to take up arms against an insurgent army of marauding Sunni extremist militants who have captured broad stretches of northern territory this week in a sweep toward Baghdad.

title: A German Rebel in South Africa
description: When Jrgen Schadeberg was forced to join the Hitler Youth, he knew wearing brown shirts, marching in step and singing the glories of the Fhrer and the Fatherland were not for him. Even before his teens, he abhorred what they stood for.

title: More Protein in Diet May Lower Stroke Risk
description: Getting more protein in your diet, though not red meat, may reduce your risk for stroke, a review of studies found.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 1 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: Our Summer Reading Contest begins!

title: Debate Rages After Death Sentences Overturned in Child Prostitution Case
description: Should a person be executed for raping or prostituting a child? That question  which lay behind an explosion of comments as Chinese responded on Friday to a Supreme Peoples Court decision overturning the death sentences of two men for crimes committed against an 11-year-old girl  seemed hardly the point.

title: Wrongness, OK and Not
description: USA! USA! NYC! Back from Oxford, but still  as you can see from the posting time  jet-lagged. I have a steakhouse dinner tonight in honor of Eric Cantor with some business economists; well see if I end up face down in my tenderloin.

title: New York Today:  Test Drive on a Roller Coaster
description: Happy gloppy Friday the 13th.

description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

description: Updated, 8:51 p.m. |

title: Univision Owners Said to Weigh a Sale
description: The owners of Univision Communications, the biggest Spanish-language broadcaster in the United States, have held preliminary discussions about a potential sale with media companies in recent weeks, people briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

title: Daily Report: Scrutinizing Silicon Valleys Response to Obamas Climate Goals
description: If the United States is going to achieve President Obamas new climate change goals, an X factor is how Silicon Valley will respond, Claire Cain Miller reports. Success will depend, many analysts think, on whether the policy will spur entrepreneurs to come up with new technologies and create a clean energy economy.

title: Company Backed by Robert Diamond Likely to Miss Fund-Raising Goal
description: LONDON  The investment company Atlas Mara Co-Nvest, backed by a former Barclays chief executive, Robert E. Diamond Jr., is likely to fall short of the $400 million it was seeking in a second round of fund-raising to back investments in the African financial sector, according to a person briefed on the matter.

title: A Better Way to Rank Soccer Teams in a Fairer World Cup
description: The World Cup draw needs to be fairer, as I proposed last week in a system that includes the seeding of teams from 1 to 32.

title: China and Japan Face Off Over Documentation of Wartime Atrocities
description: China and Japan, whose festering relationship has seen their rival military aircraft buzz each other over the East China Sea, have found yet another forum in which to duel: Unescos Memory of the World Register.

title: No Ceremony for Bowe Bergdahl Upon Return to U.S. Soil
description: SAN ANTONIO  Exactly 1,809 days after he was captured by Taliban fighters who kept him in a metal cage for weeks and possibly months during nearly five years in captivity, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl returned to the United States early Friday to a homecoming void of any of his relatives and dampened by a swirling controversy over his capture and release.

title: Tableau Software Helping Data Become More Visual
description: Data point, meet data stream.

title: States Choose to Defer Employee Choice for Health Plans
description: When it set the final rules implementing small-business health insurance exchanges for next year, the federal government gave states the option of taking a one-year pass on one of the exchanges most attractive features: the opportunity for small-business employees to choose among a variety of health plans. This week, the Department of Health and Human Services announced that 18 states would in fact defer employee choice until 2016.

title: Eric Cantor Is Not a Reform Conservative
description: One thing were hearing about Eric Cantors primary defeat is that its bad for reform conservatism. Thats a term that means different things to different people, but for these purposes Im talking about a different domestic agenda from the one the Republican Party has been pursuing in recent years and one that centers on middle-class economic concerns.

title: Morning Views
description: Whats happening in Iraq is a disaster and it is astonishing that the Iraqis and the Americans, who have been sharing intelligence, seem to have been caught flat-footed by the speed of the insurgent victories and the army defections.The New York Times editorial board comments on the sudden capture of Mosul by Sunni militants, and the greater threat to Iraq and the Middle East region, noting there are few good options in resolving the crisis with ease or speed.

title: Fears About Iraq Continue to Push Up Oil Prices
description: LONDON  The oil markets are likely to remain on edge, as escalating tensions in Iraq prompt concerns over supplies in the major oil-producing country.

title: Islamic Insurgents Advance on Baghdad
description: Extremists have crossed over the border from Syria into Iraq.

title: Morning Agenda: Univisions Sale Talks
description: UNIVISION OWNERS SAID TO WEIGH A SALE | The owners of Univision Communications, the biggest Spanish-language broadcaster in the United States, are said to have held preliminary talks about a potential sale with media companies in recent weeks, including CBS, Time Warner and Viacom, DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced writes. The talks were at a very early stage and no sales process is underway at the moment. Should Univisions owners  a consortium led by the billionaire Haim Saban  pursue a sale, they will probably expect bids to top at least $20 billion.

title: Swedish Auteur Takes On a Brave Loner
description: From High Noon to Silkwood and The Insider, the courageous loner who stands up to evil at great personal risk is a familiar film figure. Now the Swedish master Jan Troell has added to that gallery with The Last Sentence, his portrait of Torgny Segerstedt, a Swedish newspaper editor who was an early, ferocious and persistent critic of Hitler, defying both Nazi threats and his own governments pleas not to undermine its neutral stance.

title: In Our Pages: June 14
description: 1889: Paris Without Cabs

title: What to Consider When Looking for the Right Place to Retire
description: Models of pre-retirement planning, Don and Reina Weiner bought an acre of land almost a decade ago in the Woodlands of Chapel Hill, a mixed-age community in North Carolina.

title: The Lack of Major Wars May Be Hurting Economic Growth
description: The continuing slowness of economic growth in high-income economies has prompted soul-searching among economists. They have looked to weak demand, rising inequality, Chinese competition, over-regulation, inadequate infrastructure and an exhaustion of new technological ideas as possible culprits.

title: Ackmans Hedge Fund Sues Botox Maker Allergan Over Poison Pill Trigger
description: Pershing Square Capital Management, the hedge fund run by the activist investor William A. Ackman, has sued Allergan, the target of a hostile bid from Pershing Square and Valeant Pharmaceuticals.

title: Priceline Adds Restaurants to Offerings With Purchase of OpenTable
description: Updated, 4:12 p.m. | Not content with a commanding presence in online travel booking, Priceline is now taking aim at the world of dinner reservations.

description: Good morning, and happyFridaythe 13thfrom Washington.

title: Reservation for 100 at His Apartment
description: Dear Diary:

title: Indications of Growth in U.S. Job Market
description: FOR more than 60 years, unemployment in the United States was largely a short-term problem. The level of unemployment went up and down, but most of the unemployed found work relatively quickly. Few remained out of work for as long as 15 weeks. Long-term unemployment was always a lesser problem.

title: British Regulator Osborne Takes a Step Forward for Foreign Exchange Oversight
description: Michael OBrien and Bill Nosal are senior executives with Nasdaq OMXs SMARTS market surveillance.

title: And a Choir Shall Heal Them
description: The Scottish playwright David Greig was hard to pin down while traveling in the highlands of his homeland recently, so it turned out to be eerily coincidental that we finally spoke the day after Elliot O. Rodger went on a murderous rampage in Isla Vista, Calif. Efforts to understand what motivated the young man were popping up all over the Internet as Mr. Greig discussed The Events, his 2013 play about the anguished aftermath of a deadly shooting.

title: Keep Fighting For Sane Gun Restrictions. Only Harder.
description: Like many Americans  most, actually, I venture  I feel the same sense of frustration and anger over Congresss failure to approve stricter gun laws that President Obama expressed following this weeks fatal school shooting in Oregon.

title: Upset Fueling Tea Party Hope in Senate Race
description: ELLISVILLE, Miss.  Moments after a little-known economics professor in Virginia became a conservative sensation by toppling Eric Cantor, the House Republican leader, Chris McDaniel, the Tea Partys best hope for a Senate seat this year, got a text message from his best friend in Mississippis capital.

title: Selling TOMS: The Questions, and a Few Answers
description: The fashion/philanthropy world was surprised by the news in The Financial Times this week that TOMS  the shoe brand started by Blake Mycoskie in 2006 and based on the One-to-One model (for every pair sold, a pair is given away)  was up for sale.

title: U.N. Warns of Rights Abuses and Hundreds Dead in Iraq Fighting
description: GENEVA  As Sunni insurgents pursued an offensive toward Baghdad on Friday, Navi Pillay, the top United Nations human rights official, expressed extreme alarm over what she termed summary executions, rape, reprisal killings and shelling of civilians, putting the first estimate of casualties in the hundreds.

title: Comcast Seeking to Replace G.E.s Initials Atop 30 Rock
description: Comcast is known for its low-key corporate culture. At its 58-story headquarters, the tallest building in Philadelphia, a boxy glass crown gleams conspicuously but anonymously.

title: Video Reviews of 22 Jump Street, How to Train Your Dragon 2 and The Rover
description: In this weeks video, Times critics look at 22 Jump Street, The Rover and How to Train Your Dragon 2. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: In Fashion | The Return of Alice Roi
description: For girls-about-downtown in the late 90s and early aughts, Alice Roi was a patron saint. The lower-Manhattan-born-and-bred designer with the cool-kid persona created clothes that tempered a girlish sensibility with a subtle sense of humor. There were the La Caricature dresses, covered in an Honor Daumier print of two snobs turning their noses at each other. There were the Yeti-like mohair jackets and the bare-shouldered tops with cutouts meant to resemble crewneck openings. The line was a cult hit until 2008, when Roi became a mom and not only shuttered her business but withdrew completely from the fashion world.

title: A Lost Father, and a Daughter Whos Not Ready to Let Him Go
description: While preparing my daughter for her preschool graduation ceremony last year, a text message buzzed my phone from my brother: Dad has been missing for two hours.

title: 2 Private Equity Settlements Followed Failure of Broader Talks on Collusion Lawsuit
description: For six years, the biggest private equity firms fought a lawsuit that accused them of illegal collusion during the buyout boom. Their strategy, through rounds of difficult settlement talks, was to stick together.

title: Former Goldman Director Guptas Last Days of Freedom
description: On Tuesday, Rajat K. Gupta, the former managing director of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company who was convicted of insider trading, is scheduled to report to a minimum-security prison camp in Massachusetts, spending the next two years not far from his onetime friend and partner in crime, Raj Rajaratnam.

title: For Cantor, Loss of Leadership Role Means Far Fewer Perks
description: WASHINGTON  As House majority leader, Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia has enjoyed a bump in salary, a large political staff, an elegant office suite on the second floor of the Capitol and a security detail that drove him to and from his suburban Richmond home.

title: Critique of Narendra Modi in College Magazine Leads to Arrest of Seven
description: A college magazine that published an implied, strident critique of Narendra Modi, the newly elected prime minister, incited enough ill will that six students on the magazines editorial staff were arrested Wednesday and accused of printing defamatory material and of provocation with the intent of causing riots, among other crimes.

title: If a Teenager Lands a Summer Job, the Value Is Lasting
description: HUNTER-JOHN HURST, 16, of Raleigh, N.C., is a living example of a modern-day conundrum. Like many others his age, he needs to earn money this summer. But finding a job is tougher than ever, with the number of teenagers employed nationwide at a near-historical low.

title: Russia Sent Tanks to Separatists in Ukraine, U.S. Says
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  The State Department said Friday that Russia had sent tanks and other heavy weapons to separatists in Ukraine, supporting accusations Thursday by the Ukrainian government.

title: Who Made That Inflatable Noisemaker?
description: As soccer fans arrived at Portlands Civic Stadium on Sept. 7, 1997, they were handed an unfamiliar implement: a pair of long balloons, sponsored by Nike, designed to make their cheering louder. That was the first time I saw those inflatable things that people bang together, says Tab Ramos, a starting player on that U.S. mens soccer team and now an assistant coach. The sellout crowd for the World Cup qualifier, among the noisiest that Ramos had ever heard, reached maximum cacophony when he scored the winning goal. The stadium sounded like it was going to fall down, he says.

title: Reply All: The 6.1.14 Issue
description: LIFE IN THE VALLEY OF DEATH

title: Highly, Highly Recommended
description: As part of a typical hiring process, I asked a job applicant for a reference. It turned out that I already knew the reference, who was very supportive of the candidate. The man got the job. After I extended the offer, I heard through the grapevine that the applicant and the reference were romantically linked.
