The hire has performed very well, but I felt that they both should have been more forthright about their relationship. Should they have been? JEFF H., SAN DIEGO

title: Before Learning to Crawl, You Must Learn to Swim
description: Rachael Ubiera, a 25-year-old in Kissimmee, Fla., considers herself one of the relaxed moms. But the first time she saw her 5-month-old daughter, Zoe, carefully dropped underwater in a pool for infant survival swim training, it was nerve-racking. She looked surprised, Ubiera says. Like, What are you doing to me?  Zoe was being introduced to self-rescue, in which babies are taught to hold their breath underwater, kick their feet, turn over to float on their backs and rest until help arrives. The technique, photographed here by Seth Casteel, who is working on a related book that will come out next spring, was pioneered in the late 60s by Harvey Barnett, who at 18 became determined to teach infants to swim after the drowning of a neighbors child. His methods have spread around the world  taught in clinics and imitated widely. It gives the baby the best possible chance, he says. Julie Bosman

title: The Breakup List
description: It was summertime in Brooklyn, so hot that the trees were shedding leaves and the Realtors were sweating through their starched shirts and stopping on street corners to wipe down their Bluetooth earpieces. My girlfriend  wed been together, more or less, since our first date in February  was staying with me for a couple of weeks while she sublet her apartment. She was between trips abroad. She was always traveling for work. Id set her up at my kitchen table with the wireless password. I got her a partner membership at my gym. We cranked up the air-conditioner in the bedroom at night and lay across the comforter to let our sweat dry. In the mornings, the tired air-conditioner wheezed out a spray of mist.

title: Love, Kuwaiti Style
description: Way out of Eden: Adam and Eve, with fangs; pneumonia in Arizona.

title: Can General Linders Special Operations Forces Stop the Next Terrorist Threat?
description: On a searing morning this spring, Brig. Gen. James B. Linder leaned against the red-webbing seats of a C-130 as it flew over the Sahara. On his camouflaged knee, he balanced two dog-eared Moleskine notebooks and a map of Africa. Linder, who is in his early 50s, commands the United States Special Operations forces in Africa. He was on his way to visit a detachment of 12 Army Green Berets training with African troops to fight Al Qaeda and its affiliates in Niger. Through the planes scratched plexiglass portholes, dunes crested like waves in an ocean of sand, and hot blasts of wind buffeted the fuselage. An hours flight to the south, his team of Special Forces was deployed along the Nigerian border, where the militant group Boko Haram was targeting children in its bid to establish an Islamic state.

title: World Cup Is Huge on Twitter  in Japan
description: The World Cup buzz is building on social media  in Brazil, in England and, most of all, in Japan.

title: Washingtons Gyms Want a Tax Break. Thats a Problem.
description: When I went to the gym in Washington on Thursday, I was urged to get on Twitter and tell local leaders members #donttaxfitness. Thats because next Tuesday, the Council of the District of Columbia will vote on expanding the sales tax to include gym memberships and related services, like yoga and personal training; currently, those kinds of services arent taxed.

title: Charity Golf Events Have Courses Filling Up
description: HOURS before the start of the Jonas Center Golf Classic, rain was pouring down. The skies were thick with clouds, and puddles were forming in the fairways of the Stanwich Club, a private country club in Greenwich, Conn.

title: The Killer Assessment
description: Nothing inflicts fear and loathing on the heart of a co-op resident like the specter of a major assessment. The A-word has to be the most unpopular notification a co-op board ever drops on shareholders, the verbal equivalent of a stink bomb. Trouble, anxiety and intramural back-stabbing inevitably ensue.

title: Arachnid Phobia
description: What looks like a spider bite and acts like a spider bite but isnt a spider bite?

title: Should We Learn to Live With Debt?
description: The countrys $1.1 trillion of student loan debt continues to inspire plans for relief. But as these are debated, some borrowers are dealing with a more personal issue: what to do, and how to live, while they pay.

title: DiMaggio and Sinatra: The Feud Between Two Italian-American Pathbreakers
description: In March 1949, Joe DiMaggio posed in Yankee Stadium, smiling, with another famous Italian-American of his era  each in his professional uniform  but their friendship would not endure.

title: Using Artists to Sell Condos in Miami and New York
description: With cities like New York and Miami in the midst of another luxury condominium boom, developers seem to be tripping over one another in the scramble to announce their latest projects, and to stand out from the pack, they are locked in an escalating game of one-upmanship.

title: In Store | A New Multibrand Concept Boutique in Detroit
description: Perhaps the most visible new success story in the ongoing effort to revitalize Detroits economy is Shinolathe three-year-old leather goods and lifestyle brand which employs more than 130 people at its bicycle and watch manufacturing facilities there (and some 130 more in its offices and retail operations). Now, a couple of doors down from its store in the citys emerging Midtown district, the company is spawning what might be Detroits first multibrand concept boutique. Willys, which opens to the public on Saturday, takes its name from the Willys Overland Motor Company, which invented the first jeep in 1941 and was for a time during the 1910s the second-largest car manufacturer in the U.S.; the 2,900-square-foot space is housed in the former service bay of the companys old headquarters.

title: Discovering What Defeat Looks Like
description: MIAMI  Toward the end of the third quarter of Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals Thursday, an intensely generic D.J. began exhorting the crowd in the Miami Heats arena to get loud. In the stands, a few women with bare midriffs stood up and randomly started shaking.

title: A Literary Expert on Driving in the Dark
description: Stirring his pot of nightmares, legends, fairy tales and human folly into stories, the British-born fantasy writer Neil Gaiman has produced more than 20 books for children and adults, most of them scary and strange. The multitasking Mr. Gaiman is the author of the best-selling adult fairy tale The Ocean at the End of the Lane and the childrens books Coraline and Stardust, which have been made into films. He has written episodes for the sci-fi TV show Dr. Who, and is the author of the popular Sandman  series of graphic novels. And then there are his 1.9 million Twitter followers.

title: Nathan Fielder, In Short
description: For this weeks magazine I profiled Nathan Fielder, whose excellent Comedy Central series, Nathan for You, begins its second season on July 1. The starting premise of his series is that Fielder  who is Canadian and studied marketing and entrepreneurship at college before turning in earnest to his comedy career  presents himself to actual business owners as a reality-TV business consultant, pitching them preposterously elaborate, compellingly off-kilter marketing schemes and then documenting the unpredictable results. (The entire first season of Nathan for You is currently available to watch free.)

title: Today in Small Business: House Approves Small-Business Tax Break
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Behold the Fall Harvest
description: When BookExpo America, the annual trade convention, took place in Manhattan two weeks ago, the publishing industry turned its gaze to the traditionally heavy-hitting fall season.

title: Motherhood
description: DRUNK MOM  A Memoir  By Jowita Bydlowska  Penguin, paper, $16.

title: Flying Start
description: Perhaps the last of the great rugged individualists were the early pilots. Their dangerous solo missions made heroes of them all as they paved the way for modern aviation. None was more beloved than Lucky Lindy himself, Charles A. Lindbergh, who completed the first lone nonstop flight across the Atlantic Ocean on May 21, 1927. In a way reminiscent of Robert Lawsons 1939 childrens book Ben and Me, which suggested that Benjamin Franklins brilliant ideas came from a Philadelphia mouse named Amos, the young German artist Torben Kuhlmann has reimagined the Lindbergh legend through the character of an inventive rodent.

title: Cameroon vs. Mexico: Live Blog
description: Live coverage and analysis of the Mexico-Cameroon match. Mexico needs to win to put pressure on Croatia, its rival for the second qualifying spot. (Brazil will very likely get the first.) For Cameroon, this game is probably the best chance for a point in group play.

title: Dragon Seed
description: Certain fairy tales are so ingrained in our consciousness that we have no memory of when we first heard them; theres a sense we always knew them. I had that feeling when reading Rebecca Hahns debut novel, A Creature of Moonlight. Though Hahns story is new and wholly original, I immediately felt I had fallen into a dark and beautiful fairy tale, one that resonated like something important but long forgotten.

title: Drawn to the Shore
description: In the first frames of This One Summer, a graphic novel written by Mariko Tamaki and illustrated by her cousin Jillian Tamaki, a father carries his sleeping daughter down a driveway to a cottage in the dark. This is Awago Beach, where Rose Wallaces family has been coming since . . . like . . . forever. Or, more precisely, since Rose, who is now either an old tween or a young teenager (we dont learn her exact age), was 5.

title: Global Repositioning
description: The publishers of S. E. Groves novel, an ambitious and quixotic high fantasy called The Glass Sentence, smartly slapped upon the dust jacket an assessment by Megan Whalen Turner: Not since Philip Pullmans The Golden Compass have I seen such an original and compelling world built inside a book. A sensible precaution; its easy to suppose that The Glass Sentence was written in reaction to Pullmans magisterial His Dark Materials. I am hardly one to lodge a complaint about that. Great works create their own gravitational field; Pullman wrote under the influence of Milton. The question remains: Does this admirer pull off something worthwhile of her own?

title: Inside the List
description: Notorious: After spending two and a half months on the hardcover fiction list last year, Neil Gaimans fantasy novel The Ocean at the End of the Lane slips onto the trade paperback list this week at No. 8. The paperback follows on the heels of another book that should appeal to Gaimans fans  Hayley Campbells winningly scrapbookish tribute, The Art of Neil Gaiman, which Audrey Niffenegger describes in the foreword as a sort of midcareer retrospective. The book recounts Gaimans early days as a hungry arts journalist and his rise to cult success as a writer of comic books, notably the Sandman series, before he turned his hand to novels. It also reminds readers that Neil himself (as hes known on Twitter) once wrote a scrapbookish tribute of his own: His first published book  written solely for the money, he says  was Duran Duran: The First Four Years of the Fab Five (1984). I got a phone call from a lady, Gaiman explains in an interview cited in the book, and she said would you like to write a rock n roll book for us? A rock n roll biography? And I thought, Oh God, yes! Im in!  Gaiman suggested a handful of subjects, including the Velvet Underground, David Bowie and Elvis Costello, before the editor interrupted: Do you want to write the Duran Duran book, the Barry Manilow book or the Def Leppard book? Pragmatism led him to choose the relative newcomers Duran Duran. With Barry Manilow, he said, I figured I was going to have to listen to, you know, 40 Barry Manilow albums.

title: Office Max
description: How you work depends in large part on the spaces in which you work. This big theme is taken up by Nikil Saval in Cubed: A Secret History of the Workplace. There is in fact nothing secret about this history; from the Civil War on, as the white-collar world grew, managers and designers thought out loud about where workers should sit, the furniture they should use, the walls and windows that should surround them. Instead of a secret history, Saval, an editor of n+1, has written something more interesting. He has infused a straightforward factual account with all sorts of literary, cultural and political insights; these make the story he tells more dark than dry.

title: Isolation Unit
description: Evie Wylds second novel opens with its narrator, a woman named Jake Whyte, discovering one of her sheep killed and gutted. Carrion birds are feasting: Crows, their beaks shining, strutting and rasping, and when I waved my stick they flew to the trees and watched, flaring out their wings, singing, if you could call it that. Jake shouts, What are you laughing at? and throws a rock at them.

title: It Was a Dark and Stormy Night
description: Val McDermids Northanger Abbey is the second book to emerge from the Austen Project, in which Jane Austens published oeuvre is reimagined by 21st-century authors. But early on her heroine, Cat Morland, encounters, via audiobook, the Gothic work of another 19th-century novelist  Bram Stokers Dracula. For Cat, we are told, schooled only in contemporary vampire romance, it was a curious and unsettling experience. It reminded her of the first time shed tasted an olive. It was unlike everything that had crossed her palate before; strange and not quite pleasant, yet gilded with the promise of sophistication.

title: Puritans Progress
description: Concord, Mass., is a sacred spot in the mythology of New England Protestants, once the Brahmins of American society, now fast becoming just another ethnic group. With this change comes new material for our venerable tradition of ethnic comedy. The territory is not altogether virgin, of course, but Sarah Payne Stuart comes to it with freshness and flair in this memoir.

title: Abdullah Abdullah Moves Toward Center of Afghan Power
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  AFTER decades roaming the margins of power  as a close aide to the revered resistance leader Ahmed Shah Massoud, as a foreign minister and later as Afghanistans perennial opposition leader  Abdullah Abdullah may finally be arriving at the center of it all.

title: Southern Living
description: Throughout Frances Mayess idylls about the sweet life in Italy  the subtitle of one of her best-selling memoirs  there are glimpses of a childhood, far less blissful, in the American South. In Bella Tuscany, she mentions her tyrant grandfather, Daddy Jack. In Under the Tuscan Sun, she touches on her resigned disappointed ancestors back home. Even as she enjoys a pure surge of pleasure while restoring Bramasole, a villa near Cortona, Italy, and discovering what it means to surprise your own life, she must keep the shadows cast by the town of Fitzgerald, Ga., at bay. To put it mildly, she remarks in passing of her father, Garbert, he was a difficult man and to complicate that, he died at 47.

title: Nothing to Hide
description: Paula Bomer writes the kind of womens fiction that critics like to call raw. Her stark portrayals of biological womanhood have been described as raw and angry, raw and darkly funny, brutally raw and urgent. The word is meant literally, to a degree: Her earlier books, Nine Months and Baby, feature birth scenes that spare no anatomical detail. But raw has also come to mean something specific in blurb-speak about quasi-confessional writing by women, and its not always fitting or fair. Half praise, half dis, it commends the struggle to embrace female ugliness while finding the work unsatisfactory. Raw work is visceral but also hard to digest  a kind term, in other words, for something half-baked.

title: Late Bloomer
description: In 2012, at the age of 82, the indomitable stage and screen actor Christopher Plummer won his first Academy Award for his energetic portrayal of Hal Fields, a 75-year-old who comes out of the closet shortly after his wifes death, in Mike Millss structurally complex romantic comedy Beginners. In the film, Hals full-throttled, last-call embrace of life inspires his son, Oliver, to fully embrace his own, while asking what exactly it takes to start life anew, and when, if ever, its too late.

title: European Pastoral
description: Michel Dons 1975 novel The Foundling Boy (in French Le Jeune Homme Vert, or The Green Young Man) is a bildungsroman, an account of a nave young persons education and the formation of his character, in this case inspired by Henry Fieldings 18th-century novel Tom Jones, about a similarly clueless but likable character making his way on the road of life. As witty as its English forebear but with French savoir-faire, The Foundling Boy may win new readers for books translated from French, of which too few are published. English PEN and Arts Council England have supported Julian Evanss translation, evidently in hopes of broadening our reading of these classics.

title: G.M. Recalls Camaros to Replace Faulty Keys
description: General Motors is recalling more than half a million Chevrolet Camaros because of the danger that a bump to the keys could suddenly turn off the ignition  a problem similar to the defect that led the automaker to recall millions of small cars this year.

title: Heres How
description: It is entirely possible, if you sit down on a comfy couch with a plump pillow, a good reading light and a crack pipe, that you can read a bunch of parenting books and not feel terrible.

title: All in the Famiglia
description: In Blood Brotherhoods, the British scholar John Dickie sets himself the wildly ambitious task of writing the histories of Italys three major criminal organizations from their origins in the mid-19th century to the present. The result is a book that is alternately impressive and infuriating. Dickie has amassed and digested an astonishing mass of material (tens of thousands of pages of trial documents, newspaper accounts and secondary literature) and followed scores of different characters (bandits, crime bosses, policemen, judges, politicians) in disparate places across a 150-year span. And yet he has managed, despite the girth and diversity, to sustain an argument and a story. He entertains the reader with dozens of fascinating figures  both noble and blood-chilling  while making frequently shrewd judgments that place this story in context, as a central feature of Italian life.

title: Paperback Row
description: BELIEVING IS SEEING: Observations on the Mysteries of Photography,  by Errol Morris. (Penguin, $25.) Morris brings his great talent as a filmmaker to this investigation of the contested reality behind an eclectic range of documentary photographs  from the Crimean War, the Depression, Abu Ghraib and elsewhere. Intercutting his essays with maps, letters, timelines and interview excerpts, Morris refines our most basic way of understanding the world, Kathryn Schulz wrote here.

title: A Second Chance to Help Families Save Their Homes
description: Jennifer Taub is professor at Vermont Law School. Her book Other Peoples Houses was published in May by Yale University Press.

title: Obama Says He Will Decide on Military Support for Iraq in Days Ahead
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Friday that he would make a decision in the days ahead about whether to use American military power to help the besieged Iraqi government stave off collapse at the hands of Islamist insurgents, but he ruled out using ground forces.

title: Editors Choice
description: WHAT IS VISIBLE,  by Kimberly Elkins. (Twelve, $25.) While contemplating the bare requisites of being human, this historical novel about the Helen Keller-like Laura Bridgman also dishes dirt on a pantheon of 19th-century heroes of civil reform.

title: Heavy Lifting From the Vaults: Lots of Allmans and Elvis on the Way
description: Classic albums by the Allman Brothers Band and Elvis Presley are to be given expanded reissues that, depending on your level of fascination with these musicians, are either textbook examples of bloated archival sprawl or something like perfection.

title: A Reagan or a Blair?
description: I wrote a little on Wednesday about what I described as the uncertain implications of David Brats primary victory for the future of a more reform-minded conservatism. For a less uncertain take on the matter, here is David Frum, arguing that the only way to reform the Republican Party is for figures like Eric Cantor  or, I suppose, his successors in the leadership to take the fight more ruthlessly to the partys insurgents:

title: Thad Cochrans Unlikely Donor Lineup
description: The adage that politics makes for strange bedfellows may have few better examples than the Senate race in Mississippi, where Senator Thad Cochran faces Chris McDaniel, a state senator, in a June 24 runoff.

title: A Trip That Will Assist the Rhino
description: Extraordinary Journeys, the New York City-based safari outfitter, recently announced a new 10-day safari to Botswana and Zambia that is intended to benefit the Great Plains Foundations Zeros for Rhinos initiative.

title: Portraits From Kiev
description: Photos of the protesters and the mourners at Independence Square in Kiev, Ukraine, in February.

title: Strike a Pose
description: The actress imitates the poses from fashion catalogs and magazines for Leanne Shaptons forthcoming book, Women In Clothes.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Nikil Savals Cubed
description: This week, Nikil Saval talks about Cubed: A Secret History of the Workplace; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the weeks literary news; Lenore Skenazy discusses two new books about parenting; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Five Things to Do This Weekend
description: There are a lot of cultural options out there. Too many to choose from? Perhaps. So below weve winnowed them all down to a few, for brows of all kinds.

title: Document | Act Natural
description: Soon after the Canadian-born artist Leanne Shapton ordered a nightgown from the Vermont Country Store last year, she began to receive mail-order catalogs from National (their tagline: Living the comfortable life since 1952) and Woman Within. Struck by the models demure stances, she cut out certain images, before turning to her own fashion magazines and other periodicals. Last September, she asked Zosia Mamet to imitate the poses she had collected; the photographer Gus Powell shot. Posturing  inspired by the grids of the German artist Hans-Peter Feldmann, illustrated workouts and 1970s yoga manuals (hence the unitard)  is one of the many projects in Women in Clothes, out this fall. Edited by Sheila Heti, Heidi Julavits and Shapton, the book explores the issues women face when they get dressed. According to Shapton, the photo series evokes the energetic, experimental spirit of the publication, which features over 600 contributors. We wanted the reader to do exercises, Shapton said. Exercises for the critical eye.

title: Kevin McCarthy Wont Enjoy Being Majority Leader
description: Kevin McCarthy of California, the House Republican Whip, is running hard to win Eric Cantors post as Majority Leader, and claims he has the votes locked up. But except for the big office  and the security detail, and the power and the glory  its hard to know why he really wants the job.

title: Winning a Real Estate Bidding War
description: The low supply of homes for sale in many markets means buyers must be prepared for bidding wars. Buyers should be strategic in how they present their offers, and avoid paying too high a premium for their perfect property.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Nikil Savals Cubed
description: This week, Nikil Saval and Lenore Skenazy.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking
description: After a severe winter that sent the economy into negative territory at the start of the year, have things turned around? Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar review their predictions on economic growth for the year ahead. Are the stock markets recent record highs trickling down to everyone? Plus, whatever happened to Bitcoin?

title: Back From the Brink, Minnesota Orchestra Announces New Season
description: For anyone still waiting for assurances that the Minnesota Orchestra is settling back into its routine after a 16-month lockout and subsequent administrative drama, the orchestra has announced its 2014-15 season. And if that alone is not a clear enough sign, the orchestra and Osmo Vanska, its highly regarded music director  newly restored to his post after resigning during the dispute  plan to open its subscription season on Sept. 26 with Mahlers Resurrection Symphony. (An opening gala with Rene Fleming, and a pair of performances outside the orchestras hall precede the Mahler, but surely Mr. Vanska and company want the symbolism to be clear.)

title: Movie Review: 22 Jump Street
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews 22 Jump Street.

title: On Our Walls
description: The walls of The New York Times headquarters on Eighth Avenue are decorated with news images from the past. Prints by photojournalists hang throughout the building. In this Insider series, On Our Walls, well take you inside the building to see the photographs  many of them rich in history  and the stories behind them.

title: Son of David Rockefeller Dies in Small-Plane Crash
description: Dr. Richard Rockefeller, son of the billionaire and prominent philanthropist David Rockefeller, was killed Friday morning when the small plane he was piloting crashed shortly after takeoff, according to a spokesman for the family.

title: Driven | 2015 Audi A3 2.0T quattro
description: Dont confuse small with inexpensive.

title: Wheelies: The World Cup Nissan Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Movie Review: The Rover
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews The Rover.

title: Israeli Teenagers Said to Be Kidnapped in West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  Three Israeli teenagers were missing in the West Bank and were presumed to have been kidnapped, Israeli military officials said on Friday. The episode tested Israels already strained ties with the Palestinians and prompted the involvement of the State Department amid reports that one of the youngsters held United States citizenship.

title: Book Review Podcast: Nikil Savals Cubed
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Richard Sennett reviews Nikil Savals Cubed: A Secret History of the Workplace. Mr. Sennett writes:

title: Video: The Audi A3 Is a Small Car With a Big Price
description: There are a few key things to know about the new Audi A3 compact car, which for 2015 is being offered in the United States for the first time as a sedan, not a hatchback.

title: A Money Pit No More
description: The Long Island mansion used for The Money Pit, the 1986 comedy starring Tom Hanks and Shelley Long about the ultimate fixer-upper fiasco, is poised to go on the market for $12.5 million. The annual property taxes on the home are $65,992.

title: Bookshelf: Baby Talk
description: New picture books include Sara Gillinghams Snuggle the Baby and Lori Nicholss Maple.

title: John Kerry on Obamas Iraq Thinking
description: At the Global Summit to End Sexual Violence in Conflict, Secretary of State John Kerry spoke about the timely decisions on the violence in Iraq that he expects from President Obama.

title: Image of the Day: June 13
Tactician Will Try to Take a Title From a Brawler
description: Backgrounds often help shape boxing styles, and contrasting styles are said to make fights.

title: Fathers' Rights and Women's Equality
Assessing the Benefits of Becoming a Benefit Corporation
description: When business owners incorporate, they typically do so for one of two reasons: Their accountant told them its a good idea, or they want to be taxed in a particular manner. Now theres a third reason to consider.

title: Can Uber Live Up to Its $40 Billion Valuation?
description: Dec. 4, 2014: Uber, the mobile-phone-based car service, is getting bigger. The company said today that it had raised another $1.2 billion in funding in a round that values the firm at a remarkable $40 billion (thus post-funding the firm is worth $41.2 billion). At 5 years old, the company now has a valuation on par with that of giants like Time Warner Cable and Prudential Insurance.

title: The End of Cuisine
description: Nathan Myhrvold, the Mad Hatter of modernist cooking, invited the movements leading chef, Ferran Adri, over for a 50-course, lab-prepared meal. It was a lot to digest, sure, but what does a feast like this mean for the future of eating?

title: F.C.C. Begins Investigation Into Quality of Internet Download Speeds
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission has opened an investigation into recent deals where entertainment companies like Netflix have agreed to pay Internet service providers like Comcast and Verizon for faster video delivery, a practice that critics contend will divide Internet service into fast and slow lanes.

title: Movie Review: Dragon 2
description: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews How to Train Your Dragon 2.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: fish during pregnancy, tools to combat blindness and sex after 60. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: An Intense Chef, and His Commandments
description: The first thing you should know about Tomonori Tanaka, the owner, chef and one-man band calling the tunes at Tomos Cuisine in East Hanover, is that hes not as stern as he looks.

title: The Rebirth of the Wedding
description: A few years ago, it seemed like America might reject the wedding.Feminist criticismsof various wedding traditions gained steam; a New Yorker writer released abookon the ceremonies ballooning costs; the recession made couplesscale back. The phrase wedding-industrial complex entered common parlance.

title: John Seymour: Home for Tuck-In Time
description: When the restaurateur John Seymour moved 12 years ago from Manhattan to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, he was drawn by the raw lofts with low rents. The first place I lived was on Kent Avenue, with a revolving door of roommates and 20-foot ceilings, he said. We could throw a football inside.

title: The Halal Guys: Cashing In on Street Cred
description: Some empires are managed from a distance: in corner offices, from cellphones on beaches, under palm fronds while being fanned by servants.

title: The Times Critics Guide to the Friday the 13th Movies
description: Theres only one actual Friday the 13th in 2014  good news for paraskevidekatriaphobics. But if you wanted to complete a marathon viewing of all eleven movies in the Friday the 13th franchise on the actual date, youve probably missed your chance for this year. (If you want to go ahead anyway, note that most of the films are available for digital rental.)

title: Game of Thrones Season Finale: 6 Questions That Need Answers
description: This post contains spoilers.

title: Kerry Joins Envoys to Deplore Sexual Violence in War
description: LONDON  Secretary of State John Kerry said on Friday that sexual violence in conflict zones should be banished to the dark ages and the history books, as he joined dozens of ministers and the actress Angelina Jolie to promote efforts to bring perpetrators of such crimes to justice.

title: Stayin Alive
description: Meryl Meisler couldnt believe the sight that greeted her when she emerged from the subway in Bushwick, Brooklyn, for the first time, in 1981. It looked like the photographs that I had seen of Beirut, she recalled of the cityscape of bombed-out buildings.

title: It Never Happened, but Its Still True
description: At the conclusion of a 2011 New Yorker article on the Church of Scientology, the writer-director Paul Haggis made a prediction regarding his very public break with that institution.

title: Kings College in New York to Accept Bitcoin
description: Bitcoin can already be used to purchase a plane ticket, donate to a political campaign and pay a satellite TV bill. Beginning this fall, it can also be used to pay for a college education.

title: Enter the World Cup
description: The world will now pause for a month. Its the World Cup. Coups and annexations, meltdowns and earthquakes will have to take a back seat to the beautiful game. No other global obsession even comes close. I have been at the last two in South Africa and Germany and came away with glorious memories. Love of the game usually wins out in the end whatever the pretournament grumbling and ugly moments (like Zinedine Zidanes head butt in the 2006 final).

title: Whom to Watch in the G.O.P. Shuffle
description: As Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, exits the scene, several candidates are vying for leadership positions, which may force a change in Republican party politics.

title: Art Matters | A Biennial in, and About, Los Angeles
description: In his infamous Artforum review of the first Made in L.A. biennial in 2012, the critic and curator Michael Ned Holte used some choice language: the survey of nascent L.A. artists at the Hammer Museum had a boosterish tone, he wrote. He even name-checked every Angelenos favorite Saturday Night Live sketch, The Californians, with its memorable recurring finale in which all the characters crowd in front of a single mirror.

title: President Obamas Statement on Iraq
description: President Obama announced that he would not be sending United States troops back into combat in Iraq, but said he had asked his national security team to prepare a range of options.

title: Hillary Clinton Talks Same-Sex Marriage on Fresh Air
description: Hillary Clinton has been getting some heat in the media for being evasive about her views on gay marriage during an interview with Terry Gross, host of NPRs Fresh Air program, and for snapping at Ms. Gross when she pressed her on the subject.

title: A Train to Nowhere in a New Ice Age
description: In the sci-fi thriller Snowpiercer, class warfare goes express.

title: Reassessing Reversal of Adversary to S.E.C.
description: Judge Jed S. Rakoff of the Federal District Court in Manhattan sent shock waves through the legal and financial establishments in November 2011 when he rejected a proposed $285 million settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Citigroup. Judge Rakoff said it was impossible for him to say whether it was fair and reasonable, let alone in the public interest, after the bank neither admitted nor denied the S.E.C.s accusations nor otherwise revealed any of the facts in a complex mortgage fraud case.

title: Evidence Is Still Thin That Democratic Voters Ousted Eric Cantor
description: The theory that Democrats cost Eric Cantor his re-election continues to fester. Its not impossible; its just highly unlikely. Mr. Cantor lost by 11 points, which is a significant margin in what was a congressional primary with fairly high turnout. Ive not seen any evidence that there was a surge of 15,000 Democratic votes.

title: Skillet Chicken With Rhubarb
description: Rhubarb is just as good in savory dishes as it is in dessert. Here, Melissa Clark uses it in a bright, fresh and seasonal dish with chicken and green garlic.

title: Drinks and Food, in That Order
description: A place that bills itself as a cantina, as this nearly year-old spot does, calls to mind a few assumptions. First, that a good time will be had there. Second, that drinking  of the lively, boisterous variety  will factor heavily into that good time. And third, that food can be enjoyed there, even if it is not quite the main point.

title: Rhubarb Flaunts Its Savory Side
description: Are you ready for the rhubarb revolution?

title: This Weekend: The Northside Festival
description: The sixth annual Northside Festival in Brooklyn kicks off Thursday and will run through the weekend. There will be hundreds of bands showcasing their latest music. Here are three to check out.

title: Early Gershwin Musical to Open City Centers Encores Season
description: The Gershwin brothers first full musical, Lady, Be Good  which yielded, apart from the title song, Fascinating Rhythm and So Am I (and from which The Man I Love was unaccountably dropped during an out-of-town run)  will open City Centers Encores! season on Feb. 4. The musical, which has a book by Guy Bolton and Fred Thompson as well as Ira Gershwins lyrics and George Gershwins music, ran for 330 performances on Broadway in 1924 and 1925.

title: Love, Fear and Anxiety in Suite 719
description: For most of his career, Neil Simon explored family relationships in plays that were either comedies or bittersweet dramas tinged with humor. Even his funniest work, though, was often built on pain. Where would The Odd Couple be without the marital difficulties that brought Oscar and Felix together as mismatched roommates?

title: Iraq May Turn to Iran for Help, Maliki Aide Says
description: BAGHDAD  A senior Iraqi official on Friday warned that his country might be forced to turn to Iran for military help if none were forthcoming from the United States, but he insisted he was unaware of any Iranian military units in his country so far.

title: The Snakes May Not Bite, but the Humidity Devours
description: MANAUS, Brazil  It is the one place all 32 teams probably wanted to avoid in the World Cup, this Amazon city where the heat and humidity feel like a dryer full of damp clothes.

title: Spain vs. Netherlands: Live Blog
description: Welcome to our live coverage of Fridays Group B clash between Spain and the Netherlands, a rematch of the 2010 World Cup final.

title: High Cost to Focusing on Student Loans Over Saving
description: This week, President Obama ordered changes to the federal student loan program that could help millions of borrowers make their payments more affordable starting in December 2015.

title: Malfunction Seen in Jet Crash That Killed Co-owner of Philadelphia Inquirer
description: The wreckage of an executive jet that crashed on takeoff at an airport north of Boston on May 31 shows signs of a mechanical malfunction, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Friday in a preliminary report.

title: A First Great Love Plots the Course for the Second
description: The night before she died, Diane Gamble helped plan her husbands life without her.

title: Training at the Top of the World
description: To train for the largest descent of his life, Jeremy Jones partnered with the legendary climber Conrad Anker for an ascent of Denali.

title: Unraveling in Iraq, and Beyond
China to Prosecute Pu Zhiqiang for Activism
description: BEIJING  The Chinese authorities on Friday announced the formal arrest of a well-known rights defender who last month took part in a private seminar where participants discussed the armys violent suppression of the student-led protests of 1989 in Tiananmen Square.

title: Iraqs Uncertain Future
description: As President Obama weighs whether to help defend the Iraqi government against insurgents, analysts around the world are offering their prescriptions (and their sometimes-dire predictions) for a country in the throes of worsening conflict.

title: Talking Talent | Jenny Mollens New Book of Laughs
description: Honest and often painfully embarrassing, Jenny Mollens debut book, I Like You Just The Way I Am: Stories About Me and Some Other People (St. Martins Press), hits bookstores on Tuesday and is poised to be one of the seasons funniest reads. The 35-year-old wife of the actor Jason Biggs and mother to their newborn son, Sid, spent over a decade appearing in barely-there parts on film and television, but found her true calling when she decided to put pen to paper to chronicle her every phobia, sexual encounter and misadventure while stalking her future husbands exes. With over 125,000 Twitter followers who hang on her acerbic pearls of wisdom  Its 10:40, Hes not calling to make plans!  Mollen, who looks more like a Maxim pinup than a raunchy comedienne, is amassing a devoted legion of fans, one selfie at a time.

title: 30-Year-Old Decision Could Serve as Template for N.C.A.A. Antitrust Case
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  William Isaacson has only a few items in his trial binder at federal court here every day. There are both sides pretrial briefs filed in the antitrust suit brought against the N.C.A.A. by his client, the former U.C.L.A. basketball star Ed OBannon. There are the major decisions by the presiding judge, Claudia Wilken. And there is the full text of a 30-year-old Supreme Court case.

title: A Better Ranch Dressing
description: Ranch dressing for dipping makes almost any vegetable more appealing to children, but commercially prepared ranch dressings have nutritional drawbacks. So heres a salad dressing base made with yogurt and white beans that can be the foundation of a healthful ranch dressing as well as a few variants.

title: A Little Assistance on the Path to I Do
description: It takes a village, the saying goes, to raise a child. And in todays world, it may take an army of consultants, and the cash to pay for them, to bring two lonely souls from bar stools through bended knee and into a glittering wedding celebration. Here is just a partial rundown of the consultants, or concierges, if you will, that the lovelorn may encounter on their road to wedded bliss, and beyond.

title: Big Ticket | At $70 Million, a Manhattan Co-op Sales Record
description: A palatial Fifth Avenue penthouse embraced to the west and south by a wraparound terrace with 100 feet of panoramic Central Park frontage sold for $70 million and, along with breaking a sales record for Manhattan co-ops, was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Iraq Reportedly Blocks Social Networks
description: As officials in Baghdad searched for ways to blunt the momentum of Islamist militants who have seized large stretches of Iraq in recent days, the government blocked access to social media sites including Facebook, Twitter and YouTube, bloggers and journalists inside the country reported on Friday.

title: New York City vs. Street Peddlers, a Brief History
description: A selection of articles from The New York Timess archives chronicling the battle.

title: The Beautiful Data Set
description: THE World Cup is finally underway. At long last, soccer fans can don their team colors, head down to the local pub  and begin collecting data to test economic theories.

title: Weekend Autos Calendar: Henry Ford Museums Motor Muster Celebrates the Mustang
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: Cara Delevingnes Acting Debut, Karlie Klosss Designs and Jeff Koonss Storefront Show
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: In China, Negotiating Peaks and Police
description: The black sport-utility vehicle stopped about 300 feet behind us at a bend in the road. Its occupants were hidden behind its tinted windows. Inside, we assumed, were police officers assigned to follow our group of five foreign men and a local driver up the narrow mountain road. A metal bar across the road had brought us to a halt. It was a police checkpoint, and a man posted at a booth said no outsiders were allowed farther.

title: Finding Mexico City, and Luis Barragn, Again
description: Memory, in its random way, erased the reasons I stopped going to Mexico City.

title: The Sister of Second Chances
description: Venita Pinckney grew up around Catholic schools and churches, and she thought she knew about nuns. Then a small, gray-haired sister named Teresa Fitzgerald came to fish her out of a Harlem crack house. Ms. Pinckney had been a drug addict for 23 years, a dealer and a prostitute, and had lost both of her children to foster care. She was high at the time.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Giants Beason Sustains Foot Injury
description: Jon Beason, the Giants middle linebacker and one of their defensive leaders, sustained a foot injury that may jeopardize his availability for the season opener against the Lions in Detroit on Sept. 8.

title: Priceline Will Need to Expand OpenTable Overseas to Justify the Splurge
description: The Priceline Group picked an expensive option in its search for expansion.

title: Giving a Semi-Hearty Cheer for Semi-Staged Opera
description: When the vengeful husband enters his wifes bedroom to kill her in the final act of Verdis Otello, he is accompanied by the muted snarl of a sepulchral E natural in the double basses. For several measures, the violins have been sustaining a heaven-high A flat, and the low tone suddenly replaces it, as if a candle had been snuffed out.

title: Selling Baubles on the Street: License Required
description: On March 14, Chun Yin took the subway from her apartment in East Harlem to get a good spot on Canal Street to sell jade bracelets, pearl earrings and carved figurines on red silky thread she braids by hand.

title: Weekend Reading: London Bankers May Be Slow to Return Your Calls
description: Who has time to advise a deal or underwrite an initial public offering when important events are taking place in one of the BRIC countries?

title: Taking a Spin: Republicans Have It Their Way
description: Just about everything broke right for Republicans today in my spin of Leos Senate wheels, our weekly demonstration of how much uncertainty remains in this years elections.

title: Avoiding Another Iraq Quagmire
description: Given that he built a political career on opposition to the Iraq war, it was a relief but no surprise when President Obama on Friday ruled out sending American ground troops back into the country.

title: At Bonnie Slotnick Cookbooks, Recipes to Feed Your Mind and Body
description: Theres always a slight sense of dread as you approach West 10thStreet, just off SeventhAvenue, that you might find Bonnie Slotnicks vintage cookbook shop closed that day. But if the chipped wooden Open sign (she painted it herself) peeks out from the brownstones stoop, youre in luck. Shove open the rickety door and a string of bells will herald your arrival.

title: Mick Jones: A Quiet Day, for a Juke Box Hero
description: It is an amusement of New York life that rock stars live among us, picking up dry cleaning or going to the dentist just like everybody else. And it is a quirk of contemporary rock stardom that its constituents now come in all vintages, with hairstyles and heydays stretching back for decades. So it is that Mick Jones, 69, original lead guitarist of the band Foreigner, has been living near Central Park since the 70s, long enough that he can say, in the accent of Somerset, England, Im really a native New Yorker. These days he is sometimes eclipsed by his stepchildren and children, who include: the D.J., singer and producer Mark Ronson, 38; the fashion designer Charlotte Ronson, 36; the singer and D.J. Samantha Ronson, 36; and the actress Annabelle Dexter-Jones, 27. Foreigner will perform with Styx and Don Felder at Jones Beach on Long Island on June 28.

title: The Mediterranean Seafood Salad of Your Dreams
description: Summer appetites are different, and so is summer cooking. In the morning one craves fresh fruit and little more, but by midday a voracious hunger is upon us. We want garlic and lemon and olive oil, and olives, and tomatoes with salt. Maybe a little pizza to tide us over until lunch.

title: A Ride Across America | Greenmarkets and Off-the-Grid Living in the Heart of Kentucky Coal Country
description: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, theyll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

title: Senegal to the Caribbean, With a Stop at the Church of Funk and Soul
description: Dexter Johnson

title: Have You Shopped for a 70 Ford Lately?
description: EL MIRAGE, ARIZ.  To step into Kevin Martis garage here is to travel back in time, to reset the dial on the WABAC Machine for 1970 and the destination for the Ford dealership in Anytown, America.

title: A Full-Service Time Machine
description: Kevin Martis garage and museum in El Mirage, Ariz., is a reproduction of a circa-1970 Ford dealership.

title: 24-Hour Race Could Lure Huge Crowd at Le Mans
description: LE MANS, France  Authorities here are expecting a potential record crowd  possibly approaching 300,000 people  for the start Saturday of the 82nd running of the 24 Hours of Le Mans endurance race.

title: Mayor of Venice Resigns Amid Corruption Scandal
description: ROME  Venices mayor, Giorgio Orsoni, resigned on Friday amid a mounting corruption scandal connected with the construction of a colossal flood-barrier system designed to save the lagoon city from flooding.

title: Finding Cracks in a Perfect Life
description: Wendy Wasserstein is best remembered for writing thoughtful, witty plays about smart women of her baby boom generation.

title: Tradition Will Play On at Clearwater Festival
description: The Clearwater Festival, which has grown from a counterculture-era folk picnic into a sprawling event featuring nearly 100 acts on seven stages, remains at heart a modest affair, free of corporate logos and nurtured by a handful of artist-activists who shared a smaller-is-better ethos with the festivals founder, Pete Seeger.

title: On the Market in Hilton Head, S.C.
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: At E3, Virtual Reality Goggles Dont  Fit Into Reality
description: Its tough to stand out at E3, the annual gaming conference. People wander around dressed as orks, gangsters, prehistoric humans, and no one really bats an eye. As one person put it to me, E3 is nerdier than the cantina scene in Star Wars.

title: Futebol para Cegos no Brasil
description: Os deficientes visuais brasileiros desafiam o destino ao jogarem o esporte favorito do seu pas, o futebol.

title: Where the Z/28 Legacy Began
description: Carmakers often resurrect popular model names, but only rarely do they reinstate the character that made the original so memorable. It does happen  the 2014 Corvette Stingray seems to have it  and early reports say that Chevrolets Camaro Z/28 revival is faithful to its take-no-prisoners ancestor.

title: Inside the Frog, a Prince Awaits
description: If a building contractor arrived on time, performed heroically and charged a fair price  this is a New York fantasy, stay with me  would you complain that he wasnt good-looking? Would you refuse to hire him if he didnt come with a fashionable tool belt?

title: A Legend Revived, Its Spirit Intact
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y.  For the Chevrolet Camaro, burning rubber in a straight line has rarely been a problem. Turning and stopping? Not always a top priority.

title: Taliban Run Into Trouble on Battlefield, but Money Flows Just the Same
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Despite years of efforts by Western officials to cut off the Talibans financial lifelines, the militants are as rich as ever, bringing in so much cash from opium trafficking, illegal mining, extortion rackets and other ventures that the money itself appears to be a reason for many insurgents to keep fighting, Afghan and Western officials say.

title: World Cup 2014: Switzerland Stuns Ecuador, 2-1, in Added Time
description: Haris Seferovics goal with 20 seconds left in added time capped a wild finish and gave Switzerland a stunning 2-1 victory over Ecuador in a first-round match.

title: A Vieques Hotel With Contemporary Designand Cuisine
description: The small island of Vieques, just off the eastern coast of Puerto Rico, will soon harbor one of the most architecturally significant hotels in the Caribbean.

title: World Cup 2014: France Easily Beats Honduras, 3-0
description: France rolled past Honduras in its opening match, helped by a red card to Honduran midfielder Wilson Palacios and two goals from forward Karim Benzema.

title: 2015 Camaro Z/28
description: A look at the latest Camaro Z/28.

title: Russia Sent Tanks to Separatists in Ukraine, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department confirmed on Friday that Russia had sent tanks and other heavy weapons to separatists in Ukraine.

title: World Cup 2014: Italy Defeats England, 2-1
description: With goals by Claudio Marchisio and Mario Balotelli, Italy outlasted England in the punishing heat and humidity of Manaus to win the first match in the Amazon rainforest.

title: In Baghdad, Where Hello Means Goodbye, Hellos Abound at Travel Agencies
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqis say hello when they mean goodbye. This can get a little confusing to visitors who do not speak the local dialect of Arabic and think they are hearing English, instead of a borrowed word that has been inverted in meaning.

title: World Cup 2014: Colombia Defeats Greece, 3-0
description: Colombia more than made up for the absence of Radamel Falcao, its star striker, in its victory against Greece on Saturday.

title: World Cup 2014: Costa Rica Defeats Uruguay, 3-1
description: After falling behind 1-0, Costa Rica scored three goals in the second half to defeat Uruguay in one of the first upsets of the World Cup.

title: The 2015 Honda Fit: More Than Skin Deep
description: Hondas well-mannered hatchback gets an update, proving that beauty is as beauty does.

title: Settlement Talks Stall for Citigroup and Justice Department
description: Updated, 8:21 p.m. | Talks between the Justice Department and Citigroup to settle a civil investigation into its sale of shoddy mortgage investments have deteriorated in recent days, as the sides are deadlocked on how much money the bank should pay.

title: World Cup 2014: Ivory Coast Defeats Japan, 2-1
description: The Ivory Coast recovered from an early setback, scoring two second-half goals in the space of 100 seconds Saturday night to earn a 2-1 win over Japan in Group C.

title: Revealing Art, Bursting at the Seams of Control
description: The soprano Ariadne Greif stepped out of her gown and ripped off the strips of silver duct tape that crisscrossed her torso like a girdle until she stood naked at the front of the stage, flushed and defiant. Under my skin gruesome fire smolders, she sang in a German translation of verses by Sappho. A high roaring buzzes in my ears, and from every pore seep pearls of sweat.

title: World Cup 2014: Argentina Defeats Bosnia-Herzegovina, 2-1
description: Lionel Messi scored a goal to the delight of his fans, and Argentina received the gift of an own goal in scoring a 2-1 victory over Bosnia-Herzegovina.

title: World Cup 2014: Germany Defeats Portugal, 4-0
description: Thomas Mller scored three goals to power Germany to a commanding 4-0 victory and solidified his countrys place at the top of the list of teams that will challenge for the title.

title: Electricity Reporting for Duty
description: TESTED 2014 Zero SR

title: Bumpy Road to Bright New Days
description: Time has left us older/but wiser, I know I am. Come in From the Rain, the welcoming hymn to a solid longtime friendship from which those lyrics come, was written in the 1970s by Melissa Manchester and Carole Bayer Sager. Although Ms. Manchesters original recording was not a big hit, the song nevertheless became a nightclub staple until it slowly faded out of fashion.

title: Are You a Fun Dad?
description: This week, President Obama described himself as a fun dad who teeters on the edge of being embarrassing sometimes.

title: World Cup 2014: Iran and Nigeria Play to 0-0 Draw
description: Iran and Nigeria tied, 0-0, in a match that was low on goalscoring opportunities and became the first draw of the 2014 World Cup.

title: Londons Legacy in the Slave Trade
description: It was a bright Saturday morning, and the City of London, the financial district of the British capital, was empty. I was wandering its narrow side lanes seeking a sculpture. I kept getting lost, and found myself going forward and then backtracking. Finally, in a courtyard between office buildings I came upon it: The Gilt of Cain, by Michael Visocchi and Lemn Sissay.

title: U.S.O.C. Narrows Bids to Four Cities
description: The United States Olympic Committee announced Friday that it had narrowed its list of potential American cities to host the 2024 Summer Games to four finalists  Boston, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington.

title: The Z/28 Generations
description: The Camaro Z/28 through the years.

title: A Balanced Flavor for the Modern Father
description: Fatherhood used to be so simple. Wake up, grab your briefcase, kiss your wife and kids goodbye, work all day and come home to find a clean house, kids tucked into bed and a cocktail awaiting your arrival.

title: Under an Unblinking Gaze, a Farewell to Privacy
description: Whos watching whom and to what purpose? Surveillance  a new 60-minute piece by ZviDance at New York Live Arts this week  is a shrewd collage, both appealing and disconcerting, of the Orwellian Big Brother society, aspects of sexuality and dancing to rock music. Its the urban world we know, deconstructed and reassembled. In a society in which people need to film or photograph everything, what intimacy is left? Zvi Gotheiners choreography suggests that he is as much sociologist as dance-maker.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Iraq, Afghanistan, Syria and Mexico.

title: The Duet Between the Right Brain and the Left
description: In 2003, when the Walmart heiress Nancy Laurie founded Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet, it sounded like a whim. Yet, over time, the troupe earned respect by filling a hole in the market, commissioning work by rising European choreographers gaining buzz abroad but little seen here. This is a valuable service, even if the effect so far has been to make New York dance audiences feel that they havent been missing much.

title: The Barrister Has 2 Faces
description: In one area, at least, America has a severe trade imbalance with the British. They keep sending us their brainy, urbane leading men  Colin Firth, Benedict Cumberbatch, Kenneth Branagh, Daniel Day-Lewis  and receive very little in return.

title: The World Wide Bridge Contest Results
description: The World Wide Bridge Contests were held in clubs around the world on June 6 and 7. They were organized by Ecats Bridge, which is run by Anna Gudge and Mark Newton (ecatsbridge.com).

title: Stephane Cremieux of the French Brand Cremieux Shares Fathers Day Gift Ideas Any Dad Will Love (Including His)
description: Last month, the venerable French brand Cremieux, a purveyor of preppy tailored sportswear since 1976, opened its first American store in SoHo. These days, Cremieux is a family business, jointly operated by its founder, Daniel Cremieux, and his son, Stephane. Here, Stephane offers his list of 10 great Fathers Day treats (many of which can be picked up at locations around New York City for you last-minute shoppers) that his dad and any other would appreciate.

title: Under Cover: Photographing Frontline Operations in Africa
description: The June 15 cover story about confronting terrorism in Africa is accompanied by photographs from Michael Christopher Brown. For the past several years, Brown has primarily covered North and Central Africa, particularly Libya and the Democratic Republic of Congo. Here, he discusses his recent assignment for the magazine.

title: Chile vs. Australia: Live Blog
description: Chile scored two quick goals to jump out to an early lead and held on against Australia for the victory in the teams opening Group B match.

title: Publishing a Novel to Preserve a Legacy
description: Elise Jordan curled her petite frame into the sofa in her sunny apartment in TriBeCa and kept her voice steady as she explained why she pushed to publish the unfinished novel of her husband, Michael Hastings, on the first anniversary of his death.

title: Judge to Consider Retrial or Dismissal in Malcolm Smith Case
description: WHITE PLAINS  As prosecutors hurriedly assembled a team of translators to transcribe 28 hours of Yiddish conversation, a federal judge said on Friday that he would entertain written arguments to help him determine whether the untranslated material might warrant a mistrial or a dismissal of the bribery indictments against State Senator Malcolm A. Smith and two other defendants.

title: Scoring Onslaught Does In Defending Champions
description: SALVADOR, Brazil  Sitting on the bench, worrying that history might be repeated at his teams expense, Dirk Kuyt, the Dutch reserve forward, had a perfect view of a goal that energized a nation and a tournament with its daring and flair.

title: High-End Herms Handbags at Center of Suit Against Christies
description: Locked behind glass, illuminated like a jewel, lies an Herms Birkin  totem of wealth, bestower of status, and one seriously expensive handbag.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: Tunes From the Great Shakespearean Songbook
description: In the olden days (2011 or so), if you wanted to see and hear Karen Akers doing the exquisite songs of masters like Cole Porter and Stephen Sondheim, you had to make reservations at one of Manhattans chic cabarets. But here she is in all her splendor, onstage at the Westport Country Playhouse, in Sing for Your Shakespeare, both standing out from and blending in with an ensemble cast.

title: The Honoree Wanted to Play, Too
description: The evenings honoree on Thursday at the Prospect Park Bandshell in Brooklyn was Ornette Coleman, and the first to pay respects was Sonny Rollins, wearing a stylish black raincoat.

title: Nostalgias Blurring Glow
description: In Mythologies, Roland Barthess classic collection of essays on the roots and consequences of interpretation, the theorist examines the ways in which consensus understanding evolves around cultural phenomena, typically  or, perhaps almost always  at the expense of layered or contested meaning.

title: After Four Decades, a School Program Still Shows Youth and Energy
description: As Eliot Feld has said, ballet is not for a class of people, but for everyone with talent. Discovering dancers through auditions at New York City public schools is his mission. On Thursday night, that talent was on display at the Joyce Theater when Mr. Felds Kids Dance revealed exactly what a student showcase should be: fresh and unpretentious, with just enough rigor to make it easy on the eye.

title: Obama Finds He Cant Put Iraq War Behind Him
description: WASHINGTON  In a high-profile speech to Army cadets last month, President Obama tried to move beyond Americas tumultuous adventures in Iraq and Afghanistan with a new doctrine all but forswearing the use of military power except in the most dire of circumstances.

title: Reactions to the Turmoil in Iraq From Those Who Served
description: Many of the American servicemen and women who served in Iraq had strong reactions this week when Sunni extremist militants seized broad stretches of the country. The New York Times asked some of the contributors to At War to share their feelings about events there.

title: Alitalias Board Agrees to Cash Infusion From Etihad of Abu Dhabi
description: Facing the prospect of bankruptcy for the second time in five years, the board of Italys troubled flagship airline, Alitalia, agreed on Friday to a strategic partnership that would give a stake of up to 49 percent to the state-owned Abu Dhabi carrier Etihad Airways.

title: Eastern Tent Caterpillar: Warm, Fuzzy and Icky
description: The eastern tent caterpillar (Malacosoma americanum) ranks high on the ick scale for many New Yorkers. Vilified by gardeners, and frequently mistaken for other more destructive caterpillars like those of the nonnative gypsy moth, it is unfairly cast as a woodlands plague. Children seem to instinctively want to squish them. But beauty can sometimes be found in unlikely places. A close examination of the eastern tent caterpillar reveals a handsome native, well adapted to life in the northeast.

title: Kevin McCarthys New Challenge
Natasha Lyonne Is the Character Who Came for Dinner
description: Natasha Lyonne had come from taping NBCs Late Night With Seth Meyers on Wednesday, and was waiting for the cable guy in her lofty SoHo apartment.

title: With Pop-Up Salons, Art Is Demystified
description: On a Saturday afternoon in Chelsea, a group of a few dozen people milled around the International Print Center New York, drinking Champagne and making small talk about the show New Prints 2014/Winter. But this wasnt a gallery opening, nor was it an artists talk. Rather it was a salon by Gertrude, a new company organizing events to discuss art.

title: At the Tone, Leave a What?
description: In a memorable scene from the 1996 comedy Swingers, Jon Favreaus romantically inept protagonist, Mike, deluges the answering machine of a woman hes just met at a bar with a spate of excruciatingly self-sabotaging messages.

title: Ayahuasca: A Strong Cup of Tea
description: On a recent Friday night, a dozen seekers in loosefitting attire, most in their 20s and 30s, climbed a flight of steps of a mixed-used community space in Bushwick, Brooklyn. After arranging yoga mats and blankets on the floor, they each paid $150, listened to a Colombian shaman and his assistant welcome them in Spanish and English, signed a disclaimer, and accepted large plastic takeout-style containers for vomiting.

title: Week in Pictures for June 13
description: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes the Puerto Rican Day Parade, fire breathers, and a soccer game that helps unite a community.

title: Defense Reports Puncture Led to Botched Execution
description: Oklahoma executioners failed to place an injection line properly in a vein in the groin of Clayton D. Lockett, according to an independent autopsy commissioned by Mr. Locketts defense lawyers after his bungled execution drew wide attention to the problems of lethal injection.

title: George Takei Is Still Guiding the Ship
description: George Takei sat in a V.I.P. room at the Waldorf-Astoria as a young makeup artist named Eryk Datura dabbed foundation on his brow.

title: Orchestrated Conflict
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  IN the lush green fields here in Ukraines troubled east, I attended a funeral and a wedding over two days earlier this month. They presented vivid tableaux of contrasting emotions  one of fury, the other of fatalism  but each contained clues to the direction of things in this country on the edge of Europe whose eastern flank has risen up in open rebellion against the central government.

title: Proving Their Chops in the Real World
description: If youve ever taken a chance on a haircut at a beauty academy or let high school football players wash your car, you might be a candidate for eating at the hands of culinary students. At the newly refurbished Bocuse Restaurant at the Culinary Institute of America, in Hyde Park, and at the year-old Dining Lab at Monroe College, in New Rochelle, diners who arent risk-averse can open themselves up to an enormously fun  and rewarding  experience.

title: Evening Hours | So Happy Together
description: With summer approaching, many celebrated outdoors.

title: First Briefing on Bergdahls Condition
description: Maj. Gen. Joseph DiSalvo of the Army said the freed Taliban prisoner Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl was in stable condition.

title: Bill Cunningham | Strutting
description: Signs of a new peacock mens wear revolution are in evidence.

title: In the Air | Paper Revolution
description: Objects made from paper, or inspired by it, are being elevated to artistic heights. Whether crinkled or cut out, prints age-old medium is a material of modern design.

title: For Early Birds and Late Risers Alike
description: After years of catering to night owls with pub offerings like the Good Life in Massapequa Park and the Phoenix in Seaford, Peter Mangouranes, 38, and Paul Oliva, 35, decided to introduce themselves to customers who like to socialize before the sun sets with an all-day breakfast spot called Jam. The cheerful, eight-month-old country cafe, just down the block from the Good Life, has been serving breakfast standards with a twist since October.

title: Bill Cunningham | Mens Wear Revolution
description: Signs of a new peacock revolution are in evidence. It features keen attention to detail, including the lapel flower, real or fake. Further evidence are the spectacular windows at Saks Fifth Avenue. A star of the movement, Domenico Spano, known to the world of custom tailoring and fastidious style as Mimmo, outside the Bowery atelier Against Nature. His style has drawn the focus of a group of young men. Also, a gentleman carries the same bright briefcase but pairs it with a different jacket each day.

title: Among the Rediscovered: Jimmy Giuffre and Eric Dolphy
description: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss two underappreciated jazz artists.

title: Beinecke Library Gets Sackville-West Papers
description: The Beinecke Rare Book & Manuscript Library at Yale has acquired the papers of the writer and gardener Vita Sackville-West and her husband, Harold Nicolson, a diplomat, novelist and historian. The couple featured prominently in Britains literary and political life in the first half of the 20th century and provided their son, Nigel Nicolson, with the subject of his best-selling 1973 biography, Portrait of a Marriage. The archives include drafts of lectures, broadcasts and articles (including a manuscript of her 1942 novel, Grand Canyon); letters from her parents; letters from close friends and lovers, including Rosamund Grosvenor, Pat Dansey, Geoffrey Scott, Hilda Matheson, Christopher St. John and Gwen St. Aubyn; and diaries and garden journals dating from 1930 to 1962.

title: Ruth Simmons at Smith College
description: Ruth Simmons, former president of Smith College and Brown University, addresses the 2014 graduating class of Smith College.

title: Bob Garfield at Albright College
description: Bob Garfield, journalist, addresses the 2014 graduating class of Albright College.

title: Oil Industry in Iraq Faces Setback to Revival
description: After a long history of wars and sanctions, Iraq re-emerged as a critical source of oil in recent years. Mounting Iraqi production helped to ease world oil prices despite the tightening restrictions on Iran and tanking exports from Libya. And Western and Chinese oil companies rushed back, revitalizing long-neglected oil fields in the north and south.

title: No Money, No Time
description: THE absurdity of having had to ask for an extension to write this article isnt lost on me: It is, after all, a piece on time and poverty, or, rather, time poverty  about what happens when we find ourselves working against the clock to finish something. In the case of someone who isnt otherwise poor, poverty of time is an unpleasant inconvenience. But for someone whose lack of time is just one of many pressing concerns, the effects compound quickly.

title: Alexis Ohanian at Carthage College
description: Alexis Ohanian, co-founder of Reddit, addresses the 2014 graduating class of Carthage College.

title: Atul Gawande at U.N.C.-Chapel Hill
description: Atul Gawande, doctor and writer, addresses the 2014 graduating class of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

title: In Two Gentlemen, Shakespeares One Dog
description: You dont see a lot of dogs in Shakespeares plays. Actually, you dont see any  except Crab.

title: Echoes of Africa Along the Carolina Coast
description: Pete Marovich has been documenting the Gullah communities in South Carolina, which maintain traditions despite the challenges of encroaching development.

title: Making Sense
description: I like to think that T is a magazine about all the things in life that you dont really need, but that make every day seem that much more beautiful and interesting. Its why, in every issue, we try to bring you a mix of the most compelling cultural ideas percolating in fashion, art, design, food, travel. This month, we decided to focus on the deeper meanings behind some of the most influential people (living and dead) and ideas shaping how we live right now.

title: Jimmy Scott, Singer Whose Star Rose Late, Dies at 88
description: Jimmy Scott, a jazz singer whose distinctively plaintive delivery and unusually high-pitched voice earned him a loyal following and, late in life, a taste of bona fide stardom, died on Thursday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 88.

title: Massachusetts Democrat Wins Over Voters; Her Party Is a Different Story
description: BOSTON  It was a cringe-worthy moment for Massachusetts Democrats.

title: Botox: A Drug With Many (Potential) Uses
description: Botox is currently approved for nearly 30 uses worldwide, including 10 in the United States. But Allergan, the manufacturer, has applied for or received patents on many more uses for the drug, a move made partly to discourage competitors while it pursues further research.

title: Martha Coakley on Lessons Learned
description: Martha Coakley, the attorney general of Massachusetts, is running as a Democrat for governor, after a failed run for Senate in 2010.

title: John A. Hamilton, Host of Public Affairs TV Programs, Dies at 84
description: John A. Hamilton, a host and producer of public affairs television programs beginning in the 1970s, died on June 7 in Fairfax, Va. He was 84 and lived in nearby McLean.

title: Prenatal Testing, Along With the Worries
description: To the Editor:

title: T Culture Issue
description: The latest issue of T peels back the layers on some of the most influential figures in our culture, past and present. In our cover story, Jody Rosen explores the meaning of musics biggest superstar, Beyonc from her teenage days with Destinys Child to her current standing as pops most glorified (and scrutinized) V.I.P. In the Seattle laboratory of Nathan Myhrvold, Dwight Garner ponders the future of food over a 50-course meal the Mad Hatter-like culinarian cooked for his hero, Ferran Adri. And in suburban Chicago, Emily Witt catches up with the teen blogger turned budding media mogul Tavi Gevinson, whose greatest act  after she takes on Broadway, that is  may be yet to come. Elsewhere, the outspoken critic and forward-thinking American fashion designer Elizabeth Hawes finally gets her due, more than four decades after her death; lits reigning bad boy and memoirist of the momentKarl Ove Knausgaardgrapples with fame in a soul-searching essay; Charlotte Moss looks back on an interview with the late heiress and horticulturist Bunny Mellon, whose fabled Virginia estate is testament to her extraordinary life; BuzzFeeds click-bait empire gets the By the Numbers treatment; and the director Richard Linklater, whose 1970s-set stoner dramedy Dazed and Confused helped define a generation (albeit almost two decades after the fact), tackles time once again in his most ambitious project to date. See all stories from the issue >>

title: Iraqs Factions and Their Goals
description: The goals of of the three main groups in Iraq  Sunni, Shiite and Kurdish  as the country threatens to split apart along sectarian lines.

title: Easy to Vote in Ohio
description: To the Editor:

title: Blocking Any Medicaid Expansion, Virginia Legislature Passes Budget Bill
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Empowered by their new majority in the State Senate, Republicans have moved to checkmate Gov. Terry McAuliffe in a monthslong contest over Medicaid, passing a budget that does not include the Medicaid expansion the governor sought and forbidding him from unilaterally expanding the health care program for the poor.

title: The Psychic Wounds of Veterans
description: To the Editor:

title: Eric Hill, 86, Dies; Created Spot, a Pup Beloved by Toddlers
description: Eric Hill, an illustrator and writer whose picture books featuring a puppy named Spot enchanted toddlers and sold tens of millions of copies, died on June 6 at his home in Templeton, Calif. He was 86.

title: The Battle Over Dress Codes
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  IN the Bay Area, the last week of school is a time to dig out cozy jackets and socks, but this year our natural air-conditioning (thats fog to you) failed, giving us a few sweltering June days.

title: World Cup 2014: USA Defeats Ghana, 2-1, on John Brooks Goal
description: An early goal by Clint Dempsey and an improbable late score by John Brooks helped the United States stave off Ghana and avoid a third straight World Cup loss to the small African nation.

title: The Fathers Example
description: RECENTLY, my 14-year-old son, Carlos, accompanied me on a trip to give a speech alongside a group of politicians. In the large holding room backstage, the speakers milled about, making small talk before our speeches. Working as my assistant, Carlos handed me a bottle of root beer, which, unbeknown to me, he had been shaking. (Behold the mysteries of the 14-year-old mind.) Upon opening it, I sprayed a copious amount onto a distinguished member of Congress.

title: Bringing Back Europes Bison
description: A German prince is leading an effort to bring back the European bison, Europes largest land mammal, in Bad Berleburg. The animal almost went extinct in the early 20th century.

title: Obama Visits Sioux Lands on a Trip Shadowed by Iraq
description: CANNON BALL, N.D.  Hours after adjourning a tense Oval Office meeting about the Iraq crisis, President Obama found himself on the ancestral lands of Chief Sitting Bull, taking part in a powwow to honor American Indians who have served in Americas foreign wars.

title: New Chairman of Board at N.Y.U. Is Announced
description: New York University has announced a new leader for its board of trustees, one of the largest and most powerful in American academia: William R. Berkley, an insurance industry executive currently serving as a board vice chairman.

title: In Iraq Crisis, a Tangle of Alliances and Enmities
description: The major players in the Iraq and Syria crisis are often both allies and antagonists, working together on one front on one day and at cross-purposes the next.

title: Eyesore and Landmark in One
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Rotting, crumbling, covered in graffiti, overrun by weeds, the hulking wreck of a building known as the Aldeia Maracan would make an unsightly addition to any neighborhood.

title: A Muslim Entrepreneur Follows a Kosher Model to Mainstream Success
