title: At the World Cup, Doomsday Predictions Give Way to Smaller Hiccups in Brazil
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  One stadium would not be ready on time. Another would not be ready at all. Violent street protests would threaten fans and upstage everything. Airport and subway strikes would strand tens of thousands of visitors.

title: Kids Activities, Sonoma Style (New Museum Included)
description: With more than 400 wineries, Sonoma County, Calif., might be known as an oenophile destination, but the region is making a big push to also draw in families with several attractions and events.The Childrens Museum of Sonoma County, for example, opened in March and has an outdoor nature education area thats representative of the local landscape with a redwood grove, a mini version of the Russian River, and wetlands.

title: Wars Hell, Especially for Editors
description: What was meant to be Michael Hastingss first novel, The Last Magazine, is his final and only one. This talented young journalist and war correspondent died last year in a car crash at 33. This book, which hed apparently told few people about, was rescued from his laptop.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Iraq, Cambodia, India and France.

title: Appeals Court Affirms Sherlock Holmes Is in Public Domain
description: A federal judge has rejected a copyright appeal brought by the estate of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, opening the way for writers, filmmakers and other creators to make free use of Sherlock Holmes, his sidekick Watson and any elements of their story that appeared in Conan Doyle works published prior to Jan. 1, 1923.

title: Giants Beason Avoids Surgery, but Status for Opener Is in Doubt
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants middle linebacker Jon Beason will not need surgery to correct the ligament tear and small fracture in his right foot sustained last week in an off-season practice, the team announced Tuesday. But Beasons foot will be immobilized for six weeks, which will precede an additional, undetermined period of recovery. His availability for the season opener Sept. 8 in Detroit remains in doubt.

title: Put Language Aside, Then Let the Music Take Time to Speak
description: Nina Garenetska makes an unlikely rapper. Along with the two other women in the Ukrainian band DakhaBrakha, which performed on Monday night at Brookfield Places Winter Garden, she was wearing a white lace wedding dress, a tall black lamb-fur hat and half a dozen beaded necklaces. Ms. Garenetska was also holding her cello, painted with bright geometric designs.

title: Lawmakers Introduce Bill to Ban Paid Prioritization
description: WASHINGTON  Democratic members of both houses of Congress introduced legislation Tuesday that would ban Internet service providers from charging content companies for faster or more direct connections to Internet service subscribers.

title: Putting Duct Tape to Yet Another Use: Opera
description: The Kitchen in Chelsea is not a big performance space. So when Ariadne Greif, the soprano starring in Opera Cabals production of Georg Friedrich Haass Atthis, came to the front of the stage on Thursday evening, stepped out of her dress and began to tear off the metallic-looking strips of duct tape that girded her naked torso, even the last row of audience members got a close-up of what must be one of the most searingly painful and revealing operatic performances in recent times.

title: Reviews  Murdered: Soul Suspect, Transistor, Among the Sleep
description: MURDERED

title: Extremist Gains in Iraq Confirm Fears in Middle East
description: The recent capture of Iraqi cities by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, the Sunni militant group known as ISIS, has added credence to widespread fears in the Middle East of extremists taking control of Syria and of violence spilling beyond its borders.

title: Walter White, Meet Walter Blanco: Its the Same Story, With a Different Desert
description: A scrubby landscape. A pair of white pants floating through the air. A large vehicle driven by an overexcited man in a pair of tighty whities and a gas mask.

title: Elephant Tusks and Rhino Horns in New York City
description: The stories are horrifying: ruthless criminals slaughtering thousands of African elephants for their ivory tusks and wantonly killing rhinoceroses for their horns. Besides the terrible suffering inflicted on these animals, there is a growing fear that they could soon become extinct. The best way to stop this killing is to stop the market.

title: Tom Ford: Spring 2015 Menswear
description: London

title: Ukraine Suspects Terrorism in Pipeline Explosion
description: MOSCOW  A major natural gas pipeline exploded in central Ukraine on Tuesday, a day after the Russian energy behemoth Gazprom said that it was cutting off supplies to Ukraine in a dispute over pricing, and officials immediately labeled it a possible act of sabotage.

title: PBS Plans to Add a Shorter Version of Sesame Street
description: Viewers of Sesame Street are about to get a big lesson in how to divide in half and multiply by 150 percent.

title: London Mens Fashion Week: Burberry Prorsum Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

title: As Chinas Leader Fights Graft, His Relatives Shed Assets
description: HONG KONG  As President Xi Jinping of China prepares to tackle what may be the biggest cases of official corruption in more than six decades of Communist Party rule, new evidence suggests that he has been pushing his own family to sell hundreds of millions of dollars in investments, reducing his own political vulnerability.

title: Sharing Cultural Jewels via Instagram
description: On a recent spring morning, some 90 minutes before the Metropolitan Museum of Art opened, Dave Krugman, a 26-year-old photo retoucher from Bushwick, Brooklyn, ushered six friends into its cavernous halls through a side door near East 81st Street.

title: Stressed Out
description: My NYRB review of Tim Geithner is up.

title: Mexico Sings Praises of Its Goalie
description: FORTALEZA, Brazil  It is a hard thing to have your voices heard over tens of thousands of people who are screaming at the same time, hoping to drown you out, but that did not stop the fans of Mexico here Tuesday from trying and trying and trying.

title: A Crown Spurs Fashion in Spain
description: The coronation of Crown Prince Felipe de Borbn as the new Spanish king and his wife, Letizia, as queen consort on Thursday is generally being greeted, anti-monarchists aside, as a new start for Spain; a smart move on the part of Felipes father, King Juan Carlos; and the introduction of a new royal fashion icon  this last even though the event itself is billed as an austere affair, without the usual pomp and elaborate gowns a coronation implies.

title: Saving, and Splurging, in Guyana
description: Where I come from, we dont put ice in our Guinness. Or Red Bull. But in the gold-mining frontier town of Bartica, Guyana, I became a (temporary) convert.

title: New Energy Rouses Bostons Downtown Crossing
description: BOSTON  Ever since the postwar demise of the venerable department stores that once distinguished Downtown Crossing as a shopping hub, the central section of this city has struggled to survive as a retail destination.

title: A Gleam of Renewal in Struggling Detroit
description: Corktown, once a desolate strip just west of downtown Detroit, is a serious hotbed of new restaurants, bars, hotels and more, all sitting in the shadow of one of the most glaring icons of Detroits demise, the skeleton of the old train depot, Michigan Central Station. In this ailing city, people look at Corktown as a bright example of what rebuilding can do. The resurgence of Corktown, originally an Irish enclave, began with the 2005 opening of Slows Bar B Q. These days, thanks to low rents and a consumer base hungry for things to do, the area is now a vibrant community of passionate restaurateurs, stylish shopkeepers, meticulous coffee connoisseurs and craft cocktailers.

title: Restaurant Report: Opposite Mess Hall in Bangkok
description: If you spot a Bangkok chef or two dining at Opposite Mess Hall, dont be surprised. With its signature cocktails and small inventive plates inspired by cuisine from all over Asia and beyond, this ingredient-focused restaurant and bar has become a popular post-service spot, a kind of stylish mess hall for those looking for an unpretentious but excellent meal.

title: Fragrance Foundation Awards: Glory and Aromatherapy
description: The fashion editor Carine Roitfeld scanned the lobby at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening. She was there for the annual Fragrance Foundation Awards (formerly nicknamed the FiFi awards), and it was cocktail hour, before the ceremony. Ms. Roitfeld was mostly left to herself.

title: Hotel Review: Mashpi Lodge in Ecuador
description: Rates

title: Despite Protests, Canada Approves Northern Gateway Oil Pipeline
description: OTTAWA  The Canadian governments approval of a major pipeline running from the Alberta oil sands to a new port on the coast of British Columbia has intensified opposition from aboriginal groups, environmentalists and community advocates.

title: She Wasnt Called Sleepless Beauty
description: Dr. Amy Wechsler, a New York dermatologist, recently had a patient walk into her office and point to a wrinkle that had not been there a week before.

title: Ori Allon
description: Mr. Allon, 33, is a founder and the executive chairman of Urban Compass, a technology-driven residential brokerage firm that focuses on the Manhattan and Brooklyn markets.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Makeup for the Sleep-Deprived
description: A full nights sleep may be the ideal way to a bright, refreshed face, but for the many days we are short on shut-eye, there are products to help you fake that slept-for-eight-hours look. Here are four.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: World Cup 2014: Chile Eliminates Defending Champion Spain
description: The defending champion Spain failed in its attempt to win a second successive World Cup after a 2-0 defeat to Chile on Wednesday.

title: World Cup 2014: Netherlands Outlasts Australia, 3-2
description: The Netherlands beat Australia, 3-2, in a back-and-forth game that gave the Dutch an excellent chance of qualifying for the knockout stages, and all but assured that Australia would exit the World Cup after the first round.

title: World Cup 2014: Croatia Defeats Cameroon, 4-0
description: Croatia is still alive and Cameroon is out of the World Cup after a very one-sided encounter in Manaus.

title: Jewish Groups United by Prayers for 3 Missing Youths
description: On the windswept shore of Atlantic Beach, on Long Island, merriment was postponed as a bride and groom said a prayer on Sunday for three teenagers kidnapped late last week in the West Bank.

title: Dont Fight in Iraq and Ignore Syria
description: WASHINGTON  FOR the last two years, many people in the foreign policy community, myself included, have argued repeatedly for the use of force in Syria  to no avail. We have been pilloried as warmongers and targeted, by none other than President Obama, as people who do not understand that force is not the solution to every question. A wiser course, he argued at West Point, is to use force only in defense of Americas vital interests.

title: Assessing Fukushima Damage Without Eyes on the Inside
description: A particle that barely ranks as a footnote in a physics text may be about to lift the cleanup of the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex in Japan over a crucial obstacle.

title: Kampgrounds of America Sets First National TV Campaign
description: THE recreational vehicle industry was riding high in 2006, with the number of motor homes and towable trailers shipped to dealers reaching a 30-year high of 390,500, according to the Recreational Vehicle Industry Association. Then came the blow of the economic downturn and rising gas prices, with units plummeting 58 percent over the next three years, to 165,700 in 2009.

title: Paying for the Forest Fire Next Time
description: WERE just midway through June and have already witnessed major fires in California, Arizona, New Mexico and Alaska. Many of these wildfires have grown in heat, intensity and size in recent years, consuming millions of acres with disastrous consequences and costs. They have become the new reality in the Western United States.

title: Social Security Agency Cuts Services as Demand Grows, Senate Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Social Security Administration is closing field offices and reducing services to the public even as demand for those services surges with the aging of the baby boom generation, according to a bipartisan Senate committee report.

title: Parasites, Killing Their Host
description: You can buy food from farmers  directly, through markets, any way you can find  and I hope you do. But unless youre radically different from most of us, much of what you eat comes from corporations that process, market, deliver and sell food, a majority of which is processed beyond recognition.

title: College Essays: Going All-Out to Get In
For U.S., Win Over Ghana May Be Enough to Advance
description: The United States earned 3 points by winning its World Cup opener against Ghana on Monday night. Ordinarily, the team would expect to need at least another point and maybe more from its last two games to advance.

title: Abuse in Orphanages
description: To the Editor:

title: Benefits of Payroll Cards
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C. Investigating Carringtons Mortgage Deal With New Century
description: On the eve of the financial crisis, the hedge fund manager Bruce M. Rose did a surprising deal that took his firm into the business of collecting mortgage payments from people with tainted credit.

title: Always Iconic, Empire State Building Now Goes for Hip
description: Workers inside the Empire State Building may soon be able to imagine testing their weight-lifting prowess or other muscle-building regimens against the mythical feats of King Kong who once scaled this buildings facade.

title: Food Ads and Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Female Genital Cutting
description: To the Editor:

title: Governors Unite to Fight Heroin in New England
description: WALTHAM, Mass.  Facing a heroin crisis that they say has reached epidemic proportions, the governors of five New England states met here on Tuesday to devise a regional strategy to combat the rise in overdoses and deaths from opioid abuse.

title: Voting Restrictions
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry Widens Into Hyness Spending as Prosecutor
description: Federal prosecutors have joined a state investigation into possible fraud by Charles J. Hynes, the former Brooklyn district attorney, signaling that he could now be facing federal charges with longer prison terms.

title: Argentina Defiant Against Supreme Court on Bond Payments
description: Argentina said on Tuesday that it had started to take steps to circumvent a United States court order to avoid a technical default.

title: F.D.A. Proposes Rules for Listing Risks on Social Media
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday proposed new rules that would require drug and medical device makers to disclose risks, along with benefits, of products on social media platforms, even when the allowable length of messages is very limited as on Twitter. Until now, many medical product makers have refrained from using Facebook and Twitter to talk about their products because they were unsure of the rules or whether the F.D.A. would censure them, said Lori Leskin, a lawyer at Kaye Scholer. The rules would also permit, but not require, companies to correct misleading information posted by third parties about their products.

title: A Rally for Missing Israeli Teenagers
description: The mother of one of three Jewish seminary students kidnapped in the West Bank last week appealed for their return as hundreds rallied outside the Israeli embassy in New York on Monday.

title: Obama Discusses Innovation and Economy
description: The president delivered remarks on how to remain the most innovative economy in the world at TechShop in Pittsburgh.

title: Inside a LED Factory
description: Workers manufacture LEDs at the GuoLi Optoelectronics Technology factory in Foshan, China, contributing to the countrys rapid gains in global market share in the LED industry.

title: As LED Industry Evolves, China Elbows Ahead
description: GUANGZHOU, China  A year ago, Chinas light-emitting diode industry seemed like a case study of industrial policy gone awry. Hundreds of factories built all over eastern China, often with lavish clean energy subsidies from state-owned banks and local governments, were operating at half capacity. The share prices of LED manufacturers were plunging.

title: Julian Koenig, Who Sold Americans on Beetles and Earth Day, Dies at 93
description: Julian Koenig, who is widely regarded as one of the 20th centurys most innovative advertising writers  a creative force behind an array of memorable campaigns, including for the original Volkswagen Beetle and the enduring environmental brand Earth Day  died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Is a Pill Enough to Fight H.I.V.?
The Non-Disappearing Web Reacts to Facebooks Slingshot
description: When Facebook unveiled Pokelast year, aservice that enabled people to send photos, messages and videos with a built-in shelf life,the tech world thought it was trouble for Snapchat, a competing vanishing messaging service.

title: SunTrust Settles With Justice Dept. Over Mortgages; Talks Continue for Citigroup and Bank of America
description: Just as the federal government reached an agreement on Tuesday with SunTrust Banks over questionable mortgage practices, the governments talks to resolve Citigroups mortgage issues grew increasingly tense and veered toward a lawsuit.

title: Arizona Cities Could Face Cutbacks in Water From Colorado River, Officials Say
description: Arizona could be forced to cut water deliveries to its two largest cities unless states that tap the dwindling Colorado River find ways to reduce water consumption and deal with a crippling drought, officials of the states canal network said Tuesday.

title: Forbidden Afghan Couple Are Reunited After Arrests
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Zakia and Mohammad Ali, an Afghan couple who married for love despite death threats from her family and criminal charges by the authorities, were reunited on Tuesday after they were both freed from custody.

title: The Fed Appears to Have Been Wrong About Growth. Again.
description: WASHINGTON  Federal Reserve officials, who have persistently overestimated the strength of the economic recovery, predicted last June that the economy in 2014 would finally grow more than 3 percent for the first time since the recession.

title: 11 Years Old, in the Open, and Carefree
description: PINEHURST, N.C.  Hannah Pietilas father was walking the fairways on Monday with his daughter during her first practice round at Pinehurst No. 2. He was supposed to be marking off yardage in anticipation of his caddying duties for the 69th United States Womens Open, which will get underway on Thursday.

title: Daniel Keyes, Author of Flowers for Algernon, Dies at 86
description: Daniel Keyes, the author of Flowers for Algernon, the story of a man with an I.Q. of 68 who temporarily becomes a genius after surgery  a book that inspired the film Charly, starring Cliff Robertson  died on Sunday at his home in South Florida. He was 86.

title: In G.M. Hearing, Lawmakers May Focus on Contradictions
description: Mary T. Barra, chief executive of General Motors, is expected to tell a House panel on Wednesday that the auto giant is determined to change its culture and prevent another safety crisis similar to its deadly delay in recalling millions of small cars with a defective switch.

title: Nature, Opaque and Mysterious, in All Its Seasons
description: Four of the five sections of From a Fireflys Eye, a suite of dances presented by Zendora Dance Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Fishman Space over the weekend, took their titles from the seasons. But the show was no pastoral, no pretty nature calendar, and the music was definitely not Vivaldi.

title: Citys Love Affair With the Summer Sprinkler Bursts Forth
description: Just after 2 p.m. Tuesday, with the temperature bursting 90 degrees, Sariya Rodriguez, age 20 months, stepped into the sprinkler section of Printers Park in the Longwood section of the Bronx. The water jets  set in the ground in a circle  were resting at the moment, but there were ample puddles for her to stamp with her pink plastic sandals. Suddenly, the water sprung from the jets. Sariya, who had never been in that part of the playground before, now was encircled with dancing streams of water. Her eyes and mouth opened in surprise. She looked up at her mother, Yajaira Rodriguez. Then they both laughed.

title: U.S. on Protecting Pacific Ocean Areas
description: President Obama, Secretary of State John Kerry and the actor Leonardo DiCaprio expressed their support in protecting areas of the Pacific Ocean from overfishing and environmental damage.

title: With Altidore in Doubt, Americans Look to Portugal
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  As Jozy Altidore was lifted onto a stretcher just 20 minutes into Monday nights victory over Ghana in Natal, Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States national team, leaned over and cradled his strikers head in his hands.

title: Yahoo Reveals Work Force Data, Joining Techs Small Diversity Parade
description: Defining the scope of a problem is the first step toward solving it.

title: Schools Chief Vows to Preserve Number of Gifted Programs and Their Exams
description: Schools Chancellor Carmen Faria plans to preserve the hallmarks of New York Citys gifted programs, the immensely popular classes and schools that draw high achievers but have been criticized as shutting out low-income children.

title: Mr. Obamas Ocean Monument
description: They are seven sand-and-coral dots in the middle of the Pacific Ocean, far west and south of Hawaii. They are known best, if they are known at all, for guano mining in the 19th century and nuclear tests in the 20th.

title: In Mississippi, Largess Helped a Senator, Until It Hurt Him
description: HERNANDO, Miss.  Senator Thad Cochrans critics may disparage him as the King of Pork. But to the local politicians in the booming suburbs here in northwest Mississippi, just south of Memphis, it is good to be in the realm of the king.

title: Accused of Unheroic Acts, a Spider-Man Claims Self-Defense
description: By Times Square standards, the act was nothing extraordinary: A man in a Spider-Man costume was accused of throwing a punch at the mother of two young children after an ugly argument over a tip.

title: Soccer Fans Dream Job Has a Catch: No Peeking
description: FORTALEZA, Brazil  At first blush, it probably sounded like the best job in Brazil.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 17, 2014
A Balancing Act on Iraq
description: President Obama has, so far, struck the right note on Iraq, where Sunni extremist militants are seizing territory and threatening the existence of the state. He has been cautious  emphasizing the need for political reform in Iraq and reaching out to other countries that could have an impact on its fate.

title: Lawmakers Skeptical on Emails and I.R.S.
description: WASHINGTON  Six additional Internal Revenue Service workers lost emails sought by congressional investigators when their computers crashed, investigators announced Tuesday, escalating Republican suspicions that the employees may have been trying to cover up political targeting of Tea Party organizations.

title: Bill to Reduce Speed Limit to 25 M.P.H. Gains Favor
description: A proposal to lower the New York City speed limit to 25 miles per hour cleared a critical hurdle on Tuesday, as a bill in the State Senate won the support of the de Blasio administration and some, though not all, traffic safety advocates.

title: The Limits of the Fed
description: The Federal Reserve is expected to conclude its two-day meeting on Wednesday afternoon with another $10 billion scale-back of its monthly bond purchases. At that pace, the bond-buying program  an effort to stimulate the economy by lowering long-term interest rates  will be over by December at the latest.

title: Following in a Writers Rhythms
description: In Everybodys Autobiography, Gertrude Stein explained why she preferred saints to martyrs. A really good saint does nothing, she wrote. Anybody is more interesting doing nothing than doing something.

title: A Womans Place at a Pivotal Moment
description: The year is 1972, and a new age of feminism is dawning as women grope to find voices to match their evolving identities. Well, some of them are groping. The female characters in When We Were Young and Unafraid, Sarah Treems debate-driven new play at City Center Stage 1, appear to have little difficulty articulating their viewpoints or making sure that we know exactly where to place them on a shifting scale of political consciousness.

title: What Youd Need To Play
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  In 1938, an architect named Alfred Mosher Butts created a word game that evolved from an earlier one he called Lexiko. The new game, which criss-crossed letter tiles to form words, used a distribution and points system that he developed after doing a letter-frequency analysis of various sources, including The New York Times.

title: Talks on Medical Marijuana Bill as Time Starts to Run Out in Albany
description: ALBANY  For a drug known for tranquillity, marijuana has become a very tense issue here.

title: Woman Sentenced to 41 Months for Fake Water Park Plan
description: An Orange County, N.Y., woman who duped investors out of more than $1 million through a fictional proposal to build a water park for foster children was sentenced on Tuesday to 41 months in prison.

title: What to Do With the Twins?
description: There is much talk right now about America teaming up with Iran to push back the coalition of Sunni militias that has taken over Mosul and other Sunni towns in western Iraq and Syria. For now, Id say stay out of this fight  not because its the best option, but because its the least bad.

title: With War at Doorstep, Iran Sees Its Revolutionary Guards in a Kinder Light
description: TEHRAN  They came to celebrate the short life of Ali Reza Moshajjari, a local boy from a south Tehran neighborhood and apparently the latest Iranian victim of the escalating sectarian conflict in neighboring Iraq and in Syria.

title: Stamp Sells for a Record $9.5 Million
description: A tiny square of very old red paper with cut corners  a one-cent postage stamp from the 19th century  sold for $9.5 million on Tuesday, the most ever paid for a stamp at auction, but $500,000 short of the auction houses $10 million to $20 million presale estimate.

title: Obama Is Said to Consider Selective Airstrikes on Sunni Militants
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is considering a targeted, highly selective campaign of airstrikes against Sunni militants in Iraq similar to counterterrorism operations in Yemen, rather than the widespread bombardment of an air war, a senior administration official said on Tuesday.

title: Obama on Captured Benghazi Suspect
description: President Obama said that Ahmed Abu Khattala, suspected of being the ringleader in the 2012 attack on the U.S. diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, was being transported to the United States.

title: Aftermath of Sadr City Bombing
description: A car bomb was detonated at a crowded outdoor market in the Shiite district of Sadr City in eastern Baghdad.

title: U.S. Suggests Getting Tougher With Syria on Chemical Weapons Deadline
description: The United States suggested on Tuesday that the global organization responsible for overseeing the ban on chemical weapons would have to take more assertive action than a simple condemnation concerning Syria, which will miss a June 30 deadline for the destruction of its chemical munitions and has been accused of using chlorine-gas bombs in its civil war.

title: Tanakas Bold Brushstrokes Paint Blue Jays Into Corner
description: Masahiro Tanakas latest gem, on Tuesday against the Toronto Blue Jays, materialized a little differently from most of his other performances. It seemed to develop slowly, like a mosaic. It was not until the later innings that the full form of his mastery took shape.

title: Cutting the Poor Out of Welfare
description: Over the past three decades, Congress has conducted a major experiment in anti-poverty policy. Legislators have restructured benefits and tax breaks intended for the poor so that they penalize unmarried, unemployed parents  the modern-day version of the undeserving poor. At the same time, working parents, the aged and the disabled are getting larger benefits.

title: Bringing Turkish Flavors to Boston
description: Ana Sortun built a restaurant group inspired by the subtleties of Eastern Mediterranean cuisine.

title: Lawyer Not Entitled to See Classified Surveillance Material, Court Rules
description: WASHINGTON  Reversing a potentially groundbreaking ruling, a federal appeals court this week said the government need not show a defense lawyer classified materials related to the national-security surveillance of his client.

title: Obama, in a First, Attends a Super PAC Fund-Raiser
description: President Obama once criticized the flow of money to political action committees, calling it a threat to democracy.

title: U.S. Defends Prosecuting Benghazi Suspect in Civilian Rather Than Military Court
description: WASHINGTON  Conservative lawmakers on Tuesday sharply criticized the Obama administrations decision to prosecute the suspected leader of the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya, in the civilian criminal justice system, arguing that he should be questioned and tried by the military.

title: Fargo Finale Recap: Mortons Fork: Theyve Come Undone
description: In the criminal wilderness, invading Fargo, people align themselves with good or evil, as protector or predator. Few fall in between.

title: Sudan: Attack Ravages Hospital
description: A hospital run by the humanitarian group Doctors Without Borders was heavily damaged by the Sudanese Air Force in an attack on the village of Farandalla in the South Kordofan region, the group said Tuesday. The groups head of mission, Brian Moller, expressed shock, especially since it was clearly identified with a flag and a cross on the roof. One hospital staff member was hurt, as were five villagers, the group said. Rebels in the region have been fighting the government in Khartoum since 2011. In recent weeks, the Sudanese government has stepped up its offensive in the region. The Sudanese Armys press officer could not be reached for comment.

title: Exercise and the Good Bugs in Our Gut
description: Being physically active may encourage beneficial germs to thrive in your gut, while inactivity could do the reverse, according to an innovative new study. The findings suggest that, in addition to its other health benefits, frequent exercise may influence our weight and overall health by altering the kinds of organisms that live inside of us.

title: Word of the Day | penury
description: penury \pen-y-re\ noun

title: Brazil: Biden and Rousseff Meet
description: President Dilma Rousseff met Tuesday with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. as Brazil and the United States moved to improve relations. Ties were strained last year by revelations of surveillance of Ms. Rousseff and other Brazilian officials by the National Security Agency. Mr. Biden told reporters in Braslia that their conversation about the spying was candid, while emphasizing the potential for improving ties. He also handed over to Ms. Rousseff declassified documents related to Brazils military dictatorship, which seized power in a 1964 coup supported by the United States. Ms. Rousseff is a former Marxist guerrilla who was tortured by agents of the dictatorship. She said this month in aninterview that she was prepared for a thaw in ties with Washington.

title: Canada: Carbon Monoxide Affects Scores at Day Care
description: About 70 children and 10 adults were overcome by carbon monoxide at a day care northwest of Montreal on Tuesday and were rushed to the hospital by ambulances and school buses. Health and fire officials said at a news conference that no one had lost consciousness during the episode in St.-Eustache, Quebec. But the five children with the most severe symptoms were transferred to a larger hospital for further examination. The source of the gas was unclear, but fire officials are investigating the cleaning machinery used in the day care center the previous night.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 18, 2014
description: There really isnt much better dietary advice than eating your veggies, exercising and limiting calories. People just seem to like making eating difficult for themselves.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 3:05 P.M. (Cinemax) SAVAGES (2012) Two Southern California marijuana dealers  Chon (Taylor Kitsch), a cynical combat veteran, and Ben (Aaron Johnson, above right, with Mr. Kitsch and Blake Lively), a soulful Berkeley graduate  and their gorgeous significant other, O (Ms. Lively), take on Mexican traffickers in what A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called Oliver Stones feverish, fully baked, half-great adaptation of Don Winslows ferocious and funny drug-war novel of the same name. The film, he added, is a daylight noir, a western, a stoner buddy movie and a love story, which is to say that it is a bit of a mess. But also a lot of fun, especially as its pulp elements rub up against some gritty geopolitical and economic themes.

title: N.C.A.A. Begins Its Turn in Antitrust Case Brought by Athletes
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Christine Plonsky, the director of womens athletics at the University of Texas, took the standTuesday morning in federal court here in an effort to persuade a judge that the N.C.A.A. and its biggest athletics programs are not the commercialized profit centers they have been accused of being by a string of witnesses during the past week and a half.

title: Georgia Inmate Is Put to Death in First U.S. Execution Since Botched Procedure
description: JACKSON, Ga.  Marcus A. Wellons, who was convicted in the 1989 rape and murder of a teenage girl, was executed at a Georgia prison on Tuesday, becoming the first inmate put to death in the United States since a botched execution in Oklahoma seven weeks ago prompted renewed questions about capital punishment.

title: Mets, Stifled by Cardinals, Waste Solid Start by Niese
description: ST. LOUIS  The way he pitches, Jon Niese is often overlooked. He is not imposing. He does not throw particularly hard. His strikeout rate is not high. And pitching for the Mets, because of their low-octane offense, he is often deprived of wins.

title: Citics Missing Alumina Prompts Concern Over China Commodities Fraud
description: HONG KONG  Citic Resources, a Chinese state-owned commodities trader, said on Wednesday that it had been unable to locate more than 100,000 tons of alumina at a port in northeast China that is the focus of a commodities fraud investigation.

title: Corrections: June 18, 2014
description: NEW YORK

title: Rebels Reject Ukrainian Leaders Cease-Fire Idea
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  After Ukraines new president, Petro O. Poroshenko, told reporters in Kiev on Wednesday that he might soon order a temporary, unilateral cease-fire as part of a broader 14-point peace plan, it took all of several seconds for pro-Russian militants to rule it out.

title: Malaysia Searches for Survivors After Boat Sinks
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Five people died when an overloaded wooden passenger ship carrying 97 Indonesians back to their home country sank off the west coast of Malaysia early Wednesday, Malaysian officials said, and search-and-rescue teams were working into the night looking for 32 others who remained missing.

title: Student Crossword | Meteorology
description: Test your knowledge of meteorology by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: 6 Qs About the News | U.S. Says It Captured Top Suspect in Benghazi Attack
description: In U.S. Captures Top Suspect in Benghazi Siege, Pentagon Says, David D. Kirkpatrick and Eric Schmitt report on the capture of a suspect in the 2012 attack on the United States mission in Benghazi, Libya.

title: Asset Transparency Advocates to Be Sentenced
description: Updated, 9:30 a.m. |

title: 1939: Frances Last Public Guillotining
description: Weidmann Goes to Guillotine With Firm Step But Eyes Shut

title: Betrayal in Charlie Rangels Harlem?
description: St. Johns Baptist Church, in the Sugar Hill section of Harlem, is a modest redbrick building, discernible from the buildings on its block by two white Corinthian columns and a large, illuminated plastic cross hanging from the second story. Back in the civil rights era, the church housed a thriving congregation, many of them African-Americans who had fled the South. Its rolls have since dwindled to about 250, but Harlem is a neighborhood eternally preoccupied with its past, and St. Johns remains a place where local power brokers  and former power brokers and aspiring ones, too  gather to debate issues and anoint leaders.

title: Taking Care of People and Pictures in Hong Kong
description: A stream of images from Hong Kong caught Rick Rocamoras attention on Facebook: black and white street scenes, with dramatic light and compositions that ranged from kinetic to serene. The fact that the photographer, Xyza Cruz Bacani, was from the Philippines  like Mr. Rocamora  intrigued him, though he was reluctant to contact her.

title: British Property Website Zoopla Valued at $1.5 Billion in I.P.O.
description: LONDON  Zoopla Property Group, a British real estate listings website, was valued at more than $1.5 billion in its initial public offering in London on Wednesday.

title: Setting Sour Words Aside, Li Keqiang Begins Visit to Britain
description: After an exchange of unflattering comments between the Chinese and British sides threatened to overshadow Prime Minister Li Keqiangs trip to Britain, sunny skies greeted him on Tuesday, the first full day of his visit. Following a meeting with Queen Elizabeth II in the morning, the second-ranking Chinese leader met with Prime Minister David Cameron at 10 Downing Street for talks and lunch with business leaders.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: New York Today: A Scorcher, for Real
description: A sticky Wednesday morning to you.

title: Dutch Coach Keeps Expectations in Check
description: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil  The excellent news for Louis van Gaal is that the Netherlands beat Spain, 5-1.The bad news for Louis van Gaal is that the Netherlands beat Spain, 5-1.

title: Japan Outlaws Possession of Child Pornography, but Comic Book Depictions Survive
description: TOKYO  Yielding to years of pressure to fall in line with the rest of the developed world, Japans Parliament outlawed the possession of child pornography on Wednesday. But the new law left untouched the nations popular and sometimes sexually explicit manga comics as well as other portrayals of young girls as objects of sexual desire.

title: Insurgency in Iraq Widens Rivals Rift
description: Tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia, Islamic rivals of the Middle East, appeared to escalate on Wednesday over the Sunni extremist insurgency convulsing Iraq, as President Hassan Rouhani of Iran declared readiness to defend Iraqs Shiite holy sites with force and Saudi leaders issued a barely veiled admonishment not to intervene.

title: Daily Report: AT&T and Udacity Create Online NanoDegree Program
description: This week, AT&T and Udacity, an online education company founded by the Stanford professor and former Google engineering whiz Sebastian Thrun, announced something meant to be very small, Eduardo Porter reports: the NanoDegree.

title: Morning Views
description: The New York Times welcomes the news that President Obama will double the area of protected waters in the Pacific Ocean. The United States does not have an Amazon basin, the editorial board writes, but it has the watery equivalent, a paradise of turtles and sharks, seals and dolphins, coral reefs and giant clams, frigate birds and boobies. Mr. Obama is expanding on the legacy of his predecessor, George W. Bush  a fact The Times finds heartening: Environmental conservation has a long bipartisan history in this country. These remote waters are a part of America most citizens may never see, but they should be thankful that presidents, of both parties, had the foresight to protect them.

title: Extremists Attack Iraqs Biggest Oil Refinery
description: BAGHDAD  Refinery workers, witnesses and an Iraqi Army officer reported the seizure of Iraqs biggest oil refinery by Sunni extremists on Wednesday after army helicopter gunships failed to repel their attack. But other Iraqi officials, including the commander of the garrison defending the refinery in Baiji, asserted that fighting was still going on inside the extensive facility, shut down by the violence.

title: Ackmans S.E.C. Filing on Bid for Botox Maker Allergan Contains an Error
description: William A. Ackman has made billions on a reputation for being the smartest guy in the room. Sometimes, it turns out, even the smartest guy can be wrong.

title: What Makes a Great Editor? Part 2.
description: Only Southerners have taken horsewhips and pistols to editors about the treatment or maltreatment of their manuscript. This  the actual pistols  was in the old days, of course, we no longer succumb to the impulse. But it is still there, still within us.

title: Women Who Belong in the Kitchen: Ana Sortun
description: This is part 2 of a two-part series on entrepreneurial female chefs. Last week, we spoke with Jody Adams.

title: G.A.O. Tech Chief Says Washington Should Start Small on Big Projects
description: When it comes to technology, Washington needs to learn how to fail smaller.

title: Push Polls, Defined
description: Push polls  which are not really polls at all  are often criticized as a particularly sleazy form of negative political campaigning. Voters pick up the phone to hear what sounds like a research poll. But there is no effort to collect information, which is what a legitimate poll does.

title: U.N. Report Details Casualties in Eastern Ukraine
description: GENEVA  Hundreds of people have been killed and thousands have fled their homes amid rising violence, insecurity and crime in areas of eastern Ukraine that are under the control of pro-Russia armed groups, the United Nations said on Wednesday.

title: Bain Capital Ventures Raises $935 Million to Back Growth Firms
description: In a sign of continued investor enthusiasm for venture capital deals, Bain Capital Ventures has raised $935 million to back young companies, according to a person briefed on the matter.

title: Wrestling With Heartache in a Birthplace of Soul
description: At this point, the Apollo Theater exists largely in totemic form, a repository of credibility available for loan to those seeking to cloak themselves in its legacy, whether out of homage or insecurity. Its meaning is fungible, whatever its occupant for the night needs it to be.

title: Morning Agenda: SunTrust in Mortgage Settlement
description: The Federal government reached a $968 million settlement on Tuesday with SunTrust Banks over questionable mortgage practices, underscoring how state and federal authorities have been targeting banks beyond Wall Street, Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. But even as the government reached one settlement, its talks to resolve mortgage issues with one of the nations largest banks, Citigroup, grew increasingly tense and veered toward a lawsuit.

title: PEN Announces Shortlists for 2014 Book Prizes
description: The PEN American Center today announced the shortlists of finalists for its 2014 PEN Literary Awards. Taken together, the awards, fellowships and grants from the literary and human rights organization total nearly $150,000 for writers, editors and translators.

title: The Hillary Clinton-Fashion Love Affair Continues
description: If anyone is wondering which potential presidential candidate the fashion world may support in 2016, I think the question is fast being put to rest.

title: Manhattan Spring Colors
description: Dear Diary:

title: Palestinian Leader Pledges to Hold Abductors of Israeli Teenagers to Account
description: JERUSALEM  President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on Wednesday strongly denounced the kidnappers of three Israeli teenagers who went missing in the West Bank six days ago and said he would hold the perpetrators accountable.

title: Soft Moneys Squishy Political Influence
description: To congressional campaign workers, the groups that can raise and spend unlimited donations can seem like unpredictable wedding guests: You dont know when theyll show up, what theyll bring or whether their presence will prove a welcome distraction or a disaster.

title: Seen on the Street | Outside the Spring/Summer 2015 London Mens Shows
description: A peek at what some of the peacocks in London were wearing.

title: Whats News in Washington: Situation in Iraq Worsening
description: GoodWednesdaymorning from Washington.

title: Obama and Lawmakers Meet to Discuss Iraq Action
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and congressional leaders on Wednesday privately confronted the politically delicate question of whether Mr. Obama would be required to ask Congress for permission to take military action against Sunni fighters in Iraq, but emerged from an hourlong Oval Office meeting with different views of what was said.

title: Europe May Be in a Recession (Still)
description: Is the European economy expanding, or is it in recession? Turns out, even the people whose job it is to decide arent sure. And their reasoning shows why the economic situation seems so perilous in Europe, even though its economy isnt clearly shrinking. In fact, part of their hesitation to call the end of the recession stems from their fear that policy makers may not be sufficiently concerned about the state of the economy.

title: Its So Immersive, You Even Get Wet
description: Theater doesnt really have an equivalent of the summer blockbuster. If anything, the home of the biggest, showiest spectacles  Broadway  is usually quiet during the hot months, with few new openings. But if youre looking for high-energy fun and empty-headed action accessible to anyone, head to Union Square, where the high-flying acrobats from Fuerza Bruta: Wayra will splash around in giant pools over your head. From the makers of De la Guarda, this show, which opens at the Daryl Roth Theater on Friday, is an expanded version of a production that ran in New York from 2007 until January, with 20 new minutes added.

title: Boston Bombing Suspect Seeking Change of Trial Venue
description: BOSTON  Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, accused in last years marathon bombings, said Wednesday that their client could not receive a fair trial in Boston or elsewhere in the state, and asked for the trial to be moved to Washington.

title: Spains Incoming King Takes Over a Throne Heavy With Political Tension
description: MADRID  This year, while visiting a telecom conference in Barcelona, Crown Prince Felipe worked the room as the heir apparent to the Spanish throne, smiling and glad-handing the crowd, until he ran into a Catalan businessman who refused to shake his hand because of the Spanish monarchys opposition to a planned independence referendum in Catalonia this fall.

title: In the Euro Zone, Recession Is Not Quite Over, Economists Say
description: FRANKFURT  Many people probably thought the euro zone recession ended about a year ago when output began growing again. Not so, a group of leading economists argued this week.

title: The Democrats United?
description: Voxs Matthew Yglesias, seconded by my colleague Paul Krugman, has writtena seven-point response to my argument that the Democratic coalition is more fragile, and more dependent on Hillary Clintons unique strengths, than many people (mostly liberals) tend to think. Yglesiass rebuttal focuses on the Democratic Partys apparent lack of deep policy divisions, which he regards as the main reason why theres so little opposition to Clinton at the moment. It is impossible, he writes, to mount a coherent anti-Clinton campaign because there is no issue that divides the mass of Democrats. Theres no equivalent of the intra-Democrat war over the Iraq War that gave us Dean v. Kerry and than Obama v. Clinton; the neoliberal/populist debate over Wall Street is muddled and complicated; theres unanimity on the need to tackle inequality; the education reform debate is real but doesnt matter enough at the federal level to shape presidential politics; and the partys demographic diversity coexists with increasing ideological conformity. Then as his parting point, he notes that polarization and partisan rancor make it hard to imagine either political coalition truly dissolving any time soon: The collapses of the past, where one partys candidate gets utterly blown away  simply cant happen under modern conditions.

title: Pro-Democracy Media Companys Websites Attacked
description: Next Media, which publishes Apple Daily, an independent Hong Kong newspaper often critical of the Chinese government, saw the largest attack ever against the companys websites on Wednesday, taking the groups websites offline for hours.

title: Whats on Your New York City Reverse Bucket List?
description: Future comments on this post have been closed. We have published a selection of our favorite reverse bucket list items from readers here.

title: A Darker View of the Age of Us  the Anthropocene
description: I alerted a batch of scholars and scientists focused on climate change and sustainable development to my taped talk on Paths to a Good Anthropocene at the annual meeting of the Association for Environmental Studies and Sciences.

title: Barra Faces Scrutiny in House Over G.M. Recalls
description: WASHINGTON  Mary T. Barra, chief executive of General Motors, walked into a crowded House hearing on Wednesday with her high-powered lawyer at her side, confident that his exhaustive internal investigation about a deadly defect would convince lawmakers that G.M. is taking safety seriously.

title: Just How Were Those Underwater Babies Photographed?
description: What better way to welcome summers arrival than with pictures of happy babies underwater? The June 15 Look features children from 4 months to 22 months during infant survival swim training in Kissimmee, Fla. They were photographed by Seth Casteel, who specializes in animal photography and is publishing a book called Underwater Puppies in September. Here, Casteel talks about what babies and dogs have in common when theyre all wet.

title: Valeant Takes New Step to Pressure Botox Maker Into Sale
description: Updated, 12:07 p.m. |

title: A Glimpse of Syrian Lives Ravaged by War in Homs
description: Anne Barnard, the Beirut bureau chief for The New York Times, traveled to Syria recently and reported her experiences in Damascus and Homs via Twitter. Her social media dispatches provided a rare view into the dire circumstances in Syria where the three-year conflict has killed an estimated 160,000 Syrians and left millions displaced. And she shared some poignant reactions to the devastation there.

title: Right Out of Hollywood, a Witness to History
description: In the summer of 1964, Richard Beymer  the actor who a few years earlier had made a splash playing Tony in the film of West Side Story  furiously drove his Austin-Healy from Los Angeles to rural Mississippi. He was going to join the hundreds of young people heading there, mostly white students from the North, who would become part of the audacious civil-rights campaign known as Freedom Summer.

title: St. George, S.I.: Framed by the Harbor
description: In praise of St. George, a historic neighborhood on Staten Island that gazes on New York Harbor, residents invariably mention the free ferry to Manhattan. They often cite the affordability of a place where one-bedroom apartments can cost less than half of what they go for in pricier parts of the city. And they might even point out the wondrously out-of-place look of some blocks, with fanciful Victorians on steep hills that can feel cut-and-pasted from San Francisco.

title: Jay Leno to Receive Mark Twain Prize for Humor
description: Have you heard about this? Have you seen this? Jay Leno, the doggedly populist comedy monologist and former host of the Tonight show, will be the next recipient of the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, the prizes organizers said Wednesday.

title: Daring Deeds
description: In Nick Bertozzis graphic novel Shackleton, the great man who between 1901 and 1921 embarked on four attempts to reach the South Pole is first depicted in a moment of total failure. So sick with scurvy that he can scarcely lift his head from his pillow  let alone pull a loaded sledge  Shackleton is ordered back to England, forced to abandon Robert Falcon Scotts Discovery expedition. But he is determined to return to the Antarctic, despite his wifes entreaties (The children are growing so quickly!) and the claims of common sense. Though its easy to miss in Bertozzis telling, Shackleton went back about 5 years later, leading the Nimrod expedition, which came within 97 miles of reaching the South Pole. He managed to secure funding for a third attempt in August 1914, on the eve of the First World War. It is this famed adventure that is the focus of Shackleton.

title: Charges Against Simon and Brickell Are Dropped
description: The disorderly conduct charges that were brought against Paul Simon and Edie Brickell after a domestic dispute in late April were dropped by prosecutors in a Norwalk, Conn., courtroom on Tuesday. Mr. Simon and Ms. Brickell, who had made a court appearance when the charges were brought, did not appear to hear them dismissed, The Associated Press reported.

title: HelloFresh, a Meal Delivery Start-Up, Raises $50 Million
description: The race for dominance in the dinner-kit delivery business  where companies ship out packages of fresh ingredients for specific recipes, ready for customers to turn into home-cooked meals  is intensifying.

title: Latinos Onscreen, Conspicuously Few
description: If you went to the movies in 1946, when Latinos constituted barely 3 percent of the American population, you might have caught Carmen Miranda, reportedly the highest-paid woman in the world at the time, dancing with her improbably tall fruit hat. By the 1950s, Desi Arnaz graced network TV as a star of I Love Lucy.

title: Redskins Lose Ruling on Trademarks, but Fight Isnt Over
description: For years, the N.F.L. and the Washington Redskins have defended the teams name by claiming that it is a sign of honor and bravery, not a slur. When critics disagreed, the team pointed to a survey showing that a majority of Native Americans supported the name.

title: Cherries Go Savory, Sweet and Boozy
description: They can be in every part of a meal, including a cocktail.

title: Australia vs. Netherlands: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: The Netherlands is virtually assured to make the knockout stage, although that would change should Australia somehow pull off a shocker here. For the Socceroos, a point in any of their matches would be a triumph.

description: 1939: Million-Ton Rocket Needed

title: WETA to Take Ownership of PBS NewsHour
description: WETA, the Washington, D.C., public broadcaster, is expected to take over ownership and control of PBS NewsHour on July 1 from the programs longtime owner, MacNeil/Lehrer Productions, the station announced Wednesday. Approval for the transfer came late Tuesday at a meeting of the WETA board of trustees.

title: U.S. Opens Safety Review of Chryslers
description: Concern over the safety of ignition switches is spreading beyond General Motors cars.

title: Wheelies: The Black Plate Special Edition
description: California has received the 7,500 preorders required to begin reproducing its classic yellow-on-black license, says a report from Hemmings Daily. The plates, which were originally issued from 1963-69, will be made with a reflective finish that complies with state laws. The plates will be available in nine to 12 months. (Hemmings Daily)

title: A Conversation With Health Minister Harsh Vardhan
description: Dr. Harsh Vardhan was sworn in as the new union minister of health on May 26, taking over a ministry with substantial challenges.

title: Character Study: Corey Kilgannon
description: Corey Kilgannon writes the Character Study column weekly for the Metropolitan section. In a video shot by two journalism students, Mr. Kilgannon becomes the subject of their character study.

title: What You Get for ... $1,300,000
description: WASHINGTON, D.C.

title: How to Build a Better Neighborhood
description: A great public place gives residents of a neighborhood a sense of belonging, pride, connection and beauty. But too many neighborhoods have no such place. Some have been destroyed by recession, with shuttered businesses and boarded-up buildings. Others are simply soulless, built for cars, not people, featuring strip malls that require driving instead of places for residents to walk, bike, play or gather.

title: A Retailer and Vintner Recalls Her Bohemian Hamptons Upbringing
description: Joey Wlffer, 32, the founder of the mobile shopping truckthe Styleliner and co-owner of Wlffer Estate Vineyard, recalls the Hamptons of her childhood as a very different place: miles and miles of potato fields and a low-key vibe inspired by artists, poets and writers.

title: Is This the Beginning of the End of the Redskins Team Name?
description: We can only guess the exact volume and color of the steam coming out of Daniel Snyders ears right about now. Wednesday morning, the United States Patent and Trademark Office canceled the trademark for the Washington Redskins, the pro football team that Mr. Snyder owns  and that he has steadfastly refused to rename, amid accusations that its mascot is racist.

title: Candidates Protest Clouds Afghan Vote-Counting for President
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans presidential election was cast into crisis on Wednesday as the candidate Abdullah Abdullah announced a boycott of the electoral process, accusing his opponent and President Hamid Karzai of engineering huge fraud in the runoff vote on Saturday.

title: A Retiree, 89, Is Held in Deaths at Auschwitz
description: WASHINGTON  The 89-year-old Johann Breyer shuffled unsteadily into a federal courtroom in Philadelphia on Wednesday morning, using a cane for support as he sank slowly into a chair at the defense table.

title: The ISIS Advance Provokes the West and Arab States
description: As the Islamic State of Syria and Iraq, or ISIS, advances in Iraq, many eyes are trained on Washington and on the governments of Mesopotamia. Two questions are being hotly debated: First, will the United States take military action to prop up a fragile government it left in place after a decade of battle and more than 4,000 casualties? And, at a higher level, what does ISISs rise say about the prospects of an effective governance ever being established in the region?

title: House Hunting in ... Sweden
description: A MODERN FOUR-BEDROOM WATERFRONT VILLA OUTSIDE STOCKHOLM

title: Police Bullying on Tape
description: Because I want you to go away and not stand here and argue with me. Otherwise youre about to get locked up.

title: Ask Martha Rose Shulman
description: Have a question for Martha? With the Ruder family traveling next week, shell be taking questions from readers instead. Have a vegetable you dont know what to do with? A recipe that never works? Tired of your go-to spinach? Ask Martha here, and look for answers to the most common or interesting dilemmas next Wednesday, June 25.

title: Detroit Rolls Out New Model: A Hybrid Pension Plan
description: In the face of Detroits tumultuous bankruptcy proceedings, in which multiple parties are quarreling to protect their interests, the city and its unions have quietly negotiated a scaled-back pension plan that could serve as a model for other troubled governments.

title: Arguing About the Truth of Disruption
description: Most big ideas have loud critics, writes Jill Lepore in The New Yorker. Not disruption.

title: Abdullah Halts Work on Afghan Vote Count
description: Abdullah Abdullah, a candidate for Afghanistans presidency, said he suspended work with the countrys electoral bodies and asked officials to stop counting votes because of widespread fraud.

title: A Gilded Monument Is Mysteriously Shedding Its Brand-New Gold
description: Crazing. You know what it is if youve ever looked at your grandparents chinaware and discerned a web of hairline cracks fracturing the glaze.

title: App Smart | Going Green
description: Kit Eaton reviews three apps that can help you adopt environmentally sensible habits in your daily life.

title: For Ideas on How to Live Greener, Think Mobile
description: SMARTPHONES and tablets may not seem to be designed with the environment in mind, being made of complex layers of plastics, metals and electronics, with chemical batteries. But apps may help you adopt environmentally sensible habits in your daily life.

title: BBC Anchor Who Delighted in Blistering Politicians Steps Down
description: LONDON  Famed for his combative questions, disdainful delivery and lack of deference, Jeremy Paxman, one of Britains best-known broadcasters, on Wednesday made his last appearance on the TV program he has dominated for a quarter of a century.

title: MoMA to Host Bjork Retrospective Next Year
description: The Museum of Modern Art will present what it is calling a full-scale retrospective of the Icelandic rock composer, singer and otherworldly fashion-plate Bjork next year. The exhibition, which the museum announced on Wednesday, is beingorganized by Klaus Biesenbach, the museums chief curator at large. The retrospective will run from March 7 to June 7, 2015.

title: France Sees Double Standard in U.S. Prosecution of BNP, but Justice Is Weak
description: Events in the Middle East and Ukraine demonstrate that the United States cant always be the worlds policeman. But there is one arena where it is still the top cop on the block: corporate law enforcement.

title: Amid the Tombstones, a Look Back at Life
description: Given Thornton Wilders specification that Our Town be presented in minimalist fashion, you wonder what he would have made of Brooklyns majestic Green-Wood Cemetery as a theatrical setting. There is no curtain, of course, in this presentation by the Green-Wood Historic Fund of Wilders drama, only the wind rushing through the tall trees and the jets streaking overhead and the glittering spires of Manhattan in the distance. It doesnt get more urban Americana than this.

title: YouTube to Block Videos From Some Indie Labels
description: Soon to disappear from YouTube: videos by Vampire Weekend, the Arctic Monkeys and perhaps hundreds of other independent musicians.

title: Report on New York Citys Underground Infrastructure
description: The office of Mayor Bill de Blasio issued a report on the citys underground infrastructure on Wednesday.

title: Fire Dept. Is Now Responding to All Gas-Odor Calls
description: New York Citys Fire Department has started responding to all reports of gas odors that the city receives, a significant change in policy put into effect in the wake of an explosion in East Harlem in March that killed eight people.

title: Google Ready to Comply With Right to Be Forgotten Rules in Europe
description: LONDON  Your right to be forgotten on the Internet is almost here.

title: Bachfest Celebrates Monteverdi Choirs 50th Anniversary
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  If ever there was a composer to be celebrated on Fathers Day, it is Bach. Of his 20 children, 10 died in infancy or early childhood, but that still left his hands full. And though inhumanly busy with composition, performance and teaching, he took an active hand in the childrens upbringing and education.

title: Cant Fake the Funk
description: In its small confines between the Fort Greene and Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhoods in Brooklyn, Clinton Hill is home to multimillion-dollar historic brownstones and towering housing projects. The area is a mix of young professionals, Pratt Institute art students and locals whose families have lived in the area for generations.

title: Porsche Tops J.D. Power Initial Quality Study for Second Consecutive Year
description: The 2014 J.D. Power Initial Quality Study found that new vehicle owners experienced more problems with their vehicles than the previous years respondents, the company said on Wednesday.

title: Image of the Day: June 18
Today in Small Business: Banking on Belts
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Iraq Under a Colder Eye
description: Let me be clear, as the president would say: Like many better-informed people, I have no definite idea what our current strategy should be in Iraq, and unlike some of them Im willing to admit it. In the same lukewarm/conflicted way that I supported the 2007 surge, Im semi-persuaded by the Dexter Filkins argument (amplified here by Reihan Salam) that a residual American force might have made a difference in the current mess constraining the Maliki governments sectarian impulses, stiffening up the Iraqi Armys backbone, giving us better intelligence about ISISs development. But thats pure hindsight, and looking forward most of the strategic options being discussed look somewhat fantastical, from the invasion 2.0 favored by the editors of The Weekly Standard (in whichspecial operators, and perhaps regular U.S. military units would rout ISIS, and then somehow re-join together what Maliki has very deliberately put asunder) to the ally-with-Tehran option advanced as the thinking internationalists alternative(which even its advocates acknowledge requires lending U.S. resources to the cause ofa strengthened expansionary Iran), to the targeted air strikes reportedly being contemplated by the administration (which, as a certain general with some in-theater experience just pointed out, would risk turning the U.S. military into the air force for Shia militias).

title: In Israel, Masks With a Past
description: It is a tiny yet haunting exhibit: just 12 stone masks, primitive faces with only holes for eyes, small gaping mouths without lips and uneven, spiky teeth.

title: With Blood Pressure, Lower Is Not Always Better
description: In treating people with high blood pressure, most experts believe that the lower the better. But a new study suggests that that there are limits beyond which there is no benefit.

title: Vegetarian Meals Are a Success, But the Real Win Is Learning to Plan Ahead
description: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist and cookbook author, is working with the Ruder family (Renee, her husband, Chris, and their three daughters, ages 11, 9 and 7) to help these meat lovers adopt a plan of eating two vegetarian meals a week without feeling deprived; and to take advantage of a C.S.A., a community-supported agriculture program basket often filled with foods to which they are unaccustomed. This week, they tried a Big Bowl with Black Beans, Greens, Avocado and Salsa Fresca.

title: Select Home Care Weighs New Wage and Labor Regulations
description: SELECT HOME CARE, based in Westlake Village, Calif., offers 24-hour nonmedical care to elderly clients in California, Nevada, Utah, Colorado, Oregon and Texas. It has nine offices, 500 employees and more than $10 million in annual revenue.

title: Listen Up | A Danish Duo Gets Moody With Ukuleles
description: In their early 20s, Rasmus Bak and Bjarke Niemann bonded over a shared love of ambient music. Nearly 10 years later, on a whim, the Danish pals embarked on a journey from Copenhagen to upstate New York, where they spent seven days with 20 bottles of wine and two ukuleles in the Rubber House, a desolate black building covered with neoprene sheeting once owned by the actor Willem Dafoe. There, isolated from the outside world and surrounded by woods, their new musical project, Death Has No Dominion, was born.

title: Delaware Museum Faces Sanctions From Directors Group
description: The Delaware Art Museum, which recently began to sell works of art to help dig its way out of debt incurred by a 2005 expansion and renovation, has been sanctioned by the Association of Art Museum Directors, which said the museums actions violated one of the most basic and important principles of a collecting institution.

title: Britains Thaw With Iran, Coming at a Crucial Juncture, Could Be Useful to Allies
description: LONDON  With the election of a relatively moderate president in Iran and the rise of radical Sunni fighters in Syria and Iraq, Britain is pressing ahead to improve relations with Iran and reopen its embassy in Tehran.

title: How Should Select Home Care Adjust to New Wage and Labor Regulations?
description: Weve just published a case study about Select Home Care, based in Westlake Village, Calif., which offers 24-hour nonmedical care to elderly clients in California, Nevada, Utah, Colorado, Oregon and Texas. As the article explains, Select is confronting an array of regulatory changes that will necessitate shorter shifts, more employees and higher wages.

title: BlackBerry to Add Amazon App Store to Phones
description: OTTAWA  In a side story to Amazons expected move into the smartphone business, the ailing handset maker BlackBerry said on Wednesday that it would include Amazons app store on its phones.

title: Thirteen in Years, but 10 or 15 in Thoughts and Action
description: Gather together a random assortment of 13-year-olds, and youll likely find yourself looking at a group of people who have only their age in common. Some will be way into teenage culture, into hanging out and hooking up, even into alcohol and drugs; others will be little changed from the children they were at 12, 11, even 10 years of age, still singing the songs and playing the games of children.

title: For Vietnam and China, No Easing of Tensions
description: HONG KONG  China and Vietnam exchanged sharp views Wednesday in their dispute over a Chinese oil rig deployed in contested waters in the South China Sea near Vietnams coast and appear to have made little headway in cooling tensions, according to accounts by both governments summarizing a top-level meeting in Hanoi.

title: Street Style at Florences Pitti Uomo
description: Fashion from outside the international mens trade show at Pitti Uomo.

title: Federal Reserve Sees Slower Growth, but Maintains Plans to Trim Stimulus
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve on Wednesday sharply cut its economic forecast for 2014 even as it said the economy had bounced back after a nasty winter, allowing the central bank, in its view, to continue to retreat from its stimulus campaign.

title: Ban on Gun Straw Purchases Survives, But Only Just
description: The Supreme Court came alarmingly close this week to eviscerating one of the most important gun safety rules on the books  the federal ban on straw purchases.

title: Spain vs. Chile: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: Spain must win or their title defense will be over. Chile can probably afford a loss, but would much rather get a point or three to make their final game less crucial.

title: Messaging App Gets People Talking With One Word: Yo
description: Some technology start-ups want to cure the worlds ills. Others want to disrupt major industries. One app has a strategy that amounts to a single word.

title: Fire Phone Immerses Users in Amazons World
description: SEATTLE  Amazon on Wednesday announced a device that tries to fulfill the retailers dream of being integrated into consumers lives at every possible waking moment  whether they are deciding where to eat, realizing they need more toilet paper or intrigued by a snatch of overheard music.

title: G.E. to Propose Sweeteners to Its Alstom Offer
description: PARIS  Jeffrey R. Immelt, the General Electric chairman and chief executive, is heading back to France with sweeteners for his $13.5 billion bid for Alstom, hoping to lure the government away from a rival offer from Siemens and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries.

title: Readers Mourn the Loss of The Gun Report
description: Gun violence has rarely been more relevant in America than it is right now, so a recent decision to discontinue The Gun Report on Joe Noceras blog struck many readers as a simply terrible idea. My office has received more than 100 complaints or laments that it has been discontinued; they dont seem to be a part of a writing campaign but an outpouring from individuals with strong feelings.

title: Elon Musks Halo Effect
description: Elon Musk is applying his magic touch to mergers and acquisitions.

title: Rail Strike Strands French and Tests Their President
description: PARIS  Now entering its second week, the national railway strike here has stranded thousands and exasperated millions more. It has brought on even more stress for high school students trying to reach their nationwide graduation test sites; upended business trips, hospital visits, vacations and daily commutes; and cost the state rail system upward of $250 million (about 184.2 million euros).

title: Mother Charged With Fatal Poisoning of 5-Year-Old Boy
description: Lacey Spearss struggle seemed like every mothers worst nightmare. From the moment her son was born, she said, he was afflicted with never-ending illnesses.

title: Soul Doctor Will Return, Off Broadway
description: Soul Doctor, the musical about the guitar-strumming, folksong-composing rabbi Shlomo Carlebach that had a brief Broadway run at Circle in the Square in 2013, will return in an off-Broadway production at the Actors Temple Theater. Previews begin on Nov. 25; the show opens on Dec. 13. Jeremy Chess is producing. Casting details for the production have not been announced.

title: Indictment of Lacey Spears
description: Ms. Spears, 26, was arrested and charged with murder in the death of her 5-year-old son on Tuesday.

title: Redskins Trademark: A Primer on the Cancellation
description: The United States Patent and Trademark Offices decision Wednesday to cancel the Washington Redskins trademark registration will probably increase calls for the N.F.L. team to change its name.

title: The Scene at Pitti Uomo
description: At the international mens trade show at Pitti Uomo in Florence, a thousand or more exhibitors set up in a chaotic cluster of pavilions scattered throughout fairgrounds inside the 16th century Fortezza da Basso.

title: Intel Introduces Custom Cloud Chip
description: Intel is solving a tough business problem, using a little technical innovation.

title: G.M.s Chief on Staff and Restructuring
description: Mary T. Barra, the chief executive of General Motors, returned before a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee and said the implementation of new safety reviews and procedures are underway.

title: A Retro-Flavored Playlist from the Spring/Summer 2015 London Mens Shows
description: During a typical show season, there is usually one genre-crossing Top 40 track that gets played ad nauseam  on the runways, during presentations, at parties  until it has been beaten into the brains of showgoers. Thankfully, the spring/summer 2015 London mens shows offered a diverse and unexpected soundtrack. There was late 90s and early 00s R&B and hip-hop at Astrid Andersen, which used Affirmative Action by the short-lived super group the Firm, and at MAN, where the finale, Freak Me by Silk, was like bedroom music for the collection of duvet-worthy linens and pillowcase-shaped bags. At the Agi & Sam after-party, Black Robs 2000 track Whoa got everyone (including fellow designer Matthew Miller) onto the dance floor. At the other end of the sonic spectrum, Topman presented a trio of nostalgic songs by contemporary bands  Temples, Saint Etienne and Tame Impala  that fit the retro-inspired collection without making it feel dated.

title: The Next-Generation Fitness Bands
description: Molly Wood reviews the LG Lifeband Touch and the Samsung Gear Fit, two wearable devices that marry fitness bands with smartwatches.

title: Fitness Devices That Do (Just) a Bit More
description: WEARABLE technology is having an identity crisis.

title: Jack White Hits No. 1, With Strong Vinyl Sales
description: When it comes to the music charts, a victory for Jack White is a victory for vinyl.

title: When Mysterious Symptoms Strike a Small Town
description: Megan Abbott is a seasoned, Edgar Award-winning author with exceptional gifts for making nerves jangle and skin crawl. She is also skilled at turning teenage sexuality into cause for squirming, like watching a movie with her dad and suddenly theres a scene you dont want to watch with your dad, as Deenie, the heroine of her latest, The Fever, nicely puts it.

title: Learning Lear': John Lithgows Shakespeare in the Park Diary
description: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses King Lear for Shakespeare in the Park. His first report follows.

title: Shift Emerges in Europe on Focus on Austerity
description: BRUSSELS  France and Italy, still struggling to meet the euro zones tough budget targets, may be gaining support for an effort to relax the rules.

title: Ivory Coasts Cornerstone Becomes a Catalyst
description: BRASLIA  Perhaps it was the moment when Didier Drogba rose from the bench to warm up, drawing the attention of almost everyone at Arena Pernambuco in Recife, Brazil. Or maybe it was when he stood poised to enter the game, inspiring his teammates with just his nearing presence.

title: Times Square Spider-Man Found Not Guilty of Assault
description: Extra! Extra! Read all about it: Spider-Man Is Not Guilty!

title: What Janet Yellen Is Trying to Tell Us
description: One huge question was hanging over the Federal Reserve before Wednesdays Fed-a-palooza. And in the course of a statement after the central banks policy meeting; new forecasts for the economy and interest rates; and a Q. and A. from Janet Yellen, the Fed chairwoman, it got at least a semblance of an answer.

title: City Ballet to Add a Week to Its Saratoga Residency
description: The Saratoga Performing Arts Center has found a way to stop the New York City Ballets slow disappearing act. Having seen the companys residency dwindle from four weeks to three in 1978, then from three weeks to two in 2009 and then to a single week in 2013 and this year, mainly because the cost of presenting the company was outstripping the centers ability to raise money to pay for it, the centers board of directors announced on Tuesday that it would reverse that trend: when the City Ballet returns to Saratoga in 2015, it will be for a two-week season.
