title: Domino Sugar, Brooklyns Sweet Story, Makes History
description: Almost 20 years ago, the Miser stood on the Brooklyn waterfront in Williamsburg, wondering how long it would take the citys savvier real estate developers to salvage the considerable stock of forsaken lots and warehouses, perched perfectly between a rapidly gentrifying neighborhood and sweeping river views.

title: Five Plead Guilty to Beating a Motorist in Detroit
description: Five people involved in the severe beating of a Detroit motorist after his truck hit a 10-year-old boy pleaded guilty this week to reduced charges, ending a case that had raised concerns about racial tension and vigilantism in the bankrupt city.

title: Obama on Engaging Iran in Iraq Crisis
description: The president discussed Irans declaration to intervene in Iraq.

title: Neruda Poems Found
description: Twenty previously unknown poems by Pablo Neruda have been discovered by the Pablo Neruda Foundation in Santiago, Chile. Seix Barral, Nerudas Barcelona-based publisher, announced the news on Wednesday. Elena Ramirez, the companys editorial director, called it the biggest find in Spanish literature in recent years, and emphasized the extremely high quality of several of the poems.

title: Video of Man Rescued From German Cave
description: Rescuers from Bavarias Mountain Rescue Service carefully extracted an injured explorer through a series of shafts and tunnels after he was trapped for more than 11 days.

title: Wisconsin Governor at Center of a Vast Fund-Raising Case
description: CHICAGO  Prosecutors in Wisconsin assert that Gov. Scott Walker was part of an elaborate effort to illegally coordinate fund-raising and spending between his campaign and conservative groups during efforts to recall him and several state senators two years ago, according to court filings unsealed Thursday.

title: Baptism by Fire
description: Coming soon, by N.R. Kleinfield: Jordan Sullivans decade-long dream of joining the Fire Department had come true. Now he had to prove himself.

title: At Art Basel, Works With a Museum Presence
description: BASEL, Switzerland  In an old market hall adjacent to the cavernous center where Art Basel, the gold standard of contemporary art fairs, is taking place, there is a happening unlike anything ever staged here. Called 14 Rooms, it consists of 14 mini-performances created by artists including Marina Abramovic, Damien Hirst and Yoko Ono, each secreted in a small space behind mirrored doors. Open one door, and theres a Marina Abramovic look-alike naked and astride a bicycle seat, arms outstretched. In another, identical twins sit in front of identical spot paintings by Mr. Hirst.

title: Public Worker Testimony Is Protected, Justices Rule
description: WASHINGTON  The First Amendment protects government employees from retaliation for giving truthful testimony that was not part of their job responsibilities, a unanimous Supreme Court ruled Thursday.

title: A German Voice, Hans-Olaf Henkel, Calls for Euros Abolition
description: BRUSSELS  He was once one of Germanys most prominent business leaders, head of a major industry lobby and IBMs top executive in Europe. But recently Hans-Olaf Henkel has embarked on a new career, one that puts him radically at odds with most of his European business peers.

title: As Demand for Education Rises in Brazil, For-Profit Colleges Fill the Gap
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Higher education in Brazil is increasingly in the hands of profit-seeking entrepreneurs.

title: Ask Well | Game On, Weekend Warrior
description: A reader asked Well if occasional cardiovascular exercise is better or worse than regular workouts.

title: Money Remains Crime-Fighting Tool for New York Police
description: Amid advances in data-driven policing and forensic science, one traditional crime-solving tool has remained a constant for the New York Police Department: money.

title: Sunday Night Dinner | At Il Buco, Platefuls of Pasta Seem Made to be Lingered Over
description: The writer Charlotte Druckman and the photographer Melanie Dunea spend Sunday evenings at New York City dining establishments to find out whats new with the people behind them.

title: Whats a Tiara Like You Doing on Reality TV?
description: A first ladys diamond tiara will head home to Ohio soon.

title: Ask Well: Weekend Warriors
description: Question:

title: Support From the Left Helps Keep a Right-Wing President in Power in Colombia
description: BOGOT, Colombia  Going into Sundays presidential election here, many people expected that the right-wing former president, lvaro Uribe, would be the one whose outsize influence might tip the balance in favor of his preferred candidate, scar Ivn Zuluaga.

title: Iraqi Youth Orchestra Cancels American Trip
description: For the 43 teenage musicians of the National Youth Orchestra of Iraq, it was a dream about to come true: the ensemble, formed by the Iraqi pianist Zuhal Sultan in 2008, was planning to visit the United States this summer to work a similarly constituted American group, the Elgin Youth Symphony Orchestra, of Elgin, Ill., and then to perform in Elgin, Washington, D.C., Chicago and possibly New York (a concert was in the planning stages).

title: 36 Hours in Madrid
description: In the five years since Spains economy took a nose-dive, madrileos never stopped going out, but they did become more judicious in their spending. While not easy on businesses, this has ultimately been good for consumers, as retailers and restaurateurs dug deep in the treasure chest of Spanish talents and traditions  not to mention agricultural bounty  to weather the economic storm. Before that storm, Madrid seemed frantic to become a copy of any other European metropolis, but now the city feels more Spanish again. Resourcefulness, creativity and reinvention are bubbling up in art galleries, designer ateliers and restaurants. The citys symbol may be a bear, but for style, culture, history and sybaritic delights, there are plenty of reasons to be bullish on Madrid.

title: Valencias Newest Sounds of Music
description: Music is at the heart of Valencia, Spains third largest city. For hundreds of years, people in and around the city have formed symphonic brass bands. Children grow up learning to dance the jota and boleros and to play works by Mozart and Stravinsky, with flamenco coursing through their veins as well. Bordering the Mediterranean on Spains east coast, Valencia has long been the nexus of Western, African, Hispanic and South American cultures, the various musical traditions blending with the local.

title: A Mother-Daughter Test: London, Together
description: Traveling with children seems to operate on a continuum that begins with plane discomfort for the gravely pregnant and ends with teenagers taking ski trips without you. Its the various in-between stages that currently occupy me: the necessary Children-as-Extra-Luggage travel, as I once did on a book tour with a 5-month-old, coordinating feeds between readings; followed by attempts at Traveling Despite the Child, which my husband and I once did in Japan, hoisting our 10-month-old in a backpack and dining in our hotel bathroom while she slept. And then there is the interminable Where Else Could We Possibly Go? stage, a yearslong stretch of visits to the in-laws, house rentals in places where you wont bother other people, forays into Disneyland. Into this category fall the whiling away of two-week breaks, babysitter vacations and four-day weekends that constitute the academic calendar.

title: Moments in Iraq Reporters Will Never Forget
description: Over the course of the United States long entanglement in Iraq, many reporters from The New York Times have cycled through the bureau in Baghdad. As the country once again teeters toward sectarian warfare, we asked these reporters  now on other beats, in other parts of the world  which stories from their time in Iraq have been resurfacing in their minds. Several recalled ominous hints of what was to come, while others described the moment that pushed them to see just how deep-seated Iraqs problems are.

title: Unplugging in the Unofficial Capital of Yoga
description: It was a hot and dusty afternoon, about 30 hours into my Indian journey, when the bus driver dropped me off in a small town that he said was near my destination: Rishikesh, regarded as the unofficial world capital of yoga. Only a short rickshaw ride, it seemed, separated my fatigued self from inner Zen. Nearly two weeks of life with monks at an ashram awaited.

title: Congressional Panel Subpoenaed in Insider Trading Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  Federal prosecutors and financial regulators have subpoenaed Congress in an investigation that could test the limits of federal insider trading laws.

title: Picnic Tables for Dancing, Bookcases for Naps
description: FROM a distance, the yellow clapboard house on Governors Island looks normal, with its pretty pink flowers, white gingerbread porch railing and wide side yard. But move a little closer, and you start to wonder.

title: Our Robot Nightmares
description: As robotics technology grows ever more surprising, its developers and users face a difficult problem: Robots are kind of scary.

title: Congress and Us: A Hate-Love Relationship
description: Dear Congress: Our relationship has soured. I no longer have confidence in you. Ive asked my friends, and they all agree. Only 7 percent of my fellow Americans now tell Gallup they have either a great deal or quite of lot of confidence in you. A mere 15 percent approve of the way youre handling your job. They never really liked your friends  big business, organized labor and the banks  but now they tell me they have more confidence in each of them than they have in you.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: postpartum depression, celiac disease and mammograms. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: A Reporter Unplugs and Still Finds Connection
description: After spending three weeks in Russia covering the Olympics in Sochi, sports reporter Mary Pilon took a vacation in Rishikesh, India. This weekend, the Travel section will publish a story that she wrote about her time there. Here she shares how the trip, inspired by her desire to unplug, and the travel piece came to be.

title: Pictures of the Day: Spain, Iraq, Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Spain, Ukraine, Afghanistan and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Greece vs. Japan: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: Japan worked hard against Ivory Coast and might have won in slightly different circumstances. Greece was simply woeful; a complete offensive rethink is necessary, and its unlikely one was made in the past few days.

title: Pictures of the Day: Spain and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Spain, Iraq, Afghanistan and Ukraine.

title: Seen on the Street | Outside the Spring/Summer 2015 Pitti Uomo Shows
description: A peek at what some of the peacocks at Pitti were wearing.

title: With Pine and Ambrose Out, Rockwell and Arianda Step Into Fool for Love
description: Tony winner Nina Arianda and film and stage actor Sam Rockwell will play a battling couple in Fool For Love at the Williamstown Theater Festival this summer, replacing Lauren Ambrose and Chris Pine, who dropped out citing scheduling difficulties.

title: A New Guide to the Grand Canyon by Wheelchair
description: Wheelchair users might not think of the Grand Canyon as a place to visit comfortably, but the accessible-travel writer Candy Harrington says it can be done in Barrier-Free Travel: The Grand Canyon for Wheelers and Slow Walkers.

title: Icahn Urges Family Dollar to Sell Itself
description: Updated, 6:38 p.m. | The activist investor Carl C. Icahn has turned up the heat on Family Dollar Stores, the discount retailer in which he holds a 9.39 percent stake.

title: Auditor Moore Stephens Said Not at Fault; Puda Coal Investor Suit Is Dismissed
description: In 2010, Puda Coal, a Chinese company traded on the New York Stock Exchange, raised $116 million from American investors in two public offerings. It presented audited financial statements showing that it had assets of $111 million and a net worth of $84 million at the end of 2009.

title: C.D.C. Details Anthrax Scare for Scientists at Facilities
description: As many as 75 scientists from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention may have been exposed to live anthrax bacteria after potentially infectious samples were sent to laboratories unequipped to handle dangerous pathogens, a spokesman for the federal health agency said Thursday.

title: Praise to Make a Californian Blush
description: Not so long ago, the stereotype of California ross included all the characteristics you would never want in a pink wine: heaviness, sweetness, high alcohol.

title: A Summer Dinner With Echoes of Paella
description: Do not lose any sleep over what to serve with a ros, be it from California or elsewhere. Mia Van de Water, one of our panelists, said that people tend to order ros the way they do Champagne, because thats what they want to drink, and it has nothing to do with the food. Jerusha Frost, the other guest panelist, agreed. Its rare when you get an opportunity to pair food with a ros, she said.

title: Unsealed Court Order and Exhibits From John Doe Investigation
description: These court documents detail a secret investigation into whether Gov. Scott Walker and his campaign illegally coordinated fund-raising with 12 conservative groups during efforts to recall him in 2012.

title: Cybercriminals Zero In on a Lucrative New Target: Hedge Funds
description: They say crime follows opportunity.

title: F.C.C. Plans to Fine C.T.S. Technology of China for Selling Signal Jammers
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday proposed a $34.9 million fine, its largest ever, against a Chinese electronics company for illegally marketing cellphone and radio jamming equipment online in the United States.

title: Promoting Mortgage Preapprovals in Competitive Markets
description: Smaller lenders are using preapprovals to attract borrowers in markets where competition for homes is fierce.

title: Turkish Officers Convicted in 2012 Coup Case Are Released
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys highest criminal court on Thursday ordered the release and retrial of 230 military officers who were convicted in 2012 of trying to overthrow the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The decision came one day after the countrys constitutional court delivered a landmark ruling saying that the defendants rights had been violated.

title: Torn by Three Loves and Styles of Jousting
description: Eric Rohmer, the French New Wave master, was in his mid-70s when A Summers Tale, the third installment of his Tales of the Four Seasons cycle, was released abroad in 1996. The only one of the cycles four films not distributed in the United States, it is finally having an American release, and it was worth the wait.

title: Eye of the Beholder
description: My friends wife is an amateur painter. She gave me a painting as a housewarming gift a few years ago. I dont like her work, so I stashed it in my office. Recently, she borrowed it for a charity exhibition, and later told me proudly that the painting sold for $10,000. She offered me another as replacement. I think selling the picture without asking was tacky. I also think I should receive the tax deduction for the donation because the painting belonged to me. Do you agree? And may I tell her I dont want a replacement?

title: Indie Rock Reflections on a Place and Time
description: Frank Zappa made a hobby out of tilting at rock journalists. He called the lot of them, in a tidy summary, people who cant write interviewing people who cant talk for people who cant read.

title: Globe Wiped Out? Tips From the Vault
description: You know the feeling. You emerge from a nap in your wine cellar or from a month in a submarine to find that during your absence, civilization has been destroyed, and only you, and perhaps a few other people, are left alive. Youre panicky. Grief stricken. Bummed. Full of impotent rage. Perhaps even a little gleeful.

title: Jamie Sneider: Thierry Goldberg
description: 103 Norfolk Street,

title: A Family Man (Daddys a Dictator)
description: This boy toys all grown up. To play Bassam Al Fayeed, a Middle Eastern dictators son living incognito as a Beverly Hills pediatrician named Barry on FXs new Tyrant, Adam Rayner traded the callow sexual maneuverings he optimized in British series like Mistresses and At Home With the Braithwaites for the gravitas befitting a family man.

title: Kahn & Selesnick: Truppe Fledermaus & the Carnival at the End of the World
description: Yancey Richardson Gallery

title: Sterling Ruby: Sunrise Sunset
description: Hauser & Wirth

title: The Shaped Canvas: Luxembourg & Dayan
description: 64 East 77th Street

title: Vincent Fecteau: Matthew Marks
description: 523 West 24th Street

title: A Calligraphic Answer to I Like This
description: Chinese calligraphy can seem daunting to viewers who are unfamiliar with the characters of this ancient art form. Some, stymied by the language barrier, tend to think about the physical act of the brushwork in the more familiar terms of dance or choreography, or to see the characters as abstract shapes (which, of course, they are not, although they have inspired abstract painters like Brice Marden and Franz Kline).

title: Leaping Away From Success
description: In the last nine years, the contemporary ballet company Trey McIntyre Project became something almost unheard-of in the often beleaguered cultural landscape: a small, independent dance troupe that was a familiar name both at home in Boise, Idaho, and nationwide. A darling of festivals, the company traveled to up to 40 cities a year, finished each season in the black, gave its dancers full health insurance and offered them over 30 weeks of work each year.

title: One Centurys Breathing Room Is Anothers Hiccup
description: The old network of easements and rights of way beside and behind the mansions on Fifth Avenue between East 78th and 79th Streets made life more comfortable for millionaires, but in 2014 is creating a headache for New York University.

title: A Sadist and a Masochist Walk Into a Theater
description: Venus in Fur, Roman Polanskis nimble film adaptation of the play by David Ives, might provoke a lively post-viewing argument. Is it about sex or power? Art or life? The nature of theater or the logic of desire?

title: Presbyterians Vote to Allow Same-Sex Marriages
description: DETROIT  The Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) voted at its General Assembly on Thursday to change its constitutions definition of marriage from a man and a woman to two people, and to allow its ministers to perform same-sex marriages where it is legal.

title: An Empty Heart Is One That Can Be Filled
description: I was 31 before I got my heart broken.

title: The Man in the Gold Lam Suit
description: James Lee Byars (1932-97) was one of the more intriguing characters to stir international art waters during the 20th centurys second half. An American playing the role of artist-as-shaman, he was lionized in Europe but not so well known in the United States. James Lee Byars:  an Autobiography, a retrospective at MoMA PS1, offers a valuable opportunity to assess his career. Was he the real deal, a true mystic sage? Or was he a canny, charismatic showman who knew how to exploit a modern hunger for timeless wisdom? The question hangs in the air throughout the exhibition, which was organized by Peter Eleey, the museums curator and associate director of exhibitions and programs, and Magal Arriola, curator at Fundacin Jumex Arte Contemporneo in Mexico City, where it had its debut last November.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Third Person
description: Paul Haggis narrates a sequence from Third Person, with Adrien Brody and Moran Atias.

title: The Birth of a Theatrical Comet
description: The musical Rent was featured on the cover of the Arts & Leisure section of The New York Times on Sunday, March 17, 1996.

title: Steve Scalise, Obstructionist, Joins the House Leadership
description: Interest groups love keeping scorecards measuring the fidelity of lawmakers, but to judge the new leaders that House Republicans elected today all you really need to know is how theyd answer the question: Do you believe in governing by consensus or by destruction? Republicans today elected one of each type, which will probably lead to more tension, more obstruction, and less progress.

title: If Seeing Is Believing, a Panorama of Truth
description: The Queens Museum has a big advantage when it comes to the familiar curatorial tactic of using older works from its permanent collection to inspire an exhibition of contemporary art. At the museums figurative and actual heart lies one of the great visual wonders of New York: The Panorama of the City of New York, a nearly 10,000-square-foot miniaturization of every building, street, park and bridge in the five boroughs, complete with day-night lighting cycles and tiny planes zipping in and out of La Guardia and Kennedy along almost-invisible wires.

title: Events That Ponder a Grim Anniversary
description: PARIS  A century ago this month, the great powers of an earlier order began to unravel. World War I redrew the world map, ending the Hapsburg Empire and the Ottoman Empire and shifting the tectonic plates beneath Europe and the Middle East in ways that still resonate. From June 28, the date in 1914 when a young radical assassinated Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in Sarajevo, setting off a chain of events that started the war, to Nov. 11, the date that the Allies and Germany signed a first armistice ending the war in 1918, hundreds of cultural events are planned across Europe and the United States to observe the wars 100th anniversary. Here are a few of them.

title: I.R.S. Eases Some Rules for Taxpayers Overseas
description: WASHINGTON  Facing criticism that its crackdown on overseas tax cheats had disproportionately hurt small taxpayers guilty of innocent oversights, the Internal Revenue Service said it would revise its rules, lowering or eliminating some fines while tightening other requirements.

title: The Sadness of Bugles as Soldiers Head Home
description: Ralph Vaughan Williams, the British composer long pigeonholed as a purveyor of bucolic calm, knew war, though he didnt have to. When World War I began, he was 41, old enough to have avoided military service.

title: In an Ironic Lens, a Latin Myth Evaporates
description: A Latin American spring is about to turn into a Latin American summer in New York City art museums. Purely, it seems, by chance, a record number of institutions have recently opened significant shows of work from South America and the Caribbean. The International Center of Photography, as usual one step ahead of the curve, has two.

title: Dissimilar Figures, Revolted by Carnage
description: World War I made for strange bedfellows. One such pair, who never met, haunt me.

title: Paul Haggis Narrates a Scene From Third Person
description: In this video, the writer and director Paul Haggis discusses a sequence from his drama Third Person featuring Adrien Brody and Moran Atias.

title: Visceral Reality vs. the Big Picture
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  In the century since the First World War began, there have been bloodier conflicts and more barbaric ones. There have been wars that seem more pointless and wars that seem less conclusive. But the First World War remains distinctively stupefying.

title: Future Shock: Whispering Harleys
description: Sales of electric motorcycles are just a tiny slice of a market that totals about 370,000 road-legal motorcycles a year in the United States, but Harley-Davidson, the proudly American maker of rumbling, brawny heavyweights, is hinting that it would like to change that.

title: A Test for the Early Detection of Alzheimers Disease
description: Liz Arledge is all too familiar with the ravages of dementia. Her mother died of Alzheimers, and one of her brothers has been found to have the progressive brain disease as well.

title: Q. and A.: Michael C. Davis on the Battle Over Hong Kongs Future
description: Hong Kong is undergoing deepening tensions over its political future as a self-governed territory under Chinese sovereignty. Democratic activists have demanded that residents win the right to elect Hong Kongs top leader, called the chief executive, without procedures that would ensure that only candidates approved by Beijing appear on the ballot. Many of the activists have endorsed Occupy Central with Love and Peace, a movement whose members have said they will stage civil disobedience protests in the citys financial heart if electoral reform plans proposed by the Hong Kong government and Beijing, possibly later this year, do not meet their criteria for universal suffrage.

title: A Venn Diagram of Love and Its Mutations
description: In Paul Haggiss film Third Person, Liam Neeson plays Michael, a Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist who has lost his creative mojo and is holed up in a Paris hotel, completing his latest opus. Accompanying him but staying in a separate suite is his girlfriend, Anna (Olivia Wilde), a wacko celebrity journalist who has literary pretensions that Michael is quick to shoot down. They go at each other with the merciless cruelty of two egotists whose only harmonious moments are bouts of frantic sex.

title: Pitti Uomo: Z Zegna Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Adam Katz Sinding.

title: Simple Fare, Bursting With Flavors
description: In recent weeks, when I told friends I was reviewing Crabtrees Kittle House, I received a consistent response along the lines of: That used to be my favorite place. I havent been in quite a while. It wasnt a terrible experience that had turned them off; there was just a general feeling that the longtime Chappaqua star had lost its zing.

title: Good Feelings About McCarthy and Scalise Elections on Twitter
description: Republicans elected two members of their caucus to the No. 2 and No. 3 leadership positions in the House of Representatives today.

title: Waiting in Existential Ennui
description: Many and contradictory are the claims that have been made for Journeys End, the British playwright R. C. Sherriffs 1928 portrait of life in the trenches and probably still the greatest of 20th-century English-language war dramas. It has been extolled and reviled as an impassioned plea for pacifism, a jingoistic celebration of homegrown heroes and an indictment of shortsighted military blundering.

title: Surez Staggers England With Finesse and Ferocity
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Luis Surezs first goal on Thursday was a delicate touch of class, a deft header nodded in with precision and purpose and placement. Surezs second goal, however  the one that was a death blow for England  was something closer to a savage blast.

title: A Rent Duo, Now Reunited
description: Scene Unseen is a new occasional series in which Sara Krulwich, a staff photographer for The New York Times, digs into her archives to talk about a theater photo that has never before been published. In this first installment, Ms. Krulwich takes a look at an image, taken in March 1996, of the original production of the musical Rent that features the actors Idina Menzel and Anthony Rapp. The two are now starring together in the new Broadway musical If/Then.

title: A Chef Takes Time to Work the Crowd
description: The hamburger or the pulled pork sandwich? I wondered aloud one lunchtime at 55 Main, failing to notice that a wide-mouth bottle of ketchup on each table pointed the way. Jonas Gold, 43, the owner and chef, stopped by my table with the answer. That he is a burger man, as he told my party, shows in the quality of the hamburgers here  strip steak and filet mignon trimmings ground in-house, char-grilled as rare as you like, served with a brioche bun and crisp, fresh lettuce, onion and ripe tomato. French fries on the side are hand-cut in the kitchen. The only thing better would be a burger and a beer, Mr. Gold joked. It was true, though with liquor licenses so few and far between, good times take planning in New Jersey. Bring your own cold one, and follow the ketchup to this burger.

title: The Clerk at Checkout Has Reasons to Be Happy
description: In Neil LaButes I Dare You, part of Theater Breaking Through Barriers Power Plays, a woman in a wheelchair dismisses another womans romantic overtures. Im not. ... she says, gesturing reluctantly toward her legs, unable to complete the sentence. I dont care what youre not, the other woman answers. I want you to find out what you are. Who you are.

title: Clip: Venus in Fur
description: A scene from the film directed by Roman Polanski.

title: A Familiar Taste of the Mediterranean
description: On a recent Tuesday night at Yevma Authentic Greek Cuisine in East Meadow, a young man approached the takeout counter and complained that the gyro he had just purchased lacked lettuce and was studded with French fries. Peter Messaris, 48, the owner and chef, offered to add lettuce but also explained to the customer that gyros in Greece sometimes have French fries  not lettuce  tucked into the pita. The patron left with a smile on his face and we (seated nearby) learned why authentic is part of the restaurants name.

title: Theater Listings for June 20-26
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Comedy Listings for June 20-26
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: For Your Alfresco Friends
description: Gift ideas for an easy day trip based on lightweight, portable equipment for transporting food, cooking and lounging.

title: Canadian Judge Says Google Must Remove Links Worldwide
description: OTTAWA  Google will appeal a decision by a court in British Columbia that requires the company to remove specific search results worldwide. While the case stems from an intellectual property dispute between two small industrial equipment companies, some legal experts say that if the decision is upheld it could have far-reaching consequences for the Internet.

title: Staying Afloat in End Times
description: Premium cable hasnt just influenced television, it has mated with it and spawned hybrids. The Last Ship, a maritime drama that begins on Sunday on TNT, is one of the better results of crossbreeding.

title: Movie Listings for June 20-26
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: A Familiar Name Looks for Consistency on a Womens Tour
description: PINEHURST, N.C.  Walking along the fairways of Pinehurst No. 2 at the United States Womens Open, Cheyenne Woods could not help but smile when fans yelled Go Deacs! as she passed by.

title: For Clam and Lobster Lovers, Theyre Palaces
description: Cruising the coast, a summertime tradition, has more purpose when one of Connecticuts many clam and lobster shacks is the destination. Picnic-table views of the water are the rule, plastic-cutlery casual is the norm, and a sense of urgency is imposed because these spots are open only for the season. The three seafood shacks listed below deliver quality food in unsurpassed waterside settings.

title: Kevin McCarthys Tea Party Bona Fides
description: How the moderate Republican from California got elected House majority leader with overwhelming Tea Party support.

title: Carla Laemmle, Actress Since the 1920s, Dies at 104
description: Carla Laemmle, a dancer and actress whose screen career began in the silent era and ended with newfound celebrity in the Internet age, died on June 12 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 104.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for June 20-26
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for June 20-26
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for June 20-26
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: McCarthy on House Majority Leader Role
description: The newly elected House majority leader, Representative Kevin McCarthy, spoke after he was chosen to replace Eric Cantor who unexpectedly lost a primary election last week.

title: Dance Listings for June 20-26
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Garbage In, Art Out
description: Plastic spoons, bullet shells, tennis balls.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for June 20-26
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Questions on Treatment of Mentally Ill by State
description: The sheriff of the states largest county is peeved with the Texas Department of State Health Services, the agency that runs the states mental health hospitals.

title: Women of Congress and the Press Battle Breast Cancer, and for Bragging Rights
description: WASHINGTON  There are two foes capable of bringing together members of Congress: breast cancer and the press.

title: McDaniel Drawn Into a Shouting Match at Campaign Event
description: JACKSON, Miss.  State Senator Chris McDaniel, who is in a runoff with Senator Thad Cochran for the Republican nomination in Mississippi, was drawn into a shouting match with a critic on Thursday as he met with a dozen retirees over cranberry and carrot cakes at a grocery store.

title: Witness to Fatal Shooting of Palestinians Reports Threats From Israeli Soldiers
description: A Palestinian carpenter whose security cameras recorded the fatal shooting of two Palestinian teenagers at a protest in the West Bank last month told Human Rights Watch that he was threatened by Israeli soldiers this week during an hourlong interrogation.

title: This Weeks Movies | June 20, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review Venus in Fur, Norte, the End of History and Jersey Boys.

title: Spare Times for Children for June 20-26
description: Sharks

title: Tally of Cyber Extortion Attacks on Tech Companies Grows
description: Tech start-ups continue to get hit by extortion attempts from cybercriminals who aim to shut down their systems until companies pay their ransom.

title: Carley Roney: Picnics in the Park, and Selfies With Brides
description: Carley Roney nearly wore black at her wedding in 1993, but decided at the last minute to wear her mothers wedding dress. She planned the reception in three weeks; it turned out to be on a sweltering July evening. I was the anti-bride and now Im the queen of weddings, she said. Ms. Roney, 46, and her husband, David Liu, 48, were among the founders of the wedding resource company The Knot in 1996. It has since become the XO Group, a media company that includes sites for new and pregnant couples. Ms. Roney and Mr. Liu and their children, Havana, 16, Cairo, 10, and Dublin, 6, live in Dumbo, which Ms. Roney calls wedding central, especially in June. Every bride in the city, she said, seems to take pictures beneath the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Spare Times for June 20-26
description: Adventures NYC (Saturday and Sunday) A bit of the great outdoors can be experienced in the city during this free, two-day celebration of rock climbing, kayaking, fly casting, slacklining and other activities in Central Park (on Saturday) and Marine Park, Brooklyn (on Sunday).

title: I Was a Digital Best Seller!
description: WEST TISBURY, Mass.  FIVE months ago I published a short book called Boom. Commercially it was a bust. No news in that: Most books lose money and are quickly forgotten by all but their wounded authors.

title: Gerry Goffin, Hitmaking Songwriter With Carole King, Dies at 75
description: Gerry Goffin, who collaborated with Carole King to write some of the biggest hits of the 1960s, songs that endured through generations and became classics, including Will You Love Me Tomorrow?, Up on the Roof, One Fine Day and The Loco-Motion, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 75.

title: Lucy Li, 11, Tops a 78 With Ice Cream at the U.S. Womens Open
description: PINEHURST, N.C.  Lucy Lis historic United States Womens Open debut was marred by two double bogeys and a triple bogey, which she handled with equanimity. The most disappointment Li showed all day was after her round of eight-over-par 78, when she had to hand over her pink ice-cream bar to her aunt to answer a videographers interview questions.

title: The Hard Choices in Iraq and Syria
Live Music or Digital? The Drama Is Operatic
Congress and Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Events on Long Island for June 22-28, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Caring for Circus Animals
description: To the Editor:

title: Suit by Protest Groups on Spying Is Dismissed
description: A federal judge in Washington State has dismissed a lawsuit that accused a civilian intelligence analyst working for the military of breaking the law by using a fake name to infiltrate antiwar groups and trying to thwart protests by sharing information he collected with the Army, law enforcement agencies and private security firms.

title: Clip: Coherence
description: A scene from the film directed by James Ward Byrkit.

title: The Fricks Expansion Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Female Playwrights
description: To the Editor:

title: Just Another Little Dysfunctional Dinner Party
description: Its a commonplace that speculative fiction speaks to the anxieties percolating in its age. Such seems the case with the likes of Edge of Tomorrow, which kinks up its narrative by repeatedly cycling back to the past, suggesting that complex theories about space-time are now so mainstream that theyre the stuff of mass entertainment. The same might be said of the far more modest Coherence, although its also true that digital tools, which allow directors to shoot fast, cheap and sometimes sloppily, are also helping pry loose linear narratives hold on movies.

title: The Maze of Homelessness
description: To the Editor:

title: After a Fire, a Dusty Town Hopes Not to Evaporate
description: FRITCH, Tex.  A month after a fire roared through this Panhandle town, all that remains of Sam Joness house is its concrete foundation, a row of charred pine trees and the underground storm shelter where he now lives.

title: A Push for New Look into Tainted Waters Source
description: WEATHERFORD, Tex.  Steve Lipsky has nearly everything he needs on his 14-acre estate along the Brazos River, west of Fort Worth. The estate includes a guesthouse, a resort-style swimming pool and a seven-bathroom, 15,000-square-foot home where he lives with his wife and three children.

title: Luxury Apartments? Later. For Now, They Burn Sage.
description: The increasingly glassy Williamsburg waterfront seems an unlikely place for a sacred site. Yet among mirrored high-rises and a manicured shoreline, near the decaying remains of the Domino Sugar refinery in Brooklyn, there sits on a shaggy patch of grass a 30-foot-tall white tepee, the smoke flap open to the sky, the door positioned east (toward the rising sun) and the poles lashed together, stretching out to infinity.

title: Portrait of a Marriage, With a Star Turn for a Townhouse
description: The real star of Exhibition, the third feature by the British filmmaker Joanna Hogg, is an austere but elegant, ultramodern townhouse in West London. Within its chilly spaces, the principal characters have lived and worked for 20 years. Married, childless artists in their 50s, the couple  identified only as D (Viv Albertine, an alumna of the rock group the Slits) and H (Liam Gillick, a well-regarded Conceptual artist)  work on separate floors connected by an elevator and a spiral staircase, and communicate via intercom.

title: Chinese Government Tightens Constraints on Press Freedom
description: HONG KONG  China introduced new restrictions on what the government has called critical news articles and barred Chinese journalists from doing work outside their beats or regions, putting further restraints on reporters in one of the worlds most controlled news media environments.

title: Tablet Geared Toward Children Underscores Power of Imagination
description: TO introduce the Nabi DreamTab, a computer tablet for children from a partnership between DreamWorks Animation and Fuhu, the companies are not initially focusing much on the devices technical specifications, like its operating system and parental control features. Instead, advertising, marketing and promotional events are going out on a limb, in every sense, and prominently featuring treehouses.

title: No to Guantnamo for Ahmed Abu Khattala
description: NEARLY eight years ago, 14 men arrived at Guantnamo after years in Central Intelligence Agency custody. Since then, only one has been tried and convicted with the case upheld on appeal. That was Ahmed Ghailani, a Tanzanian national who received a life sentence for his role in the 1998 bombings of the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania that killed 223 people. Mr. Ghailani was tried in federal court in New York, and he is serving his sentence in a federal prison in the United States. His 13 comrades from the C.I.A. detention and interrogation program are still in limbo at Guantnamo, where justice for them and the families of their victims remains elusive.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Clip: The Last Sentence
description: A scene from Jan Troells film.

title: International Monetary Fund Says Europe Should Weigh Bond-Buying
description: LUXEMBOURG  The International Monetary Fund on Thursday said that if inflation continued to drag, the euro zones central bank could do more to invigorate the economy by buying government bonds and other financial assets.

title: Gay G.O.P. Candidates Feature Partners in Ads
description: WASHINGTON  Richard Tiseis new campaign ad offers a scene of domestic bliss.

title: After Challenging Hitler, It All Goes to the Dogs
description: Its plausible that Torgny Segerstedt, a crusading Swedish journalist, was every bit as heroic, freethinking and sexually irresistible to women as he is portrayed in The Last Sentence. But you will need to take it on faith even after seeing this stultifying movie, a fictionalization of how Segerstedt (1876-1945) positioned himself on the right side of history by writing an editorial that declared Herr Hitler is an insult. Hermann Gring sent a telegram objecting to this boldly tossed gauntlet, one of many such complaints that challenged Segerstedts lonely fight.

title: Health Exchange Enrollees Had Mostly Been Uninsured
description: WASHINGTON  Four in 10 people enrolling in health plans through the new insurance exchanges already had insurance, but six in 10 were previously uninsured, according to a Kaiser Family Foundation survey released Thursday.

title: We Should Be Further, Dominicans Say
description: The manager of Best Barbers in the Bronx offers free political advice to his fellow Dominicans sitting for $12 haircuts: Vote for Adriano D. Espaillat.

title: The Corporate Daddy
description: For some time now, Republicans in Congress have given up the pretense of doing anything to improve the lot of most Americans. Raising the minimum wage? They wont even allow a vote to happen. Cleaner air for all? They may partially shut down the government in a coming fight on behalf of major polluters. Add to that the continuing obstruction of student loan relief efforts, and numerous attempts to defund health care, and you have a party actively working to make life miserable for millions.

title: Rays of Humanity in a Vile World
description: More than four hours long, filmed in expansive takes with almost no close-ups and very few camera movements, Lav Diazs Norte, the End of History is a tour de force of slow cinema. The movie, something of a sensation at Cannes last year, is not difficult or obscure  there is a clear, dramatic story involving characters who solicit both empathy and curiosity  but it does require an adjustment of the usual viewing metabolism.

title: Looking After New Mothers
What Happens in Vegas ...
description: Well, you cant fault Think Like a Man Too for being a sequel too much like the original. The first film, inspired by Steve Harveys how-to-get-your-guy best seller, Act Like a Lady, Think Like a Man, was a blatant product promotion, complete with bookstore signings and author appearances.

title: Federal Reserves Bond-Buying Fades, but Stimulus Doesnt End There
description: WASHINGTON  THE Federal Reserve is poised to keep purchasing large volumes of mortgage bonds, and potentially Treasury securities too, even after the likely conclusion of its prominent bond-buying program later this year.

title: Those Who Took the Veil vs. Neighbors Who Take It All Off
description: STONE PARK, Ill.  It was a muggy afternoon, but the Sisters of St. Charles were wearing turtlenecks, long-sleeved habits and stockings as they gathered next to a microphone and an unsavory stretch of four-lane highway. They stood on the sidewalk below a billboard picturing a blonde who appeared to be wearing only eyeliner and a come-hither look: a jumbo-size invitation to Club Allure, a 20,000-square-foot strip club that is a newcomer to the neighborhood.

title: Candidate Says He Cant Trust Officials Tally of Afghan Vote
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah intensified his political brinkmanship on Thursday, insisting that he would not accept any result put forth by the countrys election commission as his supporters appeared to be gearing up for street protests.

title: Even Among No-Hitters, Clayton Kershaws Was a Standout
description: Years from now, Charley Steiner said, when he recalls one of the greatest pitching performances in major league history, he will first remember Clayton Kershaw the hitter. In the bottom of the eighth inning Wednesday night, when he came to bat with an eight-run lead, Kershaw, the ace of the Los Angeles Dodgers, competed with everything he had.

title: When Packing Up Unfurls a Hidden Past
description: A Picture of You, the feature debut from J. P. Chan, who wrote and directed, looks at one of the less cinematic aspects of grieving: packing up a house after a parent has died. A brother and sister, Kyle (Andrew Pang) and Jen (Jo Mei), spend the weekend at their mothers Pennsylvania home. Purging her computer, they discover evidence of a romantic life neither wishes to ponder.

title: Lessons for Dethroned Spain From Italy, a Rival Whos Been There
description: RECIFE, Brazil  It was a shocking about-face: Four years after lifting the World Cup trophy and charming fans around the world with its attractive brand of soccer, Spain fizzled unceremoniously out of the tournaments opening round, losing its first two games. It was cast as the sudden end of an era.

title: Clip: A Picture of You
description: A scene from the film, directed by J. P. Chan.

title: Buying Into Solar Power, No Roof Access Needed
description: Like many consumers, David Polstein had already done much to reduce energy use in his large Victorian home in Newton, Mass. He replaced his appliances with energy-efficient models, installed better heating and put in new insulation. But he was unable to get a solar system to reduce his utility bill, he said, because his roof is too small and shady to make it worthwhile.

title: Obama Awards Medal of Honor
description: The president presented the Medal of Honor to Lance Cpl. William Kyle Carpenter, who took the brunt of a grenade blast to save a fellow Marine while serving in Afghanistan.

title: Marine Cpl. William Kyle Carpenter Receives Medal of Honor
description: WASHINGTON  Cpl. William Kyle Carpenter, an automatic rifleman who shielded a fellow Marine from a grenade thrown at them during a firefight in Afghanistan in 2010, received the Medal of Honor from President Obama on Thursday.

title: Turning It on, After a Long Drought
description: SALVADOR, Brazil  The opportunities and the goals came in rapid succession for Karim Benzema in his first World Cup match.

title: Every Dish Is a Plat du Jour
description: Like the culinary geniuses of Le Chef, French cinema may need a new seasonal menu. This light, disposable souffl from Daniel Cohen at times suggests Ratatouille with humans. For a film about mouthwatering cuisine, it offers only fleeting delectable sensations.

title: 5 Exonerated in Central Park Jogger Case Agree to Settle Suit for $40 Million
description: The five men whose convictions in the brutal 1989 beating and rape of a female jogger in Central Park were later overturned have agreed to a settlement of about $40 million from New York City to resolve a bitterly fought civil rights lawsuit over their arrests and imprisonment in the sensational crime.

title: In Chaos, Iraqs Kurds See a Chance to Gain Ground
description: KIRKUK, Iraq  The chair Col. Imad Muhammad sat in belonged to a commander in the Iraqi Army. So did the tiny cup from which he was drinking his tea, the ashtray where he snuffed out his cigarettes and the Ping-Pong table and treadmill outside his office.

title: World Cup 2014: How Teams Can Advance to the Next Round
description: Analysis and graphics show what needs to happen for teams in the 2014 World Cup to advance to the Round of 16.

title: A Hit Man Repents, With Barrels Blazing
description: In No Tears for the Dead, the writer and director Lee Jeong-beoms convoluted and stylish new action film, a South Korean-born, American-raised hit man with abandonment issues is assigned to assassinate the mother of a little girl he accidentally killed during an earlier hit. (We see this incident in a prologue, scored to a jazz club rendition of Smooth Operator.)

title: Keeping Track: A Patent Decision, Overtime Pay
description: A Good Patent Decision

title: Gay G.O.P. Candidate Begins Ad Campaign
description: Dan Innis, a gay Republican from New Hampshire, announced his candidacy for the House of Representatives in an advertisement.

title: After Years of Solitude, Spanish Literary Champion Takes Partner
description: BARCELONA  Carmen Balcells was never just a literary agent. Nicknamed La Mam Grande, after a story by Gabriel Garca Mrquez, she served as a confidante and coach, someone who paid her writers dentist bills and deftly resolved their domestic problems while promoting the greatest Latin American and Spanish authors across the globe, including Mr. Garca Mrquez, Mario Vargas Llosa and many more.

title: Mark Emmert Plays Down Claims of Hypocrisy by N.C.A.A.
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  In the months before he took over as N.C.A.A. president in 2010, Mark Emmert received two important documents. One was a briefing email from his senior aide Wallace Renfro that referred to the great hypocrisy of college athletics. Renfro described it as a growing public perception that unpaid athletes were driving a multibillion-dollar industry.

title: If Health Care Is a War, Heres the Front Line
description: Idealism and reality collide in Code Black, Dr. Ryan McGarrys impassioned record of his training in the embattled emergency room of the Los Angeles County General Hospital.

title: Trial Secondary as U.S. Questions a Libyan Suspect
description: WASHINGTON  The Libyan suspected of playing a key role in the deadly attack on the United States Mission in Benghazi is talking freely with American interrogators aboard a Navy ship in the Mediterranean Sea, according to senior American officials.

title: Surez Sends Rooney and England to the Brink
description: Luis Surez gave Uruguay the lead with a header in the 39th minute. Wayne Rooney kept England's hopes alive with a goal in the second half, but Surez struck again in the 85th minute to give Uruguay the victory.

title: The Ugly Side of Bollywood
description: In Miss Lovely, Ashim Ahluwalia shoves us into a 1980s demimonde of quick-and-dirty Indian exploitation movies, run by gangsters and sweatily intertwined with the sex trade. Its the flip side, or backside, of Bollywoods sparkle, a place of intimidation, titillation and cash-for-reels deals, with only glimpses of cut-rate glamour.

title: Signs of Trouble Preceded Fatal Stabbing at Bronx School
description: When Noel Estevez and Timothy Crump were friends, they did the things that 14-year-old boys everywhere like to do. They played video games, shared dirty jokes on Facebook and had at least one sleepover.

title: Colombia: U.S. Ends Cali Gang Blacklist
description: The United States Treasury on Thursday removed 308 names from a sanctions blacklist that helped cripple the Cali drug gang in Colombia, once considered the most powerful drug trafficking organization in the world. The delisting, the largest in the history of the Treasurys economic sanctions operations, lifted penalties against 78 individuals and 230 entities, mostly based in Colombia. The move left only the two leaders of the organization, which has collapsed financially, on the list. The leaders  the brothers Miguel and Gilberto Rodrguez Orejuela  were sentenced to 30-year prison terms in the United States after their capture and extradition in 2006. The brothers also agreed to forfeit $2.1 billion in assets worldwide, which the Colombian authorities are in the process of collecting.

title: Yours, Mine and All That Other Mine
description: Diego Costa (Jos Garcia) is a feckless if amiable 42-year-old who regularly donated his sperm for research purposes 20 years ago, using the name Fonzy (no relation to Fonzie, Henry Winklers Happy Days character). A pothead with a vintage pinball machine at home, he is a variation on the movies overfamiliar man-child template. Now Diego learns he has sired 533 children, 142 of whom are looking for him. Oh, and his no-nonsense girlfriend (Audrey Fleurot) is pregnant by him, too. But by customary means.

title: With Canoes of Concrete, Engineers at City College Paddle Merrily Onward
description: It might sound like an idea that would go over like the proverbial lead balloon, but in September, a group of engineering students at City College of New York began meeting and devising a way to build a concrete canoe.

title: Gaza: Tunnel Blast Kills 5 Militants
description: Five militants affiliated with the Hamas movement were killed Thursday in what appeared to be an accident when an explosion ripped through a tunnel they had dug on the east side of Gaza City. An emergency worker also died, of smoke inhalation, while responding to the blast. Hamas, the militant faction that has ruled Gaza from 2007 until the formation of a Palestinian unity government this month, has long stored weapons in tunnels. Israel has carried out airstrikes in Gaza over the past week in response to rockets fired from Gaza into Israel, but Hamas did not blame it for Thursdays explosion. Instead, the partys armed wing said that the men were killed while carrying out their jihadist duty in one of the resistance tunnels.

title: To Be Young, Besieged and Black
description: The beats are sweet, and the words often have an electric charge in Holler if Ya Hear Me, a new Broadway musical inspired by the lyrics of the popular but troubled rapper Tupac Shakur, who was shot and killed at 25 in Las Vegas in 1996. Unfortunately, much else about this ambitious show, which opened on Thursday at the Palace Theater, feels heartfelt but heavy-handed, as it punches home its message with a relentlessness that may soon leave you numb to the tragic story its trying to tell.

title: In the Land of Mass Graves
description: Just over two decades ago, Rwanda was swept up in a murderous wave of ethnic violence that was as bad or worse as anything happening today in Iraq and Syria. The conflict was between a historically dominant ethnic minority and a historically oppressed majority, as in Iraq. Yet, today, Rwanda is a relatively successful country.

title: Veterans and Zombies
description: Youve surely heard about the scandal at the Department of Veterans Affairs. A number of veterans found themselves waiting a long time for care, some of them died before they were seen, and some of the agencys employees falsified records to cover up the extent of the problem. Its a real scandal; some heads have already rolled, but theres surely more to clean up.

title: Egypt: Court Calls for Death Sentences for Top Muslim Brotherhood Members
description: An Egyptian court on Thursday began the process of imposing death sentences on the top leader and other members of the Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist political movement swept from power by the military nearly a year ago, in the latest sign of judicial support for the governments crackdown on the Brotherhood. In the past few months, Egyptian courts have drawn international condemnation by issuing hundreds of death sentences against Brotherhood members and supporters after rushed trials that have relied on questionable evidence. On Thursday, the court referred the cases of Mohamed Badie, above, the Brotherhoods spiritual leader, and 13 other people to Egypts highest religious authority, in what is seen as the first step in confirming the death sentences. Mr. Badie was also sentenced to death in April, in an unrelated case, but he is entitled to a retrial because the sentence was passed in absentia. In the latest trial, Mr. Badie and other senior leaders, including Essam el-Erian and Mohamed el-Beltagy, faced charges that included inciting murder during violence in Cairo last August.

title: The Klinghoffer Tragedy
description: The Metropolitan Opera, which has scheduled The Death of Klinghoffer in the next season, has canceled plans to broadcast the opera live in movie theaters around the world. Peter Gelb, the Mets general manager, defended the decision this week, saying that the broadcasts would be inappropriate at this time of rising anti-Semitism, particularly in Europe.

title: Good Progress on Affordable Health Care
description: Americans are finding very affordable health insurance and a wide choice of plans on the exchanges operated by the federal government, according to a report issued Wednesday by the Department of Health and Human Services. The report was based on data from the 36 states in which the federal government is operating health insurance exchanges this year. Comparable data from states operating their own exchanges is not yet available.

title: Playing With Fire in Afghanistan
description: At this pivotal moment for Afghanistan, one of the two candidates for president, Abdullah Abdullah, is creating a political crisis by trying to interrupt the vote-counting in Saturdays runoff. On Wednesday, he demanded that the election commission stop counting ballots and withdrew his election observers from the process.

title: Uganda: Anti-Gay Law Draws Sanctions
description: The Obama administration announced additional punitive steps against Uganda on Thursday in response to the countrys new law criminalizing homosexuality. Certain Ugandan officials will be barred from entering the United States, and some aid money for Ugandan police and health agencies will be cut off or redirected, the administration said. In addition, the Obama administration canceled plans to hold a military aviation exercise in Uganda. But administration officials said the moves would not diminish the American partnership with Uganda against the Lords Resistance Army, a rebel force known for its brutality. And the new travel ban is not expected to prevent Ugandas foreign minister, Sam Kutesa, from traveling to New York, where he has just been elected president of the United Nations General Assembly.

title: Weathering the Deluge of 1927
description: The Great Flood and Visitors, two monochromatic, wordless, nonnarrative features that opened theatrically this year and are now available for home viewing, arent so much avant-garde as anachronistic  although it is that anachronism, the notion of a silent cinematic symphony, that makes them seem avant-garde.

title: Puts Somebody Out
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  UPDATE: Sorry for the delay. Back to your regularly scheduled blog.

title: A Freelance Career, Found in Translation
description: The opening of Monty Python and the Holy Grail memorably features credits translated by an overzealous subtitler. Tired of listing the cast, the unseen translator abruptly goes rogue with a tourism pitch: Wi not trei a holiday in Sweden this yer?

title: U.S. Authorities Step In to Charge 2 After Deaths From Extra-Lethal Heroin
description: The first death came in late December. A 20-year-old man and his girlfriend bought $100 worth of heroin from a man named Dennis at an apartment complex in Hopewell Junction, N.Y. It was a new brand for them: The glassine envelopes were labeled Breaking Bad and bore the distinctive logo of the television show of that name.

title: Owner of Revel Casino in Atlantic City Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: The $2.4 billion Revel Casino Hotel, whose opening two years ago on the Atlantic City boardwalk was hailed as a revival of the citys gambling industry, filed for protection from creditors in federal bankruptcy court on Thursday as the owner formally put the property on the auction block.

title: New Contract for Teachers Is Altering Schools Hours
description: For New York City public school students and their parents, the trek to school can often seem like a race to the finish line, with the constant fear of stalled subways or unexpected squalls disrupting a carefully orchestrated routine.

title: Rapper Denies Murder, but Testifies About a Life Studded With Criminal Acts
description: Ronald Herrons youth unfolded in Apartment 4E at 423 Baltic Street in Brooklyn. That was where, he testified on Thursday, he saw his mother using cocaine and heroin; where his sisters, who were professional shoplifters, also lived; and where he resided when he was arrested for his first crime at age 13.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 19, 2014
Rebukes Aside, Rangel Heads Into Primary With Large Lead, Poll Shows
description: Charles B. Rangel, the Harlem congressman fighting to secure a 23rd term in office, has retained a significant lead over his nearest rival, State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat, with only days to go in a hotly contested Democratic primary, a poll released on Thursday found.

title: New York Legislature Closing Session With a Flurry of Activity
description: ALBANY  New York States lawmakers were wrapping up their annual six-month sojourn here with a flurry of deals and decisions on Thursday, closing an election-year legislative session with little conflict or high drama.

title: Avraham Shalom, 86, Israeli Spy Chief Who Hunted Eichmann, Dies
description: JERUSALEM  Avraham Shalom, who helped track down Adolf Eichmann and led Israels internal security agency in a long spying career for his country before resigning under a cloud over the killing of two Palestinian hijackers, died Thursday in Tel Aviv. He was 86.

title: Wheeler and Wright Give Mets Everything They Need
description: MIAMI  Last month, before a Dodgers-Mets game at Citi Field, Clayton Kershaw happened upon Mets Manager Terry Collins in center field. They had known each other since 2006, when Collins was the Dodgers director of player development and Kershaw was drafted in the first round, seventh over all.

title: Chemical Companys Shares Rise in Hong Kong I.P.O.
description: HONG KONG  Shares in the Tianhe Chemicals Group rose on Friday in their trading debut in Hong Kong after the company raised about $650 million last week in an initial public offering.

title: King Juan Carlos Reign Over Spain
description: A slide show of the king through the years and the transition of power to his son Felipe.

title: Jets Geno Smith, Dedicated to Improving, Will Work Through the Summer
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  With the close of N.F.L. minicamps, many players will travel far and wide, eager to refresh their bodies and minds in preparation for the sweltering days of training camp leading to a 16-game regular season that inevitably leaves them battered, if not broken.

title: Dr. Lorna Wing, Who Broadened Views of Autism, Dies at 85
description: Dr. Lorna Wing, a British psychiatrist who was instrumental in identifying autism as a mental disorder of many gradations, affecting people across the spectrum of intelligence  and who gave autism in its mildest form the name Aspergers syndrome  died on June 6 in Kent, England. She was 85.

title: Moroccan Flair in Late-Season Summer Finds
description: Though summer doesnt officially begin until tomorrow, stores have already begun to stock autumn/winter 2014 collections. But beneath the onslaught of warm outerwear and cozy sweaters, you can still find some seasonally appropriate spring/summer pieces. There are separates and accessories inspired by both the fashion and architecture of Morocco. The exotic prints embraced by designers like Isabel Marant, Tods and Emam are as colorful as the countrys inhabitants, evoking the graphic tiles that line the riads and the vivid shades that pop throughout the spicy perfumed souks of Marrakesh. Whether worn together in some far off corner of the world or as part of an otherwise minimalist outfit, these bohemian accents are worth the hunt. (And soon, they could end up on sale!)

title: Obama Extends Marriage Benefits to Gay Couples
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government on Friday announced regulatory changes to extend a wide range of marriage benefits to same-sex couples, making good on a promise by President Obama after the Supreme Court struck down the Defense of Marriage Act last year.

title: Word of the Day | conformity
description: conformity \kn-for-m-te\ noun

title: Yankees Cap Sweep With Speed, Not Slugging
description: There are nights when the Yankees, long known for their power hitting, look meek at the plate and must find ways other than the long ball to score runs. The off-season additions of Jacoby Ellsbury and Brian Roberts to complement Brett Gardner have made these Yankees, uncharacteristically, more runners than bombers.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) TANAQUIL LE CLERCQ: AFTERNOON OF A FAUN In 1944, as a 15-year-old dancer at the School of American Ballet, Ms. Le Clercq (above, with Edward Bigalow) appeared in Resurgence, a short piece created by George Balanchine for a March of Dimes benefit. Portraying the evil Polio, Balanchine enveloped Ms. Le Clercq in a black cape, rendering her character paralyzed. After children tossed dimes at her character, she arose. In 1956, by then the wife of Balanchine and a muse to Jerome Robbins, Ms. Le Clercq, 27, contracted polio while touring with the New York City Ballet in Copenhagen. Paralyzed from the waist down, she never danced again. Through interviews with her colleagues Jacques dAmboise and Arthur Mitchell and others, this American Masters documentary, directed by Nancy Buirski, chronicles the life of Ms. Le Clercq (1929-2000), the inspiration behind Balanchines Symphonie Concertante, Symphony in C, Bourre Fantasque and La Valse and Robbinss Afternoon of a Faun.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 20, 2014
description: We will be helping Iraqis as they take the fight to terrorists who threaten the Iraqi people, the region, and American interests as well.

title: Corrections: June 20, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: A Man Takes His Cabbage for a Walk
description: The Chinese performance artist Han Bing drags a cabbage through city centers as a social commentary on peoples relationships with objects in their lives.

title: Family, Corruption and Sage Words From a News Agency
description: The Chinese language is revealingly rich in mordant sayings about the nexus of family, officialdom and corruption. When a man becomes an official, one saying goes, even his chickens and dogs become immortals. And a commentary by the state news agency Xinhua that appeared Friday, laced with similar phrases, was likely to be worrisome reading for Ling Jihua, once the powerful gatekeeper to the Communist Partys leadership.

title: In Last-Ditch Effort for Alstom, Siemens and Mitsubishi Heavy Raise Offer
description: PARIS The top executives of Siemens and General Electric on Friday made what were likely to be their final pitches to the French government in their battle for Alstom, the French industrial company at the center of a high-stakes political battle.

title: U.N. Reports Sharp Increase in Refugees as Civil Wars Cripple Nations
description: In Central African Republic, they ran from home and slept under the trees. In Colombia, they dared not return to their villages. From Syria, they fled by the hundreds of thousands, escaping barrel bombs and summary executions.

title: Beijing From on High, Just Steer Clear of the Halls of Power
description: On all-too-rare clear days, Beijing can be a remarkably beautiful city, with elegant imperial buildings, ramshackle courtyard homes, shimmering skyscrapers and jagged hills rising in the distance.

title: Student Crossword | Cooking
description: Test your knowledge of cooking by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: I.P.O. Values Euronext Exchange Operator at $1.9 Billion
description: LONDON  IntercontinentalExchange, the owner of the New York Stock Exchange, said late Thursday that an initial public offering of its Euronext unit valued the business at 1.4 billion euros, or $1.9 billion.

title: Lloyds Sells More Shares Than Expected in I.P.O. of TSB Unit
description: Updated, 3:07 p.m. |

title: 6 Qs About the News | Dubai, Once a Humble Refueling Stop, Is Crossroad to the Globe
description: In Dubai, Once a Humble Refueling Stop, Is Crossroad to the Globe, Jad Mouawad writes about the rise of the Persian Gulf city of Dubai.

title: Its Official: The Boomerang Kids Wont Leave
description: Annie Kasinecz has two different ways of explaining why, at age 27, she still lives with her mom. In the first version  the optimistic one  she says that she is doing the sensible thing by living rent-free as she plans her next career move. After graduating from Loyola University Chicago, Kasinecz struggled to support herself in the midst of the recession, working a series of unsatisfying jobs  selling ads at the soon-to-be bankrupt Sun-Times, bagging groceries at Whole Foods, bartending  in order to pay down her student loans. But she inevitably grew frustrated with each job and found herself stuck in one financial mess after another. Now that shes back in her high-school bedroom, perhaps she can finally focus on her long-term goals.

title: French Summer Castles in the Sand
description: At Pimanson, a Mediterranean beach in southern France, summer starts early. On April 30, families wait for the clock to strike midnight, ready to build makeshift beach houses on the same shoreline spot from previous years.

title: G.O.P. Senator Courts Blacks in Mississippi Primary Race
description: JACKSON, Miss.  Inside an abandoned grocery store-turned-church here, a dozen black pastors gathered to discuss a seemingly impossible task: persuading their congregations to vote Republican next week.

title: Drug Maker AbbVie Joins a Stampede to Go Abroad
description: Updated, 7:08 p.m. | At first it was a trickle. A few relatively unknown pharmaceutical companies acquired international competitors, and moved their headquarters abroad.

title: New York Today: The Longest Day
description: Good morning to you on this brightening Friday.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: Shirley and the Bodybuilder
description: When a former champion bodybuilder from Ghana opened a small gym in an affordable housing development in lower Manhattan, 90-year-old Shirley Friedman became a dedicated client.

title: A Chiseled Bodybuilder, Frail Clients and a Fitness Story for the Ages
description: With his enormous muscles bulging beneath a small T-shirt, Martin Luther King Addo guided one of his most dedicated clients through a squat exercise inside his tiny Manhattan gym. You can do it, Shirley, he said.

title: Todays World Cup Matches
description: What to watch for in Fridays Group D and E matches of Italy vs. Costa Rica, Switzerland vs. France and Ecuador vs. Honduras.

title: Lebanon Detains 17 Said to Be Islamist Militants
description: BEIRUT  Lebanese security forces arrested 17 men in two Beirut hotels on Friday on suspicion that they were plotting to assassinate a prominent Lebanese Shiite leader, a government official said, describing an attack that could inflame sectarian conflict across the Middle East.

title: As Ukraine Announces Cease-Fire, White House Points Finger at Russia
description: WASHINGTON  On a day that the Ukrainian government announced a unilateral cease-fire in its battle with separatists in the countrys east, the Obama administration raised the stakes with Russia on Friday, accusing the Kremlin of continuing to covertly arm the rebels.

title: In Hong Kong, an Unofficial Election Draws Beijings Ire
description: HONG KONG  More than 350,000 residents of Hong Kong did something on Friday that no one in mainland China can do: They participated in a free vote over their political future. The Chinese government promptly responded by denouncing the entire exercise in bottom-up democracy as illegal and invalid.

title: Morning Views
description: Americans are finding very affordable health insurance and a wide choice of plans on the exchanges operated by the federal government, according to a report issued Wednesday by the Department of Health and Human Services, writes The New York Times. The editorial board believes this indicate progress toward an America where all citizens have coverage: Though the system is still new, millions of Americans are already being helped, and every success makes it that much harder for its political enemies to repeal or disable it.

title: The Unexpected Ceasefire in Washingtons Tax Wars
description: I grew up castrating hogs, Joni Ernst tells voters in Iowa in her signature TV ad, vowing to make em squeal in Washington. But shes not talking about cutting income tax rates.

title: What Makes a Great Editor? Part 3.
description: An editor is one who separates the wheat from the chaff and prints the chaff.

title: On Our Walls
description: The walls of The New York Times headquarters on Eighth Avenue are decorated with news images from the past. Prints by photojournalists hang throughout the building. In this Insider series, On Our Walls, well take you inside the building to see the photographs  many of them rich in history  and the stories behind them.

title: More Thoughts on How Small Businesses Can Deal With Big Businesses
description: At the most recent meeting of the She Owns It business group, the owners talked about strategies for handling late-paying clients and continued to discuss the challenges of negotiating with larger companies.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 2 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: In the news this week: the crisis in Iraq. What did you read in The Times that interested you most?

title: A College Major Matters Even More in a Recession
description: Graduating into a recession is unlucky. The bad luck haunts young people for years, studies have shown, affecting their salaries, employment prospects and even their health and happiness.

title: Morning Agenda: Icahn Takes Aim at Family Dollar
description: ICAHN TAKES AIM AT FAMILY DOLLAR | The activist investor Carl C. Icahn, who has a long record of aggressively lobbying corporate boards and management, has turned his attention to Family Dollar Stores, the discount retailer in which he holds a 9.39 percent stake, DealBooks William Alden writes. In a letter to Howard R. Levine, Family Dollars chief executive, Mr. Icahn urged the company to self itself immediately. He also demanded that three of his representatives be added to Family Dollars board. If the company does not cooperate, Mr. Icahn said he plans to go directly to shareholders with an effort to throw out the entire board.

title: Israeli Troops Kill Palestinian Teenager Protesting Arrests in the West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli troops killed a Palestinian youth before dawn Friday and seriously wounded several adults as their sweeping West Bank arrest campaign following last weeks disappearance of three Israeli teenagers both slowed and encountered more resistance.

title: A Second Career, Happily in the Weeds
description: MARBLETOWN, N.Y.  STANDING at the edge of an overgrown field, Charles Noble, 65, cups his hands around his mouth and yells, Mooowaaaahhh. He hopes his bovine impression will motivate 68 cattle to follow him to a nearby creek. His herd is apparently not thirsty, preferring to munch on tall grass.

title: U.S. Will Send 300 Advisers to Iraq
description: Iraq is facing an uprising of Sunni militants.

title: Egypt Has a Sexual Violence Problem
description: CAIRO  There is a fierce battle raging in Egypt, and its not the one between Islamists and military rulers  the two factions that dominate most coverage of my country these days. The real battle, the one that will determine whether Egypt frees itself of authoritarianism, is between the patriarchy  established and upheld by the state, the street and at home  and women, who will no longer accept this status quo.

title: In a Comedic Grab Bag, Many Welcome Surprises
description: Jane Lynch signaled in the opening moments of her smart, witty show at 54 Below on Wednesday evening that this was not going to be your typical cabaret evening of songs built around a theme, with a carefully plotted narrative arc. It was the opposite. In its free-form goofiness, it was what you might call anti-cabaret. Thats my term, not hers.

title: Facing Cuts, Musicians Criticize Mets Leadership
description: The bitter labor talks at the Metropolitan Opera took a new turn this week with a blast from the pit: Musicians in the orchestra, who are being asked to accept pay and benefit cuts, sent letters to the companys board questioning the Mets artistic and financial stewardship.

title: Beethoven, Bronfman and Soaring Sparks
description: Twice now, in the course of a week, a New York Philharmonic concert has begun, uninspiringly, with a Beethoven piano concerto and has ended, powerfully, with a Beethoven piano concerto.

title: After Accolades, Trio Injects a Little Folk Melody and Switches Gears Often
