description: Before playing a note in its sold-out first set at the Blue Note on Tuesday night, the trio known as Children of the Light paused to receive some accolades. Together, its members  the pianist Danilo Prez, the bassist John Patitucci and the drummer Brian Blade  make up the rhythm section in the Wayne Shorter Quartet. As such, they were presented with awards from the Jazz Journalists Association: midsize ensemble of the year and record of the year, for Mr. Shorters most recent album, Without a Net.

title: Some Playful Touches in a Serious Approach
description: It takes grit to run a modern-dance company for 20 years, and Pascal Rioult has succeeded, driven partly by a desire to churn out works meant to pack an emotional wallop. Like his mentor Martha Graham, in whose troupe he danced, he creates efficiently structured choreography that is meant to stir and even unsettle the soul. Yet while Mr. Rioults passion for pairing dance and music is obvious, passion isnt everything, and a missing ingredient blurs his efforts: a choreographic voice of his own.

title: World Cup 2014: Costa Rica Defeats Italy, 1-0
description: With a gritty performance and a clear strategy, Costa Rica guaranteed themselves a spot in the knock-out rounds with a 1-0 victory over Italy.

title: World Cup 2014: France Defeats Switzerland, 5-2
description: The last time France won its first two opening-round games was in 1998  when they went on to win the World Cup.

title: The Goldfinch Alights in a Repolished Jewel Box
description: THE HAGUE  Since it opened to the public in 1822, the Royal Picture Gallery Mauritshuis has been one of those quiet gems, set in a 17th-century classical townhouse in the center of this patrician city and frequented by lovers of Dutch Golden Age painting. But when it closed for a renovation and expansion two years ago, and a selection from its collection went on tour, Mauritshuis gained an instant celebrity it had never had before.

title: World Cup 2014: Ecuador Defeats Honduras, 2-1
description: Ecuador is still alive for one of the top two spots in Group E after Fridays victory over Honduras.

title: A Glass Window Imperils a Baby Bird
description: Dear Diary:

title: Republicans, at Hearing on Lost Emails, Accuse I.R.S. Chief of Lying
description: WASHINGTON  A congressional hearing examining how the Internal Revenue Service lost thousands of emails sought by investigators turned confrontational on Friday, with Republicans on the panel accusing the I.R.S. commissioner of lying.

title: Does Sex No Longer Sell T-Shirts? The Lessons of American Apparel and Abercrombie & Fitch
description: O.K., I know that is a big question. But Ive been thinking about it ever since the ouster on Wednesday of the American Apparel founder and chief executive Dov Charney.

title: Listen Up | Andrea Balency Takes the Long Road to Electronica
description: The singer and producer Andrea Balency takes an unconventional tact when it comes to making electronic music. Rather than adding to what has become the echo chamber of EDM (electronic dance music), Balencys ethereal voice and soft structures instead aim to mimic the movements of contemporary dance. Ive always loved dancing, she says. Those movements are something I try to translate with music.

title: U.S. Gives Thailand and Malaysia Lowest Grade on Human Trafficking
description: HONG KONG  Thailand and Malaysia are among the two dozen countries doing the least to fight human trafficking, according to a State Department report released Friday, a finding that could lead to economic and diplomatic penalties.

title: Telling Folk Heroes From Monsters
description: Woe to the once-hallowed trickster. In ancient mythologies, the riddler-thief and agent of change held a position of prestige. Now, we dont know what to do with him. In our two Americas, we do black and white, either/or, with us or against us. The trickster is in between, both and neither, a character on the fringes.

title: America As A Lousy Exporter
description: Sorry about two-day silence  busy with real life and various obligations.

title: New York City Leaders Reach Accord on $75 Billion Budget
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio and the City Council speaker, Melissa Mark-Viverito, have announced an agreement on a $75 billion budget that Mr. de Blasio said signaled a more compassionate era for New York City, with investments in public housing, expanded prekindergarten programs and summer jobs for youths, but with no tax increases or major cuts.

title: Chinese Workers in Iraq Staying Put, for the Moment
description: As sectarian fighting continues to roil Iraq, Chinese companies say they are preparing contingency plans to evacuate their workers from the country. But Chinese citizens based in the countrys south, which is less affected by the violence and where Chinese investment is concentrated, said in interviews that they felt safe for now and had no immediate plans to leave.

title: In Our Pages: June 21
What Does It Mean to Be American?
description: Throughout our journey up Interstate 35  were at 3,500 miles, and counting  Todd Heisler and I have chronicled the process of cultural transformation in Middle America. Once-homogeneous towns and cities from Texas to Minnesota are now heavily influenced by the world; by immigrants with different customs, languages and ideas.

title: Austerity and Hysteresis
description: Larry Ball has an important paper documenting, on a consistent basis, a very disturbing point: if you believe official estimates of potential output, the Great Recession and its aftermath have done incredible damage, not just to short-run output and employment, but to long-run prospects.

title: 6 New Ways to Measure Your Financial Goals
description: Most of us want goals to shoot for, but all too often we pick the wrong ones.

title: As Child Migrants Flood to Border, U.S. Presses Latin America to Act
description: MEXICO CITY  Faced with an unprecedented surge of child migrants from Central America that is overwhelming shelters and jails in Texas and Arizona, the United States has begun pushing for stronger regional cooperation to arrest the flow and enable the childrens safe return.

title: The Unwanted Rites of Summer Phone Service
description: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

title: Orange Is the New Black Recap: Of Shower Scenes and Santeria
description: Season 2, Episode 5 Strap in. Just as the last four episodes were starting to feel a bit too linear, this one moves fast in a lot of different directions  both in the past and present stories. (Spoilers below.)

title: U.S. Moves to Stop Surge in Illegal Immigration
description: McALLEN, Tex.  White House officials, saying that misinformation about administration policies helped drive a surge of illegal migrants from Central America across the South Texas border, on Friday announced plans to detain more of them and to accelerate their court cases so as to deport them more quickly.

title: Letters: No Place to Hide
description: No Place to Hide

title: The Great Y.A. Debate of 2014
description: When the journalist Ruth Graham finished reading John Greens tear-jerker of a best seller The Fault in Our Stars, her eyes were dry, and she wondered: Does this make me heartless? Or does it make me a grown-up?

title: Editors Choice
description: A REPLACEMENT LIFE,  by Boris Fishman. (Harper, $25.99.) In Fishmans bold, ambitious and wickedly smart first novel, a Soviet migr writer in New York becomes disturbingly adept at forging applications for Holocaust reparations.

title: Paperback Row
description: WE NEED NEW NAMES,  by NoViolet Bulawayo. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $15.) Ten-year-old Darling, the narrator of Bulawayos striking first novel, a Man Booker Prize finalist, ekes out a bare-bones existence in a Zimbabwe shantytown. When shes sent to live with relatives in Detroit, Darling discovers that, far from the comforts of her childhood community, much of Americas abundance is out of reach, and she is forced to reckon with the sacrifices and mixed rewards of assimilating.

title: The Living and the Undead
description: Reading the blurbs on the dust jacket of Lauren Owens first novel  from such luminaries as Kate Atkinson, Hilary Mantel and Tana French  readers might think theyre about to embark on a highhanded version of the Gothic novel, full of metafictions and literary allusions. These do appear, along with some beautiful language, but by Page 100, when the first neck is about to be bitten, The Quick drops its cloak and becomes a good old-fashioned vampire novel.

title: The Descent
description: How, in this age of surveillance, can we lose a 210-foot airplane? With its known initial flight path and fuel load, investigators can restrict the last possible position of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 to a sliver of the globe. Trouble is, most of that sliver  like 71 percent of Earths surface  is covered by water.

title: Down Under
description: Our planets coral reefs offer nourishment and sanctuary to as many as nine million species, running the gamut of life, from single-cell organisms to whales. The Great Barrier Reef, shimmering beneath the turquoise shallows of Australias east coast, surpasses all other coral ecosystems in scale and fame. This colossal spine of life stretches for 1,400 miles, roughly the distance from Boston to Havana. Today the Great Barrier Reef seems obviously spectacular: a World Heritage Site visible to astronauts in outer space and acclaimed as one of the earths greatest natural wonders. Yet as Iain McCalman reveals in his enthralling book, The Reef, little more than 200 years ago no human had any inkling of its dimensions, far less any inkling of the complex science of its precarious vitality.

title: Secret Lives
description: TIL THE WELL RUNS DRY  By Lauren Francis-Sharma  Holt, $27.

title: For Whom the Bell Tolled
description: While many ran in terror from the mounting monstrosities of Spains civil war in the late 1930s, three couples  the bright young photographers Robert Capa and Gerda Taro, the writers Ernest Hemingway and Martha Gellhorn, and the devoted press officers Arturo Barea and Ilsa Kulcsar  jumped into the fray. As Amanda Vaill writes in Hotel Florida, they risked their lives to shape public opinion and sharpen political will, daring their way toward a new destiny.

title: Late Reinforcements
description: Of the many challenges confronting the contemporary writer of fiction, among the most vexing is the problem of goodness. How does one convincingly portray goodness in an age when the twin presiding deities are irony and violence, when the most feared transgression is the sin of sentimentality? Can there be a place for a character who seems genuinely selfless, motivated by benevolence, decency, the desire to be of help?

title: Who Made That Pacifier?
description: By the time Christian W. Meinecke applied for a patent for a new and original Design for a Baby Comforter in 1901, people had been giving babies soothing objects to suck on for centuries: knotted rags dipped in water or honey, wooden beads or gum sticks made of stone, bone or coral. But nothing would ever be quite as popular as the pacifier.

title: So You Think You Can Steal?
description: I witnessed an odd incident: Two cars stopped, and the drivers began arguing. After a few moments of yelling, one driver got into the others car, and they drove off, leaving the second car unlocked with the engine running. I saw this very situation on a reality TV show called Bait Car: a vehicle is left for someone to steal while the police and cameramen wait. I yelled: Bait car! Bait car! as a warning for people nearby. When I told this story later, I was criticized for helping would-be thieves. But I am not comfortable with the shows premise. Should I have said nothing? STEVEN FONG, SAN FRANCISCO

title: Kevin Hart: I Dont Need Therapy
description: The comedian talks to Jessica Gross about his first night onstage, growing up in North Philadelphia and learning about the existence of tall people.

title: Reply All: The 6.8.14 Issue
description: KLINSMANNS PLAN TO MAKE U.S. SOCCER BETTER

title: How to Give an Outdoor Cocktail Party
description: Advice from an event planner, plus the dangers of the Dow, sunscreen brands by S.P.F. and more.

title: What I Didnt Understand That Summer in Mexico
description: I had never been to Mexico before. It was the summer after eighth grade, and my best friends parents invited me to their condo in the Yucatn Peninsula, about an hour by car from Cancun. My mother dropped me at Newark Airport. She told me to behave.

title: Moving Forward
description: On the cusp of turning 50, the artist Tracey Emin told the BBC: I always thought that love was about desire, being with someone, holding someone, feeling someone. But it isnt necessarily. Love can be different and come in lots of different ways and lots of different guises. Her interviewer was suitably intrigued. Englands notorious bad girl no longer cared about shagging.

title: Early Frost
description: In the early fall of 1912, a blandly handsome, tousle-headed American schoolteacher arrived in London. Nearing 40, coming without introduction or much of a plan  except, as he later confessed, to write and be poor  he was making a last attempt to write himself into poetry. It would have taken mad willfulness to drag his wife and four children out of their settled New Hampshire life in a quixotic assault on the London literary scene. Still, he was soon spending a candlelit evening with Yeats in the poets curtained rooms, having come to the attention of that stormy petrel Ezra Pound, who lauded him in reviews back home. Little more than two years later, the schoolteacher sailed back, having published his first two books, A Boys Will (1913) and North of Boston (1914). He had become Robert Frost.

title: The Wordy Shipmate
description: When Geoff Dyer came aboard the U.S.S. George H. W. Bush for his 14-day stay, he had his Ping-Pong paddle securely stowed but had misplaced his notebook. Too tall, spindly, self-described as a leftover from a novel Graham Greene had decided not to write, he had managed through a stubbornness born of sheer neurotic panic to wheedle his way, despite considerable and justified resistance from the United States Navy, into private quarters on the giant but very crowded vessel: the Vice-Presidential Room, no less. His report of his first day on board is a nonstop string of complaints: The noise is unbearable, he keeps knocking his head on the low ceilings and hatches, the spaghetti is cold and the lettuce inedible, the oil fumes are overwhelming, the temperature is like a blast furnace, the air is toxic, the ocean glitters but is spoiled by a sky greased with jet fuel. Dyer admits he is constitutionally incapable of adjusting to new environments; in fact, the only thing hes grown accustomed to, over the years, is that he never gets used to things. This is the same man who, when asked by a friend (Alain de Botton) if he would like to spend some time writing in an interesting and relaxing environment, immediately replied: Put me on an American aircraft carrier.

title: Exiles End
description: In September 1939, more than 350,000 Jews lived in Warsaw. Six years later, only 11,500 were left. Most of Warsaw itself had been wiped from the face of the earth.

title: Inside the List
description: Turkey Stuffing: Diana Gabaldons hefty new novel, Written in My Own Hearts Blood  the eighth entry in her Outlander series of time-traveling romances  enters the hardcover fiction list right at No. 1. These books describe the escapades of an 18th-century Scotsman and the World War II-era English nurse who fell into his world courtesy of a witches coven; writing in Salon in 1999, the critic Gavin McNett called it the smartest historical sci-fi adventure-romance story ever written by a science Ph.D. with a background in scripting Scrooge McDuck comics. Its been five years since the last Outlander title hit stores, and with a new Starz TV show based on the series coming in August, fans are primed for the latest installment. Gabaldon answered their questions recently on the website Goodreads. People often say to me, You write such strong female characters,  she told one reader who praised the depiction of her heroine, and I say, Well, I dont like stupid women.  Gabaldon also cited her belief that fiction has three kinds of characters: mushrooms, hard nuts and onions. Its a theory shes expanded on at her official website. Onions, she explains, develop slowly through the addition of multiple layers of personality, rather than popping up full-fledged as the mushrooms do. Hard nuts, meanwhile, play a merely functional role, making them difficult to animate. Onions, mushrooms and nuts, Gabaldon writes; this is beginning to sound like an exotic recipe for turkey stuffing.

title: This Is Your Brain on Writing
description: A novelist scrawling away in a notebook in seclusion may not seem to have much in common with an NBA player doing a reverse layup on a basketball court before a screaming crowd. But if you could peer inside their heads, you might see some striking similarities in how their brains were churning.

title: Events in New Jersey for June 22-28, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: House Votes to Curb N.S.A. Scrutiny of Americans Communications
description: WASHINGTON  The House of Representatives late on Thursday voted to bar the National Security Agency from looking for Americans communications without a warrant within a database of emails and phone calls it gathers while targeting foreigners, a technique critics have labeled a backdoor search loophole.

title: Notable Fires in the New York City Area
description: The New York Times published an in-depth article about a probationary New York City firefighter this weekend.

title: For Incarcerated Japanese-Americans, Baseball Was Wearing the American Flag
description: After the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor in December 1941, some Americans expected Major League Baseball to be suspended until World War II was won. Many of the players would want to enlist, they argued, and letting baseball go on as usual might be frivolously disrespectful of the nations war effort.

title: My Lower East Side
description: The way we heard it, the rabbis wife died on a Tuesday. That left just enough time for seven days of sitting shiva, and after that, a speedy white paint job and a Sunday open house that ended with our successful offer for a spacious and sunny two-bedroom co-op apartment.

title: Dispatches From the Culture Front
description: Modernism in the arts can be traced to the late 19th century, but it was the years during and after World War I when the movement matured and produced some of its most startling work. Here are excerpts from The New York Times that show how it covered a few key figures and developments.

title: Costa Rica vs. Italy: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: When Costa Rica headed to halftime down by 1-0 to Uruguay, few expected what came next: three unanswered goals and a team-defining win. But will this long shot be simply a one-hit wonder? Italy will be better organized and more professional than Uruguay.

title: Sky Diving as a Birthday Gift? Maybe a Nice Sweater Instead
description: Everyone was so excited about George H. W. Bushs jumping out of a plane for his 90th birthday last week, it has inspired me to publicly make a vow: I will not be jumping out of a plane when I turn 90. I wont do it when I turn 80, either.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Dan Barbers The Third Plate
description: This week, Dan Barber talks about The Third Plate; John Williams on the weeks literary news; James Nestor discusses Deep; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Court Allows Coca-Cola Plant to Reopen in Uttar Pradesh
description: The National Green Tribunal, an environmental court, on Friday ruled to allow a Coca-Cola production facility in the state of Uttar Pradesh to reopen after it had been closed in early June because of concerns over waste disposal and water usage.

title: Events in Connecticut for June 22-28, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Dan Barbers The Third Plate
description: This week, Dan Barber and James Nestor.

title: In Los Angeles, Old-Fashioned Glamour or Hip Mixology
description: Los Angeles is not what you would call a bar town, and for all the obvious reasons. The region covers almost 5,000 square miles. While public transit does exist there  and taxis and Uber are thriving  it is not New York: If you stumble out of a bar on the way home, theres not a subway on the corner.

title: A Guide Who Knows the Turf
description: Tama Robertson, a real estate broker, was warming up to a landlord on the Lower East Side of Manhattan recently when he casually asked for her help in breaking the law. Ms. Robertson had heard landlords make crude requests before, but this one stopped her cold.

title: Eight Hours of Free Music at Sundays Bang on a Can Marathon
description: The Bang on a Can Marathon has been one of the central events of the new-music calendar since 1987, when the composers who founded the organization  Michael Gordon, Julia Wolfe and David Lang  invited composers and performers to present the first of them at a SoHo gallery. In recent years, the marathon has been part of the River to River Festival, and has been held in the vast Winter Garden at Brookfield Place (formerly the World Financial Center), where listeners can take it in with varying degrees of casualness, coming and going as they see fit.

title: Threes a Trend | The Return of Wide-Legged Jeans
description: Tight-fitting denim will always have its place on the runway, thanks to designers like Hedi Slimane for Saint Laurent. But in the spring/summer 2015 collections so far, looser, longer jeans silhouettes are on the rise. Unlike the baggy low-riders of the hip-hop 90s, the new crop of wide-legged jeans is surprisingly understated. At the E.Tautz show in London, the designer Patrick Grant offered a version that was dark-washed, cuffed and slightly high waisted. (He sported a pair for his bow.) Worn monochromatically with a tucked shirt and long mac coat, the runway look was put-together but relaxed. Margaret Howell, who continues to show strong collections of covetable basics, also introduced a loose-fitting pair of jeans, which was topped with a simple shirt and coat. And Marta Marques and Paulo Almeida, the duo behind MarquesAlmeida, took a more youthful approach, fraying the pants hems and pairing them with an equally frayed top and coat that evoked a similarly laid-back minimalism, but with an edge.

title: Surprisingly Good at Talking About Sex
description: I hate the word moist.

title: Michael Shannon Finds Balance on the Waterfront
description: Throughout history men have made quixotic and impressive sacrifices for the women they loved  started wars, committed murder, swallowed poison, abdicated.

title: Video Reviews of Venus in Fur, Norte, the End of History and Jersey Boys
description: In this weeks video, Times critics review Venus in Fur, Norte, the End of History and Jersey Boys. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Tracy Morgan Is Moved to Rehab Center
description: Tracy Morgan was released from the New Jersey hospital where he was being treated for critical injuries from a car accident and transferred to an undisclosed rehab center, his press representatives said Friday.

title: Broccoli, Stems and All
description: Once upon a time, when you bought broccoli you bought the whole vegetable, stems and crowns. Then it became customary for grocery store produce departments to separate the crowns from the stems and to sell the crowns at a premium.

title: TVs Messy Women
description: Trainwreck. Burnout. Poster child for IDGAF. Whatever you call her, a new female archetype has made its way to film and TV, and some viewers are more excited than others.

title: Today in Small Business: Google My Business
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: R.I.P. Gerry Goffin, a Master Songwriter
description: I used to give a class for New York Times interns on writing and editing. I would start by playing the Gerry Goffin and Carole King song Will You Love Me Tomorrow? (I used Ms. Kings version.) I wanted to make a point about brevity and beauty: to show how its possible to convey complicated emotions, deep feeling and intricate meanings with the tiniest and plainest of words. You can be short and sweet. You can also be short and heartbreaking.

title: France vs. Switzerland: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: Switzerland was much buzzed-about coming into the Cup, and after an initial struggle, it rallied to beat Ecuador.

title: A Survivor, Inspired by Love and Loss
description: HAVERTOWN, Pa.  The visual artist Christopher Cairnss sprawling studio near Philadelphia is filled with installations that include piles of skulls and forlorn figures slumped despairingly in chairs. Sculptures that evoke the victims of Pompeii are strewn across the floor near the white wall, which is made of crumbling bricks and shards of glass and will be replicated in the sets for On the Threshold of Winter, Michael Herschs new opera. Mr. Cairnss eerie art seems an aptly somber pairing for the dark-hued monodrama, which will receive its premiere at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday, Mr. Herschs birthday, with Tito Muoz conducting the ensemble Nunc.

title: A War to End All Innocence
description: I feel like a soldier on the morning after the Somme. This line of dialogue, from an episode in the second season of the BBC series Call the Midwife, caught my ear recently as an especially piquant morsel of period detail. It is uttered by a doctor to a nurse after they have just assisted in a grueling home birth, an experience that is compared to the four-month battle in a muddy stretch of Picardy beginning on July 1, 1916, that was, at the time, the bloodiest episode of combat in human history, generating 60,000 casualties in a single day of fighting on the British side alone. The doctors comparison is surely metaphorical overkill, but it also represents a familiar style of wit, a habit of linking the challenges we regularly endure with calamities we can scarcely imagine.

title: Venture Capital Firm Settles S.E.C. Charges Over Pay-to-Play
description: Updated, 1:35 p.m. |

title: Jumping Through Hoops for a Better Health Plan
description: To get an idea of what your employers health plan may look like in the near future, consider the options the government of Manatee County, Fla., offers to its workers.

title: When a Will Divides an Estate, and Also Divides a Family
description: KATES father died when she was in college, but she stayed close to his side of the family. Although she moved to North Carolina after graduation, she and her three siblings returned to New Jersey a couple of times a year to visit her grandmother, aunts and cousins. She called her grandmother frequently until dementia made it impossible for them to communicate.

title: Book Review Podcast: Dan Barbers Third Plate
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Corby Kummer reviews Dan Barbers The Third Plate. Mr. Kummer writes:

title: G.E.s Bid for Alstom Is Blessed by France
description: Updated, 8:28 p.m. |

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Soft-Shell Crab Toasts
description: Melissa Clark shows how soft-shelled crabs are at their best when broiled until crisp. Serve them on garlic-rubbed toast with a bright parsley-jalapeno sauce.

title: Movie Review: Venus in Fur
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Venus in Fur.

title: Revisiting Jazz Roots
description: Thirty-five years ago, the trumpeter and impresario Mark Morganelli opened the first of two jazz lofts in Lower Manhattan. Nineteen years later, he began presenting a series of free summer concerts in Westchester County.

title: A Soft-Shell Crab to Top Your Toast
description: Of all the things you may put on toast, one of the best has claws. The soft-shell crab isnt as classic as, say, butter and jam. But when the crabs are in season, there are few better ways to savor them.

title: This Weekend: The BAMcinemaFest
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott offers his must-see list of films from BAMcinemafest.

title: Chasing Fires in the Dark
description: In 1996, Gregory Crewdson left New York to spend the summer living alone in his familys cabin in the Berkshires. Upon his arrival, he devised a plan: He would go outside nightly to photograph fireflies.

title: Iraqs Hold on Border Crossings Weakening as at Least 34 Are Killed in Battle
description: BAGHDAD  Sunni militants overran one of the last government-held crossings on the Syrian border on Friday after a fierce battle that left at least 34 Iraqi soldiers dead.

title: Image of the Day: June 20
Afghan Leader Backs U.N. Election Role
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Seeking to quell a political crisis surrounding the June 14 election to choose his successor, President Hamid Karzai reversed course on Friday and suggested that the United Nations get involved in helping Afghanistan settle disputes over the voting.

title: There Is a Simpler Way for Students to Apply for Financial Aid
description: Any college student who wants a federal loan or Pell grant has to file a Free Application for Federal Student Aid. With well over 100 questions about income, assets and expenses, the Fafsa approaches the IRS Form 1040 in length, and is longer and more complicated than the 1040A and 1040EZ, the tax forms filed by a majority of taxpayers.

title: The Latest Icon in Artistic Rebellion: A Cabbage
description: Every so often, the artist Han Bing likes to play a little prank with a white cabbage  that iconic, rectangular vegetable synonymous in China with full bellies and good fortune. Impaled on a wheeled frame and tied to a length of rope, the cabbage resembles a miniature parade float trailing along behind him through streets around the globe. In Beijing, Los Angeles, New York, Tokyo and other cities, the spectacle has triggered laughter, finger-pointing and questions from bemused passersby. But Mr. Han, 40, gives no answers.

title: Movie Review: Jersey Boys
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Jersey Boys.

title: Asked, Maybe Answered
description: Two apps recently introduced in New York illustrate the challenges developers face when trying to make useful question-and-answer platforms. Enquire, which connects users with locals who can answer questions about the citys neighborhoods, and Pyne, which allows users to create and respond to polls, both rely on groups of people willing to ask  and answer  questions.

title: Movie Review: Norte
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Norte, the End of History.

title: When the Korean Team Plays, Eat Korean
description: Hahm Ji Bach is a robust Korean family-style barbecue on 149th Place in Flushing, Queens, with room for 150 diners and tables with built-in grills. But during the World Cup, especially when South Korea is playing, Ham Ji Bach bustles with people indulging together, as well as single eaters with giant portions at tables for one.

title: Ed Sheeran and Sam Smith, British Pop Imports
description: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the young English singers.

title: In C, and Many Other Keys
description: To celebrate the 50th anniversary of Terry Rileys In C, the seminal Minimalist score that has become virtually a standard repertory work, at least in New York  hardly a season goes by without at least one performance  11 composers have joined forces to write companion works built around the other notes of the chromatic scale.

title: Charles Barsotti, Cartoonist With Humor Both Simple and Absurd, Dies at 80
description: Charles Barsotti, a cartoonist for The New Yorker whose jaded canines, outlaw snails and obtuse monarchs made readers laugh for more than 40 years, died on Monday at his home in Kansas City, Mo. He was 80.

title: S.E.C.s Mary Jo White Seeks to Shine Light Into Opaque Bond Markets
description: Updated, 6:49 p.m. | The Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking to shine a light on trades in the relatively opaque markets for corporate and municipal bonds.

title: The House Actually Did Something About Warrantless Surveillance
description: In an unusual display of unity from the divided, do-nothing House, a bipartisan group of lawmakers pushed through a bill that basically says, yes, the Fourth Amendment applies to electronic communications, too.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: General in Sex Case to Retire With a 2-Rank Demotion
description: Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair, whose extramarital relationship with a subordinate officer led to charges of sexual assault and a prosecution that ultimately collapsed and embarrassed the military, will retire as a lieutenant colonel, two grades lower than his current rank, the Army said Friday.

title: Popcast: Ed Sheeran and Sam Smith, British Pop Imports
description: Two young English pop singers, Ed Sheeran and Sam Smith, both enthusiastically welcomed in the United States, have ambitious new records.

title: Calculated Risks: Hillary Rodham Clintons Hard Choices
description: In 1969, the night before a Wellesley College senior named Hillary Rodham gave a commencement address that would draw national attention, she was introduced to Dean Acheson, the legendary former secretary of state who had come to campus for his granddaughters graduation. Im looking forward to hearing what you have to say, Acheson told Rodham. At the time, many in the country were looking forward to hearing what Acheson had to say. He had just put the finishing touches on Present at the Creation, his landmark memoir that would come out a few months after his encounter with the young Rodham, providing a seminal portrait of his role in helping Harry S. Truman forge a new national security architecture at the outset of the Cold War.

title: Number of French Jews Emigrating to Israel Rises
description: PARIS  For Tiffany Taieb Nizard, the decision to abandon France for Israel came this month when a French-born man was accused of gunning down four people at the Jewish Museum in Brussels in an anti-Semitic attack.

title: Trumping the First Choice
description: The cover review this week wasnt our original choice  we had an entirely different plan at the ready, a review of something else, already edited with the illustration assigned  and then the review of the novel Song of the Shank by Jeffery Renard Allen came in, less than a week before we had to go to press.Mitchell S. Jackson, whose first novel, The Residue Years, came out last year, had written a total rave, calling Allens book the kind of imaginative work only a prodigiously gifted risk-taker could produce. It was an interesting match between reviewer and author because, as the assigning editor Gregory Cowles explained, Their novels are very different  Jacksons was contemporary and seemingly autobiographical, while Allens is on the face of it neither of those. But both are voice-driven and beautifully written, and both play with contemporary ideas about family, race, class and the long legacy of slavery.

title: Hoofbeats and Ocean Views in Brooklyn
description: In a city where dogs are carried around in purses, it seems amazing to find that Susan Gallahue, 64, keeps a horse. Not in her apartment on the Upper West Side, of course, but at the bucolic Jamaica Bay Riding Academy in Bergen Beach, Brooklyn, where she visits Silver Palace, her Thoroughbred-warmblood mix, about four times a week. Ms. Gallahue, a full-time psychiatric nurse, looks forward to every visit with Silver, a retired show-jumping mare she says has the best personality.

title: N.F.L. Collusion Case Reinstated on Appeal
description: A federal appeals court reinstated a case brought by the N.F.L. Players Association, which has accused N.F.L. owners of collusion by creating a secret salary cap in the 2010 season.

title: Palestinians Hold Funeral for Boy Killed
description: Hundreds attended a funeral procession in the village of Dura for a Palestinian teenager killed by Israeli troops in the West Bank during search operations for three missing Israeli teens.

title: A Revue of Pop Songs as Catchy as Poison Ivy
description: Creating a Broadway revue around a songwriting duo who specialized in pop music was a novel idea back in 1995, when Smokey Joes Cafe: The Songs of Leiber and Stoller made its debut. But it worked. The musical, based on the work of Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller, ran for nearly five years, showcasing such beloved tunes as Dance With Me, Kansas City, Hound Dog and There Goes My Baby.

title: Letting Go of Sykes-Picot
description: Earlier this week I quoted David Frum, usually more hawkish than I, on the theme that American interests in Iraq might be better pursued by looking for solid ground in, say, Kurdistan than by trying to help Iran stabilize the Sunni Triangle or replaying the Diem drama with our new batch of military advisers and Nouri al-Maliki. Now Jeffrey Goldberg, also usually more hawkish than I, has written a follow-up to the 2008 essay I cited in my Sunday column, on the Middle Easts potential post-Iraq War map, which circles around to a similar conclusion:

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $11.75 Million, With a Tycoon for a Neighbor
description: A full-floor residence at One Madison, the sylphlike bronze-and-glass tower at 23 East 22nd Street that has inspired a defection of high-rollers, including the media mogul Rupert Murdoch, from less avant-garde locales uptown, sold for $11.75 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Polar Exploration Inside an Insurance Office
description: There was Kevin Spacey. There was a weird dream about an out-of-control copy machine. And there was the unraveling of the economy in 2008. All played a part in the creation of Endurance, a 90-minute theatrical mash-up in which grumbling insurance workers morph into chantey-singing polar explorers, office furniture subs for a doughty wooden icebreaker, and a light switch conveys audiences at the Long Wharf Theater from a standard-issue Hartford workplace to the shifting ice floes of Antarctica and back again.

title: Driven | 2014 Buick Regal Turbo
description: The old slogan Wouldnt you really rather have a Buick means something again.

title: Video: The 2014 Buick Regal Turbo Is Fun for All Ages
description: Baby boomers know Buick as an automotive brand favored by their parents (or grandparents). Jingles that purred Wouldnt you really rather have a Buick? during The Ed Sullivan Show didnt work on the generation raised on Barbie, Hot Wheels and the Beatles. They ended up preferring to have a Lexus. Or an Audi. Or a BMW.

title: I.R.S. Head Testifies on Tea Party Query
description: John Koskinen, the Internal Revenue Service commissioner, clashed with lawmakers over missing emails during a heated House hearing on the tax agencys scrutiny of Tea Party-aligned political groups.

title: Japanese Report Casts Doubt on Admission of Wartime Sexual Coercion
description: TOKYO  A group of government-appointed Japanese scholars seemed to raise doubts about the accuracy of a landmark 1993 apology to women forced to work in military brothels during World War II, in a finding that could worsen tensions between Japan and South Korea over wartime history.

title: America, Online: Love for Hoppers Nighthawks
description: The plan to fill 50,000 billboards, in all 50 states, with American art works this summer is moving closer to completion. Starting in April, art fans voted for their favorites from among 100 works posted on the ArtEverywhereUS.org website. Voting was closed in early May, and the museums announced the 58 winning works on Friday.

title: New York Senate Passes Bill on Medical Marijuana
description: ALBANY  The New York Senate passed a bill legalizing access to medical marijuana on Friday, a day after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders announced the agreement on a seven-year pilot program to provide the drug to sick New Yorkers.

title: A New, Eclectic Tour of Reykjavik
description: Have a layover in Iceland, but not sure what to do? Theres a new walking tour aimed at introducing travelers  particularly those on stopovers in Iceland  to the locals side of Reykjavik.

title: Affordable Island in the Sun
description: Gus Christensen was, until six months ago, a managing director at Evercore Partners, the boutique investment bank, a position preceded by stints at JP Morgan and Goldman Sachs and an education at Wharton. Some years ago, befitting that profile, he was a Republican; but eventually the religion of the free market lost its hold on him, so much so that his politics migrated aggressively to the left. Last week he posted on Twitter a link to a tabloid piece about a billionaire who was buying a $70 million pied--terre for his children at 740 Park Avenue, with the hashtag #Signoftheapocalypse.

title: Health Insurers Pressing Down on Drug Prices
description: In dealing with health plans, drug companies are facing a new imperative  bargain or be banned.

title: Wall Streets Latest Must-Have? A Volcker Helper
description: The next accessory desired by top Wall Street traders may not be swanky cufflinks or a Swiss watch.

title: Rangers Buy Out Richardss Contract
description: Brad Richards was admired by everyone on the Rangers, including the man who decided to let him go, General Manager Glen Sather.

title: Wheelies: The Sonata Eco Edition
description: A roundup of motor news from the web:

title: Clothes That Made the Mans Mark
description: The tormented yet indissoluble relationship between Yves Saint Laurent and his life and business partner, Pierre Berg, is the governing narrative of Jalil Lesperts Yves Saint Laurent, a biopic about that French fashion designer that opens in New York on June 25. But the life of Saint Laurent, who died in 2008, can also be traced through a parallel narrative: that of the clothes he designed. Between his first collection in 1957 and his retirement in 2002, he changed the way modern women dressed, often prefiguring social change by bringing street and exotic influences to conventional wear, and showing women as newly powerful figures in trousers, trench coats and tuxedos.

title: U.N. Leader Deplores Syria Wars Spread to Iraq
description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on Friday drew attention to perhaps the bleakest chapter of his tenure at the United Nations: the three-year-old war in Syria, and now the prospective unraveling of the region along sectarian lines.

title: Grand Central Food Hall Proposal Nears Approval
description: The cavernous and elegant Vanderbilt Hall, in Grand Central Terminal, has recently been home to many temporary displays, holiday retail shops and private events. Now it is moving one step closer to housing its first permanent installation, a food hall and a fine-dining restaurant that would be run by Claus Meyer, the founder of Noma in Copenhagen, considered one of the worlds best.

title: After the Storm, 20 Months in Limbo
description: One after another, caseworkers entered the small, stuffy Downtown Brooklyn conference room  the court of last resort.

title: A Bicoastal Romance That Got a Big Kickstart
description: One would think that someone creative enough to write jokes for television shows would have no trouble finding ways to fill his spare time.

title: A Grandeur That Eclipses the Grotesque
description: WASHINGTON  The fellow with a third leg really appears to have that extra appendage, the lizard man sports scary scales, and the hermaphrodite seems to be split down the middle in the new production of Side Show at the Kennedy Center here. As they lumber, slither or caper forth in the opening number of this 1997 musical, creating a macabre pageant of human oddity, it becomes clear that what we will be seeing is less a revival than a full-scale reimagining of this show, which drew mixed reviews and closed after a few months on Broadway in its first incarnation, while quickly acquiring a cult following among, er, musical-theater freaks.

title: Drugs Not Covered by Express Scripts and CVS Caremark
description: Express Scripts (E.S.I.) and CVS Caremark, the nations two largest pharmacy benefits companies, have gotten drug manufacturers to offer greater discounts and rebates by refusing to pay for certain drugs, forcing companies to bid against one another.

title: A Central American Mouse Roars
description: RECIFE, Brazil  There was less than 20 minutes left to play here on Friday when a bundle of three balloons  red, white and green, the colors of Italys flag  floated down from the stands and onto the field.

title: Booksellers Score Some Points in Amazons Spat With Hachette
description: Robert Sindelar, the bearded, redheaded managing partner at the Seattle independent bookseller Third Place Books  definitely a David to Amazons Goliath  got the idea to take on Amazon while attending BookExpo America in New York a few weeks ago.

title: G.E.s Pyrrhic Victory
description: Theres a paradox in General Electrics French triumph. The conglomerate is finally getting Alstoms energy businesses, having seen off German nemesis Siemens and reached an accommodation with a hostile French government. Yet some other players won clearer victories.

title: Fifty Million Displaced People
description: When it comes to Iraq, the international focus is largely on the Islamic militants who have seized a huge swath of the country and are moving toward Baghdad.

title: Events in Westchester for June 22-28, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Olivier Theyskens Leaves Theory, Gisele Replaces Kate Moss and Kendall Jenner Is Here to Stay
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Whither Yo?
description: Its hard to talk about Yo. The app is so simple (it lets users send the word Yo to each other) that even to mock it feels like taking it too seriously  come on guys, its just Yo! Luckily, hackers have made things easier on all of us by making Yo do some new tricks.

title: Odd and Original, Yes. Appetizing? Maybe Not.
description: A certain barbecued blandness can infest food programs at this time of year. Frankenfood, a spunky series that begins on Sunday night on Spike, puts variety back on the plate, with ridiculous, sometimes gag-inducing results.

title: House Ethics Panel Orders Alaska Republican to Pay Fine
description: WASHINGTON  The House Ethics Committee on Friday ordered Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska, to pay a fine of almost $60,000 for using campaign money for personal purposes and for accepting impermissible gifts.

title: Chinese Company Demands Edits to New Transformers Movie
description: LOS ANGELES  The China woes are not over yet for Michael Bays latest Transformers film, Age of Extinction.

title: Raising a Glass to Chile
description: One of the great pleasures of the World Cup every four years is in the underdogs. When a smaller, poorer country vanquishes a larger, richer one, it is something to cheer, perhaps even when you happen to live in that larger, richer country.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Agricultural Output Climbed in 2013, Recovering From Drought
description: AGRICULTURE is a small part of the United States economy, but last year it was the best part.

title: Clintons Cough Was Really a Gasp
description: Hillary Clinton has apparently gotten over her allergies.

title: Saying No to Austerity, Spain Unveils Tax Cuts
description: MADRID  Turning its back on fiscal austerity, the Spanish government presented a broad package of income and corporate tax cuts on Friday that are scheduled to begin before next years general election.

title: Harleys Electric Prototype
description: A look at the Harley-Davidson electric motorcycle prototype.

title: Hi, Mom, Im Home!
description: One in five young adults lives with his or her parents. Is this a recessionary blip or the dawn of a whole new economic age?

title: Ecuador vs. Honduras: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: After taking a lead on Switzerland, Ecuador was disappointed to lose. Based on its downright bad performance against France, Honduras may be just the cure.

title: The Case for ISIS, Made in a British Accent
description: Apparently seeking to capitalize on the wave of news coverage that has accompanied their recent gains on the battlefield in Iraq, militants from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS, released a recruitment video online late Thursday aimed at persuading Muslims in the West to abandon their comfortable lives and embrace jihad.

title: Lullabies by Caruso Ignited a Love of Opera in Brooklyn
description: When Nina DiGregorio was a baby in the 1920s, her mother would wind up the phonograph and play opera records.

title: Our Moral Tongue
description: ON June 20, 2003, employees of the Union Pacific Railroad faced a difficult decision as a runaway train headed toward downtown Los Angeles: Should they divert the train to a side track, knowing it would derail and hit homes in the less populated city of Commerce, Calif.? Did the moral imperative to minimize overall harm outweigh the moral imperative not to intentionally harm an innocent suburb?

title: Using Microsoft OneDrive for Photo Backup
description: Q. The Microsoft OneDrive app on my Android phone once asked if I wanted to back up my photos automatically and I said no, but now Ive reconsidered. How can I get back to that screen again?

title: Deep in the Amazon, an Isolated Village Tunes In to the World Cup
description: MANAUS, Brazil  The PP Maus would not set sail for an hour, but its long and narrow decks were already crisscrossed with hammocks for an overnight trip down the Amazon.

title: In Colorado, a Brewers Festival Toasts an Anniversary
description: The Colorado Brewers Festival will celebrate its 25th anniversary this month in Fort Collins, Colo., a place where the thirst for craft beer is alive, kicking and growing. This years festival brings 13 new breweries to the tasting tables, offering a total of close to 120 different brews, including its first group of hard ciders.

title: The Collections | The Top Five Spring/Summer 2015 Mens Wear Shows in London
description: In a city where anything goes, at least in terms of fashion, the most impressive shows in London Collections: Men were the ones that proposed new silhouettes and ideas, yet were still grounded in reality. These five designers accomplished that delicate balance and introduced wearable spring/summer 2015 collections that would look as at home on the street as on the runway.

title: Josh Earnests First Briefing: A Few Observations
description: WASHINGTON  After striding to the famous lectern for his highly anticipated first briefing as the White House press secretary on Friday, Josh Earnest quickly did what his predecessors have turned into an art form: He lowered expectations.

title: Packed With Technology, Prepped for Hyperbole
description: Pull up to the 7-Eleven in this car and you feel like Leonard Bernstein arriving at Lincoln Center. Ride in the back and youre escorting Julie Andrews to the Oscars. The doors are substantial enough to repel anything Occupy Wall Street throws at them, and its effortlessly powerful enough to outrun any S.E.C. subpoena. The 2014 Mercedes-Benz S550 4Matic sedan is so advanced it should be in geosynchronous orbit over Gstaad.

title: Hi, Im a Tablet. Ill Be Your Waiter Tonight.
description: BRAINTREE, Mass.  An idea came to Ronald M. Shaich, the chief executive of Panera Bread, as he was driving his children to school about four years ago: What if everyone could order lunch the way he did?

title: Taking a Spin: Republicans Win Despite Some Disappointment
description: The Republicans retake control of the Senate in this weeks spin of Leos Senate wheels, our weekly illustration of the uncertainty that remains with so much time until Novembers elections. But two red-state Democrats defy the Republican sweep.

title: Next Stop, India: Full Steam Ahead
description: If you are a lover of street food, India is the place to be. Outrageously delicious snacks, of which there are countless thousands, beckon from every corner.

title: How to Translate Dppelgangers Into Hindi: Just Keep Adding Characters
description: At the beginning of the awful Bollywood comedy Humshakals, our handsome billionaire hero pursues his passion: stand-up. Hes awful. His jokes are infantile, his style eager to please but clueless.

title: Commander in Chief With Idealism Untarnished
description: Ideally, the president should be relatively smart. In the premiere of his new series on the Hub Network, Kid President proves himself smart enough to know that no one can take an unbroken half-hour of the chirpy observations that have brought him Internet fame.

title: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
description: Photos from the West Bank, Iraq, Ukraine and Yemen.

title: Week in Pictures for June 20
description: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes a memorial in the Bronx and more than one hot day.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Woods Set to Return From Surgery
description: So much for the speculation that Tiger Woods would be sidelined the rest of the year after having back surgery in March. Woods announced Friday on his Facebook page that he would make his first competitive start in nearly four months at next weeks Quicken Loans National, which benefits the foundation that bears his name.

title: Patrick Huang Introduces a Bridge Deal
description: The Longevity Valley 2nd Asia Cup Bridge Championships in Wuyi Qingshuiwan, China, will end on Sunday.

title: New Yorks Not-So-Perfect Medical Marijuana Law
description: New York is finally joining the ranks of states that allow the use of marijuana for medical purposes, becoming the 23rd in the nation to do so. Too bad Governor Cuomo, who held the upper hand in bargaining because of his veto power, forced legislators to accept so many restrictions that the law will be a lot less useful than it could have been. The legislation has passed both chambers and is awaiting the governors signature.

title: A Ride Across America | Soccer, Bourbon and a Very Special Farm in Missouri
description: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, theyll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

title: Reinventing Emily Gould
description: Emily Gould stood posing for a photograph on West 29th Street in front of the building where she works, wearing a stone-colored cardigan, her hair scraped back into a messy ponytail, her only concession to vanity a slash of red lipstick applied with apparent indifference.

title: A Civil War Skirmish, Fought With Badinage
description: ITS HARD TO CATEGORIZE Butler, a new play being staged by the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch. Its part comedy, part historical drama and part biography, often all at once, and sometimes none of those. Yet the show is easy enough to review. Just call it splendid.

title: Law to Impose Tough Limits on Sales of Ivory Art
description: To the chagrin of New York antiques dealers, lawmakers in Albany have voted to outlaw the sale of virtually all items containing more than small amounts of elephant ivory, mammoth ivory or rhinoceros horn. The legislation, which is backed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, will essentially eliminate New Yorks central role in a well-established, nationwide trade with an estimated annual value of $500 million.

title: A Night Out With Jenny Slate of Obvious Child
description: The actress Jenny Slate arrived at a panel discussion for her new film, Obvious Child, Tuesday night, where the first person she saw was a woman who reminded her of her grandmother.

title: But Can They Write Fashion Code?
description: On a brisk Thursday afternoon, Peter Semple strode purposefully through Googles Chelsea offices looking for a quiet place to discuss his latest project. I havent slept in the last four days, Mr. Semple said, bypassing the cafeteria, which was blasting En Vogue, in favor of a curtained-off conference room with a large lime-green armchair at the head of its table.

title: Swim in Bronx River Kills Boy, 13; Another Is Hospitalized
description: One 13-year-boy died and another was in critical condition on Friday after they went swimming in the Bronx River and had to be pulled from the water by emergency divers, according to the Police Department.

title: Amy Alkons Crusade Against Rudeness
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  Please let me be on time for the maniacal manners lady. I dont want her to scold me. Please, pretty please, dont let me be late.

title: To the Sea in Ships, as Naughty as Ever
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The drag queen Persia, in full bejeweled regalia, went out on one of the first rafts, sloping down the launch ramp in thigh-high red stiletto boots.

title: Translating English Protocol for a Wider Audience
description: It was a breach of protocol few of the two billion viewers of the royal wedding would have spotted, but the etiquette expert Alexandra Messervy noticed the faux pas immediately.

title: Four Guys With Swords and Morals
description: Certain stories never get old, and certain people never tire of rewriting them.

title: Marilyn Monroes Photo Caper in Poland
description: A trove of Marilyn Monroe photos by Milton H. Greene is being auctioned in Poland this week. How the photos got there  and how they will be sold  is worthy of a madcap caper.

title: Evening Hours | Warming Up
description: Opening doors for celebration and whimsy in gardens.

title: Flight Prep: The 2014 Mercedes-Benz S550
description: Mercedes-Benzs big luxury sedan glides into the future with high ambitions that are seamlessly executed.

title: For His Second Act, a Hot Rod Builder Turns Back the Clock
description: STAMFORD, CONN.  So this is it, Dennis Wuchiski says as he opens the door to what is possibly the cleanest garage this side of the McLaren Formula One racecar operation in Britain.

title: Hot Rod Hideaway
description: Dennis Wuchiskis home garage in Stamford, Conn., is both a dream shop and a display case for a lover of Ford hot rods.

title: Bill Cunningham | Great, Gatsby
description: Nearly 10,000 people attended the Jazz Age Lawn Party on Governors Island, many in costume.

title: Bill Cunningham | Jazz Age Lawn Party
description: The ninth annual Jazz Age Lawn Party took place last weekend on Governors Island with Michael Arenella and his Dreamland Orchestra. Mr. Arenella, founder of the event, paid for it himself at first, and the earliest parties drew a few hundred people. Last weekend, nearly 10,000 attended, many in costume.

title: Readers Respond: Love and Hate for Guns and Video Games
description: Discussions about the right to own a gun in real life can become quite a debate. It turns out that talking about the right to bear arms in video games can be an equally hot topic.

title: Not Your Average Garage
description: A peek at Dennis Wuchiskis custom 1932 Ford, which took him 18 years to build.

title: Under Cover: A Boomerang Kid Documents His Generation
description: The June 22 cover story about boomerang kids features photographs taken by Damon Casarez, who graduated from the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, Calif., with $120,000 in student debt. Eventually, his loan payments became unmanageable, and he moved in with his parents. The discomfort of sleeping on the living-room couch and readjusting to his parents house rules inspired Casarez to reach out to others like him. I did this project because it was something that I knew and something that I thought needed to be talked about, Casarez says. He recently discussed how his circumstances influenced his portrait-taking.

title: They Are the World: A Psychedelic Rock Ritual
description: The Swedish band Goat calls its concerts rituals, and thats how it performed on Wednesday night at Webster Hall: as a psychedelic rock ritual of rhythm, motion, hypnotic repetition and ecstatic drive. The men in the band were masked or hooded, in a mlange of ethnic clothes. The two female singers up front, dancing and shaking assorted percussion instruments, were post-hippie celebrants in colorful dresses, wearing feathered headdresses above their own glittery masks. No one spoke to the audience: The songs arrived on their own, droning and pounding, wailing with guitar solos and churning with funk.

title: Pickups Wearing Camo, but Not to Blend In
description: Hot competition among pickups has inspired automakers to seek every possible edge, in style as well as technology. So like such disparate trendsetters as downtown club kids and Duck Dynasty fans, trucks are now stepping out in camouflage.

title: All These Darlings and Now Us
description: A waterborne installation in San Francisco combines performance art, urban resistance and a sex-positive philosophy.

title: The Clubs That Connect The World Cup
description: The global tournament is mostly a remix of the professional leagues that are in season most of the time. See which professional clubs have the most players on the most World Cup teams.

title: Why Are We Importing Our Own Fish?
description: IN 1982 a Chinese aquaculture scientist named Fusui Zhang journeyed to Marthas Vineyard in search of scallops. The New England bay scallop had recently been domesticated, and Dr. Zhang thought the Vineyard-grown shellfish might do well in China. After a visit to Lagoon Pond in Tisbury, he boxed up 120 scallops and spirited them away to his lab in Qingdao. During the journey 94 died. But 26 thrived. Thanks to them, today China now grows millions of dollars of New England bay scallops, a significant portion of which are exported back to the United States.

title: Toughest Issues Still Unresolved in Iran Nuclear Talks
description: VIENNA  Negotiations with Iran over its disputed nuclear program entered their brinkmanship phase on Friday, with the toughest issues still unresolved a month before the deadline for a final agreement.

title: Beautiful Game Played With a Gacho Flair in Southern Brazil
description: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil  Tell me how you play, and I will tell you who you are.

title: Streaming Eagles
description: THERE was a situation with some bald eagles on the Internet the other day. The drama played out in a large, disheveled nest somewhere in Minnesota, in front of a camera that had been streaming the lives of those birds onto the Internet for the last two years.

title: Youre Not Really Wearing That to School?
description: To the Editor:

title: Biden Adviser Leaving Washington, but It May Not Be for Long
description: WASHINGTON  When Jake Sullivan leaves Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.s staff in August to teach at Yale Law School this fall, he will join a familiar Washington subculture: the battle-scarred White House alumnus, desperate to sample a normal life before deciding whether to jump back into the maelstrom of the next political cycle.

title: Klinghoffer: The Opera and the Furor
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Kind of Church, Led by Pope Francis
description: To the Editor:

title: The Solstice Blues
description: IN mid-June, the twilight seems to go on forever, the sky awash with translucent shades of rose, pearl, gray. These are evenings of enchantment  but also of apprehension. The moment the sun reaches its farthest point north of the Equator today is the moment the light starts to fade, waning more each day for the following six months. If the summer solstice doesnt signal the arrival of winter, surely it heralds the gradual lessening of light, and with that, often, an incremental decline in disposition.

title: Candys Dandy, but Pots Scary
description: WE know that occasionally people react badly to marijuana. Some withdraw into anxious, glassy silence. Some responses are more horrifying. In a recent, much discussed case, a Denver man bought cannabis-infused Karma Kandy and hours later  perhaps after also taking prescription pain medication  began raving about the end of the world and killed his wife.

title: Cavaliers Are Said to Hire Israeli Coach David Blatt
description: A month after leading Maccabi Tel Aviv to the Euroleague championship, David Blatt agreed to a four-year deal to become the head coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers on Friday, according to a person with direct knowledge of the negotiations.

title: Missing Israeli Teenagers Revive a Mothers Hard-Earned Intimacy With Loss
description: TEKOA, West Bank  Sherri Mandell was toasting her daughters engagement with her future in-laws at her home in this Jewish settlement south of Jerusalem last Friday morning when she heard the news. After the first sip of sparkling white wine, the groom-to-be put down his glass. Im sorry, but we have to stop the party, Ms. Mandell recalled him saying. Something terrible has happened.

title: Stephanie L. Kwolek, Inventor of Kevlar, Is Dead at 90
description: Stephanie L. Kwolek, a DuPont chemist who invented the technology behind Kevlar, a virtually bulletproof fiber that has saved thousands of lives, died on Wednesday in Wilmington, Del. She was 90.

title: The Computer Will Now Take Your Order
description: Restaurants have been late to the tech revolution, and many are now scrambling to incorporate tablets, apps, computerized kitchen equipment and data analysis capabilities.

title: Collecting Catholics Everyday Stories as an Antidote to Scandals in the News
description: The sexual abuse scandal in the Roman Catholic Church broke into the news around 2000, just as Paul Elie was writing his book The Life You Save May Be Your Own. His topic was the intertwining friendships of four great Catholic thinkers and writers, some of the best people in his tradition: Dorothy Day, Walker Percy, Flannery OConnor and Thomas Merton.

title: Fighting Off the Coast of France
description: Sunday, June 19, 1864, the C.S.S. Alabama, a swift commerce raider carrying eight guns, steamed out of Cherbourg harbor, prepared to battle the U.S.S. Kearsarge, a sloop of war of similar size and firepower.

title: Nrburgring 24-Hour Race Draws Huge Entry
description: Nrburg, Germany  An automotive clambake of enormous proportions has assembled here this weekend for the 42nd running of the Nrburgring 24-hour race, an endurance contest whose demanding course includes the fabled section known as Nordschleife.

title: Royalties and Teaching Help Fill Bank Accounts of Justices, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  Financial disclosure reports released by the Supreme Court on Friday showed that book royalties continued to fill the bank accounts of certain justices, while most bolstered their incomes with teaching assignments.

title: After a Career Peak at Wimbledon, a Long Fall and a Clouded Future
description: ROEHAMPTON, England  A year ago, Steve Darcis, a Belgian who was ranked 135th, stunned Rafael Nadal in the first round of Wimbledon, ending the 22-match winning streak of Nadal, the two-time champion from Spain. Darcis sealed the 7-6 (4), 7-6 (8), 6-4 victory with an ace, bringing the crowd of 11,429 at No. 1 Court to its feet.

title: Hackers Take Down World Cup Site in Brazil
description: Hackers on Friday made good on their threat to take down the 2014 World Cup site in Brazil.

title: FIFA Looking Into Possible Use of Gay Slur by Mexican Fans
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  FIFA has opened disciplinary proceedings against the Mexico team for what it has called the improper conduct of spectators at the World Cup.

title: Judge Blocks Evidence in Goldman Code Theft Case
description: The curious case of Sergey Aleynikov  the former Goldman Sachs programmer who was criminally convicted, then acquitted and then charged again  has taken yet another surprising turn.

title: Presbyterians Vote to Divest Holdings to Pressure Israel
description: DETROIT  After passionate debate over how best to help break the deadlock between Israel and the Palestinians, the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) voted on Friday at its general convention to divest from three companies that it says supply Israel with equipment used in the occupation of Palestinian territory.

title: U.N. Chief Served Papers in Suit by Haitian Victims, Lawyers Say
description: The United Nations has been resisting, successfully so far, lawsuits from Haiti cholera victims who assert that United Nations peacekeepers caused the 2010 epidemic still ravaging the country. But on Friday, lawyers for the plaintiffs said, something new happened: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon was personally served with court papers ordering him to appear, an assertion that his spokesman denied.

title: Administration Takes Steps to Aid Bees
description: The White House announced new initiatives on Friday to promote the health of honeybees and other pollinators, which have suffered enormous losses in recent years. The memorandum, signed by President Obama, called for research into the causes of the severe decline and the role of pesticides, and formed a pollinator health task force of more than 14 federal agencies, saying, It is critical to expand federal efforts and take new steps to reverse pollinator losses and help restore populations to healthy levels. Erich Pica, president of the environmental group Friends of the Earth, said the administration does not go far enough to address pesticide issues.

title: Weekend Auto Calendar: Camaros of the World Unite, in Maryland
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

title: Report Calls for Tracking Data on Stress Disorder
description: The Department of Defense and the Veterans Affairs Department should track their efforts to treat post-traumatic stress more carefully, to see how effective those efforts are, a government-sponsored report released Friday said. The report, from an expert panel assembled by the Institute of Medicine, noted that the agencies spend more than $3.3 billion annually on treatment of the disorder, which affects more than 500,000 veterans, including 8 percent of those who served in Iraq or Afghanistan  who are twice as likely to seek help as veterans of previous wars. It affirms the findings of a report published in 2012 that called for more careful tracking. The V.A. has tracked symptoms in some members given treatment, but it is not clear how many and whether those veterans are in fact improving, experts said. Given that the D.O.D. and V.A. are responsible for serving millions of service members, families and veterans, we found it surprising that no PTSD outcome measures are used consistently to know if these treatments are working or not, the chairman of the panel, Sandro Galea of Columbia University, said in a statement.

title: Rangel and Espaillat Discuss Foreign Affairs as House Primary Nears
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel and his top challenger, State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat, debated international issues on Friday in one of the final pushes for votes in the Democratic primary for the 13th Congressional District seat.

title: After Stumbles, Rangel Finds Some Level Ground
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel clambered up two flights of stairs into Public School 132 in Washington Heights to meet with parents on Tuesday, the second of a half-dozen stops on a full day of campaigning.

title: Googles Nest to Acquire Dropcam for $555 Million
description: Nest Labs, a maker of digital thermostats, announced Friday evening that it planned to buy another fast-growing producer of home devices, Dropcam, for $555 million in cash.

title: Lights Went Out, but He Kept Playing
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The team doctor stepped away from his patient and motioned to the coaches on the far sideline. He rolled his hands one over the other, the signal that the stumbling player beside him, Uruguay midfielder lvaro Pereira, would have to be substituted.

title: In Refugee Statistics, a Stark Tale of Global Strife
description: Statistics are not usually effective at depicting tragedy, which is why United Nations reports rarely generate passion. But the figures released this past week by the United Nations refugee agency offer perhaps the starkest reflection of the strife raking vast stretches of the globe.

title: Every Senior V.A. Executive Was Rated Fully Successful or Better Over 4 Years
description: All of the 470 senior executives at the Department of Veterans Affairs received annual ratings over the last four years indicating that they were fully successful in their jobs or even better, according to data released at a congressional hearing on Friday, despite delays in processing disability compensation claims and problems with veterans access to the departments sprawling health care system.

title: Health Site Is Changing Supervision
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration hired a top executive from the UnitedHealth Group on Friday to bolster management of the federal health insurance marketplace and to prevent a repetition of the chaos that engulfed the program last fall.

title: Patience and Crib Notes Help as Wie Moves Into Open Lead
description: PINEHURST, N.C.  Michelle Wie did her homework this week.

title: Officials Plan Adjustments as New York City Slows to 25 M.P.H.
description: Mayor Bill de Blasios traffic safety push yielded perhaps its most significant change early on Friday, when the State Legislature approved a plan to reduce the default speed limit in New York City to 25 miles per hour.

title: Amateurism and the N.C.A.A.
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  It was Thursday of Week 2 at the OBannon trial, the day Mark Emmert, the president of the N.C.A.A., was going to be on the stand.

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: A Settlement in the Central Park Jogger Case
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio acted in the interest of justice when his administration agreed to pay about $40 million to the five black and Hispanic men wrongly convicted in the brutal beating and rape of a white, female jogger in Central Park in 1989. If the settlement is approved by the city comptroller and a federal court, it will bring to a close one of the more shameful and racially divisive episodes in New York City history.

title: Adventurous Couple Arrive in New York From Africa, Merrily, Merrily
description: Riaan Manser and Vasti Geldenhuys, a fun-loving couple from Cape Town, have been together for 14 years, so when Ms. Geldenhuys, 36, suggested a vacation, he was agreeable.

title: On Immigration, the Hard Lines Start to Blur
description: FARMERS BRANCH, Tex.  Halfway through an evening of campaigning for mayor of this Dallas suburb, David Koch met a Colombian immigrant who had just moved in. Well, welcome to the town, he said, adding after friendly chatter: Why did you pick Farmers Branch?

title: Iraq Insurgents Reaping Wealth as They Advance
description: BAGHDAD  When Qaeda-style insurgents overran the northern city of Mosul, among the war booty they seized were what they claimed were five American-made helicopters.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 20, 2014
Gov. Scott Walkers Campaign Violations
description: Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy promised in 2010 that there was nothing to fear from independent spending groups that raised unlimited dollars. Because they could not coordinate with political candidates, he wrote in the Citizens United decision, they do not give rise to corruption or the appearance of corruption.

title: De Blasios Vow to Ease Reimbursement for Special Education Halts a Bill in Albany
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio has promised to make it easier for some parents of special-needs children to get New York City to pay for private school tuition, holding off an effort by state legislators to make him do so by law.

title: No Doping at the World Cup? Thats What FIFA Says
description: RIO dE JANEIRO  So far in this World Cup, not a single player has tested positive for a performance-enhancing drug.

title: In Tournament Packed With Goals, France Stuffs in Five More
description: SALVADOR, Brazil  It was a gorgeous, ruthless finish from Karim Benzema: a perfectly timed swing of the right leg on the move from the French striker that put the ball into the upper-left corner of the Switzerland goal.

title: The Heavy Burden of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder
description: Post-traumatic stress disorder has reached staggering levels in the American military. An estimated 7 percent to 20 percent of all service members and veterans who have served in the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq may have the disorder, and rising percentages of veterans from earlier conflicts are also afflicted.

title: El Greco, After Age 36
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  If there is anything that unnerves me more than realizing that I am about to sit down and solve a Saturday New York Times puzzle, its realizing that I am about to sit down and solve a Saturday New York Times puzzle under Brad Wilbers and Byron Waldens bylines. A hard puzzle is one thing; a hard puzzle by two of the toughest constructors in crossword puzzledom is wholly another.

title: Twisty, Grindy and Brightly Hued
description: Robert Battle, the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, is fond of flattering his audience. During his preshow speech at the David H. Koch Theater on Thursday, he encouraged the spectators to applaud themselves. Look at you! he said, before humorously noting the usefulness of the phrase and how it can be directed at people who arent actually looking that good.

title: On Duty, Patrolling the Projects; Off Duty, Exorcising Demons
description: The worried woman described the bizarre goings-on at her home in the Bronx, which she suspected was haunted, to the police officer standing before her. He was off duty, there on his own time. If she was braced for a gentle pat on the shoulder and a brushoff, she was in for a surprise.

title: Aid Scarce as Pakistanis Flee Conflict
