description: To the Editor:

title: When Migration to the U.S. Is Driven by Rumors
description: To the Editor:

title: Online Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: Warning: Tired Drivers Ahead
description: To the Editor:

title: Slavery and Thai Seafood
description: To the Editor:

title: Yair Levy
description: Mr. Levy, 64, sold or lost many of his holdings during the recession and was banned from selling real estate securities in New York after being convicted of dipping into a reserve fund at 225 Rector Place, a condo conversion. He maintained that any money taken was used on the building.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT LEASE

title: At Christies London Auction, Little Action
description: LONDON  In a hushed salesroom at Christies on Tuesday night, paintings and sculptures by Mondrian, Giacometti, Picasso and Pissarro failed to sell, and many things that did sell went for well below their estimates.

title: Capturing Employees Expertise on Camera Before They Hit the Exits
description: SEATTLE  Before a valuable employee quits a job, how does a company make sure a bit of his or her magic stays behind?

title: George Lucas Shifts Museum Plan to Chicago
description: The filmmaker George Lucas  who struggled to get permission from officials in San Francisco to build a private museum dedicated to his collection of illustrations, comic art, graphic art, animation and other popular art forms  will instead build the museum in Chicago, where he lives part time, said a spokeswoman for Mayor Rahm Emanuel in Chicago on Tuesday.

title: World Cup 2014: Argentina Defeats Nigeria, 3-2
description: Led by Lionel Messi, who scored two goals, Argentina topped the Group F with a 3-2 win over Nigeria, who also advanced.

title: World Cup 2014: Bosnia Defeats Iran, 3-1
description: Irans slim hopes came to an end and the Bosnians are left wondering what might have been had they played like this against Nigeria.

title: World Cup 2014: Switzerland Defeats Honduras, 3-0
description: The Swiss are through, with Ecuador drawing with France 0-0, and with those three points will take the second spot in Group E.

title: World Cup 2014: Ecuador and France Play to a 0-0 Draw
description: The French goal-scoring machine sputtered to a halt, but that did not do Ecuador any good as it was eliminated in the 0-0 draw.

title: Waiting in the Wings, a Ballerina to Save the Day
description: For the role of Odette-Odile in Swan Lake a dancer must achieve one of ballets most extreme transformations: from fragile and distant as the swan queen, Odette, to devilish and seductive as the antiheroine, Odile. On Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House, where American Ballet Theater began its weeklong run of the ballet, that metamorphosis was interrupted by a more real-world kind of fragility. An announcement at intermission informed us that because of an injury, Gillian Murphy, our leading lady thus far, would not complete the performance; Hee Seo would take her place, swooping in for the Black Swan pas de deux and Odettes final lakeside moments.

title: A Neo-Nazis Political Rise Exposes a German Citys Ethnic Tensions
description: DORTMUND, Germany  He is known here as SS-Siggi, and with his bulky frame and Germania tattoos, he certainly looks the part.

title: Oklahoma G.O.P. Nominates House Member to Replace Sen. Coburn
description: WASHINGTON  Oklahoma Republicans nominated Representative James Lankford for the Senate seat now held by Tom Coburn in a state that has not sent a Democrat to the Senate in three decades.

title: Breaking the Law to Go Online in Iran
description: WASHINGTON  WHEN Anthony Bourdain posted a cryptic message on Facebook at the end of May that he and his television crew would be off the social media grid for the next 10 days because they were truly going to #PartsUnknown, his fans around the world were intrigued. Was he shooting his CNN show (titled Parts Unknown) in a remote desert or on top of a snowy Himalayan peak?

title: Rethinking the Word Foodie
description: At a dinner party the other night where people were asked to say a word about themselves, one woman said, My name is  whatever it was  and Im a foodie. I cringed.

title: Errant Rocket in Gaza Is Said to Kill Girl, 3
description: GAZA  A 3-year-old Palestinian girl was killed, and three of her relatives were wounded Tuesday evening, apparently when a rocket aimed at Israel fell short and instead hit the familys home in the northern Gaza Strip.

title: Redskins Is Bad Business
description: ATLANTA, Ga.  THE moral arguments against the Washington Redskins team name, which is considered offensive to American Indians, are by now well known, especially in the wake of last weeks decision by the United States Patent and Trademark Office to strip the team of trademark protections.

title: Shift in Law on Disability and Students Shows Lapses
description: Fewer than a third of states and territories now comply with federal disability law under a change announced Tuesday in the way the Department of Education evaluates how well public schools educate students with disabilities.

title: When Nadal Is the Opponent at Wimbledon, a Hammer Is Required
description: WIMBLEDON, England  There was only one way that Martin Klizan was going to defeat Rafael Nadal on Center Court at Wimbledon on Tuesday.

title: Questions Rebels Use to Tell Sunni From Shiite
description: BAGHDAD  Whether a person is a Shiite or a Sunni Muslim in Iraq can now be, quite literally, a matter of life and death.

title: The Tappan Zee Bridge Loan
description: When it rains hard in New York, outdated municipal waste treatment plants often fail, sending untreated sewage into state waterways. Upgrading old plants and building new ones has long depended heavily on the federal Clean Water State Revolving Fund. It is capitalized with state and federal money, makes loans to needy municipalities and is constantly under pressure from budget-conscious legislators on Capitol Hill.

title: Indie Musics Digital Drag
description: The booze flowed freely in New York last week at the Libera Awards, a three-year-old alternative Grammys for the world of independent music, as awards went to prestige indie acts like Arcade Fire and Arctic Monkeys and executives at small labels congratulated one another about what a great year it was for their music.

title: Iran: Harvard Scholars Body Cremated After Request for Burial in Iran Falters
description: Richard Nelson Frye, a renowned Harvard scholar who wanted to be buried in Iran, a request that angered Iranian hard-liners, has been cremated by his family in Boston, the Iranian news media reported Tuesday. The Iranian Students News Agency quoted Dr. Fryes Iranian colleague Turaj Daryaii as saying the family had waited more than two months for official Iranian permission to bury him in Isfahan, the ancient capital of the Persian Empire, before deciding to cremate him on June 8. It was not clear what the family intended to do with his ashes. Dr. Frye, who died on March 27 at age 94, had dedicated his career to Irans culture and language, and he had written the burial request into his will. He was widely regarded in Iran as a friend, even among some conservatives, but his death coincided with growing resentment by Iranian hard-liners over signs of reconciliation with the United States after decades of estrangement. A month after Dr. Frye died, the leader of Friday Prayer in Isfahan denounced his burial request, calling him a spy and a robber of cultural artifacts.

title: France: Court Rules on End-of-Life Case
description: Frances highest administrative court, the Conseil dtat, ruledTuesdaythat a feeding tube could legally be removed from a 38-year-old man in a persistent vegetative state, whose care has been part of a long, bitter public fight involving the countrys end-of-life legislation. Before a 2008 accident left the man, Vincent Lambert, a former psychiatric nurse, paralyzed and unresponsive, he had repeatedly said he did not wish to be kept alive in such a condition, according to his wife and several family members, who have sought for him to be allowed to die. Given that, the court found that the feeding tube that has kept Mr. Lambert alive could be considered unreasonable medical obstinacy, and could be legally removed. Mr. Lamberts parents, who oppose that, have appealed to the European Court of Human Rights, and Mr. Lambert will be kept alive during the months or years of that courts examination of the case. French law prohibits any medical acts explicitly intended to end a patients life, but authorizes doctors to withdraw treatment or administer lethal doses of painkillers under certain circumstances.

title: Washington State to Require Approval of Packaging for Edible Marijuana Products
description: SEATTLE  Washington State will require its approval of all packaging for edible marijuana products, Gov. Jay Inslee said Tuesday, a pre-emptory move to ban cartoons, toy images and any other labels that might appeal to children.

title: De Blasio Offers Easier Access to City Money for Special Education
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio unveiled a series of changes on Tuesday to make it easier for special-needs students in New York to receive private schooling at public expense, a practice that has led to frequent litigation as the city has tried to keep such spending under control.

title: Woods Is Returning to Action, but Is No Longer in a Rush
description: BETHESDA, Md.  After all the best doctors and all the best aids put Tiger Woods back together again, he returns to competition knowing that he will have only one guide, one source of feedback.

title: Premium-Cigar Exemption Traced
description: Documents released by the federal governmenton Tuesdayprovided clues about how premium cigars got special treatment in federal tobacco regulations proposed recently. The rules, written by the Food and Drug Administration, originally subjected all cigars to federal regulation. But a proposal to exempt premium cigars surfaced after the rules were submitted to the White House for editing last year, the documents show. Matthew L. Myers, president of the Campaign for Tobacco Free Kids, an advocacy group, said an exemption, if made final, would set a troubling precedent for the future of tobacco regulation.

title: ISIS and SISI
description: The past month has presented the world with what the Israeli analyst Orit Perlov describes as the two dominant Arab governing models: ISIS and SISI.

title: Tea Party Mischief on Exports
description: In one of their odder quests, some Tea Party members have decided that the United States must shut down the Export-Import Bank of the United States, an obscure but important federal agency that helps American businesses sell their goods abroad.

title: Corruption Sweep at Rikers Island Leads to 22 Arrests
description: A sweep by law enforcement authorities at Rikers Island, part of a monthslong investigation into wrongdoing at the jail complex, led to the arrests of two correction officers on Monday night and more than 20 inmates on Tuesday, officials said.

title: Shinzo Abes Bid to Shake Up Corporate Japan
description: Even for the land that invented Toyota-style efficiency, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is on a tear. His ruling Liberal Democratic Party pushed 98 percent of its bills through Parliament, a success rate not seen in Japan for over a decade.

title: Refusals to Pay High Drug Prices
description: Pharmacy benefit managers are ramping up efforts to rein in the rising prices that drug makers are charging for some prescription medicines. The trend holds both promise and peril for patients who depend on the drugs to control their illnesses.

title: Guantnamo Detainee Rebuffed
description: A Federal District Court judge on Tuesday rejected a request by a high-profile detainee at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, that the judge order his release because he is suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder and other mental and physical ailments. The habeas corpus challenge was brought in April on behalf of Shaker Aamer, 45, a Saudi citizen and former British resident. Judge Rosemary M. Collyer gave her rejection in a terse one-page order; an accompanying memorandum opinion explaining her reasoning was sealed. The Justice Departments filings in the case were also sealed, but Judge Collyer ordered it to file a public version of her order and its documents by July 9.

title: Cracker Jack Wants to Break Out of the Ballpark
description: IT would be impossible to put a dollar value on how much Take Me Out to the Ball Game, the 1908 song ritually sung by baseball fans during the seventh-inning stretch, has had for the 121-year-old snack named in the refrain, Buy me some peanuts and Cracker Jack. But in a segment for On the Media, the syndicated public radio show produced by WNYC, Mike Pesca once tried to assess the value, equating it with Cracker Jack placing an advertisement along outfield walls of all of the major leagues 30 stadiums, a marketing campaign that would cost the brand about $25 million a year.

title: Massachusetts: Court Allows Public to Vote on Repealing Casino Law
description: The states highest court ruled Tuesday that a proposal to repeal the states expanded casino gambling law can appear on the ballot this fall. The ruling by the Supreme Judicial Court overturned a decision by Attorney General Martha Coakley, setting the stage for what is likely to be a closely watched and expensive campaign. The 2011 law allows for up to three resort-style casinos and one slots parlor to be built in the state. Casino opponents say they have more than twice as many signatures than required to get the question on the ballot; those signatures are being certified. One license has been provisionally awarded in Springfield, pending the outcome of the repeal effort; the slots parlor is under construction in Plainville.

title: Blue, as in Happy
description: NATAL, Brazil  Victory, even in the group stage of the World Cup, can make Uruguayans feel like champions again.

title: Manhattan District Attorneys Office Showing No Leniency in Daredevil Cases
description: Three men who parachuted off the World Trade Center and a speeding driver who circled Manhattan in 24 minutes have attracted plenty of fans on YouTube  thrilling helmet- or dashboard-camera videos of their stunts have been played tens of thousands of times.

title: After Opening Way to Rebels, Turkey Is Paying Heavy Price
description: HABUR BORDER GATE, Turkey  In normal times, hauling 50,000 pounds of frozen chicken into Iraq is a routine job for Turfan Aydin, a Turkish trucker who has been working the route for years. But the cross-border trade has suddenly all but halted, locked up by the insurgent offensive in Iraq and the kidnapping of 80 Turkish citizens.

title: Vast Stretches of Minnesota Are Flooded as Swollen Rivers Overflow
description: CHICAGO  Minnesota was besieged on Tuesday by some of its most widespread flooding in years. Water spilled onto streets in downtown St. Paul, crops of soybeans and corn were damaged and a state of emergency was declared in 35 counties.

title: Tying Federal Aid to College Ratings
description: College and university leaders have been up in arms since President Obama announced last year that the administration would soon deploy a rating system that evaluates schools based on factors like affordability, graduation rates, student earnings and how well institutions serve low-income students. Mr. Obama wants Congress to use the ratings to help guide the allocation of federal student loans and grants.

title: Clashing Rulings Weigh Security and Liberties
description: WASHINGTON  In two major Federal District Court rulings addressing trade-offs between government powers and individual rights, judges in Oregon on Tuesday upheld a 2008 law permitting warrantless surveillance but struck down a key aspect of the so-called no-fly list that blocks people suspected of terrorism ties from boarding planes.

title: Suit in Jogger Case May Be Settled, but Questions Arent
description: A check for $40 million, or whatever amount of money, cant settle the history of the Central Park jogger case.

title: Doubting Putin, Obama Prepares to Add Pressure
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has drawn up plans to escalate sanctions against Russia by targeting its financial, energy and defense industries, but faces resistance from European allies hoping to avoid a broader economic clash with Moscow that would hurt their own businesses.

title: U.S. Womens Soccer Stars Take Lead on Risks of Heading
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Long before millions of Americans decided that the United States mens soccer team was so cool that they couldnt live without tuning in to watch it, the players on the 1999 womens national team  remember them?  had set the bar for the sports popularity.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 24, 2014
Contract Offer Scorned, L.I.R.R. Faces Strike
description: Fearing a strike on the Long Island Rail Road, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said on Tuesday that it had expanded its offer to union leaders, granting everything that theyve asked for, with raises of 17 percent over seven years.

title: Long Absent, Nuclear Expert Still Has Hold on Iran Talks
description: VIENNA  As a team of Iranian negotiators parried with the West last week in increasingly heated negotiations over where the country will be forced to dismantle many of its nuclear facilities, one mysterious figure was conspicuously missing.

title: 3 Die as Truck Hits Disabled Vehicle on New Jersey Interstate
description: Three men were killed in a crash on a highway in northern New Jersey on Tuesday when a tractor-trailer hit a disabled truck on the shoulder of the road, the authorities said.

title: Narrow Shift by Washington on Oil Exports
description: As the oil industry pushes the Obama administration to lift a longstanding ban on the export of crude oil, the Commerce Department has granted two Texas companies permits to export a light, processed form of oil, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Like Thats Gonna Happen
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Some people like to start their crossword puzzles in the same place every time (Holla, my 1 Across-starting posse!) and others dive in anywhere they feel they can gain a toehold.

title: American Players, Dual Allegiances
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The round-table discussion with Jermaine Jones was standing room only on Tuesday morning at the United States national teams World Cup training base. But if not for a managers tough choice, Jones just might have been holding court at Germanys camp in Brazil instead, ahead of the United States final Group G game Thursday, between the teams.

title: U.S. Team Recuperates From Humidity of Manaus
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Four teams have returned to the field in this World Cup after having played matches in the heat and humidity of remote Manaus.

title: Election Results for New Yorks 13th Congressional District
description: Precinct maps of the vote in 2014 and 2012.

title: A Highway Doubling as a Haven
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Near dusk on a recent Sunday afternoon, a crowd of about 50 people mingled around a makeshift stage while warbling, in sloppy karaoke, the lyrics to the Brazilian song Que Se Chama Amor (or That Is Called Love). Nearby, a group of women sipped wine from paper cups while watching a group of boys kick a soccer ball back and forth. Next to them, a pair of families pushed strollers.

title: Lawyer Says Boy in Killing May Go Before Grand Jury
description: After a teenager was arrested and charged last week with fatally stabbing a fellow student outside their Bronx middle school, two troubled young lives came into public view.

title: New York City Council Expected to Approve 2 Plans Aiding Immigrants
description: A long-sought initiative that would provide municipal identification cards to all New Yorkers, including those without legal immigration status, has been finalized, and will come before the City Council for a vote this week, officials said.

title: A String of Sexual Assaults Puts a Bronx Area on Alert
description: Young people in some parts of the Bronx have a lot to contend with as warmer months arrive. There is a lack of organized activities, residents complain, and few summer jobs. More alarming, around playgrounds, parks and some weekend parties, bullets fly with increasing frequency.

title: A Battery of Newfound Offense Helps the Mets Romp Yet Again
description: Forget, for a moment, the three home runs hit by the Mets in the first three innings. Forget the nine hits, the seven runs, the newfound aggression, the situational execution.

title: Yanks Rally Goes for Naught As Misplays Prove Undoing
description: TORONTO  The Yankees slumbering bats erupted Tuesday night, but poor defense  including two misplays in the same inning by shortstop Derek Jeter  ultimately cost the Yankees in a 7-6 loss to the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: John McClure Dies at 84; Produced Classic Records
description: John McClure, a producer and engineer who helped shape some of the most celebrated classical recordings of the 20th century, including acclaimed sessions with Bruno Walter, Igor Stravinsky and Leonard Bernstein, died on June 17 at his home in Belmont, Vt. He was 84.

title: A Senator Wins a Race He Mulled Not Running
description: JACKSON, Miss.  The question seemed to tug at Senator Thad Cochran throughout his bumpy re-election campaign in Mississippi: Why, after a long, distinguished career  42 years in Congress, including six terms in the Senate  was he seeking a seventh term?

title: Establishment Choice Is G.O.P. Pick for Colorado Governor
description: DENVER  Bob Beauprez, a buffalo rancher and a former congressman and community banker, defeated three rivals in a crowded Republican primary election on Tuesday to become his partys choice to take on Colorados governor this November, The Associated Press reported.

title: Torontos Baseball Revival Playing to Reduced Audiences
description: TORONTO  In a city where the last playoff baseball game took place 20 seasons ago, the Blue Jays have been in first place for more than a month. The last time that happened, in 1993, Toronto won the World Series.

title: Croatian Tennis Star Cilic Rebounds From Suspension, Coached by His Idol
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Marin Cilic was not yet born when Goran Ivanisevic made his Wimbledon debut in the summer of 1988, beginning an often tortuous history at the All England Club.

title: Former White House Aide Wins G.O.P. Congressional Primary in New York
description: A pair of young Republican candidates emerged from bruising primaries on Tuesday in two congressional districts in New York State where Republicans hope to win Democratic-held seats in November.

title: Tour a New Building Made of Corn and Mushrooms at MoMA PS1
description: Each year, the Museum of Modern Art and MoMA PS1 co-sponsor of the Young Architects Program  a contest in which emerging talents compete for the chance to build a temporary structure in PS1s courtyard in Long Island City. The projects remain on-site for the duration of each summer, providing both shade and interactivity for PS1 visitors and attendees of the museums popular Warm Up outdoor concert series.

title: Time Inc. to Start 120 Sports, a Digital Network, With Pro Leagues
description: Its a sports network catering to the shortened attention spans of the mobile and social media generation: 240 clips, each two minutes long, across eight hours of daily programming.

title: For Fitness, Push Yourself
description: Intense exercise changes the body and muscles at a molecular level in ways that milder physical activity doesnt match, according to an enlightening new study. Though the study was conducted in mice, the findings add to growing scientific evidence that to realize the greatest benefits from workouts, we probably need to push ourselves.

title: Word of the Day | satirical
description: satirical \s-tir-i-kl\ adjective

title: Eli Wallach, Multifaceted Actor on Stage and Screen, Dies at 98
description: Eli Wallach, who was one of his generations most prominent and prolific character actors in film, onstage and on television for more than 60 years, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

title: Big Jump in Turnout Is Key in Thad Cochrans Victory
description: Turnout hadnt increased in a Senate runoff primary election in 30 years until Tuesday night, when a momentous surge of voters allowed Senator Thad Cochran to defeat Chris McDaniel, a Tea Party-backed state senator, in Mississippis Republican Senate runoff.

title: In Rematch, Rangel Holds Lead in a Tight House Primary Race
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel, seeking a 23rd term, held a slim lead in a fierce battle early Wednesday with State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat in their primary election contest, a rematch that was largely fought along ethnic and generational lines.

title: Voters in Mississippi React to Senator Thad Cochrans Runoff Victory on Twitter
description: After the heated campaign in the Republican Senate runoff between Senator Thad Cochran and State Senator Chris McDaniel, voters in Mississippi were ready to sound off on social media about what the race meant. Their perspectives suggested that although this particular day of voting was over, the lessons from the contest were not settled.

title: Whats on Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (ABC Family) YOUNG & HUNGRY Gabi (Emily Osment), a sassy food blogger hoping to become the personal chef of Josh (Jonathan Sadowski, above with Ms. Osment), a wealthy tech entrepreneur, must prepare a romantic meal for him and his girlfriend as a test to get the job. But when the dinner goes awry, Gabi transforms the disaster into a chance not only for employment but maybe even love. Ashley Tisdale is an executive producer of this new series, inspired by the musings of Gabi Moskowitz, the San Francisco food blogger behind Brokeass Gourmet. Annie Potts, Kym Whitley, Rex Lee and Aimee Carrero round out the cast.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 25, 2014
description: This is a football World Cup, not about morality, cheap morality.

title: Corrections: June 25, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Todays World Cup Matches: June 25, 2014
description: What to watch for in todays games, as teams from Groups E and F battle to advance in the World Cup. For the complete rundown of advancing scenarios, please visit The Upshot.

title: Cochran and McDaniel Address Supporters
description: Senator Thad Cochran and State Senator Chris McDaniel delivered remarks to their supporters after the Republican primary.

title: Student Crossword | Building Blocks of Vocabulary
description: Test your knowledge of vocabulary and its foundations by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: To: Chinese Embassy, United States; Address: No. 1 Liu Xiaobo Plaza
description: Updated, 3:42 a.m.ET|

title: Sanskrit Newspaper Sees Business Model in New Government
description: The Saturday after Narendra Modi and his Bharatiya Janata Partys historic victory in the countrys parliamentary elections was announced, some 40,000 subscribers to a weekly Sanskrit newspaper woke up to a resounding headline:

title: 6 Qs About the News | Cool at 13, Adrift at 23
description: In Cool at 13, Adrift at 23, Jan Hoffman writes about a new study that followed risk-taking, socially precocious middle school students for a decade.

title: Bobby Flays Chicken Surprise
description: Bobby Flay opened a new restaurant, Gato, a few months ago on Lafayette Street in Manhattan. Flay has been a celebrity for the better part of two decades. But he works in the open kitchen at Gato the way people do when they come to New York to make a name for themselves: head down, concentrating, hard. Its all I want to do now, he said recently.

title: Kendrick Lamar, Hip-Hops Newest Old-School Star
description: Everybodyjust wants to have fun, be with the scene, Kendrick Lamar said when we met in his cramped quarters inside the Barclays Center in Brooklyn last fall. Certain people get backstage, people that you would never expect. . . . You aint with the media! You aint into music! You aint into sports! Youre just here. The rapper, now 27, had just finished his set as the opening act on this stretch of Kanye Wests Yeezus tour, and he was sitting low in an armchair in his trademark black hoodie surrounded by exactly those people.

title: Ask Well: Diagnosing Fatty Liver
description: Recently, in Threat Grows From Liver Illness Tied to Obesity, Anahad OConnor described the growing epidemic of nonalcoholic fatty liver, an illness that affects at least one in five Americans, including many teenagers. Here he responds to reader questions about fatty liver.

title: Crisis in Greece and at Home
description: Nikos Piloss career highlights include a stint in Lebanon during the 1988 civil war, coverage of the Yugoslav wars a couple of years later and 100 days living with civilians outside the Green Zone during the height of the Iraq war.

title: Elvis Costello Treats Carnegie Hall to a Solo Show
description: If Elvis Costello had dived any deeper into his catalog for his solo concert on Tuesday, opening a two-night stand at Carnegie Hall, he would have needed scuba gear. It wasnt the kind of solo show by an established rocker that treats a bunch of old favorites as guitar-strumming singalongs for longtime fans. The hall was often silent as Mr. Costello offered something else: a continuing, challenging, intimate engagement with his songs, old and new.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: New York Today: Reading Room Refugees
description: Good morning on this damp Wednesday.

title: China Unveils New Map of South China Sea
description: China is standing tall over its expansive claims to territory in the South China Sea. This week, Hunan Map Publishing House unveiled a new map of China  a vertical representation of the country that includes the vast body of water south of Hainan Island. Chinas assertions of ownership in the South China Sea have put it at odds with at least four Southeast Asian nations, which have competing claims, and with the United States, which has said that Chinas actions in the region  including having a state-owned oil company place an exploratory oil rig near the Vietnamese coast in May  are creating instability.

title: New Area of Seafloor Is Mapped in Jet Search
description: CANBERRA, Australia  A commercial vessel under contract from the Australian government has begun mapping the floor of the southern Indian Ocean in preparation for a renewed search for Malaysia Airlines missing Flight 370, but that search has been complicated by a complete lack of satellite images of the new search area from the week after the plane disappeared.

title: David Camerons Losing Battle
description: Selecting the president of the European Commission, the powerful executive branch of the European Union, has always entailed a lot of politicking and bluster, and theres been no shortage of that in advance of a meeting of European leaders later this week. The difference this time is that Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain is staunchly opposed to the likely pick, Jean-Claude Juncker of Luxembourg, and that is shaping into a potential turning point for the entire European project. Mr. Cameron has a good case, but he should make sure that his looming defeat does not turn into an irrevocable march toward the Brexit, a British exit from the European Union.

title: In Our Pages: June 26
description: 1939: Camp Ordered Abandoned

title: Why Government Pension Funds Became Addicted to Risk
description: A public pension fund works like this: The government promises to make payments to its employees after they retire; it invests money now and uses those investments, and the returns on them, to make those promised payments later.

title: Citizen of the State of New York
Morning Views
description: Some Tea Party members have decided that the United States must shut down the Export-Import Bank of the United States, a federal agency that helps American businesses sell their goods abroad, writes The New York Timess editorial board. The bank provides loans and loan guarantees to foreign businesses to help them buy American products and services. The board is critical in particular of the efforts of Representative Jeb Hensarling, Republican of Texas, who is leading the charge against the bank and appears oblivious to the fact that if the United States dismantled the bank unilaterally, as some lawmakers are advocating, American companies could lose billions of dollars in overseas orders and decide to move their operations to other countries that provide generous export financing.

title: In the Darkness of Myanmars Camps, Lighter Moments of Life
description: Adam B. Ellick has been a senior video journalist at The Times for eight years. This month a documentary that he made with the columnist Nicholas D. Kristof drew so much attention from the international Muslim community that, for the first time, The Times released an Arabic translation of the video. It was released on Monday. Below, Adam shares some footage that was cut from the main documentary.

title: What We Learned By Doing Employee Reviews
description: This series of posts started with an explanation of why I decided to re-institute employee reviews.

title: Delivery Drones Grounded by F.A.A.
description: Delivery drones have barely taken off and theyre already being grounded.

title: Iran Secretly Sending Drones and Supplies Into Iraq, U.S. Officials Say
description: BRUSSELS  Iran is directing surveillance drones over Iraq from an airfield in Baghdad and is supplying Iraqi forces with tons of military equipment and other supplies, according to American officials.

title: Daily Report: Small Music Labels Say YouTube Employs Strong-Arm Tactics
description: Last year was seen as a great one for indie music, but anxiety about competition and fairness in the digital marketplace runs deep in the independent sector of the music industry. Small labels complain that consolidation by the major record companies has left them squeezed in negotiations with the online music services that now account for a majority of their revenue, Ben Sisario reports.

title: German Leader Shrugs Off British Opposition on E.U. Post
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany made it clear on Wednesday that Britain would fail if it tried to stop the nomination of Jean-Claude Juncker as the next head of the European Commission.

title: East African Court Blocks Paved Serengeti Highway
description: Since 2010, conservationists and wildlife biologists have been fighting Tanzanias plan to build a paved national highway through the northern part of Serengeti National Park  directly across a migratory path for millions of wildebeests and other grazing mammals.

title: The Lively Soul of a Decaying City
description: DETROIT  There are cities that get by on their good looks, offer climate and scenery, views of mountains or oceans, rockbound or with palm trees, Elmore Leonard wrote. And there are cities like Detroit that have to work for a living.

title: North Korea Warns U.S. Over Film Mocking Its Leader
description: SEOUL, South Korea  For years, anaylsts have said that one of the best kept secrets inside North Korea was that the despotic and often virulently anti-American leader at the time, Kim Jong-il, was a closet fan of Hollywood blockbusters, especially James Bond films. His son, the nations current leader, appeared to have picked up the bug, allowing the Rocky theme to be played at a special state concert.

title: Angela Ahrendts Finally Speaks at Apple, and It Is Not What You Expect
description: O.K., thats a bit of an exaggeration. Angela Ahrendts, the former Burberry chief executive lured away to revitalize Apple retail and e-tail did not exactly speak  she wrote a diary entry-cum-inspirational post about her new job, titled Starting Anew, on LinkedIn.

title: Judge Dismisses British Hacking Jury, Hung on Remaining Charges
description: LONDON  It was an unspectacular denouement to Britains spectacular phone hacking trial: The jury was dismissed Wednesday after failing to reach a verdict on two outstanding charges against Andy Coulson, a former tabloid editor who had been found guilty of conspiracy to intercept voice mail messages a day earlier.

title: Listen Up | A Brazilian Rock Band to Get You Into the World Cup Groove
description: Its World Cup season, and native Brazilians cant get enough of the attention. My country is living and breathing soccer more than usual, says Rafael Rocha, the frontman for the band Wannabe Jalva, which is based in Porto Alegre in the south of the country. Brazil has kind of stopped for a bit. Rocha and his bandmates Felipe Puperi, Fernando Paulista and Tiago Abraho are in an especially celebratory mood these days: theyve just finished their upcoming, as-yet-untitled EP, and are planning to take their sound  which theyve curiously taken to calling uterus-space-groove-rock  global. Thats a term we put together only because everybody needs a label, Rocha explains. We have so many influences, from newer acts like Queens of the Stone Age to older ones like the Doors. We also have a funk and soul vibe going on. Our music somehow links all of that together  we try not to place any boundaries on ourselves.

title: AbbVie Signals It Will Continue to Pursue Irish Drug Maker Shire
description: Updated, 2:28 p.m. |

title: ABC Anchor Shift Signals Mornings Triumph
description: ABC News on Wednesday announced sweeping changes among its top news personalities, with Diane Sawyer to step down as anchor of the networks evening newscast in August, replaced by David Muir, a rising star anchor at the network.

title: Princess Cristina of Spain Is Charged in Corruption Case
description: MADRID  The Spanish monarchy was dragged deeper into a corruption case on Wednesday when Princess Cristina was charged with tax fraud and money laundering by a judge investigating whether her husband and business associates had embezzled millions of dollars in public funds earmarked for sports events.

title: Economy in First Quarter Was Worse Than Everybody Thought
description: The beginning of the year was not just bad for the United States economy; it was  on paper at least  the worst quarter since the last recession ended five years ago.

title: Barnes & Noble to Spin Off Nook Unit as Sales Continue to Fall
description: Updated, 7:16 p.m. | When it introduced the Nook e-reader in the fall of 2009, Barnes & Noble celebrated it as its answer to Amazon.com and its popular Kindle device.

title: Morning Agenda: Searching for Young Financial Advisers
description: A HUNT FOR YOUNG FINANCIAL ADVISERS | Wall Street has an aging problem. The average financial adviser in the United States is older than 50, a number that shows no sign of getting lower because relatively few young people are interested in the work, Rachel Abrams writes in DealBook. Now, as Wall Street turns more to asset management, it must figure out how to attract and retain a fresh pool of talent that is increasingly looking to find its riches elsewhere.

title: My Yearly Camp Permethrin Dance
description: The season of sleep-away camp is upon us, and in our house that means its time for the yearly pesticide ritual.

title: Panel on Surez Can Weigh Past Incidents as It Decides Punishment
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The FIFA disciplinary committee investigating Uruguay striker Luis Surez for apparently biting an opponent during a World Cup match Tuesday has broad authority to consider any evidence, including Surezs two past biting incidents, and determine any punishment.

title: Why You Should Root for Nigeria (or Brazil, Mexico or Ghana)
description: Most of the world considers soccers quadrennial World Cup to be the most important sporting competition of all. A growing number of Americans have embraced the event, but many are only vaguely aware of it, and, aside from the United States, not so sure for whom to root.

title: On a Bronx Street, a Long-Absent Weasel Returns to the City
description: An unfamiliar creature is slinking through the streets of the Bronx.

title: Aereo Loses at Supreme Court, in Victory for TV Broadcasters
description: WASHINGTON  Aereo made an all-or-nothing bet. The digital start-up threatened to upend the media industry and transform the way people watch television.

title: On the Social Responsibility of Wonks
description: Jared Bernstein agonizes over the role of wonkish analysis (which spell-check keeps trying to change to monkish) in a political environment in which facts and smart policy are on the run. Its something I worry about too.

title: Sunni Militants Advance Toward Large Iraqi Dam
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi security officials said Wednesday that fighters with the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria were advancing on the Haditha Dam, the second-largest in Iraq, raising the possibility of catastrophic damage and flooding.

title: Argentina vs. Nigeria: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: Argentina has clinched advancement, and will top the group with a win or draw. Nigeria will also advance, unless it loses and Iran beats Bosnia, in which case tie breakers will come into play.

title: Bosnia-Herzegovina vs. Iran: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: Nothing but pride for one nation; possibly everything for the other. Bosnia is out, and Iran only advances with a win, a Nigeria loss, and favorable goal differential. That could require Iran to score two or three times, which seems like a tall order.

title: Supreme Court Decision in Aereo Case
description: Citing copyright law, the justices rejected the streaming services model of capturing broadcast signals and delivering them to subscribers.

title: Major Ruling Shields Privacy of Cellphones
description: WASHINGTON  In a sweeping victory for privacy rights in the digital age, the Supreme Court on Wednesday unanimously ruled that the police need warrants to search the cellphones of people they arrest.

title: Rangel Leads in Democratic House Primary
description: The Democratic primary between Representative Charles B. Rangel and his challenger State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat is still too close to call despite a declaration of victory from Mr. Rangel.

title: With History in Mind, Black Voters in Mississippi Aided Cochran
description: WASHINGTON  Voting rights for black people did not come easily in Mississippi in 1955, but the Rev. George Lee was not one to give up. Using his pulpit and his printing press, he tried to sign up African-Americans in the Delta to vote, despite threats to his life.

title: Think They Got Killed? 1964, L.B.J. and Three Civil Rights Icons
description: Fifty years ago this week, three young civil rights activists  Michael Schwerner, James Chaney and Andrew Goodman  vanished in Neshoba County, Miss.

title: Mountain Lakes, N.J.: A Resort Getaway to Call Home
description: Before Herbert J. Hapgood came to Mountain Lakes in 1910, the area was largely woodlands. Over the next dozen years, Mr. Hapgood built a planned community of hundreds of large, Arts-and-Crafts-style houses on lush grounds as summer homes for wealthy New Yorkers. After the Lackawanna Railroad built a station here in 1912, families began seeing Mountain Lakes as a permanent residence.

title: A Closer Look at 10 of Masterpiece Londons Finest Offerings
description: Sandwiched between Royal Ascot and the Henley Royal Regatta, the fifth edition of Masterpiece London, the annual fine art and antiques fair, opens its doors tomorrow. For one week, everything from 19th-century Italian paintings to a 2013 Italian Maserati will be up for sale on the South Grounds of the historic Royal Hospital Chelsea.The London Season has made its return, says the events chairman, Philip Hewat-Jaboor, and I see Masterpiece very much as the glue that cements the astonishing array of activities in these summer months.

title: At 30 Rock, Recreating Rotunda With a Nod to the Past
description: There was a time in the 1930s and 40s when the excitement of attending an NBC broadcast at Rockefeller Center began long before you were ushered into Studio 6B, where Bob Hope held forth, or the astonishing 1,500-seat Studio 8H, home of Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra.

title: The No-Fly List Is Unconstitutional
description: The federal governments no-fly list, which prevents those suspected of terrorist ties from boarding flights in the United States or flying through American airspace, is reported to include more than 20,000 namesa number that metastasized after the Sept. 11 attacks. Theres a low evidentiary standard for getting on the list. Once on, its not only difficult to get off but almost impossible to find out why, exactly, one was added in the first place.

title: Germany Can Inflict Pain on the U.S., as It Has Before
description: How can Germany make the United States suffer this time?

title: What You Get for ... $1,000,000
description: BOISE, IDAHO

title: N.F.L. Makes Open-Ended Commitment to Retirees in Concussion Suit
description: The N.F.L. has made an open-ended commitment to pay cash awards to retired players who have dementia and other conditions linked to repeated head hits, according to documents filed in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania on Wednesday.

title: Teddy Roosevelts Confederate Uncles
description: On June 19, 1864, the Confederacy lost one of its most effective weapons of the Civil War: In the Battle of Cherbourg off the coast of France, the Union warship Kearsarge sunk the notorious Confederate commerce raider, the Alabama. In its two-year career, the Alabama had claimed 65 ships, totaling $6 million, a huge hit to the Union war effort. The Alabama continued to wreak posthumous havoc after the war; since it had been built in England, in the late 1860s the United States pressed a claim for damages, even threatening to invade Canada as compensation.

title: House Hunting in ... South Wales
description: A RENOVATED HISTORIC HOME NEAR SWANSEA

title: For Budding Book Lovers
description: Reliability is one of the things book lovers cherish about books. The words books contain are the same on every reading; set a book down, and there it stays, until you are ready to pick it up again. But in two new picture books, My Pet Book, written and illustrated by Bob Staake (The Red Lemon, Bluebird, The Donut Chef) and Brother Hugo and the Bear, written by Katy Beebe and illustrated by S.D. Schindler, precious books go missing, and have to be found  or recreated.

title: What It Takes to Legalize Sex Work
description: A bill introduced in Canada by Prime Minister Stephen Harpers Conservative government would criminalize buying sexual services but would not necessarily make selling them illegal. It follows a Canadian Supreme Court ruling last year that overturned most laws governing the sex trade.

title: Rangel Wins House Primary Rematch
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel, who said he wanted to be able to decide on his own when to retire from a career in Congress that began in 1971, held off a determined challenge by State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat to win the Democratic primary for a 23rd term.

title: What Would You Think of Living in Luxembourg?
description: Heres the opposite of fun: One of your 5-year-old twins has fallen from a tall, dangerous playground apparatus, and possibly broken a bone, and so you are in an emergency room where English is not spoken, trying to have a type of conversation for which Berlitz doesnt prepare you, and the pain and suffering and maybe long-term well-being of your kid hang in the balance.

title: Restaurant Report: Suliko Restorani in Hollywood, Fla.
description: If you know Suliko Restorani, its probably because of the word-of-mouth reviews that flow among Soviet-bloc immigrants living in South Florida. Unmarked and unadvertised, Suliko opened in July 2013 at the back of Aquarius, a nondescript condominium in Hollywood, Fla., and quickly became the go-to spot for Russian speakers, until recently a majority of patrons.

title: Scene City: Broadway Comes to Central Park
description: The Public Theater holds its annual gala for Shakespeare in the Park.

title: Malaria Prevention, With Both Reward and Risk
description: Alassane Dicko shivered and sweated through part of his childhood. Sick with frequent bouts of malaria, he often missed school. His older brother died of malaria, and so did his best friend. This disease can be cured with a pill, yet it claims about 1,700 lives each day  mainly children in sub-Saharan Africa who dont take this medicine within a week of falling sick. Even when kids survive, some remain disabled or irrecoverably behind in school. Thats why Dicko, now a malaria researcher at the University of Bamako in Mali, took matters into his own hands when he became a father.Dicko gives malaria medicine to his children before they get the disease during the rainy season  the period when the mosquito-borne illness peaks in Mali. Tourists do something similar by taking malaria drugs prophylactically on trips to Africa, but for decades, health officials have said that Africans should not do so, because the widespread use of a drug eventually renders that drug ineffective. However, Dicko, who studies malaria prevention, has come to believe that the immediate health benefits are worth that risk.After a decade of clinical trials demonstrated that the preventive measure reduces malaria cases by 75 percent, medical authorities reversed their position against it, in areas where its most effective. They decided that the number of lives saved outweighs the cost of losing these drugs eventually. For every drug you give, you will increase the risk of drug resistance, Dicko says. But these drugs are efficacious right now, so why dont we use them and save thousands of lives?

title: 36 Hours in Stockholm
description: If Stockholm residents seem particularly smug these days, its for good reason. The Swedish capital has long ranked among the loveliest in Europe, with an inner-city beauty characterized by stately architecture and graceful waterways. But openings in outlying neighborhoods  galleries in the north, boutiques in the south, a craft brewery in the suburbs, art in the archipelago  are expanding the limits of the city worth exploring. Add to that Stockholms exciting restaurant scene, born from the popular New Nordic food movement, and the hometown pride is perfectly understandable.

title: Hy-Fi at MoMA PS1
description: In this exclusive video, T tours Hy-Fi, a new structure in the Long Island City, Queens museums courtyard built with bricks comprised of shredded corn stalks and fungus.

title: Live Stream | Valentinos Spring 2015 Collection at Paris Mens Fashion Week
description: The latest mens collection from Valentino at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Venus Williams Rallies From Early Hole at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England  The subject of retirement from tennis persistently follows Venus Williams wherever she goes and whenever she plays. At 34, without a title in a Grand Slam event since 2008 and with just one third-round appearance at a major since 2012, who can resist the temptation of asking?

title: Image of the Day: June 25
Today in Small Business: Women Are Starting More Businesses (But That Might Not Be Good)
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Classical Playlist: Verdi, Schubert, Michael Gordon and More
description: VERDI: Don CarloJon Vickers, Gr Brouwenstijn, Tito Gobbi and other singers.The Covent Garden Orchestra and Opera Chorus, Carlo Maria Giulini, conductor(Andromeda; three CDs)This live 1958 recording of Verdis Don Carlo from the Royal Opera in London, though not an ideal performance, is great to have. Of particular interest is Jon Vickers in the title role. Here, Vickers is early in his career before it became clear that he would be the great dramatic tenor of his generation, bringing a powerhouse voice and expressive intensity to roles like Wagners Tristan and Verdis Otello. This is Vickers in a more youthful, lyric mode, but still singing with chilling power and ardency, despite occasional moments of strain in his high range. The cast boasts Gr Brouwenstijn as Elisabetta, Tito Gobbi as Rodrigo, Fedora Barbieri as Eboli, and Boris Christoff as Filippo II. The great Carlo Maria Giulini conducts a majestic account of the score. The performance comes through cleanly on this remastered recording. (Anthony Tommasini)

title: Q. and A. About Student Debt
description: Dire warnings about student debt have become so common that many people may have a hard time believing that the problem is often exaggerated, as I wrote in my column Tuesday. Sure enough, readers raised several thoughtful questions about the research in the column, which found that large student debts are rarer than widely believed.

title: Ballet at Your Fingertips
description: The new iPad application Passe-Partout puts users in control of the choreography.

title: R.B.S. Chairman Says High Banker Pay Contributed to Financial Crisis
description: EDINBURGH  Like its rivals in Britain, the Royal Bank of Scotland has been unable to escape criticism from shareholders over the amount of compensation that bankers are paid.

title: Taiwan Protest Leaders Blocked From Visiting Hong Kong
description: A group of protest leaders from Taiwan was barred from traveling to Hong Kong to participate in a forum on democracy, which the event organizers called a sign of the Chinese governments concerns about the push for more open elections in Hong Kong.

title: Too Much Creative License: Amnesty International Withdraws Iggy Pop Ad
description: The ad was a grabber.Posted a little over a week ago on the website of Amnesty Internationals French-speaking division in Belgium, itshowed the rock star Iggy Pop, his face battered and bruised, saying, Justin Bieber is the future of rock n roll. Underneath was the slogan: Torture a man and he will tell you anything. In smaller letters it continued: Besides being inhumane, torture doesnt work. Lets stop it.

title: Youre the Choreographer, an iPads Your Stage
description: There I was, riding the subway over the Williamsburg Bridge, making a dance. The stage was my iPad.

title: Appeals Court Rejects Utahs Ban on Gay Marriage, Prodding Supreme Court
description: DENVER  Expanding a streak of legal victories for same-sex marriage, a federal appeals court ruled on Wednesday that states may not deny same-sex couples their fundamental right to marry, overturning Utahs voter-approved ban on such unions.

title: In Iraq, Switching Allegiance Once Again
description: For a few days last week before YouTube pulled the video, Clanging of the Swords IV gave a graphic visual account of the violence unfolding in Iraq. The hourlong reel is a mash-up of attacks, allegedly by militants with the Sunni extremist group Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, against Iraqi security forces: drive-by shootings; roadside bombings; a beheading. Like most jihadi videos, it has a soundtrack of atonal religious chanting.

title: Movement and Space Have a Meet-Up
description: The choreographer Jill Sigman, its safe to say, is fueled by a sensitivity for perceiving the movement in nature and the nature in movement. Her latest work, (Perma)Culture, performed last Thursday at Danspace Project, gathers eight dancers, dozens of ceramic objects, several pieces of sod and a timekeeper  Mary Suk  to explore connections between movement research and permacultural design.

title: Immigration Reform Is Dead
description: Representative Luis Gutierrez, the Illinois Democrat, took the House floor this morning and declared the end of immigration reform.

title: For Espaillat, Strong Start Was Marred by Missteps
description: When State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat decided to challenge Representative Charles B. Rangel for a second time, many analysts saw the race as his to lose.

title: In Brussels, a Colorful Floral Carpet
description: A Turkish carpet measuring 246 feet long and 82 feet wide and made up of about 800,000 cut begonias will blanket Brussels Grand Place, the citys main square, from Aug. 15 to 17. The biennial Brussels Flower Carpet, which combines art, architecture, and landscaping, this year celebrates the 50th anniversary of Turkish immigration in Belgium.

title: Oculus Response to ZeniMax
description: The two companies have been disputing over intellectual property related to virtual reality technology, which Facebook recently made a big bet on.

title: A Place Out of the Sun
description: Some people in Arizona are putting on their winter gear and heading to the Coyotes Curling Club, where it is an invigorating 42 degrees.

title: Palestinian Detainees Suspend Their Mass Hunger Strike in Israel
description: JERUSALEM  Scores of Palestinian detainees in Israel have suspended their mass hunger strike after more than two months without food, Israeli and Palestinian officials said on Wednesday, removing one source of friction in a volatile period since the recent kidnapping of three Israeli youths in the West Bank and a subsequent Israeli military crackdown.

title: Wheelies: The Hydrogen Toyota Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: A New Kind of Wine Business
description: Using innovative technology, Lysanne Tusars company produces local wine, thousands of miles from the nearest vineyard  but now faces a difficult challenge.

title: Hanes to Buy DBApparel, Wonderbra Maker, for $544 Million
description: HanesBrands said on Wednesday that it would acquire DBApparel of France from Sun Capital Partners for about 400 million euros in cash, or $544 million. As a result of the deal, Hanes will acquire worldwide rights to the Playtex, Wonderbra and DIM brands.

title: Google Unveils Ambitious Android Expansion at I/O Conference
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google wants to be everywhere: in your home, your car and even on your wrist.

title: G.O.P.s Rifts Laid Bare in Reactions to Mississippi Runoff
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans reacted on Wednesday to Senator Thad Cochrans victory-by-inches in a primary runoff in Mississippi with a mix of views that reflected the sharp divide between the partys establishment and Tea Party wings.

title: Airlines Halt Flights to Pakistan City After Attack on Plane
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Two major airlines suspended their service to Peshawar in northwestern Pakistan on Wednesday, after a gun attack on a crowded airliner here that killed a passenger and raised fears of a concerted militant campaign against the countrys airports.

title: Metropolitan Opera Offices Vandalized, Police and Company Say
description: The unusually eventful post-season at the Metropolitan Opera continued on Wednesday morning when some administrative offices inside the opera house were vandalized with spray paint, the police and the company said.

title: Valentino: Spring 2015 Menswear
description: Paris

title: How Select Home Care Is Coping With New Wage and Labor Regulations
description: Last week, we publisheda case study about Select Home Care, a nonmedical home care company with operations spanning nine states. Facing new state and federal regulations that will affect his employees, Dylan Hull, one of the companys owners, concluded he needed to rethink his business model. The new regulations would push wages higher and require additional overtime hours, increasing costs for Select.

title: Narrow Tea Party Loss in Mississippi Emboldens Its Senate Bid in Tennessee
description: LASCASSAS, Tenn.  As Senator Thad Cochran eked out a victory over a conservative insurgent on Tuesday in Mississippi, Tea Party members here were making a bold  even defiant  proclamation: They will win the Senate seat in Tennessee.

title: Film Society Chooses Lisandro Alonso for Filmmaker Residency
description: The Argentine director Lisandro Alonso will be the Film Society of Lincoln Centers filmmaker in residence this fall, the organization announced Tuesday. The position, created last year in partnership with the watchmaker Jaeger-LeCoultre, is intended to support a filmmaker at an early stage in the creative process against the backdrop of New York City and the New York Film Festival.

title: So Far This Year, Less Talk About Grass
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Long before he became the head groundsman at the All England Lawn Tennis Club, Neil Stubley was a chef. He sees similarities in the jobs.

title: S.E.C. Limits Derivatives Trading by Foreign Branches of U.S. Banks
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted a rule on Wednesday to rein in derivatives trading by foreign branches of United States banks, moving to strengthen oversight of a risky business that helped cause the financial crisis.

title: Ecuador vs. France: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: France has advanced and needs a draw to be certain of winning the group. Ecuadors situation is complex; with the right results it could advance even with a loss or be eliminated even with a win.

title: Western Hemisphere Continues Its Romp Through World Cup
description: The World Cup already features an entire portion of the Round of 16 bracket thats dedicated to South America. It includes Brazil, Chile, Colombia and Uruguay and guarantees that one (and only one) of those four teams will reach the semifinals.

title: Boomerang Kids Article Prompts a Rich Range of Views
description: Within an hour of its publication online on Friday, a New York Times Magazine story about boomerang kids  young adults who move back in with their parents after graduating from college  was a hit. During that mornings news meeting, Karron Skog, the day editor, and Ian Fisher, an assistant managing editor, said they would give the story more prominent promotion based on its web traffic and comment numbers. By 5 p.m. the story had drawn nearly 1,000 comments; by Sunday, when the piece ran in print, it had 1,657 comments.

title: The Challenges of Starting an Urban Winery
description: Ask most winemakers about the pitfalls of harvest, and they talk about excessive rain or pesky bugs. Lysanne Tusar, owner of the 8th Estate Winery, has a more unusual problem: the rising cost of rent in the city.

title: The Scene | Paris Mens Fashion Week: Haider Ackermann Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

title: German Artist Wins the BP Portrait Award With Depiction of Homeless Man
description: LONDON  A portrait of a homeless man, Man With a Plaid Blanket, by Thomas Ganter, has won the BP Portrait Award, the National Portrait Gallery announced here on Tuesday. Mr. Ganter, who is the first German artist to win the prize, an annual award aimed at encouraging artists to focus on portrait-painting, received 30,000 or roughly $50,922 at an award ceremony hosted by the actor Nigel Havers. The prize, which is sponsored by BP, also includes a commission to paint a portrait for the National Portrait Gallerys permanent collection.

title: Google, Microsoft and Others Delve Deeper Into Cloud Storage for Businesses
description: SAN FRANCISCO  File cabinets  the digital kind  may be the technology industrys next big battleground.

title: Recalling Dad and Disease With a Roar
description: Benjamin Scheuer is the center of attention. After a performance of The Lion, his coming-of-age solo musical, audience members mill about Manhattan Theater Clubs studio space, where the show is playing. The ladies flock to him first, perhaps attracted by his linen suit, mop of sandy hair and slight British lilt, a product of his bicontinental heritage. He swiftly diverts the focus to his admirers, chatting with anyone who stops to flirt or offer congratulations.

title: Judy Blume Novel for Adults Set for 2015
description: Judy Blumes first novel for adults since Summer Sisters appeared in 1998 will be released in summer 2015, according to her publisher, Alfred A. Knopf.

title: Iraqi Premier Rejects Unity Government
description: Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki dismissed the idea of a national salvation government and asked Iraqs political blocs to close ranks in the wake of the Sunni insurgency.

title: Despite Aereo Decision, TV Is Ripe for Digital Shake-Up
description: Aereo is dead. Long live television disruption.

title: Boehner Memo on Suing Obama
description: House Speaker John A. Boehner sent this memo to members of the House of Representatives, outlining plans for the chamber to sue President Obama for allegedly exceeding the lawful scope of his executive powers.

title: Honduras vs. Switzerland: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: Although it theoretically could advance even with a loss in certain scenarios, Switzerland really needs a win, or a draw if Ecuador loses.

title: An Unlikely Trip to the World Cup
description: Instead of taking an expensive direct flight to the World Cup in Brazil, Seth Kugel, the Frugal Traveler, took a cheaper and more adventurous journey through four countries over 16 days.

title: 2 V.A. Officials to Leave Posts as Agency Seeks to Remake Itself and Rebuild Trust
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs said Wednesday that two senior officials would be leaving their posts as the departments acting secretary moved to remake the agency and rebuild trust amid a scandal over falsified waiting lists that were used at many hospitals to hide delays faced by veterans.

title: To the Cup, the Long Way Round
description: It can take about 16 hours and two flights to get from New York City to Natal, Brazil, where the United States took on Ghana in their World Cup opener last week.

title: Messi Lifts Spirits of Argentines, Even Those Without Tickets
description: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil  An estimated 50,000 Argentines completed the trek to this World Cup city by Wednesday morning. Many of the soccer pilgrims were wearing long faces along with their Lionel Messi jerseys as they roamed the parks and the streets and took in the hazy view of Guaba Lake while carrying hand-lettered signs that read, Compro (Im buying).

title: Oculus Portrays Accuser as Opportunist, in Lawsuit Over Virtual Reality Technology
description: Oculus VR fired back at ZeniMax Media on Wednesday in its first formal response to accusations that it stole ZeniMax virtual reality technology.

title: Machiavelli in Mississippi
description: There are momentswhen debates about policy and ideology and The Direction of the Republican Party have to take a back seat to an appreciation of politics-as-politics: The second oldest profession, the game of thrones and transactions, the sleazy science of relationships and favors and dealmaking and turnout and (with apologies to Charlie Sheen) winning. And the spectacle of Thad Cochran which is to say, yes, the Haley Barbour political machinepulling out an unlikely comeback in the Mississippi Senate run-off by persuading African-American Democrats to turn out in a G.O.P. primary is such an occasion: A time to savor some of the historical ironies at work, to appreciate the establishments back-to-the-wall strategery, and to let the Penn Warren-ish phrase Barbour brothers roll over and over on your tongue.

title: The Art of the Vacationship
description: I love to do the thing youre supposed to do in the place youre supposed to do it.

title: Lana Del Rey Scores Her First No. 1 Album
description: Lana Del Rey, the pouty, retro torch singer for the millennial generation, scored her first No. 1 on Billboards album chart with her new album, Ultraviolence (Polydor/Interscope), beating out new releases by the young British vocalist Sam Smith and the rock band Linkin Park.

title: Rate Manipulations May Distort Banks Market Risk Models
description: Mayra Rodrguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm in New York. She also teaches at Financial Markets World and the New York Institute of Finance.

title: What Are You Really Worth to Your Employer?
description: Chief executives are always going on about how employees are their companies most valuable assets. They say it even as wages stagnate and executive pay skyrockets. They say it amid layoffs and as non-executive jobs are shifted overseas along with company profits.

title: Learning Lear': When To Hold Back, When to Let Go
description: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses King Lear for Shakespeare in the Park.

title: League of His Own
description: If ever there was a time to interest the American reading public in a 700-page novel about a real-life British soccer coach, it might just possibly be now, with David Beckham an A-list celebrity (and underwear model), and the 2014 World Cup underway.

title: Barclays Faces New York Lawsuit Over Dark Pool and High-Frequency Trading
description: Updated, 8:25 p.m. | The top law enforcer in New York State, Eric T. Schneiderman, filed civil fraud charges on Wednesday against Barclays over its private stock trading platform, contending that it favored high-frequency traders over other investors.

title: A Group Show Celebrates the Art of Cycling
description: Opening tonight at Marlborough Gallerys Broome Street location is Joyride, a group art show that inaugurates the 14th edition of the annual Bicycle Film Festival. For the exhibition  the latest in an annual series of art events tied to the festival  artists such as Ai Weiwei, Tim Barber, Francesco Clemente, Andrew Guenther, KAWS, Richard Prince, Tom Sachs and Kiki Smith have contributed cycling-themed work. Some, like Clemente and Guenther, created pieces specially for the show.

title: In Inheritance Battle, Judge Sides Against the Perelmans
description: The bitter legal fight involving Samantha Perelman, the daughter of the billionaire investor Ronald O. Perelman, came to an end on Wednesday, when a superior court judge ruled that Ms. Perelmans uncle did not cut her out of her inheritance by unfairly manipulating her dying grandfather.

title: Small Blasts Across Cairo Disrupt Calm Since Election
description: CAIRO  Five small bombs exploded around Egypts capital within two hours on Wednesday, injuring six people in the first such attacks since the election of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi this month.

title: Between the Lines of the Cellphone Privacy Ruling
description: In a pathbreaking case on Fourth Amendment privacy rights and modern technology, the Supreme Court unanimously ruled that the police must obtain warrants before searching the digital contents of cellphones taken from people who are placed under arrest. Here are some key points in the opinion by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and a concurrence by Justice Samuel Alito.

title: Red Bulls and M.L.S. Return to Field
description: Theyre back. Well almost.

title: Google Unveils Android Expansion
description: Sundar Pichai, a senior vice president at Google, spoke about Androids expansion during his keynote address at the Google I/O developers conference in San Francisco.

title: Dallas and Cleveland Are Finalists for G.O.P Convention
description: WASHINGTON  The 2016 Republican National Convention will be held in Cleveland or Dallas, the party announced Wednesday.

title: Goldman Sachs Reorganizes Investment Banking Division
description: Goldman Sachs is combining its consumer retail and health care investment banking groups, according to an internal memorandum sent on Wednesday. The move comes as drug company takeovers and retail advisory deals are on the rise.

title: G.M. Holds a Corvette Track Day for Potential Customers
description: MILLVILLE, N.J.  There is probably no better way to sell sports cars than to get people talking about how hot they are on a track. Last week, more than 170 people statistically selected by Chevrolet were able to do just that, getting to drive the 2014 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray at New Jersey Motorsports Park.

title: The Supreme Court Saves Cellphone Privacy
description: The nine justices of the Supreme Court  whose average age is 68  often admit to being unfamiliar with modern technology, if not befuddled by it. While listening to oral arguments in April, Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. asked, with apparent sincerity, why anyone other than a criminal would carry two cellphones.

title: Medium Hires Tech Writer Steven Levy as It Moves From Platform to Publisher
description: Medium, the online writing system created by Evan Williams, one of the founders of Twitter, has been something of a tabula rasa. Its publishing system and pretty interface have drawn raves, but as a media business it has been tough to pin down.

title: With Boyhood, a Portrait Every Year
description: Accompanying David Marcheses story about Richard Linklaters film Boyhood, a 12-year project, is a slideshow of portraits of Ellar Coltrane, who grows up onscreen as the main character. In taking these pictures, Matt Lankes developed a relationship with Coltrane that he hopes will continue beyond the films completion. Lankes recently talked a bit about working on a movie for more than a decade.

title: The First Rule of Stir-Fries: Be Prepared
description: Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist and cookbook author, is working with the Ruder family (Renee, her husband, Chris, and their three daughters, ages 11, 9 and 7) to help these meat lovers adopt a plan of eating two vegetarian meals a week without feeling deprived; and to take advantage of a C.S.A., a community-supported agriculture program basket often filled with foods to which they are unaccustomed. This week, while Renee is out of town, Martha lays the groundwork for stir-fries, and answers readers questions.

title: What the Aereo Decision Means for TV
description: The Supreme Court ruled that Aereo violated copyright law, granting television networks a much-desired win that will preserve the status quo  at least for now.

title: Buffeted by Tumult, Jewish Population in Tunisia Dwindles
description: DJERBA, Tunisia  On a recent Sabbath morning, just five men sat reciting prayers in the sanctuary of the Ghriba synagogue, the oldest synagogue in North Africa and the holiest place for the Orthodox Jews who live here on the resort island of Djerba.

title: Contentment at a Hells Kitchen Diner
description: Dear Diary,

title: David Muirs Youth Appeal
description: Some highlights of Mr. Muirs on-air style. The anchor will take the reins of ABCs evening news in a move that executives hope will appeal to younger viewers.

title: Smithsonian Festival Will Stay at National Mall for Now
description: WASHINGTON  The turf war on the National Mall has reached a cease-fire, for now.

title: For Many Mormon Athletes, Mission Is to Play
description: On Thursday night, an N.B.A. team will select Jabari Parker, a 19-year-old basketball prodigy, with one of the top picks in the 2014 draft.

title: House Panel Seeks to Block Washington Marijuana Law
description: WASHINGTON  The House Appropriations Committee passed a measure on Wednesday to bar the District of Columbia from using either federal or local funds in carrying out a new law decriminalizing the possession of small amounts of marijuana, a move that could block the law if approved by Congress.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Valentino Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

title: Raf Simons: Spring 2015 Menswear
