description: A court in Slovakia on Thursday cleared Andrej Babis, the Czech finance minister, of charges that he had been a Communist-era spy for the secret police in Czechoslovakia.

title: Thats So Random: Why We Persist in Seeing Streaks
description: From time to time, athletes get on a streak. Suddenly, the basketball goes through the net every time, or a batter gets a hit in every game. This blissful condition is often known as the hot hand, and players have come to believe it is real  so much so that they have made it a part of their strategy for winning games.

title: Algeria vs. Russia: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: Algeria was startlingly good in shredding South Korea in the first half of a 4-2 win. Striker Islam Slimani will find the Russian defense stingier. Russia has just one goal in its first two games and may need to makes some changes to find the back of the net.

description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

title: Belgium vs. South Korea: World Cup 2014 Live Blog
description: Belgium ground out victories over Algeria and Russia, but still hasnt shown its best. Well have to wait even longer for that, as the team is already in the next round and is likely to rest some players. South Korea has been disappointing, especially when torn apart in the first half by an unheralded Algeria side. Maybe Kim Shin-wook, who played well as a substitute striker in that game, will salvage something from this tournament.

description: Delia Fischer, a FIFA spokeswoman, announced that Luis Surez, Uruguays striker, will be banned for nine matches after being found guilty of biting the Italy defender Giorgio Chiellini.

title: A Journey of a Thousand Miles Begins With a Single Scoop
description: The ice cream had been cut into a half-moon slab that was dense to the touch and so cold my fingers went numb. It required teeth. It tasted as if it had been made on a planet with stronger gravity, concentrated yet airy, and smoking cold all the way down.

description: A decade ago, Corinthian Colleges was a Wall Street darling  a company that seemed to be able to coin money from the federal government and from desperate students. Now it is on the brink of collapse.

title: Dries Van Noten: Spring 2015 Menswear
description: Paris

title: In Store | Courtshop, Jeans-Maker to Indie Rock Goddesses, Opens in its Natural Habitat: Brooklyn
description: Jeans and rock n roll have always been bedfellows. Lately, some of the most stylish names on the indie scene  Caroline Polachek of Chairlift and Ramona Lisa, Alexis Krauss of Sleigh Bells, Victoria Legrand of Beach House, Megan James of Purity Ring,Angel Deradoorian of Avey Tares Slasher Flicks have been sporting pairs by the New York-based labelCourtshop, known for its rock-starish high-waisted cuts and palatable price points. Now, in addition to its boutique in NoLIta, the brand is setting up shop in the neighborhood where many of its customers live and play: Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The new store opens tonight with a party at which Polachek herself will make an appearance in the D.J. booth. She plans on picking up a few things for her summer wardrobe, too. I quite like their shorts, which is surprising since normally Id never be caught dead in shorts, she says. The fit makes me feel like Laura Dern in Jurassic Park, or a sexy-awkward 70s camp counselor. In other words, totally ideal.

title: Exploring Anarchism in a Play at the Library
description: In spite of an emphatically bourgeois background, the Miser, as a youngster, fancied himself enough of an anarchist to scrawl the famous symbol of a capital A enclosed in a circle on his denim jacket in indelible black ink.

description: Zapped, a new Disney Channel movie on Friday, is about Zoey (Zendaya), a high school student whose mother remarries, giving her a new family, a new school and new faith in biological determinism.

description: The two major technology-related decisions handed down by the Supreme Court this week have been widely greeted by people in the tech industry as one win and one loss.

description: An interactive matrix of game outcomes detailing how Algeria, Russia and South Korea can advance to the Round of 16 in the World Cup.

description: LOS ANGELESThe Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences once again went large with its annual list of prospective new members, inviting 271 film professionals to join, including the veteran actor David Straithairn (Lincoln), the newcomer Barkhad Abdi (nominated for best supporting actor for Captain Phillips), and 22 casting directors, who will help fill out the groups recently created casting branch.

description: Compromise or persevere?

description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The good news for the United States mens national soccer team is that it has some experience against Belgium, which will be its next opponent at the World Cup. The bad news: It was not exactly a pleasant experience.

description: Relational Investors, the big activist investment firm, plans to push for the breakup of yet another company.

description: Elizabeth Lowell Boland, the rising Canadian singer-songwriter who performs under the moniker Lowell, has multiple personalities when it comes to her music. I have a tendency towards making super-quirky, happy pop, but I can also write Lana Del Rey-style dark, depressing music, she says. Im great at drug references, and writing about sex!

title: Clueless and Gloomy in Suburbia
description: If that was the Christian rapture, then some of the worst people were chosen for eternal salvation.

description: LONDON  Germany said on Thursday that it would cancel a contract with Verizon Communications, part of the fallout from continuing revelations by Edward J. Snowden, a former National Security Agency contractor, who says that American intelligence agencies had routine access to global data provided by telecom companies.

description: OPENING

title: Museum of Fine Arts in Boston Returns Art Works to Nigeria
description: The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston has returned eight works of art to Nigeria after determining that the documentation accompanying some of the items, six of which were bequeathed in early 2013 by a prominent donor and collector, was suspect or fraudulent.

description: MOMA PREPARES

title: The Secret of the Disco Clams Light Show
description: Ctenoides ales is well known to scuba divers, who call it the disco or electric clam for its mirror-ball luminescence. But few scientists had given it much notice until Lindsey Dougherty came along.

title: Decision by Justices Opens a New Debate on the Limits of Presidential Power
description: WASHINGTON  Thursdays decision by the Supreme Court to curb President Obamas ability to make recess appointments opened a new debate in the nations capital about the proper limits of presidential power in an era of intense partisan gridlock.

title: Troubled Inquisitor
description: Political novels are full of pitfalls, particularly for a novelist with strong political leanings. Writers may craft their world however they like, so they need not deal with the complexities of reality if it inconveniences their narrative. Ayn Rands philosophy can work in Atlas Shrugged, for example, because its a fantasyland of her creation. A better approach can be found in The Brothers Karamazov, in which Dostoyevsky makes his ideological opponents his most articulate characters. Great writers force themselves to confront the challenges the world can throw against what they believe. The poet Tom Sleigh explains this as the difference between exploring a political emotion, say, rather than a political conviction. Whereas a political emotion is concerned with the lived experience of how politics impact peoples lives, a political conviction is primarily didactic  it weaves no web, traps no chaotically buzzing flies  its hygienic, and easily put aside when the moment of outrage or conversational animus has passed.

title: Deep Cover: Alice Goffmans On the Run
description: On the Run is, first and foremost, a remarkable feat of reporting. Its author, Alice Goffman, a young sociologist, had an ethnography assignment for an undergraduate class at the University of Pennsylvania, and she, the daughter of the renowned sociologist Erving Goffman (1922-82), didnt take it lightly. She hung out with an older African-American food service worker at the university, and one thing led to another. Before long, she had moved into an apartment in a poor, largely black neighborhood in Philadelphia, her housemate a young man whose family lived down the block. Goffman became such a part of the fabric of the community that she was harassed by the police, witnessed someone getting pistol-whipped, was even set up on a blind date. And all the while she was furiously taking notes, trying to make sense of what at first glance appeared to be utter chaos going on around her.

title: A Call to Rally
description: Somewhere along the long, bumpy road of human evolution  between the emergence of Davos Man and the TEDification of everything  a new breed of journalist emerged, specially adapted to the corporatized landscape of the modern media biome. Call him Aspen Man, after his proclivity for Ideas. (Aspen Woman exists, too, but the breed skews male.) Like all journalists, Aspen Man feeds upon stories, studies and statistics, but his unique genius lies in his ability to transform the resulting partly digested mix into brain candy for well-heeled aficionados of Malcolm Gladwell and Thomas Friedman.

title: Despite New Opt-In Rules, Overdraft Fees Still Baffle Consumers
description: IT has been nearly four years since rules went into effect to help clarify when banks may charge you penalties if you overdraw your checking account using your debit card. But many people remain confused about so-called overdraft fees, a new report finds.

title: Between the Lines of the Recess Appointments Decision
description: The Supreme Court on Thursday handed down a major decision concerning a presidents power to appoint executive branch officials when the Senate is in recess without going through the confirmation process. The court rejected the validity of four appointments President Obama made in January 2012, when the question of whether the Senate was in recess was in dispute. While on the surface the ruling was a blow to executive power, on a deeper level it was also a victory for executive power because it rolled back an appeals court ruling that had gone much further in restricting such authority.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Begin Again
description: John Carney narrates a musical sequence from his film Begin Again.

description: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

title: Clip: Tick, Tick ... Boom!
description: Lin-Manuel Miranda performs a song from the City Center Encores! production.

title: Rebekah Brooks on Her Not Guilty Verdict
description: Rebekah Brooks, the former head of Rupert Murdochs newspaper holdings in Britain, said she felt vindicated after being found not guilty of hacking phone messages and other crimes.

title: Espaillat, Conceding to Rangel, Sets His Sights on Another Race
description: State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat officially conceded to Representative Charles B. Rangel on Thursday and announced his intention to run for re-election to the State Legislature.

title: Zero for Six
description: For reference: I count at least six distinct predictions of Obamacare doom made by the usual suspects, not one of which has come true. Here they are:

title: A Prodigious Beginning, Then an Early Ending
description: Moving and maddening in almost equal measure, Brian Knappenbergers The Internets Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz is a devastating meditation on what can happen when a prescient thinker challenges corporate interests and the power of the state.

title: In the Company of Known Strangers
description: I pulled into the gravel driveway of my childhood home, parked my ailing Ford Ranger and practiced the mantra I had invented during my two-day drive from Salt Lake City to Coos Bay, Ore.: Take a deep breath. Dont argue with your father. Do this for your mother.

title: Celebrate Summer 2014: Ways to Teach the Season
description: Every year as summer hits full swing, we post a list of ideas for teaching and learning about the joys  and challenges  of the season.

title: John Carney Narrates a Scene From Begin Again
description: The writer and director John Carney (Once) brings his latest film about musicians, Begin Again, to the big screen. In this video, he discusses a musical sequence featuring Keira Knightley and Mark Ruffalo.

title: Hey, Taking Off My Clothes Is Hard Work
description: La Bare takes its title from the club it chronicles, a male strip joint in Dallas. The name proves unfortunately apt for a rambling, superficial documentary that straddles the line between expos and infomercial. Directed by the actor Joe Manganiello (who was inspired by his role in Steven Soderberghs Magic Mike, set in the world of male revues), this celebratory film argues that male stripping is more strenuous than its female counterpart: It requires a full-fledged act and an athletes regimen. We learn a bit about the stagecraft, such as how audience volunteers are selected and why underpants with flies are forbidden.

title: Artifice, Historical Transcendence and Cactus Plants
description: Celebrating the close of its 50th-anniversary season, Boston Ballet has come to Lincoln Center with two programs at the David H. Koch Theater. The second program, which opens on Friday, includes two masterpieces of different stages of radical modernism, Vaslav Nijinskys 1912 Afternoon of a Faun and George Balanchines 1972 Symphony in Three Movements. The first program, which opened on Wednesday, is all postmodern, all chic, all wiseguy, all full of theater games, all laden with production concepts and entirely loathsome.

title: Caseworker, Into the Woods
description: The unforgettable hero of Fourth of July Creek is Pete Snow, a social worker charged with rescuing troubled children in the wilds of northern Montana. At work, he is preternaturally kind and helpful, even in the face of unbearable situations. In this rugged country, way off the grid, it seems theres no horror he hasnt seen, from newly suicided fathers and their wreckage to the mother who calls your office wondering if you could take her child, God is telling her to kill him, you better hurry.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Syria and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Paying for Quality Education
description: Early this year, President Obama announced version 1.0 of his college-rating system at least in part to help clarify what constituted a good investment for students.

title: Events in New Jersey for June 29-July 5, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: U.S. Prepares for Sale of Bitcoins Seized in Its Raid on Silk Road
description: Updated, 7:46 p.m. | On its face, it looked like a typical government raid: Federal agents shut down an online drug marketplace, seizing millions of dollars of ill-gotten gains in the process.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, the Netherlands, Russia and Germany.

title: U.N. Official Says Syrian Rules Are Preventing Aid Delivery
description: Ever since the Security Council reached a hard-won consensus to help United Nations aid agencies deliver food and medicine to Syrians trapped by war, compliance with its resolution has been low. On Thursday, the United Nations top aid official told the council that new Syrian bureaucracy had made compliance even lower.

title: Forced to Hand Over Data, Facebook Files Appeal
description: Facebook and the Manhattan district attorneys office are in a bitter fight over the governments demand for the contents of hundreds of Facebook accounts.

title: Facebook Case Over Search Warrants for User Information
description: Facebook has argued that Manhattan prosecutors violated the constitutional rights of its users last year by demanding the nearly complete account data of 381 people, from pages they liked to their photos and private messages.

title: Fewer Loan Applications
description: Spring failed to inspire a surge in home sales nationally this year, even though mortgage rates are still reasonably low. Although economists insist that the housing market is on an upward trend, abnormal conditions left over from the recession continue to be a drag.

title: Howard Makes Enough Stops to Keep the U.S. Going
description: The United States, needing only a tie against Germany to advance to the Round of 16, began the game on their heels.

title: Let the Mass Destruction Begin
description: Transformers: Age of Extinction, the fourth film in an apparently inexhaustible, profoundly exhausting series based on Hasbro toys, raises, not for the first time, a basic question: Who are these movies for? This one, like its predecessors, is likely to make a lot of money all over the world, but that only makes the matter more puzzling. The Transformers franchise seems like the most baldly and cynically commercial calculation imaginable  it is merchandising-based entertainment at its purest  and yet somehow it does not pander.

title: Globalfest to Make Its Summer Debut
description: Eleven musical acts, three film screenings, family-friendly performances and an underground bass stage will mark Globalfests summer debut, at Lincoln Center on July 27, organizers announced on Thursday.

title: Court Rules Against Aereo, but Not Against Innovation
description: On Wednesday morning, the Supreme Court handed down a 6-3 ruling that it was unlawful for Aereo, a television streaming service, to capture and stream broadcast television signals to subscribers. The court found that Aereos service violated the Copyright Act by not securing permission from broadcasters to enact public performances of their programs. This result is a largely seen as a boon to networks and a threat to start-ups, particularly those that use cloud-based technology to allow file sharing.

title: Say Hi, but Dont Pry
description: My husband and I were sitting in the waiting room of a fertility clinic, when I recognized a woman who was a friend from college 18 years ago. I hadnt seen or spoken with her since. Would it have been O.K. to say hello to her in this situation? Could I have asked if shes married and what shes up to, the way I would any other friend? How about explaining that we were not there for IVF treatment but for a follow-up, since we lucked out and got pregnant on our own?

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Dries Van Noten Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

title: Torture Details for U.S.S. Cole Bombing Suspect
description: Defense lawyers for terrorism suspects at Guantanamo Bay have long complained  and with good reason  that ongoing government resistance to sharing details about mistreatment while in U.S. custody makes it hard, if not impossible to provide adequate legal representation.

description: Elizabeth A. Sackler has been named chairwoman of the Brooklyn Museum, the first woman in the museums nearly 200-year history to serve in that position.

title: World Cup Captivates America, Except for Ann Coulter
description: Many Americans were excited to learn on Thursday that the United States would advance to the next round of World Cup competition. One who probably was not: Ann Coulter.

title: With Rangels Win, Another Chapter in the Gang of Four
description: Yesterday, Representative Charles B. Rangel won the primary election contest to represent New Yorks 13th District in Congress. Darren Sands wrote about the campaign in last Sundays magazine, noting that Rangels political strength in the community began in the 1980s, when the Coalition for a Just New York rallied minority voters and African-American and Latino candidates. The most prominent among the coalition was the Gang of Four, which included Charles Rangel, David N. Dinkins, Basil Paterson and Percy Sutton. Sands says that for decades the Gang of Fours influence went virtually unchallenged, and for now Rangel seems to be holding on. Heres a selection of what has been said over the years about the Gang of Four and their influence in Harlem:

title: The Genre, if Not the Song, Remains the Same
description: Before it was a Tony Award-winning Broadway musical, Once was a scruffy and charming movie, written and directed by John Carney, about a man and a woman united by their love of music and their unstated but obvious attraction to each other. Filmed at street level in the lived-in parts of a picturesque city, it managed to be touristic and authentic at the same time, partly because the central pair consisted of a native and an outsider. Mr. Carney pulled off the enviable trick of dressing unabashed romantic sentiment in a style that felt rough and real, so that every clich he touched felt shiny and new.

title: Fear of Packing
description: We all have our favorites when it comes to the life-changing inventions of the 20th century, and mine is the Baggie.

title: Rapper Convicted of Murder, Racketeering and Drug Dealing
description: After one day of deliberations, a federal jury on Thursday found a Bloods gang leader from the Gowanus Houses in Brooklyn guilty of all 21 counts he had been tried for, including three murders, racketeering and drug trafficking.

title: Senior U.S. Prosecutor Joins Paul Weiss
description: A day after Lorin L. Reisner announced that he was stepping down as head of the criminal division of the United States attorneys office in Manhattan, the law firm Paul Weiss on Thursday named him as a partner in its litigation department.

title: Clip: Transformers: Age of Extinction
description: A scene from the movie.

title: The Dark Side Gets Its Due
description: Most of us dont stop for death until it kindly, or unkindly, stops for us. And then there is the new Morbid Anatomy Museum, which will throw the Grim Reaper an enthusiastic welcome party when it opens its doors this weekend in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn.

title: A 3,000-Mile Road Trip to the World Cup
description: Dado Galdieri, a photographer, followed Chilean fans driving to Brazil in hopes of seeing their team make the finals.

title: Inner Musings on a Precarious Descent
description: On certain college campuses, Michael Herschs new opera, On the Threshold of Winter, would come with a boldface trigger warning. The two-act monodrama, which received its searing premiere on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is about illness and death. Its texts, taken from deathbed poems by the Romanian writer Marin Sorescu, offer an unflinching look at the rage, despair and sense of isolation he felt in his final weeks in a Bucharest hospital ward.

title: Theater Listings for June 27-July 3
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Comedy Listings for June 27-July 3
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for June 27-July 3
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Art as Architecture and as Currency
description: For refreshingly un-Koonsian ideas about sculpture, look no further than the three solo exhibitions now at SculptureCenter. One is a large-scale installation by the midcareer Icelandic artist Katrin Sigurdardottir; the other two are smaller projects by the emerging American artists Liz Glynn and Jory Rabinovitz. Shiny objects and artisanal craftsmanship play a role here, as they do in Jeff Koonss survey at the Whitney, but so do imperfection, evanescence and parsimoniousness.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for June 27-July 3
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Crumbs Bake Shop Set to Delist From Nasdaq
description: The cupcake craze may be getting stale.

title: A Shift in the Beautiful Game
description: When Spain, Italy and England have all gone home, and the United States is through to the Round of 16 of the World Cup, something has shifted in the beautiful game. Jurgen Klinsmanns U.S. team has been gritty, cohesive and occasionally explosive, as when Jermaine Jones almost burst the net with his equalizing rocket against Portugal. America, less nave with each recent World Cup, deserves its place in the knock-out phase.

title: Jazz Listings for June 27-July 3
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Stuck in Steerage for the Postapocalypse
description: In the mood for allegory? Have a look at Bong Joon-hos Snowpiercer, which proceeds from a fantastical premise rich with real-world relevance. After a human-engineered planetary catastrophe (trying to arrest the planets warming, we accidentally froze it solid), the remaining people are stuck on a train that never stops moving. A few thousand survivors live in railway cars, sorted into a rigid and ruthlessly enforced social order. In the back are huddled masses fed on gelatinous, insect-based black protein bars and kept in line by a combination of propaganda and brute force. Toward the front, the more fortunate enjoy access to schools, nightclubs, fresh food and the reassurance that they deserve everything they have. An unseen, quasi-mythical entrepreneur is in charge, and a group of rebels have decided to challenge his power and the extreme inequality he represents.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for June 27-July 3
description: Reviews of classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: F.C.C. Issues Snapshot of U.S. Internet Service
description: WASHINGTON  The number of homes in the United States that subscribe to Internet service has grown at a 15 percent annual rate over the last decade, to 85 million. But as much as 30 percent of households do not have a connection faster than dial-up speed, according to government figures released this week.

title: A Brooklyn Show Celebrates an Inventive Mind of the Midway
description: A KING OF THE MIDWAY,

title: Dance Listings for June 27-July 3
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: A Matchmaker in Reverse
description: The jokes and sight gags fly in exhausting profusion in The Breakup Guru, Deng Chao and Yu Baimeis antic, scattershot romantic comedy. Mr. Deng plays the titular fixer, Mei Yuangui, a successful specialist in terminating the relationships of celebrities and socialites through entrapment, public humiliation and other unsavory methods. (These tactics are accompanied by a lot of mugging and extreme grimacing.) Now, with three trusty helpers, Yuangui has one last job: to help a smarmy, Western-style motivational speaker and successologist (Liang Chao) unload his Beijing mistress, Ye Xiaochun (Yang Mi). To that end, Yuangui resolves to trick the mistress into falling for none other than himself. Somehow, for all his overemphatic mannerisms, he succeeds.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for June 27-July 3
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Environmental Agency Approves $511 Million Loan for Tappan Zee Replacement
description: The New York State agency that lends federal money for sewer plants and other clean-water projects on Thursday approved a $511 million loan to the Thruway Authority for 17 projects that are part of the building of a twin-span replacement for the Tappan Zee Bridge across the Hudson River.

title: From Letter Carrier to a Name in Lights
description: In various incarnations, the animated childrens series Postman Pat has been a staple of British television since 1981. The title character is a letter carrier who, along with his cat, Jess, brings joy and generosity to the farm community of Greendale.

title: Spare Times for Children for June 27-July 3
description: Bug Day

title: Michaels I.P.O. Prices at $17, at Low End of Range
description: The Michaels Companies, the arts and crafts retailer that has spent nearly eight years in private ownership, is ready to make its public markets debut.

title: Two Lives, Ruthlessly Exploited
description: Every few years, it seems, someone rediscovers the Hilton sisters, the conjoined twins who spent decades as a sideshow attraction and then a vaudeville act in the heart of the last century. They are having a moment again: A new production of Side Show, the stage musical inspired by their lives, has recently opened at the Kennedy Center in Washington, and now Bound by Flesh, a straightforward documentary by Leslie Zemeckis, is being given a theatrical release.

title: Spare Times for June 27-July 4
description: NYC Pride Events (Friday through Sunday) The monthlong celebration of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender diversity concludes this weekend with something for everyone. A free rally with performances will kick things off on Friday, from 6 to 9:30 p.m., at Pier 26, in Hudson River Park, at North Moore Street, TriBeCa. It will be followed by a dance party for men, starting at 11 p.m. at BPM, 516 West 42nd Street, Clinton. Women will get their own party at Pier 26 on Saturday, from 4 to 10 p.m.

title: This Weeks Movies | June 27, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review Transformers: Age of Extinction, Snowpiercer and Begin Again.

title: Mixed Emotions at a Gathering to Say Goodbye
description: Joanna Hogg  where have you been all my movie-loving life? That thought buzzed through my head after, with intensifying greediness, I tore through this British directors three features: Unrelated, Archipelago and Exhibition. Theyre finally receiving American distribution, so if youre lucky enough to be in New York, run over to the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center and catch them now.

title: Stiff Drinks and Stiff Upper Lips: Britons on a Tuscan Holiday
description: Because it has no conventional action or schematic story, Unrelated, Joanna Hoggs dyspeptic portrait of upper-middle-class Britons on a summer holiday in Tuscany, is the antithesis of popcorn entertainment. The guests, who span two generations, convene in a spacious rented villa equipped with a large swimming pool and caretakers. The movie observes their leisure activities with a chilly documentary objectivity.

title: Lost to the Grim Realities of India
description: Mahendra Saini (Rajesh Tailang), the meek, sad-eyed protagonist of Richie Mehtas touching film Siddharth, is a resident of New Delhi, with a wife, a son approaching puberty and a younger daughter. He ekes out a living on the streets fixing zippers, touting his service through a bullhorn, but business has been bad. In the films opening moments, he says goodbye to his son, Siddharth, who is leaving on a bus to work in a factory in distant Ludhiana. The boys employer, Om Prakash (Amitabh Srivasta), is a distant cousin of Mahendras brother-in-law, Ranjit (Anurag Arora). Both are hardened in ways that Mahendra is not.

title: Slain Libyan Rights Activist Documented Her Last Hours Online
description: Just hours before she was assassinated on Wednesday, one of Libyas most prominent civil rights activists, Salwa Bugaighis, logged on to Facebook to urge her fellow citizens of Benghazi to head to the polls and vote, despite violent clashes in the streets between Islamist militias and the forces of a renegade general.

title: When Boy Meets Girl in Ben Franklin Wigs
description: In They Came Together, a sloppy, fitfully funny broadside at the romantic comedy, the director David Wain goes after that oft-abused genre with a metaphoric jackhammer  as well as a bat, a machete, a couple of knives, one or two missiles and the sort of sizzling cartoon bomb that Wile E. Coyote used to hurl. Mr. Wain has some expert help with his demolition work, namely his stars, Amy Poehler and Paul Rudd, who with another dozen or so cutups, embody assorted romantic comedy stereotypes with wide smiles, seasoned technique and unfettered spleen.

title: After More Than 100 Days Away, Tiger Woods Plays Like His Partners: Raggedly
description: BETHESDA, Md.  If it had been a band from the swing era, the Tiger Woods trio would have been booed off the stage Thursday at Congressional Country Club. But it was a golf group, and the crowd, which lined up five deep around the 10th tee and formed a human outline around the 208-yard par-3 hole, was overwhelmingly supportive from start to finish.

title: In Prisons, Sky-High Phone Rates and Money Transfer Fees
description: Inside the razor wire on Eagle Crest Way, in rural Clallam Bay, Wash., telephone calls start at $3.15. Emails out, beyond the security fence, run 33 cents. Money transfers in, to what pass for bank accounts, cost $4.95.

title: Navigating the New Publishing World
description: To the Editor:

title: 178 Years Late, a Briton Replenishes the Alamo
description: SAN ANTONIO  Phil Collins, a member of Genesis and a staple of 1980s-era MTV, arrived at the Alamo here on Thursday carrying a sword and a dagger. Jerry Patterson, the Texas land commissioner, brought two guns, one tucked in his cowboy boot and the other in his waistband.

title: A Trial in a Troubling Context
description: James J. Bulger, better known as Whitey, was a notorious and widely feared criminal in Boston in the 1970s and 80s. He disappeared after being tipped off about an impending arrest in 1994, and after that was a famous fugitive. Captured three years ago in California  where he had been living quietly with his longtime girlfriend  Mr. Bulger was tried last summer on a host of charges, including 19 counts of murder. His trial is the subject of Whitey, a gripping and troubling new documentary by Joe Berlinger.

title: Resilient Dreamers
description: Patti Smith and Klaus Biesenbach have teamed up to start a new festival to celebrate the re-opening of Fort Tilden and their adopted community in the Rockaways.

title: Action by Argentina Seems to Defy Judges Order on Bond Payments
description: Argentina made a puzzling and potentially provocative move on Thursday in its landmark legal battle with New York hedge funds, which are suing the country over bonds that it defaulted on over 10 years ago.

title: Jookin in the Spotlight
description: Lil Buck, born Charles Riley, has bounced from music videos to a Super Bowl halftime show to Lincoln Center. He introduced mainstream audiences to jookin, a street dance born in his hometown, Memphis.

title: Finally, a Tide of Celebration in the Rockaways
description: PATTI SMITH has been visiting the Rockaways in Queens since the 1970s, when she would venture around the secluded Fort Tilden, the national park and beach, with Robert Mapplethorpe.

title: Why Immigrant Children Are at Our Door
description: To the Editor:

title: No Conclusion in Inquiry Into Scott Walkers Campaign Fund-Raising
description: CHICAGO  A special prosecutor investigating possible illegal fund-raising coordination between the Wisconsin campaign of Gov. Scott Walker and conservative groups has reached no conclusion as to whether there is enough evidence to charge anyone with a crime, the prosecutors lawyer said in a statement issued Thursday.

title: Shapes of an Extroverted Life
description: There are so many strange, disconcerting aspects to Jeff Koons, his art and his career that it is hard to quite know how to approach his first New York retrospective, the Whitney Museum of American Arts largest survey devoted to a single artist.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Comedy and Carnage
description: There are few circumstances in which its comforting to find yourself under interrogation, but Oscar (Kyrre Hellum), the hero of Jackpot, is in an especially tight spot. Can he explain how he ended up surrounded by eight dead bodies in a Swedish sex shop  the last man standing, despite never having fired a shot?

title: In Gaza, Work but No Pay
description: Being a government employee in Gaza does not guarantee a paycheck, as workers hired by rival political factions fight for scarce funds.

title: Fans Hospitalized in Latest Dance Music Setback
description: In the latest headache for the growing business of electronic dance music, three dozen fans were hospitalized in Boston on Wednesday night after going to a concert by the star D.J. Avicii, apparently for problems related to drugs and alcohol.

title: Leave Iraq to the Iraqis
description: To the Editor:

title: With Aplomb, Young Star Passes Test
description: WIMBLEDON, England  If adversity is the best education, the 5-foot-10-inch Madison Keys experienced a competitive growth spurt after dropping the second set of her second-round match here Thursday against the physically overmatched but persistent Klara Koukalova of the Czech Republic.

title: Money Splits a City Still Mourning Its Firefighters
description: PRESCOTT, Ariz.  Smoke drifted from the fire that tore through the chaparral brush on nearby mountains after the flames had claimed the lives of 19 firefighters almost a year ago, immersing this tight community in heartache. In the months that followed, tributes  on storefronts, on bumper stickers and along the mesh-iron fence surrounding Station 7, the firefighters home base  stood as glaring reminders of a tragedy no one here has forgotten.

title: Israel Names Prime Suspects in Abductions
description: JERUSALEM  Marwan Qawasmeh and Amer Abu Aisha, both residents of the West Bank city of Hebron, were last seen on the night of June 12, shortly before three Israeli teenagers went missing while hitchhiking a few miles to the north.

title: Make College Accessible
description: To the Editor:

title: Libraries and the Young
description: To the Editor:

title: For British Spy in Iraq, Affection Is Strong but Legacy Is Unfulfilled
description: BAGHDAD  A picture of Gertrude Bell, the British diplomat and spy, still hangs on a wall in the Alwiya Club, the Baghdad clubhouse for the social elite that she established, and black-and-white photographs of her can be found in the collections of the citys old families.

title: Militarism and Humiliation Cast Shadow on Germany
description: KIEL, Germany  On June 28, 1914, Kaiser Wilhelm II was preparing to indulge in a favorite pastime: racing his yacht Meteor at a regatta that is still held each year in this seafaring stronghold. When he learned of the assassination in Sarajevo of Archduke Franz Ferdinand, the heir to the Hapsburg Empire, he hastened to Berlin. But he quickly returned to this Baltic Sea port, on which he lavished so much money and time in his frantic race to match or outdo British naval superiority.

title: The War to End All Wars? Hardly. But It Did Change Them Forever.
description: ZONNEBEKE, Belgium  To walk the orderly rows of headstones in the elegant graveyards that hold the dead of World War I is to feel both awe and distance. With the death of the last veterans, World War I, which began 100 years ago, has moved from memory to history. But its resonance has not faded  on land and geography, people and nations, and on the causes and consequences of modern war.

title: Belgians Share Their Land With Wars Reminders
description: YPRES, Belgium  The padlocked cage beside the driveway on the Butaye family farm near this town in western Belgium is almost full of rusting bombs again. Since January, Stijn Butaye has collected 46 mortar shells on his familys 100 acres, World War I munitions he found among the sugar beet and potato fields, sometimes with the help of his metal detector.

title: In Sarajevo, Divisions That Drove an Assassin Have Only Begun to Heal
description: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina  As the 100th anniversary approaches, the clusters of visitors have thickened at the street-corner museum in Sarajevos old town that stands where Gavrilo Princip claimed his place in history on June 28, 1914, firing the shots that killed Archduke Franz Ferdinand and his wife, Sophie, and setting off World War I.

title: A Battle in Ukraine Echoes Through the Decades
description: MOUNT MAKIVKA, Ukraine  In a conflict that cost millions of lives, destroyed four empires and introduced Europe to the horrors of chemical weapons and total war, the battle on a pine-covered mountain in what is today western Ukraine was a modest affair. A few hundred soldiers died, and the outcome was so muddled that all sides claimed victory.

title: When the Americans Turned the Tide
description: CHTEAU-THIERRY, France  Fifty miles to Paris. That was all that separated a hardened German Army from, perhaps, the end of the Great War. By early 1918, the Germans were rolling through northern France, and French commanders feared they were planning a decisive attack against the capital. First, though, they had to cross a ribbon of green water known as the Marne. And traverse a small forest known as Belleau Wood.

title: Murdochs Letter on Slaughter at Gallipoli
description: In 1915, Keith Arthur Murdoch wrote an 8,000-word letter to Prime Minister Andrew Fisher of Australia, describing what he called one of the most terrible chapters in our history.

title: Destroying Bombs From World War I
description: Frances Department of Mine Clearance is responsible for collecting and destroying unexploded shells still found by the thousands nearly 100 years after the Battle of Verdun.

title: The Bomb Collector of Ypres
description: World War I relics, including unexploded shells, are exhibited by Stijn Butaye, 26, on his family farm.

title: At Gallipoli, a Campaign That Laid Ground for National Identities
description: CANAKKALE, Turkey  The trenches are still there, carved in the green hills of the slim Gallipoli Peninsula just across the Dardanelles, the waterway that connects the Aegean and Marmara Seas on the way to Istanbul from the port city of Canakkale. Gravestones adorn the beachheads and lands farther inland, marking the lives of the young men  Britons, Frenchmen, Australians, New Zealanders and their enemies, the Ottoman Turks  who died there, almost a century ago.

title: Tourists Flock to Damaged Cars
description: A sinkhole that swallowed eight cars in the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Ky., is now attracting tourists.

title: Heedless of Traffic Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Florida Court Overturns Death Sentence for 1985 Killing
description: MIAMI  With new DNA evidence in hand, a divided Florida Supreme Court on Thursday overturned the death sentence and conviction of Paul C. Hildwin, a man found guilty nearly three decades ago of strangling a woman in Hernando County, Fla. The woman, Vronzettie Cox, 42, whose body was found in the trunk of a car, had been raped.

title: Tribe, Purveyor of Hummus, Hopes to Narrow Sabras Lead With New Campaign
description: HUMMUS, the dip made with chickpeas, is believed to have been eaten for millenniums, but it has flown off deli section shelves in recent years as if it were a novelty. Sales in the United States of refrigerated flavored spreads, a category dominated by hummus, grew 21 percent, to $695.5 million, for the 52 weeks ending May 18, according to IRI, a market data firm.

title: U.S. Defense Is Bolstered by a New Man in the Middle
description: RECIFE, Brazil  Because the memory of Portugals fifth-minute goal against the United States on Sunday was still so fresh, the last thing the team and its fans needed to see Thursday afternoon was another early defensive miscue.

title: Lock Em Up Nation
description: How did the United States, land of the free, become the worlds top jailer? Its a question asked by visitors from other democracies, and the American citizen who wakes from a stupor to find that our prisons are stuffed with people serving interminable sentences for nonviolent crimes.

title: In Atlanta, Some Dispute Murder Charge Against Father in Hot-Car Death of Boy
description: ATLANTA  The legal drama that has gripped this city for more than a week comes down to whether a 2011 Hyundai Tucson should be considered the scene of a crime or of a horrible mistake.

title: Where Killings Are Common, Death of Activist Stuns Benghazi
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Salwa Bugaighis, a Libyan lawyer and civil rights activist, stood on the roof of her home in Benghazi on Wednesday and watched as armed groups fought gun battles on the edges of town.

title: Guantnamo Detainees Lawyers Urge Obama to Approve Release to Uruguay
description: WASHINGTON  Lawyers for six low-level detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, whom Uruguay has offered to resettle sent a letter to the Obama administration on Thursday urging it to act on the deal, which has been awaiting the signature of Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel since March.

title: Artful Guises in the Belle Epoque
description: Popular culture at its most pop produces our modern mythology of superheroes, monsters and galactic conspiracies. But not all myths are created equal. Writing about mid-1950s sci-fi films, the British critic Raymond Durgnat discovered a necessary dialectic that he called the wedding of poetry and pulp.

title: The Supreme Court Was Right to Allow Anti-Abortion Protests
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Even as a committed supporter of a womans  increasingly imperiled  right to choose, I must acknowledge that the Supreme Court got it right on Thursday.

title: Obama: You Guys Are the Reason I Ran
description: In remarks delivered Thursday, President Obama discussed the ways in which he relates to the problems of common Americans.

title: High Tension and a Cold Shoulder at Border of Two Koreas
description: PANMUNJOM, South Korea  Lt. Cmdr. Daniel McShane dashed from the rainstorm into the sentry post. Minutes earlier, he had walked up to a strip of concrete that marks the de facto border with North Korea and, through an interpreter, read out a request: An American colonel wanted to meet face to face with his North Korean counterpart.

title: Clip: Earth to Echo
description: A scene from the film, directed by Dave Green.

title: In a Diner With Obama, a Serving of Ordinary Life
description: ST. PAUL  In the first episode in a series the White House is marketing as Day in the Life visits ahead of the midterm elections in November, President Obama spent part of Thursday with a mother who had written to him about her struggles.

title: The Incompetence Dogma
description: Have you been following the news about Obamacare? The Affordable Care Act has receded from the front page, but information about how its going keeps coming in  and almost all the news is good. Indeed, health reform has been on a roll ever since March, when it became clear that enrollment would surpass expectations despite the teething problems of the federal website.

title: Cavaliers Pick Wiggins at No. 1, Bringing N.B.A. Draft Speculation Full Circle
description: As the college basketball season hummed along, speculation of who would be the top pick in theN.B.A. draftshifted from Andrew Wiggins to Jabari Parker to Joel Embiid. On Thursday, as Adam Silver conducted his first draft as commissioner, things came full circle, and it was Wiggins who walked onto the Barclays Center stage sporting a Cleveland Cavaliershat as the No. 1 overall pick.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for June 26, 2014
Here Are the 43,634 Properties in Detroit That Were on the Brink of Foreclosure in 2014
description: A mosaic, created with images from Google Maps Street View, shows one of the many enormous challenges facing Detroit as it tries to climb out of debt.

title: Secrets of the Universe, Embedded in Pop Ditties
description: Airless and earthbound, Radio Free Albemuth  resembles a weird artifact from the early days of science-fiction television  a lost episode of The Outer Limits or Tales of Tomorrow. Based on the novel of the same title by Philip K. Dick (published posthumously in 1985), this lifeless adaptation only proves that making entertaining movies out of hard-to-swallow ideas is as challenging as you might think.

title: Most Will Be Able to Automatically Renew Coverage Under Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration announced Thursday that most people would be able to renew subsidized health insurance coverage without filing an application and without going back to HealthCare.gov, the website that frustrated millions of consumers last fall.

title: Redrawn Lines Seen as No Cure in Iraq Conflict
description: ISTANBUL  Over the past two weeks, the specter that has haunted Iraq since its founding 93 years ago appears to have become a reality: the de facto partition of the country into Sunni, Shiite and Kurdish cantons.

title: Bleak Prognosis From Both Sides of Aisle in House for Immigration Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON  Two leading House lawmakers  one Republican and one Democrat  declared efforts to overhaul the nations broken immigration system all but dead for the year, the result of hardening Tea Party opposition and growing mistrust of President Obama among congressional Republicans.

title: A Dark Horse Is Adjusting to Rising Expectations
description: SO PAULO  It was always the neighboring Dutch who painted their houses orange for the World Cup, drove orange cars and wore orange outfits until everything and everyone in the Netherlands was the color of a traffic cone.

title: Politicians Prescriptions for Marijuana Defy Doctors and Data
description: New York moved last week to join 22 states in legalizing medical marijuana for patients with a diverse array of debilitating ailments, encompassing epilepsy and cancer, Crohns disease and Parkinsons. Yet there is no rigorous scientific evidence that marijuana effectively treats the symptoms of many of the illnesses for which states have authorized its use.

title: In the Eye of a European Political Storm Stands a Quiet Enigma
description: LUXEMBOURG  As millions of Greeks faced misery amid Europes debt crisis, Jean-Claude Juncker, the Luxembourger helping to oversee their rescue, was asked at a news conference what would happen if Greece failed to meet the demands of the lenders who had bailed out the country.

title: The Supreme Courts Powerful New Consensus
description: WASHINGTON  FOR years, particularly after the 2000 election, talk about the Supreme Court has centered on its bitter 5-to-4 divisions. Yet it is worth reflecting on a remarkable achievement: The court has agreed unanimously in more than 66 percent of its cases this term (and that figure holds even if Mondays remaining two cases, on the Affordable Care Acts contraceptive coverage and on public-sector unions, are not unanimous). The last year this happened was 1940.

title: As a Bandwagon Fills, a Team Fails Forward
description: RECIFE, Brazil  The United States soccer players seemed to pass the ball to Germany more often than they did to their own teammates. Late in the game, two Americans  Jermaine Jones and Alejandro Bedoya  were left splayed on the field after running into each other and knocking heads. Jones had also hit the turf earlier when he ran at full speed into the referee.

title: This Weekend: A Jeff Koons Retrospective
description: Make this weekend an art-filled one. Theres the Jeff Koons retrospective at the Whitney, a new morbid museum in Brooklyn and an arts festival in the Rockaways.

title: The Road to Dov Charneys Ouster at American Apparel
description: In a dimly lit private dining room at the Redeye Grill in Manhattan, four board members of American Apparel and their lawyer plotted out their next 24 hours over steaks and red wine.

title: In Botched Case of Park Jogger, an Altered Life
description: After the man was finished raping the 20-year-old college student and searching her apartment for money, he announced that he had to kill or blind her. He held an ice pick to her eyes, then found a blade. Already he had bound her with telephone wire ripped from the wall.

title: A 100-Year Legacy of World War I
description: World War I demolished empires and destroyed kings, kaisers and sultans. It introduced chemical weapons and aerial bombing. It brought women into the work force and hastened their legal right to vote.

title: They Dont Make Em Like They Used To
description: ARROWSIC, Me.  TO reach our house in Maine, my wife and I drive hundreds of miles on highways, cross scores of bridges and even go through a tunnel or two. And as we come down the home stretch on a dirt lane full of rocks and ruts, I am reminded of how a piece of private real estate is a microcosm of our national infrastructure.

title: As Pakistan Advances Against Taliban, Fleeing Civilians Pour Into Northern Towns
description: BANNU, Pakistan  Pakistan stepped up its drive against the Taliban in North Waziristan on Thursday with heavy strikes and a commando raid on Miram Shah, the districts largest town, in what military officials described as the prelude to a major ground offensive.

title: Songs and Scars From Father to Son
description: Benjamin Scheuer, the writer and star of The Lion, has a pretty mane of blond hair and a wide, friendly smile thats cuter than a dozen kitty videos. When he bounds onstage to open the show, guitar in hand and dressed in a natty suit with the tie slightly askew, he looks as if hes just stepped off a fashion runway, or leapt to life from off an Abercrombie & Fitch shopping bag (albeit fully clothed).

title: The Disturbing Anthrax Accident
description: It is distressing that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which is supposedly expert at handling extremely dangerous pathogens, was so sloppy this month that it potentially exposed more than 80 people at its laboratories in Atlanta to deadly anthrax spores. The incident carries a stark warning that even the best laboratories can slip up, with potentially catastrophic consequences should they be working, as some are, with germs that can spread a lot more readily than anthrax.

title: Mangrove Menace
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  This was the worlds easiest and most enjoyable Friday puzzle I can remember doing in quite a while until I got to the bottom half. Thats when things fell apart for me.

title: BNP Paribas Expected to Plead Guilty and Pay $8.9 Billion Fine
description: BNP Paribas is set to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion penalty to state and federal authorities, according to people briefed on the case. The move would be the culmination of a widespread investigation into the French bank for transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries blacklisted by the United States.

title: The Spiritual Recession
description: For the past few centuries, the Western world has witnessed a contest of historic visions. On the one side was the dream of the beautiful collective. Human progress was a one-way march toward socialism. People would liberate themselves from religion, hierarchy and oppression. They would build a new kind of society where equality would be the rule, where rational planning would replace cruel competition.

title: In the Shadows of Shrines, Shiite Forces Are Preparing to Fight ISIS
description: KARBALA, Iraq  A dozen miles outside this shrine city, on the edges of the uninhabitable western Iraqi desert, a group of paramilitary policemen provides the only visible line of defense against the extremist Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

title: Parts Supplier Delphi Is Scrutinized in G.M. Recall
description: Senate investigators are widening the scope of the inquiry into General Motors decade-long failure to recall cars with a defective ignition switch to also focus on the supplier that made the flawed part.

title: A Unanimous Supreme Court: Abortion Rights Lose a Buffer
description: In the world as Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia imagines it, anti-abortion advocates resemble Eleanor McCullen, a self-described mother and grandmother who stands outside a reproductive-health clinic in Boston and attempts to gently counsel approaching women out of getting an abortion.

title: A Unanimous Supreme Court: A Blow to Presidential Appointments
description: When one branch of government routinely abuses its constitutional power in order to prevent another from functioning, the Supreme Court is expected to take notice and stop the abuse. Unfortunately the court failed to do so on Thursday in an important balance-of-power case, raising the prospect that President Obama and his successors could have trouble making necessary appointments to executive posts as the nations politics become more sharply polarized.

title: Events in Westchester for June 29-July 5, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Lew Unveils Small Steps to Augment Loan Modification Program
description: The Obama administration will take further steps to ease foreclosures, rising rents and scarce mortgages, Jacob J. Lew, the Treasury secretary, said on Thursday at a conference observing the fifth anniversary of Making Home Affordable, a suite of federal programs aimed at helping homeowners after the financial crisis.

title: In Bronx, Joy and Agony for Ghanas World Cup Match
description: The faithful filed into a tiny back storeroom of the Malata African Market in the Bronx, making their way past the bins of giant yams and the freezer of dried fish, and took their seats in rickety rows.

title: Events in Connecticut for June 29-July 5, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: F.D.A. Approves Remote-Control Brace
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first wearable motorized device that helps people with spinal cord injuries to walk. The device, called ReWalk, consists of a fitted metal brace that supports the legs and parts of the upper body, and a motor that moves the hips, knees and ankles. Users can command it to stand up, sit or walk using a wireless remote control worn on the wrist, but they must be assisted by another person, the agency said.

title: Events on Long Island for June 29-July 5, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Mets Night Features Lots of Outfielders, but Few Runs
description: PITTSBURGH  As the Mets took the field here Thursday, Bobby Abreu went to left field, Curtis Granderson to right and Juan Lagares to center.

title: Honduras Releases Jailed Florida Crew
description: Six Americans who traveled to the Mosquito Coast of Honduras last month planning to dredge a river but instead ended up in jail were released Thursday.

title: Knicks Draft Cleanthony Early of Wichita State
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Draft night has not always been kind to the Knicks. Not that anyone needs reminding, but there have been missteps over the years, including the selections of projects. Renaldo Balkman, anyone?

title: Plan Expedited for Affordable Housing Near Barclays Center in Brooklyn
description: After 11 years of delays, lawsuits and a recession, the developer behind the Atlantic Yards project has agreed to greatly accelerate the construction of affordable housing in a deal that involved delicate negotiations with state officials, the de Blasio administration and a coalition of community groups.

title: Cuomo Signs Bill Seeking Reforms at Queens Library
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed a Queens Library reform bill into law Thursday, a move intended to bring order to a system that has recently been under fire over its use of funds.

title: How Texans May See a Property Tax Cut
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: When to Use Your Head
New Twists as House Weighs Impeaching a Regent
description: During a special session of the Texas Legislature more than a year ago, a resolution calling for the impeachment of Wallace Hall, a University of Texas System regent, was filed in the House  and according to the leadership, it could have passed.

title: At Border, Immediacy of a Crisis Supersedes Politics
description: McALLEN, Tex.  The child whose dull eyes came alive when a shelter volunteer handed her a floppy-eared, pink bunny doll does not know she and her mother, who crossed the border with her, are in the middle of a political firestorm.

title: John Tull, Lawyer Whose Illness Created a Bioterrorism Scare, Dies at 65
description: John Tull, a New Mexico lawyer who was found to have bubonic plague during a visit to New York in November 2002, prompting alarm that the infection might have been caused by bioterrorism, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 65.

title: The Runway Is Clear
description: If Willy Wonka ran a boatyard, it might be along the lines of Evers Marina and Seaplane Base, on the Bronx waterfront.

title: Detroit Needs Residents, but Sends Some Packing
description: DETROIT  Ronald Ford Jr. has watched neighbors move away and brick houses on his familys block crumble to nothing, but he says he wants to stay put and give a chance to city leaders who now promise a renaissance. Id like to try to go with the new Detroit if thats really coming, Mr. Ford, 49, said, standing outside the house on the citys east side that he describes as precious, like a family heirloom.

title: Ask Well: Fatty Liver and Diet
description: Recently, in Threat Grows From Liver Illness Tied to Obesity, Anahad OConnor described the growing epidemic of nonalcoholic fatty liver, an illness that affects at least one in five Americans, including many teenagers. Here he responds to reader questions about what to eat if you have fatty liver.

title: Word of the Day | savor
description: savor \sa-vr\ noun and verb

title: For Young Offenders, a New Confidence Game
description: At the Crossroads Juvenile Center in Brownsville, Brooklyn, shrill buzzers announce the movement of sliding doors, and visitors leave all metal objects in lockers by the entrance. The residents are as young as 10 years old, awaiting trial on charges ranging from trespassing to murder.

title: Kenyas Future Clouds as Tensions Rise and Tourists Flee
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The line at the water tank in the Kibera slum is not as long as it used to be. Its not because of a sudden advent of indoor plumbing. Its because fewer people can afford a 10-cent jerrycan of water.

title: Niki Acosta: Camp Boss Covers All the Bases
description: When 200 or so young New Yorkers converge in Battery Park City on June 30 for the first day of a camp run by Asphalt Green, there is one thing they will not have in common with the manager Niki Acosta: She never went to camp as a child. I went to Y.M.C.A. programs, but it was only weekly, or sporadically, Ms. Acosta, 28, said the other day in her office, where she was immersed in preparations. Now in her second year at the nonprofits downtown outpost (there is also a 5.5-acre campus on the Upper East Side), she said, she has been gearing up for the first day of camp since September of last year. Ms. Acosta lives in one half of a two-family house in Woodside, Queens, with a poodle named Otis.

title: Whats on Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) BLUE JASMINE (2013) Cate Blanchett, above, won an Oscar for her role as Jasmine French, a Park Avenue matron fallen on hard times after her husband, Hal (Alec Baldwin), lands in prison for bilking his clients out of millions  leaving her with little more than her pearls, white Chanel jacket, Herms bag and monogrammed Louis Vuitton luggage. Destitute, in a manner of speaking, Jasmine flies first-class to San Francisco to begin life anew with her sister, Ginger (Sally Hawkins), whose scrappy existence and brutish men (Andrew Dice Clay and Bobby Cannavale) Jasmine can barely stomach without self-medicating with vodka and Xanax. Then she meets a diplomatic type (Peter Sarsgaard) with an appreciation for her decorating talents and designer threads, and starts to see light at the end of her terribly dark tunnel. With intimations of Ruth Madoff and Blanche DuBois, this shattered woman is brilliantly brought to quivering life by Ms. Blanchett, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, in Woody Allens most sustained, satisfying and resonant film since Match Point. What did Jasmine know about her husbands unscrupulous business dealings, and when did she know it? These questions come to haunt Blue Jasmine, and as the past catches up with the present, they help drive this moving, sometimes funny film toward its shattering end, Ms. Dargis added.

title: N.H.L. Draft Prospect Is Familiar With Pressure
description: Considered by many as the most N.H.L.-ready prospect in this weekends draft, Aaron Ekblad is no stranger to playing under immense pressure.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, June 27, 2014
description: A painted line on the sidewalk is easy to enforce, but the prime objective of the First Amendment is not efficiency.

title: Corrections: June 27, 2014
description: THE ARTS

title: Shia LaBeouf Arrested for Disorderly Conduct at Studio 54
description: The actor Shia LaBeouf was removed from the Studio 54 theater in Midtown on Thursday and arrested after disrupting a performance of the musical Cabaret.

title: Peoples Daily Takes Firm Stance Against Urine Consumption
description: If imbibing urine is not your cup of tea, Peoples Daily the solemn voice of the Chinese Communist Party is with you on that one. On Friday, the newspaper took time off from its usual encomiums to party leaders to warn people against drinking their own pee.

title: First if No Longer Foremost
description: It is called the nations Mother Court because it was created even before the United States Supreme Court, in 1789, when New York City was the nations capital. (In truth, though, the court for what became the Southern District of New York was first only because the opening of the federal court in New Jersey was delayed after a jurist became indisposed.) In The Mother Court: Tales of Cases That Mattered in Americas Greatest Trial Court (American Bar Association Publishing), James D. Zirin, a trial lawyer and former federal prosecutor, engagingly introduces readers to some of the signature trials and towering jurists of the Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: The Taco Truck Stops Here
description: The sidewalks of Sunset Park are rarely empty. Most mornings, elderly Chinese women gather on a grassy hillside in the Brooklyn neighborhood to do calisthenics to pop tunes. In the evenings, Latino kids race up and down the sloping blocks. And even in a humid drizzle, at least two dozen people lounge against a chain-link fence across from the Jackie Gleason Bus Depot at Fifth Avenue and 37th Street, waiting for tacos.

title: An Icon of Indian Roads Is Set Out to Pasture
description: When the Ambassador car was born in 1957 to a newly independent India, it was the height of style and status, Nida Najar wrote in The New York Times.It was standard issue to senior civil servants and government officials; its possession implied status, and its ubiquity was a sign of an earlier, seemingly simpler India.

title: Student Crossword | Africa
description: Test your knowledge of Africa by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Lawsuit Adds to Concern Over China Commodities Fraud
description: HONG KONG  Chinas commodities fraud scandal continues to widen, with more companies reporting losses on bogus aluminum and copper financing deals, while Chinese authorities now say gold contracts have also been faked to secure more than $15 billion in loans.

title: 6 Qs About the News | U.S. Moves On With Assist From Portugal
description: In U.S. Moves On With Assist From Portugal, Sam Borden writes about the results of Thursdays United States-Germany World Cup game.

title: UniCredits Online Unit Raises at Least $916 Million in I.P.O.
description: LONDON  FinecoBank, an online banking and brokerage arm of the Italian lender UniCredit, said on Friday that it had raised at least 673 million euros, or about $916 million, in its initial public offering in Italy.

title: U.S. Lays Groundwork to Reduce Land Mines and Join Global Treaty
description: After five years of study, the Obama administration put the United States on a course Friday to eventually sign the global treaty that bans antipersonnel land mines, announcing steps that will gradually reduce the American stockpile and find ways to adjust for any military disadvantage in purging the weapons.

title: What the Camera Sees, and Doesnt See
description: The photograph from January 2013 is ethereal: a close-up of goldfish swimming in an aquarium. The water that sustains them is ominously cloudy. Yet, they survive.

title: Defying Russia, Ukraine Signs E.U. Trade Pact
description: BRUSSELS  Dealing a defiant blow to the Kremlin, President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine signed a long-delayed trade pact with Europe on Friday that Moscow had bitterly opposed. He then declared he would like his country to one day become a full member of the European Union.

title: New York Today: Pick Your Pool
description: Good morning to you on this summer-break Friday.

title: In Taiwan, Chinese Official Confronted With Voices of Democracy
description: Zhang Zhijun, the highest-ranking Chinese official to visit Taiwan, has said he wanted to hear the voices of its people during his four-day trip to the self-governed island. Demonstrators in Taiwan have tried to meet that request, following him since the start of his visit on Wednesday. And while the official meetings have been less confrontational, with talk of increasing trade and travel across the Taiwan Strait, some local leaders have also talked up Taiwans democratic values, a sharp contrast with Communist-ruled China, which considers Taiwan as part of its territory.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now.

title: A Minimum Wage That Makes More Sense
description: Travel around this country a bit and, assuming your purchases are not confined to airports and big hotel chains, you will find that prices vary a great deal. Prices in New York State are 15 percent above the national average, while those in Arkansas are 12 percent below average. Housing is about twice as costly in Massachusetts as in Mississippi.

title: Daily Report: Effort by Facebook to Safeguard Data From the Law Fails, For Now
description: Facebook and the Manhattan district attorneys office are in a bitter fight over the governments demand for the contents of hundreds of Facebook accounts, Vindu Goel and James C. McKinley Jr. report.

title: The Agriculture Secretary Sees a Smart (Phone) Solution to GMO Labeling Fight
description: Ive been at the Aspen Ideas Festival, which has focused this week on next steps for healthy living, including better food choices.

title: New Signs That China Is Scrutinizing Foreign NGOs
description: An image being passed around the social media site Weibo  posted by the Chinese newsmagazine Phoenix Weekly, among others  shows several men straining to hoist a flag atop rubble, a reference to the iconic World War II image of American troops hoisting the United States flag at Iwo Jima.

title: Sorry, Harry Reid: Koch Industries Probably Pays a Lot of Corporate Tax
description: In 2010, the economist Austan Goolsbee said something he would come to regret: On a White House conference call, in his capacity as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, he named Koch Industries as an example of a large company that does not pay corporate income tax because of the way it is organized.

title: Junya Watanabe: Spring 2015 Menswear
description: Paris

title: A Photographer Hunting for Light
description: Throughout the Times headquarters on Eighth Avenue, the walls are decorated with news images from the past. In this series well take you inside the building to see the photographs  many of them rich in history  and the stories behind them.

title: In Class Action Against Apple and Others, Concerns From the Judge
description: Silicon Valley, at least according to myth, is all about risking everything on an idea. You seize a dream and do not let it go until you make it or they come and repossess your desk. Failure in the valley is admired. It makes you smarter, tougher, more likely to succeed next time.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 3 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: In the news this week: Supreme Court rulings on abortion protests, cellphone searches and more.

title: Morning Views
description: In the world as Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia imagines it, anti-abortion advocates resemble Eleanor McCullen, a self-described mother and grandmother who stands outside a reproductive-health clinic in Boston and attempts to gently counsel approaching women out of getting an abortion, writes The New York Times Editorial Board, in response to the Courts decision to strike down a Massachusetts law that established buffer zones around abortion clinics. The editorial says the ruling ignores what actually happens on the ground, including a long and sometimes violent history of protest at reproductive-health clinics.

title: Report Underscores Lingering Doubts in Search for Missing Plane
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  As Australia prepares a yearlong search for the jet carrying Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 in an area of ocean floor the size of Croatia or West Virginia, a government report underscores the lingering uncertainty about where the plane went down, noting that it might have fallen in an area of the southern Indian Ocean up to 19 times as large as the new search area.

title: Why Is the World Silent?
description: TORA, Egypt  In a few days time, I will complete 365 days of imprisonment, more than half spent in solitary confinement and under severe limitations in the maximum-security Scorpion wing of Tora prison in Cairo. I have spent the past year thinking about what drove me to where I am today. I have also been thinking about an explanation for why politicians, human rights activists and the media have largely been silent about my case.

title: Chinas Anticorruption Campaign Unseats a Powerful Party Chief in Guangzhou
description: HONG KONG  The Communist Party chief of Guangzhou, one of Chinas most populous and wealthiest cities, has been held for investigation by the partys anticorruption agency, state-run media announced on Friday, one day after he admonished city officials to embrace President Xi Jinpings campaign against lax discipline.

title: Morning Agenda: $8.9 Billion Penalty for BNP
description: BNP TO PLEAD GUILTY AND PAY $8.9 BILLION FINE | BNP Paribas is set to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion penalty to state and federal authorities, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. The move would be the culmination of a widespread investigation into the French bank for transferring billions of dollars on behalf of Sudan and other countries blacklisted by the United States. The plea deal, which authorities hope to announce on Monday, will include a statement of facts that outlines how BNP, Frances largest bank, hid the names of Sudanese clients when processing transactions through its American operations.

title: Oh You Silly Thing, of Course Hes Gay
description: As he descends a staircase in the opening scene of Vicious, a new comedy making its PBS debut on Sunday, Ian McKellen overhears his lover, played by Derek Jacobi, reacting to bad news he received on the telephone.

title: Orange Is the New Black Recap: All Theyre Missing Is a Black Market Etsy
description: Season 2, Episode 7 The world is too much with our friends at Litchfield as their various commercial enterprises kick into high gear. And this episode, Comic Sans, brings the mounting sense that all this getting and spending will not end well.

title: How Islamic Fundamentalists Will Rule Mosul
description: From the way they have run Raqqa city and parts of eastern Syria, we can make an educated guess as to how jihadis from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) will govern Mosul. Women probably wont be able to go out on their own. Coke and other Western products will likely be banned. Suspected thieves may well be detained and might risk amputation, execution or public flogging. As the group sweeps through Iraq in a surprise advance thats left everyone from Assad to Obama wondering how to halt it, Mosuls residents just need to look next door for evidence of the extremist groups notoriously harsh governing tactics.

title: While You Were Watching World Cup 2014
description: Nobody was watching the skies.

title: Today in Small Business: How Much Cash Can I Take Out?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Among Gay C.E.O.s, the Pressure to Conform
description: In 2007, John Browne, Lord Browne of Madingley, resigned as chief executive of the British oil giant BP after being outed as gay by the tabloid The Mail on Sunday: The True story about Lord Browne  by ex-rent boy lover.

title: Milan Fashion Week Crowd Honors Dorchester Boycott
description: MILAN  It was nearing midnight. On television screens in the bar of the Principe, on the last day of the mens wear shows here, a World Cup match was playing. Unusually for this venue, every kick and call could be heard. Roughly half the tables were filled with couples or groups drinking quietly, and at the overstaffed bar, at least five servers waited to fill orders.

title: Chinese Workers at Iraq Power Plant Said to be Headed to Safety
description: More than 1,000 Chinese workers at a power plant north of Baghdad were being evacuated to the capital city after previous attempts to move them to safety had failed, associates of the workers and Chinese state media said on Friday.

title: Reliving Childhood Excursions
description: For children of the 1980s, there was no shortage of opportunities to see kids like themselves being heroes, while also being kids, on the big screen. Movies like E. T. and Stand by Me were hallmarks, placing young people in extraordinary situations and giving them room to explore new worlds just a bike ride away. They showed boys and girls on adventures of their own making, with their parents often on the sidelines. If the new science-fiction film Earth to Echo, due in theaters on Wednesday, bears a resemblance to these 80s movies, its because the men behind it were raised on them.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Junya Watanabe Spring/Summer 2015
