description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

title: After 25 Years, Modest Gains at Mumbai Breast Milk Bank
description: MUMBAI On a recent afternoon, 27-year-old Ashwini Agarwal adjusted her sari as she emerged from the crowded outpatient department at the Lokmanya Tilak Hospital, a public facility that houses the oldest of Indias roughly 14 breast milk banks, established a quarter of a century ago.

title: An Education of the Heart: The Glenwood Towers Senior Center Prom
description: Can I have this dance? a woman in a strapless black sundress said, offering her hand to my son. It was 93 degrees out on the patio at the senior center in downtown Raleigh, N.C. Aidan, dressed in his only suit and a striped tie, said, of course. I heard Esther counting the steps for him as she guided him into a waltz. One-two-three. One-two-three.

title: Russia Abruptly Cancels Rocket Launch
description: MOSCOW  The long-awaited inaugural launch of a new Russian space rocket, the Angara, was abruptly canceled on Friday just minutes before takeoff, the Russian space agency Roscosmos reported.

title: Shiite Cleric in Iraq Urges Quick Decision on New Government
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs top Shiite cleric on Friday urged the countrys divided political factions to select a prime minister by early next week in a public call for a political solution that increases the pressure on the embattled prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

title: In Our Pages: June 28
description: 1889: Salvation Army Versus Police

title: Shes No Ones Idea of a Grandma
description: Susan Sarandon was mildly disappointed that she wouldnt make the trek to Burning Man this summer. She attended that free-spirited Nevada desert festival for the first time last year, and said she felt safely inconspicuous since theres a lot of girls walking around with amazing bodies and no clothes on, so youre not that interesting. She even thought about bringing some of Timothy Learys ashes with her on a return visit.

title: Lawyers Defend Hong Kong Rule of Law in Show of Unity Against Beijing
description: Hundreds of lawyers, many clad in black, marched in Hong Kong on Friday to demonstrate their concern that a recent policy paper issued by Beijing poses a threat to the rule of law in the city.

title: A New Search Zone for Malaysian Jet
description: Officials expanded the hunt for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 into an area farther south. An investigation concluded that the plane was likely on autopilot before it vanished.

title: Is The Times Ignoring a Scandal at the I.R.S.?
description: Has The Times been interested enough in the politically charged events involving the Internal Revenue Service?

title: Whats News in Washington: Obama Returns, Powers Diminished
description: GoodFridaymorning from Washington.

title: A Nudge to Save a Bit More
description: If youre an active participant in social media, its nearly impossible to avoid a running tally of everyone elses spending. New cars and home renovations are all over Facebook. Vacation photos, exotic meals and charity benefits are a fixture on Instagram.

title: The Art Crowd Returns to Kent, England
description: The Isle of Thanet, a thumb of land protruding from the Kent Coast in England, has always been a draw for creative types. T. S. Eliot wrote there, referencing Margate Sands in The Waste Land; Broadstairs was a favored getaway of Charles Dickens; and the 19th-century painter J. M. W. Turner supposedly said the skies over Thanet are the loveliest in all Europe  a sentiment no doubt shared by many of the artists who are again coming to the area.

title: Not So Fast on the Use of Google Glass in Britain
description: LONDON  For tech-savvy Britons, the debut in this country of Googles Glass headset on Monday was greeted with much fanfare.

title: Q. & A. | Fashion Designer Duro Olowu on Curating His Second Art Show
description: Do you think its a bad idea to put this on the floor? asked the fashion designer Duro Olowu yesterday as one of his assistants positioned a bulbous ceramic vessel near the entrance of theSalon 94 Bowerygallery. As he directed art handlers and gallery assistants to arrange a hodgepodge of sculptures, textiles and framed artworks into dense vignettes in preparation forhis second gallery show as curator, More Material, which opens to the public today,Olowu seemed as hands-on as he would designing a dress in his studio.

title: A World Cup of the Americas Ends Upbeat First Phase
description: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil  The opening phase of this World Cup ended with Algerians celebrating, and they were hardly the only ones feeling upbeat after a first round to remember.

title: A Fashionable Role for Julian Assange?
description: No, this is not a joke. Ben Westwood, the 51-year-old son of that agent provocateur Dame Vivienne Westwood, on Friday proved himself heir to his mothers crusading mantle by announcing he was planning to have Julian Assange, the Wikileaks founder, model in his debut fashion show in London this September.

title: Presenting Play-Doh
description: The artist Jeff Koons unveils his new sculpture Play-Doh in a retrospective at the Whitney Museum. The piece took 20 years to complete.

title: In Paris, the Bastille Neighborhood Recaptures Its Cool
description: Fifteen years ago, Bastille was the emerging cool neighborhood of Paris. Then, as the masses discovered the south side of the 11th Arrondissement, the inevitable backlash occurred. The citys self-appointed tastemakers declared the area fini and decamped for points north and west. Bastille descended into a haven of grungy student bars, low-end creperies and charmless fast-food outlets. Over the last year, however, some of Frances most famous restaurateurs, chefs and designers have planted their flags in the neighborhood where the famous prison once stood. Style-savvy upstarts have done likewise, further elevating the areas profile for epicures and night owls. Little by little, a new crowd is storming Bastille.

title: At the Month-Mark, Modi Reflects
description: NEW DELHI On Thursday, as the government headed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi completed 30 days in office, Mr. Modi, with a perceptible confidence in his political persona, reached out to the public through a blog post.

title: Sleep as a Competitive Advantage
description: At 6 p.m. last Friday, I boarded a plane for Bangalore, India. At 1 p.m. Tuesday, I arrived back in New York after two days of meetings and traveling 34 hours across nine time zones. As you can imagine, I didnt see much of Bangalore.

title: R.B.S. to Spend $1.7 Billion on Mobile Banking Growth
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland is making a major bet that consumers in the future will do most of their banking on mobile phones or tablets.

title: After Buffer Zone Ruling, Abortion Rivals Prepare to Square Off Anew
description: BOSTON  Lorraine Loewen, 74, says she comes here once a week to demonstrate against abortion outside of the Planned Parenthood League of Massachusetts health care center.

title: The Perils of Anaerobic Driving
description: Plus: Gazprom vs. the prom; fireworks displays, ranked.

title: The Real Hedwigs
description: The Broadway success of Hedwig and the Angry Inch suggests that gender-bending male performance has moved closer to the American mainstream, but it has also been flourishing in clubs around the world. The photographer Magnus Arrevad spent close to five years in several countries, documenting men applying makeup, dressing in elaborate costumes and performing. One of them, Eric Gorsuch, who goes by Mr. Gorgeous, says he has witnessed the transformation of the art form in real time. Im superlucky in that I feel like, even looking five years ago till now, so many people today are aware of and acknowledge different kinds of sexuality  gay, straight, bisexual, whatever, he says. When society becomes a little more aware of other peoples lifestyles, it allows people to make decisions artistically. For me, if it was 10 years ago, I dont think I would feel as confident being a male performer doing a parody of a stocking peel in high heels. Julie Bosman

title: How to Solve an 88-Year-Old Literary Mystery
description: As Edward and Rebecca Cummings passed the town of Center Ossipee, N.H., in their new 1926 Franklin sedan, it began to snow. They left their home in Cambridge, Mass., hours before, driving a car with high seats, no defroster and a top speed of about 50. Rebecca took over the driving for the last part of the trip to their summer place at Silver Lake.

title: Reply All: The 6.15.14 Issue
description: THE NEXT FRONT IN THE TERRORISM FIGHT

title: Looking for the Russia I Once Knew
description: On my last night in Petrozavodsk, in the last months of the Soviet Union, I stood in an unlit back alley buying boots off a soldier from the nearby army base. They were knee-high, and black, and illegal. It was midnight. I was 14. For about a month, Id lived with a host family as part of a student exchange. In a week, leaving the country, I would wait, sweating, at Sheremetyevo airport while security rummaged through random suitcases, hoping they wouldnt choose mine. Soviet Army surplus is ubiquitous now, but in 1991, you had to buy it on the black market and smuggle it out. If you got caught, I figured, you probably stayed in Moscow while the rest of your exchange group flew home.

title: Who Made That Slip N Slide?
description: Long before Apple and Amazon were founded in humble garages, another quintessentially if decidedly lower-tech American success story began the same way  only the garage was used as a human launching pad.

title: Carl Hart: Crack Wasnt the Real Problem
description: The Columbia professor talks to Amy Chozick about what the public, politicians and even Public Enemy don't get about drug addiction.

title: Is It Wrong to Spoil World Cup Results?
description: A friend of mine is a soccer fan, but instead of checking scores and highlights of the World Cup while hes at work, he records every game to watch later on  usually in the evening, sometimes the next day. He gets annoyed when friends ruin the outcome of a game before he has had the chance to see it in full; he acts as if weve just spoiled the conclusion of Breaking Bad. Do I have an ethical obligation not to discuss the outcome of games in my friends company until he has caught up? J. S., COLUMBUS, OHIO

title: The Brave New World of Three-Parent I.V.F.
description: In August 1996, at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J., a 39-year-old mechanical engineer from Pittsburgh named Maureen Ott became pregnant. Ott had been trying for almost seven years to conceive a child through in vitro fertilization. Unwilling to give up, she submitted to an experimental procedure in which doctors extracted her eggs, slid a needle through their shiny coat and injected not only her husbands sperm but also a small amount of cytoplasm from another womans egg. When the embryo was implanted in Otts womb, she became the first woman on record to be successfully impregnated using this procedure, which some say is the root of an exciting medical advance and others say is the beginning of the end of the human species.

title: Image of the Day: June 27
Weekend Auto Calendar: Goodwood Is Addicted to Winning
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: Reform Conservatism on Work and Poverty
description: Turning back to this weeks official theme, reform conservatisms liberal critics, I want to discuss a recent column from my colleague Thomas Edsall that, without mentioning our quasi-movement by name, raises one of the sharpest objections to our program of any left-of-center piece Ive seen. Where reform conservatives tend to argue for a welfare system and tax code organized more explicitly around work and family, Edsalls piece makes the case thatweve already tried something like that approach have been trying it, in fact, since the early 1990s and that it has worked out pretty badly, failing completely at its stated work-promoting aims while making life increasingly desperate for the very poor.

title: U.S. Catfish Program Could Stymie Pacific Trade Pact, 10 Nations Say
description: WASHINGTON  Ten Asian and Pacific nations have told the Office of the United States Trade Representative that the Agriculture Departments catfish inspection program violates international law, and their objections could hamper Obama administration efforts to reach a major Pacific trade agreement by the end of next year.

title: Mary Rodgers, Author and Composer in a Musical Family, Dies at 83
description: Mary Rodgers, who wrote songs and childrens books and, by virtue of genetics and serendipity as well as talent, lived at the red-hot center of American musical theater, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 83.

title: Shares of Michaels, Arts and Crafts Retailer, Are Flat on Debut
description: Updated, 5:41 p.m. |

title: Five Guys and a Mean-Looking Dude
description: Dear Diary:

title: Kris Van Assch: Spring 2015 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Letters: Carters Woman Question
description: Carters Woman Question

title: Starting From Scratch
description: Robert Galbraiths The Silkworm is reviewed this week, and with all due respect to Galbraith, the extent of his success may be due entirely to J. K. Rowling. The mystery is the second written by the Harry Potter creator under the pseudonym. I was yearning to go back to the beginning of a writing career in this new genre, to work without hype or expectation and to receive totally unvarnished feedback, she wrote on her website last year after being unmasked. Oh, well.

title: Paperback Row
description: FORTY-ONE FALSE STARTS: Essays on Artists and Writers,  by Janet Malcolm. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.) Whether shes observing artists and writers present (David Salle, Thomas Struth) or past (Edith Wharton, the Bloomsbury group), what resonates most here is Malcolms cool intelligence and psychoanalytic knack for noticing. The title essay, a 1994 profile of Salle, starts over 41 times, parodying Salles own violent juxtaposition of images.

title: Editors Choice
description: SONG OF THE SHANK,  by Jeffery Renard Allen. (Graywolf, paper, $18.) Allens masterly novel blends the personal story of the enslaved autistic piano prodigy Thomas Wiggins with the history of the Civil War and Reconstruction.

title: Filmmakers
description: FIVE CAME BACK  A Story of Hollywood and the Second World War  By Mark Harris  Penguin Press, $29.95.

title: Ghost of the Confederacy
description: Robert E. Lee occupies a remarkable place in the pantheon of American history, combining in the minds of many, Michael Korda writes in this admiring and briskly written biography, a strange combination of martyr, secular saint, Southern gentleman and perfect warrior. Indeed, Korda aptly adds, It is hard to think of any other general who had fought against his own country being so completely reintegrated into national life.

title: The Awakening
description: Le Roy, N.Y., a former factory town between Rochester and Buffalo, became famous three years ago when 14 girls and one boy were afflicted with undiagnosed verbal and physical tics. Cheerleaders writhing and snarling on the Today show: Its not hard to understand why Megan Abbott, a reliable producer of noir page turners, based her seventh novel, The Fever, on the Le Roy outbreak. In real life, the underpinnings of the teenagers outbursts turned out to be psychological. But in The Fever, Abbott attributes the epidemic to a curious brand of black magic.

title: Marooned
description: To quote a line thats sure to make hearts flutter: Were almost completely cut off here. In THE BONES BENEATH (Atlantic Monthly, $25), we is a party composed of Mark Billinghams supersleuth, Inspector Tom Thorne; a skeleton staff of police officers and crime scene investigators; and two murderers. Here is a mountainous island off the coast of Wales, said to be the resting place of 20,000 saints. And being cut off from civilization is fair warning that the characters in this thriller are likely to revert to savagery.

title: Feds Balance Sheet Punctuated by a Big Question Mark
description: In the midst of the Federal Reserves creative but controversial quantitative easing program  the five-year plan of buying billions of dollars in debt securities each month and forcing down interest rates to historically low levels  the central banks balance sheet has ballooned to nearly $4.3 trillion in assets from $800 billion, leaving one large unanswered question hanging over the marketplace: What does the Fed intend to do with all those bonds?

title: Photographers on the Front Lines of the Great War
description: A century after the start of World War I, the trail blazed  and lessons learned  by pioneering photojournalists on the front lines still resonate..

title: Nixon and Pel: No Meeting of the Minds
description: On Tuesday, May 8, 1973, at midday, Richard Nixon received the soccer star Pel, member of the Brazilian team that won the World Cup championship of 1970. (In 1999, the International Olympic Committee voted Pel Athlete of the Century. He is now 73 and retired.)

title: Art Matters | The Gallery Queen of Palm Beach Takes L.A.
description: Most art dealers have opened their happy-go-lucky summer shows and are gearing up to close for the dog days come August. Last night, however, Sarah Gavlak  whose Gavlak Gallery in Palm Beach has survived many a balmy winter as the only game in town  opened a new space in Los Angeles. And this time, Gavlak has plenty of competition in her new backyard. The L.A. gallery occupies a former manufacturing plant on Highland Avenue below Santa Monica Boulevard  just a couple of storefronts up from Hannah Hoffman gallery, around the corner from Regen Projects, and just a block or so down from Kohn Gallerys roomy new digs that opened just last month.

title: Bargains With a But
description: A four-bedroom on the Upper West Side listed for $875,000 has been languishing since December. A $385,000 two-bedroom in Manhattan Valley has been available for six months. And a studio in Chelsea with a $299,000 price tag only recently went into contract after nearly a year and $60,000 in price cuts.

title: Dov Charney, Vying to Regain Control of American Apparel, Seeks to Increase His Stake
description: The pressure is mounting at American Apparel, the retailer of American-made clothing that fired its founder, Dov Charney, last week.

title: Gunslingers
description: Wonderful title. Head-scratcher of a novel.

title: Ltranger
description: How long can we keep on kidding these people? George Orwell asked in 1939 after a walk through Marrakeshs vast squalor in French-ruled Morocco. Orwell, who himself had earlier been a colonial British official in Burma, went on: How long before they turn their guns in the other direction?

title: Fortunes Daughter
description: At the end, she loved watching SpongeBob and the Smurfs, bidding (by proxy) on antique French dolls and writing enormous checks to her nurse, sometimes two in one day. When she died in 2011 at 104, Huguette Clark was flush with property  apartments totaling 42 rooms on Fifth Avenue, a 23-acre estate in Santa Barbara and a 22-room mansion in New Canaan, Conn., that she had never bothered to furnish. (In 1961, her Santa Barbara caretaker quit because he was suffering from the isolation: Clark had reportedly not visited the place since 1953.) Yet despite such splendid real estate, Clark had chosen to spend the final two decades of her life in a series of modest hospital rooms attended by a small circle of extremely well-paid retainers, including her doctor, her nurse, her accountant and her lawyer.

title: These Ages of Shoddy
description: Henry Petroski, an engineer whos also a fine writer, has a lament about the decline of good construction in todays Times. Its a great read; Im trying to figure out whether I believe in his premise.

title: Neighborhood Watch
description: In the middle of the night, a jet-lagged woman, unable to sleep, goes for a walk along a country road in the New England town where her family has summered for generations. Frankie Rowley, newly returned from years of relief work in Africa, is certainly lost in the middle of her lifes journey, and in a dark night, if not precisely in a dark wood. Unsure of her place in the world, unsure whether she has a place in the world, Frankie has come to Pomeroy, N.H., for a life-reassessment disguised as a visit to her parents, who have decided to live full time in their summer house following her fathers retirement from teaching. Its only after a car passes Frankie on the road, its headlights sweeping past in a disorienting arc, that she realizes the smell of smoke has been in the air for some time.

title: Inside the List
description: Inner Bloke: Back in 2006, when J. K. Rowling was at work on her seventh and final Harry Potter novel, an unnamed publishing insider told The Daily Express in Britain that she will soon be in a position where she doesnt have to write if she doesnt want to, and if she does, she can write whatever she chooses. Heres the update, eight years and three non-Potter books later: Rowling wants to write. But she could do without the distractions of fame; thats why she adopted the pseudonym Robert Galbraith for her Cormoran Strike crime series, also projected to last seven volumes. (The Silkworm, the second entry in the series, enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 2, while its predecessor, The Cuckoos Calling, is No. 8 on the trade paperback list.) When I unmasked myself to my editor, Rowling says on the official Robert Galbraith website, one of the first things he said was I never would have thought a woman wrote that. Apparently I had successfully channeled my inner bloke!

title: Li Na Ousted at Wimbledon; Novak Djokovic Advances
description: WIMBLEDON, England  After leading out of the gates at the beginning of the year, Li Na has now twice become one of the fastest top players to the exits at the last two Grand Slam events.

title: Between Innings
description: The sport of deciphering baseball  of finding embedded within the history, structure, statistics and conventions of our national pastime some secret cultural code that might cast light on our cryptic national character  was born in 1954. Seven years earlier, Jackie Robinson had signed with the Brooklyn Dodgers to break the sports color line, finally giving baseball the conditio sine qua non for any democratic claims it might make. Two years before that, American servicemen in Europe had celebrated Germanys surrender by gleefully retrofitting the Nuremberg stadium into a ballpark, holding regular games where Hitler had recently rallied the Nazis.

title: As Bad as It Gets
description: Between 1921 and 1970, the Chicago Bears won eight N.F.L. championships as tenants of Wrigley Field. The Yankees and Tigers have clinched the World Series there, but the Cubs, who have played in the park since 1916, never have. In fact, they havent won a World Series since 1908, a stretch of futility longer than that of any other North American sports franchise. Whats the problem?

title: As Iraq Smolders, The Times Fortifies Its Baghdad Bureau
description: BAGHDAD  Three weeks ago, the Times bureau consisted of two rooms in the BBC house in central Baghdad. The nonresident bureau chief, Tim Arango, had moved to Istanbul, though he had been back many times in the past year as the storm clouds gathered, and the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria grew ever stronger.

title: Moving In, Slowly, to Billionaires Row
description: As soon as Linda Phillips and her husband heard about One57, a luxury 90-story skyscraper that is nearing completion on West 57th Street, they raced from the pied--terre they rented at the Time Warner Center across Columbus Circle to take a look.

title: Saudi King Promises Help in Delicate Effort to Unite Factions in Iraq
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia assured American officials on Friday that he would use his influence with Sunni leaders in Iraq to try to speed the formation of a multisect government there, a senior State Department official said.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking
description: For a government agency thats flown under the radar for most of its 80-year history, the Export-Import Bank of the United States is getting a lot of attention recently: Its now at the center of a fight in Congress over the role of government in business. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar look at why the Export-Import Bank is under such scrutiny, and what it means for business in general.

title: 50 Ways to Love Your Quinoa
description: Youd think I would eventually run out of ideas for quinoa. Ive posted over 50 recipes on this page over the years. But ideas keep coming and I keep loving this grain (O.K., Paleos, I know, its a seed, not a grain. But we use it on the plate like a grain, so thats what Ill continue to call it.)

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The French Intifada
description: This week, Andrew Hussey talks about The French Intifada; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the weeks literary news; Alice Goffman discusses On the Run; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties:

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The French Intifada
description: This week, Andrew Hussey and Alice Goffman.

title: Ukraine Signs European Union Trade Deal
description: President Petro O. Poroshenko spoke at the signing ceremony of the trade deal between Ukraine and the European Union in Brussels.

title: When Negativity Is What We Need
description: If your friend is feeling bad about himself, you might try to convince him that everythings actually O.K. But a new study suggests this kind of reassurance doesnt necessarily make people with low self-esteem feel better, and some say its further evidence against the idea that positive thinking heals all wounds.

title: Mysterious Art: An Installation Inspired by the Bermuda Triangle
description: Fifty years ago the Bermuda Triangle entered international pop-culture consciousness with a cover article in the pulp magazine Argosy describing a treacherous patch of sea that seemed to swallow up aircraft and ships with alarming and mysterious frequency.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Driven | 2015 Subaru Legacy 2.5i
description: All-wheel drive and invisibility come standard.

title: New York Parish Fears Losing Daily Dose of Spiritus Sancti
description: As the Rev. Justin Wylie took the pulpit at the Church of the Holy Innocents in Manhattan last month, anger and anxiety emanated from the pews. The church is the only one in New York City to offer a daily traditional Latin Mass, but an archdiocesan panel had recommended that it be closed.

title: Defending Devotees of the Latin Mass in New York
description: At the end of his sermon on May 18, the Rev. Justin Wylie, a visiting priest from South Africa, defended the traditionalist parishioners of Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Innocents on West 37th Street in Manhattan. He told them that even if the Archdiocese of New York follows through with a recent recommendation to close their church, they should still insist that the archdiocese provide devotees of the Latin Mass with a spiritual home.

title: After a Dismal Quarter, a Rosy Outlook
description: THROUGHOUT the economic recovery since the Great Recession officially ended in the summer of 2009, consumers have generally remained doubtful that the economy really has gotten better. Now, as they finally conclude that the business climate has improved, a hitherto perfect recession indicator has sounded a warning.

title: Movie Review: Snowpiercer
description: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews Snowpiercer.

title: Photographers on the Front Lines of the Great War
description: A century after the start of the First World War, the trail blazed  and lessons learned  by pioneering photojournalists on the front lines still resonate.

title: Movie Review: Begin Again
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Begin Again.

title: What Happened to the Facebook Phone? Not Very Much, It Seems
description: Facebook has long wanted to be a major part of how you use your smartphone. Now, it looks as if the company has all but abandoned one of its major strategies to do so.

title: Video: The 2015 Subaru Legacy Feels Better Than It Looks
description: Its better to look good than to feel good, or so said Billy Crystal channeling Fernando Lamas. Why choose? These days, you can have it all in the midsize sedan segment. The current Fusion, Optima, Mazda 6 and Chrysler 200 all look mah-velous. More important, sales numbers reflect their fashion-forward confidence.

title: Movie Review: Transformers 4
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Transformers: Age of Extinction.

title: Days of Imperial Pleasures and Regrets
description: SANDWICH, England  Jane Gardams most famous novel, Old Filth, begins with stage directions and elliptical dialogue, which its tempting to imitate in describing Ms. Gardam, a writer who unites literary critics in puzzlement over why she isnt more famous.

title: Where Old Curiosity Shops Abounded
description: Just when did we let 57th Street slip out of our hands? I mean the fashionable address that had room for the funny little shop, the offbeat bookstore, the aged brownstone, the fragment of a mansion? It is hard to put a finger on any particular new development that crossed the line, but one disappearance sums up for me the long-lost magic of the street.

title: Military Multipliers of Death
description: In World War I, technical advances in warfare on land, sea and even the air put deadly new tools in the hands of millions, and death and destruction resulted on a scale without precedent.

title: Broken Windows, Broken Parks
description: A few weeks ago in an interview with The New York Times, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton signaled his distaste for subway showmen, suggesting that their music-fueled cartwheeling was not just a disruption of mass-transit reading habits but, rather, symbolized a sort of latent urban menace. Two decades after he last ran the countrys largest police force, broken-windows policing, the practice of combating minor offenses in an effort to deter more serious ones, hasnt lost its fascination for Mr. Bratton.

title: Hillary Clintons Hard Choices Blocked in China
description: BEIJING  The new memoir of Hillary Rodham Clinton, Hard Choices, which gives blow-by-blow accounts of tough discussions with Chinese officials, particularly on human rights, has been blocked in China, according to the American publisher.

title: A Show House With Lots to Show
description: Starting on Sunday, Holiday House Hamptons will showcase indoor and outdoor living spaces created by 18 interior and landscape designers, each honoring a holiday of its creators choosing and often of the designers invention. Presented by Hamptons Cottages & Gardens magazine, the event benefits the Breast Cancer Research Foundation.

title: Book Review Podcast: The French Intifada
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Mitchell Cohen reviews Andrew Husseys The French Intifada: The Long War Between France and Its Arabs. Mr. Cohen writes:

title: What to Look for in the Penny Dreadful Finale on Sunday
description: With just one episode left, the witching hour may finally be upon us.

title: Martin Indyk, U.S. Mideast Envoy, Steps Down
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department said Friday that Martin S. Indyk, who led the yearlong American effort to revive Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations, was resigning from his position as special envoy.

title: Allergan, Maker of Botox, Acquiesces to Special Shareholder Meeting
description: Allergan, the maker of Botox, and Pershing Square Capital Management have struck an agreement that will allow for the calling of a special meeting of Allergan shareholders, the latest development in the slow-moving $53 billion takeover effort by Pershing Square and Valeant Pharmaceuticals.

title: Smart Beta Investing Lets the Yardstick Pick the Stocks
description: WHEN it comes to investing money, most people want to be smart about it. So an increasingly popular strategy with smart in its name has intrigued certain investors, while turning off others who see it as little more than a marketing gimmick.

title: My-House-Is-Your-House Rules
description: Painted seashells, a lurid conch, a Pierrot-themed weather vane, a giant starfish waving an American flag, two raffia chickens with googley eyes, an ambitious amount of tern art: If you had to categorize the contents of the beach house I rented that summer under one artistic school, youd probably go with Alcoholic Gift Shop.

title: The Times Critics Guide to the Transformers Movies
description: With Transformers: Age of Extinction opening Friday, viewers may be wondering what critics for The New York Times had to say about the previous installments in this enduring saga of flying robot battles. Wonder no more. If you want the current review, it is here.

title: Yes, if You Cut Taxes, You Get Less Tax Revenue
description: Kansas has a problem. In April and May, the state planned to collect $651 million from personal income tax. But instead, it received only $369 million.

title: Camerons Protests Rebuffed as European Commission Leader Is Chosen
description: BRUSSELS  Despite bitter opposition from Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, European Union leaders voted on Friday to name Jean-Claude Juncker as the next president of the blocs powerful bureaucracy, bringing an end to a struggle that had pitted some of the groups top leaders against each other.

title: Argentinas Bond Payment Is Rebuffed by U.S. Judge
description: Updated, 7:35 p.m. | A federal judge on Friday delivered a stern warning to Argentina after the country deposited $539 million with the Bank of New York Mellon for the purpose of paying its main class of bondholders.

title: The Timess Coverage Related to Patrick Lavin
description: From the 19th century.

title: Historical Documents Related to Patrick Lavin
description: Testimony from the manslaughter indictment of Patrick Lavin and the coroners report on the killing of Casper Pfost, as well as Patrick Lavins retirement certificate.

title: A Copper, a Dust-Up and Death
description: I found it after reading through the indictment, consulting archival maps and applying the measurements where the original tenements once stood, in Chelsea. Now, on an innocuous patch of crab grass between the corner of a red brick building and a concrete walkway winding through the Chelsea-Elliott housing complex, I was standing on the spot where, 125 years ago, my great-great-grandfather killed a man.

title: 2 Carmakers to Share a Plant in Mexico
description: FRANKFURT  Daimler and Renault-Nissan significantly expanded their automaking alliance on Friday, saying they would jointly build a production plant in Mexico to build a new generation of compact Mercedes and Infiniti cars.

title: Looking to Cars, Trucks Step Up Safety
description: Large trucks may be involved in fewer crashes than passenger vehicles, but their size almost guarantees that the consequences of those collisions will be severe.

title: Letter to Obama Administration About Guantanamo Uruguay Deal
description: Lawyers for six Guantanamo detainees who were offered resettlement by Uruguay earlier this year sent this letter to top Obama administration officials on June 26. Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel has not acted on the deal.

title: Seeking Divine Intervention, or at Least Some Lucky Shorts
description: SALVADOR, Brazil  There is a saying in this coastal city of mixed religious heritages and creeds that goes more or less like this: If superstition decided soccer matches, all matches would end in a tie.

title: Inventive Cocktails That Pack a Low-Proof Punch
description: For all the many virtues of a potent Manhattan, Martini or Sazerac, the all-spirit cocktail doesnt lend itself well to, say, postwork happy hours or, for that matter, pleasant mornings-after. Happily for the congenitally thirsty, a new wave of complex and inventive low-proof cocktails is popping up, and theyre a far cry from that less-potent fallback drink, the white-wine spritzer. Coming on the heels of the relentless rise of the Aperol Spritz,these new, lighter drinks appeal as much to those with an aversion to strong liquors as they do to the heartiest of drinkers after one dirty martini too many. And as Dinah Sanders, author of The Art of the Shim: Low-Alcohol Cocktails to Keep you Level, says, The more subtle ingredients these drinks often feature dont overwhelm the palate, so they are generally more food-friendly. Thanks to exotic sakes, a variety of vermouths, a growing range of bitters, flavorful teas, infused syrups, fresh herbs and wines of all colors and ranges of effervescence, the skys the limit in creating easier-to-drink concoctions, as evidenced in the following five recipes.

title: Head of Dollar General to Retire
description: Richard W. Dreiling, the chairman and chief executive of the discount retailer Dollar General, said on Friday that he was retiring. The move is effective May 30, 2015, or until the company names a successor.

title: Eastern Garter Snake: The Well-Tempered Slitherer
description: It is not entirely surprising that children who find an eastern garter snake (Thamnophis sirtalis) excitedly tell their friends they found a garden snake. This innocuous New York City resident is as happy slithering through neighborhood parks or backyards as through wilder terrain.

title: Voter-Fraud Claims and Activists Suicide Add to Turmoil in Mississippi
description: WASHINGTON  The long and bitter Republican primary fight between Senator Thad Cochran and his Tea Party challenger descended into accusations of voter fraud on Friday, with the defeated candidate, State Senator Chris McDaniel, making clear he would not accept the results anytime soon.

title: What to Do When Twitter Locks You Out
description: Opening a Locked Twitter Account

title: Technology as a Path to Product Transparency
description: After I posted yesterday on Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsacks push for using scannable codes to provide consumers with information on food ingredients from genetically modified crops, Ben Grossman-Cohen of the anti-poverty group Oxfam International sent a reaction that merits publication as a Your Dot contribution.

title: An International Art Festival in the Azores
description: Sao Miguel, one of the nine Azorean islands that huddle in the Atlantic, has long attracted visitors with its pastoral setting dotted with cows, waterfalls and volcanoes. But Ponta Delgada, the capital, is transforming into a center for the avant-garde with Walk & Talk, an annual international public art festival.

title: TUI of Germany Reaches Agreement to Acquire British TUI Travel
description: LONDON  The German hotel and cruise ship operator TUI said on Friday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the British travel and leisure company TUI Travel, in which it is already a majority shareholder.

title: Taking a Spin: An Odd Turn for Republicans
description: This weeks spin of Leos Senate wheels, our weekly demonstration of the uncertainty remaining before the election, offers head-scratching results.

title: Lawmaker in Manhattan Pleads Guilty to 2 Felonies
description: A New York assemblywoman in her first term became the latest state lawmaker to be forced out of office as she pleaded guilty on Friday to two felonies in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Barclays Investors Express Investment Bank Fears
description: The markets reaction to allegations that Barclays duped clients in its dark pool reflects more general fears of investment banking. Shares in the bank dropped as much as 9 percent on Thursday after the New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, accused Barclays of misleading investors by playing down the number of predatory high-frequency traders on its private trading platform for equities. Barclays says it takes the allegations very seriously.

title: Our Economic Growth Is a Mystery. Obamacare Is the Reason.
description: Imagine you decide to replace the engine of a car. You have two goals: To make the car go faster, you put in a more powerful engine, say eight cylinders rather than six. But you also want to make it more fuel efficient, so you add some sophisticated new technologies to cut back on its gas guzzling.

title: San Francisco Noir
description: San Francisco is well known for its transformations, the most recent one fueled by tech money that has seemingly scrubbed much of the city clean. Evidence of it tends to be easy to mock: the $4 artisanal toast, the shuttle buses carrying workers from the city interior to Silicon Valley, the preponderance of reclaimed wood. But for almost a century, the city has been indelibly linked with an enigmatic genre that might be considered an antidote to all of that: noir.

title: New Father? New C.E.O.? Theres a Boot Camp for You
description: IN the face of the yelling, B. J. Perlmutt hesitated, then took the plunge. After all, this was boot camp, and wasnt the point to break you down and make you a man? He was sweating a little but competently finished the task.

title: Five Stories of Luxury
description: A classic brick Greek Revival townhouse at 10 West 10th Street, one of the more idyllic of the tree-lined residential blocks in Greenwich Village, is poised to enter the market at $24.75 million.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week: Comme des Garons Spring/Summer 2015
description: Scenes from the mens fashion week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

title: Obama Chides G.O.P. for Blocking Economic Measures
description: MINNEAPOLIS  President Obama rebuked congressional Republicans on Friday for opposing his economic initiatives, saying they should be held accountable for not doing enough for the middle class.

title: Retirement Plans Thrown Into Disarray by a Divorce
description: AFTER enduring a divorce four years ago, Mike Millers vision for a golden retirement got an unexpected makeover. Mr. Miller had been married for more than 30 years, and now he was single. His longtime dream of a shared retirement was shattered. He was also facing another unwelcome outcome: living in a smaller home and taking fewer vacations.

title: Transition Ahead for The View, as Two Hosts Depart
description: The latest cast changes at ABCs daily talk show The View may signal a more sweeping transition, as two hosts will depart by the end of the summer, and the new participants may include the shows first permanent male host.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: Alice in Wonderland syndrome, a type of hospital unknown to most of the world and a study on the cool kids. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Shia LaBeouf Arraigned on Disorderly Conduct Charge
description: The actor Shia LaBeouf was arraigned on Friday morning on charges of disorderly conduct and criminal trespass after an incident the previous evening at Studio 54, where he was removed after disrupting a performance of the musical Cabaret.

title: Amid the Rap Music, Echoes of an Orchestra Playing in a Dark Past
description: BERLIN  AT various points during shows, the German rapper Kutlu Yurtseven gestures to a bandmate sitting demurely off to the side. Thats the cue for 89-year-old Esther Bejarano, a diminutive woman with a snow-white pixie cut, to jump in with a song. When will the heavens open up, again, for me? is one favorite, the refrain of a local carnival tune. When will they open up?

title: John Boehner Deflects Attention by Suing the President
description: President Obama was generous on Thursday in referring to Speaker John Boehners proposed lawsuit against him as a stunt, a word generally used to mean a playful attempt to get attention. In fact, the suit is a mean-spirited attempt to deflect attention  specifically from the Houses refusal to engage in the act of governing.

title: Big Ticket | A Grand Gothic Duplex for $16.5 Million
description: A 12-room duplex on upper Fifth Avenue, with a Gothic decorating theme but no Central Park views from its grand primary rooms, sold for $16.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The monthly maintenance is $11,048.

title: AT&T Names Silver Lake Co-Founder to Its Board
description: To fill an empty seat on its board, AT&T has turned to one of the countrys top investors in technology.

title: Venus Williams Flashes Old Form at Wimbledon, but It Is Fleeting
description: WIMBLEDON, England  It has been six years since Venus Williams last won a Grand Slam singles championship, a title that came here at Wimbledon.

title: Broth Spoils the Cooks
description: Its got hot caldrons, sour plum juice and sliced lotus roots and it seats up to 200 people. Little Sheep Mongolian Hot Pot, which opened in Edison last month, might be a novelty in New Jersey, but some consider it the Applebees of China.

title: Comme des Garons: Spring 2015 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Depression Economics and Climate Policy
description: Theres been a bit of back and forth over reform conservatism  which is, depending on your point of view, either an important new trend or an attempt by reasonably sane conservatives to pretend that they arent part of an essentially insane movement. And climate change, where the current GOP orthodoxy essentially revolves around a crazy conspiracy theory, is the flash point.

title: A Beverage for Brazil and the World Cup
Kanye: the Professor, Pradas Revolutionary Runway and Fendis Latest Leather Accessory
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: The Book Reviews Killer Cover
description: There was no question that this weeks cover was going to be Harlan Coben on The Silkworm by Robert Galbraith (a.k.a. J.K. Rowling). This is Cobens first review for us, and weve had our eye on him as a reviewer for years. And of course, like most media outlets, we missed the first Robert Galbraith novel, before J.K. Rowling was unmasked as the true author. We werent going to lose that opportunity again.When the review came in, it more than lived up to our expectations. Here was one of the masters of literary genre fiction writing on someone who is relatively new to the genre, though of course a gigantic success elsewhere in the book world. It was a strong and logical, yet also slightly unexpected match between book and reviewer.

title: Two Stars With Intertwining Peaks
description: Robert Fairchild and Tiler Peck, two principal dancers with the New York City Ballet, were married at the Chapel of the Good Shepherd in Chelsea on June 22.

title: Soros Dabbles in Shareholder Activism
description: Is George Soros turning activist? His $29 billion hedge fund has famously confronted governments. But facing off with a $1 billion United States oil and gas company is novel. The move gives underperforming corporate bosses another scourge to fear.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: New Dylan Thomas Drinking Song Discovered
description: Just in time to comfort British World Cup fans still crying into their beer, a new drinking song by Dylan Thomas is to be published.

title: Afghan Candidate and Thousands of Supporters Continue Protests
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Thousands of supporters of the presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah poured into the streets of Kabul on Friday, blocking roads and clogging squares as they demanded that allegations of election fraud be addressed before ending the political crisis that has stratified Afghanistan for the last two weeks.

title: More on How We Chose the Hardest Places to Live
description: Our interactive map yesterday on the hardest places to live in the United States provoked, not surprisingly, some lively discussion in the comments section. Several of those comments raised thoughts that were worth addressing.

title: Vatican Defrocks Ambassador in Abuse Inquiry
description: The Vatican has defrocked its former ambassador to the Dominican Republic, an archbishop from Poland who was accused of sexually abusing boys while he served as the popes representative in the Caribbean nation.

title: Eric Clapton Says He May Stop Touring
description: First Philip Roth quits writing books and giving readings. Now Eric Clapton quits touring?

title: The Trauma of Parenthood
description: EVERYONE knows that being the parent of an infant is hard. Theres the sleeplessness, the screaming fits to tend to, the loss of autonomy, the social isolation and the sheer monotony of it.

title: Death by Netflix?
description: Binge-watching has now joined a pantheon already occupied by fast food, alcohol, and sitting on couches: It is extremely popular, and in large amounts, it appears to be deadly.

title: A Crush of Summer Flavors
description: There are many kinds of frozen concoctions to help you navigate the summer heat.

title: The Hardest Place to Live in America
description: What does concentrated rural misery look like? Like eastern Kentucky.

title: Givenchy: Spring 2015 Menswear
description: Paris

title: And Sometimes They Dance
description: This is a boy-meets-girl-at-a-barre love story.

title: Persecution Captured on Film
description: As readers of the blog may know, Im the journalism student from the University of Notre Dame that accompanied Nicholas Kristof on his annual win-a-trip journey in Burma. While reporting on the ground, I captured a number of my experiences and interviews with members of the Rohingya Muslim minority on film. As always, reader comments and questions are welcome!

title: Ford Introduces Side-Curtain Air Bags for 15-Passenger Vans
description: Ford announced Wednesday that it had developed its largest air bag for the 15-passenger Transit van.

title: Pro-Abdullah Rallies Held in Kabul
description: Thousands of protesters in Kabul showed support for presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullahs allegations that mass fraud had been committed in Afghanistans presidential runoff.

title: A Casual Stage Where Steak Is the Star
description: Union Republic houses an expertly outfitted butcher shop, so it is not surprising that its porterhouse and rib-eye steaks, marbled but not gristly and sauted so quickly that the caramelized exteriors spurt when punctured, are first-rate. Not to be outdone, its mushroom-studded risotto, taco with cubes of silky beef cheeks and even its vegan bowl of cauliflower, leeks and ramen noodles are also exemplary. They are reason enough to head to this latest outpost of innovative cooking in downtown Jersey City.

title: Investors Who Bought Foreclosed Homes in Bulk Look to Sell
description: A year ago, buying foreclosed homes to rent out was the sure-thing trade for investment firms backed by money from private equity companies, hedge funds and pension systems. But with the supply of cheap foreclosed homes dwindling, some early investors are looking to cash out a bit by flipping homes to competitors.

title: Weekend Reading: Advancing on Bank Penalties
description: Following DealBooks report that BNP Paribas is expected to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay an $8.9 billion fine, Wall Streets attention will soon turn to two civil investigations into the mortgage crisis.

title: Learning Lear': Playing to the Camera
description: John Lithgow, a Tony-winning actor and writer, will be regularly blogging on ArtsBeat as he rehearses King Lear for Shakespeare in the Park.

title: Coach Boldly Moves U.S. Forward
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  In late March, just before Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States national mens soccer team, went into the meeting in which he demoted Martin Vasquez, his longtime assistant, he asked a staff member with U.S. Soccer to knock on the door and interrupt after about five minutes.

title: The U.S.-Germany Match Through a Social Media Lens
description: The United States-Germany soccer match on Thursday was a roller coaster of emotions. And an analysis of the social media communications before, during and after the match shows the minute-by-minute shifts in sentiment and in subjects discussed, as the American team lost to Germany but moved on in the World Cup competition.

title: How Records in Group Play Predict World Cup Success
description: Teams performance in the World Cups group stage often says a lot about how theyll fare in the knockout rounds. Since 1986, when a version of the current format began, no team has won the championship without winning at least two of three group matches. And six of the seven champions in that time did not lose any group-stage matches  going either 3-0-0 or finishing with two wins and a draw in the group stage.

title: Hip-Hop From a Holocaust Survivor
description: Esther Bejarano, a survivor of the Auschwitz concentration camp, may be the last thing youd expect in a hip-hop singer. She uses her music to spread a message against fascism.

title: AT&T Sells Its Stake in Mexican Telecom Amrica Mvil to Carlos Slim
description: Updated, 7:46 p.m. | AT&T said on Friday that it was selling its $5.6 billion stake in Amrica Mvil, the Mexican telecommunications company, back to its majority shareholder, the billionaire Carlos Slim Hel. The sale comes as AT&T seeks to acquire the satellite television operator DirecTV in a $48.5 billion deal.

title: Berluti: Spring 2015 Menswear
description: PARIS

title: Michael Arrington Drops Suit After Rape Accuser Recants
description: Last spring, Jennifer Allen began sharing a harrowing tale of abuse she said she had received at the hands of a former boyfriend  Michael Arrington, the tech investor and blogger.

title: Follow That Cab! Vintage Checkers Flock to Brooklyn
description: For a few hours, Box Street, a semi-industrial thoroughfare in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, seemed a whole lot like Kzoo.

title: Revisiting a Checkered Past
description: The Checker cab, a New York City icon, was back on the streets of Brooklyn for a gathering of the Checker Car Club of America.

title: Confinement as a Kind of Freedom
description: The first voice you hear in Me and You, Bernardo Bertoluccis first film in nearly a decade, is that of an unseen psychiatrist asking his patient, Allora? (So?) Then the point of view shifts and you see the doctor sitting in a wheelchair, rolling himself closer to his desk and his patient, a troubled 14-year-old boy who looks at the floor and answers, Nothing.

title: A Ride Across America | In Kansas, A Man Cave Becomes a Thriving Family Farm
description: Over the course of eight weeks, Ben Towill, the co-owner of the Fat Radish, and the photographer Patrick Dougherty are biking 4,500 miles across the U.S. to talk to strangers about food. Each week, theyll file a dispatch for T about their discoveries.

title: Making Everything Shipshape
description: TACOMA, Wash.  As construction crews 5,000 miles away are working to widen the Panama Canal to allow much larger ships to sail straight to the East Coast, this historic port city and others along the West Coast are doing everything they can to avoid becoming superfluous.

title: With Alstom Deal, G.E. Gains Bigger Foothold as Utility Supplier
description: BELFORT, France  The Alstom and General Electric turbine factories in this French city near the Swiss and German borders sit just a stones throw apart. They are so close, in fact, that their employees share a cafeteria, and two-company families are not uncommon.

title: Fighting for Movies With Pen and Thumb
description: Life Itself, the new documentary about Roger Ebert, examines many facets of the nations most famous film critic: his newsman background, his exhaustively chronicled battle with cancer that ended in his death last year, his drinking, his wit, his love for his wife, Chaz.

title: This Time, the Cake Is Fully Baked
description: When Hyundai dipped a toe in the luxury-car waters in 2009, it followed an underdog formula set by Toyotas Lexus division two decades earlier: Mimic the established brands design, undercut them on price and overdeliver on features.

title: Is This Cold War II?
description: On Wednesday June 25, the New York Times and Chatham House convened a panel of former New York Times op-ed contributors in London to debate the future of the Wests relations with Russia in the wake of the Ukraine crisis. The panel included John Mearsheimer, a professor of political science at the University of Chicago and the author of The Tragedy of Great Power Politics; Chrystia Freeland, a former Financial Times editor and now a member of the Canadian Parliament; Michael McFaul, the former American ambassador to Russia and now a professor at Stanford University; and Dmitri Trenin, the director of the Carnegie Moscow Center. Roger Cohen, a columnist for The New York Times, moderated. Panelists debated whether the recent crisis was caused by Vladimir Putins zero-sum view of geopolitics, whether the Ukrainian people will have a say in the eventual outcome and whether Russia is really a rival to the United States. An edited transcript follows.

title: 2015 Hyundai Genesis: Upgrading the Upgrade
description: An upward striver fulfills its potential with a splash of style and a new dash of spice.

title: Fewer Breaks, but Belinda Bencic Makes the Most of Them
description: WIMBLEDON, England  All points in tennis are not worth the same. Some are critical to the final outcome. Others are simply building blocks to reach it.

title: Digital Success Comes to Radio Broadcaster
description: For years, radio stations have watched as online upstarts like Pandora and Spotify attracted a new generation of listeners. Now, one conventional broadcast network, Clear Channel Media and Entertainment, seems to be gaining a significant audience with its own streaming app.

title: A Designer Transformed
description: The Transformers film franchise has locked the Chevrolet Camaro deep in the subconscious of millions of children who know it as Bumblebee, a robot that disguises itself as a sporty coupe.

title: Transformers and the Summer Blockbuster
description: The numbers behind Transformers: Age of Extinction- expected to gross one billion dollars - and other summer blockbusters this year.

title: Detroits Troubles: A Mosaic Says What Words Cant
description: Today, an ambitious interactive graphic accompanied a front-page article by Monica Davey about the high rate of home foreclosures in Detroit. The graphic was presented as a mosaic of the more than 43,000 properties that were subject to foreclosure this year. Haeyoun Park, a graphics editor for the national desk, and Matthew Bloch, a graphics and multimedia editor, worked on the project and shared some details about how it came to be.

title: Love With the Proper Dose of Disdain
description: Vicious is not the most informative title. It sounds like a nasty little thriller on FX or Cinemax. As it turns out, its a British sitcom on PBS, but its nasty, all right. Where else on television are you going to see two superb classically trained actors calling each other a rotting corpse or a big bitch?

title: Your Evening Briefing
Hot Streets for Chilly Lawyers
description: Reckless, a summer crime-lawyer-melodrama mishmash that begins on Sunday on CBS, is determined to be vacuous, even though, every so often, it hints that it could be more substantive if it wanted to be. That makes it maddening; youd like to commit to it, but you know that more clichs and indifferent acting are right around the corner.

title: Week in Pictures for June 27
description: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region includes a look at a Congressional primary race and a Central Park luncheon.

title: 3 Freed in Central Park Jogger Case Thank Supporters
description: Three of the five men whose convictions were overturned in the 1989 beating and rape of a female jogger in Central Park appeared in front of City Hall on Friday, thanking their supporters and praising Mayor Bill de Blasio for agreeing to settle their longstanding lawsuit against the city.

title: Plis With an Elephant, And Other Tales for Men
description: It cant be easy for a company called 10 Hairy Legs to live up to the playful audacity of its name. Randy James formed his New Jersey repertory troupe in 2012, intending to explore a range of male dancing. (Hence the hair.) That name turned out to be the most offbeat thing about the group, which performed five dances on Thursday, at the start of its run at New York Live Arts.

title: Pictures of the Day: Saudi Arabia and Elsewhere
description: Saudi Arabia and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Pictures of the Day: Saudi Arabia and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Saudi Arabia, Sudan, India and China.

title: Before Night Falls
description: Death typically appears in photographs as an intruder: an unbidden force that sweeps down on a battlefield or leaves survivors pained and bereft. We see the images and know that just hours or moments earlier, the subjects lives were intact, the world complete and in order. In Arthur Nazaryans photographs of a hospice nurse and her patients, death plays a different role, shaping the scene by its absence, not its presence. It is the reason the characters are assembled, the order toward which the chaos of life is resolving itself; not just their lives, but ours as well.

title: Building a Full Meal, Bite by Bite by Bite
description: They say there is nothing new under the sun, but the Bartaco concept may be an exception. Bartaco in Westport, an indoor-outdoor locale, offers a limited menu, more snacklike than full service, in a noisy, lively atmosphere, with seating for 110 inside, and for 25 more outside, facing the Saugatuck River.

title: Tiger Pulls Man From Boat in India
description: NEW DELHI  A man poaching crabs in an eastern Indian tiger reserve was killed by a tiger that leapt into the mans boat and dragged him into a mangrove swamp in front of his son and daughter.

title: Lana Del Rey, Downcast Superstar
description: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss Lana Del Rey and her new record, Ultraviolence.

title: Under Cover: The Wonder of an Egg
description: When Jake Silverstein, the magazines editor, read the final paragraphs of Kim Tingleys cover story about three-parent I.V.F., in which she describes a researcher removing nuclear DNA from a human egg, he was struck by an idea for the cover.

title: Popcast: Lana Del Rey, Downcast Superstar
description: The singer Lana Del Rey of Los Angeles, nee Lizzie Grant of Lake Placid, N.Y., elicited some opprobrium in 2011 and 2012, through songs and videos and a first album (Born to Die) and a Saturday Night Live performance that all seemed, to some, thin or calculated or grandiose or overposed.

title: Bringing the British Countryside to Life
description: As Elisabeth Fairman, of the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven, puts it, the exhibition Of Green Leaf, Bird and Flower: Artists Books and the Natural World is something of a walk through the countryside.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week Spring 2015 Accessories
description: Highlights from the mens collections in Paris.

title: Time Doesnt Dim Its Sparkle
description: Time is easily quantifiable yet unknowable, at least as it affects wine. We know wine ages in the bottle, but how will it evolve, and why? We can estimate based on experience, but we are never really sure.

title: Nepals Premier Is Being Treated for Lung Cancer
description: NEW DELHI  Prime Minister Sushil Koirala of Nepal is undergoing radiation therapy in New York to treat a cancerous tumor found on his lung, and his indefinite absence could further paralyze Nepalese politics.

title: Christian Sudanese Woman and Her Family in Protection of U.S. Embassy
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  A Christian Sudanese woman who was detained at the airport in Khartoum with her family by Sudanese authorities after an appeals court overturned her conviction and death sentence for abandoning Islam and ordered her set free is now in the protection of the United States Embassy here, her lawyer said on Friday.

title: A Bridge Deal From Judy Kay-Wolff
description: A few women have been married to more than one member of the bridge Hall of Fame. Judy Kay-Wolff, for example, who celebrated her 80th birthday this month.

title: The Bride Didnt Always Wear White
description: LONDON  Queen Victoria wasnt much of what you would call a fashion plate, especially in her later years. As a widow, she would rarely venture out into public, and when she did, she would be swathed in funereal black, perpetually in mourning for her husband.

title: 25th Reunion Takes a Turn for the Explosive
description: At most 25th high school reunions, the drama does not rise above the discovery that the prom queen got fat, or the mousy kid who disappeared into the scenery founded an Internet company valued at a few billion dollars. Theres much more in store for the friends reassembling to recall semi-halcyon days in The Muscles in Our Toes, a fairly preposterous play by Stephen Belber (Tape, Match) making its New York premiere in a Labyrinth Theater Company production directed by Anne Kauffman.

title: The United States of Los Tigres
description: MINNEAPOLIS  About four hours before a Friday night show late last month, the five members of Los Tigres del Norte, the premier band in the accordion-driven musical genre known as norteo, were quietly eating dinner at the restaurant of their hotel here. None of the other diners seemed to have any notion of who they were, and neither did the staff  until a Spanish-speaking waiter spotted them and shyly approached their table.

title: Riot Music and Puppy-Love Songs
description: Rae Sremmurd

title: What Were Reading
description: Recommended reads from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading is an exclusive benefit for home delivery and digital subscribers that is sent twice a week as an email. Sign up

title: If the State Fair Were X-Rated (or at Least a Strong R)
description: Should this review begin with a warning that it deals with the conventionally unmentionable? Or that it refers to images here unprintable?

title: How the National Anthem Has Unfurled
description: When the baritone Thomas Hampson sings The Star-Spangled Banner at the Library of Congress in Washington on Thursday, it wont sound quite like the familiar tune belted out at ball games and presidential inaugurations.

title: Prosecutors Ask at Least 8 Years for Martoma in Insider Trading Case
description: Federal prosecutors are recommending that Mathew Martoma, a former trader who worked for the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen, be sentenced next month to at least eight years in prison for insider trading, if not significantly more.

title: Irelands First Billionaire Ordered to Sell Assets to Repay Loans
description: DUBLIN  Anthony OReilly, Irelands first billionaire and the former chief executive and chairman of the H.J. Heinz Company, has been declared insolvent, and on Friday he was ordered to sell his assets immediately to repay loans to one bank exceeding $30 million.

title: Prophet Goes to Church
description: In the stage version of  ... Moses(es), performed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last December, the choreographer Reggie Wilson began by introducing himself to the assembled crowd. His dancers followed suit, adding how long theyd spent as members of his Fist & Heel Performance Group. Mr. Wilson then stuffed armloads of silver tinsel into a suitcase. He packs a lot into his dances.

title: Disparate but Connected
description: The photographer Wolfgang Tillmans has long been occupied with what he has called the objectness of a photograph, its role as a thing in the world and not just as a conduit of information, and this has often led to explorations of the relationship between painting and photography in the digital age. A tightly focused exhibition opening Tuesday at the Philadelphia Museum of Art takes Mr. Tillmanss fascinations and runs with them.

title: Marathon Tribute to Philip Guston
description: Art can start relationships, and end them. The composer Morton Feldman and the painter Philip Guston had been close for years when Feldman attended an opening of Gustons in 1970. The work on display was figurative, an abrupt turn from the abstraction Guston had been known for. Feldman was stunned silent. Telling the story much later, he said that the episode ended their decades-long friendship. The two men never saw each other again.

title: Toasting 30 Years of Raw Exuberance
description: The name Urban Bush Women suggests a fierce and perhaps frightening tribe  something to avoid, if it didnt also sound like something you really wanted to join.

title: At 50, a Debut Keeps 4 Guys Young
description: Those pivotal appearances on The Ed Sullivan Show werent the only Beatles milestones 50 years ago. This year is also the 50th anniversary of the release of A Hard Days Night, the first of the bands five feature films and, in many minds, the best.

title: Same Beck, Different Mood
description: Im so tired of being alone, cries Beck at the top of Blue Moon, the lead single from his muted and deliberative current album, Morning Phase (Capitol). I-so-lation, he sings a couple of tracks later, in the existential refrain of Wave. The purity of the sentiment, and the completeness of his commitment, could easily give you an impression about his state of mind: desolate, draggy, half-numb, forlorn. The last time Beck made an album that felt like this Sea Change, a dozen years ago that impression might have been partly true.

title: Inequality Is Not Inevitable
description: AN insidious trend has developed over this past third of a century. A country that experienced shared growth after World War II began to tear apart, so much so that when the Great Recession hit in late 2007, one could no longer ignore the fissures that had come to define the American economic landscape. How did this shining city on a hill become the advanced country with the greatest level of inequality?

title: Eking Out a Living to Chase a Dream
description: The boldface names in The Mysteries belong to the characters: God, Jesus, Lucifer, the rest of the biblical crowd. The actors playing them off Off Broadway, at the Flea Theater in TriBeCa, are not famous  but theyre young, hopeful and ravenous enough about performing to do it free.

title: Damned People Got No Reason to Live
description: When Randy Newman released Faust as a star-studded concept album in 1995, Rolling Stone magazine wrote that it breathes new life into a musical-theater tradition hijacked by the likes of Andrew Lloyd Webber. The very next year, this wry song cycle about a contemporary deal with the Devil hit the stage in a flashy production directed by Michael Greif. Yet after receiving mixed notices in Los Angeles and Chicago, Mr. Newmans Faust receded into the limbo of might-have-been theater successes that got derailed on the road to Broadway.

title: Following 9 Trips From I Do to I Did
description: Twenty years ago Doug Block began shooting wedding videos to support his true passion, documentary filmmaking. Sure, the money was good. But he soon discovered a far more intriguing aspect. I could stand just feet away, he says, as two ordinary people experience one of the most extraordinary days of their lives. But after the vows had been uttered and the videos sent on their way, he couldnt help but wonder what happened next.

title: Intensity, Instantly, and Hints of Coltrane
description: With improvised music, you get used to seeing a band warm up by degrees. It comes with the aesthetic form, and also with the business model, if its a band performing sporadic multiple-night stands. Jazz is full of groups reconvening, recohering, then pacing themselves across a few nights and days. The quintet led by the saxophonist Azar Lawrence, from Los Angeles, is of that form and that model. For the last three years or so, its been playing gigs in clubs  often on the East Coast, where all its other members are based  and then everyone scatters and does different things.

title: The Hoodie as a Tease, and Other Statements From a Sampler of Mixed Moves
description: BECKET, Mass.  Unreal Hip-Hop, a showcase organized by the Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival, seems designed to defy expectations. The performance on Thursday opened with a figure in a hoodie, hunched over and facing away in dim light. Thats an image closely associated, like hip-hop, with black males. This figure, though, turned out to be a white B-girl.

title: Hewitt Grinds Back From Two Sets Down, but His Upset Bid Fails
description: WIMBLEDON, England  It is often said that professional tennis does not have competitive contrast. Those objecting to that state of affairs should have appreciated Lleyton Hewitts attempt Friday afternoon to cut the goliath known as Jerzy Janowicz down to size, inch by tormented inch.

title: Speak Your Own Truth, on Your Own Terms
description: Billie Jean King loves to connect. The 70-year-old tennis legend  winner of 39 Grand Slam titles, the Presidential Medal of Freedom and, most famously, the Battle of the Sexes match against Bobby Riggs in 1973  peppers questions like forehand volleys. Within three minutes of walking into Boulud Sud, near Lincoln Center, Ms. King had learned that the restaurant managers mother rowed crew for Syracuse University; asked her interviewers partners name (and tossed it off casually through the afternoon); and compared notes on the French Open with the waiter.

title: At Festival, Footfalls of Farewell
description: BECKET, Mass.  The Doubtful Guest, the title character of a 1957 illustrated book by Edward Gorey, is a peculiar creature, with a flat head, a knitted scarf and wings that suggest a penguins flippers. It shows up at an Edwardian manor house and stays for 17 years (by the books end) with no indication that it might ever leave.

title: Bill Cunningham | Jeff Koons Big Bloom
description: The last big week of the social season held one final grand surprise: the Jeff Koons retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: Surgical Complications
description: Eight of 16 of the militarys largest hospitals had high rates of surgical complications, such as infections or improperly done procedures, according to a review from the American College of Surgeons.

title: American Realism by Way of Woodstock
description: Fortunes in the art world  and particularly those defined by the market  change quickly. Take Eugene Speicher (1883-1962), a painter whom Esquire magazine called Americas most important living painter in 1936, but whose name few people know today (and even fewer can pronounce: Spiker). Along His Own Lines: A Retrospective of New York Realist Eugene Speicher, organized by Valerie Ann Leeds at the Samuel Dorsky Museum of Artin New Paltz, N.Y., seeks to redress this, examining Mr. Speichers career in the context of American realism, but also as an artist who spent months each year in nearby Woodstock.

title: Scenes from San Francisco
description: In search for noir, with Dashiell Hammett as guide.

title: Bill Cunningham | Big Bloom
description: BIG BLOOM The last big week of the social season held one final grand surprise: the Jeff Koons retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art that occupies the entire museum, including the front moat. On the top floor is Mr. Koonss latest work, Play-Doh, a monumental pile of color. The owners of the work are Maria and Bill Bell. Many of the womens dresses at the opening Tuesday echoed the colors of the sculpture and recalled the colors of the Fauve painters of early-20th-century Paris and the smaller Split-Rocker, left. It contrasts with the colossal Split-Rocker, below, covered in over 50,000 dwarf marigolds, zinnias, petunias, wax begonias, impatiens and geraniums, installed above the statue of Prometheus in Rockefeller Center. The sculpture, which exploded to 37 feet tall, was unveiled at a luncheon.

title: Bulletins From the Gut, From a Quartet at Work in the Park
description: Musical patterns are neat, stable, definite, predictable. Feelings and relationships  well, they arent. But they can all be hypnotic, compelling, even obsessive. Warpaint, the four-woman Los Angeles band that headlined Celebrate Brooklyn! on Thursday night, places its songs at that complicated intersection: where a grid of repetition meets the amorphous crosscurrents of emotion and desire.

title: Evening Hours | Including the Stars
description: Music, art and dancing to start the summer.

title: Same-Sex Marriages, 10 Years Later
description: So, what happens to a marriage over the course of 10 years? Make that a gay marriage.

title: Exploring the Continuity of the Radical
description: Since April, the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum has been commemorating its 50th anniversary with a yearlong series of changing exhibitions. Its galleries are filled with artworks that honor its legacy while highlighting the impact of that legacy on artists practicing today.

title: Rulings on Abortion and Appointment
description: To the Editor:

title: Howard Baker, Who Put the Nation Ahead of Himself
Helping a Child With Homework: Two Views
description: To the Editor:

title: Wheelies: The Electrified Audi Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Something for Tout le Monde
description: Next month, Vox will celebrate its 10th anniversary. This charming restaurant and bar has been a beacon to those navigating the sharp curves of Route 116 in the woodsy isolation of North Salem.

title: Checkpoint Showdown
description: As the immigration debate focuses on border security, some say that American freedoms are being compromised by interior Border Patrol checkpoints, like the one north of Arivaca, Ariz.

title: Watching the Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Good Marital Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: All the Worlds His Stage
description: To the Editor:

title: Ergen Sidelined in Battle With Falcone Over LightSquared
description: The bitter battle between the billionaires Charles W. Ergen and Philip A. Falcone over LightSquared, the bankrupt wireless broadband company, appears to be nearing an end. The twist is that Mr. Ergen is no longer involved.

title: She Did It Her Way
description: Staten Island has been called the forgotten borough and was home to a nearly forgotten, boundary-pushing photographer named Alice Austen. At the ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, open since 1985 in the working-class neighborhood of Rosebank, some details of her life are still blurred.

title: Presbyterians Remove Guide After Criticism
